description: The pappardelle short rib was sooo good. And they were very helpful dealing with a minor food intolerance. Service was excellent all around. My entire party of 7 had a great time.
author: Scott H.

description: The food was fantastic, everything was perfectly prepared. he portions are a little small, but that leaves room for an appetizer or dessert. The staff was very nice.
author: Eva S.

description:
A fine experience at yet another excellent San Francisco restaurant. Service began with breadsticks and a small ramekin filled with a slightly spicy pesto for dipping. We then ordered a carafe of a house-recommended medium-bodied red wine from Umbria. Unfortunately, we don't recall the varietal or the name, as we arrived having already quaffed a few and were in the "wine-yes" phase, but it was tasty. 

For dinner we started with Mozzarella di Bufala - small half-rounds of characteristically mild, locally-produced cheese served with strawberries. Our main courses were slices of duck breast tender enough to cut with a butter knife and a unique dish called langaroli - thick pasta noodles folded and stuffed with braised short ribs and black truffle butter. It was all delicious. 

We saved room for dessert, allegedly. We ordered burnt caramel gelato and something called Duo Di Bonet - white and milk chocolate with meringue and roasted cherries. No complaints. 

We'd like to make brief shout-out to the service staff. We were initially seated next to a very loud and sloppy four-top; what seemed like married men and women but not to each other. Interesting. But the noise level was the problem. So the floor manager didn't hesitate in moving us to a quieter section upstairs, and we enjoyed being served by a skilled young man named Ben. 

Perbacco is highly recommended. We'll be back.
author: Steve L.

description: Had an exceptionally good risotto dish here.  Nice brussel sprouts too.  Very attentive service.
author: Joseph F.

description: Came here for lunch and James took great care of us.  We had the pappardelle and langaroli and both were excellent pasta dishes.  Nice ambiance and convenient location close to Market Street/Embarcadero.
author: Clyde V.

description: Ambiance and service was great but the food was just ok. Had the burrata, tartare, and a couple of pastas between the group and they were over salted and didn't really stand out. Not bad, but not great either.
author: Laura D.

description: Had a decent experience here last night. Ordered apps and wine. Felt a little pressure to order entrees, but we stuck to our guns. We ordered veal and yellowfin tuna tartare. The veal was delicious, but the tuna was very average. We also had the sunchokes, pappardelle and octopus. The sunchokes were pretty delicious, the pappardelle wasn't (though it SOUNDED great) and the octopus was pretty good, not amazeballs. The wine I chose was okay, and at least the most expensive red was only $10 a glass. Service was decent, but a special thank you to the server, Jamie, who found my friend's Burberry scarf and had it sent to our hotel (our hotel made the reservation for us, it took me a while to figure out how they knew where we were staying). Overall, pretty good. Maybe we should've tried an entree...?
author: Gina M.

description: I had the Plin Al Funghi and it was absolutely delicious - some of the best Italian food I've had. The appetizers were decent and the bread with the pesto dipping sauce was excellent. Highly recommend, even for vegetarians.
author: Sampath D.

description:
Excellent Italian food, very clean, light and fresh. 
The staff are superb! perfectly friendly and service oriented. 
I highly recommend the grilled squid and the burrata of all the dishes I tried!
author: Miki S.

description: Not the best Italian place, but not the worst either. Too over priced for the food. I would rather try a different fine dine Italian restaurant. The food didn't stand out for us.
author: Himika R.

description:
Great food! great ambiance! What else does one need for a perfect dinner? Our waiter was very attentive and even suggested we order less than what we had in mind reminding us that the portion sizes are pretty generous, which is true. 

We tried their mushroom risotto, and a couple of pastas. Even though we felt stuffed half-way through our meal, we kept going and eventually emptied our plates because the flavors were right on.
author: Sharanya A.

description:
Another dinner with the fellas for a birthday celebration.  I appreciate them allowing us to have a reservation so late for a group of 8, thank you very much. Ambience is pretty nice. Now for the food.  

Apps: 
Frito Mistro- very good. 
Brussels Spriuts-ok, tender but needed more flavor (onions or bacon)
Carne-very good 

Entries
Paradelle- the flavor was great but not enough sauce or shredded shirt ribs. 
Short Ribs- very good flavor and tender

The waiter Brian wasn't that comforting, outgoing, chatty.  The entries are a little small as well. I don't remember the bartender name but he was a little snobbish too.  Overall, it was good.
author: Will E.

description:
My friend had taken me here for a birthday dinner once and so I decided to go again and it was just as good as last time! This was a pretty classy place and I made the mistake of wearing a tshirt and shorts last time because I had no idea how nice this place would be.. I didn't make the the mistake this time! I got the Piastra Roasted Octopus as an appetizer and that's probably the best tasting octopus I've ever had. Usually the octopus I eat are very tough and chewy. This one was seriously so soft and tender I felt like I was eating a cloud! I wish the portions were a little bigger because that octopus was sooo good. 

The main dishes included the Gnocchi and the Duck Ravioli. It was nice to have a variety of dishes because they each had such different flavors! The gnocchi had that classic pasta feel to it and then the ravioli had a very rich twist to it since it had duck filling instead of like cheese or beef that I'm usually used to. Seriously, why does duck make everything taste so much better?? I imagine it would've tasted beautifully if I had ordered some red wine as well so I might consider it next time! The portions are actually pretty big unlike other pasta places. Like, there were so many pieces of ravioli and gnocchi I felt it was never going to end haha. Also, the bread is really good (it comes with the meal so eat to your heart's content but don't fill up on it too fast!). A very nice classy place and I definitely would to explore the menu a little more next time! But I'm for sure getting the octopus again... No doubt about that :)
author: Patrick C.

description: The food was great but the waiter didn't like her job. She made the whole experience less than great. She was imposing on us on what to order and trying to force us to change our order. Her reasoning was she didn't want to take the food back if we didn't like what we were ordering. Wow! This place needs to fix service quickly.
author: Deepak G.

description:
HAD TO MOVE MY REVIEW OVER FROM BARBACCO HEHE


I got the Lango----something! The short rib pasta and it was AMAZING. They were little pillows of happiness exploding with savory and just the right amount of saltiness. I loved the sauce and asked for bread just to soak it all up.

Portion size - GET THE LARGE. Unless you are NOT hungry, just get the large. The waiter kept doubting me saying I wouldn't finish it and I am SOOO GLAD I didn't listen to her! She kept telling my date that he would have to help me. 

Beef tartare - Also very noms! I always like to try beef tartare everywhere I go and it did NOT disappoint here!!

Service - Except for the part where the waitress kept doubting that I could finish my food, everything was great. I will be back fo SHO.
author: Teresa T.

description: First dinner in SF and was not disappointed. Amazing flavours, perfectly cooked pasta and wonderful staff. I will be back for more soon!
author: Monica D.

description: Great meal from beginning to the end.   The crudo was amazing.  We also tried the risotto and the duck which were both excellent.   Looking forward to our next visit.
author: Seth T.

description:
Great service and that is by far one of the most important things in having a night out dinner. 

Food wise, tried much better for the price with much more satisfaction. 
Duo of braised beef cheek tasted like over steamed beef which could have much more to it. No no. 
Pesce Crudo was delicious though.  

Will try some other place next time though.
author: Slava C.

description:
Great Italian spot in downtown SF! Came here with my girlfriends on a Tuesday and would definitely recommend getting a reservations. It will get packed! They also offer complimentary bread sticks. 

For appetizers we ordered Burrta Cheese with green peppercorn marinated strawberries / almonds / basil / old balsamico. SOO GOOD! 

As for entrees, you should order pasta and it comes in two portion options. 
- Stracci: rye pasta "rags" / rossotti ranch veal sugo / roasted mushrooms
- Coujette: occitaine chive potato gnocchi / mt. shasta porcini mushroom ragu / chives
- Trofie: hand rolled pasta / haricots verts / new potatoes / basil and pine nut pesto / pecorino cheese
author: Jenn L.

description:
Great food, good service, always crowded 
For sure I will come back 
Try the sole and tonato vitelo
author: Enrique L.

description: Maybe we just caught them on a bad night but both entree' we ordered were really bad, so bad we didn't even eat them. Pork chop was 75% fat, cold and tasteless. Ravioli dish was bland at best and only partially cooked. Hamachi starter was good but that's about the only positive. Unfortunate result for an expensive dinner.
author: So H.

description: Stylish? The food was alright but this is such a tight place that the elbows of your neighbors are right in your dinner plate. Style-wise, this is a tad above McDonald's.
author: Baer B.

description:
Came here for lunch with a few co-workers and first impression was that it was VERY loud. It didn't bother me, but for those who want to have a business lunch to discuss business things, not sure if this would be a good lunch spot.

Service was great! From the hostess to the waitresses/waiters, and bartenders. They all greeted us and said goodbye when we left.

Love the open kitchen layout! It's pretty cool to see the line and watch the talented chefs in action. Wish we were seated at the tables right by the kitchen. 

I had a pino grigio, not bad. We ordered an appetizer that had fried olives, fried shrimp, fried onions, not sure what it was called. The shrimp was on the small side and the sauce that it came with was bland...could've kicked it up a notch just by adding more acid. The sauce basically tasted like mayo.

For my main, I ordered the fishermans stew. it had two toasted pieces of bread with the what looked like plain mayo sauce, shrimp, mussels, clams, etc. Boy did they really butcher the seafood. I'm not sure if I was because it was busy, but the seafood was overly boiled and became extremely rubbery. I'd give them another chance but it just sucks that they did such injustice to the seafood!
author: Jerrica N.

description:
My boyfriend made a reservation here for my 22nd birthday, overall experience here was lovely. Ambience was definitely nice although oddly incredibly noisy, not sure if due to construction of the place or if ambient music resulted in patrons speaking even louder to hear each other. We were seated in a nice corner area and the server was still very attentive and patient despite our indecision. 

The foie gras terrine was definitely the highlight of our meal, we were quite sad when we finished it. She recommended a nice Italian red that we did enjoy (know absolutely nothing about European wines, but we expressed partiality to dry cabs and she helped us along). The one negative is that our server did keep correcting my pronunciation of various dishes (granted I am not French) but that was awkward, and even more confusing when the male server bringing us the food (who seemed very much European and possibly French) pronounced it the same way I did. The duck was arguably better than the short rib but both were satisfactory, and both had a sauce pairing that was absolutely amazing. 

They were oh so sweet and sent along complimentary Italian almond cookies (almost like a meringue but denser) with a "happy birthday" note with it, and the persimmon sorbet was absolutely light, refreshing and delicious. Would love to come back here next time and try their pate and cheese selection.
author: Joy H.

description:
I couldn't say enough good things about this place! The food was absolutely AMAZING! The service was right behind being even more Amazing!
I flew in from Austin the evening b4 to celebrate my Son's 20th birthday. It was a very last minute trip. That evening I called around trying to organize him a last minute party for the next evening and no one was willing to do anything special on short notice. I hit pay dirt when I called Umberto the owner of Perbacco.
He was absolutely lovely to work with and extremely accommodating. Umberto quickly helped me decide on a fixed menu (keeping it within my budget) and wine list. He put together a beautiful table next day for my group of 15. When we got there, he had a birthday card waiting for my son, and personalized menus for each guest all done very classily! He came by our table numerous times to make sure we had everything we needed and the waiter assigned to us was very attentive too. All our guests (locals who had never been there) were super impressed and they will all definitely be going back to Perbacco. 
Kudos to you Mr. Umberto for making a fantastic memory for my 20 yr old! I'll be coming here for a meal the next time in to SFO for sure!
Love, Love, Love this place!
author: sudha p.

description: Everyone should have a friend like ours who treated us to this fabulous restaurant. The ambiance is terrific.  But the menu...OMG what do you pick.  Luckily we shared so we were able to sample many of the dishes.  We had three appetizers, the roasted beets, the octopus and Brussels sprouts.  If your budget allows only one, get the octopus.  It is superb. Now let's talk beets.  I have always needed a dog under the table for beets.  Not here.  And who doesn't love roasted Brussels.  But let's talk pasta.  They make their own, I make my own.  Mine is slightly worse than the better San Francisco restaurants and a lot better than Columbus restaurants. We ordered, at the server's recommendation, the RICCIA NERA and the LANGAROLI. Yum and a very generous serving.  Probably the best pasta I have ever had.  Finished up with a chocolate mousse thing with pumpkin ice cream on the side. Like I said, we were treated to this wonderful meal.  I thought prices were reasonable for the fabulous selections, unlike anything I have seen before. Thank you to our friend for a memorable evening.  It merits more than five stars.
author: Vickie B.

description:
This is for private events only.

I walked in, to see the space and i spoke with the owner, whom was REALLY NICE.  I liked him and did as he said: followed up with his sales manager for a private event (my wedding). 

Sales never got back to me. I called as well.  Completely disappointed. I am in sales and would never not respond to a lead..!
author: Sara S.

description: Good food. Get the meatballs. Also get the Brussels sprouts. I docked a star because of the noise level. Expect to speak with a raised voice and be unable to clearly hear anyone sitting more than a couple feet away.
author: Eric A.

description: I enjoyed this restaurant. Beware that they change the menu based on what is available at the local produce market.  Our waiter was pleasant and was more than happy to look at a picture i was interested so that he could tell me whether or not they still had that item on the menu.  I ordered the sweet potato gnocchi. It was good but the sweetness became a little overwhelming towards the end.  I think the smaller size would have Been sufficient.
author: Shay L.

description: Great place for business lunches and dinners.  Owned and managed by an Italian, which is evident when you taste the dishes.
author: Ben M.

description:
We enjoyed the Happy Hour yesterday.  The cocktails are wonderful!   The small plates too.   The roasted squid was excellent but you must try the  spicy chicken wings.  The olives were awesome as were the piquillo peppers.  We will definitely try to stay for dinner next time.

The service was excellent!
author: Emilia G.

description: Nice selection of wines and really good pasta dishes, but the ambiance is a bit more on the older side.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Came here for an anniversary and I will say that the restaurant went out of their way to honor that by having a handwritten Happy Anniversary card ready by the time we sat down and a special treat at the end of the meal. We had an 8:30 pm reservation and wet seated promptly. The food was good, but nothing memorable. We had the shrimp dish as an appetizer, and although it was good, it was messy. The presentation was poorly done and overloaded with fried onion rings. My girlfriend had the appetizer sized rib eye pasta dish. It was good and got the job done. I had the pork chops and they were definitely not to my satisfaction. 

I was never asked how I would like my pork chops cooked and I was unimpressed with how much effort it took to chew and eat. 

Atmosphere-wise was good. We had a nice corner table, perfect for people watching. The Server was very helpful and there was a vast wine selection. 
Lots of great food selections in San Francisco I will try all the other before I return here. Overall I would rate 3.5/5. 
PS, great ambience.
author: Jag S.

description: Wonderful!!!! Went for our anniversary and the service and treatment was above and beyond. Thanks for making our experience so great, we will definitely be back. The food is fresh and real italian! Feels like you're in Italy.
author: Bridget C.

description: My wife and I experience great food and service.  Fantastic and creative pairings of flavors within each dish we enjoyed. Started with the beet salad/blackberry/Gorgonzola. Then Burrata paired with peaches/plum and toasted peppercorns. For mains I had 5 hour pork and porcini sugo over tagliatelle my wife had amazing cannelloni filled with corn and truffled ricotta. Like nothing we've had before. We always look forward to great meals in SF and we were not disappointed at Perbacco!
author: Michael R.

description:
Perbacco was very busy when I came for lunch so I suggest that reservations are in order. 

I had the Plin Al Brasato - tender pockets of pasta filled with flavorful short rib meat in a luscious truffle red wine sauce. For $19, this pasta was well worth it. 

I also tried the brussels sprouts and my friend's chicken dish - both were tasty and excellent. The brussels sprouts were tender and nicely salty. The chicken was moist and not overcooked. 

Service was friendly, although I didn't realize how loud it was in the restaurant until our waiter started speaking and I could barely hear him, although he was standing right in front of me. 

I'd love to return for dinner!
author: Maya S.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed a birthday lunch here today. We had the burrata starter with asparagus, two orders of the pappardelle, and a couple of desserts (lemon crostata and some chocolate thing). The food was fantastic from start to finish, and the service was attentive but not overwhelming. FYI the restaurant can be pretty noisy when busy.
author: S M.

description: This was a special anniversary and birthday dinner, and it couldn't have been more perfect! Our server was wonderful, and she made great recommendations. The pasta dishes we shared were unique, rich, and so beautifully balanced. Plus, we were shocked at the final bill - it was so reasonable for such an outstanding experience. Beautiful decor, great service, and amazing food. This is our new favorite Italian spot in the city!
author: Megan R.

description:
Did not leave with the most satisfied feeling due to rather rude service and undercooked food.

While the atmosphere and decor of this restaurant definitely feels upscale and luxurious, the food itself and service had me feeling otherwise. Not only was it very dim inside the restaurant, we were also greeted by a waiter whose demeanor felt patronizing and judgemental with the way he spoke to us. He seemed impatient and annoyed when we asked about certain dishes, and when our food finally came, my friend's scallops were undercooked, and my pasta was underdone. We also felt rather rushed by him, although I did not see any reason why, as although we came during dinnertime, it was not busy at all. The food was affordable and seasoned well, however, yet I had hope there would be more selection.

I admire the high-class dining experience this restaurant should provide, yet we will probably not be coming back here for dinner.
author: Kyrie S.

description:
Dined at Perbacco on (2/9/16) and was really impressed with their lunch service. A relatively swanky stop for a Tuesday afternoon, it was packed full of the FiDi crowd and people were in/out quickly. Their ability to get people seated and fed so quickly is truly a feat not meant for many restaurants in the area. It's a great stop for a business meeting and the pricing is super fair for the area. 

I didn't want to break out my phone to take pictures because I was chatting with a mentor and didn't want to be "that guy", but I will say the food was def photo worthy. I had the dover sole, beet salad, and we split the oxtail tagliatelle. All were very impressive. 

The only reason I'm holding it to 4 stars is because I want to come back for dinner and be wowed! Everything I had was definitely above par, but nothing screamed super original. Totally worth the trip though!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I have planned several events here, from simple networking lunches to private dinners for groups of 50+ with the guidance of their special events manager, Stephen. Each time, my inbox fills up with glowing "thank you" emails from my clients. Perbacco is one of the first places I call when I need a classy venue to host a corporate meal.

Not only is the food delicious, but they are accommodating to all kinds of allergies, not batting an eye when I tell them someone is allergic to dairy and gluten and does not eat red meat. It always feels like they go the extra mile to make sure everything goes smoothly and that even *I* as the main point of contact have an enjoyable time when I am running around making sure my event is going smoothly.

Aside from that, I have dined here on my own and enjoyed my experience here even as a regular patron. I lived in Italy for a period of time a few years ago and the food here, especially the pasta, remind me of that time.
author: Jenn C.

description: Good Italian food with great vine selection. Delicious pasta and risotto! Also the grilled octopus appetizer was great!
author: Reuben H.

description: Good service, gnocchi needs some work, it was too sweet..
author: Karishma A.

description: Lovely, upscale atmosphere, beautifully presented food, and impeccable service. Will definitely return next time I'm in SF.
author: Myriam G.

description: Terrible vibe here. From the moment we walked in... we felt an uptight vibe. This place takes itself way too seriously. The food is just alright. Honestly, I felt uncomfortable here. We've been to better restaurants in SF (like award-winning, Michelin star type of restaurants) that are way better and even more expensive than this place and not felt the uncomfortable, disgusting feeling we felt here at Perbacco. We won't be back. I don't recommend this place.
author: Jessica O.

description:
I would like to share our GREAT restaurant experience last evening at Perbacco in SF. http://www.perbaccosf.com  

The ambiance is warm and inviting. From the time the four of us stepped in the front door, we were made to feel like family; and it remained the same throughout the evening.  

The service was outstanding - from the bartender who created pre-dinner cocktails and hand walked them to our table, to the server who was knowledgeable about the menu selections, to two knowledgeable and friendly wine stewards who recommended a great selection for us- a 2011 Le Chiuse Brunello di Montalcino DOCG, Tuscany, Italy (we had 2 bottles). 

The food was wonderful and presented beautifully.  For appetizers we had FRITTO MISTO: shrimp / seasonal beans / piquillo pepper / olives / fennel / lemon aioli;  and LOCAL MOZZERELLA DI BUFALA: meyer lemon creme fraiche / house cured lonza / langhe hazelnuts.  

For the main courses, we had BROWN BUTTER ROASTED PORK CHOP: charred cabbage / passato di sancrau / lingonberry jus; WOLFE RANCH QUAIL: black chanterelle and sunchoke ragout / carrot puree / natural jus; and SEARED SEA SCALLOPS: brown butter cauliflower / black truffle salsa verde / caper butter.   

For desert, we had KAFFIR LIME LEAF PANNA COTTA: candied buddah hand / lemon balm / kishu mandarins / chamomile / poppy seed merengue; and BURNT CARAMEL GELATO: tahitian vanilla sea salt / pignoli cookie. 

Simply put, a great price performer for 4;  and we have definitely added Perbacco to our list of family favorite restaurants.
author: Jim C.

description:
It was GAME OVER after saying "I do". Unlike the concept of utter demise on the usual marriage gone awfully wrong, the "Game Over" in context here is the same as "Dropping the Mic" or "This is it" or "There's nothing that can possibly top this" or "There's no returning to a mediocre life after this fate changing experience" or just simply "I win"..... Do you get what I'm saying? All they did was ask, "Do you want our white truffle from Alba, Italy to go along w that Agnolotti?" "I do." Game over. 

What led to this post today began last night at dinner:

PLIN DI TOPINAMBOUR - agnolotti filled with roasted sunchokes, ricotta, mascarpone, parmigiano reggiano topped w a generous layer of shaved White Truffle from Alba.

The simplicity of the dish itself makes it rely heavily on the nature of its ingredients and the chef's passion for its flavors n aromas.  A great house made pasta is always an extra star or 2 for me.  Service that matches the quality n mastery of its dishes is what makes it a 5 star here.  I've had plenty of other pleasant experiences here but never made it to write a review for them.  Last night's dish n service lingered on my mind throughout today n brought back other fond experiences at Perbacco, so I found it hard not to just hop on here n get it off my chest.
author: Colin M.

description: Menu was tired and uninspired.  Strange odor in the restaurant. Olive Garden food and ambiance would have been better.  Not sure what the hype is with this place. Food was salty.
author: JP S.

description:
Overall average. Started the meal with two appetizers: Frito Misto and the foie gras. The Frito Misto was nothing exciting- pretty much like Italian tempura- fried veggies and shrimp felt more like something I could get from a mom and pop authentic Italian restaurant. The Foie gras had a metallic taste to it . Not impressed. The pasta I got the agnolotti  wasn't cooked well- it stuck to my teeth. 

Service was not impressive either. How are you gonna rush us when you see that we're still eating our apps just because you 'fired' our main course? I don't care if you're in a rush because it's 9pm and you need to be out by 10. I expect that kind of service from a diner, but from a restaurant that advertises itself as upscale, do us a favor and act like it. In addition she double charged my card complaining that the restaurant was "busy"-that was a negative. 

Pro tip: if you like pasta, go to Cotogne instead. Less expensive and better customer service
author: Kai A.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place so I finally went with a friend last night after work.  However, we came in between lunch and dinner so we had the limited bar menu, which was fine and gives me a reason to come back.

We had such a lovely server.  I can't remember her name, but she was very helpful and great at helping us decide on our dishes.

We had the caramel corn with sea salt, tajarin, fritto mista, la tur, sola di val and the candied walnut turnover.  I really enjoyed the tajarin and fritto mista.  These dishes were good sizes to share between 2 people.  I really enjoyed the cheese too.  I liked the dessert, but not for $11.  It was small and I barely got to enjoy because I felt like I finished it too fast. :(

Overall, the ambiance was great.  I sat at the bar table in front of the restaurant.  I had great service and the food was good.  I just wish that the dessert was really worth $11.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Went here on Saturday night-- made reservations for 2. Host greeted us warmly, took our coats, and were escorted to our table. The wine som helped us pick out the right bottle of wine-- went through a few tastings and ended up with a Montepulciano. 

We ordered the burrata, gnocchi with pesto and mushrooms, and braised short ribs. Food was delicious. Fresh, well cooked, and flavorful. We ordered the chocolate ganache for dessert-- hubby loved it, super super dense and rich/creamy. It balanced nicely though with some orange peels and peanuts, and other goodies on the plate, but still a lot of pure chocolate for me.

Service was fabulous-- friendly, witty, and comfortable. Overall, a great experience.
author: Jasleen S.

description:
Booked marked for centuries, finally got to Perbacco last night, a bit drenched from the pouring rain, but we made it.  Didn't have to deal with parking since we Ubered, but they do have valet.

Inside is very nice.  The fine dining vibe def comes through.  No crowded seating which was thrilling to see.  I hate when you come into a nice place and then they squeeze you into a tiny corner, 6 inches away from the couple at the next table.  Seriously, I'd rather give up my fine dining experience and go out for pizza somewhere than to be practically holding hands with the people eating next to us.  Can somebody explain that to some of these restaurant owners and managers that try to use every last square inch of their seating space!??

OK.  I'm done.

I like Perbacco's decor.  Clean and relaxing.

Our waiter was young and slightly inexperienced but he did a pretty good job, except no parmesan cheese offered--always had to request.  And the gnocchi came cold.  He gladly offered to reheat and it came back cold again.  I'm not sure if the blame should go to the server, but he ended up bringing a brand new order that was up to temperature.

Here's what we ingested:

PESCE CRUDO (HAMACHI) (2/5)  Low marks for the hamachi which was ever so slightly fishy and not impressive in the least.

ROASTED OCTOPUS - (4/5)  The folks at the table gave this dish a thumbs up.  Very small portion so don't plan to share unless you're a party of two.  

BURRATA W/PERSIMMON (2/5) If an appetizer with burrata is on the menu, we order it.  We've had our share of burrata appetizers.  By comparison, this one is at the bottom of the totem pole.  Underwhelming not only in portion size, but also the cheese lacked flavor and creaminess.  This one I would not recommend.

AGNOLOTTI (3/5) Filled with roasted meat and cabbage, many Yelpers sang its praises.  I liked it but didn't love it.  A bit too one note and salty for me.  After a few bites, you were looking for something else.  Best agnolotti that I've ever tasted came from Il Ristorante di Giorgio Baldi in LA. It's the AGNOLOTTI in CORN TRUFFLE SAUCE.  When you're in LA, please do yourself the favor of getting to that restaurant to eat that specific dish.  Getting back to the point, I would not order the agnolotti again at Perbacco's.

TAGLIATELLE w/VEAL RAGU (3/5)  My daughter didn't complain about this dish, but I'd like to take the opportunity to tell you what was wrong with this pasta dish.  First, the pasta itself was good, very good.  The problem was the veal ragu. It was dry, lacking flavor and uninviting. The ladle-ful of ragu was sitting in the middle of the pasta.  Normally, you would take one forkful of the pasta and the sauce in the center would start naturally start spreading over the plate and onto the unsauced pasta.  But not with this sauce.  It was too dry and not saucy at all, which is one of the biggest reasons this dish doesn't pass the test.  If you're going to put a sauce in the center, it needs to be saucy enough to work itself around the plate.  End of pasta sauce 101 tutorial.

BEEF LOIN & BRAISED SHORT RIB (3/5)  Another just OK dish.  On one side of the plate, one small braised short rib, and on the side was a very small slab of beef loin.  I didn't care for the short rib and I'm hard-pressed to tell you why.  The flavor not there, yes tender, but the sauce wasn't good.  The beef loin was good, and the little there was, I enjoyed it with the horseradish.

Perbacco has great potential, but tonight it wasn't realized.  Maybe this is a restaurant that 
*used * to be good.  I don't know.  But if I base my judgement on last night's experience, it's a three at best.  I wonder if we ordered different things off the menu if that would have impacted our lack luster experience??
author: Darien R.

description: Had a great pasta and duck at this place. Most of all, customer service was fantastic. I believe we were served by 5 different people and all of them are attentive. A plastic wrap was accidentally left in our appetizer plate, when I told the server about it, he apologized and offered if we want to return and be served a new one. I said, it's fine, I just want to let them know. When he returned he said he took it off our tab. I think that was nice. The food quality wasn't really affected by the misplaced wrapper. At the end of out meal we were given free desserts because of the incident, I didn't expect that but it only shows how they value customer service. The food was delicious and our cocktails were unique and refreshing. It was such a nice experience dining with Perbacco.
author: Roxanne C.

description:
Came here because we're big fans of Barbacco next door.  We got:
- Slow roasted veal appetizer (3/5) - really tender, thinly sliced veal with mild flavor.  Decent, but not too exciting.
- Agnolotti (3/5) - pasta stuffed with roasted meats.  The filling was fine, but overall it was a bit on the salty side.
- Stuffed quail (4/5) - only had a bite or two off my girlfriend's plate, but it's tough to go wrong with boneless quail.

The service was extremely attentive, but overall the food was just OK.  Compared to Barbacco, we definitely prefer Barbacco.
author: Simon L.

description:
Oh man, Perbacco.. I can't pronounce your name or any of the items on your menu, but the pastas here are really some of the best I've had! It was double date night and we had a reservation for 9 pm, but got there around 7. We were absolutely famished and were lucky to be able to be seated immediately upon arrival. The restaurant had a lot of open tables when we arrived, but filled up pretty quick! While waiting for our orders, we had bread sticks and bread with the most delicious pesto dip!

We ordered the burrata with strawberries as an appetizer and oh my goodness... this was one of the highlights of the meal. The cheese is so delicious with the strawberries and almonds, I think I could eat this every single day! For my entree, I ordered the gnocchi with chestnuts and persimmons (it had a much fancier name, sorry I didn't jot it down). It's not the fluffiest gnocchi I've ever had, but it had really good flavors. I haven't had chestnuts in a pasta dish before, it definitely was interesting! The boyfriend ordered agnolotti (again, it had a much fancier name) and this was really yummy! It was somewhat similar to a ravioli, except it was stuffed with delicious meats! I really enjoyed this dish! The other couple ordered tajarine (these noodles were like fresh ramen noodles, really tasty!) and pappardelle (had short rib and was definitely one of my other favorites of the night). 

At the end of our main courses we were completely stuffed! But for some reason still ordered two desserts to share. I ordered the salted chocolate cake with honeycomb and grapes and cherries. It was very delicious, but heavy. Definitely worth the try! The other couple ordered a panna cotta that had thyme in it. It was very interesting, although I have to say I preferred my cake better!

TL;DR: SF has so many amazing restaurants to try, and Perbacco is one of the ones I'd definitely want to come back to some time! I'm definitely going to be dreaming about that burrata!
author: Angel K.

description: The decor, service and location were nice. But if you want food that's bland and without much taste, then this is definitely the place for you. We ordered the squid appetizer with the sole and papardelle entrees and while the portion sizes were large and the prices more than fair, adding salt and more salt did nothing to fix the lack of flavor.
author: wendy w.

description: I've come here many times with business associates and enjoyed a fantastic, authentic Italian meal with great service. Brought my Italian business associates here for dinner and it was an amazing experience. They enjoyed it so much and considered it "as good as a fine restaurant back home."
author: Art S.

description: We've been three times.  The service and ambience are excellent, as is the wine list. The food is very good, just too salty at times---thus, four stars.
author: James M.

description:
Adding one star. Today's lunch was impeccable. The grilled squid app was amazing, lightly grilled, with green leaves, and beans with a light paste. Wow...

Entree was Raviora, butternut squash ravioli. I cannot describe it any better than flawless. Washed down by Rosso di Montalcino ($15x2). Perbacco is perhaps the best restaurant in FiDi.
author: Massimo M.

description: This place is great for an intimate business lunch.  It can get loud, in a convivial way.
author: Brian W.

description:
One of my fav restaurants in all of San Francisco!

First ate here to celebrate the ipo of opentable. I was blown away back than and every single time I have come back; it never disappoints!

From the beautiful setting to the service and the lovely food Perbacco is the full package. No wonder the place was totally packed for lunch on a Tuesday at the end of the Summer lull.

The pastas are always amazing. My Gnocchi, with duck ragu, was really light and bursting with flavor. The Gnocchi was not lumpy or heavy just light pillows of potato goodness. My little Gem salad was a nice lightly dressed salad with lovely fresh veggies. 

My partner had the Brussel sprouts which were delightfully cooked with a sprinkling of cheese. His Tonno Salad looked really good as well.

Perbacco also caters to vegetarians...and not in a half ass way. You can get a really lovely vegetarian meal here with great flavors and textures.

Wine list is phenomenal.

It is pricey but it is sooo worth it.

Finally the owner Umberto is such a gentlemen (in his prince of wales plaid suit) and wonderful operator of this lovely dinning establishment you cannot  help but feel the love and care that goes into this place.

Mille grazie signor Gibin!
author: David G.

description:
I reserve this fabulous restaurant for special occasions. You know the kind of occasions where you whip out your best, little black dress, diamonds, an imported tally shawl from Egypt and a gorgeous ex-boyfriend on your arm to boot! Last night was that occasion, and I must say, as usual you never fail to deliver! With a nickname like "Doc Bubbles" of course we ordered the BEST Rosé on your wine list along with the braceola salad, the risotto with black chanterelles and the branzino... can you say succulent! From the ambiance, the delectable meal, to the champagne... I'm still bubbling!

Jacalyn Buettner, DC
author: Union Square C.

description:
Perbacco is a nice upscale Italian restaurant situated in the financial district in SF. You can take a stroll along the Ferry building, see the Bay Bridge from afar, and even drop by the Cupid's Span and then plan a little dinner at Perbacco since it's walking distance.

The overall ambience of the place was nice. It was chic and modern. One side of the wall were bricks decorated with a span of mirror that ran across. It was nice because if you are sitting on the other side of the table facing the wall you're not just limited to look at the wall. You are able to see the whole restaurant and be immersed in its overall ambience. And I believe ambience is key at any restaurant. The place was dimly lite but not too dark. It gives off a nice romantic feel which isn't bad for an Italian place since it would be perfect to bring your date... Overall I like the overall feel of the restaurant.

To jump into the food... 

My friend and I started off with their Pesce Crudo (4/5) which was really good. The hamachi was really fresh which was really surprisingly since it's an Italian place. The whole dish had a lot of different flavors going on but surprisingly everything went really well together. I would definitely recommend trying this dish.  

For our entrees, we got their Duck Rissotto (4/5) and Pappardelle w. Lamb Ragu (4/5). The duck risotto was very creamy and rich and yet had this hint of sweetness that accentuated the dish. The Pappardelle was cooked al dente which I love. I've tried Pappardelle at other places and sometimes it's really bad bc they undercook the pasta but Perbacco was right on with the texture of the dish. I was impressed. The lamb was very tender and moist and wasn't gamey. Both dishes were excellent. 

For dessert we got their Lemon Thyme Panna Cotta (3/5) which was a very pretty dish with an array of fruits and nuts. Loved the side of sorbet which was very refreshing. The panna cotta was good and you could definitely taste the thyme but I've had better. 

Our waiter gave us an extra dessert for free! Yay free food! He gave us their Hazel Nut Meringue which was good... there was chunks of hazel nut embedded into the meringue... I can't complain it was free. 

To end the dining experience they also handed out petite four at the end that consisted of chocolate and a nut based chew... it was good but I was uncomfortably full at that point... 

Overall it was a nice meal. Our waiter was nice and was very attentive to us. Made sure our wine glasses were full at all times... Oh we ordered a bottle of Barbera upon recommendation from our waiter and it was very good... Yum! :) If you're in the area you should definitely check this place out!
author: Stella M.

description:
Friday, 1:30 PM. 

Quickie:
* Food
++ Service
-  Slow turnaround
+  Hygiene
+  Lively vibe

And then...?
A few tweaks and Perbacco will make it into the rotation. 

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Butternut Squash Cannelloni
     -  Dry interior. 
2. Seared sea scallops
     +  Cauliflower and grape are interesting additions. 

Constructive comments:
*Source ingredients
author: Chuck N.

description: I ate here a while back I have to say that it was a great first for what I would consider a more fancy restaurant date. The food my girlfriend and I shared for $100 left us very full and fascinated with what we just ate. The ambiance of the place was wonderful. It had a very relaxing vibe to it all. On the day that I went, it was even more relaxing as the restaurant is much less crowded for lunch that I would assume it would be for dinner, leaving me and my date room and quiet to talk and enjoy the food in the surprisingly blissful privacy their table had to offer.
author: Renneth D.

description:
Meh, service was nice, but rather abrupt and not too attentive.  Not a deal breaker since Perbacco does get packed after work on the weekdays.  It's a nice place to grab dinner before heading home on BART/MUNI but don't expect to meet clients here as it is almost impossible to carry a conversation through all the noise.

Food was good, but nothing memorable stood out.  Execution of each dish had a few ups and downs, I was expecting a lot from their Pappardelle w/ Shortrib Ragu dish but sadly, it was just ok.  I do appreciate that they properly cooked the fresh pasta though, nice and al dente. 

Highlight of the night was definitely the pesto that came with the bread and breadsticks, yum yum!  Our waiter also brought out meringues for the birthday girl which was a nice gesture to end the evening.

I won't go out of my way to come here, but if I'm in the area...I may meet up a few friends for drinks and a quick bite.  Check out their sister restaurant, Barbacco, I think I prefer the more casual setting + menu offering there more.
author: Janetto L.

description:
I made a rez on opentable and requested a birthday dessert and they executed.  They even had a birthday card ready with our menus.  We came here a little early but they seated us right away (our rez was at 6:30 p.m.).  Armando, our waiter, was great!  Very friendly, informative and efficient.  The wait staff that cleared our tables and filled our waters were very attentive and efficient.  The older men in suits helped with carrying out the entrees and there were plenty of staff and help (reminded me of Barbacco where there is plenty of staff and they all work with one another seamlessly!).  Service was excellent!  The wine Armando recommend was great with my dinner.

We had the beef tartare as the appetizer and it was delicious.  It came with a raw quail egg on top with garlic bread on the side.  YUM.  WAYYY better than the beef carpaccio at Foreign Cinema.  I had the lamb ragu parpadelle (similar to the ragu pasta dish at Barbacco) and BF had the scallops.  Both were amazing.  The side of brussel sprouts was a nice touch.  

MUST ORDER DESSERT.  We had the salted caramel gelato with pinenut cookie.  They also gave us the coffee gelato with another cookie.  I loved both.  I'm glad we got to try both instead of just the birthday dessert.

I would definitely come back.  I love Barbacco too so it's hard to pick!  I would come here for a special occasion or client meeting and Barbacco for a casual dinner.  Both are a short walk from the Embarcadero Muni/BART station.
author: Chris L.

description:
Came here about a month ago for an early Mother's day dinner. Since I had an OpenTable gift card for $100, I thought why not try Perbacco! It's been on my list of places to try for a while now. We had a 6pm reservation on Fri 5/9. Parking was pretty easy. We found a spot a block over a little before 6pm.

Complimentary breadsticks with pesto - I love pesto, but this was just bland! Plus with the crunchy breadsticks it was actually a little messy which I didn't like. Who wants to drip pesto on tablecloths?!

Salumi misti ($29 for a large) - A selection of house cured salumi inspired by traditional piemontese recipes. There was a good amount of meats, but none of them stood out except the pate. They were all a little lackluster and didn't have much flavor. I don't get why this was/is on the 7x7 list.

Pesce crudo ($15) - Hamachi, shaved hearts of palm, blood orange, kumquat, serrano pepper. I love hamachi, hearts of palm and serrano pepper. I wasn't sure if I would like the kumquat but it didn't make the dish overly sweet so I didn't mind it.

Piastra roasted octopus and pork belly ($14) - Olive oil crushed potatoes, salsa verde, celery fennel salad. The octopus was a little tough. And I love chewy octopus! The flavors blended well together, but I had a texture problem with this dish.

Seared sea scallops ($31) - Hearts of palm and seasonal citrus ragout, sea urchin, chrysanthemum. Good thing I like hearts of palm cuz it was in this dish too! The scallops were nicely cooked. The sea urchin added a lovely subtle touch.

Pappardelle ($19 for a large) - Wide pasta ribbons, slow cooked short rib ragu, grated horseradish. The pasta was perfectly cooked! And the short rib was nicely stewed, but together, something just didn't gel. The sauce didn't seem to bring the meat and pasta together.

Dry aged liberty farm duck breast ($28) - Stone fruit radicchio panzanella, basil, apricot duck rillettes. I don't know why, but the duck itself had no flavor. The skin didn't have that nice crispiness I love when it's browned on a pan. Not sure how they cooked it, but maybe it was sous vide and then put on the plate? I also didn't care for the panzanella as it was too sweet.

Wolfe ranch quail breast filled with wild mushrooms ($32) - Potato puree, chard, wild mushrooms. I don't really remember this dish so I can't really comment. I do adore mushrooms and chard. And with quail it should be a winning combo.

New potatoes tossed in herb butter ($6) - Sea salt. The most disappointing dish of the night. I rarely order potatoes as a side but I was craving some buttery carbs so I decided to get this dish. The potatoes were under cooked and underseasoned. Not good at all! 

Olive oil panna cotta ($10) - Sprouted almonds, borage, strawberry white balsamic sauce, rhubarb sorbetto. We ordered this based on the recommendation of our server. I liked this dessert better than the one my dad chose. The panna cotta was nice and silky and creamy. The sauce and sorbetto complimented it well.

Mascarpone cheesecake ($10) - Pistachio sponge, poached rhubarb, candied kumquats, mandarin sorbetto. I didn't care for this dessert. The cheesecake was lighter than I expected and didn't hold up to the pistachio and fruit flavors. It didn't feel like the cheesecake was the star of the dish.

Our server was nice and attentive through most of the meal. Remember to ask for bread and butter if you want it. I didn't read the menu til we got our Salumi misti and had to find our server to get some bread to go with the dish. I think if you order it they should ask you if you want bread.

I debated giving this place 3 or 3.5 stars. After taking into account the food, service, and price, I'd say Perbacco is a solid 3 stars.
author: Elena N.

description: setting with table cloth, service the best, love the squid ink linguine but size is small though
author: Freya-Loki O.

description:
Great place for a business lunch.  Be sure to make reservations as the lunch crowd comes in fast and both floors can really fill up.  This was my second visit... Service was good this time (as was last time) but not overly friendly.  For my beverage, I asked for some cranberry juice mixed with Sprite and my server seemed a little put off by the request.

I had the plin al brasato (agnolotti filled with braised beef) and it was wonderful.
author: Ann J.

description:
Came in here during a business trip.  They had a great selection of Italian wines and the food was decent.  I got the squid ink pasta and the dive scallops.  The place was extremely noisy and I sat right by the kitchen.  The service was decent.  The food came out fast and overall it was great.  There is just something about this place that prevents me from giving it five stars.  Maybe I'll go back again just to see if it feels the same way. 

I went to the bar the following day which is right by the restaurant.  Not bad, I would recommend it.
author: Jimmy Y.

description:
We came in with some of an expectations as we were referred by our hotel.
Not much flavor built into the food. Every single fish was BLAND. The service was also the same as the flavor. To top it all off, the portions are extremely small (for dinner) as if the food is "gourmet"
Maybe if was an off day for this establishment
author: Oren G.

description:
Service is stellar - it's that noticeable.  The staff is well trained at Perbacco.
We were seated at a table that just wasn't going to work--a small table where one diner would have to face a brick wall.  I am not a fan of when the hostess seats patrons at the most unwanted tables first.  We politely asked the owner to change us to a different table and he moved us to table 53 without a problem.  Great table!!  As a side note, our original table was left empty for the rest of the night.........

After that misstep, service began and it just kept getting better and better.  What a team!
We shared the vitello tonnato and two appetizer sized pastas: the pappardelle and the tajarin.
The lamb sugo in the pappardelle was the favorite.
Their full bar kept our vodka martinis coming to our table without delay.

I had the pan seared beef loin and braised short rib for my main course.  My partner had the seared scallops. Both were paired with a glass of wine with help from the sommelier.  Mine was a glass of Italian wine from the area around Venice--very nice.
We are so spoiled living in SF and have become accustomed to incredible food,  That is the reason for the 4 star rating.  The food is very good--not great.

Dessert was the Angel Food cake with seared peaches and plums.

Dinner for two with tip: $287.00
author: Thomas D.

description:
Simply fantastic. We loved all the dishes we had and also the portion are decent.

For appetizer we had carne crudo which is a fantastic beef tartar, local mozzarella cheese with prosciutto and the pears (for a veggie dish)
For main we had scallops which were great, five large once done perfectly and two great pasta dishes.
For desert the panna cotta was truly outstanding.
author: Yishay M.

description:
Went to Perbacco for a work lunch, and I have to say that it's definitely out of my comfort zone.  I normally go to quick places, so a sit down place with white table cloths is definitely not the norm.

I ordered the risotto, which on that day was described as "braised point reyes porcini mushrooms, caramelized onion, spinach, and la tur cheese" and a side of fingerling roasted potatoes. 

Overall, the food and experience was great.  While I wouldn't go again just for a regular lunch, I would definitely recommend it for a special lunch.
author: Nadeem A.

description: Had a business dinner their and really enjoyed the evening. Service and food was spot on. I'll be coming back.
author: Marky M.

description:
A vendor took me here for a lunch.  We were seated in a corner booth.  They brought by breadsticks with a pesto dipping sauce. Also nice fresh focaccia and a big hunk of butter - "carbs - how I miss you so"

I am trying to not eat carbs, so we ordered the tomato and watermelon salad, a side of the brussels sprouts. I ordered the Polpette meatballs - comes with roasted peaches and a bit of mashed potatoes. It was good, and since I only ate half - even better the next day. My friend go the parppadelle, which looked REALLY good.

I will be back to try the pasta.
author: Amy W.

description: What an incredible dining experience when wanting upscale Italian cuisine.  When you first walk in, you sense a cool, hip and classy atmosphere.  An attractive after work crowd gathers dressed in suits and work attire but you also see tourists and locals who are dressed casually hip which is also part of the vibe from fabulous this place.  We landed a nice seat in the dining room in the middle of the restaurant that was busy and bustling on a Friday night.  For cocktails, our orders were a nice extra dirty martini and their Perbacco cocktail that was so exquisitely refreshing we have been wanting to create this exact cocktail at home.  For starters, we went with the roasted octopus which had nice big pieces in olive oil, potatoes, shaved radishes, vinaigrette and salsa verde.  SUPERB!  I then had the dry aged liberty farm duck breast that was so moist and creatively done with apricot mostrada, stonefruit and watercress salad.  AMAZING!  My boyfriend had the pappardelle wide ribbon pasta with slow cooked short rib ragu and horseradish.  The pasta was perfect with an ideal compliment from the richness of the short rib.  Service was impeccable and our waiter had a lot of knowledge in wine recommendations for our meal.  Having dinner at Perbacco was an outstanding choice for our first night back in San Francisco.
author: Kelly P.

description: Food, drink and ambience mixed together for a wonderful evening. My wife had the pork chop and I had pasta "pappardelle w ragu alla bolognese". We each shared the two dishes to maximize our experience. The serving size was just right and although a little pricy, it was worth it in our opinion. Umberto, and Leslie are delightful.
author: John A.

description:
Beautiful open space with a view into the kitchen, which is always inspiring.  Extremely knowledgeable servers who can recite the menu from memory and give excellent recommendations.  Interesting food, with several vegetarian options.  

The meal starts with breadsticks and some sort of green pesto/garlic dipping sauce.  Both are nice.  They bring boules of bread for each person if desired.  One complaint:  the butter brought with the bread is not butter.  It's margarine.  

The appetizers were wonderful.  The BURRATA WITH ASPARAGUS AND LEMON BUTTER was a large portion and very tasty.  There was just enough lemon sauce to enjoy with all of the large stalks of asparagus.  The burrata was perfectly creamy. The BIBB LETTUCE SALAD was absolutely delicious with feta cheese, a citrusy dressing and shaved radishes.  Unfortunately there were only about 5 pieces of lettuce.

The RAVIORA, with fennel scented ricotta, asparagus and a lemon butter sauce, contained house made fresh pasta.  This was a beautiful plate and quite tasty.  Get the full portion size, though, as the half is quite small and only a few dollars less.  

Others entrees at my table: SLOW ROASTED PORK SHOULDER with PEAR AND WALNUT "CUGNA", MUSTARD SEED JUS & POLENTA.  This was touted by a North Italian expert as one of the best, most fulfilling dishes he'd ever had.  He claimed that it the sweetness of the fruit perfectly paired with the tender thick chunk of pork.  

The OCTOPUS with SQUID INK PASTA was also a hit, despite the waiter's warning that one needed to really love those ingredients to enjoy the dish.  I would have been warned off of it at that point, but my companion chose to forge ahead.  She thought that the breading gave the dish an unusual but delicious and welcome texture.  

The ROASTED WINTER VEGETABLE / KALE RYE BERRY "RISOTTO" & CITRUS GREMOLATA appeared bland and uninteresting.  Likewise, the diner that chose this dish had nothing to say about it.  

For dessert, we shared the LIME-MEYER LEMON PANNA COTTA with CANDIED CITRON, LEMON CREMA POMEGRANATE SEEDS & SPICED RED WINE SORBETTO, which was perfectly creamy and light, making one feel that it could not possibly be bad for you.  

We also tried the SALTED DARK CHOCOLATE BONET on ALMOND CAKE with GOLDEN CARAMEL GRAPES, HONEYCOMB & VANILLA CREMA.  While I could take or leave all of the other elements of this dessert, the honeycomb was one of the best tasting and most interesting items I've eaten in a long time.  Flaky, crispy crunchy, airy texture with a rich dark caramel and honey flavor.  Amazing.  Just give me those and I'll be happy.  Beware if you have fillings or caps, as this is a sticky item. 

The ambience, service and food were excellent.  The price is a bit high, but to be expected out of a swank FIDI restaurant.
author: Sasha R.

description: I've had many dreams about the gnocchi. Soft, pillowy and luscious like a fat lady's bosom. There is nothing better than burying your face in these mounds.
author: Suany W.

description:
Came here for our holiday dept. lunch. This is the 2nd time I've had lunch @ Perbacco, and it didn't disappoint. we started off with the marinated roasted beets, Fritto Misto of Shrimp, Burrata cheese, and olives.  I think we could have just had that for lunch everything was filling and delicious.   For our main course I had the risotto it was oh, so creamy and the portion was huge. My coworker had the duck, She enjoyed it...the boss had the meatballs.  and 2 others had the pan seared hanger steak. Can I suggest their brown butter Brussel Sprouts, fingerling Potatos and Squash (squash had a very nice sweet taste to it) everything looked so delicious, needless to say every one cleaned their plate out.  I was already busting out of my pants, but I had to try dessert...LOL!!!! 

We got apple sorbet (real good), Brutti Ma Buoni. (a merengue like with hazelnuts inside). dark chocolate Bonet, and cappucino's  to keep us from not going into a food coma.

Service?   Our Server was excellent. kept our glasses full of sparkling water, refilling our drinks. and checking up on us every 15-20 minutes.
author: Claudia E.

description: Ate here last night for second time.  Food was delicious again service was so so at best.  Out of 2 Gins for cocktails.  All said great food 5 Star, Bar and Service 2 Star last night.  Would still recommend.
author: Ray H.

description:
I got taken to this place tonight because I "like Italian". 

Sorry, but this food is tasteless. I sent back the Frito Misto... and the pastas were pretty much useless. It's got a nice ambience, and the service is fine... but Italian is all about the food and this place just doesn't have it. 

I'll never be back.
author: Brad C.

description: After my birthday dinner, my BFF took me here for dessert in April 2016 (because we enjoy variety, and I'm very particular). I ordered a chocolate dessert at first, but then decided I wasn't in love. I envied his beautiful and delicious strawberry dessert, so we swapped mine out. :)
author: Sally M.

description:
Wow! The food was SO good here - so glad we were able to get last minute resos to Perbacco.

The pasta here is really, really good - and they come in small or dinner portions so if you're not feeling too hungry, you can still have a taste. I had the Agnolotti (YUM) while others at the table had the Gnocchi, Shortrib Pappardelle, and Risotto. For starters, I had the Peach and Mushroom appetizer and wow - I could have had two more plates of that.

Great wine selection, including some glasses that you can try through the Corovin method. This is a neat contraption where a slim microscopic needle pierces the cork and allows the wine to drain through - such that the cork is never removed ensuring constant freshness of the wine. It's pricey starting with the one I had at $25 but boy it was good.

Service was amazing - my husband had ordered a side of Brussel sprouts and when asked about it, the waiter apologized profusely and said he misunderstood and didn't catch it. We decided not to get it even though he said it would only take a few minutes. We still said no (not maliciously but we were happy with ou plates). Our waiter still brought it out complimentary. That was really great.

Desserts are also good, but the main features at Perbacco really are the pastas.

Great space: modern, sleek, and actually quite large (two floors). I think Perbacco is one of the restaurants to eat in SF, and undoubtedly so! 5 star in my books and the best restaurant I tried while in SF.
author: Charlotte W.

description: Had an amazing family birthday meal here the other night. The service is wonderful, the wine rec from our server was great, and the food was decadent. Recommend the veal tartare and the gnocchi!
author: Danielle T.

description: This place is nice - I got the duck dish and I quite liked it. However, I probably wouldn't write home about it. The burrata starter was good too. Overall you'd go here to look good and eat classy food.
author: Dany K.

description:
There comes a time in every woman's life when she realizes she needs a tablecloth to be happy. A tablecloth, and a cocktail.

That's what I realized the moment I walked into Perbacco's sister restaurant, Barbacco, where we had a dinner reservation for our one grown-up date night in San Francisco.  I just need a good meal, not a fancy restaurant -- or so I'd figured when making our reservation. Who needs pretension? 

It turns out that *I* need pretension...or at least a cocktail list. When we walked into the noisy Barbacco and discovered that they only served beer and wine, we popped next door into the serenity of Barbacco and were thrilled that they were able to seat us.

Even though the restaurant was crowded and noisy, the acoustics meant that we were able to have a quiet conversation without difficulty. The service was excellent -- almost too prompt! We ate a two-course dinner in barely more than an hour.

The food itself was excellent: we had a delicious fritto misto and salad to start, followed by two very good, meaty pasta dishes. We were grateful that the waiter explained their cuisine comes from a region of Italy known for its meat dishes, since that let us focus our choices. For the same reason, it's not a great choice for vegetarians, even though they have vegetarian options.

I gave the restaurant four instead of five stars simply because it wasn't one of those mind-boggling meals that I'll remember for years. But it really was a very good dinner, in a very good restaurant.

And the cocktail -- that I *will* remember for years. Not just because I was grateful for a full bar, but because it was literally the best cocktail I've ever had: the Senza Nome, made from equila, cantaloupe juice, aperol, lime and basil syrup. Wow!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
This is a 41/2 star restaurant.

Seems to be a popular birthday spot. I also was taken their for birthday. Their was a card on the table - honestly, though, people signing a card for someone they don't know?

Had the Loves Me/Loves Me Not cocktail and loved it. All the others looked powerful and I wanted a buzz, not getting knocked onto my can.

My friend, who has been there before, recommended the mozzarella di bufala. Good choice, the cheese was good and tomatoes ripe. Enough to take the edge off without stuffing us. They brought rolls. Roll was very good but I did not ask for another as I did not want to fill up on bread. My friend got halibut. I thought of scallops, I have not had scallops in an age, but when I asked if it was a cream-based sauce the waiter got a little evasive, well, not really a lot of cream blah blah. I got quail. Very good quail. Crisp skin, interior perfectly cooked, with a corn dish and roasted mushrooms. Everything good and very attractively presented.

For dessert got boccone dolce. They wrote "happy birthday" on my plate in chocolate but the dessert was a little disappointing. It looked beautiful but just did not seem to bring out the flavors. The crema had no chocolate flavor and even the ganache had very little. Could they have skimped on chocolate? Seemed unlike them.

I also had to ask to bring sugar for my tea, should be automatic, after having to ask twice for them to bring the tea. So they lose a half star.

But I'll probably return someday. Try the duck or halibut - both looked good.
author: Carol S.

description:
Although I can't pronounce more than half the items on the menu, this place was spectacular. Came here for the first time for a birthday celebration and the evening was great. There was a birthday card placed at our table by the time we were seated. Small detail, big plus! Our waiter, with a heavy (I like to call authentic) Italian accent, went really in depth when describing the dishes we were interested in. I was able to try 8~10 dishes including appetizers since we all share a bit with each other. Other than the eggplant, I have nothing bad to say about any of the dishes. And I'm biased because I've never really enjoyed eggplants. 

Perbacco was recommended to us and I would definitely come back and recommend it to others. I saw some guests dressed up, some were very casual. It seems to be good for all occasions!  

P.S. don't skip on the dessert, So. So. Good

Cliffs: Great food, great service. Dress up or down, try it out!
author: Tim L.

description: Ridiculously disappointed.  I don't know what this place once was but my first and last visit this past week was utterly disappointing.  The salads were very basic and uninspiring for the price and the seared squid was forgettable.  The Langaroli which is basically a braised short rib ravioli was so salty that it was difficult to continue eating.  It felt like there was a teaspoon of salt in every ravioli.  I would normally let the server know about something like this and order another entree but this was a business lunch.  I'm really not sure if everyone else at the table just tolerated the food secretly like I did or actually enjoyed their meal.
author: Michele L.

description:
I took two colleagues here for lunch and regretted it very much. We ordered a wide variety of dishes and they fell short on every single dish when it came to the most basic essence of any Italian restaurant - taste!  We ordered the following:

1) roasted baby beets - poor and lacked taste 
2) two sides of the brussel sprouts - average 
3) tajarin - handful thin tagliatelle with pork and mushrooms - this was my main course and the top five worst dishes for me 
4) duck leg confit - average 
5) chioggia salad - average 

Appetizers range between $10-15, main course dishes between $16-24 and sides are all $8 - by all means a pricey affair. Service was average as well so did not make up for the food. Our bill came out to ~$140 for three people which is outrageous. 

In summary, quality and taste were well below average and the food prices are not at all aligned with what they're offering their customers. I'm told this used to be a good place back in the day but they are shambolic at the moment. Will not be going back or recommending to anyone.
author: Kabir S.

description: If you're looking for a great Italian Restaurant in the Financial District of SF, this is definitely a must!! We were staying in Union Square and took an uber over to the restaurant, which made life much easier in terms of traffic and parking. Now for the good stuff, for appetizers we ordered the Carne Cruda (tartare of beef tenderloin) and Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts. Both starters were excellent! For our main courses we ordered the Piastra Seared Scallops which was light, refined and phenomenal, and the Red Wine Braised Beef Short Ribs which was just mouthwatering delicious!! Our meals were perfectly paired with a Cabernet Sauvignon. As for dessert, we indulged in the Brutti Ma Buoui (hazelnut cookies) and the Burnt Caramel Gelato and of course a delicious cappuccino to top off this lovely course. Service was friendly and attentive. This is definitely a place for foodies!!
author: Yvette G.

description: I gave it four stars last time I was here in 2012. Tonight pushed it to five. Everything was perfect, especially the tuna, the pappardelle, and the salted caramel gelato. Service was friendly and expert. We had a memorable evening.
author: Morris R.

description:
My boss loves having business lunches here. I love ordering their alcoholic drinks because not only is it free for me but I get pretty tipsy off of one cocktail. Which means I become more animated and talkative and people actually don't think I'm lame.  Or that could all be what I perceive in my head and in real life I'm slumped down in my seat with drool trickling down the corner of my mouth.

Great salad! It's what I always order and it's filling with the bread that's served at the beginning of the meal. But the pastas look so good too!
author: Annie A.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday with a 6:15 reservation from OpenTable and it was already busy. I had the gnocchi with mushrooms and my sister had the gnocchi with tomato sauce. Both were delicious! They will give you bread upon request. Service was good and food came out quite quickly, but it was a bit loud  and tables are close together. 

By the time we left, every table was full. I highly recommend making a reservation.
author: Sarah K.

description: FOOD POISONING! BEWARE! Was visiting San Francisco and wanted a nice "Italian" dinner so decided to try out Perbacco. Our waiter was unpleasant and the menu didn't really scream Italian food. Either way, we ordered the "carne cruda" which is essentially beef tartare. Approximately 17 min later my boyfriend is sick in the bathroom. Approximately one hour later I'm sick in the bathroom. This goes on for the next 12 hours. Either our waiter played a really bad joke or they don't know how to handle raw food. Either way, I give one star for my food poisoning experience and ruining my first trip to SF.
author: Tara L.

description:
Location:

Great! In Financial District of S.F. near the Embarcadero

Service:
Awesome! Made a mistake for booking a 5:45 PM reservation for dinner on a Sat and asked to change it to Fri, and host changed with no issues! Service staff was awesome

Food: 
Delicious! Two appetizers: The Beef Tartar and the grilled octopus, both recommended by the waitress.  Entrees: Gnocchi and Truffle Ravioli.  Both delicious and smaller portions can be ordered which is nice! Dessert: Strawberry shortcake and cappuccino.  Decent. The cappuccino wasn't hot enough we sent it back and they remade it with no issues.

Bottle of wine recommended by the Som was great too!

Price: For once...NOT SHOCKING. We expected higher but for the quality of food we were more than impressed.

Overall: GREAT DINNING experience and great food. The place was nice and upscale, a louder crowd but that's what you expect with Italian ;-)
author: Simon S.

description:
The girls and I had reservations for four of us one evening.  They seated us at a four top table at the main aisle near a column.  We had chosen a perfect restaurant to all get together.  Perbacco is upscale in decor, romantically lit but a loud atmosphere with a large space to accommodate a higher capacity of people.

We brought in a nice bottle of bubbly, and they chilled it for us.  The breadsticks with some dip was a nice touch but, they turned out to be stale.  Our waitress made up for it by bringing fat, warm, soft dinner rolls with our entrees later though.  She was also very patient, personable in dealing with us.  Sometimes when a bunch of us haven't seen each other in a few months, we get very chatty and lose focus on ordering!  I was able to get everyone in line to make up their minds though.  

We ordered a nice bottle of sav blanc for the table.  As an appetizer, we ordered the Fritto Misto of Shrimp under the recommendation of our waitress for sharing.  It was pretty good and interesting.  I never had green olives tempura style though.  It was a good choice for us though.

I ordered the duck breast with parsnips, radicchio and roasted pears.  It was quite the exquisite dish and a harmonious concoction of flavors.  It was nice to indulge in duck other than the typical Peking style I'm used to.  Two of my gf's ordered sea bass which I did a little quality control on and approved of!  My other friend had the Pappardelle which was wide pasta ribbons with some shortrib ragu.  Omg...  This was amazing, carbolicious pleasure!  Since, she was from out of town, I took hers home with the rest of my entree I didn't finish.

Halfway through the meal, we realized they forgot about our Veuve Clicquot.  They brought it out towards the end which was fine, but by then we couldn't finish or walk out of there overly tipsy!  

I'm not a fan of splitting the bill four ways unless you're armed with cash, but they did it for us.  Shame on me for not coming more prepared!

I would undoubtedly return.  We were a handful being so engrossed in our conversations to acknowledge staff sometimes.  Thanks for the excellence in service, with great attitude, friendliness and of course the unique, delicious Italian fare!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: To start this place is WAY overrated in me and my husbands opinion. We dined at the restaurant last night per a friends suggestion that it received almost 5 star reviews and a Zagat rating. We were greeted by a nice enough staff that showed us to our table; however when I asked the hostess if we could just sit one table from where we were she acted as though we asked for a VIP seat at the queens table! No biggie we took our booth at the corner of the restaurant. Next we were given menus, which were extremely difficult to read and understand and we're from the Wine country so we're definitely used to reading upper scale type menus. We were then assisted by our waiter, which took down our appetizer choices a beet salad for me and a beef tar tar for my husband. The beet salad was one of the worst I've ever tasted with shriveled up beets and a very dark and extremely bitter green which I have no idea what it was! I immediately decided I'm not eating this horrible bitter thing they're calling a salad and placed it in front of the table expecting our waiter to immediately notice it since he never even bothered asking how anything tasted after he dropped off the appetizers. However he didn't even notice and the water server who was more attentive to our needs replaced it with what they call their market green salad, which is not on the menu...why I have no idea! The waiter made it sound as though it was a big secret! My husband enjoyed the beef tar tar and I thought it was average. The water server then brought out the market salad, which I did think was very fresh with greens but much too lemony on the dressing. Then came the horrible entrees. I ordered the "famous" pappardelle pasta with short rib ragu and my husband ordered the veal chop. First the pappardelle was nothing like I've ever had. It hardly contained any pasta and the ragu was a sweet shredded beef more like a stew than a beef pasta sauce. My husbands vealchop was strange to stay the least with orange zest in the crust which was very overwhelming and made it taste just like Chinese lemon chicken at a mediocre Chinese restaurant...not at all what we expected from this highly rated and in our opinion over rated establishment. To add insult to injury we had an extremely inattentive waiter who only seemed interested in us when it came time to pay! Save your money and dine at Michael Mina close by or Tadich.
author: Tina A.

description: Absolutely amazing! For appetizers had the raw tuna and avocado salad and they were both the freshest and most delicious raw foods to want to begin with. The tuna was paired with a delicious sauce, avocado, oranges, and grapefruit which made it perfectly zesty and fresh. The avocado salad was delicious with various leaves that left a refreshing taste after each bite. For entre I had the paparadelle and scallops which were both made to perfection. Scallops were so tender and cooked just right and the pasta was hearty and delicious. Would definitely recommend and come again
author: J J.

description:
Absolutely lovely place.  Service is top notch, food is top notch and atmosphere is top notch.  From the minute you walk into the restaurant to the moment you leave, you are taken care of and and and they have deliciously prepared meals.  

Can't mess up going there with friends, co workers, customers or on a date!!
author: Susan P.

description:
meh food is decent but not sure what the fuss is about 
way overpriced and super small portions 
good dessert and atmosphere i guess
author: Rim E.

description:
Very nice romantic place. Ordered the Squid pasta, which I didn't like the noodle and not your usual ..pass. Flavor was lacking and hardly any sauce. However, tasted the Braised short rib ... Now that was awesome and flavorful. Cooked well. Had the pesce crudo , came with yellowfin tuna. I'll past, no flavor . 
Scallop wasn't too bad, probably won't order that again. I truly enjoyed the Foie gras.
