My only complaint was what the server said to me when a Bug flew into my drink. She said , it's only a fruit fly... Ohh Gheez  of course it was replaced, but honestly it should have been comped!!!
author: Nhung T.

description: Came here for appetizers with a friend.  Ordered pesce crudo and piastra roasted octopus.  Both were very well presented and very good!  The service was very attentive.  I'll definitely like to come back and try out the entrees.
author: dina d.

description:
I have come to San Francisco regularly for 5 years and never made it here, even though I had heard good things and walked by it and million times.  Great place.  

Decor is chic and stately.  The menu is not cheap, but I didn't expect it to be, even for lunch.  A good amount of choices, but I was fearing pastas were off the list of possibilities, because I try to be gluten free.  To my excitement, they offered fusilli gluten free pasta.  I had it with the lamb ragu and it was outstanding.  Some gluten free pastas are clearly a nice try at making a good tasting substitute.  This was great tasting and with pasta-like texture.

The service was also fantastic.  Attentive, professional, on top of it.  When you see people delivering food in suits (manager or owner, I assume), you know they care.  The place was packed by noon for lunch.  I can see why.
author: Marc F.

description: I come for the meatballs, Brussel sprouts and Nduja.  Always great.  Reservations and seating is always a struggle.
author: A S.

description: I've only dined here for work, but both lunch and dinner/drinks have gone well. This isn't the most memorable restaurant considering entrees here are like $30, so I probably wouldn't come back on my tab. Given the FiDi location and nice decor I do think it's a solid option for a convenient but still nice meal. Make a reservation!
author: Connie Q.

description: My favorite SF dining destination for years! Solid service every time. Love Italian wine so a big plus for me. On our visit on Monday we had a pasta and fritto misto at the bar. It was mid day and the staff was setting up for dinner service. Our bartender frequently checked back with us to refill drinks and ask about our food. The pasta was AMAZing! We will be back.
author: Angie S.

description: Everything was very good here no reason to complicate this .  We were all very happy, service was excellent as well .   I'm just a visitor but I'll be back to Perbacco every time I'm in town
author: William D.

description:
Go here if you want to get insulted or talked-down to. I would give them zero stars if that were possible. 

I feel compelled to write this review owing to the terrible treatment that was meted out to us at this restaurant yesterday night - 7th December 2016. 

I had booked this restaurant on a Tuesday after speaking to staff over the phone, and mentioned to them, that we are vegetarians and would appreciate if they could make some simple pasta dishes for us. 

I again called them on Wednesday, and mentioned our vegetarian preferences. On both conversations, staff told me that they would accommodate our preferences and make some simple pastas for us. 

We reached the restaurant at 9:45 PM, hungry and tired. We were expecting a simple meal at a so-called "Zagat" rated restaurant. Apparently that was too much to ask for. 

The manager came up to us, and told us we would have to eat from whatever was on the menu (there were hardly 2 dishes and a few vegetables on the side). I mentioned to him I spoke to their staff prior to coming there and they mentioned they would accommodate  us. 

He glared at us, and said that if we were coming to his restaurant, we would eat whatever they serve. They would not make anything special (BTW - All i asked for was a simple Aglio Olio - a pasta with Garlic & Olive Oil.) When I tried explaining that this was not what was his staff communicated to us, he simply said, "Well you should ask the right questions". 
Needless to say, we walked away from the restaurant without ordering anything. 

I do not know what gave the manager the right to treat us in this manner. Maybe he thought he could speak to us in anyway he wanted because their restaurant is "highly-rated". He should remember that restaurants go by word of mouth too, and they can lose their statuses as quickly as they gain them.
author: Veera B.

description: The hostess that sat us wasn't the nicest. The other one who is taller and at the podium was nicer. The waitress we had was not that attentive. We requested to see a menu and never received it. There must've been like 15 waiters and waitresses at the restaurant and we had one that was just okay. Frito misto fell short. Shrimp was too fishy and veggies were okay(not too crispy). The skirt steak was good and after a few more bites, it seemed gross. Restaurant tends to get very loud during busy hours and reservations are recommended.
author: Ann L.

description:
Let me start to say - I love Perbacco, and that is why writing this review is difficult to write.
I often bring work colleagues and clients for lunch to Perbacco - the food is consistently amazing and the service discrete but attentive.
I took 4 people for lunch today and had a wonderful lunch - at the end of the meal we all surprisingly decided to go for a glass of port. I ordered the table 4 glasses of Tawny Port 20 years old ($20 per glass), this took over 20 minutes to arrive at the table which was surprising as our table was next to the bar and we were one of the few tables still occupied in the restaurant. One of guests who loves port commented it was not a 20 year port but much younger - as I'm not a port expert I thought I'd ask to see the bottle to show my guest. I asked our waiter if he could bring us the bottle and some 20minutes later he appeared with an empty port bottle - a 20 year Tawny port. I asked why it took so long to reach over the bar and how come it was empty - there was no response. The bottle had been washed out so I could not show my guest that what we were drinking was really a Tawny 20, and the restaurant had no other bottles.........it all seemed very fishy and we all felt we had been served a sub-standard drink and not what we had ordered. 
This may all sound snobbish but at $20 a glass I think a wonderful restaurant of this caliber could have managed this situation far better...... I left with a $340 bill feeling like I'd been ripped off and taken advantage of. Will I return? Sadly I feel the spell of Perbacco has been broken......
UPDATE*******i received a call from the owner - a lovely gentleman - who explained the mix up with the port and very graciously apologized. I made a lunch reservation and took a client to Perbacco that week and was warmly greeted by the owner. We were also treated to a complimentary and delicious appetizer! The magic is back!
author: Nev S.

description: Have done lots of lunch meetings here and it is great if wait isn't too bad. The food is definitely good, with both indulgent and healthy options.
author: Alexander G.

description:
One of my favorites in San Fran.  Menu is changed up regularly.  Have never had a bad meal here.  Service is very attentive and knowledgeable.  Wine list is great.  

Dessert could use some improvement though!
author: Lori S.

description:
Perbacco is a lovely Italian restaurant with an atmosphere of quaint traditionalism - a no hipster zone. Between a party of three we had 2 appetizers, 3 entrees, a cocktail, 1/4 liter of white wine, dessert wine, coffee, and a dessert. The bill with tip came out to a very reasonable $200. Everything was plated beautifully and the portions were pretty spot on. 

1. Hamachi crudo with clementine, hearts of palm. Very sashimi-like, ultra fresh fish. 

2. Seared octopus with black chanterelles and broad beans. One of our favorites. Extremely fragrant and multi-dimensional dish with the varying textures of the octopus and silky beans. 

3. Barley pasta "rags" with veal suco and black chanterelles. Another favorite. I'm guessing their housemade pastas are all a standout and have that unmistakable "toothsome" fresh texture. Just a tad salty. 

4. Suckling pig with brussell sprouts, chestnut spaetzle, persimmon. This meaty dish had different cuts of pork - mostly pork belly. Need I say more?

5. Butternut squash cannelloni on top of a bed of vegetables and black chanterelles - probably the most unimpressive thing we ordered. It was good, but almost too simple. You literally were served two crepe-like cannelloni's with pureed butternut squash.  

6. Almond semi-freddo with chocolate, pomegranates. Beautiful dessert with lots of playful bits and fruity things scattered on the plate. 

Great service, lovely meal!
author: Amber M.

description: Excellent dining venue if business or pleasure takes you to the financial district in San Francisco. If you desire more intimate dining, request the mezzanine level. We were seated immediately upon arriving for our 6:45 reservation. Our server was Tamara and she was nothing short of exceptional in offering good wine pairings as well as guiding us through the menu selections. My wife ordered the gnocchi and I had the braised short rib. Both were exceptional with the gnocchi being light, almost fluffy and served in a beef ragu.  The reduction served on my braised rib was superb without being overly rich. The meat was tender and perfectly prepared. All in all, a great dining experience. We will return on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Harry S.

description:
This was my second time at Perbacco, and I was just as impressed as my first time. I arrived an hour or so earlier than my reservation, hoping that they would take my friend and me, but not expecting it. They had us seated within the next 20 minutes or so! 

Food: Incredible. It's an experience, not just calories you consume. The flavors, textures, and colors all complement each other. This food is definitely NOT something you can make at home. OH! THE TAGLIETTELE. get it. enough said. 

Service: Wonderful. Polite, respectful, timely.

This is great for a little date spot or a birthday dinner for a friend. Intimate.
author: Miriam F.

description:
It's about time I review Perbacco. Our sales team has eaten lunch here 6 times in the last 3 months. I'm the food guy on my team. I pick the restaurant and we go. The food here is fresh and they serve you fast. (we always eat at the counter unless our boss is with us)

The apps we've all eaten: Little Gem salad, Burrata cheese, Marinated beets, Fritto misto of shrimp, Seared local squid, Vitello tonnato.  All equally delicious. My personal favorites are the seared local squid, marinated beets. 

Several of my teammates are major red meat eaters and love the hangar steak and the pork meatballs, that's all they every order. It's hard to go wrong with rare hangar steak.  Two of the guys are big pasta/carb eaters and have eaten: COUJETTE, AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN and the TAJARIN. I think the Tajarin in particular should be a little more al dente. 

In short, in the last 3 months, we've ordered everything on the lunch menu except for sides: turnips, cauliflower and the carrots.

It helps that the restaurant is 2 blocks away from us and it caters to the business crowd during lunch.
author: Al G.

description:
I wasn't particularly blown away with this place. 

- The service was kinda weird: really slow at taking our orders, checking on our drinks, or getting us the check, etc, but their bus boys were hovering over us, waiting for us to take our last bites so that they could remove the plates. It was a little unnerving.

-The food had some delicious stuff, but it also had some m'eh things. I personally don't like really bitter citrusy things, so there were a few dishes that I couldn't eat at all. But, I realize that is a personal thing.
author: Dave R.

description:
This is my fourth time at Perbacco. I make it a priority to have lunch or dinner there when I come to town because it's just the best Italian restaurant in the city. Period. 

The fresh, homemade gnocchi was out of this world, as was the beet salad and green salad. The chef's use of unique ingredient combinations (in just the right proportions) are one of the things that make this place so special. it's not your average Italian restaurant. 

Get lots of small plates to share because you're going to want to try everything.
author: Mrs Cella S.

description:
This restaurant is really nice and classy. There's also plenty of tables and space inside, so the tables weren't squished together.

The food was pretty good, I ordered the risotto. Usually risotto tends to be a bit too salty for me, but this dish was the right amount of savory and I loved that it had truffle butter in it. My friend ordered the pasta with butternut squash and pomegranate, which I thought was very unique, and she really liked the dish.
I also liked that they can make most of the pasta dishes gluten-free. I'm not allergic to it but it's nice to have that option for those that are. The food's a bit pricey but given the area it's in, that's to be expected.

The service was great, our food came pretty quickly and our waitress knew the dishes and recommendations very well. The only aspect I wasn't into was that most of the people who ate here seemed to be in their late 40s or older. My friends and I are in our early 20s so we felt like we didn't exactly fit there, but the food and service was good!
author: Kailin H.

description:
Came here a couple days ago with a special someone and it's now on the top my "places to go in SF" list! We decided to come here instead of another more fancier and $$$$ place at our original 9:30 reservation time and it definitely was a good idea.

The meal itself was excellent: we started off with foie gras, Pappardelle, duck breast, and Brussel sprouts, and salted dark chocolate bone. I tried foie gras in the past and didn't really like it but I guess not all foie gras is equal! This restaurant's version was very savory and good. They had a slight acidic sauce with it that was a very nice compliment to the fatty dish. The pappardelle, duck breast, and salted dark chocolate dessert were all phenomenal and I really did savor every single bite. Not sure if some people came on a bad day or something but I seriously enjoyed every bite. The only dish I was disappointed in was the Brussels sprout dish. This restaurant's brussel sprout dish was very salty and burned so that was a big let down ...and a waste of brussel sprouts!!

But what made this experience a 5 star even with the less than stellar brussels sprout dish was the service. Our server (forgot his name) was just super pleasant and would give us great recommendations (on wine, menu choices). And usually, when customers order things servers don't stop them because larger orders = larger tips (since people calculate it %wise) but our server told us to order slowly one thing at a time and stopped us from ordering too much food. I guess some people would find that annoying or rude but I thought it was very nice of him to do, so +++. 

(Didn't pay so I don't have the prices...)
author: Sarah K.

description:
If you are looking for spaghetti & meatballs don't come here. That's in the north beach. Don't get me wrong, I like spaghetti & meatballs. 
Things to get: Salumi misti, Raviolo, Seared octopus, 
Dry aged duck breast, Hamachi crudo, and Parpadelle. You can't go wrong with those items. Throw back a Perbacco, allegesh beer, or hitachino beer and everything will be A - ok!
author: Dub C.

description: We had great service and exceptional food. The wine list was impressive, too. We were out for our anniversary. This was a nice spot to celebrate. It is family friendly (we don't have little ones so that could have been distracting, but wasn't with the well behaved kiddos near us) and it is fairly bright upstairs and lively. I wouldn't describe this to be an intimate, quiet, or cozy place but the food and service are top notch. I will be back. Richard, are server, was very knowledgeable and took great care of us. Thanks!
author: Sue L.

description:
I enjoyed this Restaurant. The Restaurant is on the pricey side but It was
Great. The Waiters and the Servers who provided our food definitely knew exactly
what was needed.

The foods appear to be more of the Northern Italian type. Why?  Not too
Much of the use of tomatoes.

The tuna salad with fava beans is very 
Tasty!
author: Alexander M.

description: Delicious food and great service with a classy ambience! We (group of 6) went for lunch on a Wednesday, the place was packed so good thing we had reservations. Tip: they charge a no show fee for reservations. We were served delicious breadsticks with pesto and super soft and flavorful foccacia with butter, yummy! For apps we ordered the roasted beet salad - oranges, grapefruit and beet in a special honey smoked yogurt and beet sauce along with the Salumi.  I ordered the Rabaton as an entree - was pretty good. I heard good things about the duck and risotto too. Only negative - not too many vegetarian options.
author: Reema B.

description:
Came in on a Friday night. I was actually meeting a friend next door but I mistakenly went to this place instead. 

Service: smooth as can be. The service here was exactly as good as one would expect entering an establishment like this. Polite, brief yet helpful and make you feel at ease. 

Food: delicious. 

Parking: you could get lucky. Metered street parking.

Price: San Francisco offers diverse cuisines and a variety of pricing. Id say the pricing fit the neighborhood.
author: Neek W.

description:
I brought my mom and husband here for Christmas Eve dinner.  I had been here before, had a great meal, and my mom enjoys Italian food so decided on this place.

Made OT reservations for 6PM so it wasn't too crowded yet that we were quickly seated as soon as we arrived.  Then while we sat down and ordered, the 2nd level became pretty full filled with a bunch of happy guests.  I noticed they have a private room on the second level with the view of the kitchen.  That's nice!

We started off with the small Salumi Misti plate.  As I raved about their pasta, my husband and I each had 1/2 order of two different types.  I realized now that I ended up eating the same one: Tajarin (Tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo, porcini mushrooms, and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese).  HAHAHAHAA!  So much for trying something new!  Still looked like Japanese ramen noodles, but the sauce was still good.  

My husband ordered the Tortelli di Aragosta (pasta filled with lobster and polenta), but they brought out the wrong dish so we had to send it back.  It took a few minutes to bring out the correct dish.  Those were shaped like mini wontons, but it was delicious with the cream sauce.  My husband enjoyed it very much.

For the main course, I had the Branzino (Mediterranean sea bass with matsutake mushrooms in dungeness crab jus).  Pretty big portion of fish, but I ended up eating it all.  Loved the nice clean flavors.  My husband had the Quail filled with chestnuts, braised chards, mushrooms in a huckleberry jus.  Good, but not great.  I would have preferred roasted quail instead of a stuffed one.  My mom had the Pappardelle with the short rib ragu.  It was a little lukewarm when she got it that we had them reheat it.  I had a taste and it was a definitely a meaty ragu, but I liked it.  

Overall, a great meal and decent service.  Only negative was the long wait for our main entrees, but it was Christmas Eve and we did notice servers take full plates back to the kitchen and many staff running around so it must have been a chaotic night for them.

We ended up taking a bottle of wine so we paid for the $20 corkage fee.  I was surprised when our server advised that they took off my husband's pasta dish due to the error they made.  We weren't expecting that, but that was a nice gesture on their part.
author: Erica S.

description: I came her for lunch I got the Pan-Seared Steak Hangar. It was delicious. The focaccia bread they serve you in the beginning is good too. I'm glad they only give you one piece and not the basket, I'd eat the whole thing! Definitely make a reservation for lunch they get very busy and the service is great and quick. We had reservations at 1145 AM and we're out by 12:30 PM, and we weren't rushed at all. Good spot.
author: Mal L.

description: Great service, good food, and a great ambiance. The staff is very courteous and helpful. We ordered the Carne Cruda which was amazing and Mozzarella Di Bufala which was good but not my favorite dish. If you are in the mood for something warm, I highly recommend the celery root soup. For our entrees we shared the Tajarin and Brasato and both of which were cooked to perfection. Brasato was my favorite dish. For dessert we had the kaffir lime leaf panna cotta which was a perfect balance between sweet and sour. We also had the burnt caramel gelato which was really good but a little on the sweet side for my taste. Overall, a great restaurant with amazing food!
author: Nini S.

description: Had a great business lunch. I had short rib stuffed tortelli.  Very good.  My only complaint is the stuff you in like sardines for tables of two.  After my meal I had to move the entire table to get out of my seat.  It was hard to have a private conversation in that atmosphere.
author: Mike B.

description:
The understated appetizers won us over compared to the less-than-luscious pastas.

The roasted octopus was the best dish we tried. The seemingly simple dish had a slightly smoky char that matched the delicate octopus. The crushed potatoes along with the shaved radish and celery leaves gave the plate a salad-like feel.

Another lovely salad-like starter combined seasonally fresh sweet peaches with large earthy slabs of grilled porcini mushrooms. The flavors were further enhanced by a thyme-tinged sauce and thick-leafed purslane. Although quite good as is, it might have been better with another element like sweetbreads.

Their signature dish, the tajarin pasta, didn't impress. The ramen-like tajarin noodles were too thin to hold the diced "salsiccia di bra" sausages and didn't want to absorb the sauce. Although full of rich ingredients like a pork sugo, the sauce wasn't luscious, but watery.

The "coujette" entrée had large and spongy gnocchi in a sauce of duck, cream, and onion. The menu said "foie gras butter" was in the dish, but there was no hint of foie - particularly when the sauce was thin and not rich.

The atmosphere was not as high-end as I expected with plenty of diners in jeans and sweatjackets. The restaurant seems to attract families with children (including the messy and screaming variety). The price wasn't outrageous either.
author: Brian U.

description:
Such a delightful experience! Perbacco seriously had the best pasta in San Francisco. 

Table cloth on the tables and romantic ambiance makes it a special place. 

You have to try their lamb pappardelle! Paired with 20 rows Cabernet, it tastes like heaven!
author: Yuliya B.

description:
I had come here once a few years ago on a company credit card and had a good impression of it, so was excited to try it again for a dinner date. However, I was pretty disappointed with the food and presentation overall.

We started out with the risotto as the appetizer. It was tasty, though rather lacking in presentation. Next I got the tagliatelle with the pork sugo and my bf got the duck breast. I was very disappointed in my pasta. Not only was the presentation pretty laughable (I suppose it's hard to dress up sugo, but the noodles were so thin they looked like ramen), but I found the sugo rather one-dimensional and couldn't taste any porcini mushrooms. And the duck breast, though a sizeable portion, was also rather bland (from the bite of my bf's that I had).

We ended our meal with the semifreddo dessert to share. Though there were many components to the dish, the portion was actually quite tiny, and I didn't think it was worth it for the price. ($10)

The servers were friendly and attentive (although they did give us another table's entrees by mistake), but overall I don't think the food here is worth the value.
author: Audrey G.

description:
Very good Italian. Relatively upscale setting. 

If you want a hip dinner, this isn't it. But if you want excellent Italian food with attentive service and a good cocktail list, this is a good option.
author: JM H.

description: Excellent and attentive service without being overwhelming. Food arrives out fairly quickly even for having a packed house. And their pasta lunch portions are extremely hearty! The only complaint is that their Coujette was a bit under seasoned.
author: Thao T.

description:
Ugh... absolutely awful! I've been to Perbacco several times, granted perhaps 7-9 years ago. I used to love it. Tonight, the service was deplorable, the food was horrible.... what a waste of one of two nights in SF.
I could give numerous examples of the low quality of the food and service, but quite honestly, I don't even want to give this place any more of my time. From start to finish it was just bad. Really bad. Sigh.
author: Shawna M.

description: This place was rather good. Portions are generous. We had the salumi, the pork chop, the truffle pasta, and the cauliflower. All of these were really delicious. The price was reasonable. The only negative thing I have to say was that they kept staying at us as we finished up, presumably to fill the table again.  The service and ambiance were both very satisfying. The meal came out to about 120 with two glasses of wine. Nor cheap but not amongst the expensive options in San Francisco.
author: Ming C.

description:
I could see Perbacco working well for a date, business lunch/dinner, or a night w/ the girlfriends like me. Just be aware that you might end up right next to a table full of bankers loudly saying "f*ck" every other word. Otherwise, it was a pleasant experience! Good service.

MUST-HAVES: Pork shoulder, Panna Cotta

* Free breadsticks & pesto - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#N7xbp6EedwBYIcAa-edZkw
Fantastic. Don't know how these little things can pack so much flavor, but they did. I only wish I could scoop more of that pesto dip w/ the breadsticks.

* Salumi Misti - 3 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#eixdC-amvYWxutfe1IOjGQ
(A selection of house cured salumi inspired by traditional piemontese recipes. $18/$28)
My friend wanted to get this. While the meats were good & there was tons of variety, I found this dish basically a way to stuff & bloat us so we couldn't enjoy the actual cooked entrees later. I also just noticed the immense price tag on this plate. There was also sourdough, breadsticks, & a preserve/jam that came w/ the meats. However, unless you are a cured meat fanatic &/or get some sort of immense pleasure out of it, I would probably skip this. Or at least go for the half portion.

* Roasted figs - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#eixdC-amvYWxutfe1IOjGQ
(w/ scidumin cheese, toasted hazelnuts, juniper cured lonza, white crane springs' greens. $13)
Really nice! Every ingredient was intense but it worked well. There was a cheese spread on the side (the texture was like hummus) - it looks innocent but is about 3x stronger than blue cheese. The greens were bitter, the figs fresh & sweet. But when you got it all in one bite, pretty close to perfection.

* Rabaton - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#5JemtEuuyFwJMI8eUnmtyA
Cross-section:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#zMdtKseG39sgLo41nhpI0A
(herb & spinach ricotta gnocchi, blu di langa fonduta, toasted hazelnuts. $13 half/ $18 whole)
My friends didn't like this, but I enjoyed it for being a unique gnocchi! The texture had a little more give than you'd expect, but was still soft. You can actually see pieces of the herb in each piece. The flavor of the white sauce was pretty strong, & it was very viscous. A pretty intense dish, but I liked it!

* Stracci - 3 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#AJqVXsFf24ratdhlRtheSA
(baladin beer pasta "rags", liberty farm duck ragu, brown butter apples. $14 half/ $19 whole)
I liked the texture of the curly thin pasta - soft, not too al dente which I don't usually prefer. However, I found the duck ragu to be too salty & thought it was just a big mass of ground meat in a thick sauce. Duck is so much better when you can feel the texture of the meat!

* Capicollo arrosto - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#AW1MZnxmW-tv-4lWVPDojQ
Cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#R-umuC7Neuw4uOsveGoKBw
(slow roasted pork shoulder, roasted corn polenta, baby turnips, charred shallots. $24)
Fantastic. The pork was super tender & hearty. They kept the green stalks on the turnips & it was incredibly fresh & crunchy. The polenta was fantastic, probably helped by the fact that it had whole kernels of corn. That instance of sweetness in the savory dish was always a nice surprise. 

* Fingerling potatoes - 2.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#ZLC3E-B9-uJS7RextappyQ
(pan roasted in lardo w/ rosemary & garlic. $5)
Not impressed, but probably because my friend requested it to be made vegetarian, ie. no pig fat =(. This was dry & the skin didn't have a good crunch.

* Panforte - 2 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#4N_XTtBVvTVoeDdPC-WZ7g
(spiced nut & dried fruit cake. $3)
The entire reason I went to this restaurant was b/c my friend kept raving on & on about an Italian bread pudding dessert. I showed her the dessert menu & she said it was the panforte. I blindly ordered this & she must've chosen the wrong one! It was pretty bad, very dense - I like dense but this was too much! Like hardened jam. Only one of us liked it, but even she couldn't finish the last tiny bite.

* Rose geranium panna cotta - 4.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ
(w/ raspberries, cocoa nib lime crumble. $9)
Props to our server for getting this order through, even though we were the last table at the restaurant & they were closing up the kitchen! This was fantastic, perfect soft texture, subtle flavors, plus the crumbles for added texture.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Perbacco is legit. And coming from a full-blooded Italian who cooks his own serious Italian food, that's saying something. 

We started with the Burrata salad, which unlike most that has just tomatoes also had white corn and toasted almonds. It was a wonderful blend of flavors and the cheese itself was perfect -- not too soft/runny or too firm. 

For entrees, my wife and I split two pastas. One was the herb and spinach ricotta gnocchi with wild mushrooms ragu and snap peas. It was as good as it sounds -- rich mushroom flavor and soft, decadent gnocchi. The other was a pappardelle with a short rib ragu. The meat was so tender and created an amazing gravy. 

For dessert, my wife got an aged cow's milk cheese - testun al Barolo, beppino occelli. She went crazy over it. I, however, opted for a nice dram of grappa. And it was really lovely. 

So the food was spectacular. The space was also cool, sort of elegant but not stuffy vibe. The service, though, was only average. Our waitress wasn't particularly attentive and it took some time to get our bread at the start. Though that made the experience slightly imperfect, the food was good enough that I can't not give this place 5 stars.
author: Dan I.

description:
Since I've become knocked up and Bridge and Tunnel, diners at these types of joints happen a lot less frequently then they used to. 

I pass Perbacco nearly everyday and it's been high on my list for a culinary splurge. Also recently saw it on Check Please where it received a very favorable review. 

The pricing is about what I expected and fair for the quality and level of service. I opted for the pappardelle with a side of Brussels sprouts. Both were brought out at the same time. My friend opted for the butternut squash ravioli with a side of sunchokes. Oh and the rolls with butter are amazing and worth every carb. 

We were both pleased with the pasta dish, but each of the veggie sides were severely overcooked. Mushy Brussels sprouts was a first for me and were void of flavor. We each barely ate half so I thought the server might question, but another of the staff took the dishes away without any question. When a couple of people are attending to the table, it makes it awkward to raise these types of issues. 

The strawberry themed dessert was amazing in presentation and taste. I'd like to return at some point and try some of the spring fare.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I can't get enough of SF and the food it has to offer. I'm glad I can add this place to my list! Went here for dinner with some friends. I love the ambiance and the overall decor of the place. It's very modern and clean. 

We started off with a large plate of cheese and meat. The salty meats were balanced out with the creaminess of each cheeses. The burrata cheese appetizer was very fresh and creamy. You can't go wrong with fresh burrata. 

I ordered the Tajarin and it was quite amazing. The pasta was very fresh and the sauce was very flavorful. The boyfriend was so hungry that he ordered TWO dishes! He ordered the pappardelle which was my second favorite dish. The meat melted in your mouth and the sauce was very bold. 

I will go back again to taste more of their dishes! So far this experience was A OK, mainly because the service that nice was not what I expected. There was a bit of a waiting game between us and the waitress and I asked for balsamic three times before getting it.
author: Angelie D.

description: Good meal, good service, quality of food was better than average.  Place was busy so things ran a little slow.  I'll go back.
author: Kris C.

description: The "Raviora" is to die for!!!  Wowowow.  Best pasta I've had next to Ortolana in New Zealand.  Glad I don't have to fly back there to satisfy my pasta cravings.  I love that Perbacco offers half-dish portions too - was able to try 2 dishes :) "Farfalle" was good, but not mindblowing like Raviora. Strawberry fields drink is yummy. Service was awesome/friendly/helpful!  Definitely going back. Like tomorrow.
author: Deanna T.

description: Great service, bad food, low value. I was really happy that they had a booth available for two for a last minute lunch at 1pm. I was equally impressed by the attentiveness of the wait staff who got my drink order before I even had a chance to look at the menu and his attentiveness throughout our meal, filling water glasses and bringing us more bread as soon as we scarfed down the first pieces. Our food came out really quickly but we were quite disappointed with the overall quality, preparation and flavor. The Tajarin (handcut thin tagliatelle, 5 hour pork and porcini mushroom sugo) was like ramen topped with dry sloppy joe meat and the Polpette (meatballs over mashed potatoes and raisins) was a little sweet with too much cinnamon. We only liked the Brussel Sprouts but funny enough both the sprouts (cooked with duck fat) and meatballs (served with marinara and no cinnamon) are way better at Barbacco where the service is not as good! The service at Perbacco is always great, whether lunch, dinner or after dinner drinks and desserts but I'm never wowed by their food anymore. My friends and I used to love their Papperdelle with meat cooked with horseradish but apparently it's not on the menu anymore. If you like mediocre food outstandingly served, topped off with a large bill at the end of your dining experience, go to Perbacco. They won't give you what you bargained for.
author: Jen L.

description: Amazing food and really great service. My husband made reservations for Valentine's Day dinner. We were seated right away (upstairs). Ambiance was good, the food was delectable (my husband had beef tartar and the John Dory Fish), I had the Burratta (best ever) and scallops in truffle butter. Our waitress was very attentive, recommended wines that were perfect pairings to our meal and was overall knowledgeable about the menu (explained it was built around tastes and cuisine from northern Italy). She was pleasant and helpful and our meals came out at good timing (thank you back of the house)! My husband, being a high caliber chef, is mostly critical about other people's food but was extremely pleased with his fish dish, he almost ordered another! We had a really good experience and highly recommend this restaurant.
author: GINA R.

description: Outstanding service and food. The wine selection was amazing and the Somm did a great job thinking of other choices. The pasta was fresh and the octopus rocked. Love this place!!!
author: Todd G.

description: I came here last night before a holiday concert at the Warfield and I'll definitely be back. Everything was amazing! My party of two arrived earlier than our reservation and we were sat immediately. From there, our waitress was attentive and quick the entire duration of the meal. The food was exquisite; everything sounded good, so I'll definitely have to return to try more. I know the menu changes daily, so I am excited to see what will be present when i return. I'll also try dessert next time. Definitely worth every penny and the portions are perfect.
author: Jae J.

description:
Perbacco is my go to place for business lunches.  When someone asks where I want to go for a business lunch, I say Perbacco, because it's 1/2 a block from my office at 101, and the pastas are consistently delicious.  My go to order is the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu.  Order that and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.  

When I have the appetite, I like to start (and share) the Fritto Misto (deep fried medly of shrimp, I think calamari, lemons, and string beans served with lemon aioli); or when I'm not pregnant, the salumi misti (selection of house cured meats).

But, I should give fair warning that the I have been disappointed with the meat entrees.  Once I had some steak at an alumni lunch.  It was under-seasoned and overcooked.  Another time, I decided to go out on a limb and step out of my comfort zone, so I ordered the pork and hazelnut meatballs.  They were not good.  The pork with hazelnut and roasted pear combo was weird.  I couldn't get into it, and abandoned the dish for the free focaccia.
author: Christina L.

description: I'm not a big Italian food fan, portions for the dinner size are more like an appetizer. Realistically for being one of the top rated Italian food destinations I felt like a fettuccini Alfredo from CPK or something would have been more just
author: Hov P.

description: So delicious, as always! I had the squid ink pasta, and it was absolutely divine. My friend said the same for her short ribs. Service, once our waiter appeared, was very good. This would have been an enthusiastic 5-star review if based solely on our dinner and our waiter. But the disorganization at the front desk before we were finally acknowledged and seated, and the fact that we waited 15 minutes at our table until I flagged a woman who was standing not five feet away from us talking with another staff member while ignoring us, detracted from our overall experience.
author: E. G.

description: Great Italian food. Nice atmosphere. Not too expensive. Great date spot. Pretty easy to get a reservation. Order the raviola.
author: Kelli L.

description:
Servers were really friendly, but other than that, nothing to write home about.

The squid ink cavatelli looked like black larvae and was tasteless. It definitely put me off. It helped that the restaurant is dark, but when I'm just filling up on bread for dinner to avoid my pasta, that's bad news.

The pesto that comes with the bread was delicious though.
author: Diane Z.

description:
Came here today with my sis and my cousin for one of our gabathon lunches.  I asked if we could sit upstairs, since it's slightly quieter, and they were quick to accommodate us.  I hadn't been here for several years, like Rene C. and was pleased that I'd come back.  We had come once for an anniversary dinner not that long after they opened and liked it.  I saw more men (and women for that matter) in suits here today than anywhere else for years, but decided not to hold it against them.

First the service was just perfect!  Our server totally got us from the start, seemed to know that while we're food lovers, we were also there with a big talking agenda.  She paced things perfectly, didn't rush us, but didn't ignore us either.  I wish I'd gotten her name, so I could give her credit.

I was most intrigued by the appetizers, although there was a smattering in the soup/pasta category that looked good, as did several in the entree section.  I just wasn't up for a full entree course.  One appetizer didn't seem like enough, and two seemed like too many, so I worked out a deal with my sis to share one, and then we each ordered another.

One order of the beet salad:  Lovely to look at with micro beet greens.  The roots were impeccable, the preparation was a little boring though.  It would have benefitted from something with a tart note.  There were two tiny roasted onions; more would definitely been better.  The three of us all ate this one.

Two of us got an order of the frito misto.  It included rock shrimp, fennel, green beans, onions, lemon slices, and OLIVES.  Who wouldn't like a deep fried olive.  The server had said there anchovies, and try as I might, I never could locate one of those much coveted little guys.  It came with an uninspired aoli type dip on the side.  The portion was big for an appetizer, and if you weren't making it a main course, as we were, it would definitely cry out to be shared.

One order of butternut squash ravioli with a brown butter sauce with pomegranite seeds strewn on top.  It looked lovely and the pasta part of it had a lovely texture.  There was something in the brown butter that kind of over exerted itself - sage maybe.  As I've said before, I'm not a big fan of the baked squashes, and this was no exception.  It was too sweet for me, but those who like that sort of stuff said it was good.

We shared something that I think was called a tarrone for dessert.  Dense dark chocolate with dried apricots and nuts inside.  I liked its rustic quality and the deep chocolaty quality was further emphasized by a chocolate sauce on top.  I probably wouldn't order it again, but the two chocoholics with me seemed to be in heaven.

The bill including 3 coffees and tax, before tip was $73 - very reasonable!

Food:  36/40
service:  20/20
atmosphere/ intangibles:  17/20
value:  18/20
91/100= A=5 stars, just barely

Frankly, I'm surprised.  If I hadn't used my rating system and just guessed, I think I would have given 4 stars, but given that would I ever give any 5's?

I don't, however like the bathroom arrangement, down two flights into the basement and unisex.  Sorry, I believe there are times where we should be segregated by chromasomal arrangement.
author: Diane B.

description:
I was thinking about the seafood place next to it but there was a very long queue there so we chose this one...it s also popular and therefore crowed....
The food was not bad...maybe slightly greasy n salty for me...
service was not bad. I wish the seating area could be more spacial...
author: Safina Z.

description:
One of my favorite spots in San Francisco!
Food is so amazing, everything on the menu, and I mean everything is beyond delicious!!! Staff is very attentive and genuine!! Wine list is fabulous!! This place is a guaranteed time well spend!! You will want to be back, because the dinning experience will be as memorable!
Good for any occasion, lively cozy atmosphere, classy yet modern!! 
Go try it out!! 5 stars!! Cheers!!
author: Iryna R.

description:
What a pleasant li'l find this was nearly 2 months ago, close to the Embarcadero in the Financial District. We didn't have reservations, but my group of 3 were still seated quickly on the 2nd level. I primarily remember three things, all good:

1) I ordered the Tonnarelli Neri, which was their hand-rolled ink pasta with octopus and prawn Ragu. Perfect amount of spice to it, and the octopus was decently prepared. Love squid ink pasta already!

2) Good wine conversation with friends over dinner. 'Nuff said.

3) Our waitress, who was already fantastic, had a particularly short and interesting hairstyle. We asked her about it, and if I recall correctly, she had actually just donated her formerly long locks to help people affected by cancer. Awesome!
author: Garett T.

description: I recently hosted a family party in the Barolo room, and it did not disappoint.  the team was easy to work with in setting up the event and the food and service were both high quality.  prices are high but so is everything in San Francisco so bring your wallet.
author: Bob D.

description:
I've always loved Barbacco, and for whatever reason, I never made it to Perbacco until now.  It's kind of a more formal version of its sister restaurant, but the pasta prices aren't significantly more. 

They have a liquor license, but none of the cocktails stood out to me, and I thought wine better matched the meal.  They had many glasses by the glass with a good number of Italian wines.  I thought the glasses were a bit expensive.

Starters: 
1. Pan seared foie gras: with classic accompaniments of brioche (a toasted rectangle) and a cherry compote
2. Heirloom tomatoes: the tomatoes are in season, but the peach compote with the saltiness of the ricotta salata were awesome together. I used the house bread to soak up the rest of the sauce at the bottom 
3. House bread: free upon request; good flavor, reminded me of the acme baguette in flavor

Pastas: the 3 of us ended up doing 2 regular sized pastas and 2 appetizer sized pastas.
1. Gemelli: squid ink pasta with an octopus and shellfish ragu (shrimp, clams, mussels all out of the shells).  This was probably the lightest of the 3 pastas in terms of fattiness, and it was a good seafood option
2. Papparadelle: rich, super flavorful slow cooked short rib ragu, which wasn't overly fatty.  The grated horseradish was a really nice contrast.  This dish had tons of flavors going on 
3. Tajarin: I don't usually love thin pastas, but this one was so fresh and had tons of flavor with the porcini mushrooms and pork sugo.  It may have actually been my favorite 
4. Coujette: potato gnocchi (the pillowy soft kind but larger than usual) with a duck ragu and foie gras butter. Needless to say, this one was the heaviest one, so the light nature of the pasta helped. It was a bit rich for me, but it was one of the more interesting gnocchi dishes I've had in a while

Side:
1. Sugar snap peas: with pea tendrils and a minted pea sauce.  The snap peas were a bit oily, and I couldn't taste much of the pesto.  I would probably skip this one. We felt compelled to get a vegetable to counter the pastas..

Dessert: 
1. Citrus mint panna cotta: super smooth, very refreshing.  The mini white donut peaches and blackberries were super sweet, and the peach sorbet was a nice contrast to the panna cotta itself.  This was a really impressive summer dessert. We all thought we were full, but we had no problem finishing it in minutes 
2. Chocolates: for the table at the end (complimentary)

The bill ended up being less than we had expected since we mostly went for pastas.  If it were up to me, I would do just pasta and nothing else (fresh pasta is a weakness of mine). The server was very helpful when we were trying to portion everything out.

Between the two, I would say I probably still like Barbacco more, but Perbacco is a different experience and is worth trying.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
I've been here a few times and the service is always great.

the food is pretty good, but a number of their dishes are usually a bit under-seasoned. Ordered their braised short rib and it was real tender, but didn't have a lot of flavor... marrow nochi was ok.

ordered their hamachi crudo and the portion was super small.

Their seafood stew is pretty good, but had too many potatoes and not enough seafood.
author: Webbster G.

description:
Great place for lunch in the Financial District with pretty reasonable prices.

They bring breadsticks and some type of green olive oil (pesto?) mix and then fresh bread and butter afterwards.

Ordered the flank steak and it was pretty good! Came with a very tiny small salad and some large buttery croutons.

Also tried a little bit of the seafood stew and that was good as well.

Good service and food came out very quickly for it being noon!
author: Yas G.

description:
Been here a few times for dinner and every time a great experience! 

Salumi plate and pastas!!! Delicious wine selection also!!

Salumi plate has a good variety of cured meats and my fiancé loves their their sheets of fat (yea, sounds nasty, but the plate comes with a couple pieces and he'll wrap it around the breadstick and enjoy it like a lard popsicle... I can see why he likes it... For those who like fatty smokey tastes of cured meats). I particularly like their pastas very much because they remind me of those I had in Italy, very fresh, tasty and I believe they are house made! Yum! Also, their menu changes so it's great to try something new each time. 

For sure a restaurant that I would recommend for dates and groups!
author: Iris H.

description:
I was a bit overwhelmed. I just yelped something for pasta, I didn't read any reviews and chose to home here. 

I felt a little underdressed with fishnet leggings and a sweater, everyone else was all fancy and business like around us. Oops!

It looks small from the entrance, but once we got in pass the bar, wowzers, was this place nice. I mean really nice! Large flower case for center piece and everything!

We sat down and honest to goodness I've never been asked "is house water okay?" But they sure did-- and I just said "yup"

The menu was a daily printer one-- and one my friend and I giggled about, we couldn't pronounce the name of the dishes! You know you've gone up a notch in everyday pasta eating when you realize there's a bunch more one has never experienced. 

Breadsticks were brought out with what appears to be pesto sauce? Extra crunchy, extra hard. Maybe the little Italian places I've been to spoiled us with the soft chewy kind?

Keith, when he took our orders was cool about it-- he said as long as you day the name, he'll know what we want, no matter how we say it incorrectly. 

Order was taken, bread and butter was brought is to us. No kidding on the brought out part. They place one bread on your little plate and butter in the center-- when you're out of bread, they'll walk by to ask of you'd like another. Double wowzers. 

Meal came -- my friends Tarjarin looked like ramen served with chilli-- also tasted like chilli, had a bite and was underwhelmed. 

Although my dish, Plin Al Brasato, was just stuffed agnolotti :similar to a ravioli: it was yum. Black butter truffle and red wine ristretto for sauce. Didn't go wrong with my choice!!

Portions are small for $20-- but one shouldn't be eating a large portion of pastas anyway :)
author: Dany B.

description:
Good Italian restaurant with a vibe that crosses between classy and homey- the perfect place to celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, etc. 

Tried a variety of dishes- beef, pasta, all delicious. Came with a group of people and same reviews across the board. Don't forgot to leave room for dessert. 

A bit of a tip though, try to make a reservation because the wait does get long!
author: Patricia K.

description: I've been here three times in the past year and this is now one of my favorite Italian places in SF. We came for my husband's birthday and we really enjoyed it. The service, atmosphere, and food were excellent. And then more recently, we had a small private party here. From the time I reached out to Stephen to arrange the party, to when we said goodbye to the staff that night when we left, the experience was excellent. They helped us arrange flowers, set up the cake, and any other request we had asked for that night. Our guests were all impressed with the restaurant, service, and food. I'm still dreaming of the house made pasta and can't wait to come back.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Excellent Menu for all foodies including vegan/vegetarians!  The marinated baby beets amazing....Pasta's amazing...  Wine list amazing. Great atmosphere overall. It can be a little noisy at times due to the layout (reserve a table near the back corner if privacy is needed)... but enjoyable all round.  Top notch excellent service. 

The owners are hands on and are very passionate about their clients.
author: S C.

description: Once again, Perbacco does a beautiful job. You can't go wrong by starting with a glass of their very find Prosecco. Members of my party had the quail the short ribs and I had the scallops. All were more than perfectly prepared very tasty and very fresh. Since we were on a budget that evening we chose to drink wines by the glass. They have a great selection of both domestic and Italian. Even though we went to the prime time and they were very busy service was still up to par. Without a doubt still one of my favorite Italian restaurants in all of San Francisco. Enjoy!
author: John H.

description: Great wine list and classic menu. Disappointed with service - a waiter told me to "get the hell out" at the end of my firm's holiday party this past Monday. Not sure why he addressed only me and not the rest of the group or why his tone was so rude when I was merely standing there. Pretty shocked at the moment, but I didn't want to spoil my team's night by pointing it out.  Never had bad service here before, maybe this was a one off thing. Not sure.
author: Lera D.

description: Sat down order a bottle of Swanson Merlot had one sip ordered dinner was out in 5 minutes. Never had a chance to even finish a glass before our dinner came out. Felt my husband and I were rushed.
author: Teresa V.

description:
Very happy.  We don't get upscale Italian very often down here in the 'burbs so I grabbed a res here for dinner on a quick trip out of town.

Vitello tonnato -- One of the better renditions of this I've had.  Everything was seasoned properly and balanced (I've had this at other places with bland veal or overly tuna-y sauce).  Want more. 

Risotto with duck and orange -- Husband ordered this, it was quite good.  Citrus and duck is a thing, but citrus and duck and pancetta and a perfect, oozy risotto is a very interesting tasty thing.  This kind of stuff is the reason we go to restaurants.  Quite pleased.

Stracci (spinach pasta with rabbit sugo) -- I love wide flat pastas and this did not disappoint.  Very light sauce with ground rabbit and some meatier chunks.  

Whoever posted the pic of multiple pastas in a tasting arrangement -- they wouldn't let me do that. Woe.  (I wanted to try at least four of the pastas.)

If the dessert had knocked it out of the park it would have been five stars, but we didn't really like the puffed rice with spiced chocolate mousse.  The puffed rice was too...cereal-y.  Maybe that sounds silly.  JMO.  

Overall: I would certainly go to there again.
author: Michaela L.

description: The place was definitely fancy, not gonna argue with that. The service was excellent. The staff was very attentive. The food was kinda disappointing. I ordered Tajarin which was basically a thin tagliatelle noodles with pork. The pork tasted alright and it left some weird aftertaste in my mouth afterwards. Visually, it didn't look appealing to me. The noodles had some cheese added to it which made it even more overwhelming.
author: Lilly C.

description: We got the mozzarella app.  It was decent, but nothing special.  I had the pork and pasta for my entree.  It was fine, but nothing worth going back for.  It tasted like pot roast.  My gf ordered the ravioli which was just ok.  The strawberry sorbet was the highlight of the night.  The service was decent as well.  For these prices, I expect more.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Please consider this review to be 3 1/2 stars--just wasn't an option.

So, nice waitstaff, very good herb-olive oil dip with the breadsticks, and total and ongoing neglect about refilling water glasses.  I have a feeling that the waitstaff is overextended.

-tasty but un-ample, beet salad--I had two slivers of beets in mine. 

-husband's pork chop was very (!) good, perfectly done

-side of Brussels sprouts was tasteless and uninspired.  The ones I made tonight, in my home, with a parsley-lemon-shallot dressing, with a few shelled and roasted pistachios, atop, was way more imaginative and tasty

-beef ragu atop pasta was very tasty but too salty

-the herb-ricotta cheese gnocchi were good, not great

-I liked my lemon drop cocktail

-bread was good, but, like their precious truffles being brought out in a locked box in our periphery, getting a roll was like asking for the security codes for a nuclear attack.  Wasn't happening.  

Salted caramel ice cream was good; the peppery cookie that came with was purely bad.  I asked for the burnt sugar cookie instead, that was really a shortbread cookie masquerading as something fancy, and it was very good.  

I guess I just want to feel that if I am eating out and paying fifty dollars+-person, I want the cooking to be as good as, and, ideally, better than my own.

No shortage of self-curating and image-conscious patrons in my periphery, so that initially made for some fun people-watching. 

The bathroom, downstairs, feels a little tawdry and old, and I kept waiting to be approached to buy drugs.
author: J J.

description:
Delicious lunch here! Beet salad, gnocchi, and risotto were all delicious. Service was really wonderful too. Love the focaccia basket that comes around the dining room. Wish it was served with olive oil instead of butter though.

When we sat down, it was really hard to decide what to eat b/c every.single.thing looked delicious. I want to come back and try some of the pasta dishes and entrees. 

It's definitely a nice place for a business lunch. On the pricey side but worth it for the ingredients and service.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Came here once before for lunch but I was unimpressed with the slow service. 

Came again for dinner just for the white truffle menu.  This time service was a lot better, perhaps because I was one of the early dinners at 5:30pm. and business hadn't picked up yet.

Ordered the beef tartare, barrata salad, risotto with white truffle and tajarin with white truffle.  Both the appetizers were excellent.  In fact, the beef tartare was the best I had of all the ones I'd tried.    

The risotto was lacking in flavor, although the white truffle was supposed to enhanced the dish but it didn't since the 3 grams of shaved truffles just wasn't enough for such a large plate of rice.

On the other hand, the tajarin with prosciutto and hen egg and white truffles was delicious.  This is the dish to get.

You can see how much of 3 grams of white truffles you will get from my picture.
author: Shirley H.

description: Came here yesterday for lunch knew it was going to be good. A lot of people talk about this place and it is listed on a lot of SF restaurant lists. I got the potato gnocchi and really liked it. Someone else at the table go the pappardelle with short rib and it looked and smelled amazing! and they wouldn't stop talking about it so I am definitely getting the pappardelle next time. Also make sure to get the burrata cheese app. It was gone within a second and we had to order a second one! Service and all that was great as well, but that cheese tho!
author: Thielson D.

description:
Loved our experience at Perbacco. I rarely give 5 stars and in this case (although the food was also very good) it was because of the excellent, attentive and friendly service. When something was needed, staff was available. When we wanted additional sides after the main courses were served, they quickly accommodated us. The sommelier was available for recommendation, which I found necessary because the wine "book" was extensive, with too many choices. We had seating upstairs and they fortunately have an elevator in addition to stairs, for the less-abled.

The dish I enjoyed the most was the agnolotti dal plin (small filled pastas in a delicious brown gravy), which I ordered as an entree size, to share with the table (you can order the pastas 2nd course size, which is smaller, or entree size). They were thoughtful to split the serving into two plates, so it was easier to share. Frankly, I could have eaten the whole thing myself (yum!), but I did want others to try it. The papardelle (with short rib ragu sauce) was excellent. I had the crepes (butternut squash, I think) which was very good (finger-licking), creamy and flavorful. Most of our table ordered the duck breast entree, which is not my cup of tea, so I cannot comment on how it tasted, but everyone cleaned their plates completely! Also loved the Brussels sprouts.
author: Shan H.

description:
FANTASTIC place - there are so many great Italian restaurants in the city and this is certainly one of the best. I walk past Perbacco almost every day for work and I'm so glad I finally stopped in for dinner! 

This place has truly elicious food and is a lot more welcoming/un-stuffy than you would think. The ambiance was definitely on the more formal side, but there was a nice mix of couples/families/and small groups of friends. The Rabaton (ricottta gnocci with mushrooms) was delicious- incredibly light and flavorful. Our waiter was incredibly attentive without being overbearing or hovering. 

A note on the portions: I avoided getting the smaller pasta portion for fear that it wouldn't be enough, and the larger size ended up being far too much food.
author: Hailey H.

description:
As we were being lead through the simple but nicely decorated restaurant to our table, my husband told Adelino (sp?) that we were celebrating our anniversary.  Adelino congratulated us and said he wanted to check if he can get us a corner booth.  Unfortunately the booths were already reserved but it was really nice of him to offer.  Our server Tamara was just as friendly.

*Salumi Misti - delicious
*Marinated Hearts of Palm & Cardoon Salad - refreshing
*Risotto with Truffled Scallop Boudin - AMAZING
*Capicollo Arrosto - delicious, cuts like butter
*Beef Short Rib Stracotto - amazing, so tender no knife needed
*Burnt Caramel Gelato - AMAZING, love the Tahitian Vanilla Sea Salt
*Warm Brown Butter Pistachio Cake - AMAZING

The desserts alone are reason enough to dine here.
author: Rose A.

description:
My birthday dinner choice when I went up to SF for my birthday weekend.
My friend made the reservations here, they do require a credit card to hold a dinner reservation here, I want to say this is their requirement if its more than a party of 4.

Got there on time a little earlier than our 8:30pm reservation and we got seated in less than 10 minutes. We were seated on the 2nd floor, which felt really nice and "personalized" for our group. Only disappointment was a table away from us, that decided to bring a little kid to dinner, and the parents wouldn't quiet the kid down. Good thing, they were ending their dinner soon. There was a private event going on, also on the 2nd floor, yet they didn't disturb us.

We had a great and attentive server assigned to us...her name was Alexandra. She was very sweet, personable, knowledgeable and even treated our table to an additional dessert, since she knew that my friend and I were indecisive between 2 desserts. Alexandra thought it would be a nice surprise to serve both desserts, especially because it was my birthday. She gave the best description, when we asked her about a certain entree on the menu.

The hostess needed to be less snobby, and more friendly. I mean come on... I have received friendlier service in Beverly Hills.....smile and ask how we are doing! :)

They do change their menu from time to time. 
For appetizer I got this mushroom type soup, which was a delish grown up version of a cream of mushroom.
Main entree was a pork loin. I tried their wild salmon, pappardelle and gnocchi, which is also delish.
My friend got the butternut squash cannelloni and she wasn't quite happy with it. The texture was a little bit weird for me and my friend was right that it would be better off as a ravioli type of dish. My friend was offered another dish since she barely touched her dish, but she graciously declined the thoughtful offer, and went on eating our friend's pappardelle.
author: Abby C.

description:
Why You Should Check Out Perbacco:

1)  It is Italian mom approved (according to our Italian friend). 

2)  You will be ushered into an elegant, large, bustling, and VERY LOUD dining room with brick walls and horizontal mirrors.  

3)  If it is your birthday, you will be thoughtfully greeted by a handwritten birthday card. 

4)  Flawless service.

Your server will enthusiastically and sincerely wish you a happy birthday and the bussers will ask you if you are done before taking away plates promptly.

5)  You will have complimentary breadsticks, pesto, bread, and a really fantastic bit of butter.

6)  You will have an ample selection of cocktails and wine.  

I ordered the Fior d'Arancio which was a processo cocktail that basically tasted like a mimosa ($10).  J had a class of Pinot Noir which he enjoyed ($14).

7)  Fantastic Appetizers.

My favorite dish of the night was the freshly made Burrata Cheese.  It was atop a pile of basil sprinkled marinated cherry tomatoes and slices of ripe nectarines.  Summer in a bowl! ($14)

The Hamachi Appetizer was fresh and elegantly plated.  While I liked the kumquat, fennel, and olive oil drizzled on top, the salty and briny black olives overpowered the fish ($14).

8)  Pastas that are as good as they say!

I ordered two half portions as an entree.  Of the two, I preferred the pillowy soft Potato Gnocchi, with a rather salty Liberty Farm Duck Ragu, and some sliced cherries ($13).  

I also tried the Agnolotti filled with Porcini Mushrooms.  Although I liked the huge mushroom flavor of the Agnolotti itself, I didn't care for its cream sauce and toppings.  While the addition of blueberries and douglas fir needles on top was definitely creative, it didn't meld for me and I felt like I was nibbling on a Christmas tree ($12).  

J loves rabbit so he tried and devoured the Spinach Pasta "Rags" with Devil's Gulch Rabbit Ragu ($13).  

9)  Entrees

If you aren't a Carbivore like me, there are plenty of Entree options.  J tried the Wolfe Ranch Quail with roasted chanterelles and cipolline onions which he enjoyed ($27).

10)  Elegant Desserts

They surprised us with Brutti Ma Buoni Cookies on a plate with "Happy Birthday" prettily written in chocolate.  Although they are supposedly "ugly but good," these hazelnut filled cookies made of sugary sweet meringue were actually were not ugly at all!  

We also tried a Goat Cheese Mousse ($9) and a Chocolate Tasting ($10) but honestly I was too full to fully appreciate them. 

Grazie Perbacco!



AT38
author: Amy C.

description:
Fantastic meal here.

Pesto opener with bread--- yum.

Appetizer: Turjin (a pasta with a slow cooked meat sauce)---orgasmic.

Entrees: Short ribs and braised beef--melt in your mouth
               Quail stuffed with mortadella--very interesting and nice taste complements. Big portion

Side: Brussel Sprouts--good, but not shockingly delicious or unique

Bottle of Wine check
author: Stella H.

description:
I'm more of a mom and pop type of restaurant girl but we went here last night for the bf's holiday party. It was a set menu of farmer's salad, choice of scallops or filet mignon, or gnocchi as the main. Dessert was butter bread. I got the scallop which was nicely cooked. I like this place because they did accomodate to some requests such as no cheese on the dressing and then gave me muchrooms as well. I asked for no almonds so they actually gave me a different dessert too. It was a gelato type dessert but was soft by the time it got to us so didn't love that at all. It was also overly sweet. 

I mean nice restaurant and classy - really 3.5 but its nothing super special.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: This place had excellent service but the food was meh... Not worth the price. One pasta dish we ordered tasted like instant ramen noodles. Will not be dining here again after spending over $250 for dinner.
author: Barbara F.

description:
Sat at the open bar for lunch. 
Wine by the glass will cost between $11-$16...ouch
I immediately realized lunch will NOT be inexpensive. Had the housemade braised short rib Agnolotti pasta in a red wine, black truffle reduction. Pasta was light and extremely fresh. The flavor and aroma of truffle was divine. The short rib meat was puréed, which reminded me of baby food, but overall the dish was delicious. Two glasses of wine and pasta was $54.00
Double ouch
Will try them for dinner sometime down the road
author: LisaLisa F.

description: Very unique Italian food. I'd say modern Italian. Everything was delicious. Cocktails are good but very small. Service is great we had a very knowledgable waiter. Manager/host guy was very stuck up and rude. But the hostess was nice. There was a bit of awkwardness between the two upon arrival.
author: Suzanne R.

description: recently had a work lunch here - the service was quick and efficient and the food was great, better make a reservation... it was super packed for that lunch rush... but the guys in front of us didn't have a reservation and they were told the bar is first come first serve - so if you don't have a reservation, the bar is always a good option. i enjoyed the dessert too! I am not dessert fan but that olive oil gelato hit the spot.
author: Royce S.

description: We were a group of ten with attentive, discreet service.  The waitress was extremely helpful with quiet suggestions when I asked on how to round out the ordered dishes with sides.  The food was all absolutely delicious!  I was so pleased to see everyone order the gormet  desserts.  The raspberry cheesecake was so fun to eat, tasting all the added bits on display along the dish.  We were told not to rush, to enjoy ourselves and take our time. We were celebrating a university graduation with friends and family. The menu states a gratuity may be added for large groups.  Our bill did not include this so we made sure we left a tip to reflect the superb service.
author: janet s.

description:
Quite simply, the best pasta I have ever had in the US.  I have been to this place 5-6 times over the last three years, and it just keeps getting better and better.  First, the service is wonderful.  I always come to SF on business and generally eat alone, so I sit at the bar and order from the regular menu.  The bartenders at Perbacco are great people and know their food, wine and cocktails extremely well.  

And oh, the food, the food.  If you are lucky enough to eat at Perbacco while heirloom tomatoes are in season, ORDER THEM.  I have never had such wonderful varieties anywhere, and they will not serve a tomato unless it is at its ripe peak.  The basil, ricotta salata, olive oil and whatever other wonderful goodness they sneak onto the plate is all wonderful.  Their vitello tonnato starter is also a revelation - juicy, rosy and thin slices of roasted veal slathered with a tuna-anchovy mayonnaise.  You must try it. 

Their pastas are the true star here, and frankly I have never ordered an entree as the pastas are just that sensational.  The tajarin with the 5-hour pork sugo, the ravioli filled with braised short ribs and porcini mushrooms and the recently added agnolotti filled with slow cooked pork and hazelnuts in a plum jus are each unique and memorable.  The gnocchi with the gorgonzola fonduta sounds heavy but isn't - the gnocchi are light as a feather and melt on the tongue.  The fillings and sauces here are not only perfect, but the pasta itself is a wonder.  Filled pastas sometimes have great flavor but the pasta turns out gummy - not here.  The pasta itself is always toothsome, light, perfectly cooked and delicious in its own right.

They have a very nice selection of reds by the glass.  The 2008 Langhe Nebbiolo is superb with any of the pastas mentioned above.  

The only dessert I have ever had here is the brown butter cake with pistachios.  In a word - YUM.  I hope to return here again and again for years to come.  It is always a terrific experience.  These people love to provide wonderful food and service - an art form.
author: Steven H.

description: Great place. The atmosphere is very nice. It's a fine dining restaurant. We loved the food and we will definitely go back. They have a Moscato to die for. Check out the deserts, yum!!:)
author: Ruxandra I.

description: I was so excited to try this restaurant as I had heard such great things, but once we got there, we were horribly disappointed and offended.  The front of the house refused to accommodate us even though we had a reservation because my boyfriend had his service dog with him.  The older gentleman at the front of the restaurant told me he didn't have to serve us because of the service dog even though we had his ID card with us.  We asked to speak with a manager, but this man claimed that he was it.  We have eaten in the top restaurants in SF, Chicago, NY, and Miami with the my boyfriend's service dog, and this is the first and only restaurant that has refused to accommodate us.  I informed the man that what he was doing was a violation of the ADA and discrimination.  He did not seem to care.  All he answered was, I don't have to serve you!  I had tried to be very polite, all to no avail.  We ended up leaving embarrassed, hurt, and hungry.  Thankfully, Pabu, which is across the street,accommodated us with zero issues and we had a delicious meal.
author: Carly K.

description:
Perbacco is perfectly fine, but there are far better choices.  

Upon entering, there is very limited space to check in and wait for a table. You are crunched up against others waiting with people waiting and those at the bar. 

The decor is nice, yet bland. Dull. The highlight is a smart strip of mirrors that allow those facing the wall to seemingly look across the room. Nice touch. 

Service was fantastic. Our server knew the menu well, made great recommendations, was attentive but not intrusive. Five stars for her.  

We found the food to be very good but equally unexceptional. Nothing to write about.  Had we ordered the $65 truffle menu items, perhaps we would have been amazed.  

Prices are typical SF yet on the high side. My glass of wine was $18 or $20 and quite delicious. A quick check on my app showed a bottle at $28 retail. Ouch. Entrees are overpriced at around $28-30. 

Restrooms are near a kitchen area, down the stairs, and with communal sinks. Turn the wrong way and you see the underbelly of the beast. Unimpressive. 

Overall, this is a perfectly fine place. But, one can do much, much better.
author: Scott W.

description:
I'd read good reviews about Perbacco on Yelp, so I chose it for a business lunch... and it seemed everyone else had as well (super crowded). While the decor is beautiful, the food is highly mediocre. I ordered the quail with a side of fingerling potatoes. The potatoes were awesome, but the quail was barely seasoned and inconsistently cooked (some overdone, some underdone). The service was what you'd expect for a lunch place where executives dine in the Financial District of San Francisco. My colleague and I were the only two people of color in the place, and the manager kept slowly walking past our table, which was a bit off-putting. Our server was nice enough.

I surely wouldn't return to this place for the food. Maybe drinks... and that's a big maybe based on that manager.
author: Dom J.

description:
I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about Perbacco and wasn't expecting that much because I've been to their sister restaurant next door, Barbacco, and thought it was okay at most.  However, I went here for a business lunch and knew this was a nice treat.  The fresh bread was delish and we loved the pesto sauce that the breadsticks were served with.  I got the Tarjian, which was handcut tagialette, 5-hour cooked pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.  

The pasta looked like ramen noodles (the 4 packs for $1 instant ramen kind)..they were pretty curly.  Pork sugo was plentiful though lacked deep flavors, and I didn't see any porcini mushrooms in there!  The portion was huge so I had leftovers.  We shared two orders of the brown butter brussel sprouts which were excellent.  

Service was excellent but the food didn't wow me.  Definitely better than the budget friendly sister Barbacco though.  3.5ish.
author: Cat C.

description:
Absolutely amazing dinner this evening.  Arrived early'ish at 6:30, had the Heirloom Tomato Salad and the Marinated Baby Beets as our appetizers.  So delicious!! I'd have to say I liked the Baby Beets, but my sister loved the Heirloom tomato salad, it's really difficult to say which was better, because they both rocked...

Main courses included PAN SEARED SCALLOPS, FARFALLE NERE, RAVIORA (my dish), PAN SEARED SCALLOPS, and PAPPARDELLE. (Sorry for the caps) just copying it from the menu because I don't want to hand type them.  Let me say they were all absolutely amazing :)

Finished it off with some amazing desserts, I got the Panna cotta which was heavenly.

I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone that wants amazing Italian.

Great job guys, we'll be back!! :)
author: Delilah W.

description:
Bar review only.  I was waiting for my group to arrive at Barbacco next door and I was early.  So they told me that I can wait at Perbacco's bar.  So I go in and order the usual $10+ drink.  It was a ginger ale plus ginger liqeur and some Jamison in there.  As I waited, I saw many groups all dressed up for a nice dinner.  I was actually dressed in semi-fancy garb despite the fact that my workplace dress code is casual.  

The bar folks were pretty nice but there was an absence of affordability in this bar in terms of food and drinks.  Then again, this place seems to be the high end luxury Italian dining sibling of Barbacco and lest I forget, I'm in the Financial District(palm of my hand hitting forehead).

 Hopefully I'll come back here and try their food.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Excellent pasta. All handmade and fresh from the kitchen. We came here first for dinner in 2011  and then for lunch today. Same great taste, same flawless service. 

We ate at the bar and ordered the burrata, pappardelle, tajarin pasta, and the Seminole-dusted sole. All four dishes were tasty and amazing.  We are sad to admit we licked our plates clean! 

Must-order: The standout short rib pappardelle is the signature and an all-star dish. The short ribs and sauce coated the fresh pasta just the right amount. We ordered this the first time and the taste was just as delicious. 
 
For dessert, we ordered the bambolino donuts with strawberries. Despite us being full, we still managed to devour our dessert clean. 

This is a reputable Italian restaurant.  You will not be disappointed!
