author: Linh Dan V.

description:
Fancy shmancy but with verrry long wait time during lunch hours. My dining companion had to leave for her meeting a couple minutes after they came with the food. 

The steak had some flavor although not enough sauce. Casual dress code, respectable place, but not enough staff to handle lunch hour traffic.
author: Quinn N.

description:
A weekend in San Fran with my wife and we picked this restaurant for a nice evening. We weren't disappointed. It's located in the heart of down town, in the Financial District, and just walking distance from the Ferry Building. 

The atmosphere is fun, sophisticated, and even romantic. The restaurant is long and narrow with an open kitchen in the back. There are two cove-like areas for additional seating, with low ceilings and mirrored walls. Great for conversation. 

The first thing we noticed once seated was the extensive wine list was almost entirely Italian. I don't know my Italian varietals but thankfully our waiter did and recommended a wonderful red at about the $50 price point. 

We started by splitting the large risotto, which had a green sauce and sliced asparagus - very tasty and came out piping hot. We then split the quail (see pic) which was equally as good and a really unique dish. They roll spinach into the meat as well as add various toppings and garnishes. Not a huge portion but a really good dish. It wasn't gamey at all, which sometimes is the case with this type of bird. 

Over all a really nice evening, good food, even unique, and good service as well. Highly recommend for a romantic night in San Fran.
author: Nate M.

description: I had the sol and it was great. Also the breadsticks and sauce they serve beforehand was extremely good. It's definitely pricey but the service lives up to the cost and the food is also great. Not sure if I would go back for the price though.
author: Rohan S.

description:
One of my best friends and I came here on a weeknight. I was in town for a conference and had read great reviews on it and wanted to try. My friend had been here once before and warned me that the food wasn't so great but we decided to give it another try. 

We ordered a bottle of wine, two appetizers, two entrees, and dessert for just the two of us. We started off with the burratta with autumn squash and pomegranate. The skin of the burrata was tough and did not taste very fresh as if it was just pulled out from the freezer earlier that day to defrost. We were very disappointed since we both absolutely love burrata.  The second appetizer we had was the Vitello Tonatto, a slow roasted veal sliced very paper thin slices of veal similar to Carpaccio. We liked it a lot but because it was so thin, we had two bites each and it was gone. 

For entrée, my friend had the risotto. That was probably the best dish of the evening.  I ordered the papardelle with short rib ragu. The sauce was on point, perfectly seasoned and the short rib was soft. However, the noodles were overly salty. After a couple of bites, it was difficult to enjoy because all I could taste was how salty the noodles were.  We ended the evening with a chocolate dessert. I honestly can't remember what it was because it wasn't memorable. Overall, the food was underwhelming  when the menu and reviews sounded promising. We bill came out to be about $200 for the two of us.
author: Victoria N.

description:
A long loitering session in an SF parking lot after work ended up bringing my friends and I to Perbacco. When we first decided, I was ecstatic; I've been waiting to try the salumi misti for quite a long time after seeing it on 2012's 7x7 big eats list. It wasn't until after the dinner when I found out that the same dish wasn't on 2013's list. I absolutely understood why...it is way overrated! For what its worth, the dish was good, but it was nothing that blew me out of my mind. I also got a pasta dish with pork and horseradish...while you could taste the uniqueness in the dish, it didn't live up to my heightened expectations. 

Regardless of the food, the drinks and service made up for the experience. They made one of the best dark and stormy's I've had, and the waitress came to check up on us at just the right moments every time (don't you hate it when a waitress asks you how your table's doing right in the middle of everyone chewing?) For that, I rate this place a 4 star: High quality food that is good if you don't overhype it, and excellent drinks and service.
author: Victor C.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with this downtown restaurant. I went in expecting something geared toward the business crowd, but was delighted to find that there were many high quality, creative options on the menu.  My table enjoyed the scallops, halibut, and pork chop entrees, all of which were very good. Good alcohol choices across the board, from cocktails to beer and and wine. And great dessert options - the peach leaf panna cotta with roasted peach sorbet was excellent. This is a really loud restaurant though, and it may be difficult for groups to have conversations if you're seated in the middle of the action. Service was very friendly.
author: John S.

description:
Perbacco serves consistently tasty, carefully prepared, and refined entrees whether you are dining there for lunch or for a private party.  Lunch is like a fancier, more leisurely version of lunch at Barbacco, and requires more time to fully appreciate and digest the delicious courses.  My favorite menu items include the generous salumi misti platter, any version of the delicately prepared fresh pastas with a slow cooked neat ragu, and the complexly flavored meat stews.  I also enjoy the brown butter brussels sprouts.  For dessert, the gelati and panna cotta are reliably satisfying yet light.  

Perbacco also excels at private parties.  My colleagues and I came here for a company-hosted party, and the meal was generously proportioned, perfectly paced, and well-executed.  Service was quick and responsive.  Best of all, the private party menu did not feel like a quick and dirty version of the regular menu, which is sometimes the case when restaurants have to accommodate large groups.  

Perbacco's only drawback is that the service and atmosphere can feel a bit stuffy, which is quite relevant if you are looking to have a comfortable and casual meal.
author: Chris T.

description:
Came here with a group for lunch and it was a very classy, upscale dining experience. We started our meal with the Salumi Mitsi, a presentation of different kinds of cured meats on a plate. It was fatty but delicious. Then moving onto the entree, I got the Langaroli, which is similar to a ravioli, but filled with short-rib. I did not like this dish very much because I thought the pasta wrapping was a little hard and it felt like it was not fully cooked. I did enjoy the sauce that comes with the dish. After finishing the entree, we all opted for the dessert. Hey, everyone got a second stomach for dessert right!? I glanced at the dessert menu, which has gelato, torn cakes, and many others. But one dessert captured my eyes: Dark chocolate lavender bonet. Just by reading the name makes my mouth water. I am a huge fan of dark chocolate and lavender. A combination of these two would be magic and heaven on a plate for me. When my dessert came, I loved the presentation and design. When I took a small bite of the bonet, my mind exploded. It was rich, smooth, not so sweet, and the lavender scent lingered along my taste buds. DELICIOUS! I would come back to eat at this restaurant because of this dessert because it was just that amazing. 

The service is amazing as well. Our waitress would always ask if we have any questions about the menu and we would always do because we cannot understand maybe 50% of it! (We are not italian). The atmosphere is classy and almost everyone is dressed in business attire. Great place to dine at for a special occasion or a business-related meal. This place got very busy after we dined here for 1.5 hours (12 - 1:30pm), so do make reservations! 4 stars because of the great atmosphere, good customer service, and amazing dessert!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
Originally, I was only going to give them 4 stars since I've only tried a few of their dishes, but they were so good, I decided; why postpone the inevitable.  

This place is so incredible.  If you only try their Fricassea (Lamb Stew), you'll be the happiest person in the world.  I know the vegetarians, vegans, etc, don't want to hear it, but this was totally a "cycle of life" moment.  This dish, from the first taste, immediately takes you to a place and a moment where everything in the world makes sense.  Yes; its that good.

Their deserts were amazing too.  The Lavender Chocolate Mousse Cake is out of this world, and the salads are also amazing.  

I would knock it one star off for the noise of the place, but the food makes up for it.  Its that good!!!
author: Tom D.

description: My business partner and I came here for dinner and we were really disappointed with the service. We were seated at our table and after we received water and breadsticks it was almost like we didn't exist. We finally waived a woman over who seemed to be a manager and she took our order. After our order was taken, a gentleman started attending to the table and after him, another. I finally asked the second gentleman if he was in fact our server and he said, "Oh yes! I was busy earlier." I mean, ok sounds good, but an introduction letting me know you will be taking care of us would be nice. On top of that, I told them it was my business partner's birthday in advance. There was no mention of that at the end of the dinner and instead of bringing us some type of dessert to celebrate, he brought us the dessert menus. The bartender double charged us for drinks as well. The food was good, but I work with restaurants on a regular basis from a PR and marketing standpoint and I always say, "You can have good food, but if you don't have the service aspect down you're business is going to suffer." I don't care how great the food is, nobody wants to go to a restaurant with bad service. I'd rather take my business elsewhere.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I once met someone who told me "I only eat Italian food in 2 places: New York and Italy" - While my sentiments have reflected his for years, I must admit, Perbacco does a great job of making me believe that it's not 100% true.

This place was great.  Perfect service, great ambience, fantastic food. The charcuterie plate we had was one of the best I've had...

Great experience.  Next time I'm in SF, I hope to make it back...
author: Josh D.

description: I had a great lunch here, the service was great. The menu has options but is concise for those quick business lunches.
author: Tina W.

description:
too dark for a lunch meeting - packed with white men in business suits laughing too loud for being seated so close.

I had "RAVIORA - PASTA FILLED WITH ROASTED BUTTERNUT SQUASH / SAGE BUTTER / POMEGRANATE / RADICCHIO" (from lunch menu) - don't get misled it's just overdone ravioli  -  the ravioli being hard on the edges (that happens to me at home when I nuke ravioli in the microwave) in way too much oil, some herbs and pomegranate seeds (why?) - now I feel sick in the stomach from all the grease and would actually need a good grappa... 

Oh well - my colleague had a tuna salad - better choice; 

As every so often Italian restaurants in the City mostly stay below what you can do at home with fresh pasta and a half way decent sumo...
author: Flo B.

description:
Very unfriendly staff
Limited selection of food
We arrived at 5:15pm and they didn't let us order food till 5:30. They didn't give us the menu. While waiting, didn't offer any water or bring bread to our table.
Tables and seats are so tightly set that a chubby person will have problem fitting between the table and the seat!!
Portions are very small even though we ordered entree size.
Our waitress was not focused and just going to other tables while getting our order.
They just told us that they could not fit highchair at our table and didn't change our table. I had to ask for booster which did not work because the seat was too small.
The only positive point: one pasta dish that we ordered tasted good.
author: Neda M.

description: I have now eaten here twice and the food is consistently great. Most recently, I had the strawberry appetizer and the scallops as a main. Both were fantastic and not too heavy. Skip the bread, there are much better things to fill up on from the menu - the bread is undersalted. Ambiance is good, as is the service.
author: Andra G.

description: An expensive authentic  Italian food with a flair. For the five us our bill totaled $330.00 which did include a bottle of Dolcetto DogliaAbbona for $56.00. We were seated in the upper level which is away from the crowd, however, if atmosphere is important this upper level is not for you. One of the owners came to our table and suggested we try the Agnolotti which was stupendous.  The pasta was certainly fresh and delicious. If you want to spend quite a bit of money for a special meal this is the place, but I do suggest you make a reservation for the street level. Jacob was our server and did an excellent job.
author: Pam M.

description:
Very good pasta.  My only complaint is that dishes tend to be too salty for my taste. 
Service was excellent.
author: Eric T.

description: Thoroughly authentic Italian food. I can tell the chef knew what they were doing. Our server was sick but she barely missed a beat. My only complaint was that the pasta was a little overdone for me, I was surprised by that actually. I feel like that was such a subliminal mishap compared to how amazing the rest of the food tasted. Excellent wine selection. Their new strawberry tart dessert with the candied Douglas fir is off the charts. Would highly recommend, will be back. Thank you for a lovely evening.
author: Christopher J.

description: One thing that is truly 5 stars is their service. they go above and beyond to make sure you have a great dining experience. Food is your average american fare. Not bad if someone is paying for it :) I have only been for lunch so can't speak for their dinner menu
author: Dan A.

description:
Hmm, I wish I could say that I liked this place, but I honestly wouldn't care to recommend it to any of my friends. We had the following:

- seared octopus
- brown butter brussels sprouts
- pappardelle with short rib ragu
- risotto with porcini mushroom

Out of all the dishes, the seared octopus was my favorite, but that's not saying much as I've definitely had better. It wasn't as tender as I would have liked it and was a bit on the chewier side. The brussels sprouts were alright, but not a must have. The papardelle and the risotto were equally average, which basically sums up the overall dining experience. Frankly, it'll be a while before I decide to try this place again.
author: Ty L.

description:
Absolutely loved this place, just thankful I didn't pay the bill! I came here with my bosses and some coworkers for an 8:00 dinner on a Saturday night. I ordered a tasty cocktail while I waited and we were seated about 30 minutes later.

They gave us a 6 person high top table right by the open kitchen in the back of the restaurant which I loved. I also adored the overall ambiance of the restaurant, very contemporary, chic, and trendy. Very California in my opinion. Two floors, including a nice bar in the front of the restaurant, very open layout, and on the upstairs floor, a private room for private parties. 

Now for the most important part...the food. Fantastic. The moment we sat we were given some breadsticks with pesto sauce. Yum. For a starter I had their burrata which came with pieces of roasted brown sugar coated butternut squash, pomegranates, and arugula. The burrata was absolutely delightful, creamy, milky, and just melted in your mouth. It paired beautifully with the sweet, roasted squash and the fresh and crisp arugula. The pomegranates were a nice and interesting touch, as well. For dinner I had the scallops, I can't even describe how amazing they were. 4 roasted scallops in a herb aioli and red wine jus. The sauces paired exceptionally well with the perfectly cooked scallops. Everything in the dish just came together nicely. Highly recommend this. We also ordered some pan roasted cauliflower and roasted carrots as side dishes. I I never had carrots roasted to the point of being almost black...they were tasty. 

For desert I ended up with the burnt caramel gelato, which was exceptionally sweet and came with vanilla sea salt and some pignoli nut cookies. I couldn't stop eating it! A little sweet, but the sweet paired so well with the salt. 

The wine menu was excellent and the bottles that were chose were perfect. Service was great, the waitress knew the menu very well and was very helpful in picking out dishes and wine. Overall, a great experience, I would highly recommend it.
author: Shannon W.

description:
I cannot tell you how fabulous Perbacco is. Spent Saturday dinner here for 20 year anniversary and birthday celebrations. The day after, I feel like I am on some kind of wonderful drug /elixir hangover. 

The atmosphere and service are impeccable, and the food is sublime. I started with the fritto misto, and Mark had a salad with kumquats and cherries, which were both superb. The frito misto even had a thinly sliced fried lemon-a big surprise which I loved.

For mains, Mark had the plate of short ribs and tenderloin. The short ribs were flavored with red wine and melted in your mouth. My pasta with veal and mushroom sugo, well, I can't stop thinking about it, it was that good. From now on, I will always order a pasta every time I come back to Perbacco, which will be very soon.

Let's not stop here, moving on to dessert, I had the ricotta cheesecake with candied mandarines and rhubarb, and Mark had a dark chocolate mousse. There was a great selection of desserts, which makes me happy, cause I love a beautifully crafted and executed dessert. This is also the place for wine lovers. The wine list has a table of contents and is probably about 25 pages long.

This truly is one of SF's finest for Italian (or any other) food. This will  become our go-to place from now on for special occasions or just to grab a bite on Friday night. . Thanks Perbacco for a beautiful evening.
author: John M.

description:
Amazing! Came here for lunch and was blown away by every aspect of my meal. At the waiter's recommendation I ordered the duck conserva, which was served with absurdly flavorful spinach and sweet, soft onions. The entire entree just melted in my mouth, and the duck was cooked to perfection, falling-off-the-bones tender. And for $20? I'd come back in a heartbeat.

Even before that, the meal was off to an amazing start. The pesto for dipping breadsticks was the best I've ever had, and the focaccia was a dream. The service was friendly, and quick without being rushed.

It's not a cheap place, but I can't think of many places with food THIS good for a relatively affordable price. Come here for a date if you want to impress while still (kind of) on a budget.
author: L H.

description:
Wow- just...wow. 

Service here was great (after getting seated- the hosts where you check-in are not very friendly)! Our favorite dishes were the AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN and POLPETTE. We mentioned it was my birthday and the dessert was comped and decorated beautifully. 

Definitely a great place to splurge for lunch since dinner will be even more expensive (with drinks).
author: Ami D.

description:
Food was amazing, but being condescended to all night by the waitress was obnoxious.

I understand I'm slightly younger than the usual business crowd, and she was just trying to do her job, but the fact she felt the need to explain (unprompted) that pancetta was "a meat like bacon" left me insulted.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
A nice, modern, upscale Italian restaurant that may be slightly stuffy for some but me it was fine.

Food

Appetizers:
- Burrata with strawberries, tarragon, and almond slivers ... I really enjoyed the strawberries and tarragon which was a unique and new combination to my taste buds.
- Grilled octopus with veal tongue and fennel celery salad ... I was expecting this to come out perfect but the octopus was slightly overcooked resulting a short workout for my jaw.  Overall taste and charring was good.

Entrees:
- Roasted rabbit (my boyfriend ordered this and ravished every bite so I'm assuming it was good)
- Pappardelle with lamb ragu ... the pappardelle was cooked perfectly and I did not leave one bite left on the plate. The lamb ragu however was so incredibly salty and inedible. I picked every bit out and sobbed a little until our waiter took it off our bill which was incredibly nice of her.  Great service!  

I initially thought because we ate at a later time (9 p.m. ish) the ragu gets so concentrated towards the bottom of the pot.  But she explained that they salt the ragu as ordered so I guess the chef just had a heavy hand that night.  

Dessert
Salted Caramel Pot de Creme - delicious. duh. 
FREE pignoli amaretti cookies with meringue - the cookies were chewy, fresh, and FREE :-)

I'm dining at their sister restaurant next!
author: Angela D.

description: Awesome place.  Attentive staff.  Only downfall.....and it's extremely small, is that it was packed while I was there which made for shouting and straining to converse. But that's just me being critical.
author: Malcolm D.

description:
An outstanding dining experience.
From the friendly hostess that greeted us, to the knowledgeable, but not overly solicitous waiter that served us and from the outstanding wine and delicious, innovative appetizers, through to the pastas and dessert, dinner last night was flawless. I can't wait to go back.
author: Harris P.

description: Here for a company dinner.  We had great dinner courses from fish of day (sea bass) filet mignon and chicken, all were very well prepared.
author: Irene M.

description:
Excellent, excellent service!

We sat at the chefs table and had a nice view of how the well run kitchen operated.  My favorite dishes were the pappardelle with short ribs and my wife's duck entree.  I just needed a bit of salt on my pappardelle dish, but other than that everything was excellent.

Our waitress was very knowledgeable about the menu and could not have been nicer.  This place was very welcoming and friendly, one of the best service experiences I've had.  We were visiting San Fran for the first time and our waitress gave us useful information about what was in the area and also tried helping us get a cab at the end of the night to our next destination.  As we were leaving, everybody from the wait staff, to the bartender, to the host thanked us with a smile for coming.

My party and I absolutely had a great and memorable experience. Thank you Perbacco!
author: Andy C.

description:
3.5 stars 
so the food was ok - typical italian
we had the octopus to start - a bit underflavored
then the mains- papardelle, short rib, and scallop - ok
i think the ambience or decor of the place could be improved
it felt like a banquet hall
author: Marie r.

description:
Came here on a whim after get manicures with my girl friend. I can't believe I don't come here more often! Delicious wine selection to start. Had an amazing burrata appetizer which was seasonally complimented with butternut squash, arugula, and pomegranate. The combination was superb. I had the Coujette as my main, which is potato gnocchi with duck ragu, chestnuts, and persimmon. It was simply divine! Unfortunately I did not leave any room for dessert :(

If you're looking for a place to have a superb Italian meal and great service, I'd highly recommend you book here tonight :)
author: Kaya F.

description: Stellar experience from start to finish.  Pappardelle with short rib ragu was everything I hoped it would be.  The horseradish finish was sublime and meat falling apart tender.  I ordered the halibut for my main and was impressed.  Nothing overpowered the delicate fish that was cooked to perfection.  My husband had the scallops and although they were tasty, the accoutrement was a tad on the fishy side.  Even the bread was something to return for served with fresh, sweet unsalted butter.  Fabulous beverage selection and impressive service.  I will definitely be back for more.  Thank you Perbacco staff.  You aim to please and we certainly departed more than satisfied.  Great place for a gathering of large groups especially when seated upstairs.  We all had a blast.
author: A H.

description:
I have never been to New York but Perbacco makes me think of what a restaurant would be like with power lunchers and women who lunch. 

Cool, hip, elegant long space with attentive wait staff and down right delicious food. My Strawberry and Arugula Salad only had a few ingredients (white balsamic vinaigrette, red spring onions and ricotta salata) and it was so simply flavorful. The Risotto (roasted morel mushrooms, pancetta, spring onions, sweet english peas, parmesan) was the BEST risotto I have ever had. I think I am slightly still in a food coma from it and that was many-a-meals ago.

They start you off with thin breadstick crackers and a olive oil pesto dip. I was on the tired side so I went with an iced tea and fell in love when they served a mini carafe of simple syrup on the side. Napkins were folded on the table after every time we got up. You know how that extra touch of service gets me. 

I by all means had zero room for dessert but could not pass up the Warm Brown Butter Pistachio Cake filled with Vanilla Custard and topped with Cherry Compote. Heavenly, simply heavenly. 

A great lunch in a great city recommended by a great yelper (Kim D.)
author: Ciara G.

description:
I'd gotten a recommendation to Barbacco next door but ended up walking in this side of what's apparently a couple of places next door to each other run by the same outfit. Really enjoyed the food and place.

Had the heirloom tomato salad. Came with burrata cheese which is essentially a creamy mozzarella. Good stuff.

Rissotto was good too. Included white corn and chanterelles, with pancetta. The pancetta left it a little salty overall so I was drinking water all night long. 

Side of brussel sprouts which were excellent.

I'd go back.
author: Chas E.

description:
Amazing experience from booking the reservation with Jeremy to finishing with dessert and coffee. We were a party of five celebrating a birthday. The guest of honor not only received a handwritten birthday note from Perbacco, her dessert plate also was inscribed with chocolate birthday wishes (and who wouldn't love that!?)

Service was top-notch from everyone, not only Hank, the gentleman (truly) who served us. We were warmly greeted by everyone upon our arrival, and it was abundantly clear that the staff are well trained and are there to ensure we were happy and well taken care of. We wanted for nothing over the course of our evening. 

Now on to the food. Everything was delicious and some dishes were outstanding. Standouts include: fritto misto, escargot, octopus, scallops,  duck breast and roasted cauliflower cooked with anchovies. Yes, we ordered a lot of food!

It's been years since I've had dinner at Perbacco. After tonight's standout experience, it won't be so long until I'm back again.

Thank you, Perbacco!
author: Kim N.

description:
The food is tasty and delicious and if you sit at the bar and Chris is behind it, you will NOT be disappointed.  This guy is as smooth as butter and an amazing person to have a real conversation with. 
Thus place is great and that's why this is not my first time. Classy place with a lot of class.
author: Ed F.

description:
I came here on a date a while back and really enjoyed the experience! We sat upstairs and the seating was much more private and the dim lighting/candles made everything very romantic.
I don't remember much about what we ordered (it was a long time ago!) but I do remember that we got this charcuterie plate with salami and different jams/pates with fruits, nuts, etc and it was amazing! Date picked the restaurant because he read that perbacco was famous for their salami, so when we came here, we had to have it. The rest of the meal was smooth sailing after that (I think both of us got some type of pasta), though perhaps we were a little full from the starter...heh.

On a separate note, the bathrooms are also really nice. it's like an open room (think of a rectangular room with 3 walls) with individual toilet stalls and a few sinks along one wall. And they play music in every stall..kinda cool.
author: Jiyea C.

description:
Fabulous dinner- we had the burrata and strawberries with balsamic vinegar, the ravioli with Meyer lemon ricotta, the duck breast, and the pork chop. Everything was phenomenal,  and the duck paired perfectly with the cab recommended. I'm not a duck person and this dish made me fall in love;  it was almost like eating steak,  no gamey notes whatsoever. 

pro tip: ask for the bread so you can mop up all the fabulous sauce (or just lick the plate, no judgement)
author: Katherine M.

description:
Went with 3 vegetarians and a meat eater. 

Meat eater was happy, veggies were not. Not going back anytime soon.
author: Dimple B.

description:
***Perbacco is a good upscale Italian lunch spot; the portions are generous and almost all of their pastas and entrees are below $20***

Perbacco is a surprisingly big restaurant that sits right in the Financial District.  The restaurant has two floors and the first floor actually accommodates a lot of seating.  I like the dining room.  The low ceiling kind of gives it a more intimate feel and the dining room is contemporary and elegant (nice light colors throughout the room that do not clash).  The restaurant has a really clean and refined feel to it.

Perbacco gets busy at lunch.  Perbacco offers an upscale lunch with pastas and entrees that feature high quality ingredients.  Despite the fine dining menu, the pricing is not that bad.  Almost all of the dishes are below $20 and the portions are surprisingly generous.

For complimentary items, Perbacco features crispy breadsticks (maybe overly crunchy) and pesto.  They also offer just okay focaccia bread.

I started with the burrata, spring pea and artichoke salad.  The salad was garnished with mint, preserved Meyer lemon, and artichoke crema.  The salad was light and refreshing.  The burrata was creamy and the peas were nice and plump.  The artichokes were tender while the greens were fresh and had a nice fragrance to them.

It was a nice salad even though none of the elements (or the combined flavor combination) were that special or memorable.

I liked my pasta entrée more.  I had the agnoli di conglio, which was ravioli filled with devil's gulch rabbit.  The pasta was tossed with black chanterelles, braised greens and a rabbit jus (and then topped with grated parmesan by the server).  The pasta was very good.  It was nicely thick but not doughy and had a good flavor.  The filling was great--meaty and juicy.

I also really liked the sauce.  Pasta sauces can often just be salty (or just one flavor), but the rabbit jus here had several dimensions to it.  There were definitely salty notes, but the red wine flavor really came across and added a surprising and welcomed light sweetness to the dish.

For dessert, I had the almond brown butter cake that had a center of lemon curd.  The dessert was garnished with toasted meringue, pate de fruit, strawberries, strawberry sauce, and candied lemon peel.  I thought this was a nice dessert and much more refined than what I've had at several other Italian restaurants.

The brown butter cake was good and moist.  It had a good crust as well as a good flavor.  The lemon curd was also good--creamy and smooth.  I think it got baked a little too much because there was not as much curd in the center as I was expecting.

I thought the garnishes were good.  I really liked the toasted meringue and I liked both the strawberries and strawberry sauce (they were not too tart).

Service was okay.  The servers seemed to be working hard, but there did not seem to be enough staff.  Because Perbacco lists many Italian names/ingredients on their menu, many customers were (not surprisingly) asking a lot of questions.  And this kept the servers from being as attentive as they should be.  The food itself came out at a good pace.

As mentioned, prices are not that bad considering you can easily go with just one item here (and most of their menu is below $20).

Perbacco is a good upscale lunch spot.  It gets quite busy and it is easy to see why.  Their upscale lunch features a lot of good food and the atmosphere is nice and very welcoming.  I also like nearby Michael Mina and Wayfare Tavern for an upscale lunch, but Perbacco might be the best value of the three.

Parking in San Francisco is difficult.  There are several parking lots and parking structures nearby.  You can also find metered street parking along the street adjacent to the Ferry Building.
author: Anthony N.

description: I loved this place, now I was there to work a job for an event there.  I was not hired by the restaurant, but by clients and they had their event/dinner there on the top floor. I was photographer and cinematographer, however they treated us very nicely when I asked if the lights can be turned on a bit more, there was no rudeness and just cooperation.  We were also bought a dinner that night same as all the guests, wow! 4 course meal and it was delicious, everytime we finished a plate we couldn't wait for the next.  Staff were amazing, amicable and service was great.
author: Lesley C.

description:
Oh My Gosh!!! It's New Years Eve and we just finished the most incredible meal at this restaurant! 

We had the greatest waitress (Tiffany), although I'm 100% positive that any server you have is going to give 110% to you and your table!

The food was unbelievably delicious! So good! 

Arrive early to get drinks at the bar, get a table upstairs if you can because it's got a quiet, beautifully tender intimacy to it which is wonderful, and then spend a luxuriously calm evening in good company with mouthwateringly great food!
author: Abby W.

description: Came here for the first time on New Years Eve. We had an early reservation. The restaurant was nice without being pretentious. Hostess and waitstaff and bartenders are stellar. I forget what cocktail I ordered, but it was delicious! Had a market salad and the Pappardelle for dinner. Both were sooo good. All ingredients in the salad were uber fresh and were perfectly balanced with a light vinaigrette. The pasta was homemade and perfectly cooked with the hearty lamb ragout. It was wonderful. Good Wine list too. I'll add this to my favorite spots for dinner in the Financial District.
author: Peggy K.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for the first time for our Christmas dinner for two on a Friday night. Our reservation was for 8:30 PM and we arrived on time. We only had to wait a few minutes while the table was being cleared for us.

The interior is open and modern without being pretentious, while also being intimate. We were seated at a large table (probably large enough to fit four), which I thought was great. There's nothing worse than being crammed into a row of tables for two where the person at the next table is 3 feet away from you, so thank goodness for the seating arrangement. The noise level was moderate: although there were a lot of people talking, you could pretty easily have a conversation with your party.

Our server was attentive and answered our questions well. He also helped me pick out a wine for dinner, even bringing over a couple different ones for me to try until I found one I liked (since I was only having a glass). Every chance he had, he would check up on us and ask us how our food was, let us know the status of our food arrival time, etc. They also fold up your napkins for you when you get up from the table! Cute. :)

Here's what we ordered:

-- Small salumi misti: a plate of house-cured meats. This was fantastic - if you come here, you MUST get this! I honestly can't remember which meats were which, only that every one of them was insanely good. I liked that they were served with little breadsticks as well as pickled veggies, which cut the richness of the meats nicely to refresh the palate. The pickled carrots didn't even taste like carrots, they just tasted good (and I hate carrots normally).

-- Stracci, half-portion: Spinach pasta "rags" with a veal sugo and golden chanterelles. This pasta was so delicious. It was rich and savory while still being light, despite the heartiness of the veal sugo. There were large chunks the chanterelles, which made my tastebuds do the happy dance. BF and I took pieces of the house bread to mop up the sauce, it was so good.

-- Cunij: BF's entree. This was braised rabbit with roasted butternut squash, green apple, and chestnut polenta. I had a couple bites... quite tasty indeed. BF liked it a lot.

-- Quail: my entree. This was a HUGE (and I mean huge for a quail... like the size of a mango) quail breast stuffed with wild mushrooms, served with potato puree, chard, and black chanterelle jus (can you tell I like chanterelle mushrooms?). AMAZING. It was everything I wanted it to be... juicy and savory and just perfect. The chard wasn't even that bitter (like I have known some chard to be) and I liked that the potatoes were pureed - kept things light. And the chanterelle jus? It tied everything together so well. This was a very umami-heavy dish and I loved it. LOVE LOVE LOVE. The portion was very large (BF ate half of the quail to help me out) and I was still really full by the time I "finished' my plate.

-- Burnt caramel gelato: Quite nice end to the meal. BF and I shared this, although I ate 70% of it by myself. Nice smoky, earthy notes and enough sea salt sprinkled on and in it to balance out the intense sweetness. Comes with a cookie (I think it had pine nuts in it?).

One thing I will note is that there was a significant length of time between when we finished the appetizers and when we got our entrees. BF commented on this and wondered where our food was, but I didn't mind since that gave me time to digest and zen out before tackling the entrees. Dinner took a total of 2 hours from start to finish, so if you go here, treat dinner as the main event for the evening.

So with the items above, plus 1 glass of wine and 2 beers, the total was about $135 for the two of us (not including tip, which brought it up to ~$160), which I thought was just about right considering the portion sizes. They are not trying to gipp you food here... you will be full and happy at the end of the meal.

Verdict: Go! You won't be disappointed. It is well worth the money.
author: Kimber L.

description:
I've had great luck this trip with food!  My tuna salad had so many interesting ingredients, fennel broad beans green beans roasted peppers red onion, all with a delicious dressing. The side of Brussels sprouts was yummy and there was a
Spice I can't quite identify in them. Also, the iced tea was very flavorful.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Walking in around 6PM, and there's a crowd at the host/ess stand. A minute or so later we're taken to a 2-top mid room. Lots a big tables of 6-8 here and there, a few 4-tops too. Busy...and there are menus and then our waiter (Adriano, I think) and water choices and back to the menus. 

Lots of interesting plates, must try the salumi, the vitello, the beef and beet salad. Our waiter, when asked, suggested wines to compliment perfectly.

Pasta next, agnolotti and sugo. Not as hot as I would have liked it, but both were excellent.

Cheeses were perfect, and the desserts we tried were fantastic!

Expensive ($100 per) but worth it. 

My only complaint: it is too loud, very distracting.  

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
This place has very delicious menu options, but it is definitely an upscale restaurant. 

I made reservations for two on a Wednesday evening. We arrived five minutes early prior to our reservation. Upon researching, it seemed as if there was a dress code or to at least be dressed nicely. My boyfriend dressed nice casual and I wore a nice dress. Upon arriving, we saw some people were more business casual. I felt over dressed, so you can certainly come nice casual. When we arrived, the two hostesses were talking, and it took them a couple of minutes to acknowledge us. Which was a little awkward, we just stood their for a couple of minutes unsure if we should interrupt or not. After we checked in, we were sat within a minute or two. 

We were sat in a corner table behind the mirror, which wasn't a bad seat. It was perfect for us. There's also enough spacing between tables which I liked. We didn't have any drinks, just water. The waitress brought us something to snack on, which was long get thin breadstick with olive oil and pesto blend. It wasn't bad, but not great. I didn't particularly care for it. We ordered one appetizer and a small plate, the appetizer was the ravioli with black truffle sauce. It was really good, the sauce was fantastic. However, I wasn't expecting one giant ravioli. It was literally one giant ravioli. It was great, and the taste was there, but figured two would be appropriate for the price, and it was also cold. Not sure if it was supposed to be that way. Our small plate was mushroom risotto, and this was portioned enough for the both of us. The risotto was great and wonderfully seasoned, probably some of the best I've had. 

As for entrees, he had the halibut and I had scallops. Both were pretty amazing. We didn't have any complaints about our main dishes. The scallops and halibut were coked perfectly. By that time, we were pretty full and took a dessert to go. As ordered the lavender bar, which was mousse and Devils food cake all mixed together, with rice puffs, lemon, and lavender. It was really good. I we both felt like it certainly wasn't worth $11. It was a very small portion. Before leaving, they did give us some chocolates, which was nice. 

Overall, I would come her again for a nice time and beautiful dinner, or maybe a special occasion. For two people, it was $125 - one appetizer, one small plate, two entrees, and one dessert. This isn't too bad for a nice dinner.
author: Cecilia V.

description: While I've eaten at Perbacco multiple times (and enjoyed the food and experience), this review is for private dining I have booked with Stephen Lee.  Stephen is consistently prompt, professional, and pleasant.  He has been very helpful with finding a date that works for my party, even when it was somewhat of a moving target, as well as answering all of my questions and offering helpful suggestions.
author: Anna L.

description: Had lunch here again today. It's not often that I come here--but when I do--I remember why I love this spot. Great entrees, cocktails, and desserts. Gotta start having more business lunches here.
author: Juan T. K.

description: The manager saw my review and immediately answered apologizing. While I won't be in San Francisco for a while to dine here again, his acknowledgment meant a lot to me.
author: Christine M.

description:
This place is fabulous - perbacco!!!

I brought my family here for dinner. Combined we had the pesce crudo, the seared scallops, one of the fish dishes and the mushroom risotto with bone marrow. All were tasty and flavorful. I couldn't have asked for a better dinner. 

For desert we tried three items - I can't remember what they were called, but all three were divine. DIVINE. 

Drinks were great - I had the buddha hand infused vodka cocktail - highly recommend!

The prices are reasonable. The service was fantastic. My family already decided that we'll be back.
author: Riana L.

description:
It was decent. Crowd was older and seemed a little stuffy. 

Won't be back but it was fine for 1 time as we try various restaurants in SF.
author: Rohit R.

description: Have eaten here lots of times. My go to Italian restaurant. Not the same as the north end or Brooklyn, but definitely old world charm meets new (California fresh ingredients.) Incredibly fresh house made pasta. House cured salumi is amazing. Wine selection is good.  I would not call it a date restaurant, Seems to be better as a group dinner setting.
author: Victoria E.

description:
My new SF obsession. I've always been a huge fan of Barbacco, so it was difficult making the reservation for Perbacco instead this time. However, I'm so glad I did because it surpassed all of my previous expectations.

Our whole experience from start to finish was absolutely great. As some others have mentioned, service could be slightly improved due to the at times inattentive servers. However, we also dined like it was a three course meal and they continuously replaced our dinnerware so I'm not complaining.

The meal begins with complimentary bread crackers with a chimichurri sauce which was a great touch. We decided to order three things to split: the herb and mushroom ricotta gnocchi, risotto, and duck breast. My first bite into the gnocchi was heavenly - I've never had such rich gnocchi that melted in my mouth before. The risotto was also extremely flavorful with hints of apple and mushroom. Finally, the duck breast was cooked to a perfect medium rare with a really interesting peach salad on the side.

I would highly recommend each of the dishes we ordered. At the price point that Perbacco is at, I'm completely blown away by the quality of their food and service. I'm already planning my next trip and I can't wait to be back!
author: Sunny H.

description:
This place gets really crowded at lunch time! Its prime location in the financial district makes it a destination for business lunches, so make a reservation. We were able to sit in the booths on the first floor, so we never saw the full restaurant, but it looked pretty upstairs!

Our server was super hipster and super informative. He recommended starting with the burrata cheese plate as well as the salami plate. These were both delicious, especially together. I would always order both, since I need cheese with my salami and salami with my cheese. They were very good and complimented each other well.
 
For entrée, the tajarin was exceptional. I don't know what they do for the five hours the pork is cooking, but it is sure good! The sauce and meat with the noodles were so flavorful. It definitely hit the spot and I ate the whole thing. My friends ordered the gnocchi and the risotto, both of which they were very happy with. Our server was great about coming back to check on us and was very nice. Overall, great food in a prime location with fantastic service.
author: Alisha K.

description: My wife's family originated in Northern Italy in a small town called Piamonte. She has always had a dream to eat real Northern Italian food like her ancestors enjoyed in Italy. She located this restaurant and we booked reservations. We arrived on a Saturday night and found a delightful venue full of happy customers. We were seated at a nice table. My Margarita was good and Elena's wine was superb. We ordered a beet salad and a main course of Italian pasta. What we got was a pleasant surprise.It was real Northern Italian food that seemed almost like it came from the wild. Forget all of the tomato paste and things normally associated with Italian food. I was flat spectacular!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! We finished up with an excellent dessert and custom coffees. We were expecting a bill in the range of $175.00 ad got one for only $119.00. This is a fine place to have dinner with that special one in your life.
author: Jack W.

description:
I ate here well over a year ago, and just today saw a video on Eater SF with the Chef reading his bad reviews from around the internet (oh internet, you are truly hilarious) so felt compelled to write this long-overdue review.

First of all-- people who are whining about the lack of chicken options on a menu (Italian restaurant or elsewhere) should eat at KFC. When making reservations at a restaurant, don't you typically do your due diligence (ie check the website or menu) beforehand, to set proper expectations?! People are funny.

Anywho, I digress. Perbacco was an incredible dining experience for me and the rest of my group. Like many people, I too have been to my fair share of Italian restaurants both in the US as well as when I lived in Florence a few years ago-- Perbacco certainly knows what they are doing. I say this because I haven't been to the restaurant in over a year and still remember the tagliatelle w/ pork sugo I ate. This was after a delicious antipastO/salumi platter and coupled with a delicious bottle of Sangiovese. The service was great, and the ambiance at Perbacco is understated and elegant.

Keep up the great work, Perbacco (and Steffan!)
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
We went here for our friend birthday.   Had reservation at 8:00 but got seated about 15 minutes later.  My husband's drink actually didn't arrived until we asked our server for it after get seated at our table and food arrived ( 30 minutes since we ordered)
Overall it was a casual environment,  a bit on a noisier side.  Service was decent, the food was more on the traditional Italian cooking.  The chacuteries plater was very good, the pate was excellent, that would be a great choice if you are in for a night cab or sitting at the lively bar for a drink.  I love the tender octopus dish and the butter quash ravioli.  My husband enjoyed his braised lamb shank.  The scallop was okay and the heirloom tomato salad was a okay too.  But overall nothing really jump out at me to say I must come back for more.
With so many amazing restaurant out there, for a Meh experience I will take my chance and hope to discover a new place to love.  Perhaps I will be back just for a night cab at the bar but dinner for sure can wait!
author: Toni L.

description: Service was slow and our server was not very good. Disappointing after reading the reviews.  Good okay. The gemelli was bland. The langorali was so rich.  Would not come back rather try somewhere else. I was so looking forward to this place.
author: Steven K.

description: Our party of 4 was placed at an upstairs table overlooking the kitchen where we were assaulted by odors, often unpleasant, throughout the evening. The raw tuna starter was very tasty and the pasta in a veal meat sauce was quite good. The stuffed quail entree was a major disappointment, dry and unpleasant. The wait staff was attentive and personable.
author: BettyLou H.

description:
Perbacco has been around for a while, and while it's no longer the hot new thing in town, it still remains one of SF's finest restaurants. I've been here several times for lunch and dinner, and I've been hooked since the first time I went. Before Perbacco, I'd always scoffed at Italian dining out as being a thoroughly heavy, carb-loaded, gut-busting Olive Garden/Buca di Beppo-like experience. I never knew Italian cuisine could be so inventive, light, and refreshing without making you feel as if you've added 20 pounds of gut and booty ballast.

Weekday lunch at Perbacco is a total power scene, with lots of business deals being discussed everywhere. If confidentiality and discretion are a concern to you, the tables downstairs might feel a bit intimate and closely spaced. Yet overall, the atmosphere is loud and lively. Not so much so that you have to shout to be heard by your companions, yet just enough so that you likely won't be overheard by the tables next to you.

Dinner at Perbacco can run from semi-formal to business casual, with younger professionals sticking to the bar and well-dressed, reservationed older folk sitting down to an intimate dinner before a night at the theater. 

I didn't have a reservation the last time a friend and I went for dinner, but we still managed to get accommodated immediately by having table settings placed on the last remaining empty bar table up front. Everything from the salumi platter, veal, hanger steak, to a cheese platter struck the right "balance" for almost any attribute you could imagine - whether unique flavors, the "magnitude" of the flavors, "lightness" vs. "heaviness," and even portion size/value.

Overall, a memorable and truly positive dining experience that makes you feel lucky - and proud - to be in such an amazing city.
author: Vincent L.

description: Came here while waiting for our table at Tadich Grill and I should've stayed here instead. Sat at the bar with a friend nibbling on a good selection of cheese and wine... I'll be back!!
author: Maria D.

description:
Loved the atmosphere. Felt like I was in a restaurant in New York or something.

Definitely a place I'd hit up again (in fact, going this weekend)

Big enough for birthdays/large groups.

Food was delicious...here are my recommendations so far:
Salumi Misti
Pappardelle
Langaroli al Brasato

If you're hungry, order the big size - the half plate of pasta was like 3 bites for me.
author: Emily Y.

description: Restaurant was great and our server was very accommodating and helpfu.l He helped us choose the best meals and prepared a special vegan pasta dish for me.
author: Pooja S.

description: Perbacco used to be a reliable restaurant for good Italian food. Now, they mix things up a bit with surprise special events; keeping diners on their toes. Shortly after we were seated, a server behind my wife slammed a heavy silver tray into her head so hard it immediately brought tears to her eyes. No apologies, just a comment that "that was weird."  Now that's what I call guerrilla dining. A new approach to an exciting dining experience. Decent food rounded things out. The randomness continues in the kitchen too, with dirty pots and pans strewn around the floor. You never know when someone needs to slip and fall for added excitement. Sommelier poured the initial taste to the wrong person. Maybe she took a blow to the head too. Dining room was partially full all night on a Saturday. I'm guessing not enough people have subscribed to this new level of dining adventure. Are you up to the challenge?
author: Shaban S.

description:
This is a very classy place full of beautiful people.  We got a both near the front (the back has a low ceiling and is a bit claustrophobic).  The food is delicate and well presented.  Service is impeccable.  

Servings are somewhat small but very attractive to look at.
author: M S.

description:
I enjoyed Perbacco a lot. Food was all excellent -- hightly recommend the rock shrimp misto, the braised short ribs, & the stuffed quail. (Stuffed quail was hands down the winner -- fantastic!) We had a lovely endive salad as well.

Service was excellent, with two somm-type-people walking around to help with wine selection. The woman who helped us with wine knew her stuff, & directed us to a perfect match based on our food, preferences, & price point. The rest of the service was excellent as well--the server did a great job of explaining to us exactly how everything was prepared so that we knew what we were getting.

We split the brown sugar gelato for dessert, which was very good. (I had a hard time deciding between that & the salted caramel. Now I really want to try the salted caramel!)

In any other city (except maybe New York or something), I'd probably give Perbacco half a star more--the food was all very good, but I have had so much food in SF, and so much Italian food, that has utterly blown me away, so the bar is really high. There was nothing at Perbacco that I felt rose to the "foodgasm" level, which has kind of become my standard for rating something five stars.

The only other drawback was the noise level. We were lucky enough to be seated upstairs, which was definitely quieter than downstairs, but it was still a bit loud. (Which....seems to be par for the course in SF.) There were also a couple of very loud (possibly intoxicated?) tables near us, which didn't help.

BUT, overall, totally worth a trip, and while I might not go out of my way to eat here again, I would happily go along if someone else suggested it.
author: Angela B.

description: I really liked my experience here. Most of the dishes were really good. Between the service and the food, I would definitely be back. I'm not sure view much anything cost BC I was with my colleagues and my boss expensed it. Perhaps if I paid, if have a better idea of what value I got, and I would then have a different view... Possibly.
author: Sau y.

description: Very disappointed from the noisy atmosphere, crowded seating, to the mediocure food. Not the least bit impressed, do not waste your time, I'm not wasting anymore of mine writing about this place!
author: Mark B.

description:
Great place for a business meeting.  Wait staff is always very attentive.  They get you in and out of there without making you feel rushed.  

I will say it is WAY to loud in there at times.  So if you have a important, detailed topic to cover this isn't the place for you.  Much easier to have a social work dinner vs. an actual work dinner.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Love the ambiance of this place, it's big for a SF restaurant, classy, muted lighting. Our server was so sweet, wish I remembered her name!

Had a glass or two of rose, the beet salad, and the mushroom ragu gnocchi. I wanted to love the gnocchi full of gorgeous chantrelles, but it tasted like a salt bomb. The caramel ice cream for dessert was incredible. Will be back just for that. The rhubarb sorbetto with olive oil panna cotta was a beautiful and light dessert.
author: Jane R.

description:
Perbacco is an amazing restaurant for larger parties. I was planning a company team lunch for 10 and for both vegetarians and meat-lovers. Perbacco is the perfect place because they have a large selection of dishes that cater to people with all kinds of taste and they have an decent whiskey and wine selection.

Overall, it is definitely a place that I'd come back to!
author: Grace Q.

description:
Overall a very solid experience. I thought the food was pretty good, but not super memorable. The bar area was nice with a great selection of wine/cocktail. The main dining was pretty average... more cramped and loud than I would have liked. Price was higher than I thought it should be for the quality of food.

I've been to Barbacco (next door) a few times but went to Perbacco for the first time... I think I prefer Barbacco a bit more.
author: Michael C.

description: Good food, but expect more from a $$$ place. We both had fish, but I can't remember what we had since it was back in October. You might still be hungry after your meal. It was the night I proposed, but they didn't really do anything special for us.
author: Andrew O.

description: I had lunch today at the restaurant. The service and food was great. I had the meatballs and they were excellent. The entire meal was great until dessert. I wanted to just get a scoop of vanilla gelato for dessert. It appears to be in a dessert however I couldn't get the dessert because they only make enough for the dessert. I was very disappoint that they could accommodate a simple request in my opinion. It appears if you don't conform to the chef's way of serving food then you are out of luck. It was great food, great service, great atmosphere however don't ask for anything different in the menu because it won't happen. I am not looking for free food. Just want to have food the way that I want it. Simple request for the price of eating out.
author: James R.

description: Everything we ate was just ok. Excellent service though. Food not good enough for me to wanna come back. I will give Barbacco a try next.
author: R A.

description:
Came here for NYE dinner with my love. The place was packed! Good thing I made a reservation a month in advance for 8pm. My date came 10 minutes before I did, he ended up waiting by the bar. We were then seated at a corner table. Quite roomy for a corner booth I must say. It's a square table that would be for four, so it's extra plate room for our dishes. Service was a bit slow, most likely due to greater traffic for the special day.

The menu was slightly different from the one I browsed earlier that day, with more choices. I ordered this Citrus Cured Langoustine, with Maine Lobster, Dungesness Crab, Sturgeon Caviar and Langoustine Panna Cotta. Shellfish heaven I must say! The presentation was beautiful, with various colors of citrus fruits and seafood. I have a thing for savory panna cotta, or perhaps panna cotta in general. I like this soft, gelatin texture, yet I'm not to expect a sweet vanilla taste, but rather something that would not normally come to mind. Overall, the dish was a bit lacking in taste and texture. Not that it's a bland dish, in fact, it's a bit too salty for the caviar. I can see why the fruits came in handy and the seafood were prepared as close to their normal seafood taste as possible. However, the tastes don't seem to blend it well. It was a bit choppy, doesn't flow. It's like a festival rather than a show. I find it a bit interesting on how the lobster pieces were overcooked, which became a bit tough, the crab was just right, and the langoustine had a sashimi texture but slight fishy taste. The idea is definitely there, it's just in need of more of a technical touch on the execution.

My meal continued on with the Cunij, Roasted Rabbit Leg & Boudin with Rye Berry Risotto, Chanterelle Mushrooms, and Braised Greens. I enjoyed that risotto!! The flavors were a bit overwhelming if I had a bite of the risotto before the rabbit meat. The rabbit leg was perfectly cooked, tender and juicy, has the texture of a game hen, but has a light but gamey taste to it. There's a lot of meat in that tiny little leg. Oh that cute rabbit, I just love it. (Sue me for eating a cute creature.) Portions were just right, but perhaps the flavors had tricked me well, it is quite a heavy dish. I had to stop halfway if I want to save room for desserts.

On the side, we ordered Brussel Sprout as our usual dining action. Unlike its sister restaurant, Barbacco, these were not deep fried in duck fat. Instead, these were sauteed in brown butter, with Parmesan cheese sprinkled on top and capers mixed in. Definitely a different texture and taste. I don't quite enjoy this type of preparation for Brussel Sprouts, it's lacking texture and could be too mild in taste.

I ended the meal with a Burnt Caramel Gelato with Sea Salt and Pignoli Cookie. I was simply too full to try the cookie. I picked at my gelato though. Unfortunately, as good as the dessert had sound on the menu, I could not stand the sweetness. This is rather a personal preference item. The aftertaste of caramel was just a tat too strong. I'm sure those who are capable of eating sweets, which means the major population, will enjoy this gelato. The flavors were rich and blasting, the texture wasn't extremely thick and creamy. It's also a generous scoop, not bad for sharing.

Goods and bads about this place. I'll grade it a 3.5 for the most part. I guess I might have had a higher expectation since I seriously love Barbacco. Bumping it up for doing a great job on the risotto.
author: Connie C.

description:
A strong 4 stars. This is a great place for business or a nice dinner. Everything was quite good. 

enjoy!
author: Gilad B.

description:
I was lucky enough to dine here for lunch for a business meeting. The food here is delicious, and service very accommodating. 

I ordered the slow roasted short rib pappardelle , and shared the Brussels sprouts, sun chokes, and carrot side dishes with my fellow patrons. The pappardelle was extremely tasty! The noodles were cooked to the perfect texture, and the meat was savory and juicy, accompanying the pasta well. The sides were scrumptious as well, and reasonable at $6 each. I liked the Brussels sprouts the most. The carrots were good as well, but I could have passed on the sunchokes (tastes like potatoes). We also shared a salami plate as an appetizer- which was okay. I wouldn't get it again. They also pass out some cheese bread, which goes really well with the dip they serve with the bread sticks. I shamefully ate two. 

Service was attentive and my water cup never ran empty. Nor did my bread plate. Our server was friendly and knew the menu extensively. The only drawback is that food came out extremely slow, so I was quite hungry!

Not a bad experience to impress a client or business partner for lunch.
author: Mina K.

description:
After scouring Yelp for a couple weeks for the perfect Italian restaurant to have my Birthday dinner, I finally settled on Perbacco.  I had heard great things about it, and the Yelp reviews were off the charts. When we entered the restaurant I was given a Happy Birthday card...that was a nice touch!  

One of the deciding factors in my decision was that the Salumi Misti was on the Big Eat, so naturally, my family started off with one of those.  I have never been a big fan of salumi plates in general, but thought I would try each kind. They were good, but because salami is something that I'm not a particular fan of, one time was enough.  We also ordered that Burrata with sweet corn and cherry tomato crudo.  I work at a cheese shop and know my burratas...this one wasn't curdly (the death knell of mozzarella's) and the cherry tomato crudo was flavorful. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=6Ljap5vwurZCKsRTMsHJIg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=zJqYLy_4xU2ZEeACMkntuw

For my main dish, I had the Pappardelle with braised short rib ragu.  I was a bit disappointed that the sauce tasted like Thanksgiving gravy...I was expecting something more earthy and meaty.  Aside from that fact, the portion size was perfect and the pasta cooked to perfection.  

Dessert was good...so good that my family of 3 ordered 4 and finished every last bite.  I had been dreaming about the doughnuts. They came out warm, in a bag, with a nice "Happy Birthday" chocolate stencil on the plate.  The citrus wasn't overpowering, but enough to taste. The Butter Pistachio Cake was good as well. There was some filling in it...almost custard like.  The Burnt Carmel Gelato is to die for...and I've been to Bi-Rite, so don't even try to compare the two!  It was topped with coarse salt which added an addictive crunch to the creamy concoction. By far, my favorite dessert was the Chocolate Torrone.  It had chunks of hazelnuts in it and was served with blackberries on the side...extremely refreshing and a chocolate lovers dream.  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=cDJ4bRfKKCnyG_yPlIg0xg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=Mv00nKAsnXI8niNRE_LI0w
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=jvPPoc7lGTmUaLEOoVwUyg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=ba5IP3z3Qot0TGwuDE6arA

All in all we had a good experience. Service was a bit lacking. Our waiter didn't go out of his way to answer our questions and I even had to pour the wine for my parents.  I would save it for a special occasion, but I would look for another cozier Italian restaurant in the city before revisiting.
author: Hayley H.

description:
Decent service. Food a bit too rich for our salad-eating stomachs. 

Salumi platter. I really wish that we asked the waiter what was on there. Actually, I wish that he just kind of told us. We heard him explain it to other people, but is it because we're young and asian that you're not going to explain it to us? Whatever.

Drinks were good. The pastas were just too much. I ordered the gnocchi with rabbit which for some reason my boyfriend won't eat. Rabbit is one of a few animals he will not eat - including dog.

He ordered some other pasta with a shortrib sauce. It was good, but it was just so rich for both of us.

For dessert we had the salted caramel gelato. It came with this pinenut cookie...and I stole his. It was so delicious and gluten free!
author: Nina Y.

description: Great service.  Noisy.   Nice place.  But...pork chops...yuk.  Fatty...with a taste of tainted seafood.
author: A. C.

description:
came here for a business lunch.  The staff was really friendly, and even though we had to wait for a few moments until they actually open for business, our wait was pleasant.

I had the steak option was really good, and cooked as I asked.  I believe one of co-workers ordered the rossita which she sweared by it. 

Over all.  really nice place for lunch
author: Mike S.

description:
When do I get to go back!? Relaxed environment with high quality food. Makes me think of a more approachable version of Boulevard, not so many suits or stuffiness.

Menu changes daily which I'm a huge fan of and it's a decent sized menu (impressive). Two apps. for three people, the first was the burrata cheese and butternut squash, so satisfying. We also had the endive salad with porcinis, it was good, I think the plating may have been a little off (aesthetically)  not sure what it was, the flavor of the dish was fine.

We shared three pastas I only tried two (vegetarian), the raviora = roasted butternut squash and maracona almonds, sooooo goood, i wouldve eaten a third and fourth dish with squash, they prepare it so well!
The rabaton which was a gnocchi and pesto like sauce was good.

Dessert. Both were Devine. Sugar cake and cupolina. Great way to end the perfect evening.

Service was perfect.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
This place is really good. I came during white truffle season and had the truffle course. Splendid, but perhaps too much truffle in one sitting.
The atmosphere and ambiance was good, as was the wine, which was not overpriced. The bar was a little crowded, so our apéritifs were not as comfortable as they might have been. Once we were at our table though, all was good.
author: Bob S.

description:
I find myself writing reviews either if I'm highly satisfied with a venue or highly dissatisfied and unfortunately it was the latter for this place! First time here-purely lured in because of the reviews but I won't make that mistake again. My husband and I ordered the rabaton and pappardelle 
-both flavorLESS pasta dishes and they were COLD! The only positives for this place: the service of our waiter and the ambiance (also mediocre). Don't waste your time here!
author: Jyoti S.

description: White table clothes and friendly, professional staff make for perfect place for a business lunch! Great menu!
author: Kelly A.

description: I walked in expecting nice things from this place but the moment I caught a glimpse of the menu... I knew I was in for a travesty. I did not understand most of the things that were written on the menu and they didn't have normal Italian food. Bad bread, bad lemonade, bad bread sticks and tapenade, bad pasta, bad everything goodbye
author: Roz R.

description:
We originally tried to go to their sister restaurant next door but we didn't have a reservation and thankfully Perbacco had a table for us. 

I had the steak tartare and the pappardelle. The steak tartare was delicious, it had grated horseradish on top which gave it a great kick without being overwhelming. The pappardelle was served with a shortrib ragu, the ragu was so tasty, it had a sweetness and the spring onions cut right through it. This was hands down the best pasta dish at our table! 

Our friends at dinner also ordered the cauliflower side dish and it was served on top of this delicious sauce of some sort! Definitely a great side dish to have. 

The service was great, atmosphere was nice. Only thing was my glass had lipstick stains... And I wasn't wearing any lipstick!
author: Chyng H.

description:
Craving tartare and seafood - I knew Perbacco has good veal tartare so we headed there.  

We took one of the pub tables near the window by the front.  We were greeted quickly by the host with wine list and menu.   

What we had:
Maker's Mark on ice - $9 - for hubby
Timorasso - $12 - crisp, just as I wanted

Jewel box of citrus marinated abalone and shrimp, sea urchin over shrimp panna cotta - $15 - wow, genius!  The panna cotta was rich, creamy with an intense shrimp flavor.  The shrimp was sweet with just the right hint of citrus, which helps with the rich panna cotta.  

Tartare of pastured veal, black truffle lardo crostino - $14 - always good.
author: Gloria H.

description: Disappointing meal especially considering the high prices. The duck pasta dish and the pork chop were awful. Squash ravioli was good but not great. Had to ask for bread - orherwise excellent service. This was the first dinner of two for our family while on vacation in San Francisco. Wish we'd gone elsewhere.
author: Karen B.

description:
Here is the 3-1-1

Food: Its been almost 10 years since I came back and the food was not what I remembered; did not have the "WOW" factor from the 1st time. The Pesce Crudo (big eye tuna) was ok, not what the menu described given that it was served with watermelon so I envisioned a more salt/sweet flavor profile rather than slightly bland attempt at a sashimi platter. The grilled octopus was slightly better as the char and lemon vinaigrette was a good combination. The roasted beets were ok but didn't have any "pop" to make it memorable.
For the entrees Pappardelle with short rib ragu was tasty and rich, definitely a small portion was plenty; the recommended seafood risotto was not as successful, it unfortunately had a fishy smell and taste with the risotto being wet providing a unpleasant texture.

Service: Excellent! Our waitress was attentive and even though she was a fan of the risotto when she heard from another server that we were not satisfied with that dish she removed it from our bill and comped our glasses of wine. That was a very pleasant surprise.

Ambiance: Noise level was ok, the bathroom is hidden downstairs but overall very lively atmosphere. Recommend definitely to eat upstairs versus underneath the 2nd level.
author: Irwan A.

description:
Food: Salami shared appetizer with group of 4
- Duck Risotto
- Salted Dark Chocolate Bonet
- Brussel sprouts
Pros: good ambiance, good service, salami's are cured inhouse, delicious food! Bread/butter was also very tasty. Would definitely recommend saving room for dessert.
author: Megan M.

description:
This is definitely a cozy place to go for down-to-earth yet sophisticated hearty Italian food. It is absolutely delicious!

My friend and I came for dinner on a Saturday night. It got progressively busier as the night went along, but the service stayed fantastic throughout. For our starter, we shared the Carne Cruda -- a wonderfully rich and tasty, veal tartare. It came with some black truffles as well as a wafer-thin biscotti complement to serve the tartare. It was the star of the meal. It was tasty, a top selection of meat and had a delight creamy texture. I would absolutely return for just this dish.

For mains, we had the Rabaton and the Pappardelle. The Rabaton was a filling gnocchi with wild mushrooms which were not overpowering or overly watery. The spinach and herb really shone through and we never felt as if the pasta was too doughy or plain, which is a common symptom of bad gnocchi. Additionally, neither the garlic nor the ricotta were too strong--it was well balanced. The Rabaton was amazing! It was drenched in a rich ragu from a beef short rib stew. The meat was melt-in-your-mouth good and had the fall-off-the-bone texture. It was not tough at all, very savory and not in the least bit dry. In general, the pasta was perfectly al dente, just the way I like it. 

Dessert was top notch as well. We shared the Dark Chocolate Bonet, a cross between a custard and a pudding. It was soft and rich, a theme through the night, but was not too sweet for our taste. It came with an awesome caramel honeycomb which was so good that I hogged. 

All in all, I would come back as soon as possible. It was a great experience and I'd be excited to try their other dishes. I'd get that Carne Cruda again, though...
author: Larry Y.

description: Perbacco's not a bad choice if you're in the area. Probably the best thing we had here was the housemade charcuterie. Everything else was pretty standard- not bad, just not all that memorable. I think if you're in the area or you live in this neighborhood this would make a nice weekday dinner spot. Otherwise I wouldn't call this a must have...
author: Art C.

description:
We had a great dinner here on a Friday night.  We were able to make last minute reservations for 6:45pm and were seated immediately upon arriving. The decor and ambiance is great. The customer service was great...they were quite patient with me even though I kept asking if there was dairy in everything. Prices are average and overall a good dinner experience.

Mission fig and endive salad with hazelnut vinaigrette -$10
-The figs were so decadently sweet and tasted like they were soaked in a dessert wine. Besides the endives, this dish also comes with arugula.  

Duck Breast and slow roasted duck leg -$24
-Delicious! The duck meat was so tender and juicy. The skin was cooked with just the right crispness and the sauce was great. Good portions. 

Beef short ribs with sweet pea-potato puree -$23
-The short ribs were braised just right. Very tender and juicy also. Sauce is great and the pea-potato puree made the dish even better.

Their Salumi misti is on the SF 7X7 list but I'm not a fan of salami and cured meats so we didn't order it. It's worth a try though!
author: Angela F.

description:
Went here for a nice dinner, nice atmosphere and great service. I ordered the Gnocchi, which isn't either of the versions I am seeing on their menu at the moment. It was good, just not amazing and for the price I would expect amazing. My BF got the Halibut, which according to him was good but again not worth the price. We got the burrata appetizer which was good, especially if you put it on the bread. 

I have been here before for lunch and had the Raviora, which is great, a little sweet but something I would get again. 

Overall good place, but just not amazing.
author: Elise M.

description:
Had dinner tonight and the best part of the evening was our server (very helpful, fun, very tall man) and support staff and the burnt caramel gelato. The food was not up to
what you'd expect given the atmosphere and price point. Shared all plates: hamachi crudo was very bland, pappardelle with short rib didn't have any depth, scallops were good but again, simple. Brussels sprouts had good complexity. Gelato was insanely tasty- creamy and rich flavor. Overall it just wasn't exciting and with a couple glasses of wine each, tab was $110 per person. I've eaten at its sister Barbacco a few times and enjoyed each visit. Go there instead.
author: Shari D.

description: Forget little italy, this place serves probably the best pasta in the country.  made from scratch at the restaurant and flavor is to die for.. Please try the Tajarin and the lamb leg Ragu.   Atmosphere is a bit stuffy, but food scores top
author: Zeo S.

description: Food is consistent, and service is pretty good.  Only a suggestion to change the menu as it's getting stale.  I work a block away and quite often have business lunches and dinners here.  Perhaps that has biased my view about the menu needing updating.
author: Cookie D.

description:
