I must say I was impressed with the service provided! I celebrated a friend's birthday and avoiding the awkward fight about who's going to pay, I called the host (think her name was Olga) to ask if I can just pay in advance and she kindly accepted and made the whole experience the best! 

I know most of you are curious about the food and honestly I was so happy about the service that food was just simply amazing. We shared the cheescake and the pairings were perfect!

I will definitely come back again. Thanks Perbacco for making it such a great experience. :)
author: My N.

description:
Good food, refined tastes. The desserts were somewhat artful in a difficult-to-eat way but we're otherwise beautiful.

The issue I have with perbacco is when I compare it to it's more trendy neighbour barbacco.

Perbacco is the more refined older brother of barbacco and the slight price increase is what separate the clientele who are looking for a slightly quieter and more refined evening.

If you're budget conscious, perbacco is a splurge when you have same quality next door. But excellent when looking for a quiet and refined evening.
author: Chloe A.

description: Came here for leisurely lunch with a friend. At first, the service was paced nicely for us to enjoy the food and chat. Towards the end when we were ready to go back to work though, our server had disappeared and we had to ask 2 other staff on the floor to close out. The food itself was simple Italian. The ravioli was ok. I enjoyed the green strawberries wit burrata and balsamic best.
author: Zara S.

description:
One of my go to's for lunch in the financial district.

 recommendation:

Appetizer
Burrata
Salumi plate

Entree:
Meatballs
Sol (if you prefer fish)

Pasta & desserts: can't go wrong.

Friendly staff, good service.
author: Azizi A.

description: went there for NYE dinner. Service was good. Not sure if the bread is freshly baked though.
author: Lanxing L.

description:
Went here for a dinner date on a Friday night. I was glad I made reservations in advance, because there was a 30-45 minute wait otherwise.

The service and the ambience were nice but my guest and I found the place slightly overpriced for the main dishes (quail and rabaton respectively). Overall, we were glad we came here but probably won't be back.

One caveat: the burrata appetizer was the best burrata dish I've ever had! I really love cheese, so I might consider coming back just for that.
author: Aditi J.

description:
My brother and I were trying to decide on a restaurant for our final dinner in San Francisco, and, as usual, it was taking us hours to finalize a selection.  By the time we had even narrowed down our options, it was pretty late into the evening, so we figured it would be best to dine somewhere near our hotel.  We agreed that Perbacco seemed like a fantastic choice and rushed over to satisfy our growling bellies.

We walked into the elegant dining room, which was quite expansive and extremely packed.  We were seated at a comfortable table and presented with a lengthy wine list.  My glass of 2008 Alto-Adige, Müller Thurgau was crisp and delicious.  Fabulous bread also helped tide us over as we awaited our meal.  

After gazing around at the neighboring tables, we started salivating over the decadent pasta dishes.  Each creation was offered in full or half portions, but we decided to split the larger plate as our starter.  There did not seem to be a poor choice among the bunch, as they were all exquisite and unique.  We settled on the Pappardelle, which was tossed with a short rib puree.  The dish was earthy, savory, and comforting.  My duck entree was equally fabulous.  The meat was lean and perfectly cooked.  I actually exclaimed that it was the most well-prepared duck I have ever tried.  

Unfortunately, our spectacular meal was tarnished by snippy service.  Our waiter was extremely refined and professional, to the point where I contemplated if he disliked us.  He seemed extremely put out all evening, which made us hesitate with our requests for additional bread, and so on.

Regardless of the waiter with the attitude, our meal at Perbacco was delightful.  From the elegant atmosphere to the perfectly cooked cuisine, we were glad that we had made our dinner reservation there.
author: Alison C.

description:
Excellent meal! The dishes were all refined, luxurious, and had moments of genius. Hats off to the chef, who must be a very inspired individual. The ambiance is pleasing and the staff is 5-star. 

Don't leave here without trying the chanterelle stuffed quail, possibly the most delicious thing I have eaten this year.
author: Lucca B.

description:
3.5 stars.  My BFF told me she really likes this place so I made reservations to try it.  
We were impressed with how nice and friendly the front staff and our waiter were.
Even as we left after dinner, no less than 4 of their staff thanked us and said good-bye.  

I particularly liked the Summer in SF cocktail, $12 with Pimm's and peach or apricot. Hubby enjoyed his glass of cab sauvigonon, $14. 
We were started off with thin bread sticks and pesto dipping sauce and then great French bread rolls with butter. 
Appetizers shared by 4:
1. Fritto misto shrimp with olives, green beans, $15. Not too oily but we didn't like the green olives no matter how much you batter and fry it. Might not order again.
2. Pork belly, $15.  A 4 in long, about 2 inch thick piece of pork belly.  It was just about 1 bite for the 4 of us. 
Entrees:
1.  The agnolotti pasta with "meat" was ordered by 2, $20/each. It was chewy like a gnocchi and shaped rectangular with lots of sauce.  It was OK.
2. Duck breast - 2 thick slices of med rare breasts were tender and very good and came with a  side of salad, $30.
3. Beef short rib, $34 came with one large short rib and slices of pork. Not enough for a Jr. Yelper to eat, who welcomed shared food from our plates.
Desserts shared by 4:
1. Cheesecake $11, was OK.  Not my favorite but the tiny scoop of apricot sorbet was really good. 
2. Bonet, $11, chocolate mousse like cake.  Chunks of crunchy meringue was interesting.

The diners next to us looked like they had a veal pasta which I might've liked as well. The only disappointment was when Hubby didn't finish his entree and was saving room for dessert and asked the busboy to box the rest to take home and eat later.  The staff didn't bring the leftovers to the table and he had forgotten about it until we got home.  He was a tad upset that had happened.  Nice ambience, decent food but didn't really "wow" me.
author: Ry T.

description:
This place completely surprised me. Went  here randomly after the place we initially wanted to go to was crowded. Absolutely spectacular service. Everyone was so helpful and attentive. Really A+. Ive gone to Michelin star restaurants with less stellar service.

I had the foie and the raviolia (I am not spelling that right). The foie came with figs and fig jam with some sort of hazelnut puree. Divine.  The raviolia was meyer lemon ricotta drenched in an absolutely amazing butter sauce. I just had such a nice time, great ambiance, great food and amazing staff. Will be coming back!
author: jac n.

description:
I ordered the 5-hour pork sugo with tagliatelle noodle and a porcini mushroom sauce.  DELICIOUS!  

The portion size was perfect, I ate the entire dish for lunch, and I forgot about the surrounding business meetings taking place around me.  The dish was not salty, which I had expected with the 5 hour title but it was so nicely seasoned.  The pasta did not take over the sauce because the noodle is so thin -- perfect.  I rarely order pork but would order this dish again, for sure.

I then ordered the pear gelato, and the flavor is brow-raising.  yum.  They make their gelato in house, and the two soft cookies are nice companions to the dessert.  I was glad I didn't pass on the dessert for a nice change.

I don't remember the server, unfortunately, but I will say that the details were all there.  No mess ups on our order, and our check arrived quickly enough for us to have a one-hour lunch despite the bustling business.  

I would recommend Perbacco for a business lunch because I like the noise level (medium) and I love the interesting menu that always requires me to ask several questions.  Creative menu!
author: Julie W.

description:
Great service, fantastic meal.

We came here to celebrate a birthday and as soon as we were shown to our table, we found a card on the table. They took the time to write a nice message along with the bday wish. Very nice touch.

The salumi misti platter was pretty cool. There were about 10 varieties on the platter. They explained what each one is and how it was prepared.

We also had the fritto misto, roasted octopus, and raviolo. They were all good, not great.

We went with the Tris pasta tasting ($19/pp). It was pretty hard to understand from just reading the menu. It's basically, a pasta sampler platter for each person. Everyone at the table will get the same platter with the same three pastas. It's basically reverse family style. The table agrees to 3 pasta dishes and the kitchen will divide it evenly for each person. When the platters come out, each person will have 3 varieties on their own plate. It was pretty cool and pretty good. 

Being that I just went to Flour + Water, I have to say Flour + Water's pasta is better however the overall experience was better at Perbacco. In terms of service, appetizers, desserts and drinks.

When it was time for desserts, the kitchen sent us a gift, it was meringue cookies. I usually don't like meringue but these were amazing. They were delicious!  We ordered the caramel gelato and panna cotta. Everything came with cookies and they were really the standouts of the night.

All in all, a wonderful experience.
author: Andy W.

description:
For a $$$ restaurant, I wasn't that impressed. Presentation was great, food was "meh" at most, and portions were small. Don't come here if you're hungry; we went to the McDonald's around the corner afterwards.

We ordered octopus to share as an appetizer and got a single tentacle that was cut up in to five pieces. Practically nothing. It was also a bit more on the rubbery side than what I'm used to. Portion size applied to all of the plates we got.

Service wasn't too great either. I felt that the waiter was judging us based on our wine selection and time to order (not long in my opinion). He could have had a better attitude.
author: Michael S.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco---and that's saying a lot! My last visit was with a group of six. We shared, so everyone could have a variety of tastes. EVERYTHING was excellent--seriously!
author: Eileen R.

description: Good place to take clients for a business lunch. Would probably not be back otherwise. I like the food but just didn't have that wow factor for me. Nice ambiance and good service.
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Like a long lost love who comes back into your life. Perbacco has made a major come back into mine.

It has been a while since I've dined here, honestly I cannot even remember when it was but it has been at least a year. I've always enjoyed some amazing meals here, but started to take it for granted and just knew that at some point I would be making a return visit. And last night was exactly that. A true sublime reconnection. A night that for the first time in years, I would actually clean my plate.

A group of four, 6:15 reservations and cocktails in hand we were ready to party and be treated to huge meal that would rival Thanksgiving. And yes, in my opinion we did order way too much, but when 99.99 percent of the menu offerings sound absolutely delicious what are you supposed to do? 

Marie and my wife are fans of beets. Markus and I hate those stupid things so we got the burrata and heirloom tomato starter. Our appetizer was amazing, but I must admit those beets looked awfully tasty, and was tempted to pry one of those away. So as of right now, I am officially still president of the "I hate beets" club, but on my next visit I am going to take a chance and put one of those purple slimy things in mouth and see what happens. 

Four mains to share,

1. Pork shoulder with polenta and turnip. Good? YES! and I am now a former member of the "I hate turnip" club.

2. Risotto with wile mushrooms. My favorite of the evening. Complex flavors with a hint of Gorgonzola. The cheese was not on the menu description, but it was there i just know it.

3. Gnocchi with toasted walnuts. Mixed reviews at the table, but I thought they were perfectly executed. 

4. Tajarin,  tagliatelle noodles with a rich pork sugo sauce. This has always been a staple here and it always found a way to our table. But last night it missed the mark. There was no problem with the pork sugo sauce, but the problem is that there simply wasn't enough of it. May not be part of the future rotation.

Two desserts to share.

1.Gelato with sea salt. So good we fought over the last bite

2. Gianduja. Dark chocolate, hazelnut and praline bar. Also served with a sea salted gelato. OMG! Yes, it was amazing.

Cheese course to share.

1. La Tur. One of my all time favorites, creamy goat cheese. Try it with honey.

2. CAPRIAGO, BOHEMIAN CREAMERY, SONOMA (had to copy and paste that). Made a nice compliment to the La Tur, a hint of nutty (think softer Parmesan).

Wine, a $45 dollar bottle from sardinia that was a bargain.

Dessert wine, PAYS D'AUGE, 6 ANS D'AGE, ADRIEN CAMUT. At $16 a glass it isn't cheap, but deep dark and delicious. Would get it again in a second.

In the end , Perbacco has not missed a beat. They still churn out some of the best Northern Italian cuisine in all of San Francisco. Great night out with two really great people and my wife course. I cannot wait to make a return visit.

4 1/2 stars.
author: Rene C.

description: Good pasta and very flavorful. The only thing was our duck wansovercooked and but dry, but overall a nice place with pretty interiors.
author: Ying Z.

description:
Long over due, but this place was the bomb. A new twist on Italian cuisine that is rather different than most I've tried. Unfortunately, it's been a while since I've been back to this place to give a full on detailed opinion, but from what I remember, it was great. 

The staff was really friendly and knew their menu, and the food was delectable. The one thing I can't get over is that ooey, gooey fig cake; you can't miss dessert here.

In terms of food, their bruchetta's (sp?) are really good, especially the one with mushrooms. I also had a mushroom risotto which was really earthy and warm. My mother had a sort of pasta that had a pesto sauce which was great too. 

And, for being an "expensive" restaurant, the value and the price was actually not as expensive as we thought, even with appetizer, entree, and dessert with wine!
author: Bahar A.

description:
Items selected:

Grissini with Olive and Cilantro
Warm Focaccia with Butter
Stracci - Spinach Rags, Devils Gulch Rabbit Ragu, Golden Chanterelles, Peas and Carrots
Coujette - Occitaine Potato Gnocchi, Liberty Farm Duck Ragu, Roasted Cherries
Bombolini - Candy Cap Donuts, Green Strawberry Compote, Douglas Fir Crema, Warm Summer Berries
Burnt Caramel Gelato with Pine Nut Cookies

Largely replicating the dining path of the day prior due to convenience, lunch amongst the power brokers on Tuesday saw me seated at a hightop near the front of Italian stalwart Perbacco.  Ostensibly a modernized take on Piemontese and Ligurian cuisine from Nordic chef Staffan Terje the first thing that struck me upon walking in was the impressive size of the restaurant and the seemingly 1:2 ratio of servers to tables assuring that each and every diner is never for want, a particularly good thing for keeping the water and bread basket clean in such a busy space and all the more so when my server, Christopher, explained to me that most plates could be ordered in half portions thus opening up my options substantially.  Clearly the sort of place where a lunch could be leisurely or fit within the typical lunch hour it would not be long after my focaccia arrived that the first of two pastas would come, in this case the rich and earthy stracci, and close on its heels three of my favorite things all on one plate; tender gnocchi, supple duck, and sweet cherries - a 'best of' dish on a trip with many and good enough that I actually requested a second demi-portion that arrived fifteen minutes later - a decision I'd regret only slightly when I realized there were at least four desserts I wanted to taste, instead limiting myself to the truly fascinating sweet mushroom donuts filled with green strawberry jam...plus a scoop of intense caramel gelato flecked with smoked sea salt rounding out a truly excellent lunch.
author: Michael U.

description:
We heard that this restaurant was quite good from a friend so we decided to give it a try. I went with both of my parents and had a reservation for dinner on August 2nd. We had the salumi platter, fritto misto, braised rabbit, duck breast, and short rib beef.

Everything tasted very delicious but what killed the whole evening was the waiter. He was especially rude to my disabled mother. 

We didn't order any alcoholic drinks and that is when the "attitude" started. He then asked us in a sarcastic way, "Are you going to order ANYTHING?". He would then continue to just stand there and not speak and made it extremely awkward. Acting like Lurch from the Adam's Family, he would creep up behind my dad and put his face right next to my dad's ear to whisper creepily, "How was your meal?", which startled my dad.

At first I thought maybe that's just how the waiter was and then as I watched him interact with other customers I noticed he was MUCH more accommodating to them because they had ordered alcohol. The whole experience was extremely uncomfortable and I couldn't wait to get out of there. 

Bottom Line: I would never go back and I would only recommend it to my enemies.
author: Nicole H.

description: delishhhhhhhhhhhhhh will definitely return for the pastas and other dishes, great ambiance, superb wine selections
author: Jeene L.

description: Fantastic ambience and the staff were extremely helpful and thoughtful. Came here for my girlfriend's birthday and they had a wonderful card and desert for her. The Risotto here is the best I've ever had and the presentation is on point.
author: Harrison Y.

description:
I've been here twice for drinks and apps, and I love it. All the food I've tried here has been absolutely delicious, and the wine tasty as well. Would definitely like to come back for a full dinner sometime.

Favorite dish was the raviola appetizer. Had it the first time I came, tried to get it again the second time but ended up with a different type of ravioli dish (one I loved was one large ravioli, the second one I tried was good, but not the same. Several small raviolis). Also love the frito misto app (had it both times!).

Staff is friendly, last time I was there our server even split the ravioli small plate we'd ordered onto two plates for us without asking.
author: Krista S.

description:
overall pretty good but the tagliatelle with the sugo was not impressive.
Tajarin -- handcut tagliatelle (version was so thin and stringy)
5 hr pork and porcini mushroom sugo -- don't order this
Pappardelle -- short rib ragu with grated horseradish -- this was good
*Brasato Braised Shortrib of Beef, Roasted Cipolline, Sweet Corn Polenta, Celery Leaf and Radish Salad
*Seared Sea Scallops with Roasted Lobster Mushrooms, Braised Little Gem Lettuce, Red Wine Butter
not too creative but good.  The risotto sauce was interesting and tasty with fresh roasted peach bits, duck conserva, basil, manodori balsalmico
author: Rob C.

description: Food was on the Mark for a highly recommended restaurant.  The hostess had no problem moving us to a less cramped table against the wall.  Lively atmosphere and not as noisy as expected.  The octopus appetizer was perfectly prepared.  The two entrees, Black Sea bass and scallops, though not a traditional Italian dish that sets expectations, exceeded any expectation of having perfectly seasoned fresh seafood.  Wine list is extensive.  A unique system allows them to serve wine by the glass without uncorking a bottle.  Didn't try it, but suggested wines paired well.  Desserts were good.  Love panna cotta but not sure how I feel about thyme lemon panna cotta yet.
author: Mike W.

description:
Awesome night at Perbacco celebrating my sister's elopement.  We sat in the upstairs private dining area and had our own little area that over looked the kitchen... What a treat.  We all started off with some excellent Italian Red Wine (to die for actually)... and the mushroom risoto balls, along with the yellowtail with radishes and other delicious accoutrements.   

Our 2nd course was Perbacco's specialty meat platter, with lots of varieties of pate, salamis, prosciutto and more.   The meat plates were eaten up quickly.  After the meat we had the salad course.  It was a simple salad with delicious tomoatos, grapefruit and nuts.  What a wonderfully light salad to start off the pasta dish.  

For the pasta we had the gnocchi with mushroom cream sauce, and a risoto with a delicious white wine sauce.  The pasta dish was amazing.  I am not a huge pasta fan, but it was great.  The entree we had a choice between duck and seabass and I had the seabass.  It was done perfectly.  What a great piece of fish.

To top it all off we had a nice dessert along with tea, coffee and more wine.  Perbacco was more than accommodating to our small wedding party of 14.

It was truly a lovely evening.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I guess I'm not a fan of salumi!  I know there's a lot of technique in preparing and curing meats, combining spices, etc - an old school thing.  But for the life of me, I just couldn't get into it.

We started with the salumi misti served with grissini - four types of salumi, pickles, chutney and bread sticks.  The sweet chutney and pickles complemented the salumi well, but my limited palette would not be able to distinguish Grocery Store packaged salami from what was on my plate.  I assume others are able to distinguish the difference....

For the main, I had the Hangar Steak medium rare.  The steak was accompanied by roasted vidalia onions, fingerling potatoes, arugula, and salsa verde.  Very nice dish, but hey...it's Hangar Steak which is not a complex dish.

Concluded with a warm Gianduja Cake with a side of toasted meringue.  The cake had a nice warm gooey middle; however, the meringue was slightly hard and chewy..possibly sat on the plate a little too long awaiting the addition of the warm cake.

The service was excellent and the decor modern and upscale.

I'm just not into lunch meats....
author: Scott L.

description:
Expectations are everything, and mine were high for Perbacco. It's one of a few places in SF that's been on my list for several years after multiple people recommend it and after reading strong reviews and learning about the pedigree and style here. So my wife and I finally had a chance to go this week for a casual dinner outing. 

The ambiance is lovely and the service is really top notch. The waitstaff was friendly, helpful, and present. Our main waiter was definitely a pro -- good stuff. I'll say the menu is fantastic as well, although the pastas and mains were largely meaty. There were plenty of creative and delicious sounding choices, especially on the appetizer list. However, before I got to the main menu, I started with the wine list. Lovely collection, but the wine prices were incredibly pretentious. I know there's a lot of markup for restaurant wine and they need to make some money here, but this list and the prices are bordering on the ridiculous. 

We ordered an Italian wine at the lower-to-mid range of prices. As expected, it was drinkable, but mediocre (actually, appalling for the price, but whatever -- I don't think we would've found better value in a different selection since it was all overpriced).

As for food: our apps were nice, especially the frito misto, but nothing spectacular. And sorry, but the mains were just so-so. I had a squid ink cavatelli with octopus and urchin that sounded amazing on paper, but just didn't come together for me on the plate. It was tough, unloved, and the entire dish, bland. I am a very low sodium user -- many dishes that would pass the normal palette taste too salty to me. But for the first time in recent memory, I actually had to salt my restaurant food here. In the end, sensing my dissatisfaction, our waiter took a few dollars off the bill and added some complimentary cookies to our dessert order. 

Which brings me to the highlight of the meal: dessert. Again, the menu was great -- good choices and quite creative. We ordered the salted dark chocolate bonet. It's was huge, and very yummy -- almost redeeming the rest of the meal! My wife commented that we should just come back here for dessert only sometime when we have that late evening hankering for some yummy sweets. 

And indeed, I'm not likely to go back soon except maybe for dessert, unless someone tells me I hit a bad night or I picked the wrong menu items. Too many other great places to eat around here, and way better things to spend my money on than a so-so meal.
author: J S.

description:
We went here for a friend's bday dinner.  Because the rest of our party had not arrived, we were largely ignored after we got our drinks and bread.  Flagging down the waiter to order was much more complicated than say airmen signaling an aircraft.  Man, that guy cannot crack a smile.  He took our order like a robot.  After a long work week, I would have appreciated a grin even if it's forced.  Service with a smile is your job, no?

The black sea bass (with wild mushroom asparagus ragout, potatoes, and spring onions, $26) were good but the skin nicely crisped, but the ragout was overly salty in my opinion.  At least my portion was sizable compared to the small piece of salmon others got.

The one shining item was the almond brown butter cake for dessert ($9).  It had a nice crust and the right amount of sweetness.  If I hadn't stuffed myself with bread while waiting for the waiter to come take our order, I would've had more room than just one bite.
author: Melinda Y.

description:
I've only dined at this restaurant once. My younger brother made reservations for two, on my birthday a couple of years back. Oh. My. Fucking. Dog. TIMES 1 Google.

Yea. EVERYTHING is Oh. My. Fucking. Dog.

EVERYTHING. just EVERYTHING. 

Service: Oh, my, fucking, dog.
Ambiance: Oh, my, fucking dog.
Food: DROOOOOOOOOOLINGGGG as I say on my hind legs... OH, MY, FUCKING, DOG.

yes. five stars and then some.
author: Hannah Y.

description: Great place if you're around the financial district. I ordered the tajarin with veal and it was delicious. I highly recommend this place
author: Mark M.

description: We celebrated our 21st  anniversary.  The food, service snd atmosphere were wonderful. We will be back.
author: Patricia G.

description:
This place is great.  Group of 7 for dinner on a Saturday night

First, service is simply outstanding.  If you want to be pampered, then make a reservation.  This place really knows how to take care of their customers

Food is outstanding.  Everything we ordered was great.  Roasted  cauliflower and  radicchio salad appetizer was crazy good.

Dessert - Almond Brown Butter Cake.  This is an eye rolling, lip smacking, get your moan on type of dessert.  Look at the ingredients - there is nothing to not like...

Get on down here

TIP:  If you cannot get into Perbacco, then make a reservation next door at Barbacco (sister location)  Another excellent choice
author: Robert H.

description:
Best pasta in SF.  Seriously my girlfriend and I still talk about how amazing it was, a year later.  And we eat well, a lot.  I'm so glad that Eater SF recommended it.

The location is a bit corporate but OMG so good.  And the service was impeccable (And I'm extremely critical about service).
author: Jon E.

description: The food here is ok. Not anything great. The service is very good. It's not a place I would return to or recommend.
author: Andrew M.

description: One of my fave places in the city. The pastas are off the hook. Two thumbs up!! Their menus are seasonal so things never get old. Can't wait yo go back.
author: Sahar B.

description:
perbacco was a great experience. i came here the other night after wanting to come here for years! the breadsticks with the parsley sauce is so good - my boyfriend was literally trying to drink it.

we ordered:
"two minute ceviche" of nantucket bay scallops / sea urchin citronette / grapefruit
roasted baby beets / blood orange / marinated fennel / mandarin vinaigrette / wild fen
raviora - pasta filled with fennel scented ricotta / orange-mint butter / shaved citron
piastra roasted octopus / olive oil crushed potatoes / celery heart / salsa verde

each of these were awesome.... the ceviche might have been the highlight though. i've never had scallops that are so tender!

my only complaint and reason for not giving it 5 stars is that the server seemed bored/ annoyed with us. not sure why... who knows, maybe it wasn't even us!
author: Taylor L.

description: I have been here several times for both lunch and dinner, and always enjoy it. Very good food, excellent service, nice wine list, good atmosphere, and the price is quite reasonable given the quality and amenities.
author: Jethro B.

description:
I am Italian and I love Perbacco! 
Perbacco is an exclamation similar to "mamma mia" but calling "Bacco" the ancient roman god of the wine and harvest, coming from the greek Dioniso. 

I know what to taste to evaluate the quality of Italian restaurants and belive me everything was extraordinary! 
Is rare to eat so well also in Italy, so go to Perbacco once, twice and again..
author: Leo J.

description: I had grilled octopus leg for appetizer, duck breast for entry and paired with wine. Very generous portion on entry, grilled octopus is one of the best I had. Price is on the expensive range but well worth the price.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Excellent restaurant in FIDI. I came here for lunch and was impressed. The décor is upscale modern. Lots of dining space upstairs, but we were seated in the front dining area. Noise level is a little high, but in the booth we had no problem hearing each other. 
Service is top notch. Very attentive and not annoying.  
I enjoyed the coujette - a garlic  potato gnocchi with beef sugo and chanterelles. Simply delicious! I paired this with their hazelnut butter glazed carrots. 
Another Yelper notes that this place is full of "pretty" people. It's true! I didn't see anyone that was not good looking and well groomed/dressed. . .
author: Greg S.

description: So Perbacco was very good but not over the top. My vegie wife's gnocci needed a bit of seasoning as did the pork on papardelli pasta..very good but not over the top
author: Frank P.

description:
This is a great restaurant. We stopped by since it was about two blocks from our hotel. The service was OK, it was a bit slow but we were not in a hurry. 
Their cocktails were pretty nice! One of the best dirty martini's I've had. 
The food was great. Well prepared and nicely presented. The server was very helpful too. I thought the prices were reasonable for their quality of the food and also the portions that they serve. The place was packed but we got seated pretty quickly even though we did not have a reservation!
author: Sonya M.

description: Great food, quick service. Came here for dinner on a Saturday night and the place was packed by 6:30. We ordered the lemon ravioli and the duck breast, both were excellent. For dessert we had the panna cotta and bread pudding, which were exceptional, I think I liked desert better than the meal. The only complaint I have is the portions are pretty small, after splitting the main courses and having dessert I was still a bit hungry.
author: Matt G.

description:
I don't know why I came here for the white truffle season since my last meal before that at Perbacco was so mediocre. 

My first experience was great but after that it all went downhill....
author: Cha C.

description:
My wife and I have eaten at Perbacco in the past and have been pleased.  However, this visit we were disappointed.  For the price, the menu needs help.  It almost appears that the chef is trying too hard to have unusual entrees.  This is not the place if you are looking for an excellent steak, seafood or real Italian dishes.  

Everything from the appetizers to the main entrees is a little like the Iron Chef ingredients.  We dine in the City often and will not return to Perbacco.  Obviously, it is rated highly by several diners, but fell way short in our opinion.  

We had a party of six and to a person, we were looking at each other wondering what has gone wrong with this restaurant.  My recommendation is to delete a number of items on the menu and add a nice steak, seasonal sea food and some traditional Italian dishes.  Completely change the  appetizer menu.  We ordered a couple items and to be honest, they were hardly edible.
author: Thomas H.

description:
I went here for a customer product review last night. The event was very well executed at Perbacco and I would recommend it for a business meeting of 9-15. 

We arrived, checked our bags, and went upstairs to the room that had been well prepared for us. Champagne greeted us at the entry way and a working table was set up complete with video projector. Had some time to network and enjoy some fabulous apps. About 8 different choices came out and they were easily edible with your fingers in 1-2 bites. Each item was plated beautifully and sophisticated in taste and texture. (fig, prosciutto & blue cheese, mushroom risotto ball, grilled shrimp with amazing dipping sauce, hamachi, burrata with tomato & basil)

After the working part of the meeting we had a four course meal: Octopus, strawberry arugula salad, scallops and panna cotta. (The other alternative was braised short rib which looked amazing too.) Service was great, the food was awesome and the space well suited to what we were doing. Nice and private.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Man, I had really high hopes for this place but it turned out to be a total letdown. Nice ambiance though. 

Things that went wrong:
-Had a reservation for 6 at 8:30PM, didn't get seated until 9PM (understandable, it's a Friday night)
-Took 20 min to take our drink orders, then another 20 to take our actual orders. THEN it took almost 1 hour to get our food. We sat down at 9PM but we didn't finish until 11:30PM (because our food didn't come until 11PM). 
-The food was okay but it wasn't anything great. Everyone at the table was pretty indifferent to the food (and no, we weren't drunk). Personally for me, the presentation was a little off-putting for the risotto. They basically brought out a big plate and it covered the ENTIRE plate. I guess it shows me how much food there was but it looked like a nasty pancake. The risotto was just okay--however, the duck in it was pretty good. 

I don't know if it was the super long wait or what, but man, I was pretty disappointed by this place. Everything was just meh.
author: Diana Y.

description:
It's really JUST ok, and I would not go back.  It's expensive, service (even at a non-busy time!) was SUPER slow, and the waiter was rude and stuck up and just...acted weird every time we asked him (very politely!) for something normal.  We were like scared to ask him for anything bc he would give us weird attitude.  

More importantly, the food is not as good as it sounds or looks.  I was disappointed, bc the descriptions on the menu and the photos on yelp make it look so good.  It is surprisingly less tasty than it looks (which is a weird thing Ive never really come across before....) 

So, good job, Perbacco at making menus that sound enticing and food that LOOKS yummy...
author: Gwen Y.

description:
This place offers some serious Italian dining. I tried many of the dishes here on my recent trip to SF...so here we go.

Salumi - got a small sampler that was more than enough for 3 people (when combined with another appetizer). Everything tasted really good, and there is one raw meat on the sampler (salsiccia cruda di bra) which was definitely the fave

Burrata Cheese - my favorite appetizer by far (don't know about the seafood stuff since I don't eat seafood). The burrata was perfect and was seasoned very smartly with the persimmon and pomegranate

Agnolotti Dal Plin - It had like a slightly sour taste..maybe from the cabbage, but was hearty and delicious.

Tajarin - Felt like it was fancy ramen served on a hearty meat sauce. It was still very good

Pappardelle - This was pretty standard, though delicious still

Coujette - the gnocchi was probably the best of all the dishes tried. Very good flavor. 

Desserts - Tried Semifreddo and the Kaffir Lime Panna Cotta. Both were delicious and thoughtfully created.

Service was very attentive, ambiance was great for a work or a dinner date.
author: Ed H.

description:
I came here about four years and many, many meals ago. My friend and I were not impressed, though the food was decent. She made a very funny and frank observation - "I could be eating this or I could be eating instant ramen... And really, I'd feel the same about it." I sort of agree. She didn't mean that the food, which is leagues above an instant ramen, tasted bad. We like Nissin. It just wasn't exciting or amazeballs. It's what you'd expect, no more, no less, and you could eat it while watching Bravo because you're not going to pay attention. 

We had ordered an appetizer and two entrees (both protein dishes). Even places I've been to once, if the dish was really good or really bad, I'd remember it. My best memory of this place is essentially my friend's comment.

If I went back, and I have been trying to find an opportunity (tried to do the bf's bday here but party grew too large), I'd order pasta instead because good pasta is hard to find. 

I do have a feeling though that when I come back and try the right dishes, this is a 4-5 star place.
author: Erika C.

description:
I love this place! It's sooooooo good. Quality for sure. Service was impeccable (I don't usually use that word but hey I needed something extraordinary).

Side note: Since I fell in love with this place the first time I wanted to celebrate my bday here this year however they are all booked! Seee I told you they're good.

First of all our server was super smart, nice, considerate, professional, understanding and welcoming. I came here with two other friends and we each ordered our entrees as well as sides. Usually when you go to restaurants such as Perbacco the sides are tiny which is why we all ordered two sides for ourselves. Our server let us know that the sides are huge and basically are considered family style. How nice is that? She let us know and was super chill.

On to the food:

They start you off with super fluffy soft focaccia bread, yummy bread sticks with pesto sauce. All totally worth eating.

Short Ribs Pappardelle:  Order this! This was such an amazing dish. The short ribs were super tender and the pappardelle (pasta) was very fresh and melt in your mouth amazing!

Petrale Sole over arugala and cherry tomatoes: Sounds super simple and it is but they cook this so well it tastes so good. They give you a really good portion. Delicious.

Pan Seared Hanger Steak: Beautiful dish and very good if you're really hungry!

Sides: 
Potatoes: YUM
Brussel Sprouts: Again very good
Turnips: Not so much, lol but that could be due to the nature of this vegetable in general
Carrots: great!

Dessert:
Candied Hazelnut Cake with poached pears and pear sorbetto: Must get this, I mean who woulda thought...pear sorbetto (yums!)

Luv this place!
author: Christina M.

description:
I wish this got a better rating. It was fine, but I felt like service wasn't great, both in getting us seated, and the waiter. To be fair, it was lunchtime rush, but if you're running a restaurant, that should be planned for.

As far as the menu, the ingredients and descriptions sounded good, but the ingredients tasted a bit flat, like they forgot to salt it. It wasn't bad, but it was a bit of a bummer because it seems like it should have been better.

I'd eat here again, but I wouldn't tell my friends "you've *got* to go here"
author: Tim R.

description:
So I finally had dinner at Perbacco yesterday, I've been wanting to visit for quite some time.  The interior is really nice, upscale, and has a casual elegant atmosphere.  For a Tuesday night, I was surprised how crowded it was, so my suggestion is to always make reservations.  Now onto the meal:

-Salumi Misti (a selection of house cured meats)- OMG, this was great! The smaller version comes with 3 types of salami, 3 types of house made pate on crispy bread, a piece of terrine, and two different kinds of lardo.  My favorite was definitely the pork terrine, I think I am now a terrine addict.  Accompanied with the house made bread, this is a meal within itself. YUM.

-Farfalle Nere (squid ink pasta and crispy octopus)- I've had squid ink pasta in NYC before and it was delicious. So I couldn't pass up the opportunity to be adventurous and order it again.  They did a great job, the farfalle was perfectly "al-dente." and the pasta tasted fresh from the sea. The octopus was perfectly cooked, tender and with a slight bounce in the bite.

-Pappardelle (wide pasta with slow cooked short rib ragu)- Tasty! I've had this dish many times at other restaurants and homemade as well, it's ALWAYS a winner. It taste good and feels comforting.  The short ribs were tender and sauce was flavorful with accents of sweetness and savory.  

-Meyer Lemon Panna Cotta w/ Rosemary shortbread- I am already a big fan of panna cotta and with the meyer lemon it was the perfect end to the meal.  The panna cotta was light and creamy and combined with the huckleberry compote, it had the perfect finish.  We shared the dessert because the two pastas had us on "carbo load." My friend really liked the Rosemary shortbread cookies, I agree they were really good. Perbacco should think about selling them in bulk, I know at least two people that would buy that!

This place is definitely great and the price is reasonable for the amount of food. Its always great to share, especially when its Italian food, there are so many appealing choices.
author: D C.

description:
Conclusion of the meal: empty plates, empty glasses, and surprisingly still a half full wallet. 

Fast service, delicious cocktails and pastas that bring a tear to your eye. 

Atmosphere is cool and relaxed. Come for a date night or a casual evening of drinks with friends. 

This place is a must!
author: Whitney P.

description: Went to perbacco a couple weeks ago to celebrate a colleague's work anniversary.  The restaurant had a big lunch crowd so I was glad that I made reservation in advance.  I ordered a duck confit for lunch and it was probably the best one I had in the recent years.  It was seasoned and cooked perfectly.  The duck was crispy on the outside and fell off bone tender inside.  The flavor was excellent and consistent throughout. We also ordered dessert.  While the dessert did not disappoint with creativity and flavor, the portion was small.  I finished it in 2 or 3 bites.  Overall, I would definitely go back again and will make sure to make reservation if I do.
author: Happy L.

description:
The one thing I hate about Italian restaurants is the pronunciation. I always have the impression that the accents are the same as Spanish accents. Is that the case? No. Me always gets to look stupid. Sadface.

I never had noticed Perbacco until the St. Patty's Day block party, while I was walking to Wayfare (which was full, so I ended up at Wexler's). I came in search of a Bellini, only to find a Bellisimo. I can't remember what was in it (champagne, blood orange, etc.), but it was enough to make me return for another.

My first experience here was nothing memorable. Bartenders loitered around the place and conversed among themselves. I sat at the bar on a Friday evening, ready to fill my spacious tummy with lots of unhealthy goodies. By the end, my tummy was only halfway filled and my wallet was $75 emptier. Sheesh. I really liked my raviolo, but just one? C'mon, I'm dying of hunger! Boo. My halibut was good, but I still craved more raviolo. Raviolo was truffley, yolky, goodness. For dessert, I had the bonet, which I didn't really like. It was like chocolate pudding with some caramel sauce and whipped cream. Bleh. By the end? I ended up eating dinner part two at another restaurant in the area.

I remember the second time a bit differently, but it could have been from the Bellisimos and champagne. The atmosphere was different. A good different. They served focaccia instead of the hard, tooth-chipping bread they served during dinner. I requested the bar menu in hopes of having some truffled egg toast, but it wasn't on the menu anymore. Sadface. I simply ordered the Catelvetrano olives with the burrata cheese. Holy ravivioli, pat me on the back! You have to try the burrata cheese, you just have to! Wow.

There was a man next to me who kept me company. He raved about their meatballs, he even let me sample some of his dish. I still thought the burrata cheese was a better choice, though (:

For dessert, I had chocolate mousse. It was so much better than the bonet, I swear on the holy grail. I let my companion have a taste, to which he said, "Mmmm!" He's not even a dessert person, proof that you should get the mousse!

On top of that, the bartender was this amicable little Spanish man. He was always very attentive to everyone's needs and made sure we were all happy. We talked about Quince, which was how I found out that I had been pronouncing it incorrectly. Boo.

Someone mentioned finding a cockroach. Well, I found a translucent red bug (about the size of an ant) on the side of my burrata plate. I wasn't sure if it came with the plate, or if it had gotten on there afterwards, but it doesn't distract from how good the burrata cheese is. GET THE BURRATA CHEESE! Oh, and pair it with a Bellisimo.

Perbacco, please bring back the truffled egg toast so I can try it. Please please please please please!
author: Elaine N.

description:
I recently had one of the worst pastas I've ever had in my life- no exaggeration- at what I thought was one of the better Italian restaurants in the city. 

The dinner started out good for our party of 6. 
Service was attentive, drinks were yummy. 

The salumi platter we had as our shared  appetizer  was pretty tasty save for an overly pungent pate. 

Then it kinda went downhill from there. 
More than half the table got individual appetizers of Summer melons which the server did a great job of over-selling to us. 
Don't get me wrong, the 4 slices of melons were super juicy. 
For $14. 
Ummm, what? 
Sure there was shaved parm on it making it somewhat diff (but not necessarily tasty). But the price was exorbitant and my 4 year old goddaughter could have plated it much better. 
The melons were just thrown on a plate.

Then came my 2 entrees; I ordered the smaller portion of the Tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo and the Agnolotti del pin. 

The moment the server set the tagliatelle down, I was like...is that the tagliatelle?!? He very apprehensively said 'yes'; which makes me think I'm not the first person to ask that question.
The tagliatelle was cut so thin, it looked like a plate of cheap instant college ramen, topped with chef boyardee canned sauce sitting on a bed of oil.
But I thought, oh well, I'll give it a try. 
I was horrified. 
It tasted worst than it looked. 
The tagliatelle was overcooked, the sauce was terrible; it tasted like canned sauce and where was the porcini mushroom?
I can't imagine Anyone thinks this is a good pasta dish- Perbacco really needs to remove this from the menu. 

Someone else in my party ordered the tagliatelle as a bigger entree and only took 3 bites; the poor girl went home starving. The look of disgust on her face said it all. 
Inattentive of the server not to have noticed the almost-full dish. Bad call. 

The agnolotti was passably better. 
Having just had Flour + Water's melt in your mouth flavorful Agnolotti recently, this was a subpar version. The pasta was too hard, it wasn't tasty and it was disappointing. 
I finished the dish only coz I was famished and couldn't eat the ramen disguised as tagliatelle. 

The dessert was also disappointing. I really wanted to wash my taste buds from the terrible pasta entrees but the bambolinis were filled with some tart nasty jelly that tasted like a cross between kiwi and kumquat. 
Why, Perbacco??? Why????

If it wasn't for the fact that I was at a biz dinner with acquaintances i just met, i would have sent the dishes back. Thank goodness I didn't have to pay a single cent for dinner. 

I'm a fan of Barbacco, but sorry Perbacco, I cannot come by again.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: It's a perfectly average-looking place. The food was only OK. The menu didn't seem to offer anything truly inspiring. We shared a pork belly app to start. I was expecting that crackle glaze top but it was absent. Too bad; it's the best part. But then again I don't recall if the menu description included that. It's just that that's the only way I've been served this dish. My main course was the seared scallops. It was actually very nice. I guess my big objection here was the price. Dinner plus a glass of wine and a cocktail came to $200. Just not worth it.
author: Paula H.

description:
I would give Perbacco 6 stars if I could!

"Perbacco" is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.  Copied this straight from their website.  The restaurant lives upto their name!

A group of us came here for lunch and so I had bites of most of the dishes.  Appetizer:  veal slices with lemon and albacore sauce with capers and some micro sprouts (radish?), grilled squid, greens salad with very light lemony vinaigrette, brussel sprouts with carmelized shallots.  Mains:  ravioli with meyer lemon and ricotta, tagliatelle, truffle with herb gnocchi with wild mushrooms, lamb stew in white sauce, and pappardelle with braised short ribs.  It was all very very delicious!  I loved the gnocchi and tagliatelle.

All their pastas are made by hand on site.  You can taste the freshness and the fine ingredients.

Ask for breadsticks and foccacia -- latter was delish!

Their food is regional - both Piedmont and Liguria so lots of fresh seafood dishes on their menu.  The wine list is huge.  We didn't order any but I'm sure they'll help you to navigate through it.

We were too full to order any dessert.

I can't remember our servers name but she was awesome.  Great service is the cherry on top for this awesome meal!
author: Susan C.

description:
The food is good, and they've got a great selection of a variety of eats for both lunch and dinner.  It's a beautiful setting in the Financial District and perfect for company meetings with hi-profile clientele.  It's definitely a workers eatery but at least it's filled with coats and not tourists.

Try out the Barata cheese and risotto (two separate dishes)
author: Kevin J.

description:
Going to keep it short since countless people have already reviewed.

I loved Perbacco! It was a perfect way to celebrate NYE Dinner with the boyfriend :)
author: Jess C.

description:
Perbacco is earning 3 stars due to inconsistency.  The food was hit or miss with the misses being really bad.  Service was good.  The place is also quite busy and goes through a lot of tables.

Piastra Roasted Octopus - awesome and perfectly cooked; one of the best dishes of the night; interesting use of the beans here
Garganelli - second best dish of the night; perfectly cooked pasta consistency; right amount of sauce; super tasty
Tajarin - I wanted this to be good so badly but horrible, horrible execution; pasta was overcooked and sitting in a pool of oil or butter which meant the sauce did not stick; sauce itself was way underseasoned (added a few pinches of salt and so much better) and the meat did not meld with the pasta; summed up, it was like a plate of soggy instant noodles with ground meat on top
Alaskan Halibut - nothing bad, but nothing spectacular either
Sauteed Swiss Chard - how can you ruin a simple dish?  easy, over season it so much that the salt burns my tongue
author: Alan C.

description: Best meal I've had in San Francisco! Amazing staff, great atmosphere and phenomenal food!
author: Audrey K.

description:
Saturday after work, decided to treat myself and my BFF to a nice dinner.  Ordered the Salumi Misti, which was okay.  For $19 appetizer I was expecting a little more.  The taste was okay definitely had better.  We ordered two pasta dishes and they were okay nothing extraordinary.  The texture and way it was prepared was good but the flavors were lacking.

Best thing about this meal would be the chocolate desert and our waiter Ben.  Ben did an amazing job of taking care of us.  Too bad the food wasn't on par with the service.
author: Bo K.

description: Food is great - both the Pappardelle and Risotto were delectable. Deserts are run of the mill and they lack the magic touch that makes for a great cappuccino. However, my biggest peeve is that the place is too noisy to be romantic, too crowded to be private, too stuffy to be comfortable. Overall this place lacks the kind of intimate and memorable dining character you find at Acquerello as a point of reference for an Italian restaurant that has it all.
author: Monish S.

description:
Let me start off by saying the food was delicious.. We ordered the parpadelle, the garganelli, the coujette, brussel sprouts, and carrots. We also had a very nice bottle of the reserve del conte, was very smooth! 

HOWEVER the service was heartbreaking. Should have seen it coming when the hostess was sort of pushy about us sitting at the bar instead of the open booth (still in the bar area we were not given the option to wait for a white cloth table in the back) The server did not once ask us about our meal. she dropped off the dessert menu and later the check still not a peep! Our group consisted of 3 people in the mid to late 20s. Perhaps she thought we did not dress noce enough and therefore did not have money/wouldn't tip?? I definitely would not go back and would not recommend it to anyone based on their rude manner. To support an establishment who treated us as less than is not how we wanted to spend our last night in Sf.
author: Hayden S.

description:
***************** REVIEW 382 ******************

4.5 Stars

            I'm surprised that I haven't written about this place. I guess must got lost in my previous Yelp account! Perbacco is probably 1 of my favorite Italian restos in San Francisco. It's a stylist spot, excellent service, and the food is consistently great.

           This is 1 of the place that we love to come to the bar for happy hours as well. Alway nice people here and the the host Steve, after all these years, still remember me by name! The new manager Mr. Carron is another wonderful Italian gentleman, that always make you feel so welcomed here, another reason for us to come back for more!

          Their menu got a bit for everyone.  Specialized in the beautifully taste of Piemonte and Liguria food, with a touch of Provence region. Their in house cured salumi and crudo are some of my favorite dishes here. Here are some of the consistent dishes that a MUST ORDER!

- Crudo - preps raw fish, bluefin tuna w/red mandarin, shallots & special sauce - delish!

- Crudo - hamachi seasonal citrus, shaved baby fennel, radish, blood orange oil -1 dish wouldn't be enough for myself!

- Vitello Tonatto - slow roasted veal with lemon & albacore tuna sauce w/capers & arugula - the flavor, the texture, was sublime. 

- Nantucket scallops with baby beets - my brokenhearted girlfriend was so in love all over again by this dish!

- Pan seared Sonoma Foie Gras and sauteed pear - I can never said enough about Foie Gras, 1 of my guilty pleasure dish!

- TAJARIN - Handcut Tagliatelle, 5 hours pork sugo, porcini mushroom - this dish I HAVE to have each time I'm here, ridiculous delicious! 

- Chocolate Souflle Cake with hazelnet Gelato - I don['t eat sweet, but I don't mind a bite from my friend's plate!

           If you can't go to Piemonte for the wines, the Truffles, the men, just come for the food to satisfy your crave, this is as good as it gets! 

Overall: 4.5 stars
For value: 4 stars
For Food: 5 stars
For Service: 5 stars
Ambiance: 4 stars
For Location: Financial District - Valet parking available!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Had a great time at this restaurant.  The food and wine were awesome along with the great customer service, making the overall experience exactly what you'd want for a nice night.

The roasted octopus and the slow roasted veal were quite flavorful and enjoyable and a great way to start off the meal.

The occitaine potato gnocchi was so light and delicious.

The rosso di montalcino was also great red wine to pair with any red meat or ragu pasta.
author: Matt S.

description:
Perbacco should be given 10 stars; there are NOT enough stars!

If you want to have a meal that you remember for the rest of your existence; take some very important people in your life and make an event out of it! This IS THE restaurant you want to create lifetime memories at!

Last night my girlfriends and I celebrated my 40th Birthday. Yes, a milestone birthday and I certainly had more than one reason to celebrate!

Upon arrival with my beautiful girlfriends we were greeted very warmly---and the staff knew it was my night. The service was impeccable kind of service where you feel like a VIP from the second you start talking with the Host and Hostess. We got to the table, not to be overlooked by the gorgeous cheese spread that our table was sitting near. 

There was a Birthday card presented to me by the Hostess and we were introduced to Allison AMAZING, INCREDIBLY attentive, smart and funny Hospitality Professional. (SERVER is way too pedestrian for this woman-you have to request her-she is unbelievable)!!! Allison definitely knows the menu and the food. She made some very nice recommendations and is clearly a foodie. I thought she was very emotionally intelligent or a former Actress...she has a high EQ as we learned throughout the evening. I wish she could have joined us, she is that awesome! We ate amazing food, lobster and hearts of palm...poached pear...amazing wine (and that was just for starters). My friend ordered the octopus app for her entree and the brussel sprouts (mind blowing). My other friend ordered the pillows of pasta filled w/goat's cheese and brussel sprouts. Little pillows of heaven with homemade pasta! Yum!

I ordered the papperdelle w/shortrib ragu topped with shredded horseradish. I have to say it was one of the best entrees of my entire life. I would order this again and again. It's perfection. The pasta is generous and beautifully cooked, the short rib is fall apart meat and the sauce w/the horseradish is a perfect marriage of flavors. 

We had drinks (Perbacco, some tequila drink and another froufrou cocktail) and then switched to wine. By the time it was desert and cheese we were done...

The bathrooms are super cool too! Don't drink too much though because you have to trek downstairs to the basement for the bathroom which is kind of a cool set up. The battery of sinks are communal and the toilets are MMWW and then a private bathroom. I liked that concept considering while I was washing my hands the most handsome young man was down there an whoa-I nearly passed out. We ended up talking...and I almost tripped up the stairs (that would have been bad)...we chatted some more and I got a Birthday hug from him...holy crap...what a bonus! He was so hot!!!

Allison knew we were skipping dessert and yet brought a plate that said 'Happy Birthday' in chocolate with some amazing lemon sorbetto and a napoleon that was phenominal...followed up by almond nougat and hazelnut chocolate squares. 

If it were not for Allison our evening would not have been the same. The food was incredible but the service and the feeling of that restaurant was superb. I talked with a man who I think was the owner or manager. Either way-he was delightful. The entire evening will not be forgotten anytime soon. Thank you Perbacco for making my 40th Birthday an experience that I will not ever forget!
author: Sherie R.

description:
I hate to give such a renowned and accolades-filled restaurant like Perbacco a poor review. But unfortunately, we went in with high hopes and came out quite disheartened. 

The service was a tad pretentious but completely understandable given this restaurant's cadence. And the ambiance was quite ordinary with an average dining age group of about 40 - 60 year olds. I suppose it's somewhat classy in a very older and sedentary manner. 

The food was honestly very disappointing. We ordered the butternut squash risotto, fritto misto, short rib pappardelle, side of brussels sprouts and the burnt caramel gelato. I honestly cannot pick my favorite since all of the dishes were equally sub par - I am probably the biggest fan of risottos but this one was simply too sweet, a bit runny and sparse with the cheese. And the pappardelle definitely did not live up to all of the fabulous reviews - it was overpowered with tomato sauce and digressed from any meat based flavor. Eeek. 

But most of all, you can clearly understand how mediocre and unsatisfying the meal was from our reaction to the dessert - we didn't even finish half of it! And it certainty wasn't because we were stuffed. We never waste desserts, EVER. 

So all in all, do yourself a favor and try one of the other Michelin rated SF culinary highlights instead. In fact, there is a wide array of non-Michelin rated restaurants that far surpass Perbacco as well.
author: Priya S.

description: Excellent service and food. I think you can get equal caliber Italian and not pay the businessman financial district prices, but you will not leave this place disappointed on account of the food. We paired some short rib and steak with two half orders of pasta and it would recommend that approach if it's two of you.
author: Robbie K.

description:
Ok, so my friend and I came here to dine on a Thursday evening with her two year old and my eight year old. I know the feeling everyone gets when they see a group like this show to a restaurant like this but we try very hard to keep our kids well behaved as we know the drill. We had an amazing experience here!!! Our waiter was very accommodating to us and never made us feel like our kids were a problem. They both actually behaved very well. We ended up dining here for three hours and this wasn't a problem. 

For starters we had the little gem salad and the beef tartare both very good, although I would say the beef tartare surpassed the salad, duh!! :) We decided to forgo the entrees and ordered four half orders of pasta to share. They also made us kid portions of a simple butter and cheese pasta for our kids. I honestly cannot remember all of the pastas we ordered but all were delicious!!! 

Overall the experience was amazing and it was really nice to go a restaurant of this caliber and not feel guilty for bringing children.
author: Marin H.

description:
I needed to find a decent pasta restaurant close to my hotel in the Financial District. A little bit of yelping later, Perbacco seemed to fit the bill.

Just 2.5 blocks from Le Meridien, and located adjacent to Michael Mina, Perbacco was very easy to find. it took them about 5 minutes to get us seated, but as soon as we were, we were greeted by our very friendly waiter. With the exception of a neighboring table seating a drunk mother (accompanied by an embarrassed father and two kids), the service and environment was busy but not overwhelming. slightly louder ambient noise than i expected.

My dining partner ordered the Tortelli di Aragosta (lobster filled pasta), while i (think i) ordered the langaroni. what i mostly remember was that both dishes were delectable. oh, what difference house made fresh pasta makes! it brought back long lost memories of my other pasta dreamventure at Scarpetta.

Our side of fingerling potatoes was glistening in oil, and lacked that slightly crispy outside i always look for in roasted potatoes. it seemed like they didn't leave it in the oven or pan long enough. it was pooling at the bottom of the dish.

for house made pasta in the financial district, this place is actually fairly affordable for a nice sit down restaurant. i'd definitely make an effort to come back again!
author: Albert L.

description:
Wow, what a bummer experience!  We've been to Perbacco before and had fantastic meals, but last night was just meh.  The salumi plate was spot on as always, and the two salads and brussels sprouts were quite tasty.  On the downside, our octopus salad was totally fishy, and the tajarin was a complete let down.  To echo another reviewer:
"The pasta looked like ramen noodles (the 4 packs for $1 instant ramen kind)..they were pretty curly.  Pork sugo was plentiful though lacked deep flavors, and I didn't see any porcini mushrooms in there!"

On the upside, our server Kyle was super cool, and when we commented on the tajarin they offered to bring us the agnolotti, which was okay but not mind-blowing.  The desserts, however, were totally amazing, so they did send us off on a high note.  However, I doubt I'll return as there are much better places to get a plate of pasta in this city.
author: kerry l.

description:
This review is for 4.5 stars.

In summary, wonderful food and an overall wonderful experience.

Given by how packed this place was on a weekend evening, I'd have to say the recession is over, at least in SF!  The place wasn't just humming, it was bursting at the seams in terms of the number of people and the high level of energy permeating throughout.  

We were seated promptly in the upstairs dining room and presented with a plate of grissini and pesto to nosh on, as well as a crusty roll.  We had a good idea of what we wanted to order as we had already reviewed the menu earlier in the week.   Oh yeah, we were excited.  Each of us had eaten here before, but not recently, so we were really looking forward to this meal.

We split an order of the pappardelle with short rib ragu and horseradish to start.  All I can say is Oh.My.Goodness.  There is nothing that compares to handmade pasta with a very tender, rich and flavorful sauce made from short ribs.  The grated horseradish was the perfect counterpoint to the richness of the meat.  The pasta was perfectly cooked.  

For the entree I ordered black sea bass, which came with mushrooms, beans, spinach and black truffle butter.  The generous portion of fish was perfectly cooked and the sauce was flavorful and rich without being heavy.   Definitely something I would order time and again.  We also orderd a side of the brussel sprouts.  Were our dishes good?  Given that the only thing remaining on our plates was the chervil garnish, I sould have to say that it most certainly was!  

For dessert we had the pistachio panna cotta and the bomboloni (doughnuts filled with fruit).  The doughnuts were served warm and were delicious, but came in a close second to the panna cotta, which was light, creamy and bursting with pistachio flavor.  

Service was good, but not as attentive as on previous visits.  Our meal lasted 2.5 hours, which was a bit longer than we had expected.   Although our waiter checked in on us serveral times during the meal, there were slight lags at the beginning and end of our meal.  I'd be happy to attribute this to it being a busy and packed weekend evening, as I had not experienced any issues on prior visits.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in the Bay Area.  A consistently great experience with great food and good service.  You cannot go wrong either here or at their sister restaurant Barbacco.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Food = delicious. Quality + flavor.  

Tabletop service of breadsticks (yes, sticks) with salsa verde.  Addicting and crunchy.  They also have focaccia, which is moist, full of flavor, and if you want more, please just ask.  

Salumi misti, not to be missed.  Meat lovers delight.
Roasted baby beets...cooling and beautiful.  
Burrata cheese...need I really say anything beyond, delicious bites of heaven?!  Along with spears of asparagus and shaved radish.  It's a beautiful springtime ensemble.

For entree, I tried the Pappardelle (wide pasta ribbons, slow cooked short rib ragu with some finishing touches)  It was flavorful, not too heavy but filling, and so addicting.  They have very nice looking fish dishes too for you non-meat-eaters.  And there are some vegetarian options. 

Service = nice.  Friendly. A bit too cloying for me, but that's okay.  They're not snooty about it.

Decor = simple elegance. Dimly lit.  

Prices = moderate.  You won't escape a meal here for less than $30.00.  Unless you're okay with splitting skittle-sized portions......(I'm telling ya...if you want a LOT of food for your money, this is not the place. But if you're able to appreciate quality and fine flavors, then this is your go-to place!)

Wine = fabulous.  I'm not a huge fan of whites but I loved their Kistler Chardonnay...I would've swam in a vat of it, if that was feasible and affordable. LOL  

Overall, I'd be back here for a nice lunch/dinner outing.  

The place looks small from the outside, but they have bi-level seating.  upstairs, definitely more room.  They do take reservations, and if you're in a large group, you won't regret it.  

Maybe next time, I'll try Barbacco next door....
author: Fannie S.

description:
I've a mondo soft spot for grissini (breadsticks). 

As a toothless wonder infant (like we all were once), give me a grissini, and I will give you peace, quiet, and cuteness through the roof while dining. Kids these days are so spoiled....they have to be bribed with iFonez, iPad$ with animation movies, just so that parents (or single parents) can go on dates have the kids to be quiet next to them. Not me, I was an easy cheap date....make the breadstick good, and everything else will be in its right place. iGrissini trumps iPad. Nom Nom Nom Yom Yom Bom Bom Bom GaGa GooGoo this breadstick is da shiznit good good! 

But to keep up with the times, you cannot just have great breadstick anymore. 

Perbacco is billed by many food geeks to be one of SF's finest old world style Italian.
Even if they think is Gangnam Style....this place is otherwise really not my style.

Grissini - shaggadelic great. Eat it plain, or dip in some special sauce (the usual olive oil + ground parsley + garlic goodness). I could clean up a whole plate of these easy, with or without salumi.

Butternut squash soup - pretty good, can't go wrong with this one

salad - forgot the name of it, but see the pic. A beautiful sculpture with a few fruits in it that was pure delightful bliss

and then it went south of there (and not south of the boot)

Braised short rib entree - not my order, but had a sample, and I'm of the conclusion that I prefer my short ribs done Asian style (primarily Korean, Vietnamese, or Cantonese/Chinese or Taiwanese). This red wine braised prep is again not my style

Tagliatelle (fresh pasta) with 5 hour pork sugo with wild porcini mushrooms - I purposely skipped the braised short rib paperdelle since a few folks I know ordered it and were not doing the horserider gallop dance afterwards. So I decided to try this pasta dish. Sugo is supposed to be some Italian sauce. Here it is a pork stew mix...and it could possibly change slightly depending on the region, but it's supposed to be like a minced pork (with a puffy texture) simmered with tomato, herbs, amongst other things (supposedly there were porcini mushrooms inside, melted into the mix). Unfortunately there wasn't much in the way of sauce or flavoring...mostly moist minced/ground pork, and fairly one dimensional (mostly a salt profile). No matter how much tossing and mixing of the pork with the pasta, there was a mismatch in general. Grated parmesean didn't improve the dish either. It's perfectly fine if this is the intended approach and execution, but to me this did not work very well. No sauce clinging to the pasta (and still ends up being a salt and pork smear). Something like a Taiwanese style rou zou (stewed minced pork) over brothless noodle, is a lot more robust, in a similar approach (but w/o the tomato). Perhaps a non pasta entree would have been better, but this was a disappointment.
author: Ken K.

description:
The food here is ok.  Went for dinner with a group.  Had a few appetizers that left a lot to be desired.  For the main course, I had halibut which was just ok.  They promote that they always change their menu but maybe they should stick to one thing, practice that a bit and get better at making it.

Service was excellent. Wine was flowing.  I must have dropped my napkin on the floor 5 times.  Each time there was a guy there with a brand new one for me instantly.  Clearly they are well experienced with napkin service but not so much with cooking.
author: Chris F.

description:
Very generous portions for quality food--a great place to grab a meal in the business district. Because of the quantity of food you get, watch what dishes you end up ordering. We got two appetizers and two entries for a party of two and were stuffed to the point of having to waste our uneaten food. 

We got a shrimp calamari appetizer, which was a mistake in the end - the dish itself was not very good and filled us up quickly. But the rest of the meal -- a sampling of Italian beers, veal tar tar, rabbit, and duck breast, were exceptionally good. Nothing my mouth would water over or think about craving in a few months, but a very satisfying and well-valued meal. Great atmosphere, good location, and excellent service. Check it out.
author: Eddie L.

description: Amazing pasta, great service. I still dream about this place (every year) when I visit SF from LA.
author: Carolina E.

description:
Ok.. Not Authenic Italian in any way. 
I just came home from a month in Italy.. And this is not Italian food.
It's geared to "Phat " Americans  & Asians  ( not Phat,  just not used to Italian) who can't get enough beef or pork in their diets.  
This is NOT how Italians eat at all!!

I'm sorry, I don't want to offend anyone, but when I go to an "Authentic Italian" restaurant. I want authentic  Italians .
 The host / greeter... Not Italian.. The wait staff not Italian.. And the entire restaurant, Not An Italian in in sight. 
Is this a " trendy" new " Italian spot geared towards tourist?? Or what?? I just don't get it.
author: S J.

description:
So, I need to go back.  Not just because it was pretty good, but because i have a really bad feeling when I think back to the night and it had nothing to do with the meal.  well actually it did.  the leftovers to be exact.  I left that box on the table.  and to this day it still pisses me off. 

This place is good.  You won't be disappointed and the location is down in the financial district so its a good after work place.  And its a good date place.  The food was all very good, from the meat appetizer (seriously its a lot of hardcore meat, my former vegetarian persona is hiding her face in shame) to the pasta to the wine to the dessert.  The service was great.  Everything was really good.  

I will be back.  And if you go, and you see a little brown box...those are my leftovers.  Please let me know.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
Prepared to be wined n dined in tru italian style. Great wines all from a region shaped like a boot.

Food... mama mia!
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
Definitely a fancy place to eat at, so being a fan of dressing up, it's my kind of place to go! Saw a lovely lambo parked right in front too, sigh. 

Anyway, I love the breadsticks they give with a pesto oil while you order/wait for your food. And the service is pretty good too. It was a bit too dark for my liking, and hard to hear people talking at my own table, but that's the price you pay for going to a popular place! 

We got an appetizer of tomatoes and cheese and it was SO delicious. Such a simple dish, but big on flavor. For the entree I got a pesto pasta and it was gourmet dining at its best as well. The only odd thing is that I asked to add chicken and she said they don't serve it. I wasn't sure why, but I didn't want to be rude or sound stupid and ask. The serving size was a tad small, but I guess it helps people keep thin!

Yummy, yummy place!
author: Ellen L.

description:
I have no idea why this place gets so many high reviews. 
Service - bad. Our waitress had an attitude and had no interest of asking the chef any questions. Instead made up her own answers. Hardly ever checked on us and clearly hated her job.
Food - my husband had the Octopus dish and said it was good, but then he followed it up with the duck risotto which came out looking like a large plate of watery oatmeal COVERED in coarsely chopped almonds. Ugly presentation and way too sweet for a savory course.
I ordered a simple pasta that was gummy and had and not seasoned. I also had a side of the broccoli and it was SO salty, I couldn't eat it. Best thing I had was the water and bread.
Ambience- big, loud and nothing inviting about the space and wait until you get a load of the bathrooms. This place is not good for a date.
Go to Cotogna if your looking for good Italian food with good service and a great vibe.
author: Michelle C.

description: I enjoyed my meal here and thought the food was pretty good.  So, why only 3 stars?  When I compare my meal here to its sister restaurant, Barbacco, I enjoyed Barbacco more and thought the food was as good (and cheaper).  Go to Perbacco if you need to have a full bar or if someone else is paying ;-)
author: Larry L.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 4
Service: 4

Came here with colleagues for dinner after reserving the upstairs Barolo room.

1. Heirloom tomato salad with greens and fresh burrata
~Delicious. Tomatoes were plump, juicy, and bursting with flavor, and the rest of the ingredients paired perfectly.

2. Filet mignon, medium rare, with asparagus and mashed potatoes
~Pretty good. Filet was prepared well, and the potatoes were nice and buttery.

3. Puff pastry fruit tart with creme fraiche
~Pretty good. Creme fraiche went really well with the fruit tart, and the crust was nice and flaky.

Service was good, and my water stayed full the entire dinner.
author: David L.

description:
This place is nice, cute! Great for an after work drink and dinner, since it's conveniently located in the financial district.  Very nice hostess. Atmosphere is on the louder side though.  And tables are all crammed together, not much privacy.  More of a social place.

I would rate the service from our waiter as a 1 to 2 stars.  For a fine dining establishment, the service we received was terrible.  It took us a really long time to put in our order.  He wasn't really friendly, pretty rude, and we had to flag him down quite a few times.  Not very attentive to his tables.  Gosh, I'm not sure how he even got a job here! 
Anyhow... onto the food and drinks...

The drinks were tasty.  The manhattan was strong, but good.  The peach punch was also flavorful, with a taste of real peach.
