The breadsticks they gave you were a nice treat as you waited for your order.  The batsoa, which is a crisp pig trotter's cake had a hint of foie grad, which complimented it really well.  You can taste how rich it was.  For my entree, I had the semolina dusted skate.  The fish was well prepared and tasted pretty fresh.  The lobster mushroom and artichoke ragu was okay.  I don't think I tasted much lobster at all though.  The halibut was also decent.  However, I noticed  the portion size seemed inconsistent.

For desert, we tried the Peach & amaretto tart, which was a real treat! The peachy tart paired well with the almond.  The gelato was a real treat.  Super smooth and creamy.  We couldn't tell whether it was gelato or cream! Yummy and a nice finish to our meal! ;)
author: Tramy V.

description:
I don't think this was the right kind of place for me and my friends. And by not the right kind of place, I mean we weren't rich enough. ha ha

True, we were in the financial district, but the 5 of us wanted to split a bottle of wine and our server saw us debating a long time because pretty much every bottle was $40 and up, mainly up.....And when we were honest with our server about how we wanted a more moderately priced bottle of wine I could tell instantly she was not pumped at all. It was pouring rain outside though. Hoe much business do you think you were really going to get that night?? 

This place is pretty nice and trendy inside, but it is so nice looking that us in our sopping wet clothes paired with out rolly bags since we came from the airport really just made us stick out pretty badly. If our server has been a little nicer, it would have made it a little better, but I don't think she is used to the non-profit grad student crowd working in the financial district ha
author: Sarah G.

description:
Brought a couple customers in for a business dinner, we left as really good friends.

The service was fantastic, the food was incredible (I had the pork chop) and the wine list was really good.   Thanks Perbacco!
author: Al H.

description:
Four words are worth the visit at Perbacco: 

Short rib ragout pappardelle
author: Mika D.

description:
Perbacco is one of the best dining experiences I've had in a long time. 
Everything from the staff to the food was impeccable. 
The restaurant was busy when we went, and starting with the thoughtful and sincere hostess (I believe her name was Katy), through the exquisite  dessert, the experience was awesome. The food is some of the most creative, beautiful, and delicious I've seen in San Francisco; it was very Italifornian. The ambience was warm and clean, the bus boys were on it,  and I will definitely be back to try more things. 

GRAZIE MILLE PERBACCO!!!
author: C V.

description:
SO IN LOVE WITH THIS RESTAURANT!!!! you get all the niceties of a nice upscale restaurant, but at a reasonably affordable price - way lower than its neighbors!!!

everything that i had was DELICIOUS. the fig appetizer w/cheese (forgot what kind) and almonds was perfect blend of flavors. i had the spinach and herb gnocchi - so divine, just melted in my mouth. and i tried some of my friend's risotto too. it was incredible. so much flavor. prawns were perfect, artichoke hearts, mushrooms, so rich with flavor. 

we got lucky and showed up around 9 without a reservation or calling ahead...the place was PACKED but there was a table leaving so we were seated rather quickly. for future notice i am definitely going to call in advance
author: Patty W.

description: Rather disappointing.  This place was very highly recommended to us, but it really just doesn't live up to the hype.  The atmosphere is very nice, our waiter was great and the other waitstaff were excellent, although a little slow on keeping the water glasses filled. We were just disappointed with the menu, they say "gluten-free" but there are very few choices - like one choice.  Overall, the menu is rather limited. There are interesting choices on the menu, and perhaps if you eat here regularly every time they changed it might be better, but overall, each of us was somewhat disappointed with the dish that we had.  Also, the restaurant manager who handles our wine was quite a bit off that evening. He brought us a bottle of wine to sample and started pouring it, but it was empty. Which surprised me because most people can tell when they pick up a bottle whether it's empty.  He also decanted our bottle of wine we ordered but left the decanter off our table away from us where they keep the other ones. So we couldn't refill our glasses until he bothered to wander by our table and check on us.  And he made a number of errors with our bill, including at one point bringing us the check for another table. And he was not particularly nice about trying to help resolve the issues for us.  With so many amazing choices in San Francisco, I wouldn't waste your time here.
author: Heather P.

description:
Unusual, tasty and breathtaking.

We came here to celebrate my friend's birthday and set upstairs. Decided to start salads, picked up Caesar as classic; continued with their fresh, hand-made, original pastas. My order was rib pasta - it was so flavory, very good)

Toooons of Hendreck's tonics were brought to our table, so I must say that it's a nice and strong cocktail with light cucumber flavor, mmm )
author: Olga B.

description:
Is it just me, or was I there on an off night? I used to like this place, but I was not so impressed when I was there the last time. 

First off, the hostess was, well...not the hostess with the mostess...she was a grumpy lady. And the table...I love the downstairs, but the upstairs does not feel very posh. It almost feels like you're at the dining room at a Hilton or something. The rock shrimp fritto was good, but the risotto a bit salty. Pork shoulder was slightly dry.

And our server forgot to smile the entire evening.

Hopefully it was just an off night for them.
author: Aya C.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends to catch up, get some drinks, and have a yummy dinner. This wasn't our first choice, but we ended up coming here on a whim. I quickly looked at yelp to see what this place was all about, and with 4 stars and the number of reviews, we had to try it. We had the salumi plate as an app, and it was pretty good. All of us ended up trying the risotto, which is why I gave Perbacco a 3. The risotto didn't really taste like risotto....literally just tasted like I was eating rice that wasn't cooked all the way. When all four of us received our dinner, it was clear that my plate lacked veggies and shrimp, which everyone else had an abundance of it! Thus, the consistency wasn't spot on, either. 

I'll have to come back here to try the other dishes that people recommend because I was definitely disappointed.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
You know I had no idea that this restaurant wasn't even a year old yet. I also have no idea why it took me so long to write this review. I had gone here during St Patty's day  and I guess you could say it was a straying from the normal Guinness swilling. However I'm the person that is always Guinness swilling so if I miss one day it doesn't kill me.

The first thing you notice before walking in is the large polished metal signage. A small host station is to the right when you enter and to the left is a long elegant bar that reaches a good ways into the restaurant.  The decor uses the exposed brick of the building and a balance of modern and classic elements through out. Finding that without reservations, our wait could have been upwards of an hour. I did however notice two open spots at the bar in which we happily jumped on right away, since it was full service there.

The first thing I notice is that we are seated right in front of the in house cured meats operation. All the salumi on the menu, right in front of us. What a way to spark an appetite. Plate after plate of meat were cut and served  from our vantage point. Of course we were going to order one of those things! First off however, being at the bar, we had  to see what the mixed drinks were going to be like, so we got a Lemon Drop and my "old man beverage" of a Rob Roy . Both excellently mixed.

As we perused the menu, the choices were:

- Tasting of Salame - NOSTRANO / FINOCCHIONA / FINOCCHIONA PICCANTE (SPICY) / SANGUINATO (BLOOD)
-  Baccala - Salt Cod mixed with potatoes and served with toast points
- Beef Short Ribs, spring vegetables, gremolata
- Braised pork shoulder

As you can see, this was a meal of meatz (yes that is with a Z). Cured meats and braised meats. The only exception was that of the bacalla. But there were no exceptions in the fact that everything was good. I couldn't tell you what all the names of the salumi were but they were delicious. 

It never occurred to us that we were sitting at the bar because the service was just as good as if we would have been at a table. We did however look around and noticed that the clientele were much older than we were. It was also pointed out to be that the guy next to us had a lot of "man jewelery". There was also this older lady that came in with a huge puffy St Patty's day hat, and our guess was she was recently ragingly drunk :) Only one person was younger than us and she seemed very bored with her parents. So you might say the ambiance was a bit older and stuffy but I think the food and service makes up for that. We were definitely well taken care of. I noticed, reading the menu recently that new items have been introduced and wouldn't mind coming back, trying those, and maybe getting a table in the upstairs area, which I never saw. 4.5 stars.
author: Kim N.

description: I just ate at Perbacco and had an extraordinary experience. The atmosphere and food were incredible. I was there with a great friend and we shared the beet salad to start. Delicious. I then had a duck pasta dish which was incredible. But as good as the meal was, our service was what made the evening exceptional. We were fortunate enough to have Amber as our guide for the night. Her personality, knowledge and suggestions were delightful. It is rare that I have received such charming service. Amber, thank you so much!!! Perbacco is the delicious cake and Amber is the perfect icing on top.
author: Michael A.

description: Great place for Italian... Elegant and tasty.... The John Dory fish was overly salty though so go with the Halibut if you decide on fish.
author: David W.

description:
I'd give 5 stars but waitress not the most pleasant. 
Many times we've sent guests here. Many times I've made reservations for others & myself This time the bar was full of businessman and women. The hostess was lovely. The placing for each table precise and detailed. Breadsticks & olive oil with pesto sauce was a good start. The white truffle risotto with pork shoulder and bone marrow made me tear. Exquisitely done. The Cousette is filling. The brown butter brussel sprouts were savory. Piastra roasted octopus is light and refreshing. The butti ma buoni was ok. The MontePulciano d'Abruzzo to pair it with was a good choice. The Fior D'Arancio is a excellent for a light cordial. Will definitely be back with more guests and clients here. Service a little off. 
Waitress seemed stressed/unengaged
author: Jacqueline L.

description: I didn't take any pictures of the food because I was too busy eating it but it was excellent. I ordered the halibut and it was cooked and seasoned perfectly. My husband ordered the Pappardelle pasta dish and practically licked the plate clean. We were in a big dinner party so we got to nibble on lots of appetizers. Everything was fresh, visually appealing, and unique. We're definitely coming back.
author: D A.

description:
When we first arrived, we were worried Perbacco wasn't going to be our kind of experience.  The place has that typical chichi look of a pretentious, expensive restaurant, and I could not pronounce or recognize half the menu.  (I'm a man of simple tastes!)

Then the food started arriving and wow. Possibly the finest, tastiest meal I've had in San Francisco.

We started with their homemade salumi (cured meats) were flavorful and delicious.  

For dinner, I had the Agnlotti dal Plin (because calling it ravioli would apparently be too pedestrian) and each bite was a taste explosion.  Rich, delicious and recommended. My wife had the quail and raved about it, also.

But perhaps the best was desert.  I honestly may return sometime just to sit at the bar and enjoy the Burnt Caramel Gelato with Vanilla Sea Salt.  It was spectacularly delicious--a completely memorable desert experience.

I still wish the place didn't feel quite so pretentious, but when you serve food this food, you earn the right to have an attitude.
author: Augie R.

description: Really good burrata, but we had to ask for bread which was kinda weird?  Maybe bread isn't a given when ordering burrata, but I'm stoked I asked for some because it went great with the cheese.  The duck breast was cooked perfectly--medium rare, but the skin was crispy--yum!  The spaghetti with veal ragu was ordered by one of my tablemates and they raved about it.  I do think it's a bit overpriced for the portion size, but don't sleep on this great italian spot
author: Ryan H.

description:
The BF took me here for an early anniversary celebration last week. Thank god we had reservations cause the place was packed! Our server was great! Didn't catch his name but he was really friendly and explained our wine and food with great detail. We each got a different glass of red, both were his recommendations. We started with the salumi assortment, which was awesome. The BF ordered the pork shoulder and I ordered the ravioli filled with short ribs. I loved both dishes and would definitely go back!!!

The only thing I didn't like about this restaurant was that it was really crowded! In my opinon the tables are way too close together. There was a group of obviously drunk women and a bitter old man and his girlfriend seated next to us. Definitely not something that would keep me from coming back, but yeah if you're looking for a quiet romantic dinner this is not the place.
author: Jen D.

description: Had an amazing dinner here on a Friday night. Everything was excellent and prepared perfectly. Ambience was a little louder than ideal, and the server could have been a little more attentive, but the excellent food overcame all of these negatives. Highly recommend!
author: Tony C.

description:
I love Perbacco (and the sister restaurant Barbacco) - Perbacco is the facier, sit down/upscale version to the Berbacco, shared table vibe - but both serve delicious Italian.

These are some FiDi gems, and certainly that is their main clientele. Weekday HH and dinner hours get quite crowded.

Perbacco serves one of the best cocktails I've ever tasted - their Fior d'Arancio is out of this world. The prosecco is lightly sweet and enhanced by the lavender and the orange flavors - you won't regret trying it! The pistachio sour is delicious too.

All their pastas are homeruns - but if you HAVE to pick one - try the tajarin.

Stop by for a drink after work (for fancier fare) or make a reservation and enjoy a lovely dinner!
author: Jocelin L.

description:
For lunch today, I had the salumi plate to start, and then polished off a big hunk of tasty capicollo arrosto (a.k.a. slow-roasted pork shoulder). I'm eating Paleo, and it ain't easy avoiding grains at a joint renowned for its pastas and bready delights. But honestly, there was no room in my stomach for unnecessary carbs after ingesting that much pig (and some goat, too).

The capicollo arrosto -- served with sweet roasted grapes and crushed hazelnuts -- was delicious and tender (albeit slightly dry), and the portion was generous in size. I subbed out the bed of polenta for Brussels sprouts cooked in brown butter, which lent the dish an enjoyably rich, bitter finish. 

Favorite line from our server, who was struggling to remember the name for one of the items on the salumi plate: "Um, uh, it's made from, you know, the meat from the pig's head, with the crunchy parts. Like head cheese. I forget the name."

(It's testa arrotolata, by the way.)
author: Henry F.

description:
Before we start, some honesty -- I'm not a foodie and, when dining out, the Financial District is about the last place I'd choose to go.

Nonetheless, I've eaten at Perbacco. Meh.

If you're all about ambiance and presentation and hoity-toity dining with a price tag, eat here. Want to impress a date? A reservation here will clear a path straight to home base. In fact, I'd wager that many of you scoping out the reviews are more interested in these aspects anyway.

The food itself? Well... the dishes are listed on the menu with all of these components with pretty sounding names and they'll look beautiful as they're served to you,... but these simply set the expectation about as high as the price, and so the disappointment hits fast and hard.

I've eaten at places like this before, and I've learned something along the way. A truly excellent restaurant that prepares their items to perfection won't set salt shakers on their tables -- the food won't need it. Perbacco? Salt shakers, every table.

Oh. It's going to sound petty but I'd like to add that the tablecloth (or maybe it was a napkin; I'm not exactly sure) coated my not-for-fine-dining black pants in white lint. The type of lint that gets a good grip and won't let go. Those of you who place high importance on your appearance and fret about it all the time might care so I thought you'd like to know.

Ah, there's nothing quite like the passive-aggressiveness of Yelp reviews, is there?
author: J. S.

description:
Came here the second time last week. Salumi Misti / Short Rib Pappardelle / Roasted Rabbit Leg / Toffee Cake. Full.

The rabbit dish was one of the best plates I've had in recent memory. Juicy roasted rabbit & sausage, fresh peas and toasted puffed rye berries that might have been the best part of the dish. This place kicks ass.

bonus: Don't have to wait 2 months for a reservation.
author: Anthony R.

description:
You know it is a good restaurant when it is full at 9pm on a Tuesday night.  And we made a reservation.

Typically, the ambient is dim.  The waitress produced a booklight to assist my menu reading.  I chose Rabbit and my company picked duck. I must say the rabbit tasted wonderful, but not as I expected.  The top of the meat was nicely crispy and well seasoned, like a traditionally roasted pig in China town.  The meat really tasted like chicken, but well cooked and delicious.

We picked a random Italian wine and it ended up wonderful.  My company ordered an orange scented donut.  It was really donut holes with a hint of orange.  Interestingly served in a paper bag as if we should take it out with us.

Overall, a very nice dinner.  I am sure it was expensive, but I did not picked up the tab.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Came on Oct 1st with 9 other girl friends...

Armando my waiter recommended the Seabass, so about 5 of us decided to go with that. I also noticed that it's not on their website menu as well as their menu for that evening was printed that day, therefore, they were probably trying to get rid of that dish..

Chilean Sea Bass are known to be buttery and tender, one of my favorite fishes. Any how, my sea bass was SOOOOOOOOOOO dry as well as the other 4 who ordered this dish. My fish tasted like white meat of a chicken breast! How can u over cook fish? The waiter was aware of this, but I didnt want any special ingredients in my new dish if i had sent it back... so i just ate that dry chkn breast n e ways. 

CONCORD GRAPE SORBETTO / CHOCOLATE HAZELNUT BARS    
was complimentary from the house... surprisingly it was very declicious! Reminded be very much of macaroons and Ferrero Rocher chocolate! HEAVEN! 

Ill be back to try something else... but DO NOT ORDER THEIR SPECIALS! It was a total MISS for us that day!
author: linda L.

description:
Perrbacco is a very nice place for dinner. Upstairs is a little quieter than down and a little more private. Service was excellent. Are waiter was attentive and very knowledgable made us feel very comfortable.
I would say the food is way northern winters comfort food.
The pasta are delicious and I think the standouts are any pasta dish with a meat type sauce or Ragu. Had the gnocchi with rabbit and wild mushrooms Ragu...excellent.
Had a pear salad delicious but it could have used a little for Gorgonzola dolce latte.
The antipasto good but I personally could do without the raw meat selections on it.
Ask for more salami instead of the raw stuff. The salami reminded me of my grandmothers house quality.
Go ,You won't be disappointed.
author: Tropical T.

description:
Bread is always a good indicator of the food in most of my experiences. Perbacco definitely lives up to this rule. I've been here a few times now and consistently the food was amazing and service excellent! Nice extensive wine list and tasty entrees with seasonal ingredients. Interior is elegant and it's a great spot for business dinners (and cheaper than MM next door!). 

- Strawberry & Arugula Salad: fresh, delicious vinaigrette made this a great starter
- Sole: slightly crispy, silky smooth, flaky, fresh tomatoes & artichokes, the tomato sauce was good
author: Linda C.

description:
I've NEVER had a bad dish here, and I go quite frequently.  Some things are menu mainstays like the vitello tonnato, roasted octopus, agnolitti dal plin and the tajarin with pork sugo. 

Prime quality ingredients, lovely execution, and just a slight California spin (on some dishes, save the pastas, which are largely authentic to their Italian originals) makes this one of the best restaurants in the city. 

The wine list is stellar, with an amazing barolo and barbaresco selection, as well as other varieties from Piedmont which deserve more cred.  

Service is always great too!
author: Robert B.

description:
This place is one of the best lunch spots in the Financial District for a casual business lunch. It's also one of the few quality eateries open for dinner in FiDi.

I definitely recommend any of the cured meats to start (though prepared to be a little overwhelmed by the serving size). The pappardelle pasta is excellent too.

The service is here is quite attentive but not overbearing and interrupting intimate or important conversations. When the venue isn't filled with business folk, it seems like a popular spot for people on dates.
author: Victor W.

description:
Went there for dinner and was disappointed.  The food was not bad, but it didn't meet expectations.  I think this is a fine place for lunch, but won't go back for dinner.

The pasta was fine, but didn't stand out.  The veal was horribly overcooked.  For the price point, it was definitely not worth it.  If the prices were cheaper, I'd up this to three stars and find it a bit easier to forgive the mediocrity, but I still don't think I'd go back for dinner.
author: Lauren C.

description:
what a fabulous meal. best Italian food I've had outside of Italy! 

was treated to dinner here by my dad who made reservations a few weeks out but couldn't have been a better experience. 

the staff was wonderfully attentive and the interior of the restaurant is modern and sleek. as far as the food, I ordered the burrata salad with fresh peaches and I was easily top 5 dishes I've ever eaten. the combination sounds interesting at first but absolutely order it, they go together perfectly and it's basically heaven in your mouth. 

for my entree I ordered the fresh tagliatelle with wild boar ragu and it was perfectly balanced with shreds of tender and very flavorful boar that wasn't over powered by a thick sauce but was perfectly complimented by a sauce with great consistency. 
overall an awesome dish and I would definitely order it again. 

for dessert we went with the salted Carmel gelato to share because we were so full from all of the good food and it was a great way to finish off the meal. 

I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone and plan to go back as soon as possible!
author: Julia T.

description: Delicious food. I loved their asparagus cheese salad. Yummy.
author: Balu V.

description: Went in for a drink. Waitress was snooty, slow to accommodate us and faked an Italian accent. I recently spent 10 days in Italy so I know phony. Only reason we were there was because Barbacco 2 doors down didn't have a bar. Never again.
author: Chris J.

description: Had a fantastic meal here - and more importantly.. An amazing service experience. Try to get a table with Amber - possibly the best server I've ever had.
author: John F.

description: Great service, wine list and the food is unreal!  The duck was perfect.  You can tell the cooks really care about what they put out of the kitchen.
author: Tom R.

description:
I LOVE the Grappa, Italian wine and Brandy here! An extra star for the top quality full bar!

I didn't have dinner but had a handful of appetizers and I found them to be greasy and not all that exotic. One of them was the salami platter. I wasn't impressed, it didn't seem like anything special and it was greasy. I also had some battered olives with aioli sauce? Quite disappointing again. But, I can't let this truly affect my rating as it was a small sampling and I didn't have any of the dinner items. 

Their bread wasn't that great either. Some rolls smothered in white flour.

4 well deserved stars for the drinks, ambiance, and location!
author: Kathy S.

description: Perbacco is one of the best restaurants in SF , period . The staff is outstanding from the time you walk into the door , till the time you walk out the door . I had the beet/white carrot/dill salad , braised beef short-rib, and the lava cake dessert . Everything was fresh , tasty , and served w care . Always a pleasure dining here.
author: Bryan Y.

description:
This place sure know how to make you feel good for your special occasion! I came here for my birthday with my boyfriend over the weekend and they seated us at a table with a personalized birthday card.  That was nice touch.

The service was quick, efficient and friendly! Our waitress was very nice and knowledgable, she was able to give great recommendation upon asking.  Also, when I decided to see the wine list mid-way throughout dinner, our waitress was busy and someone else saw me looking around for service and came right over and assist me.  Practically everyone working there knew it was my birthday and kept wishing me 'Happy Birthday' upon serving us.

Food was great!!!!!

For appetizer we had the Beef Crudo (I think that's what it was), it was delicious.  We then moved on with the Bis of pasta, we got the pappardelle and the ravoli with veal I think.  Both was absolutely delicious, the noodles were cooked perfectly the ribs was tender and flavorful.  The pasta taste of two was smaller portion, more like for tasting, therefore we ordered entrees also.  I had the salmon and my bf gotten the scallops, both was great, my salmon was juicy and flavorful and the scallops was cook just right, not overdone or undercooked.  I was stuff by this point but couldn't resist to try their dessert, I gotten the layers of chocolate and hazelnut and the bf gotten the chocolate gelato,  even as stuff as I was, I couldn't stop eating the dessert, the best part was that they gave me a panna cotta on top of this for my birthday!  A complete party for my taste buds this night!

I think I'm in love =)
author: Mimi P.

description:
What I Ate
- salumi misti (house cured meats)
- short ribs ragu
- roasted potatoes

Would I Go Again?
I must say I was somewhat disappointed with Perbacco.  I LOVED everything I ate at Barbacco, so I think I had pretty high expectations for Barbacco's more upscale sister restaurant.  

The house cured meats appetizer was okay.  Most of the meats were pretty good, although I thought the bread with which they were served was dry.

I didn't really like the short ribs ragu.  In fairness, I think the dish was made very well, especially the house-made noodles, but the ragu's flavor just wasn't my favorite.  I also thought the short ribs were tough.

The roasted potatoes were awesome, the star of the meal.  However, if the roasted potatoes are a meal's shining star, then the meal almost certainly didn't live up to expectations.

I would be willing to give Perbacco another try, but I would definitely order a different entree.
author: Ben M.

description:
Perfect! With only one word I can describe the '"experience" lived in this restaurant.

I am Italian, and you know that with regard to the food and especially the Italian restaurants abroad we are skeptical. But this time it was great!

The cuisine is the authentic cuisine of Piedmont, with dozens of alternatives. The service was impeccable, the waiter who served us was Italian and he advised us what to eat and what were the specialty of the restaurant.

I can say it is one of the best Italian restaurants in SF, probably the best one!

I will be back for sure!
author: Mattia B.

description:
My second time here and still as fantastic as it was the first time around.

Ricotta/Spinach Ravioli - A nice, decadent stuffed ravioli.  When it first arrives, it looks a bit small, but it has an amazing amount of flavor - rich and creamy.  It also has a yolk in the center, which adds another layer of richness and depth.

Roasted Fingerling Potatoes - Good, well-cooked potatoes, with a nice, delicate flavor.

Beef Short Rib - A really good piece of soft and tender beef.  It was seasoned very well and arrived with a small portion of potato puree, which helped to balance the richness of the meat.

Overall, I had a fantastic experience here.  It's definitely a scene so make sure you arrive dressed decently well and with a reservation.  This restaurant has a very lively atmosphere so if you're looking for a quiet evening with a date or some serious conversation, this probably isn't your spot.

The wine selection is incredible and includes specialty items from Italy.
author: Ken G.

description:
Had dinner here last night after reading all the reviews on Yelp and a mention in GQ magazine. Gotta admit it's probably one of the best Italian meals I have ever had. Delicious from start to finish, from the meat stuffed raviolis to the pappardelle and pork shoulder we shared... Redic blend of flavors and aromas. The wine list is impressive, a bit overwhelming but Adriano (our awesome waiter) was more than eager to explain the different blends, acidity levels and suggested pairings.

The pork shoulder was beyond delicious I wish it was a bigger portion but even so I was salivating the whole time. We finished off the night w the hazelnut cake for desert... A bit dry but the pears and hazelnuts complimented it nicely. The best past of he desert was the homemade dark chocolate made in-house, so good that we asked if we could buy some to take home (unfortunately that's not possible :( ) 

Highly recommended go with an empty stomach and enjoy!
author: Fernando D.

description:
Came here for dinner one night and got the sea bass. It was good at the time but the next morning it gave me diarrhea.

Good service, nice atmosphere. That's it.
author: Cheri S.

description:
Made a reservation here for a business dinner on short notice and was definitely not disappointed.  I liked the atmosphere in was business-nice but welcoming.  

Cocktail - Perbacco - I decided to go with the cocktail named after the place, I figured that would be a good sign.  And While this would have been nice and refreshing in summer, I probably should have just gone with a scotch.

I was eating with two women clients so we didn't end up ordering that much of the menu, but everything was excellent.
Dinner:
Charcuterie - 
Salsiccia Crudo - 
Appetizer - 
Pappardelle - You can also get this as an entree but I think its a great dish to share as an appetizer. 
Entrees
Capicollo Arosto - Roast Duck- Both of them ordered this, and both were very happy.
Cunij - Roast Rabbit Leg - It ws falling off the bone almost like an osobucco, and not the least bit gamey.  I was enamored with the barley risotto which I wish there had been just a little more of.  
Desert
Bonet - Chocolate custard - I'm a chocoholic
Burnt Caramel Gelato

Taste: 5
Presentation: 4
Atmosphere: 5
Service: 4 
Overall: 5
author: Adam R.

description: Exceptional service and food quality.  Place is very clean and surprisingly not busy for Friday afternoon lunch.  Love my rabbit dish!
author: Ed Y.

description:
Great italian food. The food was really good, the pastas are great, specially the one with snails.
We ordered some appetizers which also were really good. We were not disappointed! 
The service was also great, they were very attentive and always there.
I give 4 stars out of 5, because the noise level was pretty high. It was hard to talk and not shout.
author: Lucia C.

description:
Every time I am in the city with a spare hour or two in the early evening, I make a point to stop at Perbacco for one primary reason:

They make the best Spritz in the city. 

Its an artful, light and slighty fritzy mix of Aperol (or Campari), Prosecco, soda water and an orange wedge. And their bartenders get it right every time. 

I also love this place for how easy they make it to be a guest: Whether sitting at the bar or at a table, the menu selection has always been wonderful, authentic, well-prepared and perfectly delivered. Service is extraordinary. And the atmosphere is elegant and welcoming. 

The menu is Northern Italian (so for you meat lovers out there - this is your place) Their housed cured salamis and meats are of extremely high quality. 

Appetizers lean towards seafood - try the house-made tuna conserva (if its on the menu) and you'll never look at tuna the same way again. The beef tartare is full of flavor and truffle, and the roasted figs with cheese and hazelnuts salad is completely satisfying. 

As for their pastas: there's not one I wouldn't recommend. But my favorite: the pappardelle with short rib ragu. 

The duck, the beef short ribs and the sea scallops have always delivered. Consistency of food / ingredient quality - combined with top-notch service - is an earmark of this place. 

I could wax on for pages. But I'll end with this: this place is a frequent stop - and a constant nemesis to my waistline.
author: Gigi G.

description: I've been here a couple of times and both times the waitstaff cuz been remarkable.  The food is delicious.  I haven't had one bad thing.  I had the Tajarin the last time I went and it was a perfect mix of meat and pasta.  I also recommend getting their meat plate to start.  It's a great share for the table.
author: Amanda K.

description: Delicious food and amazing service. They have great seasonal specials and their menu is extensive. I recommend any of the pastas or the roast chicken.
author: Madie H.

description:
Friend treated us to dinner.  Gave us the choice of Bar Tartine (her favorite) and Perbacco.  We chose the latter for an experience second to none.  We entered a huge restaurant and passed a beautiful bar to their upstairs dinning room.  

We were greeted by a pleasant female waitress that turned out to be the best server EVER!  (See quick tip or read on for specifics).  An amazing thing happens when you have the experience of such a server; you realize how bad your service has been all along.  Ah, Alexandra, where have you been all my dinning life?  I highly recommend being seated in this young woman's section.  Her timing, demeanor and recommendations were all sincere and spot on.

We started with the beet and goat cheese salad, asparagus and Brussels sprouts.  Next, our party of four collectively decided to experience the most of their menu by having the following three pastas:  
TAJARIN - HANDCUT TAGLIATELLE / 5 HOUR PORK SUGO / PORCINI MUSHROOMS

RAVIORA 'D SEIRASS - PASTA FILLED WITH MEYER LEMON SCENTED RICOTTA / ASPARAGUS PASSATO

RABATÒN - TRUFFLE-HERB RICOTTA GNOCCHI / WILD MUSHROOM SUGO

Pastas were perfectly presented and portioned evenly between our four.  Everyone in our party delighted in the bounty and depth of flavors orchestrated.  

For dessert we chose:
RICOTTA MOUSSE / LAMBRUSCO MACERATED STRAWBERRIES

FENNEL DUSTED BOMBOLONI / STAR ANISE SCENTED CHOCOLATE SAUCE & ORANGE MARMELLATA 
(Everyone's absolute favorite; simply divine!)

BURNT CARAMEL GELATO / TAHITIAN VANILLA SEA SALT

A beautiful moment when you know you've experienced something special.  Like a fleeting moment of a lover's caress; or a radio song that slips your mind once the ride is over.  Hurry here while these moments still exist and are realized.  Stellar culinary cuisine & spectacular service awaits.
author: Kalani C.

description:
What a feast!! Holy crickets I was stuffed leaving Perbacco. It was a friends birthday dinner so there were eight of us at this dinner. We ordered from every inch of the menu and had a pretty solid wine aficionado working the drink menu. Dinner was glorious, however when the main course came I think I may have only eaten two bites I was so stuffed.

I would suggest seeing how you feel after each dish before moving on to the next part of the menu - they do a great job of getting food out quickly so the lag time isn't worrisome. Also seemed like a great spot to take a date.

Get reservations. Now.
author: Jason M.

description: Great food! Didn't completely blow me away though
author: Jason R.

description:
3 stars = mediocrity. In this case, good food but for $150/couple I expect to be wowed. Dazzled. Amazed. Well, if not that, at least somewhat happy.  

In this case I probably would have written a better review if the meal had cost around $80/couple. But when you raise the price you also raise the bar and I find it hard to not address the cost issue when I am reviewing food. For example, here, my entree of Seared Sea Scallops was delicious with several interesting additions including pomegranate seeds. The scallops were perfectly preparied. But with only 3 scallops sitting on a rather large plate I was left to wonder if ~$10/scallop is really a fair price rather than wow, what an interesting mix of flavors. By the way, I'm not a complete crumudgeon: I thought the ceviche appetizer was well worth the $15.

All in all, service is impeccable, food is great. Go if you don't care about the cost and only if you're in the area.
author: Hagit K.

description:
So-so food and lousy service.   The salad was good.   But the sole was laden with grease, salt and heavy cream.   The dessert was tiny but tasty.   

The waiter was extremely inattentive.  I was trying to get her attention for more coffee and another piece of bread, but finally gave up.
author: Ed W.

description:
The breadsticks here suck......makes me sad because I love grissini.

BUT, everything else, especially the pastas, are great! Perbacco is one of those safe restaurants that are great for a date, friends outing, or even a business meeting. It's formal and yet somewhat  romantic, but not stuffy. You could get away with dressing casual here.

As far as appetizers go, the burrata cheese & heirloom tomato salad is delicious. As far as the food, I would definitely opt for the pasta selections.  The TAJARIN which feature a delicious pork sugo sauce and tagliatelle is SO SO good. They use dried porcini mushrooms, but  it's great.


The wine line is great, too. Plenty of American & Italian options. 

Taking into account ambiance, food options, wine list, service, & pricing, this place is great for any occasion.
author: Veronica S.

description: Love this restaurant! Servers are so friendly. Made great recommendations with food and wine. They are constantly changing their menu which I love so you may love something one night, go back and it's not there but that's what makes it exciting!
author: Michael M.

description:
Had dinner here with some friends of ours and my fiance had been raving about this place for a long time. To be honest I have a negative bias against Italian restaurants. I just don't find most places that interesting. Perbacco was completely different than what I expected.

The food was not your average Italian boring fare. The menu was really interesting and had many items on it that I wanted to try. I think the star was the Papperdelle with braised short rib that my fiance got. Delicious and rich. I got the slow roasted pork shoulder with this killer butternut sqush puree. Omg that puree was so good.

We had several apetizers, the buratta, grilled octopus and heirloom tomatos all excellent. Service was good and the decor is modern but approachable. 

For such a nice place the price point is not bad. Mid 20's for entrees. 

Can't wait for my next trip back.
author: Hyung L.

description:
For whatever reason - Destiny - I have enjoyed the pleasure of so many celebrations whether planned or on the fly at Perbacco.  

For my most recent un-birthday, I chose to return to the scene of my 34th and where I've eaten on New Year's Eve more than once.  Actually, I chose Barbacco for dinner and Perbacco for dessert.  

I was with my much-adored former neighbors, and because of Mrs. Computer Geek's appreciation of the absurd and our history, I wanted a very laid-back venue where I could just be my uncensored self, Kimcognito...laugh a lot, and loudly.  It's not demure at all.  

Childrens:  Team Umberto & Staffan reek of truffled excellence.  They also have an exquisite Pastry Chef - Suzanne LaFleur, who seduced me with... 

Wait.  You need to know that this dessert is dangerous-sexy and cannot be consumed solo.  Would I lead you astray, Gentle Yelper?  

Douglas.
Fir.
Panna.
Cotta.
Garnished.
With.
Pignole.
And deep berries that I just recall because of sensory overload.

Hello, marry me - and it was the debut of this dessert.  The mouthfeel was liquid silk and so delicate, you can't believe it.  I know the name sounds a bit odd, but you must order it; don't even think about it.  

Redolent in f the perfect balance of evergreen, woodsy notes of pignole and just-right tart berries, it's edible ecstasy.  

I didn't take any snaps that night, because I'm an epic romantic in the manner of John Donne's sonnets - "T'would [have been]  a profanation of our love.... "  to have taken pictures; you need to experience it for yourself and be completely in the moment, sans distractions.  

Go.  Order.  And after  the edible petite morte  - linger over Suzanne LaFleure's petite fours.
author: Kim D.

description:
We went to Perbacco last night for dinner with out of town guests. 

The appetizers -- tajarin was okay (they should have asked us for cracked pepper or Parmesan cheese), carne cruda was very bland but nice presentation, big eye tuna was fresh and nicely presented and last, the octopus was chewy and tough.

My dinner was the halibut and it was very bland; the sauce should have been more seasonal. 

My husband had the quail and it was very good but the presentation was unoriginal; one of our guests had the short ribs and that was probably the best plate.

Dessert was ok; not as delicious as the waiter made them sound.

The annoying part of the evening is when they cleared our table without asking us if we were done; and I mean in one clean swoop -- bread, wine and all. 

Also, don't be fooled by the valet -- get there early and find your own parking. We found our car in the exact spot we left it and we were still charged $10 by the restaurant! 

One star goes to the waiter and his welcoming attitude and the second star goes to the sommelier for a great wine recommendation.
author: Jane K.

description: The food was very good! My husband had the duck and it was cooked perfectly. The pastas were great as well. The service wasn't as good- I had more questions that weren't really answered.. the waiter was in a hurry
author: Sarah P.

description:
We're huge fans of Barbacco, and were looking forward to trying Perbacco for a long time. We'll be sticking with Barbacco in future. Not that Perbacco was bad, it's just depressingly mediocre by comparison.

I ordered the tuna sashimi with melon and chili as an appetizer. What little flavor the dish had was drowned out by the heat of the chili slices. Followed that with a tagliatelle with pork and mushroom sugo. Again, not much flavor. Just salt. Not too much salt, just - not much else.

Atmosphere was too loud for a comfortable conversation. Service was good but not great. Wine list was long, but... would gewürztraminer really be asking too much?

Big disappointment. Not bad, just really really meh. Go to Barbacco instead: you'll get better food for less money with better ambiance and it'll be easier to get a reservation.
author: Mike D.

description: Excellent! Great food and service! Atmosphere is nice as well! Pricy but the meal warrants it! Yum!
author: sarah R.

description: We chose this place because I wanted vegetarian options and the Mr. wanted brussel spouts. We both had scrumptious cocktails. I started with an endive strawberry salad and a delicious cheese something. Both were seasoned well and were pretty much perfect. The Mr. Started with an asparagus lemon ravioli. Ummm.. Fantastic! The Mr. thought it was too buttery - but how can that be a complaint? He are every bite. As mains, the Mr. had scallops (which he thought were cooked well) and I had a very rich blu cheese pasta. Yumyum! Well worth the $160 overall.
author: jessica r.

description:
Is it bad to say the best part of the meal was the bread and butter?

My step-mother LOVES Perbacco! She knows I'm a total foodie and is constantly asking if I've tried Perbacco yet. It's been on my list for errm, over a year and the only thing that brought me there was my quest to check #18 Salumi Misti Plate off my 7x7 list...

My gf and I had reservations at 8 PM last night. Perbacco was bustling when we arrived. We waited for 10 minutes while they got our table ready for us.

FOOD:
*Breadsticks and Pesto Dipping Sauce (complimentary): The breadsticks were like ordinary breadsticks you would find at the grocery store. They were a bit too crunchy for my liking. The pesto dipping sauce was very light and fresh, but b/c there wasn't parmesan cheese in it (at least I didn't taste any), so it was bland.  

*Bread and butter: The bread was nice, crusty and had a pillowly soft center. The butter was AMAZINGLY good. It definitely had a higher butterfat content than the standard American butter has; it had a velvety texture than melted into each taste bud.

*Salumi Misti Plate (#18 on 7x7): Don't get me wrong, I love bacon, ham, salami, terrines, galantines, and pates, but I wasn't "wowed" by the Salumi plate. There were about 8 different kinds of house-cured meats, none of which were explained to us, so we didn't know what was what. Other than the pate, all the other meats just tasted like different types of fat and lard. Thank goodness the pickled gherkin, cauliflower and our chianti help balanced out the oiliness. 

*Crudo Hamachi: Three thick slices of hamachi drizzled in oil and sprinkled with shaved fennel, serrano pepper and tangerines. Although the hamachi was buttery, it had a pungent fishy smell to it, which I found to be odd. There was no "fishy" taste which perhaps  the kick from the serrano pepper and the sweet/tartness from the tangerines masked?

*Pappardelle w/ Shortrib Ragu: After seeing rave reviews on YELP, I was so excited to try this dish. But, when I finally got to, it was a let down. The handmade pappardelle was excellent and was cooked to a perfect al-dente and the short-rib was very tender. However, the sauce was a HUGE disappointment b/c it did NOT tie the dish together. I expected it to be somewhat like a marsala; rich and savory sauce packed w/ flavor, but it was nothing like it. It was flavorless, watery and did not adhere to the pappardelle or shortrib

*Slow-Roasted Pork Shoulder w/ Chanterelles and Fingerling Potatoes: The pork shoulder was fork tender, but it was evident that the accompanying sauce was just drizzled on the side as opposed to the pork being braised in it b/c it was flavorless. The chanterelles were tender, as were the potatoes and that's the only good thing I can say about the dish.

DRINKS:
*Hendrick's Tonic: Nice and strong w/ a hint of cucumber flavoring. A very clean and crisp cocktail. 
*2004 Chianti, Riserva, Riserva, Vigna Misciano, Borgo Scopeto (Sangiovese): Smooth, light, fruity notes, and a very acidic aftertaste which helped balanced out the oiliness from some the dishes.

PRICES:
*Apps: $8-12
*Pastas: $11-14 for an appetizer portion and $16-$19 for an entrée portion
*Entrees: $18-$26

SERVICE:
Our waitress was very friendly but not very attentive. It took us about 20 minutes to flag her down before we could order our bottle of wine. However, the busboys always made sure our water was filled. Our food came out in 20-25 minute increments which lead to total dining time of 2 hours.

AMBIANCE/DECOR:
Perbacco is much larger than it appears to be from the outside. The décor is very simple and clean; red brick walls to the left, marble floor, light auburn ceiling, ivory walls, white linens, brown booths and seating and large vases of flowers scattered throughout.

Perbacco was very busy for a Tuesday night; hence it was very loud. As the other reviews stated, this is NOT a date spot. This is more for  pow-wow lunches and business dinners. 

I didn't like the fact that you the bathroom is downstairs and you have to walkdown a long flight of stairs to get there which is challenging with heels after several cocktails/glasses of wine. 

CROWD:
Stuffy mature FIDI crowd dressed in suits and ties.

PARKING: 
Relatively easy street parking after 6 PM. 

I'm glad I was able to check #18 off my 7x7 list, but highly doubt I would return to Perbacco. Although the dishes were well-prepared, none of the dishes stood out b/c they were flavorless. NEXT!!!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Staffan Terje's cooking continues to evolve. We love how he gently pushes the boundaries of what American diners' conception of what Italian food is. Not everything reaches the heights, but the food is complex and unusual, and therefore worth the extra star.

The four of us shared the salumi misti platter. Mostly ordinary (the bar has been raised so high by so many places these days; we are fortunate in the Bay Area!), but loved the rillette. So often this is an overdone, overlarge, overrich spread, but Perbacco's is light, fluffy, and a perfect starter. Next time I would skip all the other salume and just have this with their lovely housemade breads.

-- Beet salad with mandarin orange: very good
-- Octopus roasted with cranberry beans in tomato concasse: outstanding!
-- Burrata cheese with roasted butternut squash and pears, cress, herb vinaigrette: a Grade B. Chunks were too large, textures too similar, flavors too mild. Squash hadn't caramelized enough to add its usual sweet notes.
-- Ligurian fisherman's soup. Good, but VERY salty
-- Fritto misto. Batter shattered off. Green beans & fennel should have been cut shorter. But the aioli was superb, saved the whole dish.
-- Vitello tonnato. Always superb, and we always order it. Tasted like they sneaked some anchovies into the tonnato sauce, which we heartily approve of. Luscious!

Entrees:
-- Risotto with local porcini mushrooms, caramelized onions, toma della rocca cheese. This was a very different risotto preparation. Compared to the usual pale-colored lemon or chicken risotto, this was more like a "short ribs" of risotto, dark and tangy. Spouose thought it was odd, but I thought it was fabulous.
-- Ravioli filled with roasted butternut squash, toasted hazelnuts, and pomegranate seeds. A beautiful dish, both in looks and taste. Very generous on the half-size serving.
-- Pan-roasted monkfish. Very good, but the veggies (previously always reliable) were al dente, too hard to eat. Had I known this I would have insisted the plate be returned to the kitchen to be redone, but I didn't find out until afterwards.
-- Liberty Farm duck breast, warm salad of brussels sprout leaves, persimmon, dates, pancetta. Very well executed; sauce was more savory than sweet which is what I prefer.

Desserts were good, not great. Service was excellent, this is one of the best-trained waitstaffs in the City.
author: Jean K.

description:
Delightful! My fellow yelper and I came here for our monthly yelp adventure.

We made the reservation for 8pm on a Weds and was seating promptly. However I do have to say that it's close to impossible to make a reservations here for 7pm. I tried to go a month and half in advance and... rejected. 

Their breadsticks with pesto sauce was phenomenal. You can always tell the quality of the restaurant by their bread. 

Salumi misti: holy cow and piggy! best cured meats I have ever had. 
Tajarin pasta: 3 out of 5. It was enjoyable, but not impressionable. 
Beef short ribs stracotto: This is the dish that will bring me back for more. Perfection.

Wine suggestions was great, our server was energetic and helpful.
author: Emily T.

description: We had a group of 35 and the feedback was unanimously positive. Six different hors d'oeuvres and there were only rave reviews. Chicken, sea bass and short ribs as entrees were all related to be fantastic (I can only attest to the sea bass). We had great service from Leo and Ener (I think that I spelled that right).
author: Christopher L.

description: Unfriendly staff - I guess that's a given in SF and I usually don't care as long as the food is good. The food was so-so. You can tell this place is hip, it knows it, and is going to ride it out until someone says "hey, this place is mediocre, expensive, and unfriendly". Or else it will continue to be a business lunch type place and succeed. Doesn't matter to me since I'm not going back.
author: jeremy m.

description: Delicious food, amazing staff, and extensive wine list. I'd highly recommend the pastas, all four of us loved ours and the buratta appetizer was incredible.
author: Courtney K.

description:
SEARED SEA SCALLOPS

BEEF SHORT RIB STRACOTTO

CAPICOLLO ARROSTO

I came here for dinner with co-workers during a business trip.  Excellent experience.  The service, food, and wine selection was on par!  Definitely recommend this place to all my Yelpers.  This is my new spot to eat at when I am in SF.  Any of the dishes listed above is a must have!
author: James Y.

description: In San Francisco recently on business. After my first meal at Perbacco I returned every night because I had to try as many dishes as possible...its that good. Highlights were the pappardelle with rabbit ragu, roasted octopus (OMG), dark chocolate-basil bonet for dessert. The food is SUPERB, and if you're lucky to have a waitress as good as Amber, your meal is elevated to a truly wonderful experience. She REALLY knows her stuff, knows her wine pairings, made great recommendations and is an absolute delight!! A memorable meal with memorable service. Can't wait to return!!
author: Ross M.

description:
Best Italian Restaurant in San Francisco. I really enjoyed my dinner with great pastas. The service is impeccable.

The Raviolini as appetizer is superb. Excellent Gnocchi as entree. 

I recommend to reserve through Open Table before.
author: Rafael S.

description:
I went to Perbacco last night with a group of friends to celebrate my birthday.  The restaurant is very classy and the decor is simple yet elegant.  Parking is also very easy in this part of town at nighttime.  

Upon our arrival, my friend secretly told the hostess that it was my birthday.  Before we got to our table, they put a birthday card at my seat!  Very thoughtful.

The food was presented well.  I'm not much of a foodie, but my friends definitely are and we all loved our meal.  I had the halibut and my friends ordered the rabbit, pork shoulder and pasta.  They were all delicious.  The meat was not overcooked and each dish had a distinct flavor.  I had the mushroom soup as well and that was very tasty.  Make sure you try the sunchokes and brussel sprouts as well.  Oh, and the breadsticks!  We couldn't stop eating them!

The staff was very attentive and did not miss a beat.  5 star experience all around.  For dessert, we had the white chocolate mousse and enjoyed that as well.  Since it was my birthday, they brought out macademia nut meringue cookies as a special treat.  Thank you!

If you're looking for a great meal that is reasonably priced for the quality of food and service, Perbacco is a solid restaurant.
author: Akash R.

description: Wonderful lunch here in the heart of the financial district of San Francisco. This was a celebratory event for a team at work, and it was wonderful. The service was capable and pleasant, the food absolutely delicious, and the wine was perfect. I hope to bring my family here for dinner soon.
author: Paul K.

description:
Power lunch.

If you're looking forward to seal the deal with your next client, look no further than Perbacco. Like-minded Fidi people flock to this lunch spot so I was glad that I made a reservation, because I was wrong to think that it would be less busy with the nasty rainy weather we have. 

Upon getting seated, water and breadsticks with pesto sauce were provided. You can skip the breadsticks, a bit too crunchy, but don't worry you also get a piece of thick focaccia bread with butter.

I had to order the salumi misti plate, which is #18 on the Big Eat SF list. We had to motion for the waiter to come over and tell us what each item is. He took the time explaining each meat but I could barely hear him since the noise level in here was pretty high. There were 5 different house cured salumi and 2 kinds of pate on the plate. I really liked the salumi di coto with its noticeable dots of fat. The prosciutto cured in red wine was definitely the saltiest of all, so I put some quince jelly to tone it down. The cornichons were a fave of my BFF! Both of us didn't want to touch the lardo because it just looked unappetizing.

Absolutely get the Rabaton, it's a truffled-herb gnocchi with roasted mushroom sugo. He kept raving about these soft pillows! This dish is a good choice for vegetarians as it is very filling.

I ordered the Tajarin. Imagine hand-cut tagliatelle, pork sugo cooked for 5 hours crowned with just the right amount of parmigiano reggiano.  A simple dish but incredibly good. 

Oh, dessert. 

The pistachio panna cotta with pomegranate gelatina and pistachio cookies were more than welcome in my mouth.  Although this panna cotta was too soft set for my liking, we still finished the whole thing.

Service was professional but could be more friendlier next time.  It was a packed house so that's understandable. A fine meal shared with a good friend at a solid restaurant, my only regret is that I had to go to work after.
author: Janice C.

description:
SERVICE:
5 stars (I'd give 7, if I could)
The phenomenal service really added to my experience here. The staff is attentive, knowledgeable and friendly. I'm vegetarian and they really worked with me to find things on the menu that worked or could be made vegetarian. You'll see that I didn't LOVE the food below, but the service was so good, that I'd consider going back JUST for the service.

AMBIANCE:
The crowd seemed like a bunch of businessmen / older individuals / couples--wasn't very diverse. The mood was on the formal side. Really good for a dinner w/ a significant other's parents or something. Formal, but not too formal, excellent service, and decent food.

FOOD:
3 stars
(out of clarity--5's are rare for me--things that blow me away, 4 is really good--things i'd go back and eat more of, 3 is okay--a decent meal that one should try but that i wouldn't really go back for, 2 is okay--a meal that i won't really remember or recommend others to try, 1 is bad)

We were served some breadsticks with delicious cilantro sauce as soon as we got there (really nice because a couple of us arrived hungry and needed that to keep us smiling til we got our meals.) The cilantro sauce was so good we asked for extra to have with our meal, and because of Perbacco's awesome service, got more in no time. 

We ordered the fig salad, which was pretty good. The cheese on the dish was rather strong, so if that isn't your cup of tea, beware. We also to the Rabaton, and two of us didn't like it very much. It was definitely the right texture (melt-in-your-mouth texture) but none of us ended up being huge fans of the flavor (may be a personal thing). We got the fingerling potatoes (made vegetarian) and they weren't too special. For dessert we got panforte and panna cotta. The panforte was reasonably good but did not blow us away and the panna cotta was DELICIOUS and great texture. Oh and the bread that came with the entrees was good.

PRICES:
Reasonable, actually! I think it was quite affordable for what it was. When I walked in, I expected each entree to be much more expensive (just given the formal decor).
author: Neeharika B.

description:
We read so many great things online about this place for vegetarians. We went there for our wedding anniversary dinner during the month of August. August is a good test for any restaurant which caters to vegetarians, when the produce is at its peak. The place was packed and it would have been impossible to get in without reservations.

Their salads, both of late summer fruits and heirloom tomatoes were outstanding. The pasta taster, where we tried the raviora and rabaton were very good, but the cheese cream sauce was heavy and smothering. Dessert was nothing to write on Yelp about!
Service was good.

I think there are plenty of other upscale options in SFO to try next time.
author: Runip G.

description:
Had a pre-Thanksgiving night dinner at Pebacco. 

I am loving ultra modern rooms and this one has it. 

Our server was very knowledgable and provided great 
information on both the menu and the Truffle Specials!

Opted for Frito Misto starter, table had a combination of the ravioli con truffle oil and wild mushrooms (amazing)

Others did the Risotto and the Gnocchi, finished with the Pistachio Gelato - TDF

Great night, great friends, great MEAL!
author: George C.

description:
I'm kicking myself for not going next door to Michael Mina's because I had a choice.

Everything was just okay.  Service was great.  Octopus was overcooked.  Food was good but unmemorable.  I guess my favorite part of the meal was the "ugly but good" cookies and the breadsticks.  

I hate to give this place such a bland review, but nothing compels me to come back here.  Sorry, Perbacco.  I disagree.  Italian food should be rich, charming, evocative, sensuous, and make you want to lick the plate and not care if sauce stains your favorite shirt. 

My dinner was like that summer of '96 where you did.....  Remember? Oh wait, I don't even remember.
author: Sandy T.

description:
I decided to eat at Perbacco on my last night in SF. I thought it was going to have a quiet peaceful dinner.  The noise level in the restaurant is kind of unbearable.

They were nice enough to move me to a more quiet area.  
I ordered the:
Mushroom soup (it was good)
Seared Sea Scallops with Matsutake Mushroom and Salsify Ragout, Leeks, crumbled Marazapane (the scallops were kinda sandy... ICK!)

The servers were great, but I don't think I'd return back :( 
Sorry Perbacco, you disappointed me.
author: Twig T.

description:
I was a little disappointed the last time I was here with the service, but the food is always amazing. Everything tasted great. The pasta is always fresh and handmade. They have a great salumi selection as well. Not sure if they still have their pistachio panna cotta, but they was probably my favorite dessert that I've had there.

Only downside are those steep stairs to get to the upper level, but the restaurant, overall has wonderful Italian food.
author: Nicole L.

description:
food was mediocre. We had the salt cod and dungeness crab frittelle, tajarin, dry aged steak and a toffee cake for dessert. The only thing that left me with a lasting impression was just the dessert. Overall, it was only ok and I wouldn't need to come back. 

On another side note, our waitress also needs to brush up on her waitressing skills. Horrible service.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This is the kind of place you take your lawyer when s/he comes in from out of town and you're working in the area (Embarcadero/Financial Districts), and feel you have to go out for a "nice dinner."  

Not the kind of place you go when you and your honey are looking for a romantic meal. Not really even the kind of place to go when a group of friends are getting together for a fun night.

That said, the food was very good, as was the service.  Had the arugula and grilled d'anjou pear salad with hazelnuts. The pears were too hard. The arugula, excellent.

Best thing about the meal was their papardelle with short ribs ragu.  The pasta was house-made and was delicious. The ragu, rich and packed with flavor.  A very good dish.

The not so great part of the meal:  their much touted salumi platter. Good, but by no means special or out of the ordinary. 

All-in-all, a business person's place to eat when the company's picking up the tab.
author: David M.

description: The best cocktails I have had anywhere in the city. Their mixologist Lisa is incredible. Her cocktails are so flavorful and not watered-down they really let you know what a cocktail should be. You need to go in and see Lisa at Perbacco. You won't be disappointed.
author: Tom S.

description: Great place for a business lunch.  Four of us met for a business discussion and a leisurely meal.  Upstairs seating, service was super, food fabulous.  The steak salad with grilled greens was fantastic, as was the seafood.  A wonderful menu and a perfect atmosphere for a good meeting and meal.
author: Maureen V.

description:
Perbacco is one of those places that the food is so good, you get flashbacks of your meal and think of those memories fondly. 

This is the type of place we bring clients to because it is consistently good, nice atmosphere and not too loud. I am happy to go anytime. 

I usually get a salad, I love the Roasted Bartlett Pear or they have a great Heirloom Tomato Salad (Seasonally) and either the Fish or the Steak depending on my mood. Either choice is usually fantastic. The bread is great too, but I try not to ruin my appetite. There is so much to enjoy here.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
What a fantastic experience!!  The reviews helped me decide to dine here, and I am very glad I did.

There's a large bar and booth seating up front.  As a solo diner this particular weeknight, I was offered seating in front, though I declined.  I wanted to savor my time and food with a conventional seat in the dining room.  I was rewarded.

My server was perfectly attentive to me while not imposing, though I was alone.  The atmosphere was busy, yet in a formal, businesslike manner, and you could appreciate the level of professionalism that is exhibited.

The quality of what I ate was squisito.  I started with the fig salad, and for my main had the halibut.  And of course I had to have a side of pappardelle, certo.  Tutti fantastico!  Mangiata bene.  I had the Piedmonte rosso wine flight which was a great way to sample five wines.

I look forward to my return to SF and this restaurant.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
I've been here twice and both time the food was delicious. On my last visit, I had the gnocchi which was amazing --so light and tender. My guest had the tagliatelle which also didn't disappoint. For dessert we shared the olive oil cake with douglas fir cremma.

We sat at the bar and received top-notch treatment by Guadalupe. He knows the menu like the back of his hand, makes an excellent drink and was totally attentive.

I highly recommend you stop by here for lunch or dinner the next time you're in the neighborhood.
author: John H.

description:
01.09.12

Hosted a company event here, complete with hors d'oeuvres + cocktail hour prior to a five-course dinner.  The staff is amazing and extremely helpful, with a side of sass to boot.  Just the way I like it!

We had the mezzanine booked for our group.  The curtains draw into the seating area, and the front was reserved for the standing reception.

We started with the six item hors d'oeuvres ($25/person).
Crudo, mushroom risotto balls, pig trotter cake, culatello (cold cut), burrata, and butternut squash croquette.  Great balance of fresh ingredients, crispy flavors, and gorgeous presentations.  I knew I was in for a treat for dinner.

Five-course dinner ($78/person).
1) Truffle, polenta, and egg filled ravioli.  Simply amazing, and my favorite course of the night.

2) Pear and pomegranate salad.  Thought this could have been done better.  The pears were drenched in sauce, and there were entirely too much endives.

3) Ricotta and herb gnocchi.  Added a pinch of red pepper flakes for the perfect punch.

4) Choice of scallops or filet mignon.  I went for the beef and never looked back.

5) Buttermilk panna cotta with pressed quince and candied citrus.  I'm not a sweets girl but this one takes the cake.  I probably could have had three of these and then went home to feel guilty about it.

Overall, it was an extremely pleasant experience.  The glasses of prosecco didn't hurt, either :)
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm sure you're thinking, how could I give Perbacco 3 stars? In all honesty it probably deserves 4 stars but when I compare it against its sister Barbacco a few doors down ... it's no comparison!

Perbacco and Barbacco are completely different restaurants. Different vibes, different food (same style). Perbacco is definitely a more upscale, fine dining atmosphere. The food was, indeed, delicious but it does lack the homeyness and punch that you get from Barbacco.

Order the Salumi Misti - it's just as good as everyone says. We also had the burrata, which is on everyone's menu these days, but was delicious.

We also had one of the evening's risotto specials - good but it sounds like there were other standouts on the menu. Scallops were perfection.

Overall, a lovely fine-dining restaurant. Great service, good food. I just prefer the Barbacco for a little more personality.
author: Vivi T.

description: Foods great, busy at lunch time, noisy though, so don't take someone with a hearing aid unless you don't want them to hear
author: Alan R.

description:
In the heart of the financial district on California, you'll find Perbacco.  You enter and are greeted by a bar and seating area.  Down the hall from the bar, the restaurant opens into a clean, slick room with brick walls and long foot long mirrors stretching horizontally across the wall above the seats and just below the ceiling.

The food was generally quite good, though not outstanding.  The highlights for me were the brussel sprout sides and the chocolate bonet.  On the down side, the pork shoulder entre was a bit undercooked.  Overall somewhere between 3-4 stars, but I'll go with four.
author: Brad B.

description: Did a corporate event.  Great service, food and venue.  Our server was Ben he was fantastic, exceeded our expectations and went above and beyond.
author: Neil L.

description: Great dining with friends, food was outstanding. The polenta is AMAZING. Will definitely return, only thing lacking is their cocktail menu. They do make a mean sidecar though, you just have to ask.
author: Melissa H.

description: Best SF Italian, IMHO.  Outstanding regional Italian wine selection.
author: Scott L.

description:
I came here on a nice dinner date with my bf one night, and we were quite happy with how the night went. Parking was definitely hard to find - lots of one way streets, so be cautious, especially at night. They offered valet parking, but we opted out and found parking in about 15 minutes. This means, plan to leave early to make your reservation!

Service here is amazing! Our waiter was friendly and very patient and attentive. The menu wasn't super long ... but I am a picky eater and found not so many choices. My bf got the Papardelle, a short rib pasta dish. I got the Rabaton, which was a herbish gnocchi dish. I only got the half portion, and found that to be filling, but my bf got the full portion and was not full. We both agreed that the dishes were excellent though!! No complaints there. We skipped out on dessert, because we had plans to go elsewhere. I want to try their desserts sometime though! 

The overall atmosphere was nice, and I had a wonderful time Definitely gets pricey fast, so this isn't a place I'd visit often, but surely a treat every once in a while.
author: Ashley N.

description:
The food was delicious!

I recently switched to the Paleo diet but I had no trouble with the great option.

Our server was attentive. Everyone in our party was satisfied!

Will definitely come back.
author: Sophia L.

description:
We had party of seven for a birthday, got the private table near the kitchen. We enjoyed excellent food and terrific service. There was a birthday card awaiting the guest of honor from the Perbacco staff when we were seated. That was a nice touch. 

For food, we enjoyed:

Appetizers: Salumi Misti (tasty, good for a group), pesce crudo (recommended, favorite appetizer! Light, refreshing, great combo of flavors), and fritto misto of rock shrimp (fried dish; taste the fried lemon together with the shrimp for a nice flavor)

Pasta course: we did the BIS (two tastings of pasta for the table), including the very nice pappardelle 

Main course: the capicollo arrosto (slow-roasted pork shoulder) was beautiful but did not quite get there on flavor for me; the beef short rib stracotto was better; the scallops looked delicious but I didn't get to try them.

I'd go back for the service, pesce crudo, salumi misti, some pasta tastings, and a bottle of the 2006 Confini, Lis Neris.
author: Tony K.

description: Really happy with my experience here although I give barbacco my 5 star rating. Granted I came here for a private function and only sampled the pre fix that was provided I will come back for the full experience based on how nice the service was.
author: Lenny K.

description: Everything was great here starting from the greeting at the door, seating, ordering, and enjoying my food and desserts :)
author: Pim H.

description:
Came here for lunch... nice place (seemed more like a dinner place honestly, but I don't mind), staff was friendly. I got the ravioli with wine and short rib... I loved the flavor and you can tell that they make the pasta themselves. I thought the portion size/food quality/service/price was all in sync. 

I think this is a good place to go when you want a nice italian lunch in the area. I still need to go back and get that salumi dish...

EDIT 5/25/2012:

I came to Perbacco again and my experience was perfect. Every dish we had was great (we took suggestions from the waiter... if you don't know what to get, the waiters there seem to really know the menu, so don't be afraid to ask for a suggestion). My favorite dish was the pappardelle. Really nothing to complain about. Perbacco is a wonderful restaurant with a great ambiance and delicious food that is totally worth the price (and it's not unreasonable by any means). Can't wait to go back!
author: Alison B.

description:
Like many other Yelpers before me, I came here on account of their 7x7 Big Eat List item, the salumi dish. 

It's a great culinary experience to taste one of the best cured-meats dishes in San Francisco. There's something for everyone. Pro Tip: The waiters are more than happy to talk about the different meats and point out where each one's from. 

The Liberty Farm Duck Breast is delicious, to boot. I mean, who messes up the fattiest bird on the planet? Overall, a great addition to the FiDi scene with a pretty comprehensive menu...even the vegetarian girlfriend would be pleased with this modern Northern Italian-styled spot.
author: Abel L.

description:
We were able to do our work holiday dinner here. They recommended the Barrolo Room for parties of 16-20 which was perfect because you can oversee the chaos in the kitchen during dinner service. 

FOOD. 5 stars. The crowd favorite was the octopus salad

WINE/CHAMPAGNE. 5 stars. Awesome selection. They helped us pick and pair our wine with our courses.

STAFF. 5 stars. Very attentive and friendly. We were the last people in the restaurant and all patiently waited for us. 

AMBIANCE. 5 stars. The Barrolo room was perfect.


I'm definitely coming back to this place.
author: J M.

description:
I went at lunch time with a group of 4 people. We ordered the salumi, the burratta cheese, and the vitello tonnato as appetizers and none of them dissapointed. Very unique and extraordinary flavors.
As an entree I had the pappardelle that was also excellent, great texture and high quality ingredients. I tried one of my colleagues gnocchi and was EXCELLENT, even better than the pappardelle.
Don't remember the name of the wine they recommended us but perfect pairing.
Good service and nice ambience. I recommend it for lunch since you don't have to wait for hours or make reservation.

I came back and ordered to go and the Fig Leaf Pannacotta and was OUT OF THIS WORLD. Taste, texture, combination of the different elements.
author: Guillermo M.

description: If it wasn't for the wine and the sommelier, this place wouldn't get two stars. Honestly, the pasta with five hour slow cooked pork (can't recall the name) tasted like top ramen with Hamburger Helper. The Scallops were good and very tender.  The service, though I would assume is not the norm at such a highly rated establishment, was horrible.  I haven't felt that conflicted about having to leave a tip in years.  Our experience had a few decent moments, but for the money, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've come here a bunch of times but never remember to review it. Must say something. 

It's ok. I like their sister restaurant next door much better, Barbacco. 

The food is really good though but for some reason, I'm not the biggest fan.

I have had their hanger steak, it melts in your mouth. Their veal appetizer is truly delicious. Their smoked salmon salad was simple and filling. I loved their side brussel sprouts though! 

For some reason, after I left this restaurant this time, I felt like food was all over me. Might be the low ceilings and the fat/oil just clings to you. Gross. 

I'd pick Barbacco for sure over Perbacco. Older crowd here.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Wanted to love it, ended up feeling it was just okay - actually kind of "meh." 

Started with the roasted and raw pears/persimmon salad which the waiter kindly offered to split for us. When the plate came, my girlfriend's salad looked picture perfect while mine looked like mush. I realize they offered to split the salad, but usually when that happens, both salads look the same - not like one of them went through the meat grinder. Oh well, the awful appearance didn't seem to impact the taste. 

My girlfriend had the short rib pappardelle, I had the aged beef and both were just okay, not what I had expected based on friend's recommendations and Yelp reviews - too bad. 

The net, net of our experience - service was great, food was underwhelming, but the Prebacco! cocktail was amazing!
author: susan H.

description:
Everyone talks about the Salumi dish at Perbacco, so even though I am not a fan of cured meats I had to try it. I wasn't surprised I wasn't a fan of eating meats that looked raw, but luckily my bf loved it.
