The pappardelle with short rib ragu had a very strong wine taste to it, but I really liked the pasta. I did not enjoy the pasta filled with short rib and mushroom ...so definitely would never order that again. The rabbit was cooked pretty well.

My favorite 2 dishes from Perbacco are their brown butter brussel sprouts and the black and white chocolate mousse! I never liked brussel sprouts until I tried it here!
author: Cindy L.

description: I had the papardelle with short ribs.  It was decent, wish it had a bit more flavor.  There were a few noodles that were stuck to one another, so those noodles were lacking in sauce.  I'll give this place another try.  The breadsticks, pesto and foccacia were good!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Out of all the places we visited while in San Francisco, this one felt the most expensive for what you got. We decided to come here for a last minute 9:00 PM dinner while on vacation in San Francisco. Since we were staying less than 2 blocks away, it was a great choice to walk to. For dinner I ordered the coujette, which was potato gnocchi with duck livers and other organ meat. It was described as very rustic and earthy. It was a good description, but the meat and the sauce was a little too game-y for my taste I think. The gnocchi was done perfectly though, as expected from a high end Italian restaurant. Lucky for me, the other half of our group ordered the shareable plates, which was about 1/2 cup of pasta, so they helped finish my meal. My boyfriend had the other gnocchi, which was a ricotta gnocchi with herbs and toasted hazelnuts, definitely the winner. For desert, we all shared my raspberry sorbetto with lemon cookies, which to me, was the best part of the meal. 

The reason I am not giving this restaurant the best review is because of 1. the portion sizes for the sharing plates and 2. our waiter who the entire time we ordered anything tried to unabashedly up-sell us on everything. I get you need to make a living, but when I say no the first time, I mean no. 

The ambiance of the restaurant had a very open and vibrant feel with lots of larger tables laughing and having a great time. I think I would return to the bar for the wine and desert.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Tried it for the first time last night.

The restaurant was a nice space.  Bar in the front, and tables in the back.

The menu is printed up daily.

Here's what we had:

The meal starts out with Bread Sticks and a nice Pesto sauce.  Later, you get bread which is OK.

FRITTO MISTO OF ROCK SHRIMP / SEASONAL BEANS / OLIVES / FENNEL / LEMON AIOLI $11 - This appetizer was really good and a highlight of our meal.

TAJARIN - HANDCUT TAGLIATELLE / 5 HOUR PORK SUGO / PORCINI MUSHROOMS $13 small/$18 large - The flavor of the pork was good.  However, there was no extra sauce.  For me, there was a disconnect between the pork and the noodles.  The noodles are set on the dish, then a scoop of the pork is put on top. I would say the dish is 1/3 pork and 2/3 noodles. While the flavor of the pork is good, the noodles are plain.  So you get, flavor with plain, flavor with plain.  I'm not sure how they can improve the dish. But, I would not order it again.

RISOTTO - ROASTED WILD MUSHROOMS / CARAMELIZED ONION / BUTTERNUT SQUASH / SPINACH / TOMA DELLA ROCCA $14 small/$19 large - I don't have Risotto often; so, I don't consider myself an expert.  That said, I enjoyed the dish.  It had nice, large, chunks of wild mushrooms.

PAN ROASTED BLACK BASS / SAUTÉED FENNEL AND FINGERLING POTATOES / BLOOD ORANGE BUTTER $28 - The wife had this and really enjoyed it.  She would order it again.

Other thoughts and comments:

The menu (as presented above) is all in CAPS and separated with "/". For me, the way the menu was presented, it was hard to imagine what the dish would be like and it was really hard for me to make a selection of what to eat.  I guess the most confusing part is that you have no sense of the proportion of the ingredients on the plate.  Perhaps they could make it more of a narrative like this:

"TAJARIN - House made (who cares whether they are handcut or not?)  Tagliatelle noodles with a scoop of Pork Sugo which is simmered for 5 hours, with porcini mushrooms"

When you order wine by the glass, they actually bring the bottle to the table and pour you a glass.  They even show you the label before they pour.  It was a nice and unexpected touch.

Parmesan cheese can be added to your dish by the waiter.  It comes pre-ground in a bowl, and they spoon it out for you.  For such a nice restaurant, I think it would be nicer if they would grind it or shave it at the table rather than spooning it out of a bowl.

The bathrooms are downstairs.  Given the lighting and the current custom of using yellow tape on a top and bottom step, I think they should add some yellow tape (especially to the top step) as after a few drinks, I could see someone stumbling down the stairs.  They have individual rooms with toilets, and a communal sink area to wash your hands.  For such a nice restaurant, I think they should try to figure out how to separate the Men's and Women's bathrooms and sink area.

During our meal, a waiter and busboy handled our table.  When we got up to leave the restaurant, not only did both of them thank us for coming; but four other employees did!!!!  It was a nice and unexpected touch, that made us feel really appreciated for dining with them.  My hats off to management for encouraging the employees to thank the guests when they leave!  As I said, it was unexpected; but both my wife and I positively commented on it when we were outside the restaurant.  It just made us feel really appreciated and wanting to come again.

Though my wife has eaten there several times for lunch, it was our first time for dinner.  We'll definitely return.

For those that care, they take AMEX.
author: Roy C.

description:
Excellent food, exquisitely prepared. The salumi was great, but there was one piece that should not have been served, as it was almost ALL fat and no meat.  That's only one slice on a dish, though, so I'm not making a case out of this.  All four of us were delighted with our food.  I would eat there again without hesitation.

My appetizer was so good, I was overwhelmed, but it's not on their online menu, so I can't copy it for you. It was a salt cod dish topped with a fried egg.  If you see it listed when you're there, you'll know what to do.

My entree was this, and it was fabulous.  Highly recommend.
LASAGNETTE - WIDE NETTLE PASTA RIBBONS / WILD BOAR RAGU / CHESTNUTS / CHESTNUT MUSHROOMS

The wine list is deep and includes a very large selection of Italian wines.  Our waitress ensured that everyone's wine needs were well accommodated.  She listened carefully to what I described as our desired characteristics and price, then recommended an Italian wine that worked well.  One person in our party didn't favor it (she prefers big, flabby over-opulent wines), so our waitress immediately poured her an alternate by-the-glass that pleased her.

We dined on the mezzanine level, with hopes that it would be quieter and easier for two couples to talk.  I would like to see some dampening elements introduced to that space, because when the restaurant was fully crowded, it was difficult to talk.  When some other tables finished and cleared, it became much easier. I recommend asking the restaurant where to sit upon booking your reservation if you want to have intimate conversation on a busy night (or any other time people get drunk and start out-bellowing each other).

The atmosphere is very lively, and the furnishings really feel like you're in a nice restaurant in Italy (lots of wood and marble).  It's very elegant, but not at all stuffy.
author: Dick B.

description: 8 of us went for dinner last night and maybe since tis BlackFriday, place was fully booked and reservations had to be made and paid to confirm a spot! Had the veal tongue+braisedsnails+roasted chanterelles+potatoes+garlic for starters, quail filled w chanterelles+douglas fir passato+chard drizzled w huckleberry jus for main and choc semifreddo almond dessert topped w sorbet and choc mousse - the veal and quail were tasty and the dessert was just ok. For drinks, had a cocktail made w Buddha'sHand Vodka which was just ok and also had a bottle of nero d'avola w the mains. Service was good.
author: Renuka V.

description: Went there last night. A bit expensive when you factor in the wine. The tagliatelle was certainly filling although on the salty side. Redemption: the cheesecake with pistachio sponge cake.
author: Jahan T.

description: Excellent place for the business lunch. Party of 3 on 08 August. Great host at the front desk. Cheerful server. Great food in nice lunch portions.
author: Philip S.

description: This place never let's me down when i come here with my coworker after a long day of work. And enjoy the good food and drinks. Also the service here is there priority....:)
author: Luis A.

description:
Came here with my whole family for a large party for my gpas 80th birthday and I was so excited for an excellent 4 star meal, when in fact, I ended up with a 1 star meal. I have never given a 1 star review before.. Until now. 
Started out with a strawberry lemonade that I was excited for but it came out to be the most sour and weird lemonade I have ever had! My dad said he hinted tomato juice in it??? Strange. But I brushed it off and didn't say anything to our waiter. 
Next came the house salad that was okay with some strong dressing on it that you couldn't change. I was eating mine, almost finishing when I found a worm on my plate. Now I'm not one to start screaming, but I was done with the salad part of the meal. My aunt wasn't though and complained to our waiter who brought me another salad that I didn't want bc I was already grossed out enough. And I hate wasting food. 
Anyways, for our entrees we had a choice of scallops or steak and I didn't feel like either. So I saw there was a vegetarian choice and I asked what it was. It was a rice with mushrooms and a mushroom sauce on top. I am not a fan of mushrooms, so I asked if I could just have some rice with some veggies put in and he said of course, not a problem! I was finally excited for some good food. When my plate came, it was a huge plate of red rice with chopped onions. UH that's not what I meant when I asked for VEGGIES.... It was the nastiest dish I have ever had and I barely ate a few spoonfuls. My gpa now thinks I never eat bc I just could not take this restaurant! I was so over the night, I just wanted to go home. The worm salad wasn't even comped for my gma and when I saw the price of the bill, I was mortified!! I have had better meals at so many places, this one just killed it for me. My mom and dad too, said they would never come back and they were not impressed at all. Sorry to say, but it wasn't at all what I was expecting that night. 
And by the way, when I got home, I was still of course starving, and had another meal at my house. 
The only good thing about that night, was seeing so many family members that I haven't seen in years and sharing some good laughs!
author: Megan F.

description:
Nice atmosphere, consistently good food. The service is always professional and kind. 
The cocktails are good.  The frito misto is delicious as well as the tagliatelle with short ribs and horseradish. Great go to restaurant.
author: T H.

description:
We had a fantastic, to die for dinner for my 55th birthday.  Although Perbacco doesn't offer senior discounts to rival the 25% off coffee special at McDonalds or the free small drink (no refills) at KFC, I agreed to eat here for my initial senior citizen dining foray.  What a treat.  Here's what to order:

Appetizers
Raviolo
Roasted Porcini Mushroom yada yada yada
Burratta cheese

The Burratta was beyond perfection if there is such a thing.  I guess it's kind of like giving 150% effort.

Main Courses
Langaroli - among top 3 pasta dishes of all time (that would be my all time since I can't account for ones that I haven't eaten - yes I know that many yelpers don't share my sentiment on this score and know when they've eaten something that's top 5 in the world.  Remember, I'm the one who got excited about the senior coffee discount at McDonalds.)

Rabaton (you can read their menu online for a translation)

Pappardelle

Even if it's just the two of you, order all three and take the leftovers home.

Dessert
I love ice cream and I've attempted to sample the best ice cream wherever I go.

Both my daughter and I think we just had the greatest ice cream in the world (in other words, I'm taking back what I said earlier in the Langaroli section of my review).  GET THE STRAWBERRY GELATO.  I'm not sure that it's even fair to call in Gelato because whatever it really was was otherworldly (my high school English teacher is turning over in her grave).

Normally, I won't give 5 stars to a place that I've only visited once but I'm making an exception tonight.  

And as if I haven't already written enough, the waitress was spectacular - a blond Italian 20-something woman who was everything you could possibly want in a server and more (perfect food and wine recommendations, personality, patience)  I left my largest % tip ever and wish I had given her more.  Go to Perbacco.
author: Mark B.

description:
Bambi makes a BIG deal about our wedding anniversary celebration, even when it's just she and me at the party. This year we decided to celebrate at Perbacco. Our expectations for a fine and fabulous dinner were high. 

And Perbacco delivered the goods with humor, thoroughly professional service, delicious food and wine, and thoughtful little extras. 

We spent 3.5 hours at table. We got an upstairs booth at the glass wall. We enjoyed every minute at Perbacco. 

My best all time SF restaurant experience has been Gary Danko. And Perbacco comes in at a very close second place for a luxury dining experience. 

Fantastic.
author: Tom S.

description: Had the tajarin for lunch, I'm incapacitated with food poisoning now.  It was either the tajarin or gelato...  :( either way, no good.
author: Paul C.

description:
The food was rich and tasty, the menu was interesting.  The service was excellent. The company was great (but not on the menu).

We went for lunch and had:
Starters: SALUMI MISTI & BURRATA CHEESE
Entrees: RABATÒN - HERB AND SPINACH RICOTTA GNOCCHI & LIBERTY FARM DUCK CONSERVA
Side: FINGERLING POTATOES ROASTED WITH ROSEMARY AND GARLIC
Dessert: BONET - WILD HARVESTED CHOCOLATE CUSTARD with 2007 PASSITO DI PANTELLERIA (dessert wine)

The starters were interesting but I wasn't a huge fan of either.  The cheese was better than the Salumi for me, but too rich to eat very much. A small bite goes a long way.  If you're debating between the two, I'd go with the Burrata.

My Gnocchi was excellent, tender, with lots of flavor.  I couldn't finish it but only because I am reserved when it comes to rich foods.  The portion is generous and more than enough to satisfy.  My companion loved the duck.  The potatoes were just ok - nothing too special about fingerling potatoes.  

The highlight of the meal was definitely the dessert, which was paired with an unbelievable dessert wine.  I'd return just for the dessert and the wine.  It was spectacular!

The service is absolutely phenomenal. I didn't see the bill, but I'm pretty sure we racked up quite a tab.  It's a great place for a long afternoon lunch, with the right company.
author: Zoey J.

description:
I came here with another foodie for her birthday and I definitely got a gold star for choosing it. 

Get the salumi misti plate, there are at least 7 different kinds of salumi. When the waiter brings the plate, they will explain to you what each kind is and honestly unless you have that good of a memory, you will forget what you are eating. I like most of them except the ones that were softer in texture...kind of reminded me of raw hamburger meat. But still get the plate. 

For dinner we did the tasting of the 2 different kind of pasta, the Langaroli Al Brasato and then Agnolotti Al Coniglio (rabbit). Both of us liked the Agnolotti  more but both were melt in your mouth goodness. 

Dessert was probably the best and I am NOT a dessert person. I would rather have salty any day but dessert at Perbacco is close to changing my mind. ORDER the ugly cookies. They look really weird but get them. TRUST ME unless you are allergic to hazelnuts or don't like hazelnuts. I am pretty sure I am allergic to ugly things but these cookies are the exception. I am pretty sure I would do some crazy things for the recipe. They were the perfect end to the meal. We also had the almond cake and it is good but the cookies were out of this world.
author: Eve C.

description: Perbacco is pretty YUM! Love having a glass of wine and some lasagna. The ambiance is good, service is good and food is good. Overall, this place is pretty good. haha... I'll be back.
author: Noneya B.

description: Great experience. The dry aged duck and Agnolotti pasta was amazing, however the papardelli was not very good at all. They used to make it with short rib but now, unfortunately, they are making it with lamb. Hopefully, the short rib style comes back soon.  Tiffany provided excellent service as always. Such a good restaurant.
author: Tim L.

description: Please note this review is for the annual Passover dinner only. We were delighted to find out that Perbacco annually hosts a Passover dinner twice during the week long holiday. What a treat! We started out with matzoh and haroset ("paste" comprised of apples and nuts) and it was fab. Next they brought us a large spread of roasted vegetables...asparagus, carrots peppers stuffed with mushrooms, and fried artichokes - delish. After that we got to choose between a mushroom soup and a chicken dumpling soup. We opted for the chicken soup and polished it off in no time. For our entrees we indulged in a lamb stew lamb and chicken in a citrus sauce. They were both good - we didn't have any leftovers. Aside from the kosher for passover food being surprisingly delicious (kosher for passover food is often bland) the service was great and all the staff members were very pleasant. Another plus is that they offer valet parking. We will DEFINITELY return for next year's passover dinner.
author: Kelsey K.

description: This was the BEST Italian food I have ever ever had!!! The service was amazing, and I was luck enough to meet the owner when I was there!!! WOO HOO!! I had the short rib ravioli and the pork shoulder!!! WHOA!!! I wanted more, but I was afraid of looking like a fatty!!! This place is to DIE!!! Please go there!
author: Courtney h.

description:
Came here during the week of Jan 19th.  this old favorite continues to perform very well.  we had pasta and hanger steak and dessert.  left the place smiling as the food was outstanding and service was very attentive.

perbacco:  thank you
author: Bill L.

description:
Holy moly.

(The great irony here is that the pricing is rated $$$, but it was $20 CHEAPER to dine here than a few recent, disappointing meals at other SF establishments.)

"Payday dinner" is my +1's excuse to celebrate the time-honored tradition of being paid for working at a real job.  I've been dying to try Perbacco, so I subtly suggested (subtle as a sledgehammer) that we make a reservation for a weeknight.  

Decor: upscale, warm, and lighting that hides the onset of wrinkles and grey hair, allowing you and your date to fool yourselves (with the aid of a cocktail or two) into believing you're not rapidly marching right out of your late-20's.

Service: friendly, attentive, and helpful (when asked which of 3 dishes he would recommend).

Food:  I had the duck with polenta, green strawberries, ginger jus, and rhubarb agrodolce.  It was presented artfully and tasted like god intended: the fatty duck with crispy skin was balanced by the sweet and tart strawberries and rhubarb.  If the +1 had asked me to marry him that night I would have been insulted that he was competing with the duck.

+1 had the short rib sugo, served over papardelle with grated horseradish.  Also excellent - the very definition of elegant comfort food.  

We shared the veal appetizer, which was thinly sliced and served with an albacore/lemon sauce, capers, and microgreens (I think).  This was, as you might imagine from the rest of the review, also delicious.

Portions were generous--enough so that between the complimentary crostini, crusty bread with butter, the appetizer, and the entree, we had leftovers to take home.  Two tiny dessert bites were served with the check, and off we went into the windy spring night.

But don't YOU go, because then it will be even harder to get a reservation at a reasonable hour.
author: Jennie K.

description:
We choose this for our Holiday meal in the city. Big mistake.

Very limited menu and they have a very snooty approach to basic  requests for information. 
Interesting this shows up as Italian...I have eaten in a lot of high end Italian restaurant in Europe and they are not like  this. 
For an Italian restaurant a few basics were missing from the menu  ..Bruschetta, Carpaccio, Anti Pasta, Chicken ( yes Chicken!) , Pino Grigio,  Tiramisu or Panna Cotta.
Forget Pizza or any classic Italian pasta dish either. When  my wife asked about any  specials or alternatives she was told that Rabbit was as close to chicken  as they had....my daughter was not impressed !
We had the Octopus for starters and it was breaded and soggy. For the main course we went with the Pork chop and Sea bass and a pasta. The Pork chop was edible as was the sea bass ...even if they were salty and slightly cold. The pasta was inedible. 

The wine we got was a Pino Blanc and was somewhat  tasteless. 

They did have expresso and grappa.( which both were the highlights of the meal) .....which apparently they do think belongs in an Italian restaurant,  how old school !
author: Patrick C.

description: Wanted to love this place but really was not that impressed. Our organizer was so excited to have dinner here and she had booked many months in advance since we were a large group.  I understand that some of the menu has to be set in advance when you have a big group but I think something should have stood out but nothing did. Not a fan of breadsticks on the table.  Makes me think of cheap Italian restaurants.  Dinner started with pear salad, followed by braised ribs and dessert.  The food was fine, but just fine, not outstanding or remarkable.  Most disappointing were the desserts. I have read all the mouthwatering reviews of yummy desserts.  Where was the dark chocolate gonet, the torta di carote, the panna cotta.  Not at our table.  Unfortunately we were offered little mini pound cakes that were dry, dull and must have come straight out of the fridge because they were still cold. I know we were a group but really - couldn't there have been some panache with the desserts at least.   The wine and service were good.  Trip to the toilet was complicated - I should have known when the waiter escorted me. Down the escalator, turn left, then right. Two drinks I made it okay - three drinks and it might have been a challenge.
author: Sami M.

description:
Yum yum yum......
This was an impromptu decision to meet up with parental's friend.
So respectable and tasty was essential...
Luckily Perbacco was able to deliver.
We started with the vitello tonnato, a veal dish almost prepared like a beef capriccio but slow cook. 
The thinly slice veal and the arugula with flavor of lemon and caper was a delightful mouthful experience.
We also order the brown butter brussel sprout that was very flavorful but over powering with butter.
My entree was the quail which was another delightful experience.
The red wine butter flavored the mushroom and quail perfectly.

Our waiter also recommended a 2009 Skewis, Ridly Vineyard, Anderson Valley Pinot Noir which complimented our meal very nicely.

Overall a great dinning experience and I will be back.....
author: YC L.

description:
Happy to say this is another place we recently tried for my bf's birthday.  I was researching for a place that celebrates birthdays, where you don't have to break the bank for great food, and we found this place.  Right when we got in, we got seated almost immediately and my bf was greeted with a birthday card.  That was an extra plus!!!  

I definitely did my homework, so the first thing we ordered was the Roasted Fig Salad...OMG, melt in your mouth figs with toasted hazelnuts (one of our favorite kinds of nuts), Scimudin cheese, Juniper Cured Lonza, and Arugula.  Highly suggest this item to order if you are a fig lover.  This item is good enough to share if you want your own entree.  

For our entree, I had the Pappardelle with a slow roasted short rib ragu.  One of the best Pappardelle I've had, melt in your mouth short rib, and cooked to perfection, both the short rib and the pasta cooked aldente.  My bf had the Beef Short Rib Stracotto, also cooked to perfection, melt in your mouth.  Very tasty, whatever sauce they used was just perfect and there were some cooked grapes that gave it an extra "YUMMYNESS" to the dish because of the sweet and savory taste.  

As we ended the meal, I had asked the waiter if I had a choice for our birthday dessert, and he said I can order whatever I wanted and he'll put "happy birthday" on the plate for us.  So when the menu came out, I found out that the gelato comes with two scoops for $7 I think, so I asked if it's ok to get 1 order of gelato but 1 scoop of two different kinds of gelato to taste, and he said it was ok to do that.  I loved that we had that option. We had the Burnt Caramel with sea salt, and also had the Blueberry Swirl Lavendar gelato.  Both were very good, but I think I liked the blueberry one better only because the burnt caramel tasted like something I've had before.  The best part was that I didn't know that they gave a complementary dessert for birthdays, and so they gave us the free dessert of the Ugly Looking Cookies on top of our gelato dessert.  So we got 2 desserts for the price of one, basically.  It was the best, the cookies were the best tasting cookies I've ever had.  It's a must try!

Then at the end we got some bite size desserts, one was a piece of dark chocolate and the other was a cubed hazelnut taffy-like candy.  It tasted like a BIG HULK.  

One of the best restaurants, by far, in SF that does not break the bank.  Everything on the menu was less than $30.  I also read on the menu that there's an option to taste two pastas that is $16 per person.  We really loved the ambiance inside of the restaurant and kind of romantic.  We definitely will come back, they have a sister restaurant called Barbacco two doors away, thats a little more casual that we may try next time too.
author: Amy A.

description:
Where do you go to get pretty good food, not worry about parking on Saturday night in the city, and feel safe dining in the neighborhood? This is definitely a good option. Celebrating a birthday, I thought this would be a nice spot especially since one guest was coming from Chinatown. After dropping everyone in front of the restaurant, I found a space less than one block away as the Financial District becomes a ghost town on weekend evenings. When arriving the table, the hostess gave the birthday person a card congratulating her on behalf of the staff and management of the restaurant (nice touch, appreciated). We then dined on the following: 
Appetizers (all shared) 
1. Fritto Misto (rock shrimp) - Deep fried string beans, olives, onions, tomato, and, of course rock shrimp. My brother likened it to a tempura batter as it was served with a creamy sauce. $11.00 
2. Chef's Salumi plate (small) - A variety of house made sausages, meats, and a small, fruity pate-like spread with small baguette slices. It was a plentiful portion with good variety. $18.00 
3. Risotto of the day (small) - I forget the accompanying meat (pancetta?) and mushrooms. My parents first taste of risotto which they likened to a thick Chinese porridge (jook). Good flavor with added shaved Parmesan for extra richness. $14.00 
4. Pappardelle with short ribs (small) - Wide, lasagna-like egg noodles with a braised short rib meat and a hearty brown sauce. This dish was just okay and didn't wow anyone. $12.00 
Entrees 
1. Grilled Pork Chop - Cooked to a pinkish medium, the 1.5 inch bone-in meat was hearty and flavorful. The accompaniments were only okay; not a knock-your-socks-off version like Spruce. $24.00 
2. Seared John Dory - This flaky white fish was cooked perfectly for my father. It had a crusty top while the meat stayed moist. $26.00 
3. Stuffed Quail - Very interesting presentation and flavors. It comes to the table in a medium sized black cast iron container. After showing the contents, the server then re-plates the contents to a normal ceramic plate. In trying a bite, it was interesting and, though the menu didn't state it as an ingredient, had an anchovy-like after taste. I liked the Swiss chard that came with this. $25.00 
4. New York Steak - My brother ordered it medium rare and he did not complain about it. Silence is golden. $29.00 
Sides 
1. White Corn with Golden Chanterelles - Nice perk of being in the Bay Area is having seasonal vegetables at their sweetest when in season. $7.00 
2. Fingerling Potatoes - Six long wedges of hearty potatoes. Did not try, but my brother's silence says it all. $5.00 
Dessert 
1. Butterscotch Budino - Think of a chocolate mousse-like pudding topped with whipped cream and chocolate shavings. $8.00 
2. Brutti Ma Buoni - This translates to Hazelnut cookies (four) served on a plate with a Chocolate-etched "Happy Birthday". The menu also describes this as "Ugly but Good" which was appropriate. Complimentary 

Overall, this was a nice dining experience which highlights the chef's rustic cooking style. Prior to ordering, the servers also brought some bread sticks with a pesto dipping sauce and later individual rolls. Service was excellent as our water and iced tea were repeatedly refilled. I don't remember how his cooking compared to his Scala's time, but I think this menu is more memorable.
author: Mike C.

description: Try octopus in the appetizer, it's very nice, I have imagined walking into this restaurant, ordering 3 of it, finishing it and walking out.
author: Tian W.

description:
This is one of the places we often go to at work for birthday lunches. It is lively inside and great for fun get togethers. They also have seating upstairs. 

I ordered lamb stew which was creamy and the lamb was oh soooo tender! The softest and most delicious stew I have had. I also recommend the risotto.

Reservations are a good idea but generally you can seated be when you walk in as well.
author: Shell I.

description:
Having dined before at Barbaco, we had some idea of the kind of food we would get, so that prompted us to make this reservation to celebrate a birthday and two anniversaries.  For some reason, we were escorted to the big marble table right by the kitchen - and we could see what was going on there- and though it wasn't quiet, it was certainly a more private space than the tables in the front of the restaurant that were much closer together.

Anyway, we had very attentive service the whole night, in addition to good recommendations for food. We had a good red wine and I had the Fior d'Arancia cocktail which was slightly sweet and perfect for me. We started with a beet salad served at room temp (props for that - beet salad served cold is criminal!) vitello tonnato, a tasty rendition of the classic dish, and a fritto misto with shrimp and other vegetables with a dipping sauce.
Absolutely yummy!  One of us also enjoyed a puree soup of sunchoke that was absolutely sublime, velvety, earthy-tasting and perfectly seasoned.
The entrees were sea bass with gigante beans and pasta pillows with a beef mixture served in a very brothy liquid seasoned with savory - we licked our plates clean.

We were very full by that time, but had two desserts - one a pressed pumpkin spice cake with slices of persimmon and a gelato, and the other one poached plums. Amazingly the plums were sweet and served also with some spiced ice cream. Although the desserts were certainly tasty, we didn't think the combination of ingredients on each plate really had much to do with the other. I forgot to mention that because it was my birthday, they brought a plate of four amazing hazelnut meringue cookies with Happy Birthday written on it in chocolate, omg! Then a little plate of fondant and chocolate pieces arrived which was the end to a great meal. 

Would go back again in a heartbeat!
author: L A.

description: Delicious food! I love wine and they have a very nice selection. I really enjoyed their Chianti. Nice ambience and friendly service.
author: Anna Z.

description:
This was one of the best meals I've had in SF ever.  What a wonderful place!

Firstly the decor is beautiful -- it has a sleek modern look without seeming cheesy or overdone. It's comfortable and elegant and clean.  

Secondly the food was incredible.  I had the rabbit leg with cherries and mashed potatoes which was potentially one of the best dishes I've ever tasted.  Also really enjoyed the salumi misiti which was quite large - I would recommend it for a group of 3-6 people.  The short rib ragu was delicious, as was the truffle polenta  ravioli.  The egg yolk in that dish was incredible. 

I loved Perbacco and can't wait to go back!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Had a company dinner here last night and it was very well done. They seated our party of 11 on the 2nd level in our own little divided alcove - it was nice having a little private space. We had one server named Ben taking care of us for the entire four hour meal, and he was great - attentive, informative, and patient, and he checked on us enough times where we never had to flag him down. 

I feel we tried everything they had on their current menu from appetizers, to pastas, to main courses, to desserts. I am horrible with remembering names of dishes, but I do recall enjoying the veal-stuffed pasta, butternut squash ravioli, beef short ribs, stuffed quail breast, and duck breast the most. The desserts ranged from a yogurt-tasting flan, burnt caramel flavored gelato, to a heartier chocolate mousse, apple cake and bread pudding concoction. Again, apologies for not being detailed in my descriptions -- really, the dishes just kept coming and we kept eating. 

For drinks I tried the Mandorino cocktail, some Sauvignon Blanc, and espresso.

The ambiance of the place is intimate, and I found the noise level to be pretty comfortable. Although there were several groups scattered throughout the restaurant, we could converse without having to raise our voices to be heard. 

Fancy dining, but without the stuck up attitude I feel from more upscale establishments. It's pricey enough for me not to be able to dine here often, but I would definitely go back someday and also recommend to others.
author: Elaine W.

description:
This place does the little things well, which I appreciate. They take care to go above the call of duty with their service (folding napkins when you leave the table, bussers whisking crumbs off the table, a coat check with the hostess). These things help enrich the experience of a higher quality restaurant, and make it more worth your while when going out. The staff is knowledgeable of the menu and wine (something you don't always notice until the waiter has to check with the back twice in a row to verify everything on the menu). They also allowed us to sample each wine before pouring and made the portions generous

The food was definitely a cut above most I have eaten since moving to the city. I went with the qual breast and was rewarded with rich meat and a filling portion. They serve both rolls and long crispy breadsticks ( a unique option) before hand, as well as a pretty darn good Caesar salad. i can also say that the desserts were worth it afterwards (even though I was stuffed beyond tasting properly). Definitely worth the trip for a nice night out
author: Taylor C.

description: Really good. The cabbage agnolotti is divine.
author: C. P.

description:
Came here for lunch for a new hire/transfer lunch and had a really great experience. We had a reservation for a private room upstairs. I must say, the place is pretty nice. When you first walk in, there's a few seats along the bar/counter. Then you hit the stairs, but beyond that there are some tables as well. When you go up, there's a couple more tables and the private dining room that seats 12-15 people comfortably at a long table. You can see the chefs working in the kitchen from the window!

Since this was a company lunch, it was paid for. The prices are on the higher end, but seeing as this is FiDi, it probably isn't an issue for its clientele. Would I pay out of pocket to come here again? Yes! I'm curious about the dessert some Yelpers are raving about.

I got the pan seared hanger steak, which was really delicious! My first though was, that's it? But then when I started eating it, I got pretty full. Great flavor on the steak. The arugula and squash salad had a nice citrus/vinegar dressing, but not overpowering. Great dish!

They were good about refilling our drinks. Our food took a while to get to us, but that's probably because we were a big group and had a lot of orders. They did get everyone's food out within a few minutes of each other though, which is nice so you don't have to sit there and stare at your food waiting for everyone else's to arrive.
author: Katherine S.

description: I took my best friend to Perbacco last night for her birthday. The dining experience started out good, we opened a bottle of wine and had the beef carppacio as a appetizer. It was full of flavor and even came topped with a quail egg. Next we ordered the tagliatelle. It looked like ramen noodles with a pile of meet sauce on top. The sauce and noodles did not go together at all, and i have never seen tagliatelle like this. We decided to try something else and the waiter recommended the truffle risotto so we went for it. The rice was crunchy and the over all dish had no flavor. When I asked for the bill I was shocked that the risotto was 65 dollars! I payed anyway and sat in the restaurant waiting for them to bring out something, anything with a candle to say happy birthday to her, but it never happened. This made me upset because I had let them know it was her birthday when we got there. I wasn't going to say anything but I was unhappy and wanted to let the manager know. When I told him everything he said the food how was sapposed to be this way. He ended up saying he would take the risotto off the bill and the credit would go back on my card but I still have yet to get the refund. I am new to yelp and this horrible experience inspired me to create a account. This place is far from authentic Italian.
author: Ashlynn G.

description:
We liked it, especially the pasta.

It's a busy place, not too quiet, at least downstairs where we were seated.  We had a leisurely meal with a friend, two bottles of wine, and a bunch of shared plates.

The Salumi Misti - a mixed plate of house-cured meats, was good but not quite great.  Nothing in particular stood out, though it did certainly satisfy any salt/fat cravings we might have had.  We also tried the baked octopus ( surprisingly good in texture and flavor ) and the smoked cod and frisee salad ( nice flavors, well-balanced ).

Also tried some pastas: Agnolotti Dal Plin and Tajarin.  The fresh pasta was spot-on in texture, and perfectly paired with the sauces.  Would definitely order more pasta next time.  Brussels Sprouts on the side were perfectly roasted, nice and dark.  Also had a nicely cooked fish entree.

We had the small size of pasta dishes and they were perfectly possible to share between three curious diners.  The menu is interesting enough that we were thinking of ordering more dishes, but the food is filling enough that we ended up not needing to do it.

The wine list is long and confusing - unless you know more about Italian wine than most people will ever learn.  Both the sommelier and our server were helpful in choosing something decent once we indicated some taste preferences and a price range. ( though the sommelier's indication that Italian wines tend not toward the fruity/jammy was perhaps put to the test by our second selection of a Valpolicella Superiore without his assistance.).

Overall, it's very good and sometimes great Italian food, appropriately priced.  It's not the most relaxing and quiet space, but we'd definitely come back again for more pasta.
author: Albert H.

description:
The website defines Perbacco "an Italian word to accentuate positive comments." I am pretty sure they strive to have every guest "perbacco" this place to all they know (and they should). 

This is Italian food at its best. I have been here for lunch and for dinner, and have been extremely impressed both times....although I wish they served the foccacia at dinner. So olive-y and lovely (see what I did there). I've had the beet salad, risotto, and the papadelle. Such layers of flavor on all the dishes!

Service is fantastic. Very attentive, friendly, and knowledgeable. I put my napkin on my seat when I went to the restroom, and when I returned a new one was put at my place setting (!). My water glass was always filled. The waiter also knew the wine list very well.

The prices range from $15-$30 for entrees, but they are so worth it. I could not dine here all the time, but how I wish I could.
author: Kerina J.

description:
We thought  chef was great years ago in Napa but every time we dine at Per Bacco we are just in love with every aspect and leave so amazed. I am gluten intolerant and our server, Claire, was so knowledgeable about the menu and my "special needs."  
We recommend Per Bacco every chance we get. 
Thanks to an incredible person, Stafan, and to an amazing staff and beautiful restaurant.
author: Laura M.

description: Oh my goodness! AMAZING doesn't even begin to describe this place. Food was unbelievable! I  completely cleaned my plate! Staff recommended a fabulous wine to compliment our meals and it was perfect. Will definitely recommend to everyone I know.
author: Tanisha W.

description: This upscale Northern Italian joint shows off the rich, hearty foods of Piedmont, and for a reasonable sum. Located in the Financial District, Perbacco gets a lot of business-dinner folks, but it'd be just as good for sharing comfort food with someone you love. The best part of our meal was the vitello tonnato, the best version of this dish I've had, with the rich yet bracing tuna sauce perfectly married to the succulent and rare slices of veal. The pastas are homemade and awesome. Two starters, two pastas and two glasses of wine came to just under $100.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
I had been to Perbacco a couple times over the last two months and I totally forgot to write a review - wow, I must've been really out of it because that never happens!  

Most memorable from my meals here were the:

*SALUMI MISTI - A SELECTION OF HOUSE CURED SALUMI INSPIRED BY TRADITIONAL PIEMONTESE RECIPES:
SALSICCIA DI BRA / TESTA IN CASSETTA DI GAVI / SALAME AL NEBBIOLO / SALAM 'DLA DUJA / PANCETTA STESA
LARDO DI CAVOUR / SALAME COTTO D'ASTI / SALAME TORTONESI / SALAME CUNEESE / LARDO REALE (wow, what a great selection of meats, I tried everything and loved the classic salumis, but it gave me a real appeciation for all the other types, especially the good and fatty ones!  Both times I came here, we ordered the smaller platter which is perfect for 2-4 people)
* Pastas (to be honest, I can't remember what they were, I think one was a tagliatelle, yum, Perbacco knows their pastas, we ordered 2 pasta dishes to share for a party of 4 before our entrees)
* If there are scallops on the menu, you MUST get these - this was a big hit both times I visited Perbacco
* And the sides are lovely - I had the baby carrots and the brussel sprouts - totally great combo with the pastas and scallops
* Their mixed drinks are classy without being too sweet or syrupy

I came here with a friend once and for a work dinner another time, and both times we had lovely service that was nicely attentive and patient.  A very nice dining experience.
author: Maile N.

description: The service was terrible, but the food and wine more than made up for it. If you like the food at Mailino at the Gramercy Park Hotel in NY, you'll like the food here, too. It's more refined, though--not as rustic.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Too bad...as I have been a frequent here and only realized today that I have not previously written them any reviews.  And today was my one bad visit - read on...

I had some excellent prior visits.  The Parpadelle here really is fantastic.  Definitely the best plate in San Francisco.  It is perfectly al dente and worthy of the Michilin star as a dish.  The meat and wine went perfectly with the pasta, and the meat pulled apart perfectly like a good braised dish should.  The parsley was just enough to bind the flavors together.

Upon my most recent visit, however, I am absolutely aghast to say that at a restaurant of this calibur, I found a piece of old risotto stuck between the teeth of my fork.  They did not make much of an effort to apologize either, as if things should just carry on.  

Too bad.  I have been a long time frequent here, bringing my clients here.  Now I am going elsewhere.
author: Mark M.

description: I guess my expectations were just too high. It was my girlfriend's birthday and she is vegetarian so I was looking for a nice place to take her for the occasion. First, parking was easy with valet and it's just $10. We were seated in what had to have been one of the worst tables in the house. I had a view of the staircase/coat rack and my girlfriend had a view of a huge pillar. It just felt claustrophobic. The waiter let us know that everything was "slow cooked" and I guess that meant just plain slow because the food took a while to arrive. Much longer than our neighbors I noticed. I was starving after bread and 2 appetizers and could hardly wait for the food to arrive. Finally it comes and it was just a few bites. I had the duck breast, which was tasty but tiny. Dessert menu was large and they had multiple dessert wines. I wish the vegetarian options were as plentiful. Overall this place is OK
author: Sold B.

description:
Definitely one of the best Italian meals I've ever had. Started off with the veal tartare, which wasn't the best veal tartare I've ever had, but was still good.  Then we tried the 3 pasta sampler, with the rabaton (spinach gnocchi), garganelli neri (octopus ink), and angnoli di coniglio (rabbit). All 3 were very different, but delicious. The gnocchi had much subtler flavors than the other two, which were very rich. My favorite was the octopus - loved the flavor and the different textures in the dish. The boyfriend's favorite was the rabbit.

I had the cunij for an entree (although I could only manage a few bites by this point!) - wish I had room to eat more because it was delicious!  The boyfriend had another full pasta for his main (the pappardelle), which was good, but I didn't feel like it was as good as any of the three we had sampled earlier.

Dessert was the gianduja... glad the waiter talked us in to trying dessert even though we were stuffed! Creamy and crunch and delicious!

Service was a little hit and miss - a busy saturday night, but it was a delicious meal and good company, so they still get 5 stars!
author: Krista S.

description:
We celebrated my birthday at Perbacco's--had been here once before. It was terrific--great wine list (although pricey), interesting menu, great service. We were given a good corner table in a quiet section of the restaurant. Our server was attentive without being obstrusive. 

Very enjoyable.  We will be back.
author: Ellen M.

description:
Summary:  Good service, small portions, boring menu, poor value.

Ordered the salami antipasto plate to start - it was okay but nothing special. I find better salami at trader joes.  Then for my $27 entree I got 3 small scallops garnished with some spinach.  The dessert was supposed to be a tart but I ended up with a scoop of sorbet topped with shredded wheat.  I kid you not.  The portions are tiny and the menu did not have much of interest which is pretty sad for an Italian joint.  No veal, no basic pastas, and featured 2 of my least favorites vegetables: cauliflower and brussel sprouts.  Overall deserves 1* for value, but I've added an extra star because the service was outstanding.  If you must eat here I'd recommend ordering a bunch of appetizers which looked far better than the entree menu.
author: Boris G.

description: I had the butternut squash ravioli and the flavors were amazing! It's a nice place to have a slightly fancy dinner. The waiter also gave great wine pairing recommendations! The prices (around $20 for a pasta dish) were also not too bad.
author: Jessica M.

description: Good food, fabulous desserts, bad bad service. Where do I start? I went to this restaurant twice. The first time, despite the fact that we had a reservation, they made us wait for 10 minutes in their awkward entrance before giving us the table. Second time, same thing, again, despite the reservation. I did not feel welcomed. It was 5:30 pm on a Friday night, and the restaurant was still pretty empty. Before we sat down, I asked if we could get the corner table next to where the host intended to sit us. She refused, saying that someone had requested it. Later on, I asked our table neighbors if they had indeed asked for this specific table, and the lady told me: "No, I made the reservation on OpenTable, it's our first time here." It made me wonder why the host refused to accommodate a pretty simple ask. Were we underdressed? Too gay for her taste? We'll never know, but one thing is for sure: I am not coming back. When paying a $100 for dinner, I expect better service than this. If you HAVE to go there, try the panna cotta.
author: Cecile P.

description: Consistently one of the best restaurants in the city and a solid choice when hosting guests from out of town.  Have yet to be disappointed with a starter or main.
author: Allan H.

description:
Nice restaurant, good service and the food here is quite good as well.  Overall I'd give this restaurant 3.5 stars.

We ordered the burrata cheese and crudo as the appetizers.  For the main entree I ordered the duck breast and sampled some of the beef short rib stracotto and white sea bass.  In my opinion the sea bass was probably the best of the three.

For dessert we collectively shared the sweet corn panacotta and the assortment of cheeses.  The corn flavor of the panacotta was pretty overpowering and the dish lacked the kind of sweetness you'd normally look for in a dessert.  The assortment of cheeses on the other hand were quite good.
author: Erich D.

description: Great food....service...but like sister restaurant Barbacco better...more casual and more my pace :)
author: Eileen S.

description:
Perbacco is fantastic. I loved everything about this place. The vibe, the service and mainly the food. A friend who is a regular was able to get us a table at short notice which was nice. 

We were a big party and tried a lot of dishes and they were all divine. The beef short rib stood out for me since it was so tender and flavorful.
I am not much of a seafood but my friends were raving about the selection of some pretty rare fish as well. Feels good to hand out a 5 star review after a while!
author: Sunil R.

description: Upscale Italian food with not so common dishes.  I would have given it 4 stars but for the second time (and I paid this time) I had dinner there, just two people: $205.  Appetizers, dinner, 4 wine glasses, shared dessert. A bit steep and while I don't expect huge portions, they can be rather tiny. I recall eating there may years ago for a bachelor's party dinner; we all split the cost evenly and it still seemed high. Again, the food is different than you will find on North Beach, which should be avoided, but similar dining can be had in the $120-$130 range at many other locations. Still, the food is good
author: A. C.

description:
The challenge was three nights and two full days in San Francisco, and attempting to find some new dining experiences mingled with old favorites. 

 We found recommendations for Perbacco on the SF Chowhound board and knew we had to have dinner here, as the pasta selections were especially noteworthy on the menu when reviewing.   He began salad prepared with marinated root vegetables, beautiful golden beets and a tasty vinaigrette.  I opted to skip the traditional appetizer menu and start with the small portion of the handcut tagliatelle with five hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.   The pasta was delicate and the the pork was amazingly rich and lovely.  If I close my eyes I can still taste it.  

For our mains, I opted from the risotto with black chanterelles, smoked pancetta, swiss chard and parmigiano reggiano, was fabulously rich and the pancetta was perfect.  He opted for the pappardelle with short rib ragu and roasted cipollines.  The short rib was braised perfectly and all of the house made pastas were melt-in-your-mouth good.  I almost didn't want to share, but what can you do? 

Everything here was amazing, honestly.  We enjoyed the fact that we could order a wine by the half liter (rather than a bottle between the two of us, sometimes) and our server made a well matched pairing to both of our dishes.   

Another SF restaurant that makes me want to move to the city in a heartbeat.
author: Suzanne J.

description:
i'm a fan of this place.
went here with my co workers to celebrate something.  It's a couple blocks from where I work so we didn't have to worry about parking.

The service was great and the ambiance was pretty good.
I loved their Frito Misto and their Black Sea Bass. dishes.
They have very wide variety of wine and our server definitely helped us in choosing the perfect white wine for everyone.

I had a great dining experience in this place.  It's a bit pricey for  regular visits but it's definitely worth it.
author: Learnee L.

description: Great Italian food, had a great time with a group of friends. All pasta dishes were awesome! Now gotta try Barbacco!
author: Alexander K.

description:
Food: They seem to have a thing for watermelons - which appear in a number of their salads.  We had the watermelon and bluefin tuna salad, which was unusual, but surprisingly good.  

Service: In our OpenTable reservation we had put in a special request for a quiet table, as we had a romantic occasion to celebrate.  They certainly didn't disappoint!  Without any fuss they seated us at a cozy, semi-private table in the corner - perfectly done.

Extras: On their website they tell you that "Perbacco" is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.  Our experience there inspires nothing but!
author: Kristen S.

description:
We had a large group and went for a sorta business-y lunch. If all business lunches turned out as good as this one, I'd do that shit all of the time. Unfortunately my business lunches are usually me in front of a laptop sucking down from flaming lava-hot ramen. Not even the good kind, but the kind you buy at the grocery for 20 cents a package.

We were seated in the table that is sort of in the kitchen area, which was very cool. I enjoyed a nice glass of wine and our server was very knowledgeable about the wine selection, which was handy. I'm no wine snob, I choose wine by the picture on the bottle, so it is exciting when I say "I'd like a wine like such-and-such" and they come back with exactly that and can tell you the particular region and climate pattern that the grapes were grown in.

We had the salumi small plate and another one with cheese and balsamic tomatoes - the cheese I don't remember the name, but it was like a house-made creamier version of mozzarella. Very tasty. The salumi plate actually got my friend to start eating cured meats, I think. She wasn't a fan until she tried the ones at the restaurant. 

And I didn't eat anyone else's food, but the pasta with the braised rabbit and chanterelles gets an A+. I always like to go for things I'd never make at home. My only wish would have been for more mushrooms. I can never have enough. The rabbit was fantastic and tender and not the least bit gamey.

We split a few desserts as well, the ugly cookies (which were actually MUCH better two days later), the chocolate/hazelnut gelato/cake item (which was rich but quite good), and they also brought out (gratis!) a meringue filled with lemon marscapone and plum sorbetto (?). 

Everything was quite good. Very business lunch clientele. I felt that many important things were being discussed at other people tables. The future of the business world was being created over filled pastas and gnocchi. I also felt that I should have been wearing a suit or something.
author: Kate C.

description:
We showed up here late on a weeknight after a work-related happy hour. The maitre'd was really friendly and nice and accommodated the group for dinner.

It's a nice space, very downtown corporate dining. Don't see this a lot in SF. Totally reminded me of NYC restaurants on the East side. 

Food was good, service was good. We didn't order much in appetizers but did get a nice bottle of wine that went down JUST fine :)
author: Dalia M.

description:
My partner and I were here at 9:30 PM on Saturday, 12/3.  The service was warmly efficient, but not intrusive. We shared the Fritto Misto of Rock Shrimp, which was out of this world!  The shrimp were sweet and succulent, and covered in the most delicious, yet delicate, batter.  Also on the plate: baby green beans, olives, pearl onions - all coated in that great batter, gently fried, and served with a tangy lemon aoili.  We loved this starter.  

I had the JLC, made with Jameson, ginger liqueur, lemon juice and ginger beer.  It was tasty and packed a subtle punch. For dinner, my honey had the Raviora - butternut squash ravioli with pomegranate arils and sage butter, topped with grated Reggiano.  It was the perfect mix of sweet and savory.  We both adored this dish.  I had the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu, Cipollines and Grated Horseradish.  The rib meat was fork-tender with just the right amount of grated horseradish to increase the flavor even further.  The dessert menu looked wonderful, but we were full.  As we left the restaurant, four or five staff members wished us a good evening.  We were very impressed with the warmth of the wait- and bus-staff.  We will certainly be back - and soon!
author: Susan S.

description:
This place was just OK. Nothing special. I didn't leave thinking much except for the fact that the place made my clothes smell like a kitchen. It was pretty awful how stinky we got after eating there.  The food kust wasn't outstanding. Definitely a FiDi, suit crowd.

The service was OK. The waitress didn't communicate much with us. We had to ask her to explain what the menu offered... She really didn't care that we had never been there. Just wanted to take our order and go. Not once did she offer any of her knowledge or expertise until we had to flag her down and ask her. Surprised at the low service.

Not worth it - you can get better at other FiDi joints.
author: Zarpana K.

description:
Fantastic experience - thank you Perbacco!  The food was great and the service impeccable!  My partner and I dined at Perbacco on New Year's for our anniversary.  We had 8:15pm reservations and were promptly seated in a corner booth on the first level.  Since it was NYE, the restaurant full, and many of the tables arranged in close proximity to one another, we were prepared to sit closely amongst others.  To our pleasant surprise the corner booth had access to the festive atmosphere, but at the same time added privacy and extra wiggle room.

Service: Top Notch - Five Stars!  We were nearly completely sold from the beginning when our server handed us a 'Happy Anniversary' card on behalf of Perbacco.  Throughout the night, our server also paid extra attention to ensure we enjoyed ourselves - the ideal amount of attention and privacy.  From the server to the hostess, each employee we encountered congratulated our celebratory event, which we didn't really expect, and therefore could not help but be thankful and impressed.  At the end of the evening the restaurant also provided complimentary cookies & chocolates with 'Happy Anniversary' etched in chocolate.

Food/Drink:  Delicious!  We started with two Negronis on the rocks - they were superb.  For appetizers we split a Beet Salad and the Fritto Misto.  Also, as it was NYE, Perbacco served complimentary seasoned lentils.  All were great.  My favorite was the Beet Salad - the red and yellow beets were fresh, slightly sweet, and cooked perfectly with just the right amount of Castelmagno cheese, microgreens, and chestnut crumble accompaniments.  The Fritto Misto, nicely paired with their lemon aioli, was satisfying & filling - great starter for big eaters.  For my entrée, I ordered the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu and my partner had the Garganelli with Duck Ragu.  We were pretty full after the appetizers, but still managed to finish both pastas (small size).  Each pasta dish was cooked a nice al dente and the ragus both wonderfully, rustically flavorful.  The horseradish in my Short Rib Ragu cut the richness of the ragu well with its pungency and zest.  

Overall:  A great special occasion restaurant - we would not hesitate to return!  The service was outstanding and really made the whole night exceptionally special.  The bar area also seemed like a nice spot to grab a drink or a spontaneous bite.
author: Catherine C.

description: Came here while on our honeymoon. Ambiance and service were spectacular they even gave us a free dessert when we mentioned we were celebrating our honeymoon which was a really nice touch. We have some great food in Miami and this place was excellent but the pasta was a bit under seasoned. The caramel gelato with sea salt was a stand out.
author: Emily D.

description:
PAPPARDELLE - WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / ROASTED CIPOLLINE / HORSERADISH 17

This pasta is my favorite of the pasta choices.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Went for a lunch mid week with hubby and a friend. The place was packed, glad we had reservations. They both had speciality cocktails that were delicious and I had a glass of Italian white wine which was very good.  Off to a good start. We ordered the Cauliflower/Radicchio Salad (amazing!), the Beet Salad (good) and the Roasted Brussels Sprouts with Brown Butter and Parm (excellent).

Main course: sole with fennel and citrus salad with blood orange sauce was wonderful. My hubby had the veal and pork meatballs and loved them and our friend had the pasta with beef short rib ragu with horseradish, which she liked but would not order again.  Said there was not enough flavor  in the dish. Too full for desserts. 
The service was excellent, the ambience okay and the food superb. Very expensive lunch, but worth it for a special outing. Would definitely go back.
author: Lori L.

description: I had a good experience here with my coworkers.  The place was packed at lunch.  The breadstick and sauce were good and the fisherman's stew was delicious.  Others ordered pasta and they also enjoyed their dishes.  The only negative part to today's meal was that they were rushing to clear off our plates without asking if we were done!
author: S L.

description:
Sure, it's rated highly. Sure, lots of people think they enjoy it. But honestly, I've never had such a rampant disregard for my tastebuds at these prices in my entire life. The first time I went, I ordered a $90 dinner just for myself, because I wanted to try the best that Perbacco--ranked third in the city by some--had to offer. Octopus and beef tongue salad, white truffle and oxtail risotto (off their seasonal white truffle menu), and tahitian sea salt caramel ice cream rounded up my order. I have but one word to say: SALT. It wasn't just that there was too much of it, to the point that I was actually gagging in the restroom before my end-meal cup of coffee, but the food itself was so tasteless that even if the only flavor available to the palate was not salt, one would have been disappointed. It was clear that the restaurant had confused subtlety with blandness.

I spoke to the owner when I was at barbacco (which oddly has far superior food--and the same chef), and he offered me a second chance, on the house, to enjoy the food. I took him up on it a couple months later. This time, I ordered a gamut of delicacies and staples, from rabbit to a simple salad. I once again have a single word: SALT. The guy next to me at the restaurant returned his spaghetti and meatballs (as well as every other dish but the wine), and when we spoke I discovered that he had traveled for the last 40 years while with the Navy, tasting and loving cuisine from across the globe. When he left, the bartender shook her head sadly at me and said "some people just don't have a refined enough palate to recognize delicious food, you know?" Oh contraire.

My mother is a caterer and I absolutely adore salt for its restorative properties to most every meal. In this case, not only was it overused to an extreme degree, but it wouldn't have helped even if it had been sprinkled with the restraint of a starving farming family saving its salt reserves to give in blocks to its two tiring horses. In other words, the chef couldn't mask the tastelessness of the food with his liberal salting, no matter how hard he tried.
author: Joshua R.

description: Lovely. I'm not much of a "foodie" and this restaurant has much "foodier" items than traditional Italian dishes like meatballs, whitefish or chicken paillard. I had the roast duck and it was delicious! Everyone in my party gave Perbacco five stars.
author: J L.

description: Fantastic experience! Called a few days before for a reservation to celebrate boyfriend's birthday. The hostess sat us at the perfect table in the corner with an enveloped card wishing a happy birthday! Then for desert they brought out a plate with "happy birthday" written out and two cookies and the best salted caramel gelato ever! The food was brilliant (Quail stuffed with mortadella, very interesting but very good; brussel sprouts, super good, salami plate), brought a bottle of wine for $25 corkage fee, and the service was on point! You could see the manager moving throughout the restaurant all night making sure everything was perfect.
author: Sydney G.

description:
As many other reviews indicate, the service really is outstanding.  The waitstaff and their assistants (probably called a busser but he does so much, he deserves a more meaningful title) were attentive, polite, and knowledgeable.

We arrived early and were looking forward to a drink at the bar but were shuffled off to our table immediately.  Not a big deal, but I hate always feeling rushed at a restaurant.  We had a reservation for 6:45, that's when we'd like to sit please.

The food was extremely delicious and beautifully presented.  The Salumi Misti is incredible and larger portion than we expected (and we got the smaller one).  We also had the octopus, which was tough & disappointing, and the veal tartare which was also a very generous portion.

I had the Pappardelle for my main and the pasta was fantastic.  However with such rich starters, I could barely put a dent in it.  The sauce is rich and flavorful with the tender meat from the short ribs in a ragu.

My dining companions had the Beef Short Rib Stracotto (beautiful meat just falling apart on the plate!) and Garganelli (ok- nothing amazing).

The biggest disappointment came at the end when we walked out the door without out leftovers.  Oops!  Went back immediately and they handed us a bag that was supposed to have our leftovers in it, but they did not save my Pappardelle!  I was so heartbroken and pissed!  That was a lot of (pricey) food left over and for them to throw it away, I was not impressed.  I was really looking forward to having that for lunch today.....hence the 4 stars
author: Lindsey S.

description: The lemon drops are to die for. Wine selection is very good. Apetizers are really good here. I had the Endive salad and Duck Breast and they were both delicious. Osso Buco wasn't that good. The noise level is very high so having a conversation is difficult. this is a high energy restaurant so plan accordingly :)
author: Mahasti T.

description:
What can I say about Perbacco except that it's AWESOME!  I usually don't prefer Italian food, but Perbacco changed my mind.  

Starters: 
- Salumi:this was pretty good.  There was a variety of meat to try.  I'd recommend this to share.

Entree:
- Risotto: one of the BEST mushroom risotto I've ever had.  I am still thinking about it.  Maybe I'll drop by and get it to go as a lunch entree right now!
- Rabbit Agnolotti: this dish was superb!  We had Spago's famous agnolotti, and it doesn't even compare to Perbacco!  

Main entree:
- Short rib: unless you're a huge short rib fan, I'd pass on this.  I've had better elsewhre.  By no means is this bad, it was just not as good as other places
- Quail: on the salty side, but very tasty.  It didn't look like quail, neither tasted like it.  But it was yummy.

Dessert:
- buttercake: DELICIOUS!  

I can't wait for lunch.  Here's to hoping I can get risotto to-go.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: I ate here a while ago, and it was just amazing food. I was very happy with everything. My girlfriend and I enjoyed everything.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Not a good experience. Came here for a weekday lunch with a friend that I had not seen in years. 

Wine and food is extremely overpriced for this type of restaurant. Everyone around us speaking louder and louder as our lunch progressed while more diners kept pilling in.

We ordered drinks while we talked about our past good times but the server seemed to pressure us in to at least ordering appetizers, which we did. We both had the beet salad but heavens, when it was presented it was like 2 tiny beets on a plate with a little lettuce. Altough somewhat on the tastey side, the price was absurd for the price and the minuscule amount of food.

Meanwhile, server is again hovering over us to this time choose and entree. We felt most uncomfortable as we realized they wanted us to eat up and get out so our table could be turned for another sitting.

 For the main course I ordered the petrale sole and my friend chose the meat balls on suggestion from the server. My sole was dry however the mushroom base it sat on was delicious. My friend said her meatballs were heavily over spiced and she offered me a bite and I had to agree.

Dont even remember what we had for dessert as by that time we just wanted to leave.

I do not recommend this restaurant due to high prices, food quality and quantity, a 'hurry up and and eat' attitude and unbearable NOISE. I gave two stars but deserves 1.5.

Very very disappointing and a waste of our time and money.
author: Bobby J.

description:
good but could have been better.It was a busy Friday night and the place is a bit on the loud side,hard to hold a conversation.Our waitress wasn't terrible although she basically phoned it in,not much passion evident.Worst of all she disappeared for 20 minutes after the entrees were dropped and we had to flag down other staff to get help.
Im in food service and she really should have been better considering this is "fine" dining.Food was good especially the roast octopus app but the Potato Gnocci w/Chanterelles was completely flavorless like the chef used no salt or seasonings.When I told her this she basically shruuged and said OK....a good restaurant that could have been memorable.
author: james m.

description:
I went here for dinner on a Thursday night with a friend of mine. Service was excellent -- we were seated right away and the waitstaff was very attentive. Our water glasses were always full. One thing I did notice about what I ordered is that it all seemed so salty. I know, that probably sounds very unusual. 

I started out with the endive and arugula salad, then split an order of gnocchi with asparagus. For my entree, which was less salty than my salad and pasta, I had a crusted halibut served with mushrooms which was really quite good. Their wine list isn't huge but the wine they do have is very well chosen. 

We both splurged on dessert and got gelato. I had the sea salt caramel (which interestingly enough was less salty than my salad and appetizer). It was a great way to end the meal. 

Overall, a very good meal, although I will probably remember it as the restaurant with the overly salted dishes. However, I would definitely go again for the service and ambiance.
author: Lori M.

description:
First of all, mmmMMmmmMMMMMMMM.  

Went to a private event on Tuesday.  Appies included tiny glass plates of shrimp, crab cakes, or risotto balls.  MmmmmMM.

Starters - salad.   Well, to be honest, it was just a salad. 
Entree - scallops.  Uh, YUM!!  
Dessert - chocolate molten cake with some marshmallowy side thing, aka a little piece of heaven on a plate.

Also, with a private event, they seriously provide never ending bottle service.  Every time my glass was half full, it would get refilled again with red wine.  LOVE.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Surprised my husband here for his birthday dinner and everything was perfect! 

No crazy birthday sombreros for this classy place. When we arrived, they had a handwritten birthday card waiting for him and everyone from the hostess to our server remembered to wish him a happy birthday. I think he liked the celebrity treatment. Even though the dining room was full, our server was extremely attentive (but not intrusive) and sent him home with birthday cookies. Nice touch!

Dinner was excellent. We shared the radicchio & pear salad with hazelnuts to start; I liked the mixture of bitter and sweet. Hubby had the pappardelle with short rib ragu. The meat was tender and delicious and the noodles were yum. I had the dungeness crab and herb gnocchi and it was sooooo good. We were checking out the desserts, but had tickets for a comedy show over at Punchline, so definitely next time. Perfect location and ambiance for a special weeknight date.
author: Emily S.

description:
I am consistently happy with my dining experience at Perbacco!!! I have been coming to this wonderful Italian restaurant for over two years and I have been wowed by the beautiful consistency of the food, wine, service and ambiance.  

There are other Italian restaurants in the city that I enjoy going to, depending on my mood and the occasion.   However, hands down, Perbacco never disappoints.  Another plus; their menu has a number of vegetarian options which a really appreciate!  

I will always be a loyal patron to this lovely Italian restaurant!
author: Mariza S.

description:
Service was awesome and the wine program was solid.  Food was ok.  Not bad, but not great.  Perhaps I ordered the wrong item--tuna for appetizer and tagliatelle for entree.  To me, it frankly didn't live up to the hype.  It wasn't good enough to bring me back.

Went on a weekday with a party of 4.  The restaurant is quite large and can be loud.  Crowd seemed to be mostly business.
author: Marissa F.

description: Ate dinner here, they make homemade Grissini which are very good. Also had the Potato Gnochhi with Duck Ragu, Gnocchi were good, everything else in the dish was just OK. Had the Papardelle with Quail Ragu, noodles were great homemade noodles, the rest of the dish was pretty good.
author: Marty M.

description:
Mediocre food.  Excellent Waiters.  Went with a group of 6 and we sat upstairs.  If you want great Italian food, don't go here.  This place is for tourists who don't live in SF and know where to go for great food.  (That's how I got dragged into going here.)  Most of us ordered a pasta, and they were quite simple and bland.  The portion was so teeny we kept having to eat bread and the bread sticks.  I had the Langaroli (supposed to come with short ribs) but instead they sprinkled ground pork into the pasta.  It's supposed to come with Porcini mushroom and they were no where in sight.  My friend ordered the duck breast dish and it was ok, but there were no sides...and again, a small plate.

We also ordered a chocolate dessert which was nothing special.  For the amount of money they charge, make the food taste better!!!  Definitely not going back, although there is a seafood restaurant next door that looks tempting.  I might try that next though and just skip this place entirely.  I don't understand all these 4-5 stars this place is getting here on Yelp.
author: Kay T.

description:
I've been to Perbacco a few times now and honestly thought I had already written a review but now it's time to.  I've been both during lunch and dinner and both have been very good meals and my dinner this past week was no different.  

The place is always packed and Tuesday night was no different with the bar being especially crowded.  We shared a few appetizers including the salumi misti which is one of my favorites, rock shrimp and potato gnocchi.  For the main meal I had the grilled hangar steak which was a little tough to cut but otherwise tasty.  Our waiter had a nice recommendation on wine as well which we all enjoyed.

Perbacco is a good place for a client lunch or dinner but just make sure to make reservations ahead of time as it can be difficult to get in to.
author: Blake B.

description:
Had dinner here last week and from start to finish it was one of the better meals I've had in a long time.  The sommelier was so nice and helped us pick a wonderful bottle of champagne and a really great bottle of wine.  He listened to what we wanted and suggested affordable bottles (he didn't automatically go for the most expensive bottles on the list) that both ended up being really good.

Our server was also great - he knew the menu well and answered all our questions like a pro.  He also struck that perfect balance of anticipating our needs and handling them before we had to ask, but not being at all intrusive.  I was really impressed with the service.  

For food, we had the Pesce Crudo (big eye tuna) which was pretty good, although I enjoyed my husband's Piastra Roasted Octopus even more (tender and flavorful).  We also had the Tajarin and Papardelle pastas, which were both good -- I particularly liked the papardelle - really rich, delicious and meaty!  For my entree I had the seared scallops - they were awesome!  I'm kind of particular about the texture of scallops and I like it when they are firm, but tender, and these scallops were cooked perfectly - the tiniest bit of crunch on the outside and nice and tender on the inside.  They also came in this garlicy sauce that was delicious!  My husband had the beef short rib -- he said it was good, but not the best he's ever had.  

For dessert we had the "ugly, but good" cookies and the caramel/sea salt gelato.  The cookies are really light and airy with hazelnuts in the middle and the gelato had a creamy, delicious caramel flavor with bits of sea salt in it - I thought both were outstanding.
