We were completely stuffed leaving Perbacco, but it was an all-around great dining experience - really delicious food, great wine and top notch service - can't ask for more than that!
author: Erin L.

description:
Romantic dinner at Perbacco, yes, please! 

We arrived for our reservation a couple of minutes late so we needed to wait about five for our table.  The table was tucked in a quiet corner so we could sit caddy-corner instead of across from each other, another plus.  

Being foodies we tend to order two dishes for every course of the meal and share them.  Perfect way to taste a vast amount of menu.  

We started with the roasted baby beets & strawberry arugula salad.  The beets were roasted to bring out each type of beets delicate flavor.  The arugula salad was tangy yet sweet at the same time.  A plate of trotter cakes were sent out as well.  Trotter is exactly what you are thinking, piggy feet.  The meat was shredded and fried inside a pressed cake, surprisingly tender and sweet.

The next course was pasta.  We shared the tasting for two.  Our two were potato gnocchi with duck ragu and ligurian pasta with pesto sauce.  The gnocchi were light and airy.  They were tasty little pillows drenched in a rich duck ragu.  The ligurain pasta was a nice contrast with the bright pesto sauce.

The main courses were sea bass and duck with stone fruit.  The sea bass's skin was crispy and the flesh just flaked apart.  The duck tasted great but was a little hard to break down to eat.  

The last course was the best, thanks to pastry chef Suzanne LaFleur.  We had the honey panna cotta, with fennel pollen and honeycomb.  The panna cotta had a luscious texture that made it move like it had a mind of its own.  The flavor was clearly honey without being over powering.  The honey comb which accompanied the panna cotta was crispy and a wonderful compliment of textures.  

We also had the gianduja, which is a dark chocolate and hazelnut prailine bar, which is served with a caramelized cocoa nib gelato.  Where the panna cotta was delicate, this was the opposite rich and imposing.  The flavors of hazelnut and chocolate were meant to be together.  Pastry Chef LaFleur marries them in a way that punches you in the face with flavor.  Each bite is better than the last.

Overall an amazing meal, but the last course was the best.
author: Megan P.

description:
Caveat: I attended a graduation dinner here where the menu was Prix Fixe

The starters were great.  A nice salumi spread and cheeses was very good - a nice selection of mortadella, prosciutto, and lardo. 

The first course: burrata cheese, spring peas and artichoke salad. (3 stars- refreshing)
The second course: beef short ribs - braised in red wine and horseradish potato puree. (4 stars - very savory)
The third course: warm gianduja cake toasted meringue (3 stars - good but not great)

Overall not a bad experience but I'm sure it could get better. And probably is with their extensive menu. We'll try it again some other time. 

Since it was private party we had ample staff, an open bar and attentive service so very hard to judge what the normal overall service would be like....especially after the open bar...those steps were brutal by the end of the night.
author: Master B.

description:
I was expecting better...

The breadsticks were great, as was the bread. But the salumi plate, while generous in its portions (the smaller portion was big enough to serve 4) was not as tasty, savory, or delicate as Bar Bambino's.  I had the beef rib papparadelle, but the meat was a tad stringy.  But the restaurant had excellent service and ended our meal with bits of chocolate and nougat.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
I was looking forward to a very nice working lunch with a co-worker and Perbacco was so pleasant.  We had reservations for 1230pm and were seated immediately.  I heard that Perbacco made their cured meats well, so of course I was eyeing their salumi misti platter.  They make their salumi in-house: seasoned, cured, rested, grounded, and then magic!  Actually, I find that I'm not soo crazy about cured meat, but it was still great to experience the pork backfat and parts mixture.  :)  

The waiter was absolutely patient with us as we took our time ordering and still chatted away about work.  We even brought our pens and notebooks out to write notes about our upcoming meetings.  They didn't rush us and returned twice to ask us if we would like to order our entrees next.

The Pappardelle was so delicious!  Wide ribbon noodles with short rib ragu!  This dish inspired me to look for a good pappardelle and slow-roast pork recipe.  I will report out on the results soon.  On the otherhand, my friend's sole was a little dry.  

This is a place to impress as the FiDi lunch crowd appeared in suits and ties.  I would love to return and also try the burnt caramel gelato dessert that others have been yelping about with a glass of wine.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
3 words: Mmmm.... Meat platter. Perbacco has all the makings of a good restaurant. We arrived early and posted up at the bar for drinks. The bar area also has a few booths, perfect for eating at the bar. A good little selection of cocktails, I also love seeing whiskey and ginger beer together in a drink. I had a drink with a mixture of gin, champagne and elderflower, very yummy!

We were seated in the upstairs portion, which was like a loft-style area. Cute table, but apparently near an exit and it was pretty chilly up there.  Now to the wine list, a bit disappointing with a limited number of reasonably priced wines. We ended up 2 carafes of wine, which were still about $35 each. But that was all forgotten when the salumi platter came out! There was oodles of house-made meats and awesomeness. I ordered the pappardelle, with great freshly made noodles, short rib and the perfect dash of horseradish. I also tasted the roasted pork shoulder, which was simply divine!
author: Janette W.

description: I remember this meal fondly as a delicious italian dinner I got to share with good friends on the first night of a recent trip to San Francisco. The food and wine here are delicious. I didn't select the wine so i can't remember what we ordered, but it was the best red wine i'd had in a while. The pappardelle pasta, scallops and several of the appetizers were all really tasty! The only downside to this stop is its financial district location, which makes it a bit uppity, but the quality of food is well worth making the stop.
author: neeta b.

description:
Perbacco is the shiiiit!

Came here a while back so I'm overdue for a review. This place is so frieking good. Came here with my sister and cousins and got seated pretty quickly.

The breadsticks and the pesto sauce was really yummy and fresh. It was good to have while waiting to order. 

I ordered the Agnolotti dal Plin and it was to die for. It reminds me of raviolis, but ten times better. It was moist and cooked perfectly. Really, really good. 

When I came here, it was around the holidays so we had this salted caramel gelato. All I can say is WOW! Never tried anything like it.

You gotta try Perbacco, you will not be disappointed!
author: Nadia C.

description:
I like to come to Perbacco when I'm feeling nice and business-y. It's a great after-work dinner spot that has the advantage of being centrally located in between Embarcadero and downtown, with a posh air about it that is professional and polished without being overtly stuffy. Service is always pleasant, although the Irish server we had at my most recent trip was above and beyond, so friendly and attentive without being invasive, she was absolutely fantastic. 

I love that they make their pastas fresh in house, you can certainly tell the difference. Service at the bar is not as warm as tableside but hey, if I'm wearing a suit jacket at a bar, I should be able to take it as well as I can dish it out.
author: Lisa P.

description: I only came here for the drinks, so this is for the bar only.  They have a decent bourbon selection (my drink) and apparently their specialty cocktails are good too.  It's a bit more upscale than a lot of happy hour spots in FiDi, so if you're looking for something that's not a dive, this is a good choice.
author: Jake W.

description:
I use to live in SF and selected Perbacco for a meal during a short 3 day visit. Generally, it was everything I remember, busy, good energy, and a clean space. It was too difficult to get a reservation for lunch but we (6) were able to get a reservation 5:45 pm on a Friday. The service was great and we were seated at the chef's table near the kitchen. The acoustics were better in this area than (what I remember) the main part of the restaurant. The issue for me was, since I was here last, I became a vegetarian and I felt that the pasta choices were limited - but, maybe I felt this way because I couldn't have the dishes that I use to have. But, I did recommend the parpadelle that I use to get, and my friends did not seem to love it.

We did get the small meat sampling platter. The explanation of the meats occurred towards the tail end/completion of the dish. Maybe we should have asked for a explanation earlier. Generally, I think my friends enjoyed it but, with 5 eating the small platter, we did not finish it.
author: Sandy I.

description:
One happenin' spot...

Attentive service at bar...

Romano bean appetizer is FANTASTIC, as well as the salumi plate...

By-the-glass wine list a touch weak, though...

Will be back for more than just appetizers in near future...
author: Gregory P.

description: Hands down, THE best pork chop I've had in a really long time.  The service was OK, but the food made up for it. I went here with my mom when she came up to visit and had a great dinner with just the two of us.  Dessert was also great, but I can't rave enough about the pork chop!
author: Lisa I.

description:
**I am strictly gluten-free, so my review is from the perspective of someone with this need.**

I was treated to a delicious birthday dinner at Perbacco by the fabulous Jeff W.

PROS: Perbacco is what every "$$$" restaurant should aspire to achieve!  The staff hit that sweet spot of being attentive and also aware of when to hang back.  The menu, from top to bottom, was mouth-watering; we had a difficult time choosing  antipasti and entrees because each sounded incredible.  

A gluten-free woman of Italian descent, I usually end up with a sad salad when I venture into an Italian restaurant.  Not so at Perbacco -- the menu is not pasta-centric (although there are several pasta dishes offered for normie foodies), and the chef accommodated my gluten intolerance effortlessly.

CONS: None; however, be prepared to dine alongside pretentious middle aged folks who become louder as they consume more wine.
author: A. L.

description: Had a lovely dinner here while having a weekend away in the city. Hubby and I both started out with a 1/2 order pasta course: the Tajarin and the Garganelli. One pasta dish was a little bland, but the other was pretty good. I got the sea bass dinner, which I think was a special, and hubby got the veal dish that our waiter recommended. My sea bass was nice and moist, but nothing spectacular and I immediately had dinner envy over my husband's flavorful veal dish. I have to say that I left a lot of my dinner on my plate. We wanted to try dessert, so I got the chocolate bonet, which was very good. Hubby got the crostatina di Albicocche which was some kind of apple tart like dessert. The waiter was kind enough to substitute the vanilla gelato accompaniment with hazelnut gelato at my husband's request. Hubby enjoyed the gelato, but was less impressed with the actual dessert. Service was very good and efficient with several people tending to us. Our main waiter was actually authentically Italian, and very nice. Overall a very pleasant evening and I enjoyed the ambiance of the restaurant.
author: Goldi J.

description:
Excellent food overall, service was a bit iffy, kinda felt rushed like some people mentioned.  Food was delicious, I highly recommend the Raviolo and a tasting of pastas..

great atmosphere with low ceilings and the brickwork.

Cheese selection is awesome, but you need to have an open mind and a strong affinity for tasty cheese to try some of them... they can be very unique!

Be sure to make a reservation the place fills up fast on weekends.  


Also try their house cured meats!
author: Shawn A.

description:
went here on New Year's Eve and had a great dinner. The Bourbonmela is a smooth and tasty drink and a great way to kick things off. The roasted beet appetizer was a nice way to start the meal. The pappardelle with the short rib ragu was great, but I wish there was more ragu with it. For dessert the bonet was rich and creamy and the pistachio cake was also pretty good. 

The service was good but not great, though it was a busy night.
author: Russ C.

description:
I left Perbacco quite unimpressed after some high expectations going in.  While the wine here was quite good, I had a first time rabbit experience with devil's gulch rabitt in spiced red wine sauce that did not go quite too well.  There seemed to be 3 different pieces of the rabbit with 3 different textures.  One was a bit chewy with some substance, the other was like a dry chicken breast, and the other piece was a soft bland piece of meat either way undercooked or way overcooked.  Either way, there was no flavor to the meat (maybe I just got a bad rabbit or they just got the most recent roadkill from Golden Gate Park) but it was flavorless even with being in the spicy red wine sauce.

The roasted pear salad was also a bit flavorless for my tastes and the apple/squash crostata dessert was just a fancy name for a circular shaped sized apple pie without the crust.  We dropped over $65/person and hopefully the next time I make it back, I'll give the monkfish, duck, or quail a try as "wabbit" just doesn't do it for me here.
author: Albie F.

description: Excellent service.  Our food was prepared in no time and each plate was better that the other.  It is quite expensive but worth it.
author: Victor F.

description:
Came here the other day for a work lunch. Seems like this is the place to go for business lunches. They were packed. In fact we had to use our inside connection to get us a table, Opentable said there were no tables for 8 weeks within two hours of the time we requested. Make your reservations early.  Despite the busy lunch hour, the service was GREAT! 

We sat upstairs and ordered: 

ROASTED BABY BEETS / CIPOLLINE "AGRODOLCE" / TINY BEET TOPS / CASTELMAGNO CHEESE - A yummy mix of red and yellow beets. I love beets so I could eat this every day.  

FARMERS MARKET SALAD - MIXED SEASONAL GREENS / LEMON VINAIGRETTE / SHAVED PARMIGIANO REGGIANO  - This was good, but typical salad. You can really taste the lemon in the vinaigrette, a little too lemony for my taste. 

PAPPARDELLE - WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / ROASTED CIPOLLINE / GRATED HORSERADISH - This is what I had. It was really good. The short rib was very tasty, it was like pulled-beef slow cooked in gravy, the sauce tasted like stew.

TAJARIN - HANDCUT TAGLIATELLE / 5 HOUR PORK SUGO / PORCINI MUSHROOM - I think this is what my co-workers ordered. I was a little put off by the top ramen looking noodles and the bolognese looking sauce. From the menu description, I had higher expectations.   

RABATÒN -HERB AND SPINACH RICOTTA GNOCCHI / GORGONZOLA FONDUTA / TOASTED WALNUTS - Didn't try this, but my co-worker liked it. 

SUBRICH - PIEMONTESE VEAL AND PORK MEATBALLS / BROWN BUTTER-SAGE APPLES / POTATO PURÉE / SPICED VEAL JUS - These were very good, I just had a bite. It would have been too large a dish for me to finish alone. They served it with roasted apples along side, they looked like potatoes. And the meatballs were cooked with apple inside them, kept them sweet and juicy. 

BROWN BUTTER BRUSSEL SPROUTS / CAPERS / SHALLOTS / PARMIGIANO REGGIANO - I've never liked brussel sprouts until I came here. (well actually Barbacco got me but its the same) These are so good. I think I discovered another vegetable I'll eat. :)

We had a Hazelnut and Pecan Marzipan for dessert. SO YUM! I wish I took some pictures.
author: Ping N.

description: Exceptional food and service, even by San Francisco standards. The salami platter was incredible and every entrée was superb.  The ambience is business professional, allowing for conversation but not dull. I'll definitely be back to sample the menu and enjoy the extensive wine list.
author: Brian H.

description:
Came here recently with a colleague while in town for a meeting, and we had a great experience.  Nothing too exceptional, but it was firing on all fronts.  Service was good, wine service and selection was solid, and the food was terrific.  The Tajarin (my main) was particularly good.  

A good solid choice for a business dinner while in SF.
author: Jonas B.

description:
Modern Italian food in a super clean, swanky, FiDi-after-work atmosphere.

If you're tired of the hipster scene, shave and suit up for Perbacco!! ;)
author: Calvin W.

description: I really want to love this place. After 2 tries, I my experience has been a consistent "meh". The food is certainly is okay but does not knock your socks off. I went again today. The waiter was excellent at service. He recommended the gnocchi. It sounded really good, but it was really just okay (and probably needed salt).
author: Sile O.

description:
Will definitely come back here. Walked in on a whim and were able to be seated immediately. I had my eye on the pappardelle but my date was undecided. I think she secretly wanted it too, but also wanted to try something different. She went with the vitellone mini-ravioli. Both dishes were great. The pappardelle was perfectly al dente, and the small shreds of the short ribs were also on point. The slight sweetness of the pearl onions and the grated horseradish lifted it that extra bit. I had a couple of bites of hers and had the table been turned, I would have had food envy. She did say she enjoyed hers. 

For dessert, got the meyer lemon panna cotta. It was silky, tart, sweet, with a nice contrasting crunch and slight savory of the rosemary shortbread. Highly recommend it.
author: Mike S.

description: Pappardelle, Pappardelle, Pappardelle! Can't get enough of this stuff but everything I've tried has been good. A few months ago I had one of the best scallops I have ever had at Perbacco.
author: Reza E.

description: Underwhelmed. The food was executed well-enough but nothing stood out. There is much better upscale Italian in San Francisco than I found here.
author: patrick g.

description:
Visiting friends, they took us here.  SF has great restaurants, so there are high expectations.  But this was a great experience from the beginning.  We sat upstairs, which has a very nice feel.  The whole place is very nicely decorated.
Started with a salami plate.  They make the salami/dried meats there.  And these were very good.
A wide selection of appetizers, salads, entrees, desserts and a great wine list.
Highly recommend this for a wonderful dinner.  And the price was not outrageous, it is five star quality but reasonable price what you are getting.
author: Mike A.

description:
One of my friends had his birthday dinner here recently.  I was really looking forward to Perbacco having had a great meal before at Barbacco, the casual version of this restaurant.  Perbacco certainly did not disappoint.   

They have the same great salumi plate that is also served at Barbacco, but the similarities end there.  All of their dishes were much more refined versions of what you would find at their sister restaurant.  While most of their starters and mains are good to great, the standout is really their exceptional handmade pasta dishes.  We had a tasting of the Tajarin and Langaroli Al Brasato, both were perfectly cooked, seasoned and sauced.

If you are craving for great Italian fare, Perbacco should definitely be a restaurant to consider.
author: Wei K.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  Service is always amazing, food always amazing, drinks always amazing.

One of the best restaurants in the FiDi!!!
author: Lauren P.

description: Hot damn, that pasta's good. We had the pappardelle with short rib ragu and the rabaton gnocchi dish. The gnocchi was particularly fantastic- so fresh with bright flavors. The burrata appetizer was also especially good. The cocktails were amazing and the service was perfect.
author: Annie C.

description: I've dined at Perbacco twice, initially for dinner and then for their special Passover dinner. On my initial visit I thought the food was solid but underwhelming. Then upon my visit for their Passover dinner with guest chef Joyce Goldstein, not only was the food extremely well made and fresh, it was only $49 per person for the set menu. Since then I'll only dine there for Passover, even though I'm not Jewish!
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description:
Excellente!

My best friend and I decided to treat each other to a fabulous meal as our Christmas present.  I did my due diligence and Perbacco seemed to have the perfect combination of mouth-water inducing menu, BART accessibility for adult beverage consumption and atmosphere.

We arrived about 45 minutes ahead of our reservation, intending to get a drink.  To our delight, we were seated immediately at an excellent table.  Our service was pleasant, informative and unobtrusive throughout.   

Excellent (and strong!) drinks in hand, we started with the hamachi crudo with citrus and the burrata with jerusalem artichokes.  The burrata and the artichokes were fantastic.  The hamachi was good but lacked a bit of acidity and flavor in general.  The lightness was a good foil for both the burrata and the pasta that was to come.

We chose to do the three pasta tasting.  I was *super* bummed that the risotto is not an option (risotto with duck, butternut squash and caramelized onions, you are on notice for next time!).  We made a quick decision to add the agnolotti dal plin which was fantastic.  I'm always blown away at how such a small filled pasta can have the most intense flavor.  I had the same experience at Cuoco in Seattle. Our other pasta selections were the tajarin (nothing special, sad to report) and agnoli with rabbit which was almost as fantastic as the agnolotti.   After sopping up the sauce with their lovely bread, I was shocked to have enough room for dessert.

I'm a complete sucker for all things salted caramel so their burnt caramel gelato with sea salt was a no brainer.  It was SO delicious.  Perfect consistency and flavor.  It was served with wonderful pine nut cookies that had a texture and flavor reminiscent of marshmallow.  Delicious!  We also had the sformatina - a chocolate mousse cake that was quite tasty.  Amazing with the caramel gelato.  :D

Perbacco has an energetic atmosphere and the interior isn't quite as refined as the food but I can see how that would be appealing to the happy hour, work crowd.  We had a wonderful experience and I would certainly return.
author: Shauna F.

description: This place is getting 2 stars based on service and ambiance, but I would rate the food zero stars if i could! I was with a group of 9, so we ordered plenty of dishes and every dish tasted very very bland. It seemed like every dish was missing salt and spices. I know this is a popular lunch spot so maybe their lunch is tastier but I would definitely not recommend for dinner.
author: Clarice C.

description:
Met up here with a another couple.  My friends who live down in Palo Alto made the journey to SF for us.  So excited to catch up with them.  They mostly don't eat such extravagant meals, since I usually wind up grabbing a burger or pizza with my buddy when he is in NYC for business.  So it was nice to pick a place we all were trying for the first time.  

My buddy and his wife got a salad to start and the wife and I split the BURRATA CHEESE / MARINATED RADISHES / CITRUS CREMA / PISTACHIO OIL and the CARNE CRUDA DI VITELLONE - TARTARE OF PASTURED VEAL / TRUFFLED LARDO CROSTINO.  For our main courses the wife and I split the LANGAROLI AL BRASATO - PASTA FILLED WITH SHORT RIB BRASATO / SUGO DI CUGNA and WOLFE RANCH QUAIL FILLED WITH MUSHROOMS AND FOIE GRAS / BRAISED SWISS CHARD / BLACK CHANTERELLES.  Yeah, I cut and pasted from the website menu.  All these dishes were delicious!  

The wine list is extensive in Italian wines with some reasonably priced options as well.  

We all enjoyed our salted caramel, olive oil and chocolate gelato for dessert.
author: Caesar R.

description:
Props out to my bartender/server for the evening, Joe. As a solo diner, I got a lot of advice re some of the best things on the menu. I reserved my seat at the bar on opentable.com and was warmly greeted by the hostesses. I started with the hamachi crudo with fennel and grapefruit. This dish was amazing. The flavors were perfection. My fish was very fresh, and I savored every bite. 

My second course was something from the house-made salumi category: the pork liver terrine. . . mind, you, I would not have picked this dish from just looking at the menu, but Joe suggested it might be a nice interesting second course, and he was right. A slice of the terrine accompanied by some sort of fruit gastrique and whole grain mustard. Very rich, but a small enough portion, it wasn't overwhelming. 

Last dish, the small portion (you could select the dinner sized portion) of the ricotta gnocci. I've never tasted gnocci so light and flavorful. I'm used to a potato based gnocci, which can be very heavy. This one was made from whole wheat flour, I believe, and accompanied by a fresh variety of mushrooms. 

Nice wine list, with sizes from by the glass, to 1/4 L and 3/4 L. Beautiful restaurant with a minimalist modern decor.
author: Doreen E.

description: Currently standing in line at Chipotle filling the void in my stomach left by a puny, expensive lunch from Perbacco. The only vegan item on the menu is shockingly tiny and insufficient to be called a meal. I gasped in horror when it came out -- like, that's all the food I'm getting??  I've said this before and I'll say it again: vegans DO like to feel full after a meal.
author: Alec F.

description:
Beautiful decor and an excellent and attentive waitstaff made this a great night out.

Pricey, but worth it. Salami made IN HOUSE is outstanding, great wine list (with California and Italian wines being particularly well-represented). 

Awesome place to take a date, spouse, etc. for a special occasion, pre-theater dinner, etc.

Outstanding!
author: Aaron L.

description:
Gluttony alert.  
On a recent visit to San Fran I whipped out my trusty Yelp app and searched for a nearby Yelp-certified place to rest my tourist feet and feast.  What a find.
My gent and I are bar people in the sense we love to dine at the bar even when fine dining.  The perspective is more authentic to us, and the views are always more fun.  People watching, interacting, etc.  We began with the tuna appetizer, which was exquisite, delicate and balanced.  For our second course we chose the gnocchi with an incredible, creamy, veal ragu.  Little pillows of pure love.  Finally, we enjoyed the short ribs with polenta and black truffle.  The flavors were so deep, so succulent, a definitive win.  
I certainly love my vino, but am admittedly far from a connoisseur.  Thus, we placed faith in our server/bartender to recommend wines for each course- best decision we could have made.  His choices were positively incredible, enhancing each dish to a greater level.  And his service impeccable. You're unquestionably going to enjoy Perbacco more fully if you go with the intent to splurge--it's worth it.
author: Amanda R.

description:
A good Italian restaurant does not necessarily translate into checkered tablecloths and candles melting into the necks of empty Chianti bottles. It should be like a classic Sophia Loren movie circa 1963 when she was at her most lusciously lascivious...stripping in front of a hormonally charged Marcello Mastroianni...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7E4ukdZXHew

Perbacco is not quite Sophia. It's more like Mario Batali in a g-string. Ewww...scatch that. Maybe Gina Lollobrigida wearing a bodice in a B-movie. Perbacco actually bills itself as northern Italian with a touch of Provence. I guess that means Neapolitan pizza and eggplant parmigiana are out of the question here. That's OK because the menu does look pretty good.

I had the $17 Grilled Lamb Tagliata topped with a mint salsa verde and accompanied with a warm butter bean salad. Delicioso. I had a taste of my dining companion's $16 Pappardelle in a Braised Short Rib Ragu with golden chanterelles and sprinkled with parmigiano reggiano. Really delicioso. I made a mistake. Can we switch? No? Damn. But I did start with a no-brainer, the $8 Roasted Red and Golden Beets with arugula and castelmagno cheese in a white balsamic vinaigrette. Very good if a bit skimpy.

I went yesterday for lunch with the recruiters who helped me land my new job. We could barely hear each other since the noise level is fairly unbearable, and the space feels a bit cramped despite the handsome decor. The hostess is a bit snooty, but I can see why since the army of self-important, white-collar drones who come here seem to be pushing a stick up her... Anyway, I like Perbacco, just didn't love it. Maybe I'd feel differently if I went for a Saturday night dinner.

FOOD - 4 stars...nicely turned northern Italian dishes, the pappardelle is a standout
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it's all very nice and cosmo-trendy in a loft way but so damn crowded and loud at lunchtime
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice waitress but the hostess holds a stick without the use of her hands
TOTAL - 4 stars...really for the menu
author: Ed U.

description:
Beth and I went to Perbacco with high expectations and were generally disappointed.  Almost so that I didn't want to even write about it.

Like many SF restaurants in this mid-level space, Perbacco has all the requisite qualities to be an outstanding find:

    * Striking design: 6K square-foot historic brick warehouse space with bold modern accents such as vaulted ceilings with blond wood beams, glass mirror wall panels that attempt to open the space up further, and marble-topped bar that extends the length of the main hall
    * Robust menu: Several dozen regional Italian dishes that cause your mouth to water
    * Equally impressive wine menu

But the food.  Meh.
 
We tried several dishes, starting with the herb ricotta gnocchi with roasted wild mushrooms and the potato gnocchi with duck ragu (the former was weak, the latter was a'ight) and then the beef short ribs and duck sugo (again, former was poor, the latter was good).  Service was so-so, friendly but nothing to write home about.

For the price and vibe, the food should be so much better and so I relegate Perbacco to the realm occupied by the many dozen SF restaurants that are long on style and short on substance.  So don't worry Perbacco, you won't be lonely in exile.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Great for an after work dinner with friends or colleagues. I've been here a few times and they are consistent with good service and tasty food. Everything I have ordered has turned out great. 
It is a bit noisier then I expected, but overall very comfortable.
author: Dee C.

description:
This was my first time at Perbacco and I will definitely be returning. The service staff were amazing, and everything was fresh.  Had the cherry tomato appetizer with the Coujette (garlic potato gnocchi with farm duck ragu) - it was the best gnocci I've had. 
I would not recommend kids if you want to try this food, it is more upscale.
author: Angel D.

description: Holy BLAND FOOD, Batman!! Seriously, I mean everything we order was an epic fail! The herring, duck ragu pasta, meat stuffed pasta, dessert, even the cocktails - it was like eating all forms, textures and variations of cardboard with differing levels of salt and sugar. Cocktails tasted like cough syrup. And ironically, I got a bad cough after.  And our server. Do you remember the show Its a Small Wonder? With Vicky the robot sister? Yea, this one was a robotic emotionless version of her. How-can-I-help-you-Human-beings. I-robot. Value for the money??? I should have given that 100 bucks to charity last night. Not some pretentious Italian wannabe joint.
author: Reema M.

description: Giving it 4 stars... pre-select menu that include scallops as the main course... it was a bit lite but the taste def made up for it... could on and on... but keepin it short and sweet.
author: Thomas E.

description:
Peg's Pleasing the Palate Picks at Perbacco*:

Perbacco!  (Ketel One Citron Vodka/Amaretto/Meyer Lemon) - Drink this!

Pork Chop (Grilled Berkshire/Roasted Beets/Cippoline/Manodori Balsamico) - Eat this!

Pistachio Cake (Vanilla Custard Center/Cherry Compote) - Savor and devour this!

PPPerfect!

*also get the Big Blob of Burrata!

____________________________

More deets:

Perbacco was very professional.  A perfect place for a business lunch or dinner.  Decor full of rectangles and squares.
 
Spacious restaurant - booths to the right when you walk in, bar to the left, past the big round table, there's another dining area under the mezz, we sat to the left in front of the communal table and kitchen area.  (Note:  it was a bit crowded to get to the tables on the far left back.)  White, heavenly-like bathrooms where you primp with guys.  
 
Other things we had:  the hamachi and the prawns/squid/corona beans appetizers were fine enough, but the big blob of burrata topped with black truffles was magically delicious.  Liked the duck and tajarin (tagliatelle and pork) pasta entrees, the risotto was the average of the bunch.  The chocolate torte was alright - carmel corn, whipped cream, cake itself tasted too European.

The wait staff was not as attentive as they could be, but Michel the flirty French waiter kept us entertained.  
 
Minus one star for small glasses of wine and for not coming back with my risotto leftovers, which I purposely didn't eat so I could have dessert!
author: Peg S.

description:
Perbacco has been on my to try list for awhile now and I finally decided to make reservations here to celebrate my up coming birthday. Easy and fast with opentable and you get points. 

Parking was easy and when we entered the restaurant, I was just staring at the open kitchen in the back. The decor and the workers here are so friendly! We were greeted by the hostess right away with a smile. 

We got seated up stairs, which is a more intimate dining area. It's out from all the bustling noise downstairs and I liked it more up stairs because the tables are not as together as the ones downstairs. We sat down and the team at Perbacco was so nice, they even had a birthday card for me! I think that is how a business should be run. 

The menu looked great, lots of options, vegetarians and meat eaters. 

Started with:
Hamachi ($12)-It came with four think slices! Fresh and so delicious! Had lemon zest on top and red chile? I didn't care for that but it was still really good without it.
Fritto Misto of Rock Shrimp ($11)- The shrimp was fried to perfection! It was all shrimp. There was also fried green beans, olives, and fennel, served with a lemon aioli. MmmmMMmm. I miss that already!

Entree:
Recommended by our awesome waiter, Sr. Juan, Pappardelle ($16.00)- It tasted like homemade pasta, which I think really was homemade, with duck, and some kinda ragu, forgot. It was really good too. Finished it pretty fast!
Grilled Ribeye steak ($29.00)- Grilled JUST the way I LOVE IT. It was awesome. i only wish they served with with a side like fingerling potatoes or something. The plate looked empty. I didn't care for the butter served on top, AT ALL though.. It tasted kinda like something was molding. Bad after taste. But I finished the steak so that means it's good!

Dessert:
Pear bread pudding ($8.00)- It looked more like a muffin without the paper on the bottom served with vanilla gelatin and mandarin marmellata. Looks can be deceiving! The pear bread pudding was really good. Good flavor of the pear you can taste the custardness of the pudding. Make sure you get a scoop of the bread pudding with the vanilla. Taste so yummy!

Service and food is excellent! Service actually was OUTSTANDING! From hostess, to waiter, to bussers!

**Tip: If you're sitting on the top floor and need to use the restroom located in the basement, there's a elevator so you don't have to walk all the way around the restaurant!**
author: Juliane N.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday and ordered the pappardelle, scallops (appetizer) and brussel sprouts.  Each dish was great.

Our server was very friendly and courteous.      The hostess was nice but the other lady whose sole job was to walk the guests to their table was snobby.  However, I suppose if I had her job of pacing back and forth in a huge restaurant wearing heels while seating guests all night long, then I'd be angry too.
author: Jen G.

description:
Lots of 4 stars and well worth it. I was invited by a friend and we dined to the 9's. The faire is Italian, but the experience is at the bar. if you want to enjoy this place grab a high stool and slot in. order the Charcuterie to start. An amazing anti pasta which is made with the very best home made cured meats anywhere I've ever been. And the short rib Ragu was off the hook. What a way to spend an early evening. if you've never been, follow my lead. Charcuterie and either the short ribs or the Ragu. Amazing. And the staff was outstanding. 

photo of the Charcuterie in the gallery...
author: Adam X.

description:
Stuffed to the max! Wish I wore a dress to dinner, instead of tight ass jeans that wanted to pop by end of dinner.

Came here with my team, so dinner was on the company :) We went crazy ordering food:
- 2 bottles of red -- great compliment to dinner
- 2 large plates of salumi misti -- meats all cured in-house!! Huge array, great platter
- foie gras -- nice hearty chunk of foie, no veins, very nicely done
- octopus --- lots of large chunks of octopus, nicely charred
- beet salad -- good
- pig trotter cake -- not exactly sure what this was, but it was sure tasty
- burratta cheese -- always good
- 3 choice pasta tasting option...I forgot which pastas we ordered, but the papardelle with short rib and horseradish was THE BOMB
- olive oil and burnt caramel gelato. YUM.

Solid service, delicious food, cool ambiance. More fun than Quince...but pasta at Quince might be a little better...I think? I must go back to Quince and do a comparison.
author: Carol L.

description: We had a marvelous meal for my birthday!  I ordered the quail and a side of carrots for the veggies - it was delicious!   Other people in my party had scallops and pork shoulder - every meal was perfect!  We all enjoyed various cocktails - again delicious and topped it all off with a burnt caramel ice cream.  I would definitely return and I can highly recommend you give this place a try!
author: Marianne A.

description: Came on a Saturday night and ordered the short rib pappardelle. It was good, though it maybe have even better if it was hotter and the pasta was cooked for a bit longer. My dad ordered duck breast and he enjoyed it. However, I feel that the hostess could have been more pleasant, but our waitress was nice.
author: Vicki C.

description: Although I haven't gone back recently to Perbacco (been frequenting Barbacco next door :), I have to say both are equally good, but my family enjoys the nice setting at Perbacco vs. me I prefer the great casual vibe at Barbacco.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Some fabulous friends and roommates brought me here for my most recent birthday- back in August, so this is coming a little late.

My memory serves me fairly well, however, and my first thought back to that night was how decadent, yet simple, and satisfying, but not overwhelming, every single dish was. I can't remember exactly what we had, but the brussel sprouts, the veal, the pasta with blueberries, ricotta gnocchi, breadsticks with pesto sauce, and honey roasted baby carrots blew my mind! 

We somehow lucked out and got the huge wood table that looks over the kitchen, and a birthday card was waiting for me on the table when we arrived. To top it all off, the complimentary dessert platter they brought included these hazelnut cookies called BRUTTI MA BUONI that you cannot leave without trying!!

The service is excellent, no surprise there, and the corkage fee is really decent. I think it's only $20 or something for 2 bottles. Its basically low enough that you can afford to get a decadent bottle of wine there and throw back a few of your own ;-)

As everyone pretty much concurs, its really a great restaurant- no hype, no frills, just brilliant Italian cuisine.
author: Raquel C.

description: I have never leave bad Yelp reviews, and judge those that do, but now understand why. The only reason I'm giving three stars, is because our waiter and the rest of the staff were so nice. Otherwise the food is inedible. We came here for my birthday, after someone told us how great it was. My dish was missing things described on the menu, the food seemed like it had been sitting for a while, there was something not fresh tasting about all 4 dishes. Anyway, I took one bite of my entree and pushed it aside, someone took the plate so quickly, i didn't even have an option of sending it back. I did call the manager late last night, and he did credit our bill for the entree. Again, if he and my waiter hadn't been so nice, I would give this place 0 stars. A terrible faux mock of fine dining, consider yourself warned.
author: Eliza W.

description:
We ate here specifically for the white truffles that arrived November 9 til they run out.

We had raviolo di , filled with Jerusalem artichoke and hen egg yolk with hazelnut butter, and cannelloni di, filled with slow roasted veal breast, each with 3 grams of shaved truffle

We also had the side of broccoli, bread sticks with pesto, and bread rolls.

Then off to symphony to hear the chorus, Brahms "A German Requiem"
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I had a business associate in town from Chicago. He wanted martinis and appetizers and someone suggested Tadich Grill. I really want to like Tadich but can't see the appeal so I was not very happy. After one round of small warm martinis (standing, constantly being asked to move) there, we moved the party to Perbacco. 

Perbacco is the un-Tadich. Take that however you want. We've all been to Tadich a hundred times so you know what I mean. Tadich is uber-traditional and claustrophobic. It's heavy food served by heavyhanded servers. It's expensive. 

Perbacco is none of that. Well, Ok. It is expensive.

Perbacco was equally crowded but seemed airier and much friendlier. We commandeered a table next to the window and ordered a round of larger, colder, better martinis. This was more like it. Our server was friendly, full of great suggestions and always there when we needed her. The Italian wine list was good but would have benefited from a Super Tuscan or two (La Parrina is nice~). We ended up with a couple of rounds of martinis, a bottle of wine, several rounds of appetizers (the cured meats and the stuffed dates were fabulous) and dessert.

I think some of that too new, too hip, too trendy attitude that kills cool places in this town is starting to melt away into something still hip but comfortable and friendly.
author: Brian B.

description:
T r e n d y
S m o o t h
V i b r a n t

I had just polished off only a half of the beer at Schroeder's and the pancake we had consumed between the three of us just did not cut it.  I mean, how am I suppose to support a pancake arranged on a dish Denny's level of style and presentation?

My good friend's friend was visiting from AZ for work and since I had missed connecting with her for several years, I had to delay my dinner plans with J and met at Schroeder's.  R volunteered Perbacco and since I had never been, jumped at the chance of trying a new place, plus to possibly review and check out the interior of the establishment.

First, let me state that I am all about interiors and ambiance.  I believe this truly enhances the eating process and Perbacco did an excellent job of this.  The establishment is a sleek and modern rendition of Northern Italian hospitality, echoed in the use of warm neutrals and lighting floored firmly by the rustic brick wall behind the bar.  Good thing I was in my suit, because 99% of the people here were in coats, and it must have been the destination spot for all the good looking people in suits from the Financial District.

R ran into a friend of his standing at the bar, who apparently knew the staff and the owner, and fantastically procured a banquette for us when one opened up.  Since I had already ruined my slight alcoholic tolerance earlier at Schroeder's, I declined to partake in anything special here, but did elect the Navarro Pinot Noir Juice, priced beautifully at $5.  They presented this in a wine glass and suddenly, people thought I was sipping some Pinot.  Brilliant.

Once seated, I was too busy checking out the interior and distracted by the group of suits behind us making loud discussion about an X-box game I had played in earnest (Gears of War, come on now!) but my dear friends ordered items off the menu upon the advice of our server, who was actually quite learned with the items listed and he advised that we start off with several of the appetizers (personally, they all looked quite appealing to me.)

T h e O r d e r

SALAME - NOSTRANO / FINOCCHIONA / SANGUINATO / TOSCANO / SALAME COTTO D'ASTI

A fantastic platter for the virgin to antipasti and all cured vivid meats.  Arranged artfully, the meats were arranged by type and came accompanied with little pieces of crostini as well as a sweet honey type marmalade and little gherkins.  R's special Perbacco friend questioned the use of forks, so I used my fingers to select pieces of the Toscano/Nostrano/Finocchiona (I'm a sucker for these extreme rush of tastes piqued by the curing process, the wine-garlic-herbs mix) slices gingerly and nibbled on the very rich and salty meat.

HAMACHI / SHAVED FENNEL / BLOOD ORANGE ESSENCE / OLIVE OIL

Exquisite and thick slices of the buttery hamachi, topped with shaved fennel, olive oil and slices of jalapeno peppers.  A beautifully textured piece of a gourmand's dream.  Remember to redip the hamachi into the olive oil for smooth transfer of senses.

BURRATA CHEESE / MARINATED FRIARELLI PEPPERS / WHITE ANCHOVY / ARUGULA

Resembled a little bag of fresh mozzarella, but the burrata cheese was milky smooth on the outside with a slight ricotta texture on the inside.  A mild tasting cheese, collecting a bit of the cheese in addition to the bitter arugula and the savory peppers and anchovy brought a fresh burst of a combination of tastes in my mouth.  Exquisite.

FRITTO MISTO OF ROCK SHRIMP / GREEN BEANS / OLIVES / FENNEL / LEMON AIOLI

Not the surprising course of the bunch.  Think tempura style, but the Japanese version offering a bit more on the crunchy and less oily side.  However, I was in love with the little fried balls of rock shrimp.  The lemon aioli was slightly bland, perhaps in due part that the lemon flavor was a little too mild for my tastes.  I ended up dipping it into the sweet marmalade that accompanied the cured meats plate. Fried green beans were not too entertaining, but anything fried tastes good these days.

This impressive display of vibrant textures as well as bursting flavors and the expert melding of greens and peppers to fold rather than diminish existing surprises to our palate.  The dinner was made even more enjoyable with Umberto Gibin, the part owner, assisting in the deliver of our plates.

I had to leave early from this wonderful presentation to meet up with a coworker, but will return to partake in the entree portion of their menu.

It's been a while since I've been impressed with artful Northern Italian fare and with the surprise introduction enhanced by the excellent service, Perbacco has restored my faith.
author: Miika M.

description:
Solid Californian Italian food.  Farinaceous long pencils with pesto before appetizers. Baby beet salad came with desireable carmelized whole shallots. Valiant effort by a Rumplestiltskin in the kitchen to spin gold from the tough fibers of a chicken breast, the non-pasta healthy option, but in the process of alchemy somebody dropped in too many tomatoes. Waitstaff friendly and attentive. We opted not to eat dessert because there were standing pools of butter in all of my companions' dishes. 

Came here for a work lunch.  Would I come back if not on company's dime? Maybe, but there are so many places like this.
author: Mandy H.

description:
"So" he said. "I tried to make reservations to Benu, but it was impossible, they're full for the night."
"mmm, that sucks...I would have loved to try the place."
"We're going to Perbacco instead, have you been there?"
"Nope," I replied. "What is it?"
"It's Italian and they're located in the financial district..."

Instantly  the image that popped up in my mind was Buca Di Beppo and I was secrety praying, "nooo, I hope it's not like a Buca Di Beppo!"

AND IT WASN'T! It was a very beautiful and romantic restuarant. Everyone was nicely dressed, the host and hostess looked gorgeous and the waiters were well presented too. Soon after we informed the hostess of our arrival, she quickly seated us at our table. Then our waiter quickly came to our service with the menu and the wine list. After a generalized recommendation of wine from our waiter, we ordered a bottle of 2007 Giacomo Conterno Barbera d'Alba to share. (GREAT CHOICE for those who prefers a fuller bodied wine) 

After scanning the menu for some time, we decided to opt out on the main entrees and to just share serveral appetizers, a side, a pasta and a dessert to end. 

Appetizers:
PESCE CRUDO- Big Eye tuna, cuttle fish, uni w/ an olive vinaigrette.

CARNE CRUDA- Veal tartare w/ truffled lardo crostino

*Forgot the last appetizer we ordered, but it was a crab cake mixed w/ mashed potatoes and topped with artichokes.) We could have done without that one.

On the side:
SAUTEED WHITE CORN- w/ thyme, onion and chanterelles.

Pasta:
TAJARIN- tagliatelle w/ pork sugo and porcini mushrooms 

Dessert: 
FIG LEAF PANNA COTTA

AMAZING and I was VERY impressed! Wine was great, appetizers were devoured, pasta was flavorful and the dessert.... THE DESSERT, I literally rolled in my seat laughing after each bite. It was so delicious! Another great choice, recommended by our waiter. 

5 stars for the wonderful dining experience.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I made reservations on Opentable.com and was really looking forward to this restaurant.  Unfortunately, it doesn't live up to the hype.

We were on time to our reservation, but still had to wait to be seated.  I really hate that.  Requested upstairs dining which we got.  Too dark for pics though.  Can get noisy downstairs.

Breadsticks were good, but the salsa verde was Bland.  We then got 1 roll each.  Roll is very chewy and cold, nothing special.  Butter was fine.

Dishes we tried:

Burrata cheese $11-red corn/cherry tomatoes, green onion, basil.  I thought the cheese was housemade, but one of the guys there said it's from Italy.  It was just ok.  I liked the corn & cherry tomatoes.

Salumi -tried the tasting of salume $13-nostrano/finocchiona/toscano/sanguinato/soppressata.  I thought they were ok, hubby really liked the blood one that has a tiny slice of apple on top.

brandacujun $9-Ligurian salt cod & potato gratin w/ crostini.  salty fish w/ a weird potato like mash up that was very heavy.  Crostini was ok.  Had leftovers but waiter never brought it to us & hubby didn't want it anyways.

tajarin -$15 for large serving.  Handcut tagliatte/5hr pork sugo/porcini mushrooms.  It looked like instant noodles, but tasted Bland & doughy, nothing special.  

Pappardelle-braised short rib raju/red wine/parmigiano reggiano $12 for small.   Noodles were bland & doughy.  Nothing special.

Hubby got a glass of wine (didn't catch the name) for $13. He liked it.  You can totally buy a bottle for that much at a store, whatever.

Skipped desserts, though we got 4 tiny pieces of Italian candy w/ the bill.

Separate bathrooms down in the Basement.  From the 2nd floor u can take the elevator to the Basement (B) and turn left.  Think there are many M/W stalls, I used a single Women's stall w/ toilet & sink inside.

Valet parking available out front, though on Sat after 6pm lots of FREE meter parking on Front, Battery, & California.

Our total before tip was $79.21.  Expensive for crappy food.

Not recommended.  We liked Incanto better.
author: Ann L.

description: Perbacco definitely lived up to its 4 star 1K+ ratings. I loved the upscale and spacious brick filled interior, lively but not too crowded. Service was phenomenal and the cocktail/wine list were extensive. Loved the burrata and panna cotta, can't wait to try out their sister restaurant next door Berbacco next!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Perbacco? Prebacco? PERFECTO!

This place won't jump out at you but is rather hidden amongst the giant skyscrapers in the Financial District but right when you walk inside, you know you've entered the Palace of Fine Dining.

Came with a group of 6 with lunch reservations at around 115PM. Once we entered, we were promptly seated after a wait of a few minutes. I don't know what it is about Perbacco....maybe it's been I've never eaten lunch at such a nice restaurant before...but I felt like I was Leonardo DiCaprio walking down that spiral stairwell, getting ready for dinner like a King. 

Might I say that the customer service is superb? They were very attentive but not too attentive (if you know what I mean). 5 stars for that.

Before your food comes out, they start you off with these crispy breadsticks dipped in this pesto sauce. Delicious. I could not get my hands off them. I truly believe you can tell how good a restaurant is going to be based on what type of bread they serve you. 

And for the food? I ordered the Pan Seared Hanger Steak. I can still picture the overall pinkness of the insides, while the outsides were seared to perfection. Couple that with some greens...best lunch ever.

Room for dessert? Oh hell yes. Get the Bonet (chocolate custard). Get the Bonet. Get the Bonet. That's all I gotta say.

Job well done, Perbacco. Job well done.
author: David W.

description:
Like me in the sack, Perbacco started off strong and withered away to utter disappointment as the night went on.

One thing that never disappointed was the service; second to none in San Francisco!

The wine list is great too.  Quality, diversity, and decent pricing. Above all else, not a lot of bullshit text.  Direct and to the point is just how I like it!  We started off with a lambrusco to cut the fat on some amazing meats.

The Salumi plate is remarkable.  All house-made meat, there was a wide array that satisfied a table of 5 hungry drinkers.  I can't begin to describe the wonders on that fleshy platter, so just go in an order one for yourself.  I'll probably be found at the bar soon enough with a crossword puzzle, a cocktail and a big plate of these meats. 

Appetizers were really good as well. The mixed fried stuff was tasty, but seemed to be entirely beans and shrimp, and if I had any complaint, it was a minor one that the aioli was a tad too tangy.  The trotter cake was above reproach and I wish I had gotten more than 2 small bites.

The pasta is 99% house made and also contains 99% of the salt in the Pacific Ocean.  I can only imagine what it would have tasted like if I had accepted the offer of grated cheese over the salt.

Entrees were really really rough.  The duck breast was fine but not impressive, while the little piece of confit or whatever it was tasted like someone had poured an entire bottle of cheap pumpkin pie spices over it.  It was no more enjoyable than chewing a mouthful of cloves.

The veal was a fantastic example of poorly executed sous vide.  The mushy meat was well seasoned, but the texture made it miserable to eat.  Even the brussels sprouts, which I have enjoyed here in the past, tasted like they had been doused in sand.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I cannot understand the enthusiasm for this restaurant.  I am well traveled in Italy, and I do not find the food at all authentic or tasty.  The fritto misto was too misto -- fine to add some lemon slices and fennel to the seafood, but this was all fried green beans, olives, big chunks of fennel, and a few shrimp.  The dipping sauce was flavorless.  The crab and hearts of palm was also disappointing:  there was a generous amount of crab, but the bitter, canned taste of the palm was overwhelming.  My friend had a pasta with duck that had a predominant flavor of vinegar.  The bread was a plain white roll.
This place is certainly not the best Italian in San Francisco by a long shot.  Add to that the dim lighting that necessitates all diners to whip out a flashlight to read the menu (are they trying to keep us from seeing the food??), and I would walk down the street for a piece of fish next time.
author: Andrea A.

description:
perbacco is the updated 21st century version of italian. gone are the heavy cheese loaded entrees, replaced with well crafted pastas and entrees. one saturday night, with plenty to chatter about, a few friends and i happened to congregate here. we were not disappointed. the delicious offerings, well designed, contemporary ambiance, and very reasonable prices (entrees in the mid $20's, pastas in smaller/larger portions under $20) were just what we needed to help us unwind.

while the shortrib ragu w/pappardelle was quite good, and a classic, I am on the fence regarding the desserts. the panna cotta was delightful. delicately infused with orange zest, plated with candied kumquats or oranges, and paired with morsels of orange granita. but i dislike panna cotta in general so one bite was enough. instead, my dessert of choice, bread pudding, came out dry and bland. it was quite a disappointment, topped only with some creme and white chocolate drizzles.

definitely a good place to catch up with good friends over a glass of wine. the upstairs mezzanine area would be an ideal setting for a beautiful birthday dinner, or a group event.
author: helen l.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!  Got the salumi misti plate (only because it was the 7x7 list) and although I'm definitely not a cured meat person, it was pretty obvious that it was amazing.  Each bite of meat, however small, was filled with layers of flavors that unfold as you chew... leaves you with a feeling that this must be how kings dined.

All our entrees were delicious as well.  Environment is classy, service is great - perfect for business or a nice date.
author: Judy L.

description: This is the perfect place for work dinners or great for date night. I tried the octopus and it was fantastic!
author: Anya K.

description:
I had a really great lunch last week here with my advisor from work, and I think the best advice I can give to Perbacco is keep up the good work! :) Perbacco is a distinctly regional Italian restaurant, which I truly love.  You will not find Tuscan, Sicilian, or Italo-American cuisine here, but rather classics of Northwestern Italy, done well!

I had the side of **brown butter brussels sprouts with capers, shallots, and parmigiano reggiano** as a starter, and these were reallyyyy tasty.  There were some crispy bits, but for the most part it was a smooth blend of all the flavors, and the capers and parmigiano really added to this side dish.

My main dish was the **quadrati d'anatra** which were agnolotti (like ravioli) with duck, and an orange-rosemary arrosto sauce over them, sprinkled with hazelnuts.  It was very tasty, and reminded me a lot of the agnolotti I had in Torino, but with the brightness of duck and orange flavor instead of the darker beef and red wine flavors.

We were also both curious about the **Tajarin** pasta, which were handcut tagliatelle with "5-hour pork sugo."  This dish was surprising in that it is so very simple --just a plate of tagliatelle with a generous splash of sauce in the center-- but it was no less exciting than the other dishes.  Definitely more of a "comfort" dish, with a delicious pork red sauce.

Of all the flashy places in the Financial District that can impress visually, I think Perbacco is one of the better in actually serving quality cuisine that is well thought out.  I'll try and find an excuse to be back soon.
author: David W.

description: Four of us came here from LA because of the reviews: however, we were beyond disappointed. Every single dish that came to the table was grossly under salted and spiced. We ordered a lot as we are people that believe in tasting a piece of everything, so it's sad to have nothing nice to say. Being someone that juice cleanses often, I'm also sensitive to restaurants that over salt. The fact that I had to add salt and pepper in this instance to everything is pretty horrific. Even the sea bass my mom ordered (while fresh) was grossly under salted. If choosing btw Mina's spot next door or this spot, default for next door. A few extra bucks will be well worth it.
author: Reina G.

description: I thought that Perbacco was just ok.  Ambiance was sophisticated and customer service was great, but food just did not meet my full expectations for Italian food.
author: Mei B.

description:
An upscale Italian restaurant located next door to the old Tadich Grill restaurant. The food is well prepared, European-style (small or "demure") portions served in a modern and bright restaurant setting. The restaurant is much larger than it looks from the outside. I've heard that there's also a small mezzanine dining room from which you can see the action in the kitchen. 

The menu has a small selection of crudo (raw fish slices), we tried the Hamachi seasoned with blood orange and olive oil which was delicious. The appetizer salads (also surprisingly demure) were very tasty (Roasted beets, Heirloom tomato salad), and the pastas (Agnolotti, Pappardelle) that we ordered were also good. For dessert we ordered the roasted pear which we enjoyed very much. Overall, it was a satisfying light dinner.

The deep red leather-like banquettes were not very comfortable for me. Avoid the inside corner table under the mezzanine area (slatted wood ceiling), there's a cold breeze (air conditioner?) blowing from under the corner seat (ankle level), if given that seat just ask them to give you another table. Service is slow (and in my opinion a little snobbish, or maybe it depends on which waiter you get) but attentive. We might come back to try other dishes.
author: Luis C.

description:
I really wanted this review to be better and perhaps the lower rating is due to these high expectations but there were far too many things that were average at best with my experience with the meal.

I had looked through the reviews here and on other sites and many people went on and on about the grand experience here so suffice it say, I was salivating. 

The decor was grand and indicative of a post work eatery in the Financial District of any big city and with its tiled floor and mahogony bar I felt like we were in store for a meal that was so good I'd be tempted to  slap my mama.

Let's get down to it -- 

Appetizers

1) Burrata Cheese / Black Olive Condimento / Arugula / Grilled Filone
2) Roasted Octopus / Saffron Poached Potato / Meyer Lemon Vinaigrette / Salsa Verde

The Burrata was what you'd expect. Straight forward cheese with a slight bit of resistance when sliced but roasted and creamy when spread on the bread and balanced with the olive.

The Roasted Octopus however had some winning moments as it was trying to morph into a foie gras with the soft texture and taste. This was a pleasant surprise.

Dinner:

1) Two of us had Liberty Farms Duck Breast / Brussels Sprouts And Apples In Padella / Pancetta / Passato Di Sancrau
2) Coniglio Al Civet - Devil's Gulch Rabbit / Spiced Red Wine Sauce / Otto File Polenta
3) Beef Short Rib Stracotto / Root Vegetable Purée / Roasted Golden Turnips And Cipolline

The duck breast that I and a friend had wasn't tender even though it was presented medium rare and sadly a tough duck really is a mess. The brussel sprouts were decently prepared but didn't bring a redeeming factor to the meal.

My wife had the rabbit and the saltiness was a bit overpowering and the sauce didn't compliment the meal in the least. It was as if the sauce was the star as opposed to the pasta portions.

The winner of the meal was certainly the short ribs as noted by other posts. It won far and away as the other meals certainly left us flat but also because it's just done correctly. The meat was tender and braised and matched so well with the pasta. 

If I were to ever go back I'd certainly have that meal but I doubt that I will.

There were some great aspects to the restaurant -- the drinks were made very well and were replaced with an easy frequency. And the overall bill was only 200.35 for the food and with a total of 10 beverages. 

I do have to say that our service was a seriously negative factor with the meal. Our server was hard to locate and hear, granted the place was full and she was scampering about trying to attend to far too many tables. One really odd part of the evening was when we were totaling up the bill -- we each were paying 60 dollars. So like any we have done in many other restaurants, we threw in a myriad of payment options. One person threw in 60 in cash and the I and another person decided to use a credit card. 

When we gave the server the bill, I said please put 120 on my card, 60 on the other card and use the cash as well. When I got the bill back I had a total of 140 and the cash was gone. Apparently she was so enamored with her service of avoidance and whispers that she gave herself a sixty dollar tip. Now it's not too far off from the 40 we were leaving but I'd never heard of anything like that before.

It was a slight hassle correcting the matter but at least it was done with. Just an odd experience overall.

I would recommend this place as a great spot to meet and greet for drinks and maybe eating at the bar but as for a dinner, there are more than enough restaurants in SF to venture to.
author: gerald d.

description: coming in after hidden vine sip...finally dinner....eight:thirty pm on a tuesday and restaurant full...lively and staff busy...reservations and seated upstairs...dim lighting...thin crispy breadsticks and sweet dip snacking...browsing wine and bottle of j pinot gris at $thirty-six to start...family style order of mix and match...slivers of tasty tender octopus $thirteen...wonder how long they massaged the octopus?...quite tender and sweet octopus deliciousness...small salumi meat platter quite loaded for smaller sizing $eighteen...slivers of salty meats and small sweet tangy pickles complimenting....perfection with another bottle of wine...brought a bottle and no corkage charged...taste of summer fruits in september $fourteen...wedges of sweet soft peaches piled with leafy greens...succulent!...garganell, pappardelle and risotto marvelous...$fourteen, $thirteen and $fourteen prospective...great mix of full flavor small plates...finishing with animals..tender well sauced short ribs $twenty-six fork tender beef...pork shoulder $twenty-four tasty and saucy...gulp of wine and finishing...barbera coppo $fourty-eight?...must be a wine ordered...stomach full and a lush with wine....check please!...roughly $two-hundred-eighty for dinner and wine for five...$fifty-six per person...perbacco perfect date or group restaurant...small plates and large plates to share, eat and enjoy...
author: Hen A.

description: This is a tremendous restaurant with great service and outstanding food at reasonable prices. The duck breast and pork chop are very tasty.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I FINALLY (!) made a trip to this restaurant! My girlfriends and I enjoyed a nice candlelight dinner for 3. We each ordered a different entree so we could share our dishes -- we sampled the pork shoulder, tagliatelle with pork sugo and the papardelle with beef short rib ragu and chanterelle mushrooms. All dishes were delicious! I especially enjoyed the tagliatelle because the pasta was so thin and freshly made! 

For appetizers we had the hamachi and proscuitto. The hamachi had a wonderful orange flavored dressing and the proscuitto was yummy! I'm a big fan of proscuitto too.
For dessert we tried the chocolate tart. It didn't knock my socks off but it was decent.
author: Helen Y.

description: My husband brought me here for my bday. We came on the advice of our lawyer friend who has been here many times for work dinners and lunches. We were very hopeful for an amazing dinner/ celebration for my bday. We were wrong. We had to wait over 20 minutes for our table, even though we had reservations. The staff was rude. I mean, really? Thanks for being rude to me in my bday! The place was expensive. The food was ok, that's it. We could've gone to many other restaurants and paid a fraction of what we paid and received better food and service!
author: Flora B.

description:
Friends and I had dinner here on a Tuesday evening and the place was packed.  We had reservations and were promptly seated when we arrived.  Service is hot and cold at this place.  It took a while before our waiter inquired about what we wanted to drink. 

However, after we ordered our appetizers it didn't take long before they arrived.  We ordered  Hamachi (yellowtail) with blood orange essence, shaved fennel, and orange oil, and ligurian salt cod with potato gratin and crostini.  The Hamachi was good, but it was difficult to savor the fish because the orange oil and essence were too overpowering.  As much as I love Hamachi, I don't think I'd order this particular dish again.  The salt cod was too salty for my liking.  Even with the crostini and bread sticks, I was still unable to enjoy it.

After a somewhat disappointing appetizer, I looked forward to my seared tuna entree; but that, too, was disappointing.  The tuna was seared alright, but the portion of the tuna that was uncooked was still frozen!  I should've followed my friends' lead and tried their pasta, instead.  I had a bite of the pasta and preferred it to my fish.  Try the Pappardelle, you won't be disappointed if you eat red meat and like mushrooms.

This place was batting 0 for 2, so I decided to pass on dessert.

The interior is modern and comfortable.  

Even though I was disappointed with my meal, I might be willing to give Perbacco another shot.  The pasta left me hope that I might actually be able to enjoy something in the future.
author: Annalynn C.

description: This restaurant is hands down one of the best I've ever been too. The food here is unique and delicious-- we had sea urchin, octopus, and lamb shank confit and they were all cooked to perfection. The service is exceptional-- the staff are impressively well-timed, attentive without being obtrusive, knowledgeable, and accommodating. I would recommend making a reservation, the restaurant fills up quickly.
author: Aubrey K.

description:
My 1st time here, fantastic experience. I was solo so I ate at the bar, but the service was just like being at a table. I had octopus appetizer, great textures an taste, and rabbit for the entree, great presentations and taste, I didn't want it to end. The bartender was a big help in pairing wines, he really knew the menu and the wines.
The restaurant itself was quite attractive as well, clean lines but not stark.
I'll definitely return!
author: Jay K.

description:
My sister and I were seated in this packed rectangle area that was quite noisy. All the tables were close enough that you can hear other people's conversations. 

Instead of bread, Perbacco serves breadsticks with pesto. I ordered beef short rib with pappardelle pasta which I didn't enjoy very much. I didn't like the horseradish shavings on top and the ragu pasta didn't mix in well with the sauce. My sister ordered pesto gnocchi which was quite dense.
author: Cindy H.

description:
I hosted my engagement party dinner at Perbacco and with a few weeks notice got a table for a large party (had to put down my credit card to secure).

That night we arrived on time and the hostess tells me that the party at our table has just paid the bill and should be leaving soon. Sure, no big deal. Our large party stood around waiting for about 25 mins to no avail.. Finally the previous party left and the hostess seated us. Given the long wait on a secured reservation, I felt like Perbacco could have offered us drinks, or even water, as we stood around awkwardly in the doorway. I almost wanted to leave and go next door to my fav restaurant Tadich Grill!

Otherwise it was a great night. We started out with the salumi misti for the table, which was excellent. There were so many selections on the plate and they were all delicious. Everyone had an appetizer of some sort - the rock shrimp misti was especially delicious and large compared to the appetizer-sized pastas everyone else ordered. All entrees were fantastic - specifically the pork shoulder and the scallops.

After dinner, a few of us had desserts or drinks and they brought us a plate of the "ugly but delicious" cookies on the house. Definitely delicious :)

I'd come again just for the salumi misti!
author: Wendy T.

description: My direct comparison (fair or not) is my 4 star review of SPQR the night before. Perbacco gets an extra star for having a full bar with imaginative drinks, no conversation competing music and equal food. The highs at SPQR might have been a bit higher in a dish or two, but this was a strong meal in a much better environment. Oh, it was half the price too.
author: Jon W.

description:
Just as delicious as I remembered! Lunch was fantastic:

PIASTRA:  seared local squid w/ corona bean puree, preserved lemon, chili and arugula 
TAJARIN - hand cut tagliatelle covered with their famous 5-hout pork sugo and porcini mushrooms

Also splurged and ordered a wine flight of reds from the Piedmont region: Verduno / Dolcetto d"Alba / Coste Sesia / Colli Tortonesi / Roero
Service? Professional and attentive as always. 

God, it was just the right to have a windy, chilly afternoon. Thank you, Perbacco!
author: Rene D.

description:
I went to Perbacco for lunch a few weeks ago and it was a fabulous experience. The salumi misti lived up to the hype in my opinion, and was actually quite filling when paired with warm bread. The piastra seared local squid was my favorite dish - ultra tender and bursting with flavor. Duck ragu 7-pepper pasta was also tasty and perfectly cooked.

Service was friendly and on point and the prices were reasonable for the FiDi location and the quality. I shall return!
author: Claire C.

description:
Held a small private client dinner here in the upstairs dining room above the kitchen. Excellent food, but was a bit noisy being above the kitchen.  Events team was great to work with and they put together a fabulous prix fixed menu. 

Came here a second time and dined in the main dining area. Cozy, loud, vibrant atmosphere.  Heres what I would suggest:

To start Salumi Piemontesi - an array of meats to sample
Bis pasta tasting: PappaRdelle w short rib Ragu

Capicollo Arrosto- pork shoulder
author: Samantha A.

description: I had an excellent client dinner here. Maybe it was the company, both the owner and sommelier came to the table. We had a booth. Service was very attentive. I loved looking at the exposed brick wall and high ceilings.  We shared the fritto misto , fried rock shrimp.   The shrimp were lightly battered an were a scrumptious tempura like tasting appetizer. I had the raviora pasta which is a fancy name for a fancy pecora and basil stuffed ravioli. The pasta was excellent. For my main course I had the sea scallops and they were tender, fresh and lovely.  After bread and two Eva La Mela cocktails and a bottle of Merry Edwards Pinot there was no room for dessert. Maybe I will try dessert next time.
author: Infodiva B.

description: I was expecting this place to be a lot better. The atmosphere is really nice but the food was mediocre. We came here on New Year's Eve and ordered the fritto misto which was decent. And I had the braised short rib pappardelle pasta which wasn't really good. The service is excellent but I don't know if I'd come back.
author: Collin W.

description:
Had dinner for 3 recently and had a very good experience. Let me share a bit...

Food: We had the cured salumi plate many rave about and found it very good indeed. A touch heavy on the raw meat elements for me for my hubby loved.
The quail dish was divine! Tender, moist with wonderful mushrooms and hucklberry(?) sauce. Also had the rabbit fusilli...wow. House made pasta was amazing and perfectly prepared. Mousse like chocolate dessert was heaven with delish coffee. Cocktails and a wonderful wine to top it off along with attentive and friendly service. 

Decor: Lovely restaurant with well done lighting(I am kind of a lighting freak...bad lighting can really throw off a place). We were seated on the mezzanine level upstairs which has a somewhat low ceiling and was bordering on too hot. 

Overall...great place with charming service and delicious food.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Very cute place.  When we arrived, it was in between lunch and dinner and so we couldn't be seated in the dining area.  The bar is lovely, with lots of wood and all the alcohol on display.  I am not sure if it was bad timing and the bread sticks were fresh earlier, but they looked amazing; however, they were dry, stale and tasteless.  Olives ordered from the menu were super tasty despite their strange green glow.

We also ordered a meat plate, which was beautifully displayed, but most of the meat was just salty and too warm.  One of the portions was room temperature pork back fat wrapped around a stale bread stick... I honestly think it was just a way to get rid of trimmings.

I might go back for dinner, but for sure not just for the appetizers.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
While the food was good (at least what I could eat of it), my chicken breast was rather pink inside so I had to stop eating it.  If I wasn't at a client meeting, I probably would have said something but there were more important things at hand.  Not sure I'd go back again.

Everything else I had there wasn't bad though.
author: Ken L.

description: This was our last dinner in sf and it landed in valentines day. It had some tough competition as our previous meals were at frascati, gary danko and spruce. Perbacco held it's own. We got the last reservation and the place was still pretty full. I had a great blood orange cocktail. We tried 3 half orders of pasta, all house made and outstanding. We had a grilled octopus dish which was great . We finished with the rabbit which we loved as well.
author: Michael H.

description: This was somehow my first visit to Perbacco, and I will definitely be back. The pork shoulder and duck were both phenomenal! Not as impressed with the sea bass, but everything else (burratta, crab cakes and even the breadsticks) were delish. Our waitress Tiffany was also incredible - very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful!
author: Megan S.
