description: The service was lovely and attentive, the food was delicious and the desserts were stellar.  Really the only reason they get 4 stars instead of 5 is the noise level.  We sat next to an obnoxiously loud group.
author: Lin C.

description:
Ordered the following with my lady friend:

Ice tea:  Score of 0.  I wouldn't normally include beverages in reviews, but this is definitely going down.  The water tasted like sewage, not that I know what sewage tastes like.  I didn't notice at first, but the lady friend kept insisting on the smell resembling that of sewage.  So I took a big gulp and yup, she was right.  The after taste/smell was rancid.  I'm still wondering what kind of water they used.  Server was nice about it and got a new one.  Would've been better if she comped something for sewage water.  In retrospect, the way the situation was rectified was not impressive, but we still liked her.  So I'm not going to crucify her for the service.  Second ice tea and thereafter tasted like normal black tea.  Score of 3.5.

Burrata cheese appetizer:  Solid 3.  Butternut squash and cheese with their sauce, seeds, and arugula garnish were good.  Nothing to rave about.  Nothing to criticize.  It is what it is.

Tajarin lunch portion:  Not visually appetizing but good.  It looked like what the tea tasted like.  Score of 4.25.  Pasta looked like ramen noodles.  Pork was tasty.

Black sea bass:  Solid 4.  Skin was crispy.  Mushrooms were good.  Fish was soft and flaky.  Some crispy veggie was in it for the texture as well.

Braised beef:  3.25.  Beef was cooked perfectly and tasted decent.  I can't say good because I think gal bi gim tastes a lot better.  I think the white veggie was cauliflower paired with leeks.  The menu stated black truffle salad.  Sadly, since I've never had black truffle, who knows if that was on my plate.

Burnt caramel gelato:  SO good.  4.75.  Came with pine nut cookies, and the gelato was sprinkled with Tahitian sea salt.  Sweet and salty.  Can't go wrong with that.

Service:  Spectacular, minus the aforementioned tea incident.  Am I expecting too much?  Thinking about it makes me wonder what the heck my girl and I drank.  Will update if we get E. coli poisoning and survive.
author: Steve H.

description:
Loved it!

We randomly walked in early on a Friday night after Christmas shopping.

We both got the 5 course tasting menu and it was awesome! Too bad they only have it rarely. But everything is so reasonably priced you can make your own out of the regular items.

Our server was Allison and she was wonderful. We snagged a table in the front window and it was fun to be doing our thing while everything bustled around us.

We had some Umbrian red that came highly recommended at around $60. It was lighter than some of the more tannic rich italian reds I've had. Think crushed velvet and elegance.

We were in and out in about 2 hours and got to see some findist happy hour business dude fall off his barstool drunk. 

Now that's entertainment
author: Allen A.

description:
What can I say?  Boring. (Period)

The food had no presentation and was not special in anyway.  We had some kind of cheese which i forgot because again it was boring...but it started with a "B" for appetizer.  Maybe it was called Boring Cheese.  For entrees, we had Spaghettini with Mussels and Risotto with Duck Reserva.  The Spaghettini was kinda sour and the Risotto was very "ducky" in flavor.  Food sucks...sorry... Maybe dinner will be different.

The atmosphere is very nice.  We had a very comfortable corner bench table which i enjoyed.  For two people, the table wasn't very small like most places.  The waitress was very knowledgeable about her wines and food.  But it was hard to understand her thick accent.  But it was cute after drinking all that wine.

Yeah and 2 stars only because we each had 2 flights of wine tasting which was 7 glasses each and was quite delicious!

One more time...BORING...
author: Kevin L.

description:
We visited Perbacco for dinner on a Tuesday night in October.  We were seated in Alana's section and will forever ask for Alana whenever we return.  She was very attentive but allowed us time to enjoy each others company, provided detailed, accurate answers to all of our questions, and recommended wines and dishes that far exceeded our high expectations.  

We started with a fish crudo, which was fresh & flavorful, and a duo of pasta - DELICIOUS.  We then shared two entrees - quail & duck.  Both were cooked perfectly.  We also shared two sides - brussels sprouts & white corn.  We ordered way too much food for two (and Alana warned us that it was a lot), but we wanted the full Perbacco experience.

We have enjoyed fantastic service at many wonderful restaurants across the country, but Alana gave us a truly exceptional experience.  We look forward to seeing her again when we return to SF soon.
author: Cecily J.

description:
This review is simply for the bar area. 

We had just eaten at Ziggy's hamburger joint down the street which was fine, then my wife thought lets have a drink-- its Friday night and we are in downtown SF, so woo.

I had the Jameson/lemon/ginger drink and my wife had the prosecco with elderberry...Aperol. Both were remarkably mundane IMHO, though my wife enjoyed her drink. 

Ambience was nice, staff were friendly, and we had the precious caramel corn bite with our drinks. Ok, whatever. I don't care if you dust it with fairy poop, it's still caramel corn.
 
It wasn't bad, it wasn't great. Fun to watch the young folks drink and try to impress each other. Service was very good, but we walked out of there for $35 with tip for two drinks and caramel corn.
author: Chris J.

description: We ate here for our one year anniversary. It is very heavy so make sure you don't eat alot during  the day! I have the white truffle risotto and it was amazing!
author: Virginia M.

description:
Errrmmm.....The food was nice but not fantastic. Portions are really small and I was hungry after having an apetizer and main course. Drinks are good though. However if u ask me, I won't come back. There are other really good restaurants in the FiDi with better servings and quality of food. 

Im merely paying for service and atmosphere.
author: Rachel L.

description: Wonderful restaurant. Very easy with valet and the ambiance was amazing. I had the tofio (sorry spelling!) and it was delicious. Seriously the best pesto sauce I've ever had. For dessert got the apricot tart and it was sweet and fruity and came with vanilla rose ice cream--so good. Def coming back the next time I'm in fidi.
author: Rachel C.

description: A bit of a crowded set up and noisy, but food is good, service attentive.  My pasta dish with a short rib and horseradish sauce was good, but would have been well served by more horseradish.  Cocktails were very good.  All in all, an OK place, but not a destination.
author: Howard B.

description:
Part of my San Francisco weekend included fancy dinner out on the town. We chose Perbacco after searching Yelp for a restaurant that a) was within walking distance, but b) wouldn't cause poor Nate's feet to blister anymore than they already had due to our full day of walking San Fran. 

We called Perbacco, made a reservation for 7:30pm, and got ready to go.

We arrived and were seated right away. It was a Saturday night, and the place was PACKED. So glad we made a reservation!

Since this dinner out was part of my Christmas present, Nate let me pick everything we would be eating that night. YES!

We started with the Roasted Pear Salad with caramel vinaigrette, gorgonzola crema, and candied hazelnuts. So yummy; sweet, yet savory.

Next course I chose the Tortelli Di Ciapin-Abe - Pasta filled with roasted sunchokes with sage butter, hedgehog mushrooms, and radicchio. I was expecting Tortellini noodles, which I adore, but it was more like Ravioli. Still very, very good.

For our main course, I chose the Liberty Farm Duck Breast with Roasted Pears, Butternut Squash Passato and Antica Formula Duck Jus. I have never had duck before, but OH! This was SO good. The meat was tender and flavorful. I absolutely loved it!

Dessert was the Burnt Caramel Gelato with Vanilla Sea Salt. This was what most of the reviewers were raving about, and I didn't even need to look at a dessert menu after reading all about it. And it was AMAZING!

The service was great; our glasses were never empty, and someone was always clearing or bringing out a dish. Warm bread = icing on the cake.

This was seriously one of the best meals I have ever had (top 5 for sure) and was one of the best restaurant experiences too.
author: Sarah C.

description: Place had a good vibe, pretty. Service was a 10...but the vegetarian options were few and the spinach gnocchi left something to be desired. Great wine recommendation from our server who is Italian, from abruzzi.
author: Sara S.

description: I ordered the risotto for dinner tonight (apparently they change the types of risotto daily) and it was pretty delicious.  The fact that they spice it up every night is also super appealing to me.  My friends and I sat right at the bar, and it was a great environment -- elegant without being too stuffy.  All of my friends also really enjoyed their dishes.
author: Mel G.

description:
Oh, my.  I just looked at my list of reviews and see that I never updated Perbacco.  I am ashamed of that because my experiences before and after my previous review were always great.  Their service is really impeccable and their menu is just to die for.  I love it all.  I live up the street from the restaurant and it's a great place for a late dinner with it's cozy interior and storefront window where lights spills out onto the dark sidewalk.
Small tables near the bar, larger tables beyond, plus a full second floor.  A great place for a special celebration meal, a date, or, heck ANYTIME you want beautiful food.  I've dined during the White Truffles season as well as through the rest of the year.  

Barbacco, next door, is under the same  ownership and serves lunch only, in a more casual atmosphere, also providing take-out meals.
author: Karen S.

description:
Romantic atmosphere, upscale and good-looking customers, and good (but not excellent) food.  
Salumi platter is excellent (house cured)- good start.  
I like how you can get multiple pasta dishes and small portions for each person.  Most were pretty good, but some are very rich.  My favorite was the ragu with pasta that seemed like upscale ramen noodles.
Entrees including the fish and the lamb were just ok.
Ambiance is great but the bathroom is in the back of the place down a set of stairs.  After a bottle of Barolo, I was in NO MOOD to wobble down the stairs, do my business, and then climb back up in a tight ass skirt and 4 inch heels.  Color me embarassed when my date asked why I was out of breath and I had to divulge just how deconditioned I'd become in the last few months.  All eating and no exercising makes Maxine a very plump girl...
author: Maxine S.

description:
The Salmon was to die for!!! Absolutely amazing! Had a romantic dinner date with my husband on Saturday night! also make sure to check out the wine menu, they have quite a wide selection. 
I am definitely heading back soon!
author: P M.

description: I've been here a few times. Good Italian restaurants for special occasions or take your out of town guests to.  I've had their risotto, agnolotti, and scallops. All were delicious.
author: Samson F.

description:
I took my ex to Perbacco for his birthday last month.  Gee, aren't I a doll?  Anyway, he cooks at Pizzaiolo in Oakland, so after checking Perbacco's menu I thought it would be compatible with his taste in food.  Me, I'm more of a French foodie, but it was his day.

Neither of us were disappointed, and he is a big snob. The house-cured salumis were fatty fantastic, I had the duck, which, flavored with quince compote, was the best duck that I've ever had (ooh I see someone else has said the same thing.)  The angelotti were perfect, and I finally warmed up to panettone!

Our waitress looked exactly like the actress who played Juno (i.e. short and young), but she didn't have any of Juno's saltiness.  She was purely sweet :)
author: Joanna M.

description:
Service was impeccable. I think I embarrassed myself but I dont care because I the pappardelle was THAT good.

Party: 3 (I was the third wheel)

Starters: Salumi Misti (salty goodness)

Apps: Fritto misto of Rock Shrimp 
Roasted octopus and poached Wagyu beef tounge 
Roasted formanova and baby beets

Pasta: Tris: PAPPARDELLE, Rabaton, Langaroli Al Brasato

This should be enough for the average diner but I had to take it up a notch and ordered the Pappardelle as a main dish AFTER I had the Tris.  I just couldnt help myself.  I'm glad I had the opportunity to try those three pasta dishes but their pappardelle was addictive.

Our sever was shocked by how much I was able to put away.  Needless to say I was enjoying more pappardelle while my dinner companions were working on their desserts. 

Yeah, yeah, yeah, so what I'm a pig. The bill came out to about $215 with tax and healthy tip.
author: Sun T.

description:
We came here for dinner a couple of weeks ago and ordered a Prix Fixe 4 course dinner that comes with one glass of wine for $50 per person!  It was such a great deal.  

Highlights for the evening were the fresh pasta dishes and the pork shoulder entree which made this place standout from other Italian restaurants.   The pasta dishes were made fresh with an amazingly soft yet springy texture.  Our first pasta (AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN) was filled with veal and cabbage topped with grated Parmesan.  The second pasta was a Gnocchi with wild mushrooms.  Both were some of the best pasta dishes I've had in the Bay Area.

The pork shoulder entree was also a standout.  The pork was tender, succulent and flavorful.  Our pork bar is finally raised to the level where it should be!  

As for the appetizer (a light salad-like app with beets, goat cheese and cherry tomatoes), the fresh seared Albacore Tuna entree and the Chocolate Fondant dessert, they were all good, but I thought they were predictable and were typical dishes/entrees in other restaurants with similar price range.

Overall, I thought the experience, service and food were good.  I will be back to try other pasta dishes and the pork shoulder soon.
author: Paul K.

description:
I have wanted to eat here for ages, after sending group after group of coworkers in with great success.  After one shockingly difficult work dinner, I was almost too embarrassed to stay and eat.  (Thank you, staff, for accommodating our wretched, sneaky group and not just kicking us all out.)
The cocktails were good, the food was okay - we tried lots of it, and while nothing stands out as either fantastic or wretched, I do recall being a bit underwhelmed by my expectations, but enjoying my experience.  Service was great, vibe was great - I'll have to give them another whirl, maybe for a romantic date where I don't want to crawl under the table every time I see the group function organizer.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Great food, terrific service and pleasant atmosphere. 
Pastas were fabulous and despite the fact this is a busy busy 
Restaurant it doesn't feel crowded
or rushed.
author: Karen W.

description:
It seemed like a good idea at the time....A friend who is a wonderful cook was in SF at a meeting , and he said, "I'm so tired of working on my presentation and having room service let us go out to dinner." I had been to Perbacco for lunch five years ago and it was upscale, and precise in food preparation and presentation, so I suggested we go there.  There was a crisp urban feel about the restaurant when I last visited. Tonight it just felt noisey, crowded and  very ordinary.

Perbacco  was packed on a Monday night  most folks appeared not to be  locals, perhaps they were all part of the 20000 convention members.   The service was attentive, although our waiter noted but did not ask about our half eaten main courses.
The starters of a fritto (which was not cooked hot enough) and a tartar which was fresh  were passable, but half way through the main courses my friend said, "Room service was better!"  I had the stuffed quail which was over cooked and tasted steamed and was on a mess of greens with both some kind of creamy sauce and a sauce of poultry,  It was all gooey.  His "nettle lasagnetta" was also gummy, thick with little taste of nettle and only a slight resemblance to lasagne and he said it had "specks of meat in it". 

I wonder what has happened here I certainly will not go back, but perhaps it was Monday and the chef was off  --oops I mean away--certainly the chef was off.
author: maria B.

description: Veal carpaccio was amazing. It had a dallop of whipped ahi tuna. i would go back for this dish alone.
author: Stephen C.

description: My family and I went here for my dad's birthday, and man, it was good. It was expensive, but for the price, the food was delicious. We had an appetizer with the burrata, which was REALLY good. If you want a delicious, upscale meal, this is a good place.
author: claire l.

description:
We take many things for granted in this food-crazy city: that the meal will be delicious, the service impeccable and the surroundings fabulous.  At Perbacco, most of these things definitely applied certainly, but really, it was the little things that impressed me the most, such as when our server offered us tastings of wines-by-the-glass when we asked for recommendations to go with our courses.

As for the food...

Hamachi with preserved lemon and chili peppers -- 4 large slabs of raw hamachi, drizzled with olive oil.  I felt the dish could have used a bit of acid, but the peppers were not overly spicy and the preserved lemon added a bit of pleasant bitter tang.

Roasted Octopus - octopus tentacles, fingerling potatoes and haricot verts salad. Couldn't get enough of this dish - note that unfortunately one gets only about 4 tentacles of the most perfect and tender-roasted octopus...

Risotto Milanese - listed on the menu as a "saffron risotto / slivered foie gras / nettle puree"
We ordered the large portion, and servers brought out 2 split and vrey generous servings for each of us.  It's presented to you rather dramatically with the shocking yellow saffron rice surrounding around 3 very thin slices or medallions ("shavings") of foie, and a tiny quenelle of nettles.  Each individual component tastes just ok on its own, but once you mix the lot together (smear the already- melting foie around with the nettles and gooey rice), the taste is orgasmic.

As for entrees, the boy chose the monkfish with wild mushrooms, beans and truffle butter -- I could smell the truffles as I sat across the table from him.  I opted for the milk-braised pork shoulder with polenta and savoy cabbage.  My dish was not exactly the prettiest to look at, but the meat was utterly tender and bursting with good porky flavor and the polenta rich and cheesy.  The boy's monkfish was also fabulous - perfectly cooked and firm and redolent of that singular earthy-heady truffle scent. Oh - and our side dish of roasted brussels sprouts - also fantastic...

Did we have dessert? I believe the boy had a chocolate covered creme brulee served with crisp mini cannolis -- 2 desserts in one... I was absolutely stuffed and nibbled at the edges.

I'm not a big fan of the design inside -- like Aqua next door, the small entrance belies the cavernous, long interior with high soaring ceilings and clean, minimalist lines.  Unlike Aqua, though, Perbacco lacks a bit of warmth and mystery and seems designed more for the high-end expense account power lunches and dinners of FiDi denizens rather than intimate tete-a-tetes with a crush du jour.
author: Claudine C.

description:
3 1/2 stars. food was good, but not amazing. i liked it, but not enough to come back

the bread sticks with the pesto they give you is really yummy.

roasted baby beets / testa arrotolata / pickled onions / mustard seeds / tiny beet greens: fresh and great flavors

raviora - pasta filled with roasted butternut squash / toasted hazelnuts / pomegranates: this was good, but i didn't like the pomegranates that much

pappardelle - wide pasta ribbons / slow cooked short rib ragu / grated horseradish: fave dish of the night

risotto - was with some mushroom, leeks, and onions-not good. flavors didn't go well together at all.
author: Karen H.

description:
Great food, good service. No complaints. 

I had the sirloin steak, bf had the pappardelle pasta with short rib ragu. Both dishes were excellent, perfectly balanced flavors. Yummy dinner rolls and butter softened just right. 

Service was slow at times, but it was rather busy. Our server was very polite and professional, and so were the rest of the staff. Kudos to the hostess, who updated us with the status of our table and apologized for the wait, although we didn't have reservations. Very nice of her to do so, I've been to many places where they just let you wait and wait and wait and act irritated when you ask them about the table. Not so here. 

I recommend. Yum.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Lunch review only.

Could not have been any better. We were seated right away. Great space as well with a great feel to it. Formal but not too stuffy. 

I ordered the seafood soup and the chicken. Sounds basic, right?

That was the surprise. Both dishes were spectacular.

The fish soup (forget the formal title) had a light flavorful broth, a great mix of vegetables, and well cooked fish. It was hearty and refreshing, not overbearing, and the portion size was just right.

The chicken was cooked to perfection and was a great size. The mushrooms on the plate were to die for, just perfect. I am picky about my chicken and this dish was of world class chicken cooked in world class fashion. Hard to find fault.

Oh and the free bread was delicious but quite buttery so be wary. Save your appetite for the good stuff anyway.

Service was spectacular. The waiter knew the menu well and steered me toward two dishes I ended up loving after he listened and heard my tastes. He did not recommend the safe boring choices either. Attention from the service staff was solid. Excellent high end service, but not at high end NYC like prices.

I didn't even mention this --- it was less than $20 for the chicken, and less than $15 for the soup. The chicken dish at that price is a total steal. Overall, I walked away very happy and felt like I had my best lunch in SF since moving here 3 months ago. That is worthy of a 5 star.
author: Ravi A.

description:
I love brining my friends from out of town here. When I think of a fun modern style Italian restaurant this is it. Excellent food at a good price. 

I was a big fan of Barabacco when my wife to be took me here for my birthday, so I was excited to see this place open up.

The 'nduja salumi is so good. It's a spreadable and delicious. I found the risotto to be very good as well. Great balance of not too mushy, still creamy, and lots of flavor. 

The wine selection was very good too (also it's on ipads) 

We ended up getting there pretty late, and ended up being the last people there. However, the staff did not rush us at all and made still feel welcome to really enjoy our food. 

I plan of bringing a lot more folk here.
author: Drew F.

description: I have to change my rating to 5 stars. We have been back a few times now and it is always spot on. The menu is unique, the tastes perfectly balanced on your palate, the food artfully presented and always incredibly delicious. The service is great, the atmosphere is that of fine dining, but with a casual comfort in the air. The butternut squash ravioli and the beef short ribs are among our most favorite and the carmel gelato is to die for! Especially with those little pignoli cookies. YUM!!!
author: Jen T.

description: Delicious food & wine. Peter Paul from Russian River.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Very bad experience, from a regular who has just ceased to be one.  
A bossy Australian walked in--"what do I have to do to get two seats at the bar?"--well, it turns out that all you need to be is be bossy enough, and Carla will get the whole bar to rearrange itself to accomodate, even if you are in the middle of a meal.  I hope this Aussie asshole spent a lot of money, but he won't return.  And I, who dine here regularly, won't either.
author: Guy h.

description: Two words: Eat Here. This place is superb. The pasta dishes are fresh. Everything is fresh. Haven't been here in a while as my schedule hasn't permitted it but will definitely be back soon.
author: Shariyah M.

description:
My husband and I had an amazing dinner there. The service was excellent and the food was delicious. We started with cocktails (loved the orange + Prosecco), then had a cured veal crostini, burrata & anchovy starter, meyer lemon panna cotta, and burnt caramel gelato. We did the pasta "tris" option - choosing three pasta dishes for the two of us (gnocchi, pappardelle with short ribs, tortellini with rosemary polenta and lamb ragu). 

The pasta sharing servings are not served family style; the portions are doled out in advance. This is great if you're with people who you don't want to dine with family style, but as it was just me and my husband, this led to some awkward plate-swapping when I wanted to steal all of his tortellini. Polenta-filled pasta = creamy goodness.
author: Loz L.

description: party of 2 no reservation but called in and was seated right away. started the night with piastra roasted octopus. amazing flavor and great taste would def order again. from there pasta and finished with a beef plater which tasted awesome but I would not order it again. the duck is recommended. great service
author: Shawn P.

description:
Terrific every time!!  We had a business dinner here last night and sat at the Chef's table.  Our party of 6 was well taken care of by our server and every dish was beautifully prepared.  

The house cured salumi misti platter was superb.  I usually get the staple Pappardelle ragu with shaved horseradish, but was drawn into the roasted filled wolf ranch quail breast and it did not disappoint!!  The roasted fennel paired perfectly with the stuffed breast. 

Try to get the chef's table and you can see how well the kitchen staff orchestrates the night.
author: Brian W.

description:
I just had a lovely lunch at Perbacco.  I've been there before, but never taken the time to review it.  It has been on my list for business lunches for awhile now, but it is always hard to get a quick reservation and I end up going elsewhere.

Today I had planned ahead.  Everything from the food to the service was superb.   I started out splitting a 1st course of heirloom tomato salad.  It is right on the cusp of the season, but these tomatoes were out of this world.  Flavorful and delicious, and topped with cheese and a sprinkle of balsamic.

We went with our great waiter's pasta choices for our 2nd course--Trofie (pesto, potato, veggies) and an Angolotti dal Plin.

For dessert we has chocolate mousse and gelato.  Glad I saved room!

The portions were perfect for lunch.  Satisfying, but not overwhelming.

I sat downstairs this time and it was great for business conversation.  Not too loud, not too quiet..  Good atmosphere and pretty full for a 1:00 reservation.
author: Katharine A.

description:
So after the "Tequila + Chocolate" tasting at TCHO, a group of us (14? 16? I actually lost count -- blame the tequila!) went to Perbacco for dinner.  There is a private dinning room upstairs -- in sort of a loft, overlooking the kitchen.  What a great room!  

Perbacco was wonderful -- I can only speak for what Lynn and I had, but the appetizers were wonderful:  I have the Carne Cruda di Vitellone (a tartare of veal, served with truffled lardo crostini), that was just amazing, while Lynn had the Roasted Octopus & Poached Wagyu Beef Tongue, served with golden potatoes, celery hearts, and salsa verde (and she's still raving about it 24 hours later!).

We both opted for pastas as our entrées . . . Lynn chose the Rabatòn (truffle and herbed ricotta gnocchi with wild mushroom sugo) that was delicious, while I devoured the Pappardelle with rabbit ragú, chanterelle mushrooms and braised radicchio . . . 

A wonderful evening indeed . . .
author: Jason L.

description: My husband and I went here for our 3rd wedding anniversary and we were very pleased with everything. It was a very busy night, yet all our courses came put in a timely manner. Our server was very attentive and made sure we had fresh plates and silverware between each dish. We will be back.
author: Carlee P.

description:
Excellent food and great service.  You will not be disappointed when you get the goods.  A little pricey but all in all the for and service is not something to scoff at.  Always on top of things with staff that are not only knowledgable, but also know a great deal about wine.  

The food is light, but of so filled with such rich flavors that just leave you waiting for the next bite.  The desserts are something out of this world.  Try the Mouse Chocolate Cake.  Every man, woman and child must try this.  I'm not a personal fan of sweets myself, but this just threw me for a loop.  Not only is it ridiculously rich, IT HAS NO FLOUR!!!  Wine selection is awesome and as always this place knows it's stuff.  I have become a regular here.
author: Daniel R.

description: My husband and I just went back to Perbacco to celebrate  our wedding anniversary. This was my husband's first visit and and he was in awe of this place. It was just incredible.  The food was excellent. The service was over the top. Our server was very attentive and you could tell he enjoyed his job. I had said that this place was a special occasion place, but after dining there tonight, we will be back soon. We are definitely fans!!!
author: Arlene D.

description:
Food: Fantastic and delicious food! Came here for my birthday dinner with my boyfriend and tried a small portion of the Tajarin and the Pappardelle pasta. Both were outstanding, pasta tasted so fresh and both were full of flavor. I loved it and was craving more. My boyfriend tried the rabbit which he thought was also very good. Would definitely recommend this restaurant. Very great quality food.

Price: Not bad. For a small portion of the pasta its around $12 or so and only about $4-5 extra to upgrade to a full size portion. Other entrees are $25 and up. 

Service: Very good. Our waiter was very nice and attentive and our food came out fast.

Atmosphere: I liked dining in here, very intimate setting. Can be a bit loud, but overall our experience was fine.

Location: Located near Aqua, off California. Parking is difficult in this area...we ended up parking at the Embarcadero garage and walking a few blocks up.
author: Miss H K.

description:
I dined here with a few friends, and while I enjoyed the food, I didn't think it live up to the hype of the reviews, etc. 

We started out with a few appetizers, the raviolo and a few others, but I found the portion size super small and underwhelming. 

I had the halibut, which was prepared and cooked well, but not the best prepared fish I'd ever had, by any means. Best dish: the rabbit. Other dishes that I saw was the duck, risotto, and other pasta dishes, but the reception ranged from great (duck) to lukewarm. One of my friends got the bolognese dish that looked godawful - plain, uninspired, meh. 

You have to pay for sides separately - we tasted the fingerling potatoes which were pretty solid. 

The desserts were all home runs. But can you ever really go too wrong with dessert? The panna cotta was probably the best panna cotta I've ever had.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Birthday Festa

My brother generously offered to bring me here for my birthday. We're Italian and have travelled in Italy since we were little. Anyway, my boss had brought me here for my birthday also, and I was so excited to see Vitello Tonnato on the menu.  When I told my brother how good the food had been, he offered to bring my family there on a Saturday night to celebrate my birthday. 

So I phoned for reservations (7 at 7) but they didn't have anything available at  7. Would 5:30 be oK?  I reluctantly accepted -- we never ate dinner before 7 when we were growing up, but seven people at Perbacco? I understood it was tricky.  My brother and his family live out of town, but we live in the City, so we agreed to make the sacrifice and eat way early. 

The staff had kindly asked if we were celebrating anything when I made the reservation.  I let them know that it was my birthday.  They assured me that detail would be noted on our reservation.  At the appointed hour, We arrived on time .... And were escorted upstairs and seated RIGHT NEXT TO THE KITCHEN DOOR. I was horrified. When I commented, sotto voce, "Oh ...  Right next to the kitchen", I was insulted by the "hostess" who said, "It's not the kitchen".  When I asked what it was, she said it was the stairs.  I tried to let it go but the longer we sat there, the worse it got.  There was a constant parade of waiters in & out. Then the odors started. I don't know what they were cooking in those "stairs" but it became too much. Thankfully, our designated waiter noticed me fanning the odor away and offered to check about another table. Our new table, despite being close by, proved to be a tremendous improvement. We were able to concentrate on the food, which was as it should be. 

We had the Vitello Tonnato, an old family favorite, and the Salumi Misti, Pappardelle, Gnocchi, and Risotto. The Gnocchi were a huge hit with the children. And our (new) waiter, Rocco, was fantastic. He was not only impeccable, suggesting perfect wines to accompany our meal, but he was absolutely adorable with the children.  

If it hadn't been for that insulting first table assignment, I'd have given Perbacco 5 Stars. The table next to the swinging kitchen door may be alright to assign to walk-ins, but NOT to guests with (2-week) reservations travelling from out of town for a birthday dinner. (Che bruto!)
author: Saskia Fiona S.

description:
The one thing I have to add to the 865 preceding reviews of Perbacco is that Joe Montana eats here. That's right, Joe Montana, the legendary 49er. I have to confess, I was caught off guard by how handsome and fit he is at 54 - um WOW! Starstruck Rebecca O. in da hou-ouse! 

While that was the obvious highlight of our dinner here, I did actually enjoy the food. My ricotta gnocci with mushrooms entree was good, but not special, but my husband's short rib pappardelle (rhymes with R Kelly), was heaven on a plate! I would definitely go back for that dish in a heartbeat. I was equally excited about the salted caramel gelato I inhaled for dessert. I'm really in love with salted caramel ice cream situations these days.

The dining room acoustics are noisy, so it's not the best choice for folks that are looking for a quiet, intimate ambiance. However, we were able to get a last minute reservation on a week night.  Plus, street parking was an absolute breeze, because the Financial District empties out at night. Bonus points awarded for ease of use. 

Bottom line, people - if it's good enough for Golden Joe, chances are high that you will like it, too!
author: Rebecca O.

description:
Good:
Pretty good food
We did not have to wait for our table (we had a reservation)
Extensive wine list
Very friendly hostesses (no snooty attitude)

Not so good:
Very pricey for what you get (entrees are in the upper 20 range)
Mediorce service
LOUD in the dining area
author: S G.

description:
Its allllright. 
I don't get all the hype, maybe my pallet is not refined but i definitely did not get all that jazzed up service all these people say.
The food though delicious was fairly small portioned and in order to compensate we order several appetizers of which were also small. I was so hungry after! People are comparing it to food in italy, i've been to italy i toured there for 3 weeks a this is nothing compared to there!
author: Julie B.

description:
Great service, good wine menu, not great food.  Apparently the menu is all from one region of Italy so they didn't have a lot of traditional Italian dishes.  No Alfredo sauce, no marinara sauce,  no ravioli, no chicken anywhere on the menu, no lasagna, no spaghetti, no chicken parm,  no pino grigio, no salads.

The menu was interesting. I had the shrimp risotto which was pretty good, but they did a poor job of peeling the shrimp which is a fun surprise.   Most others in our group had gnocchi,  which was poor. They were mushy, a weird consistency.   The beef short rib wasn't good either and looked worse than it tasted.   The atmosphere was average.  The prices were very reasonable, under $20 dollars for most menu items, rightfully so I think.   Oh forgot to mention they seem to not have any beer other than Peroni.  I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Austin M.

description:
Ok, so after years of avoiding this place after my first time going when the opened I went here for lunch with co-workers in my SF Office. I was PLEASANTLY SURPRISED! 

I had just gotten off of a10 day cleanse and was really still adjusting back to food so was only sticking with vegetables. We had a selection of starters including the seared squid, fritto misto, burrata, and radicchio salad. But what I loved were the brussels sprouts-- so good! Then I finished with the beet salad and had some of the broccoli and roasted fennel - I was very happy.

Service was excellent this time since we were seated at the chef's table.

I will be back for lunch again. Happy I gave them another try.
author: Helen B.

description:
I've been up here twice for lunch with clients.  It's always been incredible.  The food and the service.  It's modern but not over the top.  

This last time we had a client group lunch for 17 in one of their private rooms.  The service was incredible - we were in and out in an hour and 45 minutes at lunchtime. The food was amazing...The gnocchi was handmade and lovely.  I didn't have the chicken but it looked perfectly prepared.  The butter leaf lettuce was simple and the dressing light.  They had modestly priced (well relatively) wines that were excellent.  But the best part - i mean the ABSOLUTE best part was the tort dessert.  The buttery, flaky crust and topping, and all of the different berries hot and slightly melted...oh...my...GOD...I could have eaten 30 of them.

Although I didn't partake - they had the biggest, most diverse cheese display.  It was so big and they offered so many different kinds of cheese that looked so gorgeous the only word is display - but it was what they served from.

Anyhow...it's a very refined, slightly elegant restaurant that will not disappoint.
author: Tracy R.

description:
This review may read as lackluster as my recent experience and I apologize in advance.

Went there with a group from work and I had high hopes - really I did.  I had a martini that was excellent - I wish dinner was up to the same par.

First off, I'm not a super snobby kind of guy and will eat most everything - but the pairings of main course and vege was just a bit strange for me.  I settled on the tuna appetizer (after conferring with the waiter) and it smelled/tasted 'off' and pretty fishy.  I still ate it though and didn't suffer any ill effects.  I followed that up with the steak, a sirloin cut - really, how come not a rib-eye or a more inspiring cut?  It was ok as steaks go.  What really miffed me was the 'grilled asparagus' that came with the steak.  Nice char marks; however, they were all mushy - c'mon, if I can make my asparagus al-dente at home why couldn't they.

If I was footing the check I would have complained.  As it was, I drank more wine had another cocktail (a mojito - which was pretty tasty) and was glad the boss was paying.

I wouldn't go back though...
author: Darin W.

description:
How do you wild harvest warm chocolate cake? Apparently Perbacco knows how...

Very fancy smancy place to go for lunch with coworkers.  I enjoyed my three course business lunch. I made sure I brought my table manners since I was eating lunch with my boss and my boss' boss. Luckily there were no major mishaps although I think I accidentally dropped some fritto misto on the floor (shhh! don't tell). 
 
I definitely recommend the fritto misto of rock shrimp / green beans / olives / fennel / lemon aioli for the starter. For the main I got the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vitellone, the waitress said it was a signature dish. My taste buds appreciated her recommendation. I wish I hadn't ordered the dessert though. Don't get me wrong it was goooood but so decadent. The wild harvest warm chocolate cake put me over the edge and into a food coma. I wanted a nap the rest of the work day.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I ate here last Friday with a large group of co-workers. We were situated in a private area upstairs and were offered a separate, limited menu.

The appetizer was an amazing ravioli that appeared to have some egg in it. Nobody could remember what the dish was but we all loved it.

My main course was a gnocchi dish that was quite delicious. It was a little less filling that I'd like but I've come to expect that for the 'vegetarian option.'

The wine was great and they kept my glass full. The service was attentive and ever-present. We all had a great time.

It can sometimes be difficult to judge a restaurant when you're there with a group but overall I found the experience to be promising. I will definitely keep this place in mind next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Chris S.

description: Elegant atmosphere yet comfortable. Excellent staff and service. Sea bass blew my mind. Don't skip dessert - orange chocolate bonet is a perfect way to finish the meal.
author: Troy A.

description:
I started with the carne crudo and could have eaten another plate for my entree.. and dessert! Okay, maybe just dessert. I shared the angnolotti dal plin and langaroli al brasato, and simply adored the angnolotti. The langaroli was made with a stronger cheese, so make sure you're a pungent cheese connoisseur. 

Will definitely be coming back to try the other handmade pastas!
author: tessie n.

description: I have eated at Perbacco several times and each time it is beyond delicious.  The risotto is always a treat, great service and a nice wine list all make Perbacco a place to come back to!
author: Michele K.

description: Seems that very few places in the city can maintain high standards of food quality and service for any length of time. I had been visiting this place regularly for lunch but now I'm probably not going back again. The service has become worse, and worse, and worse with each visit. On my last visit, I didn't get my wine order until I was already half way through eating my lunch, and then I couldn't drink the wine, because it tasted more like cleaning fluid than wine. The server was completely disinterested and the manager, who is always lurking around, seems to be totally unaware of what's going on right under his nose.
author: Eater S.

description:
Nothing but "perbacco" for Perbacco.

I totally judged this place because it's in the financial district.  Sorry.  I was wrong.  The crowd seemed a little b&t/touristy/weird/douchey, but not so much so that it was distracting or that the service was catered to that.

Our waiter was helpful, knowledgeable, and attentive without being overbearing, and the other service was also excellent.

The food was all good, and some really great.  One of the highlights for me was the raviolo.  The egg yolk inside was cooked perfectly to create a slow ooze when you cut in to it, and the truffles and yolk, and spinach all worked together magically.  The brussel sprouts with capers in brown butter were so beautiful together I almost cried.  

Delish, I'll totally go back.
author: Linda L.

description: So swanky. Great Italian food, went for lunch on a weekday. If you've got the wallet for it, I'd recommend it. But I don't got that wallet.
author: Clara H.

description: I was happy with food and very pleased with the service, the hostess, waiter and servers were excellent!!! Nice place, ambiance and people. I just wish they would expand they're menu a little bit more, but I would go back
author: Rose H.

description: Overall The experience was good and the service great. The only criticism I have is everything we had was too salty . We had the butternut squash ravioli as an appetizer and it was so salty I couldn't eat it . The veal tartare was excellent. We added truffles on it which cost the same amount as an entree but it was worth it. We also had the quail and tagliatelle which were both very good but both salty. I would have given this place 5 stars if it wasn't for the over seasoned dishes.
author: Ani A.

description:
Mmm... Just thinking of our dinner at Perbacco is making my mouth water! Overall, this was a wonderful restaurant with friendly service, amazing food and a great atmosphere. 

You have to try the "tris" of pasta. It's basically a trio of pasta samples, and every single one I ordered was delicious. It was some of the most unique pasta I have ever had. Since the pasta was a bit filling, our group just split a couple entrees, and the duck was oh so tasty!

Did I mention you can bring your own wine too? (2 bottle max.) This is the perfect restaurant to go to for a special occasion.. although I also heard they have a good happy hour. We can't wait to go back!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Very romantic setting, excellent service and delicious food. This restaurant came highly recommended from my brother who works in the hotel business in SF. 

Everything was perfect, from the tasty bread sticks that they serve with aioli and their yummy fresh rolls. Antipasta appetizer was very good. I had the swordfish and it was perfectly accompanied by artichokes, and fingerling potatoes. My date had the short ribs and that was equally as delicious. 

Would highly recommend this restaurant and I think the prices were reasonable for the aviance and service.
author: Ronette B.

description: Through private dining manager Stephen Lee we booked the Barolo Room, the wine "cellar" located on the mezzanine floor.  We were only 12 guests but the room would easily accommodate more.  Mr. Lee was a pleasure to work with, efficient and to the point, a simple email was all that was needed to communicate.  We had our own private waitress, an Irish girl named Emer, and she was a delight.  She "read" the room correctly and struck a nice balance for us.  This was a wedding luncheon.  She kept the champagne and wine glasses filled...  The food was spectacular!  This place is fit for "foodies," and we will return as regular diners in the future.  All of our guests felt the same way.  We cannot recommend Perbacco more highly!
author: Betty-Anne S.

description: The fact that it's right next door to a restaurant with the same name with one letter difference fooled me. Luckily being fooled turned out to be a pretty nice experience.  The food was very well prepared and very nicely presented.  I would have to say the best mistake I made in a long time.
author: George K.

description:
* I'm back!!!  Apologies to all my good friends here that I temporarily lost touch with on Yelp.  The past few weeks have been absolutely crazy and my father's health has deteriorated greatly in so many ways.  He was hospitalized for ten days and is home now, but his dementia, alzheimer's, and poor health has been quite a test for us all.  On a good note, I used some of this hospitalization time as an opportunity to treat my poor saint of a girlfriend who hasn't had a night out in ages (since my dad ordinarily cannot be left alone and has to be watched all the time now, we normally cannot go out together at the same time at night).  If we weren't visiting him at the hospital, we were out and about, dining and drinking.  He is home now so things are back to normal and we absolutely can't get out or get away together at night now, but during that little time we had off, I really tried to make those nights special for her and show her how much I appreciate her and everything she does.  Thanks to Perbacco, I was able to.  Anyway, on to the review!

The review:

As everyone knows, I have always loved Perbacco and as such, it only seems logical that this meal turned out to be the most memorable of all the nice dinners and lunches that my girlfriend and I had together recently.  She has been so wonderful to me and my dad and with him temporarily hospitalized, I finally had the opportunity to take her out to dinner, something that has been absolutely impossible otherwise.  

Upon walking in the door, was happy to see that Carla was working behind the bar (nice new haircut!)...she really makes the place and was fantastic as always.  The hostess and people working the front desk were really great too.  As always, the service from everyone we came in contact with was fantastic too.    

Some places just always feel right every time I go there and Perbacco is one of them.  From the moment I walked in, I felt elated and at home in the uplifting environment.  This for me has always been the hallmark of a great restaurant...it's hard to describe, but in a nutshell, it's the convergence of setting, food, decor, and first class service/attitude (in a good way).  It's not just about location either, it's about a place with synergy that is run right and excels in so many ways.  Lake Park Bistro in Milwaukee overlooking Lake Michigan and Flagstaff House in Boulder, CO share a similar magic for me, every time I walk in.

In addition to the cocktails and then wines, we shared an appetizer of Vitello Tonato - slow roasted veal, lemon and albatore sauce, capers and arugula. She then had the Pappardelle which was wide ribbon pasta ribbons, slow-cooked short rib ragu, roasted cippoline, and grated horseradish. I had the Tajarin which was handcut tagliatelle, 5 hour cooked pork sugo, and porcini mushrooms.

The waiter we had, Brett, was first-rate and he really added to the experience.  Extremely professional, yet at the same time, genuine and real, he had the calm manner of a seasoned professional and his efforts made for an exceptional dining experience.  When I inquired about available roeros, he instantly suggested a special off-menu Trinita nebbiolo roero ($98) that turned out to be the perfect complement to our meal.  

For our main course, she had the Beef Short Rib Stracatto with root vegetable passatina, braised escarole, and honey glazed cipoline and carrots. I had the Striped Bass with wild mushroom and Jerusalem artichoke ragout and truffle jus. I specifically asked for no side of spinach and they were more than happy to accomodate.  Looking back, I just realized that I forgot to order the additional side of fingerling potatoes with lardo we wanted, but just as well, we were stuffed anyway. We then had a really nice valpolicella dessert wine (nice!!!) and then she had the Bonte, a wild harvested chocolate custard with whipped cream and amaretti. I had the Sformatino, a carmelized milk chocolate mousse with dark chocolate glaze, cocoa almond streusel, and creme inglese. No complaints here...it was a pricey, but most memorable dining experience for both of us, especially for her as it was her first time here. 

One of my friends, upon hearing that I spent $300 on dinner for two here took a look at the online menu and was surprised that I spent so much.  I explained that we had some nice wines and that when there are as many outstanding items on the menu, it wasn't hard to do at all.

Perbacco...just the mere mention of  the name gives me a warm feeling and makes me dream of heavenly Italian food, celestial pastas with slow cooked sauces, and fine wines in a tasteful, romantic setting.  Special thanks to our server, Brett, and Carla at the bar for a most memorable dining experience.
author: Roy N.

description: Perbacco is more on the upscale side of SF without being too stuffy. Gorgeous plates and complex flavors inspired by Italian cuisine and local ingredients. The ambiance welcoming and warm.
author: Henry P.

description: one word: awesome.  The menu looks foreign but the food hits the spot.  Waiter/esses are friendly and helpful.
author: Sid E.

description: I Love this restaurant! The food is fantastic. They make their own cured meats and the Salumi Misti plate is delicious and a great start. They have a really nice Halibut Sashimi. I also find the Pork Sugo Pasta unbelievably good. I would recommend this place for special occasions and just a great evening out with friends. I have never been dissapointed with the food or the service.
author: Niloufer H.

description:
My company had our 2010 holiday party here. We rented the top mezzanine for a stand-up cocktail/reception.

Nicole the catering manager was so very helpful and everything came together as planned. Our main concern was not ordering enough food, but she reassured me that if we wanted to we could add more as we went along. The room was cozy and warm and there were candles lit and a beautiful flower arrangement set up on a few tables. It looked amazing.

Now to the important stuff:

Open bar = A++++
Date and Celery Salad, Gorgonzola Cheese and House Cured Coppa (good)
Frutti Di Mare - Seasonal Shellfish Salad/Corona Bean Crema (good)
Piastra Seared Prawn, Salsa Verde and Herb Salad (good)
Crudo- Sashimi grade fish, served lightly marinated and served with a seasonal preparation (good)
Batsoa-Crispy Pig trotter cake / horeradish Crema (delicious)
Suppi - Wild Mushroom Risotto Croquettes served on Black Truffle Aioli (delicious)
Vitello Tonnato - Slow Cooked Loin of Veal with Albacore Tuna Sauce and capers (delicious)
Prosciutto Di San Danile and Seaonal Fruit (delicious)
Insalata Russa - Chilled, Poached Vegetable Salad (delicious)

We also ordered some plated items; Gnochi more risotto and salad.

It was all so yummy!  You know it's a hit when you manager starts drinking $180 shots and throwing out the F bomb everywhere!!! Ahhh good times!!
author: Michelle Y.

description: The food was delicious! They change the menu every night and this particular night they had a braised short rib that I just had to have. It melted in my mouth!!! I of course had to start with the butternut squash soup.. It made my taste buds dance. It was overall a wonderful meal and a great atmosphere!
author: Michelle C.

description:
A little over four months ago, my boyfriend moved to Australia for an extended sabbatical. The land down under has proven to be a clever minx, and she has seduced my boy. Seduced him good. Between Skype dates and care packages full of Cholula and refried beans, I've often wondered how I'll ever convince him to come home early.

Prior to my girl date earlier this week, he asked me why my roommate and I had chosen Perbacco. "Because, silly boy, they supposedly have this fantastic salumi misti plate." After explaining to him that the plate was essentially high-end salami, he perked up. I had the man hooked, as he loves his salami.

And you know what?

I've found the way to lure him back home. The salumi misti plate is fantastic and full of delicious salty meats and briny cauliflower and pickles and sweet quince jelly. It was everything I had hoped it to be, and it is definitely something I will share with him when he gets home.

And the thing is, everything about the food at Perbacco is excellent. Whether it was the roasted asparagus and pear salad appetizers, or the complimentary breadsticks, or the pappardelle with short rib ragu, or the rabaton gnocchi with mushroom sugo, my roommate and I were constantly wowed. Everything about the service was perfection, as well, and even though the ambiance is decidedly business-happy-hour, there were a number of couples enjoying intimate dinners around us.

So boyfriend, since I know you follow my reviews even though you're 7.5k miles away: Come home soon. You bring that sexy acquired Australian accent of yours, and I'll bring the salumi misti from Perbacco.
author: Devon S.

description:
Overall a really wonderful dinner... We started with the salumi misti and burrata, and I went for the papppardelle with short rib ragu as my entre. You could really taste the wine in the ragu which I loved! 

But the real star of the evening was dessert! We had the burnt caramel ice cream with sea salt and...

GIANDUJA "MILLEFOGLIE" - LAYERS OF CHOCOLATE AND HAZELNUT BITTERSWEET HONEY-CHOCOLATE SAUCE

Wow! It was simply amazing! A perfect ending to a great meal.
author: Jessica W.

description: The food, service, and restaurant were all impeccable.  This is one of our favorite places to dine.  The crowd there are all a bit older, but we still enjoyed ourselves!
author: Eusden S.

description:
I haven't had a real meal here in years, but I am 100% inexcusably addicted to their Olives. I don't know what sort of soy heavenly goodness they marinate their olives in, but it owns me. 

When I am feeling a bit classier than the Royal Exchange or Irish Times, I come here for a goblet of wine and my very own complimentary dish of olive heaven after work. 

It can get crowded on school nights and gets very "suit-ey" at the bar. But when its just me and the olives, I couldn't care less.
author: Meagan C.

description: Best Pasta I've ever had. The service was excellent, had good drinks, amazing food. Came here with one of my former friend, he paid for everything so I don't know how how expensive it is to be honest, but overall a great experience.
author: Claire C.

description:
Waited months to get a Friday night reservation, but this place is great.  The food was excellent.  

Recommendations:
Burrata cheese
Ricotta Gnocchi
Seabass

The menu changes daily, but I think they primarily do variations with a few staple items.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Kim D.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant.  I sat at the bar and ordered the Winter Root Vegetable Salad and Capicollo Arrosto (Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder) with a glass of Funsu, Cascina Ca Rossa, all at the recommendation of the bartender. She was very helpful making recommendations and pointing me in the right direction.   One of my pet peeves is when you ask for recommendations and they tell you its all good.  

The bread was good, but didnt seem fresh.  The Winter Root Vegetable Salad was very tasty.  I especially liked the bresola.  This is not something I would normally order, but since it was given a high recommendation from the bartender, I decided to give it a try.  Glad I did.  

The pork shoulder was unbelievable.  Not really what I was expecting either.  I thought it would be shredded or on the bone.  Instead it was presented like it was a steak, but very tender.  I am guessing it was pan seared after it was slow roasted.  The lentils were also nicely cooked. 

As a solo diner, I only wish there was a TV at the bar.  

I would definitely come back.
author: Mike E.

description: Perfect again! We went there for lunch a few weeks ago and the food was just amazing. We had the brussel sprouts and gnocchi for appetizers. They do have a smaller portion of gnocchi if you want it as an apperizer. For the main course, we had the Brasato which was divine and the risotto which was also wonderful. Overall superb food and continues to amaze. I would be hard pressed to find an italian restaurant of this quality in the city.
author: Getafix O.

description: Excellent drinks, pretty good octopus appetizer, the pappardelle was mediocre. Oh and there was something not quite right with the tartare.
author: Maria C.

description:
We came here for dinner on a Saturday night - the restaurant itself is ok - being in the financial district it has more of a business like feel than a romantic one (it can get pretty loud to the point of being unable to hear the person sitting next to you). Nevertheless, we were seated upstairs and ordered a bottle of wine and appetizer (a single raviolo with ricotta and spinach $12). If you ask me, that's an expensive raviolo. The had complementary sticks of bread that were unique and innovative and the pesto fresca dipping sauce which accompanied it was pretty good. 

For my entree, being a vegetarian and not wanting gnocchi, I had a limited selection to choose from - I  I had the raviora 'd cosse - pasta filled with roasted butternut squash, sage brown butter and toasted hazelnuts ($16). This entree was way too sweet for my liking and I was left with a meh feeling from it.  I was hoping the dessert would save the night. For dessert we did a three cheese platter of capriago, caprino di riforano, and the cuise sotto foglie di tabaco. I wasn't wowed by any of these unfortunately.  We topped off the night with the Hazelnut Budino which really saved the night. Honestly, if I came back here I wouldn't even bother with the actual food, just the budino! 

What really turned me off from this place was the service. It was slow and unattentive. What was even worse was the annoying couple sitting next to us who were making fun of one of the other guests - to top it off, they started talking to our waitress about the guest and to my shock, she joined in on the discussion! I found this to be appalling and very unprofessional at any restaurant, let alone one that's attempting to be "upscale".

Bottom line, Perbacco left a bitter taste in my mouth, quite the opposite of the expression of pleasure and surprise, as their namesake alludes one will feel after dining here. My advice, if you want good italian in SF, travel to north beach, and if you want a romantic, upscale meal in SF, try a Michelin, - do yourself a favor and leave out Perbacco.
author: H T.

description: No fireworks here.  Looking for a good option on Friday or Saturday night?  This should only be considered a backup option.
author: Michael S.

description:
RSVP at 6pm on a Saturday night.

The place was packed by about 6:30pm.

1. Started with the roasted pear salad. Excellent if you're a pear fan!
2. Tajarin pasta dish - looks like ramen with chili, but very tasty. We saw a lot of other parties ordering this dish!
3. Beef short ribs dish - very delicious with lots of flavor. Awesome! 

No room for dessert, but our waitress did bring us some small bite-size dessert! Service was great all around!
author: Roll N.

description: Went for a date night while sightseeing in SF. Delicious steak tartare and gnocci! Although the tables weren't too intimate (so close to other diners that you can easily join in on their conversation), the ambiance was classy. I would definitely recommend it!
author: Mariam W.

description: Delicious pastas, very inventive and satisfying! Sadly there are not very many places in SF to get some good pasta, but this is one of the best. You will not be disappointed. Good for special occasion, great service, nice atmosphere.
author: Chelse B.

description:
I stopped in for a late night dinner around 9:30 on the promise from my friend that Perbacco would offer a fine meal.

The dining area was still packed with a healthy dinner crowd, full of the energy of the financial district's finest. We ordered a bottle of the Peter Paul pinot noir as I perused through the difficult-to-pronounce menu items. 

I decided on the Tajarin, not knowing what it was, but the phrases" 5-hour" and "pork" together sounded delicious. What arrived before we could finish our first glass of wine was a beautiful dish of long, stringy pasta (similar looking to ramen if I may be so bold) with a neat covering of thick pork ragu sauce. 

If you're a foodie (and I don't claim I am), the first bite tells all. To me, if it makes my eyes close as I savor the flavors in my mouth, this place is getting at least 3 stars. As it turned out, the Tajarin pasta was cooked perfectly - a bit al dente to make it springy and pleasantly chewy. The thick, melt-in-your-mouth pork ragu sauce added a most excellent compliment to the pasta. I had to exercise diligent self-control as to not hork down the plate of pasta and lick the plate, as I was on a date of sorts.

Though a bit on the pricey side (one plate of pasta, a bottle of wine, and dessert) came out to a little over $100, it's definitely worth your splurge fund when you feel like you deserve a heart-warming pasta treat.
author: Jason L.

description: Go to their bar, Barbacco instead.  Better food, less stuffy, better prices.
author: Suzie R.

description:
I've been to Perbacco quite a few times and it has generally been at least very good.  Last night it was better than that.  The food was outstanding.  Given that it's so easy to forget an older standby with so many new places opening, I figured I should up-date.

First off, the service and the welcome at the door were both what you would and should expect from a good restaurant.  But for me, it's always the food.

When a salad of arctic snow peaches, spring porcini mushrooms, spring lettuces, with a stone fruit vinaigrette arrived I was a bit disappointed.  It looked a bit plain with slices of peach and mushroom over greens.  One taste disabused me of my concern as the peaches were sweet, the lettuces perfectly pristine and the mushrooms spot on.  

Tagliatelle with five hour pork sugo was all that pasta should be: perfectly al dente with a sugo that had depth of taste.

Black sea bass was perfectly seared and sweet.  The morel mushrooms that came with the fish were wondrous and the sweet pea passatina beneath the fish was nice as well.

All in all a lovely meal and a reminder not to forget places like Perbacco.
author: David D.

description: Holiday parties are great! Especially when you are invited to one at a swanky place like Perbacco. The waitstaff was very friendly and answered our questions about all the different types of appetizers that they had. For the main course I had the steak with was very tender and juicy, like butter. And the dessert was amazing, not too sweet. There was also an open bar, but my only gripe was that the bartender had the lemons in a deep glass and she couldn't get to them unless she poked them with her finger. Other than that, it was a lovely night.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I went here on a business dinner and had a very good time (was it the numerous bottles of wine on our company? I am not sure). The service was excellent and the food was pretty good. I would give 5 stars for service and wine selections, 4 was for the food. 

*I don't agree with giving places 1 star due to a bad OpenTable reservation. I never rely on that service, always best to call ahead and book it manually. I know. picking up the phone and dialing is hard work.
author: Karen S.

description: Came here on February 13, was seated right upon arrival with the requested special dinner menus that I had asked for :)!! We started with the fritto misto which was so delicately delicious I couldn't get enough of it, for entree I ordered the risotto ( which I feel like you can never go wrong with risotto) & I was right!! I was delicious and a very large portion even tho I did buy the smaller sized risotto, I took the rest of what I hadn't finished in a box to go. For dessert, I asked for the pear sorbetto w/ amaretto cookies and it was heavenly! Must recommend to anyone in San Francisco wishing to dine in a fancy restaurant, GO HERE!!! You won't be sorry, just make a reservation, it tends to get quite full
author: Astrid C.

description:
Excellent and my favorite for financial district business lunches. For dinner with wife it is also very solid. 

The homemade pasta is always very good.  The pappardelle is the best.  

Only caution is that the tables are very close together.  Try to reserve a table in a corner for a little more space.
author: Ed C.

description:
We went there for our anniversary dinner.

The place is quite big, noisy, it was busy on a Thursday night, before 7.

Staff were very friendly, they all greeted us with smile. Our waiter was gracious, professional yet warm.

I have no problem with the quality and taste of the food. While they were not exceptional, they were fine. However, I thought the display of the food, or the plating, was quite shameful. I usually don't care about it that much, but you are in a fancy, expensive restaurant, you pay a lot more than you usually do, it's reasonable to expect more.

After we settled down and ordered, I glanced at the table next to ours. The gentleman at the table was having a pasta dish, it was a plate of spaghetti with some sort of meat sauce. If you just looked at the dish, you'd think you were in Denny's, or one of those undistinguished diners. There's no such thing as plating, none whatsoever, just spaghetti with meat sauce heaped up on the plate as if I would serve at home after a hectic day and I whipped up a quick meal. 

Our main dishes came. We both ordered pasta tasting courses, for which you got to try 2 different pasta dishes. Our plates were off white color, rectangular shaped. On the plates, sat 2 small pools of pasta in their sauces. I remember, in other restaurants, even the less fancy ones, usually they do something with the plate, some oil dripping on the side, some sprinkled parsley, just so the plate looked pretty, appetizing and professional, you'd feel that the chef was having fun. Not in our case. Our dishes looked very hurried,  mindlessly put together just to get them done and over with, it somehow reminded me of assembly line. Honestly my home cooking looks better than this.

Then came the dessert Panna Cotta.  It sat off the center of a huge plate, almost tilting to the side, there were quite a lot of blank space because the plate was too big, that made the dessert looked sad and lonely. And the scarcely drizzled  raspberry sauce looked more like an afterthought, and not nearly enough to accompany the panna cotta. Remember those fanciful dessert plates? There are sprinkled powder sugar, splash of bright colored sauce, artistically arranged chocolate or cookie bits, mint leaves, I used to think it's show off, now I miss them. At least they are fun to look at.

I admit, I usually don't give much thoughts to how food is presented, or, at times, I think some of the decorating of the dishes are excessive and showy, but it is nice to look at, like a piece of visual art. The pleasure of fine dining isn't just about taste, it involves flavor, texture, color, arrangement. I would be willing to overlook all these, if the food was exceptional. But in this case, it was not.
author: Echo C.

description:
I won't delve into the starters which didn't impress me much, I think we might have mis-ordered. Now something cool about the pasta menu: for you entree, you can order 2 or 3 kind of pasta that you'll share with your dining companion. I really like that option - this allows to sample more dishes and still have room for dessert. The agnolotti dal plin (kind of ravioli) filled with roasted veal and the pappardelle with slow cooked short rib ragu were terrific. We ordered the caramel ice cream for dessert, not bad, but I thought the pine nut and almond cookies that came with it stole the show (very fresh but chewy with an unusual combination of nuts). 
The service was good too, we got some really good wine recommendations from our waiter. The red was particularly great (you can order by it by the glass, it's called Südtiroler, Lagrein, Weingut Niklas; yeah, good luck remembering that).
author: Laurent P.

description:
If you want to see some seriously amusing expressions of thinly veiled dread come across the faces of the wait staff at an upscale FIDI eatery, try walking in a little after 1:30 in the afternoon with no reservation and a cranky 6 year old in tow.

After the briefest moment of silently determining whether they would seat us, we were placed at a table as far away from the other still-lunching customers as possible.  They needn't have worried --- Ruby has been dining at posh establishments since birth, and needed only to have a basket of good bread and butter and a refreshing drink put in front of her to quell the grumpiness (kind of like her grandmum ...  ;-)

While I very much look forward to revisiting Perbacco with a grown-up the next time I'm in the city so that I can indulge in starters, sides, cheeses and wines (six yr olds have tiny tummies and short attention spans), I have to say that what we did eat was plenty memorable:  we shared a plate of trout fillets with wild shrooms and - genius - jerusalem artichokes as our starch.  Perhaps it was just the hunger talking, but at that moment I couldn't imagine a more thoughtful composition.  Although 'full', we still somehow managed to find room for panna cotta and granita  ...  ;-)
author: Susanne R.

description:
Me lovies some Perbacco anytime, any day. 

The girls and I love coming here for a special occasion or no occasion at all because it frankly serves any purpose. You have a convention, work day, cultural event, or because you're thirsty, just come by! The northern Italian cuisine is my preferred regional cuisine when it comes to Italian and you won't leave dinner feeling like you just loaded up on carbs before a marathon. Clean, bright and rich flavors on just about every dish. 

Say yes to the roasted octopus and poached veal tongue app, roasted beet salad w gorgonzola bombolino, arugula and strawberry salad, pastas of Agnolotti and Pappardelle with ragu feature of the day and pistachio pana cotta  - when they have it. If they ever have octopus/squid anything for an app - get it!

We love this place mainly because Mark works the bar and we prefer just to eat at the bar as well since we love the ambiance. Mark always provides honest recommendations, excellent service and good company to all. Did I mention there are purse hooks as well? Always a winner. Although this place gets loud, it works in your advantage if you go on an awkward date probably. 

P.S. Come Tuesday, Wed or Fri nights when Mark is working. Yes they take reservations for the tables not the bar and $10 valet out front if you can't find parking.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Perbacco was just not for me. Nothing against the restaurant or the food but it just wasn't my kind of food or my kind of atmosphere. What I liked I loved, but to describe what I disliked would require this analogy: To those who hate brussel sprouts, no matter how you cook it, you're not gonna like it. That was how I felt about the dishes I disliked. 

I apologize that the rest of my review of the dishes don't include names; I had a hard time reading the menu as there were so many things I didn't understand on the menu in one line. For those of you who don't come to these type of restaurants often or if you dont' have culinary experience, heed this warning: you will have a hard time reading the menu too. Words like passatina and passato frequent the menu often and I still don't know what they mean. I felt like I needed a dictionary or an italian-english translator to decipher the menu. Just what are they trying to prove -.- Anyways...

Food: We shared appetizers and pasta dishes and there were dishes that stuck out to me. First was this plate of fried food. It had string beans and what I thought was calamari but my boyfriend's dad said it was fried shrimp. It had the right texture and a great taste. 

Second were these pasta noodles with short rib ragu. The noodles honestly tasted like soupless ramen noodles but the lamb ragu had a great strong flavor. 

Third was the gnocchi. It was the first time i've had gnocchi so I"m not sure how they are supposed to taste but it wasn't my cup of tea. It had a mushy texture and a forgettable taste. Anyone want to tell me if gnocchi is supposed to be mushy?

Fourth was the main entree I ordered. Duck breast whatever. It was really juicy but the taste was also forgettable.

Fifth was the hazelnut cookies. Again weird texture. Half the table liked it and half the table didn't. I wasn't that big of a fan. It was as chewy as nougat is which I think is kind of weird for a cookie.

Sixth was the chocolate mousse which I thought was the best part of the night. The chocolate wasn't overly sweet, it was actually pretty perfect for me. Satisfied my sweet tooth but didn't make me reach for the water cup. 

Seventh were the breadsticks. It's actually the first time i've ever had those thin hard crunchy breadsticks, like you see in italian restaurants on television all the time. I thought the flavor was great and it was even better when you dipped it in the sauce. 

Service: GREAT. We were seated promptly at our reservation time. We were asked if we wanted to hang our coats up in the closet. The waiter was very knowledgeable and was able to give me recommendations for drinks and for the main entree. Our waters were constantly refilled and when we got up to go to the bathroom, our napkins were refolded for us. 

Unfortunately, I've had great service and great food at other restaurants so Meh is as good as this review is going to get. 

I would give this restaurant another try because supposedly they have a different menu daily so maybe different dishes will prompt me to give a better review. But I don't think I'll be coming here unless my boyfriend's family wants to give this place another try.
author: Karen C.

description: A decent Italian restaurant that seems to specialize in middle Italian cuisine. I tried the salami plate, ravioli with veal and cabbage, and the citrus gelato with kumquat.  The salami was an overwhelming plate of different types of dried meats from different animals and prepared differently too. Overall, it was interesting but a little heavy for me. The pasta was decent with the sweet and salty taste bringing out the flavors well. The gelato was actually very light and refreshing. It was a good restaurant but my bias towards tomato-based Italian left me feeling a bit bloated and heavy.
author: Wesley H.

description:
Went to celebrate my friend's 26th wedding anniversary. Indicated this during reservation. They received a greeting card on the table. Nice! 

Great food, atmosphere and vibe! Complimentary bread sticks with tapenade & freshly baked bread w/ butter. Wines: proseco & red Italian wine. Starter: salumi misti and raviora pasta. Entrees: duck, short rib, pork shoulder & paperdelle. Dessert: 3 dessert combo with sabaglione. Portions were generous and all delicious. Ended meal with complimentary small dark chocolates & nougats and heavenly meringue cookies w/ hazelnuts (took some home & still great the next day). Price was also very reasonable ~$200. 

Now, I know why many people like this resto.  Will certainly go back.
author: Mario S.

description:
The food here is really wonderful.  Tapas with an unbelievable number.
Everything was perfect.  We sat at the bar and watched them making the dishes.  Impressive wine by the glass.  I thought the prices were very reasonable.  No whiskey for this old silver bullet man.
The sacrifice to wine was well worth it, however.
Great little plates, happy and upbeat.
Fun place!
author: Bob M.

description: I had theCoujette - Occitaine Potato Gnocchi, Liberty Farm Duck Ragu, Roasted Cherries. It was amazing. It has been months since I ate there but I still remember how the sweet/sour cherries cut the rich duck fat texture. The Gnocchi was cooked perfectly. Barbacco next door is also a great place to check out. Short but sweet review for this awesome ristorante/ enoteca.
author: Billy C.
