description: Great service! Veal tartar was good but I didn't like the hazelnuts in it ... The ambience of the place is nice and they had a pretty extensive menu. I would come back to try out more items.
author: Benny C.

description:
Atmospher is great, food is sub par

I had the Gnocchi and parpadelle with short ribs. It was kind of bland and needed salt and something else. The sauce was more brothy than creamy and the gnocchi were far from pillowy. The appetizers I had were the Veal (delicious) and burrata which was too creamy, more or a spreadable consistency which is not how it's supposed to be. 

I thought it was a little tacky when the waiter served us our check before our dessert. 

I won't be coming back.
author: A.L. S.

description: One of my favorite go-to places when I'm visiting San Francisco. I'm always pleased with the wine list and the food. Even if I don't have time to have dinner, I'll always snag a pasta dish at the bar -- just too delicious to pass up. Favorites: Nickel and Nickel on the wine list; the rabbit agnolotti and the ravioli.
author: Ralph D.

description:
Dear Alberto, Owner of Perbacco (?),

I meant every word I said when I complimented your food and your awesome waiter, Armando. Kudos to the entire wait staff as well, I'm sorry I didn't catch everyone's name.

Again, veal agnolotti was to die for. With every bite oozed creamy, gooey goodness mix of veal and cheese. Cabbage was a great compliment too!

My boyfriend told me I went a little overboard with the compliments but who cares! I blame the wine but the food was that good!

And your staff as well : )

We will be back!

Best,

Tina
author: T L.

description:
What we liked about Perbacco:
1.  Service was very good.
2.  Food was great (the bread sticks and Italian salsa verde were excellent!  The salumi platter was very good, short rib w/ribbon pasta was delicous, short rib ravioli was okay.

What we didn't like about Perbacco:
1.  Tables are very close, almost too close, where you feel like you're dining with the person next to you.

Overall, great dining experience.
author: Bio G.

description:
I can't say one bad thing about Perbacco. They have ALWAYS satisfied my wine craving on the Thursday... or Monday (depending on the week) - Service is always great and they have the best little homemade bread sticks with garlic aoili sauce to snack on! 

The food is great! I have eaten lunch here and my beet salad with goat cheese was fantastic - 

They have a great wine list and no, it is not the cheapest, but if you want to step inside somewhere classy and fun, Perbacco is for you!
author: Kelly B.

description: This place has unbelievably yummy Italian food.  The pasta is amazing and a little more modern vs traditional Italian food.  As an appetizer we order fried olives.  I've never experience that before.  It was very flavorful.  Looking forward to trying some other dishes...definately going back.
author: Samantha S.

description: I came here for a work dinner.  Thinking back, I'm guessing I have fonder thoughts of this place than was really the case, since we had such a great time joking and laughing.  In all honesty, I don't remember much about the meal except that I ordered duck and it was cooked perfectly.  I don't really remember our appetizers and I don't remember the drinks either.  Everyone seemed to enjoy their food though, but I know that we all enjoyed each other's company and the staff let us sit back and enjoy ourselves without being pushy or anything.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Valentines Day - Wow what a wonderful experience. 
My husband and I were spending the day in SF, viewing an exhibit at the Contemporary Jewish Museum, so we had decided to have lunch at Perbacco.  
They do have a wonderful selection of wines by the glass.  After making our menu choices we selected our wines, sat back and enjoyed ourselves.  We were lucky to get a seat though.  We arrived just after the restaurant opened and it filled very quickly.
My husband ordered the meatballs and I had the potato gnocchi with rabbit.  Both were excellent.
Food + wine = $70.
Service was attentive, friendly and helpful.  Surroundings were very attractive.  We will return.
author: Carol H.

description:
One of the best places I've been in terms of food, service, & ambiance combined.

We got the Salumi Misti, and a couple of pasta courses for appetizers. They were all very well made and delicious! I especially liked how one of the men working there would come give us a blurb about what we were eating, how it was prepared, etc. for some dishes. For my main course, I chose another pasta (I forgot the name, but it was light green and spirally). So delicious! I would say that dessert was the best part though - I had the burnt caramel gelato with the TAHITIAN VANILLA SEA SALT. Omg, I didn't know that gelato could taste so good!! It made me want to buy my own container of sea salt so that I could sprinkle it onto my ice cream at home.

Service was of course, superb. We couldn't finish our main courses since we ordered so many appetizers, but they were not offended at all to have to pack our food up for us. My green spirally pasta still tasted great the next day!
author: Melody L.

description:
Extremely pleasing experience (party of two).

Our server Iryna - and her team - were extremely helpful without being insincere - almost like a guide and friend to navigate the wonderful menu and to suggest wine pairings.

Food (appetizer, entree and dessert) was fantastic
Drinks were great (martini's, red wine and dessert wine)
Environment and pace of the meal was terrific
Even prices quite good, too!

Embarcadero garage 1 block as well

Unquestionably, will be back - and recommend to friends (and strangers!)
author: B H.

description: Came here last night for the first time. The Barbacco a couple of doors away threw me for a moment, thinking I had written the wrong name down, but we figured out our mistake and went where we were supposed to go. Perbacco has a cool vibe as you walk in. The bar has a brick wall behind it and it is pretty dramatic. We walked past the bar and into the dining room. It is open and spacious. You can see the kitchen in the back of the room. We started with a delicious appetizer, then moved into a gnocchi dish along with the sea bass. Oh, my god!!! SO good!!! They have a thorough wine selection. The bottle we wanted was unavailable, but our lovely waitress, Jaime, brought us a similar one that we enjoyed. Our dessert, the ugly cookies, was a great way to end our meal. Not too heavy. It was my birthday, and they had written Happy Birthday on our dessert plate. Classy. We will definitely be back.
author: Robin A.

description:
I've been here several times for lunch and once for dinner.  Each time I've been, the service has been impeccable - knowledgeable and friendly, not stuffy at all.

Also, more importantly to me, the food has been consistently good.  I don't think I've ever ordered any dish I didn't like.  My favorites out of those I've ordered, though, are the tajarin (tagliatelle), the heirloom tomato salad and the brussels sprouts side dish.  Also, I wouldn't necessarily think that the desserts would be anything special (I'm not sure why), but I have tried their desserts as well and they are equally as good (especially the chocolate cake and the burnt caramel gelato).
author: B. Y.

description:
we had a 6:30 reservation on a tuesday night. the restaurant was bustling but we were seated right away. you're immediately presented with a few stale breadsticks and what the server called salsa verde. warning: the dipping concoction has oil floating on top and going from dish to mouth i shotgunned the front of my shirt with oil. luckily the lights were pretty dim...

the wine list is pretty lengthy with somewhat reasonable markups but as is usually the case we chose to byob, in this case a '11 papapietro perry pommard clone otherwise known as "heaven in a bottle". delicious. corkage was $20.

i had the vitello tonnato, split an order of agnolotti dal plin, brasato and finished up with  hazelnut cookies. all the dishes were some mighty fine eating. the sauce with the veal was nice and salty, tasting of the sea. the pasta was cooked perfectly with a great tasting roasted meat sauce. the short rib was super tender with a very complimentary  sweet corn polenta. even the cookies were good although a little too sweet. 

service was straight forward and competent. the pace of the meal was uneven. at around 7:30 there was a large influx of diners and i'm sure the kitchen got slammed. while we were waiting for our entrees the waiter came over and told us they would be coming shortly. that kind of attention is very much appreciated.

sf dining vignette:

while we were ordering dessert the booth behind us changed over. what was an older family of four were replaced, initially by three totally wasted twenty somethings. a guy with two female companions. the heavyset gal facing me had a flushed face and was squinting through narrow slits, like she was taking an eye exam and having a hard time deciphering the letters. soon, she yelled out to another table, waving. i think she said "dfkdf idiifif jnasjffhhf ha ha ha dsfdsff tretety!" but i'm not sure. the threesome were quickly joined by another couple. the new woman, a thin dishwater blonde was so drunk her eyes were crossing. so the LOUD conversation went along the lines of:

"2hsdf7f hhhsppsa ds;sd;sd; HA HA HA ldffl;ffk" said gal 1.

"dhfdhdfsh jkljkljkl fghdfkf HA HA HA HA HA HA  ddsjsdjkdsjkl" replied gal 2.

and so on...

as i was signing our check the portly gal asked the waiter "so what kind of pinot have you got?". our waiter managed a feeble smile and asked "so... how much do you want to spend?" and was confronted with a blank stare...

i gave the server an additional 10%.

buona notte.
author: Sanil S.

description:
Between the three of us we shared a bunch of stuff, but the only things worth noting were a) Beef Short Ribs and b) Salted Vanilla Gelato with Caramel.  The beef short ribs were so tender, juicy and flavorful.  Yum!  The Salted Vanilla Gelato is crack in a bowl.  Seriously, I couldn't get enough of it!!  It was just so perfect the mix of sweet and salty. 

Although we didn't have a bad dining experience, we didn't exactly have one that made us overwhelming fans.  Perbacco is another restaurant in the FD, a bunch of suits, blah blah blah.  I prefer their sister restaurant next door...much more low key and the food is better.
author: Mao K.

description:
Atmosphere: Beautiful and Sleek
Clientele: Same as the above
Food: Yummy
Service: Good
Reservations: Easy
author: beverly l.

description: Perbacco is a highly recommended restaurant. Good was good, I had the short ribs and my partner had alaskan halibut which was really delicious. They have a huge wine list. Service was great, their whole staff, from receptionist, server, bus person are great! I will go back definitely when I am in town.
author: Maryan F.

description:
DH and I had lunch here.  Service was very attentive.  The waiter showed up whenever we needed something.  DH had the shortribs and I had the grilled chicken with a side of potatoes.  Food was very tasty. 

They also served us thin breadsticks (that was good!) along with the usual free bread.

For dessert, DH had the lemon semifredde (lemon mousse) and I had the chocolate torte.  The lemon semifredde was very tart but tasty.  Torte wasn't bad either. 

A big plus, they have really clean restrooms!  The restroom reminds me of those in Nordie's ladies' lounge.

Will definitely come back!
author: Wendy H.

description:
The owner helped me choose the wine for the table. Was surprised they did not have more Albas to choose from (only one there is by the glass) and surprised the only Gaja was $130. Overall, good values can be found on the wine menu. 

  Went with my boss today who has a dairy allergy. They were able to adapt to her needs, and made a specialty dish just for her, at the chef's recomendation. The food was total yummers, I would so have the beet salad again. I had the butternut squash rissoto on the recomendation from the server. It was good. Heavy, but good. Made my tummy full, but our table still got the cheese plate, which was even more yummers. In all, lots of yummers to be had. Was my second time there, I would go again, as long as someone else is paying...
author: Danielle L.

description:
Like that saying, "you had me at hello", Perbacco "had me at the fabulous champagne concoction and a sinfully delicious pate"!   This all enjoyed in an incredibly lively spot in the bar.  Gracie and I were seated next to groups of people who were so outgoing and inclusive.  Quite honestly, I could have left the restaurant completely and totally in love.  But, Perbacco was not finished with their seduction.  We were moved to an intimate little corner table and assigned a waiter who was nothing short of phenomenal.  We explained all of the exotic pasta dishes with such aplomb that we felt as if he had lovingly prepared each ravioli, tagliatelle, etc. -- the entire meal was wonderful.  The wine list exhaustive...

Sigh.  My only complaint...I don't live in SF in order to experience this wonderful place again and again.
author: Marie B.

description:
We were in Alba, Italy (Piemonte wine region) on vacation this spring, and somebody (a NZ guy also there on vacation) we met at a local restaurant recommended this place when we told him we live in the SF Bay Area.

The cuisine is truly authentic Piemonte style, and their wine selection is also very broad, mostly Italian.  Great atmosphere, great service, and excellent wine & food.
author: Durif M.

description:
Made it here for early dinner.  The dining room filled up quickly with suits from the financial offices and the noise volume increased as well.  A large table of 10 or so was 3 tables away, yet their conversations carried across to us.

The menu is large and contains Northern Italian staples on it.  The wine list is impressive, with interesting by the glass selections.

We had the salumi platter, burrata salad, gnocchi with gorgonzola, and short ribs.  The food was outstanding, and the freshness of the ingredients impressed us the most.  For dessert, the panna cotta was good, but the plum tart was almost to die for.  

Service throughout the dining room was like a well-oiled machine--very attentive and courteous.  

Excellent dining experience!  Would be difficult on a date, as the tables are quite close together.  Classy, but not romantic.
author: John K.

description:
This was great -- much larger than I was expecting from the street, and definitely a place where you need a reservation!  We came for lunch and were pleasantly surprised.  I took the recommendation of previous Yelpers before me and tried the Langaroli al brasato: pasta filled with braised short ribs, sugo di brasato, topped with grated horseradish.  It was wonderful!  And the best part - not too rich to have as a lunch dish.  

We also had a side of brussel sprouts with caramelized shallots.  I wouldn't normally think to order a side of vegetables with a pasta dish, but I am hard pressed to pass up a wonderful side of brussel sprouts.  These were wonderful.  

We were in a side room off the main dining area which was significantly warmer than the rest of the restaurant, which accounts for part of the reason why I only gave this place 4 stars.  The other being that the service was a bit slow, and they appeared to be a bit understaffed for the bustling lunch crowd.  Other than that, the food was excellent!
author: Courtney S.

description:
My never-ending quest to find an Italian restaurant comparable to Delfina finally led me to the entrance of Perbacco (read: a very nice gentleman finally offered to take me there) - one of Bauer's 100 best of the bay, and generally known to have a reputation for delicious, sophisticated Italian in the City. Equipped with 7x7's "Big Eat SF" list (not to mention an appetite big enough to eat the world), and having researched their signature dishes, I was ready to tackle Perbacco head-on. 

I'm not going to lie, I definitely went into the night with certain expectations of how everything should play out. And, in terms of atmosphere, those expectations were filled as soon as I walked in the door. The lively, modern, refined atmosphere instantly appealed to my "city chic" preferences. And, the open kitchen not only let me catch a glimpse of what was going on behind the scenes, but let me flirt with the chefs (with my eyes of course!) on my way down to the restrooms. Unfortunately, I don't think they noticed...

The service was on point as well - there when we needed it, helpful in answering our numerous questions, friendly, even complete with a sommelier to help us find our way through their extensive list. No complaints.

But, as I always say in these reviews, my bottom line is the food, and unfortunately the word that comes to mind when I think of Perbacco's menu is "inconsistent."  I feel that one of the pitfalls of offering such an extensive menu is that some dishes are simply not going to be at the same level as others. Such was the case at Perbacco; while their specialties certainly deserved their rave reviews, the rest of our meal left me wanting more. 

**Exception: the bread sticks were buttery, perfectly crispy, and downright dangerous. Be warned that they serve bread sticks AND bread, so it's easy to fill up before the main course has even arrived!

As for appetizers, the SALUMI MISTI offered a variety of meat selections in sizable portions, however, it wasn't mind-blowing. Let's not kid ourselves here - it's sliced meat on a plate. Sure it's delicious, but it doesn't take a premier restaurant to serve it (and, I'm a bit spoiled by having Lucca down the street from my house). And, while the VEAL TRIPE was perfectly cooked, the composition of the dish was a bit uninspired and lacked seasoning. 

Since, as I said, I was ready to eat the world, we tackled 3 pastas - the AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN, the TAJARIN, and the RABATON. There was nothing especially memorable about the latter 2 - both were executed well, but I wasn't impressed by the flavors. When I eat ricotta gnocchi, I want to think I'm eating a cloud, and the Rabaton fell short of cloudliness. However, the Agnolotti (a dish they are known for) was everything I could've wanted and more. As soon as we dove into that dish, our lively conversation came to a dead silence - there was no room for words in the face of that rich, complex flavor. This was one of the top 5 pasta dishes I've had in the City, and if I was ever to go back, would be the only thing I'd need to order to feel completely satisfied. 

With so many choices on the menu, I'm sure everyone can find something that makes their heart sing. However, for me, I want any and every selection I make to inspire me to jump on a table and start declaring my enduring love (don't worry, it's only happened 2-3 times). While my overall experience was solid, my quest to find sensational Italian food in San Francisco must continue.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
Our office Christmas party was off the meat rack. Let me tell you why.

My boss had this crazy idea to do our annual White Elephant exchange at the restaurant. I was hesitant because that game can get really loud; not to mention potentially lasting for several hours. Our entire night from beginning to end was amazing starting with the staff who were all super accommodating with everything from where to put our unopened presents to discarding our leftover wrapping paper to extra bags for take-home gifts. Rock stars they are -- totally on the ball making sure we were comfortable and taken care of the entire time. 

I'm kinda upset about something though. Nobody warned me that I would be fist-pumping during my meal. It started out a slow fist-pump but gradually sped up with each dish put in front of my face. 

Not to be confused by the Sanrio character Pochacco (for all the little asian girls out there), Perbacco is one of my new favorite restaurants just because how can you reject something that loves you so much? 

And trust me, I'm totally feelin' the love...
author: Jen Y.

description:
the food and wine were just as amazing (pork sugo, risotto, burrata, and newly discovered barbaresco wine, mMm).

the service - was MEGA-amazing.

from the kitchen - who made a brand new set of entrees for the entire table when momma di decided to take J for a nap-ride - and even threw in extra desserts!

to the valet staff - who were so accommodating of bringing the car over to me so i could take J for a sleep spin.

to the hostess - who sat us strategically in a place with easy access to open walkways and spacious booth cushions so baby could bounce around.

it is definitely service like this that makes a restaurant not just a place to fill your tummy, but a place to come back to and build a relationship with. 

thank you for realizing that parents are people too - who like to eat!! momma di approved! :D
author: Diana L.

description: Hallinan & Carmignani love to go large at Perbacco...chef's table every time, life is good.
author: Brendan H.

description: Came here on Black Friday with my boyfriend and had a delicious dinner. Both my boyfriend and I both agreed that this is our new favorite pasta place. Great service, great food, great wine. We will hopefully be returning soon!
author: Kate T.

description: Fabulous service from host to waitress to busboy. Food was very refined and flavors were simple and delicious. Each ingredient was highlighted in its preparation. Very vegetarian friendly.
author: Komal P.

description:
Excellent food.  We had the roasted beets, brussels sprouts, strawberry arugula salad, pappardelle, pesce crudo.  Everything was fresh, delicately flavored, and presented beautifully.

This was certainly a fine dining experience.  We were in jeans. but among the few. People around us looked lovely in their button downs, dresses and jackets.  

Our main server was wonderful-attentive but not overbearing. His associates were not as graceful but certainly doing their jobs of refilling our waters and clearing our plates. I thought the host could have been a bit more welcoming, but no major complaints.  

Why not five stars:  

The place has great lighting, and is certainly classy with tables spaced apart sufficiently.  But it didn't win me over in decor and overall feel. It has a corporate feel to it, like it would be great for power lunches...which it probably is.  Situated in the financial district this could hardly be more appropriate. Alas, that is my reason.  

But the food is fabulous.
author: Erika S.

description: Great service.  Menu was varied and different. Salami was authentic and smoked trout was a decent appetizer. Pasta was below expectations. Pappardelle with short rib ragout  lacked imagination, sauce was bland. Stracci with chanterelle was good but not outstanding. Again sauce lacked imagination but pasta quality was excellent. Hazelnut cookies were outstanding.  Had a 1986 Nebbiolo that was interesting. If you are looking for top end Italian place, this will disappoint but if you are looking for good Italian food in the financial district you will likely enjoy.
author: Bill U.

description: Came to Perbacco for lunch with a few of my co-workers. Much more of a fan of Perbacco than its sister restaurant, Barbacco. The set up is interesting. When you walk in, the restaurant looks somewhat small, but it opens out into a large dining room in the back. I like the decor...pretty simple and clean. The homemade breadsticks with pesto are a delicious little snack while you're waiting to order. I ordered the roasted chicken with polenta, and it was very good. It had a lot of mushrooms in it (a little too many for my taste), which is why I wouldn't say it's fantastic. Next time, I'll order it without the mushrooms. The service was great! I would look away for two seconds and turn around and my iced tea would be refilled. The food literally came out in five to ten minutes. They were really on top of their game!
author: Amanda R.

description:
The food is amazing almost like home made 
The salads always taste great. The pastas alway fresh and excellent my favorite is pan seared quail ,The wine selection is very extensive. I usually do not order dessert but at Perbacco I always do. YUMMY
 I always walk out of the place very happy 
THANKS YOU UMBERTO alway a class act
author: Nima J.

description: Great place for a business lunch.  Clean, upscale atmosphere, great menu selection, good service, decent prices.
author: Poppy B.

description: I've been here twice for lunch.  Both times, my job footed the bill so I can't really comment on the value of the place. I can tell you that they have excellent food, excellent service and an excellent location.  The hangar steak with mushrooms is beef heaven.  The dessert I inhaled has a much fancier name, but lets just call it chocolate cake with meringue.  It's one of the best desserts I've had in a while.  The sheer decadence of it gave me a head rush when I stood up.  Damn, that was good.
author: Corey V.

description:
I wasn't all that impressed with the service at Perbacco, nor was I impressed with the drinks. The food, meh, it was alright. The salami plate was good but I could have gone without the description, "this was cured in lard- this one was also cured in lard, and this one was cured in lard with rosemary"... kind of lost my appetite although its impressive with the servers knowledge of the cured meat process. 
I had the weakest martini (and smallest for that matter) and the olives were terrible. My friend had a Manhattan (requested rocks)- of course it came up, and in the same little glass that resembled a proper shot glass. 
I would give this place another try if I wasn't on a budget- but for me- it wasn't worth the money; which is sad because I didn't even pay!
author: Janell D.

description:
Nice space, good food, great atmosphere, good wines.

Came here on a business dinner:

The asparagus salad appetizer was amazing, I highly recommend it.
The strawberries and balsamic was also pretty good
I had a quail entrée stuffed with foie gras that was pretty delicious as well. 

Service was good, I don't think you can go wrong with Perbacco.
author: Eric L.

description:
I had been to Perbacco a couple of years ago for lunch and wasn't terribly impressed. It wasn't that it was horrible, it just wasn't memorable enough at the time for me to really care enough to go again. 

As time passed and all my friends and coworkers raved about Perbacco time and time again, I decided it was time to give it another go. I am SO glad that I went back again because my experience was simply lovely. 

The brussel sprouts were fantastic; the beets were scrumptious and the butternut squash ravioli's were the probably the best I've had. They were drizzled with a butter sage sauce and the squash was so creamy. I would go back JUST for that dish. 

Since it was my mother's birthday we decided it a dessert was definitely in order. The olive oil chocolate cake/mousse, even though I was slightly skeptical (olive oil?), was unbelievably good. We split one but quite honestly I wanted the whole damn thing to myself! 

I'm so pleased that Perbacco is right around the corner from my work. This is definitely going to be my go-to spot for special occasion lunches in the future.
author: Julia N.

description:
This place is amazing.  Rounding out to one of the best lunches I've ever had, my experience consisted of 3 appetizers, a pasta main dish, and cafe latte.  

Located conveniently 5 minutes away from my work, Perbacco surpassed my really high expectations.  With classy, yet modern decor inside, and hip, knowledgeable, yet, not pretentious wait staff, I can see this being one of my favorite Italian spots to go to.

Starting off with a slow roasted veal carpaccio in a lemon/tuna sauce, I was impressed right off the bat.  Not being a huge fan of veal or capers in general, I was pleasantly surprised by how tender and flavorful (without the typical vealish gamey taste) this dish was and how well it went with the sauce.

Fried rock shrimp was the next order of business, where there wasn't too much batter, or too little shrimp with each bite.  This also came in a lemon sauce (aioli) as well as some other fried bits.  Definitely couldn't complain about this dish.

The seared squid on a bed of arugula was the last appetizer that was demolished.  I especially enjoyed how the arugula nor the salted squid overpowered the other.  There was a very delicate balance in this dish that made it juuuuuuust right.

For my main, I had the langaroli with braised short rib.  This was a decision I had my server make for me when deciding between this, the tagliatelle and the parpadelle (all of which I'm convinced are amazing).  She mentioned that it was new on the menu and that it was a good choice, so I went with it.  In the end, who can really complain about pasta filled with braised short rib.  There were some bites that may have bordered on being too salty, but the succulence of the short rib brought it all back.  Of course, the pasta (smaller ravioli like) was perfectly al dente, and the portion was just right....assuming there is a correct portion after eating 3 appetizers.

To top it off, I had to deny the creme fraiche panna cotta and settle for a latte, as I still needed to be functional at work.  And, to one up themselves again, the latte came with extra foam and milk if we desired.  WHO DOES THIS?!

Perbacco, you've earned a special place in my stomach.
author: Jeff N.

description:
The breadsticks and salumi misti plate were enough to give this place five deserving stars.

But the goodness doesn't stop there.  The posh sister to Barbacco next door (http://www.yelp.com/biz/barbacco-san-francisco#hrid:KQWnDd9VEnGb6QZQhbcyKw), it was definitely less cacophonous, more refined, less family-style small plates, more white tablecloth and fine china.  

Both are great, in their own way. 

Perbacco's breadsticks are oh so addictive.  It's crunchy and greasy, and would definitely cause a dent in your strict diet.  But who cares.  Goes really well with everything on the salumi misti plate, from the cured pancetta, cheese and lardo.  

For the entree I had the pork shoulder, slow roasted and tender.  The serving was generous and, I'm no wine connoisseur but the server's recommendation of a glass of 2010 Kerner (GENEROUS pour!) was probably the best that I could've asked for, as a pairing. 

Definitely on the list as my go-to Italian.
author: Ange L.

description:
"By Bacchus"
Loved the 12 cooks in the kitchen
Excellent Northern & Nova-Italian cuisine
Fantastic burrata pesto appetizer
Great house bread
Delish veal loin w/squash & veggies
Tasty parpadelle w/shreds of short ribs
Nice wines by glass; wine list has expensive Italian selections
Lots of Italian cheeses
Gelati, a little salty?
Popular bar scene
Efficient food service
Nice bathrooms
Negative: asked for Pelligrino; got other type of sparkling water
Negative: macchiato was so-so
author: Rosquete B.

description:
The boyfriend was working in SF for the week and I had class at the UCB Extension building near the Embarcadero BART. We decided to have a dinner date on a Wednesday before I headed to my 6:30pm class and I chose this place for its proximity to the BART station. We planned to meet at 5; I arrived at 4:45pm. I was told by the hostess that they did not start dinner seating until 5:30. The hostess politely inquired if I were looking for Barbacco, which, for its convincingly similar name, must be a frequent source of mix-ups. I was not; and decided to grab a bar table in the corner near the front window to wait for my bf to arrive. It was pretty empty around 5pm but I am glad I snagged that table when I did, because the FiDi after-work crowd filtered in soon after. The bf arrived at 5:15; by 5:30, the entire bar area was crowded to the point of an almost-uncomfortable capacity. 

We asked for menus so that we could choose our main dishes and put in our orders so that we could start our dinners as soon as possible. The menus for the night had not even finished printing yet, but our waitress was kind enough to bring them over as soon as they were ready, around 5:25. We ordered our mains and decided to start with the salumi plate. The salumi plate was all that it is hyped up to be in these reviews and more - the fatty selections were incredibly flavorful and decadent. 

I had the duck breast and the bf had the rabbit. These were both presented on our plates in two distinct preparations, which was refreshing as not only did it showcase the chef's abilities, but also we were able to experience our duck and rabbit in more than one way each. This was a refreshing take, as it was more interesting to my palate to be able to taste my duck in different textures and tastes that were overall complementary to each other. 

The wine list is extensive and solid. I was pleased to discover a sizeable selection of rieslings. I had a very good $12 glass of riesling, but the name of it escapes me. My bf had a bottled anchor steam. Perbacco does not have any beers on tap, unfortunately. 

Our impromptu dinner date meal cost us about $90 before tip. Definitely not a place to frequent on a regular basis, but definitely nice for an after-work pick-me-up or a celebration once in awhile.

Pros:
-Very solid and satisfying Italian main dishes 
-Beyond decadent salumi plate
-Extensive wine list
-Helpful and attentive waitress (despite the unyielding crowd)
-Proximity to Embarcadero BART

Cons:
-Very, very loud - the acoustics in the restaurant are not suited for comfortable across-the-table talking (not suitable for a first date, for sure!)
-The elbowing FiDi after-work crowd 
-Not being able to get dinner seating until 5:30 (I would appreciate being able to sit by 5pm for dinner)
author: Megan L.

description:
Nom nom... This place was the site of a delish solo business dinner while in the City. It was within a couple blocks of my Financial District hotel and it got much better reviews from you all :)

When I'm by myself I try to dine at the bar so as not to look too freaky. Worked well here... Had my spot right away despite a long wait for tables. 10 mins later and I have my first glass of Pinot blanc and asparagus and radish salad. Simple and delish.

I wasn't too hungry so I just ordered a pasta for my main course. I will not try to pronounce the name of this little gem. It was smallish raviolis with braised short ribs, topped with brown butter sauce and shaved horseradish. Should have ordered larger size since I scarfed this plate down!

Anyway, great food in the financial district.  Lots of well tailored suits and flowing proseco :)
author: Ashley L.

description:
Came here in a huge rush with Patricia P solely to try #18 on the Big Eat SF List, which is the Salumi Plate.  

We were initially going to try and hit up 3 items/places on the list that are all within close proximity to my office (Alfreds, Perbacco, and Tadich), but only made it to Perbacco and Tadich Grill.  I love the literal meaning of Perbacco, which is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments :)

I enjoyed the ambiance of Perbacco.  We found two seats at the bar right when we walked in and everything on everyone else's plates looked delightful, tasty, and delicious.  I told the bartender we didn't even need to look at a menu since we were in a hurry and knew exactly what we were getting, but I definitely went straight home that evening and took a look at it.  The salumi plate was pretty good. Lots of fatty looking meats that tasted wonderful.  There was one item in a small ramekin in the middle, which I do not recommend; it looked like and reminded me of the food we used to feed my cat back in the day.  It was even a special kind of cat food since she was always sick. 

I would love to come back for dinner one night to try out all the amazing looking pasta dishes, pork rib, duck, or the meat plate.  Oh, and I can't forget about the awesome, warm bread that was drenched in butter. Mmmm. I can't wait to come back for more of that!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite SF restaurants, and one that has never disappointed after several trips.  It's one of the few places in the city where even though I'm spending $$$, I come away happy to have paid the price.  Highlights:

-homemade salumi and pasta
-foie gras terrine
-delicate, refreshing desserts
-unique wine list with very helpful wine director
-some of owners around
author: Pei L.

description: Recently went here with the family over the weekend and it was very good! We started off with the cured meats and root vegetable appetizers and I would have to actually pick the vegetables over the cured meats. The cured meats i think needed a bit more flavor to it, but the vegetables had a nice pickling taste to it that was very good! I ordered the duck breast and that was very tender and flavorful. It came with brussell sprouts, which I am not a fan of, but these were so tasty. Usually they get a bad rap for a reason, but if you decide to get the duck here, the brussell sprouts were pretty freaking awesome lol. I had a taste of the pork shoulder and all I can say is WOW. The meat was tender and flavorful with a nice dark color of carmelization. I def would recommend this place if you're in the mood for some nice rustic food in SF.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Dining at Perbacco was in the pipeline since Piccolina P.  highly recommended it to me only a couple of weeks ago. What most interested me in this establishment is that they serve typical dishes from Piemonte  (my home region in Italy) but with a Californian touch.  Pointless to say that I had great expectations (and some fears too).

As a great start, we got homemade grissini with a typical flavourful parsley-based green dip (Bagna Verde) that Piemontesi normally use as sauce for veal tongue or boiled veal meat.

The menu itself is rather interesting: I particularly like the possibility of combining two or three different pasta dishes (I wish more Italian restaurants offered such a possibility, since I often have hard times in deciding which promising homemade pasta to pick).  No chance I could have missed this heavenly possibility. After a good looking and flavourful appetizer with raw yellowtail, shaved porcini and celery, our main choice fell upon the following pasta trio:

1- herb Maltagliati with lamb ragu', peas, ricotta di pecora and mint: excellent pasta, overkilling sauce with too much on it. I honestly find ricotta and lamb (despite its nicely melting-in-mouth texture, by the way) a rather weird combination, but I liked the mint (exactly the opposite as my gf ...);

2-agnolotti al coniglio with vermouth based sauce and fruit mustard:
those agnolotti were a real pasta masterpiece and the sauce was original, even though the reduction didn't fully kill the alcoholic taste. Forgivable sin, though, that didn't affect too much the marvellous resulting dish.

 3- tajarin (typical Piedmontese taglierini) with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini: if you wonder  why letting the sugo cook for 5 hours, this dish gives you a convincing answer. What a fantastic taste! Again, another delicious pasta.

Desserts were good (but not exceptional) and they came in huge portions:  
1- buttermilk panna cotta with a lemonish taste, raspberries and a touch of fruity granita;
2- ricotta mousse, a lemonish cake (I can't recall the name) and Lambrusco marinated strawberries. 

Good wines and beers (I got a Piedmontese Menabrea) too.

Perbacco offers a seriously good deal considering both quality and quantity (the real surprise, in my opinion) for the price you pay.  Thanks Piccolina P.: this place really deserves a visit (or two or three ...).  

Pasta lovers, here you can find "pane per i vostri denti" (literally: "bread for your teeth").

4.5 stars.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Jesus fucking christ!  Just come here and eat and be happy.

The salumi plate is a must.  They make their own sausages and other meaty goodness and you can try them all on one plate.  Their breadsticks were also extremely light and delicious.

I loved the veal carpaccio, although I'm glad there were 4 of us 'cause I think it was a bit on the oily side and I might not have liked it as much if I had to eat too much of it.

If you like fish/seafood, their octopus is pretty good, but not my favorite.  Their hamachi crudo is amazing.  The fish just melts in your mouth and it's like every tastebud is coated with flavor.

Their veal was a great entrée and could not have been cooked more perfectly.  Their duck was also very good, but not as memorable.

The scallops -- god the scallops -- were just great.  Nice sear on the outside and soft and tasty in the middle.  I think I'd kill for those scallops.

They have a pretty extensive wine list and it's a great way to experience the meal, but definitely not what I took away with me.
author: Jason K.

description:
first, i want to say that this place is perfect for dinner right before heading to the Punchline for a comedy show. it's only about a block or so away. so Guys, (nudge, nudge) make a reservation for Perbacco and then get tickets for some stand-up comedy and you've got yourself a pretty damn good date. you are so very welcome for planning out your next courtship! 

as a chinese, it's always a plus when you find yourself with free things. at Perbacco you not only get the standard bread with dinner, but you also get breadsticks. already winning, Perbacco! haha. 

we got the papardelle with short rib ragu which was as good as a well made fresh pasta could be. nothing stand out, but definitely had an appreciated simplicity. we also had the short rib entree and the scallop entree. both were cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor. 

definitely a place to return to.
author: Regina C.

description:
Solid all-around experience. I'd normally post 3 stars, but everyone else enjoyed their dish so much that I have to up it to 4.

We had a group of 9 for two of our friends' bday celebration. Great menu selection, even a special menu for some truffle event. 

Atmosphere/Location: 
Excellent seating areas, great looking bar. Too many people standing around the entrance made it difficult to walk through. 
Service:
Our server was good although missing at times. When we initially sat down we had some questions on the menu, but she as busy provided good service to other tables, so when itwas our turn, we got her undivided attention.  Our food came out promptly.
Food:
Everyone gushed about how delicious their plates were, from the earthy delicious truffle ricotta gnocchi, the did i realy just eat tongue and feet massacrin plate, to the seasonally popularbutternut squash ravioli. I had th papperdelle with a short rib ragout and a side of the beans.  I loved the beans... spicy kick, just enough bacon to give the dish an edge.  I was not a fan of the paperdelle dish.  It was missing something.  There was a bit too much freshly grated horserdish, and not a sweet element to counterbalance. The flavor scale was sharply on the bitter side... perhaps some broccoli or another kind of vegetable would have calmed it down.  The pasta and short ribs were delicious, it's just too bad that the horseradish overpowered the entire dish.
We all had dessert. Everyone loved what they ordered, but the olive oil chcolate cake and apple tart stood out.
Drinks:
Great wine list, but be ready to break the bank.  The cheapest option for CabSauv was 49. They had some goodies ont he list too, such as an Opus One. I stayed in the mixed drinks section and enjoyed a cucmber lemon concoction as was overpowered by excessive mint use on the mojito.

All in all, 4 stars. I'm not sure if I would come back because the prices and selection of other restys in SF, but I would recommend it to anyone looking for some good vitlins.
author: Matt H.

description:
-1star for forgetting my take out.

I love love love the atmosphere here. it reminds me a little of boulevard, always bustling and happening, clean and classy.

The food was great, i love that they have an option to do a tasting of their pasta's, great for people like me who can never make up their minds when an amazing menu is put in front of you.

I wasn't very hungry when i went, and even so, enjoyed the food very much. They service was great as well, very attentive BUT  a little bit rushed, and as a result the food that i had put aside to take home was misplaced and not given to me. - they lose ONE STAR for that b/c i was really looking forward to my leftovers the next day. - aside from that everything was great, i will definitely be back, i am excited to see some new pasta dishes on the menu tho.
author: Shadi N.

description: The moment I walked in, I said to myself, "Self, I've never smelled anything so good." And the meal paid off, in spades.  The number 1 item we had was the veal appetizer with the tuna sauce.  The pappardelle with short rib ragù and grated horseradish was out of this world.  Excellent wine list, too!  I'll be back next time I'm in SF.
author: warren b.

description:
reservations are a must. small place, with lots of businesses nearby = tough to get in during lunch. the menu is very unique and the best part - housemade pasta! so of course, i had to get the papperdelle - wide ribbon pasta, with braised short ribs. it was sooo good that i cleaned my plate.

the waitress was very attentive and knowledgeable about the menu which is helpful especially if i'm trying to decide between several dishes. while lots of folks come in for a business lunch, i would be careful of talking business at the table as the seating is quite close to each other.
author: Selena H.

description: My first restaurant in San Francisco, and still one of my top favorites. I am always pleased with whatever I order. The service is always great.
author: Karina L.

description:
At 5pm we arrived towards the beginning of dinner service to find great service and really creative, tasty food. 
The only negative was our seat. Maybe I am weird but when I can hear the conversation two tables down I think we all need a little more space. Not a big deal but next time  will ask for a corner seat.
author: Chad C.

description:
everything is good here. the service is very good. 

my food recommendations are as follows. even the ones that i say "SKIP" were good - just not good enough for me to order again.

apps
- pesce crudo - SKIP. just okay.
- crab cakes - YES. you will want a whole one for yourself (1 per order).

pasta
- tajarin - SKIP. overrated. didn't look that great and the tastes didn't exceed the appearances.
- lobster tortelli - YES. i would come back and order an entree size of this dish.
- spinach & ricotta gnocchi - good. subtle, delicate.

entrees
- bass - very good. 
- short ribs - very good.
- scallops - good, but not enough for the price (~$28 for just 3 scallops plus sauce). i know this is typical, but this is one of the least bangs for your buck.

dessert
- panna cotta - okay.
- warm brown sugar cake - YES. didn't like the wine-poached pears but the warm cake with walnut gelato was brilliant. a drier type of cake, so not too heavy.
- ugly but good cookies - overrated. these were more like meringues. i ordered these because there was a lot of good word on the street[s of yelp], but i wouldn't order them again.

conclusion: would definitely go again, especially since now i have a more focused idea of what to order. this place is "solid" but not mindblowing.
author: Rachel Y.

description: Great meal. The food is creative and combines interesting flavors. Really like the fennel and chicory salad. Had a couple wonderful pasta dishes and finished with the sea bass. Dessert was tasty but the gelato portions were a little large. Unfortunately the espresso I ordered was late and mediocre.
author: Pat C.

description:
oh my god this place is amazing.

my parents came to town, so me and the hubs wanted to find a nice place to take them. this was it! 

started with wine and cocktails - I had the Fior D'Arancio which was delicious. My husband and I split the burrata appetizer which was delicious. dad had the veal and enjoyed it. came out reasonably quick, which was nice.

for dinner:
- i had the gnocchi with duck - oh my god, melt in my mouth, this pasta was SO amazingly tasty. i cant say enough good things. and the portion size was good - i didn't have leftovers (but i also didn't eat so much that i'd feel guilty the rest of the week)
- hubs had the scallops. these were also delicious, and huge. really really good, buttery delicious broth.
- dad had the pappardelle. realyl delicious
- mom had the pork loin. it was good. she hadn't been feeling the greatest before we got there, and was a bit overwhelmed and kinda just wanted the polenta that the pork was served on top of to settle her stomach. Well, there wasn't a huge amount and the sauce was covering the plate...but they were kind enough to bring her some extra on the side when we asked, and some bread (and then suddenly she had finished half the pork). really nice of them to do that for us and really quickly.

we didn't do dessert (wanted to get mom home) but it was a great meal and i'm looking forward to coming here again in the future to try some more dishes!
author: Jenn E.

description:
Maybe I haven't had the right dish here yet. I've been here twice and both times I was disappointed. 

I came here for lunch with a couple of friends. The food was acceptable, but my plate of fish looked very lonely. It didn't come with friends of veggies or even sauce. It was just a lone cooked whole fish. I don't know about you, but I can't eat just fish. Maybe it's because I'm Asian, I need my starch and veggies. Maybe I was expected to order them seperately? $23 seems a lot for a plate of lone piece of meat.

And then my firm had this year's holiday party at Perbacco. The choices were steak, chicken, or butternut squach ravioli. I should have gotten the ravioli. I had chicken, and it was pretty well cooked but a piece of grilled chicken is still a piece of grilled chicken. Nothing too fancy. The steak was cooked rare. Too bloody for many people to be able to enjoy. People who got ravioli seemed to enjoy their dish the most. 

The dessert was apple pie - like thing with a dollop of cream. It was mediocre at best.

Maybe I should give it a third chance?
author: Su K.

description:
I love the urban feel of this restaurant. We came here a month ago, and Perbacco was a last minute decision after a girls' night out turned into date night. It was totally worth the change in plans. 

We ordered the dishes recommended by other Yelpers - the salumi misti, the Tajarin, three sides of fingerling potatoes with rosemary and garlic, brown butter brussel sprouts and broccoli di cicco. That was way too many dishes for two people, but nonetheless delicious. The Tajarin dish was my favorite. It's hand cut tagliatelle pasta with 5-hour pork sugo and porcini mushroms. YUM. I wiped out everything. 

The dish pacing was really good, and we didn't feel rushed at all. The only thing I would say about Perbacco was that it can get loud at times and it's hard to have a conversation when the tables are so close together. Other than that, the food was delicious. I'd come back any night for dinner.
author: Amy N.

description: Enjoyed the ambiance. Good service...great cocktails & local wines...ok food. Was excited about the fresh pastas but, wasn't blown away...You have to try the Burnt Caramel, Salted Gelato though. Things were a under-seasoned (my pasta & main course). Overall, my food experience at Perbacco was ok...nothing to write home about. In my opinion, a bit overpriced for food that was just ok.
author: Redd K.

description:
It was my birthday. Reservations made at another place fell through, so we were on a hunt for something in a pinch. Lucky us, we strolled through the doors of Perbacco. 

It was 7 p.m. The host told us they were booked solid. Just as we were about to ask how long we'd wait, a man came over and looked at the host board. He clicked his tongue. "We can seat you right now," he said, and whisked us off.

Happy birthday to me!

As we walked to our cute table for two in the dining room, we walked past the slick and sexy bar and a GIANT flower arrangement near a veritable sea of cheese selections. Oh, yes.

The service was impeccable. The wine menu was intimidating.

Overall, a wonderful experience, though I have to say for such stellar service at the door, luminous ambiance and an attentive waitress, I expected the food to blow me away. Don't get me wrong it was terrific, but it didn't dazzle me the way the rest of the experience did.

All told, this was a fantastic birthday spot. Happy to have found it.
author: Brittney G.

description:
The food was all quite nice and the prices more reasonable than I'd expect.  Skirt steak is a must have, and I also enjoyed the selection of grappa.  I took grappa in place of dessert although I'm sure those are quite fine too.  

At times I was annoyed by the somewhat fussy service.  The bread guy came like 4 times, alternating between two kinds of bread.  And each dish must be filled with them each time he visits, by God, or he will never leave.  Had this man been in charge of refilling my beer I may have been happier with such attention.  I am not a bread hater (as some have accused me, unjustly, of being), but I don't feel it warrants such devotion, particularly in a place where so many more tasty things abound.  

So really, is prostitution occurring here?  The query remains unanswered.  I will return when I am 55 for a full investigation, fear not!
author: Jared L.

description:
Perbacco is always a go-to choice for us -- usually pretty easy to get a reservation (big restaurant), the wine list is super-interesting (unusual Italian wine, you can get by the glass, 1/4 liter, or 1/2 liter or of course by the bottle), the pastas are AMAZING, always house made, always complemented by seasonal local produce.  
It's not exactly cheap but it won't empty your bank account either.
author: Jaina S.

description:
Oh my, I'm so stuffed from lunch, it's not even funny.  Took my friend here for a birthday celebration lunch.  Yum, yum, yum!  First of all, I love the decor of the place.  Very relaxing and eye pleasing neutral colors.  Friendly service.  QUICK food to table.  I had the short ribs (OMG) and my friend had the pork shoulder braised in milk.  Though her dish was very good, I liked my short ribs better.  So tender, so flavorful.  I was very full at the end, but still wanted more.

A fabulous lunch and outing with a great friend, with a great meal.  Definitely will be back to try the dinner menu.
author: Denise M.

description: Love the ambiance in this restaurant.  It was busy on Friday evening but the quality of the service did not suffer. I had the stuffed quail and my wife had the robin ...both well presented and delicious. Good wine and spirit selection.  The dessert ...the highlight. We had the caramel gelato ...could eat it all night long. Only complaint was the bread ...not fresh. The menu was somewhat limited which was the deciding factor between 3 and 4 stars.
author: Rick E.

description:
My husband and I went her recently for my birthday dinner, and I thought the food and service were both excellent..  The arugula and watermelon salad I had was one of the best salads I've had in years, and my short rib entree was was wonderful as well.  It is a bit loud in the restaurant, but I've come to expect that from alot of San Francisco restaurants.  We weren't rushed during our courses, but we weren't waiting around forever as well.  Also, they brought out a nice cookie plate for me for my birthday!

The only reason I'm deducting one star is because of the wait we had for our table.  We had a reservation, and still had to wait almost half an hour for our table.  I might not have commented on this, but other Yelpers have mentioned it as well, so I think it might be an ongoing problem with this restaurant.  They did give us a bit of a comp because of the wait, but I think they still need to work on the timing of their tables, especially on busy nights of the week when they are obviously fully booked.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
Unbelievably hip looking restaurant. You feel like Frank Sinatra 2011 might be in the back somewhere.

The items that we ate were very good bt I gotta tell ya, as a regular shmo, no meatballs, lasagna or spaghetti on a menu do not an Italian ristorante make.

We were 3 and like I said, everything we ate went down well, especially with a top notch bottle of wine. wine list was great and the wine dude expert was super Eye-talian.

I'd go again but not my first choice.
author: Gee T.

description: I was honestly disappointed with the food. I was expecting more based on the reviews. The pork shoulder was just average. The sea bass was nicely done but spending the kind of money we did at Perbacco, I could have found a 100 places in the city with better food for less. The service was very nice and the wait staff extremely polite and attentive. The drinks were decent as well. Good place but the value is just not evident.
author: Kay J.

description: Went with a few coworkers the other night. This place was really fancy but really good quality food. I got the squid and veal tongue appetizer.  It was very good. I also got their signature dish for my entree which was the "short ribs".  It was pretty good but the portion was a tad bit small for me (I eat a lot). My coworker got the pasta and it looked really good. I would definetley recommend this place for anyone wanting good Italian food.
author: Abra S.

description:
I can cross #18 off my list! 

Oh, ask for the nduja. They have it. It's delicious.
author: Jen D.

description: I often take clients here.  It has great food and wonderful service.  It is also very reasonable for the quality.  Highly Recommended
author: Anthony J.

description:
I work directly across the street from Perbacco, so I've had many occasions to dine, lunch, and happy hour at this fine restaurant.  

Yes, it's a noisy space.  So if you don't do noisy, don't do Perbacco.  My hearing is still 100%, so this does not bother me.  Also, the din is considerably less during the lunch hour, when the FiDi brass haven't taken over the bar (yet).

What I really enjoy about Perbacco is the use of local, fresh, in-season ingredients; the constantly changing menu selections; the fact that I can get dishes with rabbit in them; the class-A service; and the lovely presentation.  

Definitely order some of the salumi as an appetizer; you will not regret this!  

Next up: Perbacco's new younger sibling, Barbacco.
author: Sarah S.

description: we had a wonderful meal on Saturday Night, everything was first class. The service and the food. It was my GF bday and they even gave her a card and a special desert.The only problem was that we ate too much!
author: Mark A.

description: Nice classy place.  My work was celebrating some accomplishment here.  I had my first course of some prosciutto on some melon which I never would have ordered, but the waiter recommended and it was in fact a great compliment of tastes and textures.  For the main course, I had the rabbit and this was not some wild gamy animal, but a real farm raised succulent bunny.  Real nice.  I never had this meat before.  I'm not sure I'd come myself, but it's a class operation and good location for work dinners.
author: Marc S.

description: I admit, I was a little turned off when I first entered Perbacco. We were early for our reservation and the hostess at the front was quite rude to us. There was no offer for a drink or a seat at the bar - which was empty. If it hadn't been for the rave reviews, and the fact that I've been seeking an authentic italian restaurant in the area, we would have ended up at Tadich next door. The ambiance was a little stuffy, but the food definitely made up for it. We tried a variety of pastas, all of which were outstanding. For our main dishes, we paired the risotto with the short ribs. The short ribs were so tender, I could cut it with a spoon. They also had us in and out just in time to make it to our show.
author: Andrea L.

description: Ive now been here twice, had an enjoyable experience both times. The food was excellent, the waitstaff attentive and friendly but knew when to leave us alone, and the atmosphere was upscale without being stuffy. If you are looking for well executed Italian cuisine with out any hint of Italian american then this is the place. The wine list was also extensive and featured some vertical selections from several Italian vintners. Ill be back.
author: David S.

description: Knowing that it is going to be expensive you expect to get a fantastic meal. Mine was the worst I have ever had. I had the pasta with the 5 hour pork. The noodles looked and tasted like Ramen Noodles and the pork tasted and looked like canned dog food. With that being said, the dessert was very good, the white chocolate bar is something I would return for.
author: Eric M.

description:
A fine, classy San Francisco establishment serving rustic, homey Italian food.  My first impression was how large the actual restaurant is.  Bountiful seating in the back and a 2nd level lending a wedding banquet worthy space.  

The service from the host to each server was very gracious.  Our party of 3 came on a Friday evening as walk-ins and were immediately seated.  As I said, this place is so vast that it's hard to truly fill up the entire restaurant.  

Here are some memorable favorites from what we ordered:

The Charcuterie plate - 
The Salumi Misti had its hits and misses.  Some outstanding meats with spicy, oily flavors.  And there was a pork sausage that tasted like pork tartare of sorts... basically globules of fat, which I couldn't quite handle.  Perhaps a few crostinis could have helped with the texture.  There was another sausage that tasted like the best corned beef hash to me.  

Tagliatelle with Pork Sugo and Porcini Mushrooms - A knock out.  I loved this sort of pasta... the texture is that of the ramen you find in a Cup O Noodle, but more rough.  That may sound like an insult, but I am just describing the texture.  It had a great bite to it... as if you had wanted to nibble on each and every strand.  The taste is simply eggy.  Now mix that in with silky broken down pork sugo, it was a fine complete dish for me.  Porcini mushrooms just melded all together with a rich earthy sauce.

I enjoyed the service who checked in on us at the right amounts.  The high points were high, but in general no real low points.  Just food that weren't made for my tastes.
author: Chris T.

description:
My first dinner here was when my good friend took me here for my birthday last September. We both decided that we'd like to return, so it was my turn to host,  and both the food and service remain top quality.

It's a waste of time to describe every item because everything prepared here seems to be outstanding. Be sure to share a pasta item because the pastas are superb with intense flavors in reduced sauces that you're unlikely to make at home. 

We both had the sea bass main course which was excellent and served on greens with turnips and mushrooms and.........well, try it and you'll agree that the selection of ingredients couldn't be better.

We had an Italian red wine which was very smooth and perfect with fish or meat.

Perbacco isn't for cheap eats--you get what you pay for in this world. But the money you spend here is for the best food of its kind. 

So, I'm happy to report that Perbacco still rates 5 stars for both food along with friendly and efficient service. I look forward to my next dinner here.
author: IQuack D.

description:
Not impressed. The wine list is way too expensive. There are very few selections under $70, which is interesting because wine does not need to be $100 or more a bottle to be enjoyable. However the $65/bottle my boyfriend and I shared was definitely nice. 

I am Italian and was disappointed with the food...the sauces on the pasta and raviolis tasted kind of funky, but the noodles were cooked correctly. The salami platter was delicious, but expensive! To share a starter, get one of the cheapest bottles of wine, and an entree each (with no dessert) was about $160. 

The service here is really good! The servers were very nice and attentive, including the hostess who did not have our reservation made through open table, but happily found a table for us no problem. Thanks! I host as well and I know its not always easy.

Another disappointing aspect was the woman who opened our wine for us did not even open it at the table. We were shown the bottle, then the bottle was taken out of sight, and returned to us opened. I myself open wine at a nice restaurant and I value the presentation, especially if the wine is costly. 

Valet were very nice as well and would literally run to retrieve cars for guests, that effort is very much appreciated, especially on a cold night in the city.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
Being right next to the Tadich Grill (a San Francisco  landmark), takes guts.  You have to be sure of your restaurant, because you are competing with one of the fine all time restaurants in this restaurant crazy city.  Perbacco does it with aplomb!

So we were going to go to Tadich, but the wait was 45 minutes and we were hungry, so ... we went next door to Perbacco (actually to Barbacco, it's sister restaurant, but left because Barbacco did not have a full bar and I REALLY wanted a martini). Perbacco is an upscale Italian restaurant. We were a party of four and we had the full restaurant experience.

I had the raviolo (one big one) with an egg yolk in the center and an amazing pappardelle with braised short ribs.  Both were very well prepared and quite delicious (warning, consuming undercooked egg yolk can be hazardous to your health, but ... oh ... so ... delicious too).

The bartenders know how to make a classic martini too. Thank you.

And the service was exceptional, as they went out of their way to take care of us (and I can be a handful).  Patient, courteous, and very customer friendly with excellent food.  What more could you ask for.
author: Mark P.

description:
Really good dinner here. A weeknight, on the late side, and we were seated promptly at a large, comfortable table. Nice, warm, high-ceilinged room but a bit loud owing to mostly hard surfaces. Service was attentive, good-humored but not intrusive.

I started with a glass of prosecco, and moved on to the Raviolo filled with Ricotta and Spinach / Farm Egg / Grated Summer Truffle / Burro Fuso. This was delicious -- silky, salty, creamy and warm. For my main I had the Grilled Berkshire Pork Chop / Seasonal Stone Fruit / Arugula / Roasted Vidalia Onion / Pickled Cherries. A thick, juicy chop, seared medium rare, nicely offset by a tangle of sweet stone fruits, tart greens, caramelized onions and piquant cherries.

For dessert, at our waiter's suggestion, I had the Warm Brown Butter Pistachio Cake / Vanilla Custard / Cherry Compote -- which I would not have picked on my own. It was a very good choice: warm, mellow cake, moist with ground pistachios, filled with a soft custard and accompanied by sweet-tart stewed dark cherries.

My dining companion was similarly impressed with his meal. A delicious dinner and overall very good experience. I would gladly go back.
author: J. P.

description:
Can't review the restaurant per se since I didn't eat there. I had a few bites and drinks at the bar instead. Now any bartender that can:

- Make a solo diner feel welcome
- Make excellent, lightweight small talk
- Crack jokes that are risque but not-at-all inappropriate
- Recommend dishes in great detail and their historical origins
- Describe the harvest methods about a particular wine
- Serve and clear dishes promptly
- Make the best damn old fashioned while describing how other bartenders tend to make mistakes when making theirs

Is a damn fine class act and proud professional in my book. They don't make them like this anymore.

Seriously - If you're a party of two or less skip the dining room and grab a stool.
author: Jammypac B.

description: i love perbacco....the ambiance and the food and the wine selection..it's perfect to go on a romantic date..the last time i was here was oct of 2012 and i had a great time..i will be back soon...very very soon!...LOL
author: Izah S.

description:
What a great place! I came here recently to celebrate the end of a project with a principal. It is definitely the place to go in FiDi for a power lunch as I kept seeing droves of men in blazers come in. The atmosphere definitely felt power-lunchy, which is appropriate for FiDi. 

We started with the pan-seared octopus, then had the pappardelle with short ribs, then ended with the salted caramel gelato.  I was afraid I wouldn't like the octopus, but it was actually really delicious. It was not too fishy and the olives were a perfect compliment to the octopus flavor. The pappardelle noodles were obviously freshly made and the short rib meat basically melted in my mouth. The salted caramel gelato was admittedly not as good as bi-rite, but still a good end to the meal. The cookies that came with the ice cream were also really good. 

In total, the meal was around $100; which is admittedly on the expensive side for lunch. Perhaps, it would be better to come here for dinner. There were intimate booths that I could be really conducive to a date. If you don't mind shelling out the money, give Perbacco a try!
author: Angela L.

description:
I think Perbacco is a very good restaurant, the service is always attentive, the atmosphere is very nice, the menu is interesting.... I would have given it a 5-star if it wasn't that the dishes are a little too heavy. Don't get me wrong: I love Italian food and I know gnocchi, pasta, risotto aren't light, but I think here it is particularly heavy maybe due to too much butter or cream in the recipes... possibly combined with the fact that they serve a delicious slice of focaccia, drenched in olive oil, which pretty much fills you up before you even get your meal. Each dish is unique and full of flavor, but very rich. 

I never heard of anybody not liking their food at Perbacco, but everybody always feels very bloated when leaving. Some people love this, others don't and would prefer a more balanced menu. Thus, I can only give it a 4 star. 

PS: I would recommend the agnolotti with rabbit, and most of the pasta or gnocchi dishes, but today I had the Risotto with Figs, Prosciutto and Burrata and, while the first bite was amazing, by the second bite I was overwhelmed with too much sweetness and too much richness.... I wish it were a little more delicate.

FOOD: very good
SERVICE: very good and attentive
ATMOPSHERE: modern, happening, loud especially at lunch, busy bar at entrance, white tablecloths.
VALUE: good
BEST FOR: business lunch or dinner; birthday/occasion celebration; date; dinner with friends; long lunch with friends.
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description:
A good place in FiDi for an after work drink or dinner maybe an appetiser or two.
But not a big fan of their menu, dinner fare. Upstairs dining room is a bit claustrophobic.
A decent place for one visit.
author: Neil B.

description:
Yummy!!
This place is amazing. I had the pappardelle w/ short rib ragu. This was by far one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had. I could have eaten this all day and everyday.
This is almost as good as the homemade pasta I ate in Sicily...so the bar is high and Perbacco has met it.
author: Kathleen E.

description: Dessert was great and service was top-notch. Cocktails were tasty. The food was okay. The meat entrees were boring and the pasta dishes lacked flavor. The pappardelle doesn't come anywhere close to Delfina.
author: Bihn K.

description: I started with the endive salad, which had nice fat pieces of fuyu nested in the mizuna, with bitto cheese bits all up in the balsamic vinagrette. A lot bigger than you would expect a standard fancy pants place's salad to be. For the main course, I had some ridiculously flavorful "windpipe" (shaped) pasta stewing in Devil's Gulch rabbit sugo. I guess it doesn't matter what meat it actually is if slow-cooked correctly, but the rabbitness really shined through and the pasta's weird shape was nice for holding in the sauce. Only drawback was the table bread, which was a little oily and brittle tasting.
author: Kevin L.

description: Hesitated to review only because I'd like to make sure they have tables available next time I'm in town. This has become my favorite San Francisco restaurant. It is amazing from the attentive service to reasonably priced gourmet Italian food to the awesome wine selection to classy atmosphere. My go-to restaurant when friends and family are in town.
author: Michael N.

description:
Checking in at the end of our evening dining at this Italian restaurant in the Financial District I yelped, "OMFG! Perfect service, perfect meals to share, and perfect company to enjoy this A+ dining experience!"  I'd be hard pressed to recall a better evening of dining out than what I experienced last night, which was a tie with Zuni Cafe back in the spring so I guess my two favorite restaurants just now happen to be in San Francisco.

Working out here in the Bay Area as frequently as I have been of late I seem to go through fits and starts.  Some trips I'm all about going back to the places I've tried and liked, but some trips are like the last two weeks when every new experience seems to unfold some hidden gem that I'm just discovering for the first time.  Writing this just now I can't gush enough about how much I love this city so forgive me if you detect more than a whiff of hyperbole.

Meeting up with a former work colleague whom I've not seen in about six years and her beau, it was on me to choose the restaurant since she'd only moved to town (from New York City) just two weeks ago.  Needless to say she wanted something on par with what she'd grown accustomed to in New York.  While I thought I was making a reservation at BARBacco where I'd dined a few months back, I was pleasantly surprised when I arrived at PERBacco and realized my mistake and that I would be dining at the more established big sister restaurant.

First the service: I wish I'd gotten my waiter's name so I could rave about him personally.  As happened at Zuni Cafe, he let us take our time as we were so busy talking we'd barely perused the menu after ordering a couple of drinks.  Since we were all three newcomers he took great pride in explaining the menu and insisting that everything on the menu is special when one of us asked if there were any specials.  Indeed he was right as every dish on the menu had allure, especially the homemade pastas and house cured charcuterie.  When we noticed that we could order two or three pastas to share for the table, he recommended we get two salads to start, two pastas, and two entrees.  

We had no trouble choosing the two salads, one was roasted beets on a testa (head cheese?) remoulade and the other roasted figs with burrata, arugula and a balsamic glaze. The pastas all looked great and I might have wanted a filled ravioli or gnocchi but we had the papardelle with beef ribs and the the molto Italiano strand pasta with pesto and crushed cherry tomatoes.  Given that all of the pastas are made on the premises I'm sure there was no going wrong. And rather than serving the the dish family style, we were each given a plate with a portion of each.  The papardelle was certainly my favorite and I guess I had a taste for beef that night because we also ordered the beef rib straccato.  No one is a bigger fan of red meat braised in wine than yours truly.  I love making it at home and I love eating it when I go out.  This version came not just with a bread crumb crust but a bone marrow bread crumb crust.  Perfecto!

For the second entree we were to share, our waiter pulled a delightful trick I've never experienced at another restaurant before.  Since we couldn't decide among the salmon, the duck or the rabbit, he said let me surprise you. We were all somewhat taken aback by the proposition, but of course he promised that they were each excellent.  That we went along with his suggestion is testament to his overall competence as a waiter and how deftly he orchestrated a gratifying experience.  And of course he chose a bottle of Italian red close to the flavor profile of our consensus wine of pinot noir that would have gone with any of the three but again seemed extra special because he chose it for us.  I'm not sure how he came to decide on the duck for us, but I couldn't have been more pleased even though I was hoping for the rabbit.  What was especially delicious was the the accompaniment of roasted apples and brussel sprouts that made for such a succulent complement to the duck.

It's rare that service and meal are so perfectly combined in one evening.  Part of the magic was of course catching up with an old friend in a setting new to both of us. But our waiter took the pulse of our table and just made sure we'd have a wonderful evening.  I only wish I could give more than 5 stars for this spectacular night!
author: Sean M.

description:
I would consider Perbacco your typical FiDi business lunch or fancy dinner spot.  I would not normally consider it as a place where you'd have a casual dinner date with your sisters and your new baby niece...

My sisters, one of whom had a baby very recently, and I wanted to get together for a nice dinner.  We chose Perbacco because the menu was scrumptious!  What we hadn't realized was that Perbacco is a really nice restaurant with fancy, well-heeled patrons, and beautiful decor.  I felt a little embarassed trying to fit my 3.5-month old niece at our table, because the high chair wouldn't work with her car-seat, but the host and the servers were really accomodating and we managed to make the baby comfortable in a regular chair.

Not a single person stared at us in horror, which was really surprising, even when my sister started to breastfeed!  I give Perbacco 5 stars because it serves delicious food without any pretension.

The food was beautifully plated, and just plain yummy.  We had:
- salumi 'nduja platter (with soft, spreadable salumi, which was different but still delicious) - $8
- roasted beets and arugula salad - $10
- roasted octopus salad - $12
- burrata chese/heirloom tomato/arugula salad - $11
- tajarin (handcut tagliatelle and pork sugo) - $16
- pappardelle with short rib ragu - $17
- brown butter cake for dessert, and a complimentary Italian chocolate plate
*Total dinner tab plus a Chimay was just under $100 not including tip.  How much more reasonable can you get?!?

Everything we had was simply delicious, and I would order it all again, though I'll likely venture to other items on the menu because there are so many!  The burrata cheese app was especially noteworthy, as it just melts in your mouth.  I also love how our server automatically separated the pasta onto three dishes so we didn't have to divvy up the portions ourselves.  I really would consider this a fabulous value for your money, as we all left stuffed and incredibly happy.

I am absolutely returning to Perbacco when I'm feeling in the mood for a beautiful sit-down dinner with excellent service and delectable food.
author: Kira K.

description:
