Wife and I crawling the private galleries on Geary and we gets the rumblies. ( I dunno, Irving Penn does that to me).
Now what to do? Surrounded by a million choices. Mina's new place?Benu? Wexler's? Rose Pistola? cab up to Zuni? . We were hoplessly perplexed n couldn't decide which direction to go.

BOOM! we suddenly decide Italian.

hmm... Italian in San Francisco. Didn't narrow things much.

When wifey beams me and says, "hey whattabout that place you were telling me about  down financial district way. bocco, bococo, perboco."

EUREKA.. Perbacco! 
Radiologist pal o' mine raves about the place.

We arrive early and sit at the bar. 
Beautiful place. Warm lighting, exposed brick, comfortable stools.
All good after a long walk 'cross town.

I order a cocktail (don remember what it was but damm good) my wife an Alto Adige Pinot Bianco...fabulous.

we spend the next 2 hours sipping, munching, laughing with some of the best food and wine we've had in months. 

Didn't make many mental notes so....I must return to see what else they conjure.
Don't miss an opportunity to check 'em out.

Excellent service, superb wine list, fabulous food.
author: Kurt P.

description:
House made cured meats, modern atmosphere, great cocktails.  Go. Enjoy.  

I only had the Salumi Misti and some drinks with a friend.  These meats are house cured and delicious.  Wish we could have stayed to try some of the other selections of food or entres but time was short.  

Go check it out.
author: J T.

description: The service is fantastic and the food is mouth-watering.  What more could you want?  The sommelier is amazing and fabulously Italian - he exudes charm and intensity.  My favorite: the burrata salad was simply to-die-for.  I will visit every time we're in SF.  Every time.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Nice atmosphere, especially the bar, with ample seating in the back room.  I thought the fare decent but expensive for what it was although that could be expected in the financial district.  More a of restaurant for a business related meal, less so for a date. 

I've been here a bunch and have never had trouble getting a table even without a reservation.  They also have booths for small groups.
author: David A.

description:
I had a very random encounter with Perbacco on St. Patty's day. We were at the block party and I wasn't about to spend 30 minutes standing in line to use a porta-potty. Being somewhat familiar with the area I knew there were a handful of restaurants in the area. That is how we stumbled into Perbacco.

After taking care of business we decided to sit down and have a drink. The bartender was nice and whipped up some good Manhattans and we were content. One thing led to another and we found ourselves with some new St Patty's plans, dinner at Perbacco. The food was great, it had a cozy and sophisticated vibe and the people sitting at the bar were friendly and social. Overall, it ended up being a great night!
author: Leila S.

description:
I can't believe I lived two blocks away from this gemstone and never really went here to eat! I'd only been for a glass of wine. 

Anyway, my boss brought me here prior to my SF departure (sniff sniff) and I was totally blown away by the menu.  First off our server recommended a fantastic glass of wine to accompany our meal.  I ordered the strawberry salad for starters from the seasonal specials menu - I don't even like strawberries, so I'm not really sure why I ordered this, but I thank some lucky stars somewhere that I ordered this.  It was amazing, perfect blend of sweet and savory (dressing and nuts); my boss also got this and was equally happy with his selection. 

My entree was the ricotta gnocchi, I've only ordered this at one other place before (Zuni) and I didn't think it would compare, but it did, it was also really really tasty.  

I ate so much at lunch, I had a major food coma, AND I was a little tipsy.  =)
author: Bhumika K.

description:
I have to admit, I was sincerely disappointed.

I had heard such great things about this place and was excited to meet a friend for dinner here. The short rib pasta came highly recommended so I was excited to try.

I started with the roasted beet salad and it was delicious. Mandarin oranges were a nice touch to the overly sweet red beets. My friend's salad of Fall fruits looked something like an ambrosia salad. She seemed to like it though.

We ordered the short rib pasta, noting that they had changed the menu from pappardelle to langaroli (fancy name for ravioli). I didn't realize that would have such a huge impact. The photos on Yelp of the Papardelle showed what appears to be shredded short ribs but when they switched to ravioli they essentially pureed it with mushrooms. The result was a filling that reminded us of wet cat food. It really wasn't very good.

For the desserts, we had the toffee cake and the chocolate pudding. Both were great, a very nice way to forget about our horrible entrees.

Our server was very nice and even removed one of our desserts after accidentally forgetting to put in the order. I also loved the casual atmosphere.

That said, the disappointment over the main courses was such that I couldn't give Perbacco more than a couple of stars...so many better options I would rather visit as opposed to giving this another try. :-(
author: J C.

description: We are staying at the Fairmount and Perbacco was recommended by a few friends. We are (very) amateur food snobs from NYC, and we loved it! Sean was our waiter: adorable, perfectly attentive and knowledgeable about the menu. We had the salumi misti, burrata, and a veal filled pasta and the duck. All were fantastic! Still thinking about the chocolate lavender bonet for dessert. Highly recommend.
author: Sarah R.

description: TRUFFLE SEASON!  Perbacco started offering the truffle menu in early-November and stops when the truffle supply runs out. I am so glad we made it here in time (mid-Nov).  Truffle entrees are $50+ for a few very thin slices atop your dish, but that's the price you pay for white truffle.  The regular pasta dishes are amazing as well!  What a satisfying meal.
author: Karen L.

description:
We went to Perbacco for lunch and the place was packed. I would say that the noise level was high and that the service was slow.  The waiter/busboy were very nice but the kitchen was slow in turning out the dishes.

Other than that, the food was superb.  We had the focaccia with the pesto paste while waiting for our appetizer and it was very good.  The grissini were nothing special and the focaccia could have used a little less oil but otherwise everything was fine.

And, did I mention it is so nice to be eating in a restaurant with a white tablecloth instead of just on a table?

The appetizer was awesome, vitello tonnato.  It can be a heavy dish but the chef put the sauce on the side so you could add or substract as much as you needed. I think he even put some anchovies in the sauce to give it a kick and it was a great idea, in my opinion.

We had the duck risotto, excellent, and the taglierini with pork ragu.  The pasta was so fresh that you could smell its freshness as soon as the plate touched the table.  It seemed homemade.  The sauce was on top of it and really complemented the fine, delicate pasta.

We did not try dessert, although we were tempted by the panna cotta, and did not try the wine but we are sure, they were excellent.

We will be back!
author: Sailing A.

description: I have been dying to try this restaurant for a long time as it's a favorite of several work associates. The food is very good. I had the beet salad, the chicken and the gelato. The beet salad was very good, but the portion was tin for the price. The chicken had delicious flavor, but the chicken itself was tough and dry. The gelato was the highlight and to die for. Caramel with sea salt, yummy!!
author: Emily C.

description:
So, the online dictionary tells me that perbacco means "wow!" 

Was pretty impressed by this place.  Mind you, this comes from someone who doesn't think much of Italian food (usually prefer a good dumpling to ravioli).

The place is small-ish but gives off a good vibe.  Tall ceilings give it a roomy feel.  Tables are close enough to not feel impersonal, and there's just enough noise to give you an excuse to lean in and get closer to your dinner companion.  There were a lot of suits around, which made it a little stuffy looking, but overall quite a nice ambience.

We were in their upstairs private dining room.  It's a small space surrounded by windows from which one can watch the hustle and bustle of the ground floor. 

                                                                                 ****** Food ******

Amazing:
- Rabbit Agnolotti with Truffled Sugo D'arrosto: these were GOOD.  They're little tiny pillows of pasta stuffed with a very good filling and a delicious sauce.  Comes in a small or large plate.  Get the large - it's not that big and everyone will want to taste some.
- Mousse dessert: WOW.  I don't usually like mousse, but this thing has great presentation and then an unbelievably airy texture.  Definitely the dessert to get!  

Solid:
- Seared Local Sea Bass: Was a little firmer than expected, but the combination of corn with some sort of a lemon-y sauce and asparagus was well done.
- Goat cheese and mint ravioli: this was interesting.  Both the mint and goat cheese are subtle, so it actual tastes better than it sounds.
- Fig-leaf scented panna cotta: Was decent as far as panna cotta goes.  Hard to appreciate it after tasting the mousse (see above).

Other: Pappardelle, Prather Ranch Sirloin Steak, Roasted Octopus were all supposedly decent.  Monkfish was the miss of the evening.

                                                                               ************************

Overall? Good food, good ambience, good service...

Perbacco!
author: Linda C.

description:
Like many other Yelpers, I was lured to Perbacco by the siren song of its salumi plate. I can now rest easy with the knowledge that, according to 7x7 magazine, I only need to try 94 more dishes before laying claims to a life fully lived. 

The decor is modern and somewhat understated, although the tables are a little too close together, and I definitely felt like the diners either side of us were privy to a little too much information. The wait staff were very attentive and knowledgeable of the menu - which was absolutely ENORMOUS. Our waitress gave a great wine recommendation (Perbacco has a HUGE selection of Italian wines)  and weighed in on their many popular entrees and appetizers.

I, however, ignored most of those recommendations and decided to go freestyle. We started with the salumi plate, obviously, which was pretty incredible. Perbacco hand-makes all of their cured meats, and I've honestly never tried anything like some of the pates and sausages that emerged with our plate. Top marks, and if I'd been smart about things, I would have left it at that.

My appetizer was a watermelon salad with basic and queso fresco - which was tasy, but by no means extraordinary. I was HUGELY disappointed by my appetizer of home-made gnocchi with Early Girl tomatoes and cheese - the potato was incredibly dense and the tomatoes seemed a little too sweet and lacking in flavor - enormous bummer, because simple gnocchi/tomato dishes are my absolute fave. I left all but a bite on my plate. Donny S. was similarly underwhelmed by his pork dish cooked in milk - a dish the waitress had recommended.

We finished by sharing the olive oil chocolate cake - which was tasy, but not as 'push-the-envelope' as it sounds. The cake was a gooey fudgy sponge-type thing, and the ice cream was basically vanilla flavored with a little hint of olive oil. I think had it just been "chocolate cake with ice cream" I wouldn't really have noticed the olive oil.

So three stars - for the decor, service, and salumi. I'd probably come back here for a drink and an appetizer, but save my dinner money and take myself somewhere a little tastier.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Perbacco may be my favorite restaurant in SF, and it's lucky that I'm not around there often because I'd want to go back again and again and again. 

I went back last weekend with a certain someone before the symphony.  He has a fondness for cured meats and 7x7 said that the salumi plate is a must try.  So we decided to split the salumi, a salad, a pasta entree, and 2 sides.  This was the perfect amount of food.  

Everything was, of course, delicious.  The salumi was some of the best I've had.  The salad was not remarkable, but quite good. The butternut squash ravioli was so good that I regret sharing.  And the sides of braised romano beans and roasted fennel were fab.

Everything about Perbacco is lovely. I can't wait to go back
author: Gracie B.

description:
From EVERYTHING...food, decor, staff and noise level...PERFECTION!
The panna cotta was off the charts wonderful.
author: Michael K.

description: I took my friend to Perbacco for her birthday.  She has dined here a few times, this was my first and it was fabulous.  My friend and I shared the Fritto with Rock Shrimp appetizer with seasonal beans, olives, and fennel.  I'm not a huge fennel fan but this dish was lightly battered and all the flavors came together.  I enjoyed eating my entire share of it.  My friend ordered the Market Salad - seasonal mix greens and I ordered the Heirloom tomato salad with basil; very tasty.  For our entrees, my friend ordered the Petrale Sole and I had the Butternut Squash Ravioli with sage brown sugar.  For desert we shared the Burnt Caramel and Tahitian sea salt gelato; very good if you like a salty and sweet combination.  The atmosphere was nice, very busy with business lunch parties.  Over all I was impressed with everything.  I will recommend this restaurant to friends and collogues.
author: Liz D.

description:
This place rocks!!  The food is amazing!  The service is wonderful too.
Like Dave K. I also had one  of their "signature dishes, Tajarin -- Hand-cut Tagliatelle with Pork Sugo and Porcini Mushrooms.  I really enjoyed it.  I also had the Frito Misto of Rock Shrimp, Seasonal Beans, Olives, Fennel, and Lemon Aioli.  All of it was very lightly breaded and batter fried. Yum!  We shared a butterscotch cake for dessert that was out of this world! Check it out.  You will love it.
author: PictureGirl F.

description:
My expectations did not get met at this place, however I did like it quite a bit (except for a few minor things).  It is however a nice place for special occasions I suppose, maybe a birthday or an anniversary?  Here's what we ordered:

Hamachi: I'd give it a 3.5/5 being that I've never eaten hamachi, which is wierd because I always eat sushi? but whatever.  It was basically 3 pieces roughly 3 inches long, 1.5 inches wide, and each piece was approx. about 1/2 inch in thickness.  It had some red sauce under the pieces of hamachi along with some fresh dill & something that resembled celery?  Not sure, but you can look at the menu and find out, i'm just a big lazy right now.  A bit of rock salt on each piece gave it just the right amount to taste.  I liked it with the dill and celery, i think, together.  If not eaten together with the dill and celery it just tasted a bit too fishy to my liking.  But all in all a good choice, I'd probably order it again if i ever go back.

Salumi Misti: This dish gets a 2.5/5 because I'm not a salami expert.  Here we've got different selections of salami with a few uber tiny pickles & onions soaked in vinegar with some garlic pesto sauce, i think, along with a few slices of dried toast cracker like thingy's and some breadsticks.  I'd say i'm not a conoseuir when it comes to various types of salami, but it was pretty good.  I hear that this is a special thing that people rave about when they come here because the salami is cured in house or something?  Not being a salami fanatic, I will probably not order this again.  Guess I would've ordered it eventually since I hadn't tried it for myself.  It has a bit of a sourish taste but I guess that's a good thing? right?

Heirloom Tomato Salad:  Man, this one gets a 3.8/5!  The slices of tomatoes were fairly big.  Topped with vinegar, balsamic vinegar, garlic, basil, fresh parm, and probably a whole bunch of high qual ingredients.  Very light, tasty and smells wonderful too...although it doesn't really have a strong smell.  I love basil and vinegar.

Pappardelle: This dish definately gets a 4/5.  It's basically gravy made from pork ribs with pork ribs on flat & wide linguine with no bones!  I personally never order ribs or anything with a bone, which sucks cuz  I love pork ribs!  The meat is so tender and you can really taste the essence of whatever they're trying to portray.  Awesome awesome dish.  I'd like to try and make this at home, but it'd be alot of work.  O well, if i go back I will definately order this.  It is a must have for people who like pork, ribs or both!

Herb Ricotta Gnocchi: It was good, so I guess I'll give it a 3/5.  If you like ricotta or cheese or milk or cheese or the smell of cheese, then this dish is for you!  I think it was very well put together with the basil, spinach, and especially the cherry tomatoes.  I think they could've put a little more flavor in it, like maybe some meat or something, but that's ok.  It was still pretty good.  But I probably wouldn't order it again.

Sorbet:  Unfortunately, I dont remember which sorbet was ordered, but it was definately good.  This i'd give a 4/5.  I usually dont like sorbet's but this is definately the exception.  It comes in a ceramic glass shaped like a bent plastic cup for easy holding.  Unique Idea, definately innovative.  Also comes with 2 uber small shortbread cookies with raisin which were DELECTEBLE.  Yummm.

Pine Nut Panna Cotta w/ Blueberries:  It is a pretty dish as well a tasty one.  However, I'm a panna cotta freak so I'd hafto give this a 3/5.  If this was my first time eating panna cotta I'd definately give it a higher rating, but since I've eaten it at other places and even make it at home, I can't give it anything higher than a 3/5.  This must've been the only dish beside the sortbet I didn't get a picture of..o well.  It came on a huge white round plate with blueberries in a blueberry sauce artistically splattered around the plate with chopped pine nuts lightly spread out on top and the panna cotta being in the middle of the plate.  Again, awesome dish, awesome layout, even though I've had better, I'd still order it again.

All in all, I can't say I'll never go back, but I will not be craving to go back like I would to Katana-ya for ramen, but that's a whole other issue.  lol, that's not even italian food but whatever.  I must definately be a japanese addict.  Anyway, the ambience and atmosphere of the place definately was nice for this special occasion, except for the noise level, but that couldn't be helped being it was 6 pm on a friday night.  Definately worth trying.  I also left a fatty tip because our server was so friendly.  I dont wanna type about this place anymore cuz I hafto goto the bathroom so I'm going to leave you with this note:

I've got to take a poop.

until next time....EAT MORE FOOD!!

and oh yea, it looks like they have a dressy standard for attire, but I went in jeans and a polo.  Nothing bad happened??
author: Jack N.

description:
Midweek Lunch, on a business account.  Thank goodness I didn't have to pay my own money for this vastly overrated restaurant-that-is-in-love-with-itself.

First thing one notices is bread - not any standard Italian bread, not San Fran sourdough or such, but this meh greasy bread that at least encourages you not to fill up early.

We started with a salad that was bad enough that my friend didn't eat half.  Weird leaves, nothing exceptional about the dressing, overall bitter aftertaste.

We then split a slightly overcooked risotto, it had a decent flavor but not anything remarkable.  Not great, not bad.

Then came the steak, seasoned and cooked to near perfection ... and then rendered *absolutely inedible *  with a disgusting gorgonzola butter, that permeated itself to all corners and sides on the plate..  (Who thinks of combinations like this?)  It was the first time in ages where I sent anything back to the kitchen due to preparation.  I do suppose that had I inspected the menu closely, I might have seen the gorg, imagined the nastiness of it and asked for it to be withheld... but the menu is so cluttered with self adoring adjectives and such that it is hard to work through.

While this restaurant does some things well, you certainly have to search for them - and pay for them.
author: Fnur S.

description:
Food was ok (I heard amazing things about it, but I thought it was just ok).

The service was where they shined, best I've had short of 5 star restaurants.

The prices were actually reasonable for a nicer restaurant in SF.
author: Hans I.

description: The decor is modern and spacious, service is good, unfortunately I didn't make a reservation so I didn't get to sit in the main dining room but we manage to get a booth by the bar. We had the lardo melted on baguette and veal tartare- which was excellent. I ordered the truffle-herb ricotta gnocchi, I thought it was too soft and overcooked, my boyfriend had the rabbit agnolotti, which was very tasty but I thought the best dish was my sister's handcut tagliattelle. I had high expectations for this resto, so I thought it was just ok.
author: Ennie L.

description:
This ristorante reminded me of a place I loved in Perugia when I lived there. I met an old friend there, he treated me to lunch for my birthday. It was an idyllic 2 hours. The grissini were fresh and crisp -- didn't try the other bread. We shared appetizers:  Vitello Tonnato and Antipasti Misti. Both were very good. It was the one and only time I've ever had Vitello Tonnato outside Italy or my own home and it was very good. The vitello was sliced like prosciutto, which was unusual, but it  did taste delicious. Our entrees were the hangar steak (with Vidalia onions!) and the roast chicken served on a bed of polenta. I ordered the latter as I was craving decent polenta and it did not disappoint. My friend graciously shared some of those eXquisite onions and a bite of hangar steak and I'll go with this entree next time if it's availabe. We topped off the meal with a delicious chocolate delicacy that had a hint of espresso. I can't recall the name of this concoction, it was like a creme brulee or a heavy mousse, and it was absolutely divine. 

I'd have scored Perbacco a perfect 5 if it weren't for the uneven service. We shared a half-carafe of Sangiovese, which I'll never order again. Highly acidic, it wasn't so much the quality of the wine as it was the server who made me regret our choice. I gather he disapproved of our selection as he spilled  quite a bit of it when he poured my friend's glass. Ok. Maybe it was an accident.   My friend poured the remaining glasses himself, rather than tempt fate by having our server  . . .   pour more. That was fine until the very end of the meal when, after expertly scraping grissini crumbs from the white linen tablecloth, he picked up my glass and turned it upside down right next to my friend's elbow. There was a trail of red wine dribble almost touching my friend's sleeve.  They traded glances and then . . . He does it AGAIN! with my friend's glass. We just stared at the two little red rivulets and then my friend asked, "What's going on with this guy? Is he mad at me? He did that on purpose, didn't  he?". I had to admit that it certainly looked lthat way. Three splash-downs, and all on *his* side of  the table. We'll definitely make sure we have a different server next time. 

But even with that dodgy waiter, the food made our meal a wonderful reunion.
author: Lucia M.

description:
Unbelievable.  We ended up going here at lunch because, get this, Barbacco (their little sister next door) was full and we had NO WAIT here.  I don't get it, but I can't complain.

Their breadsticks and bread are unbelievable and they keep refilling them, which is dangerous, but so good.  Their pasta is awesome. Awesome.  We shared things around the table and oh wow, so good.  Do note, though, that their menu changes daily, so while there are staples, don't assume you'll have the same choices each time.

My group of five also ordered four desserts, which is like half of the menu.  They are ALL delicious - don't go without getting one. Such a great meal.
author: Adam T.

description:
I came here for lunch and found it to be quite good. It was just a hair too loud, which interfered with conversation a little -- no surprise given all the brick and mirrors inside. 

Complementary bread sticks with a pesto dipping sauce and a piece of baked bread before the app was a nice touch, and the service was very good. The market salad was great. 

I order the grilled hangar steak medium-rare and got it rare, which was no big deal, but the gorgonzola butter on top overwhelmed the steak's flavor. The baby beets it came with were fresh, bitter, and delicious, but the steak cried out to be paired with something sweeter, like potatoes, onions, or mushrooms. The pasta looked excellent. It's a great place for a business lunch.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Do love this place. A nice, vibrant but casually elegant space, where you can dress up, look all financial district businessy, or just go in a well-pressed casual. Lots of good Italian wines by the glass, 1/4 carafe and 1/2 carafe. And the food is excellent across the board. We had 1/4 carafe each of a Dolcetto and a Montepulciano d' Abruzzo, both good.

Tonight I started with a ravioli appetizer with egg and spinach, then had an excellent chanterelle and pancetta risotto. My friend had the hangar steak--it was delicious and perfectly cooked. Hell, even the breadsticks were good, served with a pesto dipping sauce. 

The bill for two with the wine was about $88. You'ill spend a lot more elsewhere for a much less satisfying experience. Stepping out into the chill of California Street, it really felt happy to live in this city--so full of energy, urban beauty and high-quality good times.
author: Tom M.

description:
Sometimes second chances don't live up to great first impressions.  Such was my experience at Perbacco.  Two years ago, I had a wonderful dinner at Perbacco - the service was phenomenal, the ambience earthy yet contemporary, and the roasted duck divine.  For two years I have been trying to get back to Perbacco, and finally had my chance last night.

The service was still excellent, however, I found the food to be seriously lacking in flavor.  The arugula and pear salad was drizzled very lightly with a rich gorgonzola sauce (I would have preferred a little more), and it seemed like there was all of two tablespoons of arugula on the plate.  The roasted pears were so-so; for such a savory salad, they would have done better to caramelize the crust on the pears a bit more.  With so little salad on the plate, it becomes almost essential for every morsel to literally burst with flavor, and this salad did not.

I also ordered the sea bass in a saffron broth.  I could not taste the saffron at all.  But the biggest disappointment - I did not recognize the fish as a sea bass.  I had imagined a thick, moist slab of meaty fish, but the sea bass had the texture of a mahi mahi,  It was served with the skin, but the skin was neither flavored nor crisp, so I could not understand its purpose on the plate.  The entree came with fingerling potatoes.  Again, I had imagined roasted buttery little nuggets, but these were sliced thin and boiled in the broth.  I was completely underwhelmed.

My husband had the lamb, which I thought had some good flavor.  But the medallions were so small - after excluding the bone, there was all of three bitefuls in each of the two medallions.  And at nearly $30 for the entree plate itself, I think the restaurant could have done a little better than that.  There was a glimmer of hope - one of our dining companions had the beef shortrib, which seemed to have been perfectly cooked; he did not even need his knife to slice it.

We had a flourless chocolate torte and chestnut/honey ice cream for dessert.  The chocolate torte was rich in flavor, but they missed the mark on the ice cream.  My first bite left me initially wondering if the ice cream was rancid.  It was only after I had thought about the aftertaste that I recognized the unusual raw sweetness as honey.

I may have just been there on an off night.  And, as I mentioned, the service was still very professional, friendly, and attentive.  I will not be in as much of a rush, however, for a third impression.
author: Sherry N.

description: The main seating area is towards the back. Tables are pretty close and noise level is high when it's full, which it usually is. Not exactly a romantic atmosphere, but saw a few dating couples nonetheless. Food is good quality, prepared well, and portions are on the large side. We had some very nice tomatoes to start, couple of interesting pastas and a very nice pork shoulder. Coincidentally, we sat next to a foursome, one couple who, as we eavesdropped to hear, used to farm high quality pigs, which apparently went to high-end restaurants. Finished with a "wild chocolate" pudding, which was more like a mousse, but in any case, quite good.  Good professional service and meal was nicely paced.
author: Bruce C.

description: Cute ambience....staff wonderfully amazing people...they give you an iPad to order wine while you wait for your table..I had the fish of the day and it was simply spectacular.
author: Sharon N.

description:
I had lunch yesterday with clients and hadn't been here in years since ... well, frankly, another business lunch.  It's that kind of place where I think if it was located elsewhere but FiDi, it would be a much more attractive place.

I mean, don't get me wrong.  The decor is beautiful and service is quite attentive.  But you look around and everyone looks like they're on a business lunch with their button-downs and fake smiles.

It's a shame because the food really is good.  The breadsticks with pesto are a nice touch and the warm focaccia that follows is amazing (although it will leave your hands quite oily).

For starters, the beet salad was excellent (but a bit small in size).  The client had the heirloom salad which looked amazing.  If I was only with friends, I could just reach over and ... doh!

For my entree, I ordered the tajarin, a dishfrom the Piemonte area of Italy for which Perbacco is known.  The handcut tagliatelle resembles wavy ramen and 5-hour cooked pork sugo was a like ground beef poured in the center of it.  Although it looked rather eh, the texture was al dente and quite good.  The sugo was nice but a little bland and after pretty heavy.  It would have been nice to get some veggies or crunchy nibbles to balance the heavy starch and meat.  I remember getting the agnolotti dal plin the last time ... but can't remember if I enjoyed it or not.  Everyone else at non-pasta entrees which looked much more complex (the hangar steak, the halibut) but also looked like what you might be able to get at other restaurants.

I may have to come back (maybe for a weekend) when the suit & tie crowd is far, far away and try another pasta dish soon.  Or I'll probably soon forget how the tajarin tasted (much like the forgotten agnolotti).
author: F. P.

description:
A++++across the board!*
It's like eating over there!
*but for one MINOR alleged glass of Merlot: WHAT could our waiter have
been thinking???  -He has left the country and joined an kibbutz.

-and the second time two weeks ago:  moe bella than the first time!
author: Clifford L.

description: every thing was fantastic. .. wish there were more fish choices. ..i had the scallops,  carrots, cheese tray. .. service was perfect
author: Kelly S.

description:
LOVED this restaurant!  We just stumbled upon it and decided to try it.  
OMG....the food is RICH and DELICIOUS!!!  The service is 5 star for sure!
We tried the rabbit (amazing), the quail stuffed with foie gras/truffle, and the veal tartare!  We seriously thought we'd died and gone to food heaven.  This is a place for foodies for sure!
author: Khani Z.

description:
Cost per person to do it right: $40

Consistently good meals here are the expectation.  The salumi is excellent, crudo is always worth it, pastas are fresh and the fish is thoughtful and well executed.

So, it's Italian food done by a Swedish chef with some serious classical know-how.  Strangely enough, it's amazing.  The staple truffle gnocchi with wild mushrooms and goat cheese/sweet pea ravioli are effing amazing for the price (and in general).  In fact, I would describe the worst dish I've had here--vitello tonnato--as "good."  With the changing menu and relaxed ambiance, this is a place that you should hit with some regularity.  Also, it doesn't hurt to try the things that sound a little odd or are new to the menu; the kitchen staff will sometimes brush against genius on such dishes.

While the wait staff is very helpful and polite, I sometimes find their constant, formal service a little extensive when I just stop in for lunch on a weekday, but the effort is still appreciated.  As for stopping in on any day, you probably won't want to drive.  Fortunately, it's only a few blocks from the BART station.

Verdict: Dynamic menu that pleases on all fronts.  Reasonable prices and semi-formal atmosphere make it good for anything from special occasions to weekday lunch runs.
author: Troy M.

description: So many meals and so many drinks here but I still can't decide if I like this place.  Service has gotten a bit better but some night's it's just too busy and cramped unless you have reservations.  It's okay.
author: Suz L.

description:
Little Italy meets Wall Street. Perbacco is top notch for food, service and atmosphere for happy hour, date or celebration.   
Amazing Italian wine list that your sommelier will help you make heads or tales of. The cheeses and cured meats make a perfect starter for the table as you flip a coin to help decide your courses from a fresh and varied menu. Offering of small pasta for primi is perfect and I chose the ragu with duck. Outstanding! Others in the group enjoyed gnocchi and risotto. Loyal followers will question my sway from the risotto. It was tempting but a ragu like Momma makes, that's the best. This was better but don't tell Mom. The sea bass looked like a winner for my main but I went with the pheasant and was not disappointed. 
Amazing presentation, great service and although we've never been here before, we were treated like regulars. I will be back for a drink at the bar and dinner with friends. Perbacco, I thank you.
author: Mark F.

description:
Had dinner here the other night and it was fabulous.  Umberto treated us like kings!

We walked in on a Thursday evening and were able to snag a seat pretty quickly, but that was because my colleague is personal friends with the owner.  Nonetheless, he treated us like friends entering his home.  He picked out a beautiful super Tuscan wine that we enjoyed with some appetizers and entrees.

We shared the burrata and corn, a beautiful take on caprese salad.  I highly recommend it.  For entrees we both had the 5-hour cooked sugo, a pork dish over pasta.  The pasta was quite interesting as it appeared like a ramen noodle but was clearly Italian pasta.  

I love the space, very modern but not cold.  I definitely will be going back here!
author: Scott L.

description: Delicious place! came here with the bf after a niners game and it was a great meal. we had a few salads, pear and pomegranate and roasted baby beets from what i remember, a tasting of three pastas, and the dark chocolate and hazelnut prailine bar, with amazing wines and moscato d'asti. the pasta tastings were fabulous ( i think we ordered the tagliatelle, risotto, and ricotta gnocchi). I would definitely recommend doing the tasting! I would also be interested in trying their more casual sister restaurant "Barbacco".
author: Sheeva G.

description:
went here about 10 months ago. we made reservations and was seated quickly. we had some cocktails

we had a trio of pasta...pretty good although i forgot what was the last pasta we ordered. we know we had the pappardelle with short rib ragu and tarjin with 5 hr pork sago. from what i remember, both tasted good but nothing too great. especially if i cant remember the flavor or the other pasta..must of not of been that memorable. 

but we liked the ambiance and it was pretty quiet. nice place and possibly would come here again.
author: Angela C.

description:
Perbacco is a superb dining experience in every way! 
The service is spot on, not too much hovering and not unavailable, lovely!
The food is delicious and I always enjoy the beet salad and the pastas are varied and always sumptuous!
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, where I have lived and dined for 25 Years!
author: Diane G.

description:
I've heard good things about Perbacco and I was fortunate enough to have a friend invite me along for a last-minute dinner.

The staff was easygoing and personable. We were seated at the chef's table a few minutes after our arrival. That's when the fun started! We could see all the action going on in the kitchen.

The best part about our dinner was the service and company. I had the raviolo as an appetizer which was sublime. The risotto was just OK and a little too al dente for my taste. Not to toot my own horn but there was a general consensus that my mushroom risotto is much tastier! =)

I don't remember much about dessert but after downing 3 gin & tonics, who would? Fortunately I had that little area around the chef's table to jog off the liquor. =)

I would come back to try the other items on the menu. Seems like a great place to meet up with friends after work!
author: Bernadette A.

description:
Service is great and the place is well managed with an eye for details. I had many lunch experiences here and also business functions, and their standard of service is consistent. 
Food is good and I Think it offers the best pasta selection in downtown financial district ex-little Italy.
author: Ada W.

description:
What an excellent dinning experience. Our server was AMAZING! She was so great. 6 stars for her. 

We started with a salumi plate- you can't go wrong here- it was so freaking good. 

Then we shared the anglotti- wow- what a treat. It came heavily recommended and passed the test with flying colors. 

Then we shared/split the rabbit and quail. 

I got the quail (luckily and it was very good!) Def a good choice. The rabbit was so-so .. a little too rough... perhaps over cooked. 

We took a NICE bottle of FREEMARK ABBEY wine- omg- ridiculous. It was a 92 Cab Bosche. REDICK! 

We then shared some tasty dessert.. forgot that it was.. hmm.. but remember it being delicious. 

Will def go back. 

Also, it wasn't as expensive as I thought it would be. It was totally worth it.. will def go back.
author: Art A.

description:
I had a negative experience here two years ago that involved wine, drama, and a ruined shirt. It was so bad, I did not care to write a review, but last Thursday my opinion of Perbacco changed for the better.....

I started a liver cleanse diet seven days ago, meaning no alcohol for fifteen days. My first true test of my discipline was at Perbacco when I did not order wine. Throughout the evening, only one person had wine, totaling $8.00.

For meals, I started with fresh, grilled asparagus with a beautiful hollandaise sauce. For my second course, I shared a papparadelli pasta with short rib meat on top. Both dishes were memorable. 

What made this restaurant stand out to me was:

1.) The waitress treated us like we ordered there best champagne instead of one glass of wine and tap water.
2.) They split the pasta without charging an additional fee.
3.) The meal was only $59.00 for three of us, which is the least I have ever spent for three people in adulthood in San Francisco.

I would give Perbacco a try if you have not been. If you did not have the best experience, give it another try, as I did.
author: Christopher W.

description: Had the occasion to return for a second visit. Their signature Manhattan cocktail is most likely the best Manhattan I have ever had! Ordered a simple main course, Liberty farm duck breast, slow coocked leg on a bed of sauteed brussel sprouts and apples in padella. A very fresh dish with  an uncomplicated flavor profile. The duck was cooked absolutely perfect much to my pleasure.
author: Steven B.

description: The Plin al Brasato was outstanding.
author: Brent S.

description:
I was in San Francisco visiting family and my aunt suggested Perbacco.  This place is amazing!  The restaurant is very well done in every regard but I think was impressed me most was the overall feel of the building.  The interior design is modern and original, and just feels good.  I love it when things are designed well. The menu is extensive and delicious, with enough options for vegetarians.  The staff was great as well. I got a chance to meet the owners and they were very cool and intelligent people.  It's no wonder the restaurant was so fun.

Perbacco is the  kind of place you could go on almost any occassion.  I definitely owe my aunt one for showing me this place.  Definitely my kind of place.  Overall, I had about as good of a time at a restaurant as is possible.
author: B P.

description: Food is good when it is free.  It was free for me because my friend took me out.  Yay.  I like the brick wall and the drinks really did me in.  Totally forgot what we ate for main course.  The desserts were filling.  We had some kind of brown chocolate bun cake, ice cream, and green flan.  The flan and the bun cake were nice!
author: Byron L.

description:
This is a great place for a date; we were on a date.  The waiter was wonderful and the wine was perfect.  

The rock shrimp appetizer was good, but basically tasted like lightly breaded fried shrimp with veggies.

The rabbit however tasted like chicken, the flavor was so mild one conjures up pictures of rabbits fed pellet food and caged.  I like my venison to taste like the deer has traveled and the rabbit to taste like rabbit.  Not hare mind you, rabbit!  Meh.

I've never seen so much veal on a menu either, ick.  

No dessert no coffee.  We closed the place, they were so nice about it.

I'd say the food got two stars and the service gets 5, so that's a 3 1/2.
author: JD D.

description:
One of my clients was in town for a conference, so my boss wanted to take them out to dinner.  The head honcho of the office suggested Perbacco.  Luckily, we made reservations because it was pretty packed on Thursday night.  There were alot of people at the bar enjoying their cocktails, and all the tables were full.  

I arrived 10 minutes early, but the client was even earlier.  They were already seated upstairs, so I had to entertain them until my boss arrived.  It can get pretty loud in the restaurant, so sometimes I would just nod my head and smile and pretend like I knew what they were talking about.

Once the boss arrived, we decided to order a bottle of wine.  The sommelier recommended two reds.  The client picked, but I can't remember the name....it was something Italian.  It was more of a full bodied wine, and once it had a chance to breathe, it was really good.  

I ordered the Seared Sea Bass and my boss had the Grilled Prather Ranch Sirloin Steak.  I think the clients got the Grilled Berkshire Pork Chop, some seared ahi tuna dish, and a veal dish.  My sea bass was delicious.  It was in a tomato stew with shrimp, mussels and clams.  Since we didn't order any appetizers, the portion was a tad bit on the small side for me.  All of the other dishes looked really good, but I couldn't exactly say, "hey..let me try some of that."  

The service was great.  Our waitress was quite attentive and made sure we always had everything we needed.  Our water glasses were always full, and our wine always topped off.  

If you need to use the restroom, find the elevator and head to the basement.  Its quite an interesting journey.  You exit the elevator from the back, and then you walk to a room with 4 doors.  Two M's and two W's.  Behind each door is a toilet and a sink, but there also sinks outside as well.  Kind of weird.  

With all the budget cuts and layoffs, I haven't had a free meal on the company in a while, so it was a great treat to dine here.  I'll definitely be back to try other dishes on the menu.
author: Patra I.

description:
This IS the new power lunch gathering spot and place to be seen at dinner.  Not only is it a HOT spot -- its actually very good, service is great, and NO attitude. 

The last time I was there for dinner, we ate all over the menu. We started with a bunch of apps, the house curred charcuterie was good but the octopus was phenomenal, never had I had such tender, melt in your mouth octopus as I did here (with ink and all). 

A pasta dish is a must to share before your main meal and we spit the risotto and it was sublime, creamy, aldente, and flavorful. 

I went with the swordfish and my guest had the lamb and both were over the top great. 

We washed all this food down with a nicely priced bottle of wine (needed to ask Umberto for help on the selection). 

All in all this is a go to place and I can't wait for the sister restaurant to open.
author: G R.

description:
I went to Perbacco for the first time last week to celebrate with a few coworkers. Let me start by saying that the food here is excellent. The olives and salted almonds were incredible. The bread was fantastic. My gnocci were exceptional. 

I do have to knock off one solid star for the service. While the wait-staff weren't out-right rude, I noticed that we did not receive the same level of service as some other customers sitting near us. It was kind of a disappointment.

If you do try Perbacco, I highly recommend the spiced almonds and olives - they are real treats!
author: Heather S.

description:
Just went here last night and had a fantastic time. Service and food was amazing.  I sat at the bar while I waited for the rest of my party to arrive since I was there 20 minutes before my reservation, and the bar staff was friendly and amazingly attentive. I ordered the brussel sprouts side dish to nibble on and it was literally in front of me within 5 minutes. It was melt in your mouse buttery brussel sprout goodness.  AND vegetarian, no chicken stock. One thing I really loved about the staff was how accommodating they were to my vegetarian needs, plus there were quite a number of vegetarian items already on the menu.

Onto dinner, I'll point out the highlights, which were pretty much everything. We made reservations to enjoy the special white truffle menu, along with a few items off their regular menu.

Regular menu:
Rabaton - fluffy pillows of delicious cheese and doughy goodness
Stuffed zucchini blossoms - it was ok, but we could've done without it
Oxtail risotto - I didn't try it since it had huge mounds of meat on top and the risotto was made with chicken stock, but I was told it was amazing. 

Special truffle menu:
I forget the actual names of the dishes, but I'll try my best to describe them, they were all topped with 3 grams of truffles, shaved table side:

Small delicate ravioli pasta filled with melt in your mouth cheese - I thought I didn't like ravioli, but apparently I just have never had good ravioli. I don't know what they did, but it was amazing. 

Egg noodles (I think) with pancetta and I believe a poached egg on top - I didn't taste this, but everyone at the table seemed to love it

Bone marrow risotto - again, I sadly could not try it, but the entire table also loved it

Dessert and cheese plate, which was comped due to the waiter spilling water on the table. We're an easygoing group, and we didn't mind at all. They quickly offered us the table next to us as they cleaned up the water. Super nice and attentive staff.

Blue cheese and a soft goat's milk ricotta, if I remember correctly, served with almonds, honey, and golden raisins on the side. Amazing melt in your mouth goodness.

Wine spiced sorbet - holy crap, I wanted to leave the restaurant with a pint of this stuff.  Refreshing and full of flavor, it was delicious!

Little hazelnut chocolate fudge and pistachio fudge - simple and yummy

We all left dinner completely satisfied and in foodie bliss.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Business lunch with the boss...always good...but even better b/c it was at Perbacco.  Co-worker had the Paparadelle with Short Rib Ragu...and literally sopped up every last bit of the sauce with his bread.  I had the Truffle-herb ricotta gnocchi w/ caramelized onions and wild mushrooms.  It was delish!  Perfect pairing of flavor from the onion and mushrooms with the  creamy-fluffiness of the gnocchi.  

Didn't get to have appetizer or dessert but will have to back and try the strawberry salad, and the brown butter cake with apricot.  yum!
author: Kelly K.

description: A-OK, that's all I can say.    Waiter was waaaaay too naggy and overly attentive and than sent his bus boy to do the same, trying to take plates away when there was food still on them......
author: Monster E.

description: Met a friend here for dinner last night.  The halibut entree is the best halibut I've ever had.  Perfect!  Nice place, I'll definitely come here again for that halibut.
author: SecretShopper 7.

description: Perfect place for a business lunch, the food is always done up well and the ambiance is pleasant.  My coworkers love the fish selections and the papardelle but for me the vegetarian, I enjoy their beet salads, soups and market greens with house dressing.
author: Shaw Y.

description: The breadsticks were so hard, they could chip your teeth. The cured meats weren't bad. My ribs were really good. The cod was delicious. Unfortunately, the mashed potatoes that came with the cod were just extremely salty. The service was excellent. I give 3 stars instead of 4 because for what I paid for the dinner, I expected to write a 5 star review and couldn't do it. Below my expectations on the overly salty mashed potatoes and nothing to write home about on the cured meats that everyone was having.
author: Alton Y.

description: Came here for a dinner party and ordered the tajarin (tagaliatelle with pork sugo) which was quite good.  The food and service were probably in line with my expectations considering all of the positive Yelp ratings this place has I expected a lot.  We sat in the upstairs dining area, while it is more private than the lower dining area, but somewhat claustrophobic since it has a low ceiling.  The upstairs decor also seemed a bit stale...but other than that, a great dining experience.
author: Kent W.

description:
Ate at the bar; food- excellent; service- eh (keeps me from providing a 5 star rating)

Some friends of mine ordered a couple cheeses- hard and soft-  recommended by a staff member; each was amazing and nuts (almonds), raisins, and a jam comes with... delish..  raisin nut bread was also brought but not quite enough.  It must be a commodity because when we asked for more to spread the cheese only a baguette was provided.
The Piastra Roasted octopus (octopus appetizer) was a MUST HAVE.  I have not had such great octopus since Bodrum, Turkey, where it is part of the common cuisine.  It came with a thin veal tongue tartare which was an absolute great accompaniment (for an at home version, use corn beef).
The salumi misti was a large appetizer which a great variety of meat... not sure what I ate (lardo was included)..be adventurous is all I can say!!
Now... for such a busy place it was difficult to get a bartender's attention!!   We were great customers for 2+ hours, and, though, most places want to nickel and dime you for a drink, at Perbacco you almost want to pay double in order to get prompt attention for a second glass of wine!   .... A friend of mine did not like her cocktail, and it was complimentarily replaced... no hassle, so, perhaps they aren't greedy on their liquor margins.
Bathrooms, strangely, were downstairs and a maze to find.... guess you don't want to order too much raw meat, or, get plastered on the cocktails.
author: Em H.

description:
Found the place on line as I was meeting someone coming to the city on BART.  It's an easy walk. Reservations were made on line..flawless..table ready on arrival.....Everyone was smiling..host, hostess, waiters.....modern vibe to the place...professional service, fabulous menu that changes daily
Pretty Northern Italian menu the day I was in, but a touch of the South as well....it was a wonderful surprise and one I'll visit again
author: Deb C.

description: Had a wonderful dinner at Perbacco tonight.  The main dining room is lively (and noisy) but very festive.  I had the sea scallops with caponata - dee-li-cious but I wish there more of them (only 4 scallops).  My friend had the truffle-infused fusilli, which was very tasty.  The best thing we ate was the grilled butternut squash with brown butter and pomegranates - WOW, this dish was amazingly rich and tasty!  Our waiter was really friendly and efficient - a good combination.  And the whole bill was under $100 for 2 people with drinks.  Really good value for a great meal.
author: Tony J.

description:
We were headed to Aqua when we decided to try this. It turned out to be a good choice, the prices here are quite good and the food was delicious. I suppose sometimes when one reads reviews that are great, the hype overwhelms the experience but when you just find a place and there's nothing to hope for ...that's the best.

We had pork shoulder, beef ribs, honeycomb tripe and squid and each of them was unique and satisfying. Have I mentioned how much I love the food in San Francisco. I've probably eaten at 70-75 places in my trips here and I would say that all but five of them have been a revelation. That's a ridiculous average and far better than any other city I've been in.

Food - A
Ambience - A-
Service - A-
Value - A-
author: Forrest D.

description: I sat at the bar with a friend and I felt that the service was the most distasteful in quite awhile. Just a turn off....I  wanted a wine but a good one otherwise whats the point and asked for recommendations and he recommended the most expensive glass but couldn't speak to it. I hate when people are so obvious about the tips they expect to receive based off of a % of the total bill.....then my friend, a beer connoisseur asked to see the label of a bottled beer since it sounded interesting and the bartender didn't like this.....i know they are busy and don't want to be bothered but since he once again can't speak to it....perhaps they just switched everything out on him so he didn't have time to know what they are offering at the moment nor the wine list ......then i ordered the octopus appie and never in my life have i had to cut fat off ...it was so chewy and very thick layer of fat....i guess octos DO have fat layers since they live in deep cold waters but never have i had to cut fat off ...i was wrestling with it ...just so i could chew...it looked pretty tho...i liked the pureed potato pesto type stuff  that it layed upon.....we decided to go and eat a meal somewhere else and i asked for the check "when u have time" i nicely added, then ...he says quite crudely and rudely DO YOU WANT SOMETHING ELSE TO EAT?.it was an uncomfortable silence after that.....why dud i want something else to eat when i just asked for the check when he has time? he didn't say it nicely, he said it as if it was required of me...we are at the bar....so then he brings the check....i decided to tip a dollar a drink , which is only 2 dollars plus an additional 18% of the food portion of the bill ..,,,,,,not tipping on the sf healthy tax and regular tax.... i took the the to calculate it out......wont be returning.....
author: First L.

description:
Perbacco met my expectations.  The service was non-pretentious and the dishes were mostly tasty.  The flavors didn't blow me away but price-wise, it was fairly reasonable.

I'd probably try somewhere else before coming back.
author: Ankur P.

description:
I absolutely loved Perbacco.

I sat at the bar with my Dad and Sister for a Stella Artois (poured perfectly) since we were early for our reservation. The salume platter was amazing.

After being seated, we were promptly given San Benedito water, which is the same water I obsessed over while I was in Italy. It is the best. I love that they have imported Italian "aqua frizzante".

I started with the beet salad with vinegarette, DE-LISH.

I had the grilled pork chop, which melted in my mouth. The bed of fennel it rested on was delightful as well.

A tad pricey, but totally worth it. I too BART into the City and only had to walk a block from Embarcadero BART. Very convenient. They have valet too, which is quite important.

Bomb.
author: Alison V.

description:
this place is pretty packed on a thurs night.  we had a reservation for 8 pm and were seated pretty promptly.  before ordering, we were brought breadsticks w/ pesto dip.

we each had a cocktail, and i had the perbacco which had ketel one citron and meyer lemon in it.  it tasted light, but apparently it had a lot of alcohol in it, b/c it hit me later!

after ordering, we were brought gigantic rolls, which i happily ate b/c i was starving,  we didn't have to wait long for our food to arrive though.  we got the strawberry and arugula salad, the beet salad, and the crudo to start, and they were all good.  the portions were pretty small, so we finished these up quickly.

we then each ordered the small portions of the pasta.  i got the pappardelle w/ short rib ragu, and my hubby got the meyer lemon ravioli w/ asparagus.  i LOVED the pappardelle, and the short rib just melted.  the small sized pastas were more than enuf, since we also got the brussel sprouts w/ capers and the honey roasted carrots on the side.  both veg sides were a good size, so by the end, we were stuffed.  

however, how can we leave w/o dessert?  we just shared the burnt caramel gelato w/ sea salt and a couple cookies w/ sunflower seeds on the side.  it was the perfect ending to a yummy meal.
author: Helen T.

description:
Nice lunch spot in the Financial District. I met a friend here for lunch and the food was quite tasty. 

The fried calamari appetizer was the highlight of the meal, fresh, hot, and light. 

The lamb main course was good, but a bit too mushy and a bit heavy on the salt.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
Food was mostly excellent, especially the gnochhi and tajarin.  The carmel gelato was a vertiable symphony of sweet and salty flavors - one of the best desserts I have ever had.

The Risotto with duck, plums, radicchio, and toma della rocca cheese was a bit busy.

Two things keep it from a 5-star rating:

1. The waitress didn't mention beforehand that the Salumi Misti included raw sausage...something of that magnitude is worth mentioning to the customer before a decision is made.  It was rather disconcerting when she brought it out.

I double-checked the menu this morning and it is not listed.  It lists "salsiccia di bra" but does not use the word "cruda" (raw)..."salsiccia cruda di bra" is listed as a separate item.  Either way, you can't expect most people in this country to read Italian well enough to figure this out.  

I mean, after a few months of Rosetta Stone Italian, I was good enough to be able to call the lost-and-found guy at the Venice train station and rap with him about how I lost my camera, where I had last seen it, how sad I would be to lose all my honeymoon pictures, etc. -- and I was still blindsided by the raw sausage!

2. They forgot to give us our doggie bag.  Yes, we forgot about it too until we were halfway home, but we were in a food coma....and we weren't the ones getting paid.

At the end of the day, still highly recommended - just know what you're getting into if you try the Salumi Misti plate.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Amazing! Best Italian I've ever tasted.


We ordered: 

Heirloom Tomatoes: Caramelized Shallot Vinaigrette, erbette, ricotta salata

Scarpinocc di Scimudin: Pasta (ravioli-like) filled with goat cheese, brown butter pear, walnuts, mosto cotto

Raviora: Pasta (ravioli-like) filled with ricotta di pecora and basil, blistered cherry tomatoes, basil, garlic oil

Brussels Sprouts: Brown butter, capers, shallots, parmigiano reggiano


The pasta was cooked perfectly. Al dente and somewhat chewy. The brussels sprouts had no hint of bitterness. The tomatoes were perfect.


Will definitely return if I ever find myself in San Francisco again.
author: Picky P.

description:
i wish there were 10 stars...or 20. My birthday dinner here was a class act from start to finish. 

do yourself a favor, get the salumi mixti. then an octopus salad. then do a pasta tasting. you will not need a main dish after that because you will be stuffed and fulfilled .

i had an awesome champagne drink too, with real strawberry puree in it that knocked my socks off.

i wish i had the money to go back right this second, it was so delicious. staff is epic too.GO HERE
author: Lauren V.

description: What a Wonderful restaurant.  Delicious unique food, Excellent service and a warm and attractive decor.
author: Gino S.

description:
il mio AMORE...love love love

A sensational spot to dine for everybody.

Mojito - 4.5 stars
Salumi Misti - 4 stars (a lot to try with various flavor & texture)
Squash Pasta with crush hazelnut - 5 stars (my favorite!)
Brown Butter Brussel Sprouts - 3 stars (a little soggy)
Beef Short Rib - 4 stars (tender & tasty)

I'll be back again...I need to try more food, in fact I plan to come back for my birthday with my girls...can't wait!
author: K L.

description:
Update: February 2011: Still 5-star quality food and service! Unbelievable!

Previous review:

A friend recommended this place to me for Mother's Day dinner for my wife. I have NO regrets. Okay, fellas, here's a recipe to put that smile on your woman's face:

1. Make reservation. Request a seat on the second level, in the back. the front near the bar area can get really loud.

2.  Browse Rossi & Rovetti's website. They're a premium, highly regarded florist in San Francisco.  Make your selection, and give instructions on where and when to deliver to Perbacco for your dinner evening.

3. Call Perbacco and make them note the florist delivery. Call back two more times later (a couple days before the dinner, and then again on the day of) to CONFIRM everything is scheduled as you want.

4. Take her to dinner. Forget street parking. Pay the money for valet and save yourself some stress. On the side confirm with the waiter/waitress that the flowers are in position BEFORE you are taken to the table.

5. Watch her reaction and rejoice your credit card was put to good use!

6. Order dinner and enjoy Perbacco's delicious menu items. Have a sentimental, romantic conversation. Have a card ready in which you've expressed your love, and possibly a gift to be served with dessert. The rest, gentlemen, I leave to your imagination.

Quality of Food: A+
Quality of Service: A+
General layout and setting: B+
author: Danny H.

description:
Service here is great. I was seated at a table for 2 despite making a reservation for 4, and upon notifying my waiter, he immediately apologized and corrected the mistake. Also, on short notice, I was able to put in a special touch on the meal and arrange for a birthday cake and card to come with the meal, for my friend.

Our waiter was very honest. When asked to recommend champagne, he recognized that it was not his expertise and asked the sommelier to help us. But on questions of food, he knew his stuff.

Why 3 stars? The food tasted very good - the house salami is always a fantastic array of charcuterie. But the entrees arrived at our table, cold and lifeless. For the pork shoulder, that was ok, but for the gnocchi and the risotto, it really ruined both the flavor and texture. I think it would have tasted better if I'd gone home and microwaved the two items. Mmm mmm - I'm a microwave chef master.
author: Richard Z.

description:
I heard so many good things about this place and when I went, I was very, very disappointed.   

I spent a lot of time in Italy during my youth and this isn't the food I had grown to love.

The service was horrendous!  I'm a senior citizen and I felt out of place in this restaurant.   

I try to instill humor in my reviews, but there wasn't anything funny about my experience.  

I will not go back to Perbacco again!

The owner contacted me after reading my review.   I had blocked owners from contacting me, but he circumvented this by using his quasi-private yelp account.   

I find this unacceptable.  The owner of this establishment shouldn't get bent out of shape over a one star review.   It's part of business.  It's part of life.

The guy has yelp envy...
author: Randal P.

description: I came to Perbacco for to satisfy a Friday night Italian craving. The menu was a little overwhelming as several options sounded right up my alley. The waiter was really helpful in providing some guidance as he claimed that the raviolo shouldn't be missed. The soft pasta enveloped a luscious, rich filling of truffled-polenta, egg, and corn-truffle butter. Definitely not a dish for the faint of heart. It was quite good, but I wouldn't say it couldn't be missed. The same doesn't hold for my entree, however, the seared sea scallops. The scallops were delicious, perfectly seared and the celery root puree was amazing. It was an exceptional dish and if it's offered the night you happen to come in I highly recommend it. The ambiance was nice, although I would say the tables were a little too close for my taste, or maybe the person next to me just doesn't know how to use an "inside voice." My meal didn't shake up to be classic Italian but it did stand out as a fantastic experience. I highly recommend Perbacco.
author: Stephen S.

description: Excellent Saturday night out with the girls, lovely food with great service.  Got our table right away, good times, was fun.
author: Robyn R.

description: We are sitting at the counter bar now after dinner. Service and food are excellent.  The ambiance is Asian, not at all any version of Italian. Probably took over a failed Japanese restaurant and did their best to give it appropriate ambiance without much investment.  Fair enough but we prefer the ambiance matches the ethnic theme. If you want either a modern or traditional Italian dining experience then there are many other options in SF.
author: Jim P.

description:
Another great Italian restaurant.  This was my second time dining here, and all I could remember was they had great salads and incredible pastas!  We went as a table of six, and my only complaint was that it was a little to loud to really have a nice conversation as a table.  It's okay, because the food made up for it all. I started with their heirloom tomato salad and then the boneless ribs with a bone marrow sauce.  All very exquisite!!  My husband had the mission fig and endive salad, with the parpadelle pasta, and both were simply divine!!!  All this, and a bottle of Paradigm cabernet, and we were off to a great dinner.  Dessert was okay.  Not great, just nothing memorable.  Service was good, nothing memorable either, but I certainly don't have any complaints about it.  

So, for consistently delicious dishes, I highly recommend this place.  There are hundreds of great restaurants in San Francisco, and this is just one of them.  So if you're in the neighborhood, go for it!  

Right next door is their sister restaurant called Barbacco.  It's a little more casual, and I love it for lunch! So check them both out!  They're equally great.
author: louis a.

description:
I think this place is over-rated!  Just had lunch with my other 5 co-workers today!  After reading all the good reviews from Yelp, I would expect more but it turned out "so-so" to me!  

The ambiance was great, hip and trendy!  The service was fast and friendly.  But the food were just OK to me.  First, the bread was not fresh and so-so.  

The food that we ordered:

Appetizers:
1.  Salumi Misti - Highly recommended from the servers and yelpers but I think it was lacking something (maybe it was just me).  We split the appetizers but we did not finish it.....
2.  Roasted Red and Gold Beets - OK but nothing special
3.  Market Salad - Again, nothing special

Pasta:
1.Paccheri (large Pasta Tubs with Albacore Tuna) - It looked OK but my co-worker did not finish her dish
2.I ordered Truffle (Ricotta Gnocchi) - A little bit salty to me 

Main Course:
1.Two of my co-workers ordered Hanger Steaks and two orders of Beef Short Rib - The Hanger Steaks looked much better than the Short Rib.  My co-workers said the short rib was a little salty and they liked the short rib at Tiramisu more (another Italian restaurant in Financial District).  

Dessert:
We have ordered Gelato and Butterscotch Budino which were not that good.  I don't think you need to save room for that!

I'd probably try somewhere else before coming back!
author: Liza T.

description:
My second meal here followed many, many months of lusting to go back.  The likelihood of disappointment was high, but Perbacco really pulled through.  I think two aspects of their menu are really worth highlighting - the salumi and the pasta.  The salumi might be cured on site, and if not, it's freshly sliced and there are several options every night.  The pasta is freshly made and there are many, many unique options that don't involve words like Bolognese or manicotti.  They have a (seemingly) new addition to the menu where you can do a pasta tasting for the table.  It worked out wonderfully - we got 3 small pasta servings each which was basically the portion equivalent of an entree. 

The wine list is great and my Barbera did not disappoint.  There are probably 20 nice types of wine by the glass in addition to the numerous bottle choices.  When I came here the first time, I had such outstanding cocktails that they could have been reason enough to come back.  This time, my drink (the eponymous Perbacco) was good, but nothing to swoon over.  I think it was a blip, so no poor marks on that account.

Go here!  It's really, really great.
author: Erika H.

description:
ah! My favorite new restaurant in the Financial District!

The interior is beautiful and the service was top notch. Our waitress offered excellent suggestions (I was having a rare, indecisive evening so that was greatly appreciated!). I wish I had posted my review right after dinner, it's been a few weeks so I can't remember what that DELISH cocktail that almost put me under the table I had was but I remember there were many good looking options to select from. My cohort recommended that we order the Burrata cheese. So good! And great along side of the market salad as starters. For dinner I enjoyed the potato gnocci with asparagus and stole bites of the tajarin and brussel sprouts at our table. Wonderful food and perfect portion sizes!

I can't wait to go back!
author: j k.

description: Love this place. Great atmosphere. Food is great. A little expensive but this is SF! But service sometimes is spotty.
author: Rob L.

description:
Perbacco is an Italian restaurant in the financial district which has a reputation for 'authentic/traditional' Italian cuisine.

I ate there on Tuesday evening and the place was packed. Since we didn't have reservations, there was a 20-30 minute wait and we decided to sit at the bar.

There were several people 'behind' the bar but only 1 bartender. It took about 10 minutes for the bartender to 'acknowledge' us and another 5-10 minutes to get drinks. Terrible bar service, hint: hire another bartender.

The waiter was much more prompt and I never had an empty glass. I ate the grilled prather ranch sirloin steak dinner with the grilled torpedo spring onion, arugula and gorgonzola butter. Ate the steak which was average and left the veggies/filler. 

Personally, I have had better Italian and felt this place was a little over rated. Maybe waiting 20 minutes at the bar for a drink left a bad taste in my mouth but I wouldn't recommend this restaurant.
author: Rob H.

description: Pasta is amazing, with perfect wine selection. Atmosphere is a little loud.
author: Mike L.

description:
I love Barbacco next door, so I took someone from work to Perbacco for dinner (same owners).   Unfortunately, it was not that great.

Reasons: our waitress forgot about us and was borderline obnoxious when she did come over; wood fired octopus was tough and lacked flavor; pasta was hard on top from sitting under the heat lamp too long.
author: workingstiff f.

description:
Thank you yelpers for recommending the salumi plate, we got it as our starter and it was really good!

The restaurant is larger than it looked from the outside, seating is plentiful and service is friendly! Food was delicious, especially the ricotta gnocchi!  Will be back for more!!
author: Florence W.

description:
# 18. (2009) & #20 (2010) Big Eat SF - Salumi misti plate

my friend and I made a reservation last minute on a Friday for lunch - earliest was 1:45.  though intimidated that we were probably below dress code, given Friday casual jeans isn't business casual, we ventured anyway.

The plate itself was great.... a lot of fat...., but then again, fat is flavor. our favorite were the two slivers of the "house" salami

other food (we sneakily shared everything) - 
crispy flavorul breadsticks with wonderful pesto dip
awesome Jerusalem artichoke soup 
brussel sprouts side (and I normally hate those)
ricotta gnocchi with amazing savory mushroom/asparagus bits and sauce. 
plus really oily but yummy foccacia (as much as you want to sop up the sauce!)

... and we were full. ~$50 to split for lunch without eating any actual entree and sharing to be careful of the cost... but much more generous portions than we expected from a fancy place in FiDi.

oh, and they had free coat check at the door (rainy season!)
author: S V.

description:
Good service, good food, good ambiance. I enjoyed this place with my gf...great place to go on a date. I do not like raw tomatos but my lady does, i compromised 

Heirloom Tomato Salad w/ burrata- 9/10   
       Like I said dont like tomatos, except when I had this dish.  Amazing.    Burrat cheese(like mozz) with corn olive oil and yes this one is a winner. 
 
Trio of pasta/ gnochi, pappardelle with short rib ragu, pesto-8/10
      So the gnochi was pillowtastic like it shoud be, tomato sauce was good, not great, but the gnochis themselves were perfectly cooked. the pappardelle was amazing the standout of the trio. the pesto was ok neither of us finnished it.
author: Jason C.

description:
Went to Perbacco for a work event and was generally pleased by the food. We had a set menu and 4 courses, and for my main I ended up with the beef short ribs stracatto with the sweet potato puree which was much better than I anticipated. 

However, one of the salads/courses prior, there was a beet salad that I really wasn't a fan of-- while it was pleasant, it was a touch too sweet and I could have passed on it. 

For our appetizer though, they presented us with an absolutely amazing shrimp and calamari duo, which was perfect-- the seasoning on the seafood was absolutely perfect. 

Dessert was sort of molten chocolate cake, which was served with a dollop of creme, but really ought have been served with ice cream instead, because the cake was SO incredibly rich. 

All in all, the food was great, and the short ribs were surprisingly good (I am normally not a short ribs person, but didn't want the scallops), and will likely come back for the normal menu another time with friends.
author: Melissa D.

description: We really enjoyed our meal - service was excellent, as was the seared octopus appetizer and burnt caramel gelato with pignoli cookies.
author: Sallie G.

description: We had lunch here today.  The service was A+.  Food was also great.  We shared two starters, the burrata/asparagus dish which was perfectly prepared and so, so fresh.  We also had the shrimp fritto mista which was delish. For entrees I had the gnocchi with chanterelles and rabbit.  The gnocchi themselves were perfection.  The flavors were great.  The rabbit was a tiny bit dry but the overall flavors in this dish were delightful.  Husband had the pappardelle w/short rib and it was outstanding.  We share everything, the pappardelle was his favorite dish.  Mine was probably the burrata/asparagus dish.  I don't eat dessert so ordered TWO for him when he was in the bathroom.  He was really, really full after the meal so he thought the panna cotta would be best but I had them sneak in the chocolate bonet as well. He went nuts over both and ate all of it. He thought both were original.  He is a dessert snob so when I tell you he gave these 9/10 stars you know they're off the hook.
author: Ottis M.

description: Very nice team dinner.   Service was very good, dinner options were solid.  Wine provided was good.
author: Mike T.

description: Really good pastas.  Tess the server was really nice and the hostess Chia was attentive and friendly.  I thought the scallop main dish looked really great, the table next to me ordered it and it looked really great.  I am also leaning toward getting the shrimp appetizer next time.
author: Jim J.

description:
Ambiance: B+ - Great posh location with an intimate dining room and a louder than expected bar area in front.  Looks like a banker's paradise given the FiDi location.

Food: A- - Overall, great food executed well.  We started with a pear salad which was a wonderful prelude to two pasta main courses: the paparadelle with short rib ragu and a butternut squash ravioli.  Very good paparadelle, wide ribbons of al dente pasta with slightly less than expected amount of short rib.  Butternut squash was nothing to complain about but not out-of-park.  I think I'll try the Tajarin next time since everyone around us got it.  We ended with coffee and a panna cotta with mandarin orange compote which was so-so.

Price: Relatively low prices with almost all pasta dishes under $20 for an entree size.  The meat/fish courses were closer to the $30 range but I would definitely come back to try their other pastas.

Service:  Prompt, courteous service that was not overbearing.  Recommended a good glass of white with the meal.
author: Roger W.

description: I was hopeful that this place would be great after reading all of their yelp reviews, however it was just the apposite "extremely disappointing".  Upon arriving for our reservations my wife (whose birthday we were celebrating" and I had to wait roughly fifteen minutes to be shown to our table, this wasn't a big ordeal but there were plenty of open table's. Finally after being sat to our table our waiter made her way over to us within 5 minutes and explained the menu to us, from which we told her we were now ready to order. Unfortunately she didn't have her order pad and said she would be back in a minute. Luckily I didn't hold my breath as it took her nearly 20 minutes to come back and take our order, and  I think it would have taken longer if only  the manager didn't see that I was getting pretty pissed and then approached her and asked her to get to the table.
