Now came the waiting game my wife ordered risotto and I got some sort of pasta that she said was the closest thing they had to a tomato sauce, some appetizers, and tea. Let me tell you I was only hopeful to see the service improve from here on but it only got worse, I asked the waitress for some napkins back when we first asked her to take our order when she didn't have her note pad.  After sitting at the table for roughly 40 minutes I only got the appetizers and my tea. The food was good but that's about it, I had better service from fast foo joints them I had from this place what a dissapointment.
author: Vlad M.

description:
I am beyond amazed at how much I loved this place. Service 5 stars, appetizers 5 stars, main course 5 stars, and desert 5 Star's one con-very noisy during lunch, would want to try dinner sometime. 

Today we had for the appetizers the Salumi Misti, Vitello Tonnato, Piastra Seared Local Squid and the Fritto Misto of Rock Shrimp. Please note this was split between 4 adults. They were all amazing, but my over all favorite was the Vitello Tonnato, Slow Roasted Veal. And I NEVER EAT VEAL! 

My main course was the Rabaton: Truffle-Herb Ricotta Gnocchi with Roasted Mushroom Sugo-Pretty impressed with the mushrooms and the Gnocchi was cooked perfectly. 

For Desert: Brutti Ma Buoni and the Citrus Semifreddo-OMG-don't think I need to day more! 

It's really good-amazing and if its not on your foodie list, then add it....
author: Olivia W.

description:
Part Italian, part business exec--Perbacco is a rare combination of decadent Italian wine/food and men in suits brokering deals. Love the exposed brick and modern design in the bar area, as it really adds to the vibe.

The salumi, risotto with scallops, and appetizers like the crispy pig's trotters are some of my faves (mmm...). Wine pours are generous, martinis less so (they seem to come in small-ish glasses--then again it IS straight vodka) and service is extremely well-trained and competent. 

You'll never be wondering where your entree is, why your water glass isn't full, or where that next glass of wine is. If you're a dine and dash type person, you'll love it.

With that said, if you're on a romantic date or out with a good friend who you'd like to linger with, I'd suggest a seat at the bar or another establishment just because this isn't a 3-hour, European chat and linger type of place. Not that they rush you exactly, but courses tend to come out fairly fast and close together and the atmosphere is not one in the dining room that encourages you to stay and talk for hours. The various servers and food runners clear silverware, plates, etc between courses so if you order multiple items they come by quite frequently which can be a little invasive. It's really the perfect place to come with coworkers though--I'd bring my boss here in a heartbeat.

Food and wine is fab...love the bar area...a little "meh" about the dining room in terms of design.
author: Britt M.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for his 39th birthday dinner, especially from Chicago.  The staff was exceptionally helpful, and went out of their way to make sure he felt special on his day! They arranged for us to sit at a central table, and even wrote him a card wishing him a happy birthday. As if that was not enough, the cocktails were fantastic, the server was very well versed and the food was to die for. Totally worth the walk downhill from the Fairmont. Very happy to recommend to all of my friends.
author: Oana A.

description:
Great place for people watching. I had dinner here a while back and saw old dudes with hot young chicks, date night couples, old couples co-mingling with other old couples (orgy, anyone?), and so on and so forth. Sitting in the back room area was the perfect location for checking out the "scene".

The food was OK. Breadsticks were fun to eat. The meat/cheese plate was decent. The lamb was good actually. 

I give four stars for the ambiance and company I was with. Three stars for the food. I'll round up, cause, hey, I'm generous like that.
author: Dave T.

description: Went for work dinner, absolutely delicious, and they have a fantastic wine menu. Worth it if you're expensing, but probably not a good idea for a date night if you don't want to break the bank.
author: Aaron M.

description: I had the sole, was cold, had to send it back. It came back in under 5 minutes, nice and warm but it wasn't that great.  My friend had some kind of ravoli and liked it.  I was not impressed with the restaurant as a whole.  We were seated in the large alcove section near the back that was pretty full.  It was very warm and a little uncomfortable after a glass of wine.  (Granted it was before Christmas and it was obvious a lot of people were there for a holiday lunch, as was I).  The service was impeccable and that is why I gave 3 stars.  I will probably give Perbacco another try, some day.
author: Brenda G.

description: Came here for nye and ordered the paperdelle with short rib ragu, duck, and artichoke hearts salad. The paperdelle was my favorite...noodles are cooked perfectly and the beat if juicy and flavorful. We also ordered the pistachio cake and salted caramel gelato. The salted caramel gelato is a must try!!! Our waitress was also very friendly and the service was amazing!
author: Sarah C.

description: Unfortunately I've been 3 - 4 times hoping it will get better but it's just pretty uninspiring and ordinary. And at these prices it shouldn't be. Barbacco next door and owned by the same people is much better, although not as snazzy in decor.
author: Josh F.

description:
Very good food.
Very good service.
Great location.
Warm, sophisticated atmosphere.
Affordable price.

The cliche of reviews.
author: Alejandro G.

description:
Tried to make a reservation on Open Table the day of dining. Could only get 2:30 and 9:45, so called the restaurant directly and got a reservation for 7:45. No Open Table points but, oh well. We arrived way early and were seated immediately, upstairs. Very nice! It is noisy up there and the lighting is eerie. Skinny bread sticks and olive oil basil dip are on the table. The skinny bread sticks did not taste good. Ordered a delicious beer from the Piedmont region of Italy. Best Italian beer I've ever had. We also ordered a bottle of Italian sparkling water. Rolls (Acme..delicious) and butter (sweet cream..yum) arrived...so good. We ordered the 3 pasta sampler as an appetizer...AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN FILLED WITH ROASTED VITELLONE AND SAVOY CABBAGE / SUGO D"ARROSTO,PAPPARDELLE - WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / GRATED HORSERADISH, and another pasta filled with butternut squash and garnished with nuts. All the flavorings for the pasta were delicious. Unfortunately, the pasta was a bit mushy. The guy ordered SEARED SEA SCALLOPS / WILD MUSHROOMS AND SAVOY CABBAGE / RED WINE BUTTER..and was told there would be 4 scallops. There were three and we were told that was because they were unusually large. They were large? What do the small ones look like? They must have the diameter of a bottle cap. We ordered two vegetables on the side:BROCCOLI DI CICCO / BAGNA CAÔDA BUTTER and GARLIC...wonderful...a hint of anchovy butter,PAN ROASTED FENNEL / MEYER LEMON / OLIVE OIL..very nice. Perbacco was a bit of a disappointment. I think part of this is because we had a spectacular meal at Babbo in NYC recently and thought this might be similar. This is not at all fair, I know...two different places.

Easy access from Embarcadero BART...moderately priced.
author: Bleep S.

description: Perbacco is a festive place to please the palette and take a little vacation in the middle of the work day. One of my favorites I keep returning to in the Financial District.
author: Nicky D.

description:
I finally had my Sixteen Candles moment.  No, not sitting on a table kissing Jake Ryan (although he was quite dreamy, sigh) but my mom forgot my birthday!  Ok, she was out of town at the time but they do have phones in Canada, right?  So the next day I call her and don't say anything...we talk for a few minutes and she hangs up without a word. Five minutes later she calls back and starts singing Happy Birthday (a family tradition) and then apologizes over and over.  To make it up to me she took me to Perbacco for lunch a few days later.

I've heard mixed reports on Perbacco but based on my one lunch there I quickly added it to my list of favorite new restaurants.  There was a ton of great options on the menu so we ended up splitting three appetizers (grilled squid, house made salumi plate and burrata) and one pasta (the gnocchi)  Everything was fantastic!  And portion size was huge...we were stuffed and had a bit of each leftover to take home.  

To round out the meal our waitress brought out a trio of gelato (including a fantastic salted caramel) on a plate that had "Happy Birthday" spelled out in chocolate.  Hey, at least our waitress didn't forget my birthday.

The little things really stood out at Perbacco-the complimentary dessert, the biscotti that came with my coffee, the three different cookies served alongside the gelato, super friendly service from our waitress and the manager on duty who stopped by our table to check in.  I will definitely be back soon to try dinner at Perbacco.
author: phil h.

description: It's been almost a year since I last ate at Perbacco, but it is an excellent, elegant spot for lunch or dinner in the Financial District.  Summer bean salad with heirloom tomatoes was excellent.  Main course was the beef short rib, which was cooked perfectly, tasty and tender.  I don't remember what dessert was (cheesecake?) but it was delicious.  Excellent California cuisine in a great location and a great interior.  Service was good: attentive without being rushed.  Prices are very reasonable given the quality of the food and service.  Definitely need to go back.
author: Charles W.

description:
Perbacco is definitely suitable for business type lunch venue.  Everyone is wearing suits and talks quietly which I can appreciate.  Service is very good, the servers, bread folks are quite attentive to your needs.  

I'm only giving it 3 stars because after 2 visits, there really isn't much to say about the food.  Everything seem to taste like mushrooms - the desserts aren't exactly fantastic either.  I would say their Gnocchi is cooked to perfection but the flavor lacks something - maybe they can grate more cheese on top or spice it up a bit.

This place has fantastic wine selection and cocktail menu - so if you're in the mood for some apres work drinks, this place isn't too bad.
author: Cathryn C.

description: This place is nice for a romantic dinner. The food is good. I had the Sea bass and the octopus appetizer. The octopus was amazing I wish the serving was bigger I would have made that as my main meal. The sea bass was good but nothing special, I've had better. Overall nice experience just don't know if this place would be a place I could be a regular at.
author: Janine D.

description: I'd say this is really 3 1/2.  It's good. Service is great ingredients are top notch it just doesn't have any real feel to it.  It's just a personal thing.  I guess it feels like a restaurant meal instead of one like a home cooked meal and when it's Italian I prefer the latter even if ingredients are never as good and food can be inconsistent. This is safe for a business lunch though.
author: Jayk K.

description:
Last year, soon after I wrote my 3-star review, the proprietor of Perbacco, Umberto, messaged me to apologize for the service and to thank me for the positive comments I had on the food. He said he hoped I'd be back and to make sure to introduce myself when I did.

Well, I did return - 12 months later. I'm not the type to to call in favors so I didn't seek him out when I arrived, but he made a point to find me. He sat our party of 7 at the chef's table, where we ended up dining for almost 4 hours on a Monday evening. Service was impeccable this time around, and food as delectable as my previous trip. 

We wanted to do family style, so we ordered several apps (would recommend the squid, pork pate, and veal tartare) and let the server decide how we'd mix 'n match our pastas and meats for our entrees. 

He brought us a "pasta tasting", which I would recommend if you have 4 or more people. It came out to 1.5 portions of 3 pastas, and they plated each pasta for us individually. It's the best way to eat pastas really, because a full portion of one just isn't as fun as trying a little of 3. The best one was the agnolotti with veal -- absolutely delcious.

We shared 4 "meats" (seared ahi, duck, pork,  beef short ribs). All were wonderful, but I especially liked the duck (hands down, the best duck I've ever had). The beef short ribs was also very, very good. 

But what impressed me the most was that Umberto made that initial effort after my first review, and stayed true to his word when I came back. He didn't need my business -- the place was packed on Monday night. But you can tell he truly cares about his patrons and their experiences; the excellent food and service was an added bonus.

Finally, the food is so different than what you normally find at high-end SF restaurants, even other high-end Italian restaurants, that I think Perbacco can be a destination restaurant for out-of-towners. It's so much more interesting than Gary Danko's, for example. And the prices are very reasonable (we had probably two too many dishes + 3 bottles of wine, and it came out to $95/person).
author: Veronica S.

description: Came here for an anniversary meal and we loved every bite. Good veg options, nice flavor combinations, good quality of freshness and all well executed. Fabulous deserts. Loved the presentation. Liked the decor. Service was good, not super friendly but not rude or anything. Sometimes we aren't in the mood to chat with the waiters anyway so that was really a plus. Absolutely no complaints.
author: Misha F.

description:
For a place that maintains 4 stars after 433 reviews....Id say its probably worth going to.  I realize that i cant normally afford these luxuries. The expensive meal, the wine...but when the company is treating...hell yes, Im in.  Oh, and when our party of 6 sat at the high table...we knew we were ballers.  

We did have a cap as to how much we could spend, but it never felt like we were limited.  Beets, procuitto, cheese, salami, we ordered a bunch of appetizers and they were all worth sampling.

Being the healthy eater I am, as of late anyway, I opted for the halibut.  For someone who expects small portions at expensive restaurants, I was pleased.  I couldnt even finish my buttery, flaky fish.  But man was it tasty.  The pastas and salads that were ordered at the table looked nice as well.

And yes...of course we got dessert.  We had a panacotta, a chocolate cake, and a creme brule...but im pretty sure the desserts are in constant switcheroo mode..so dont hold your breath.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Perbacco is everything I'd want in an expense account lunch (especially if it is someone else's expense account we're utilizing!). It's a sleek but warm and inviting space, perpetually boisterous with a clientle that exudes success, and that was even without me checking up the equally busy second floor. 

Our waiter was efficient but friendly, and our food arrived almost too quickly after ordering (is there such a thing as fast food fine dining?). That said, my Tajarin pasta was a culinary marvel of flavors:  handcut tagliatelle with a 5-hour pork sugo over it, porcini mushrooms, divine. The three of us split the gelati misti - a trio of chocolate, hazelnut and caramel with vanilla sea salt - for dessert.  

Looking over the other selections of pastas and main courses, I can only foresee more visits to Perbacco in the future, be that for lunch or in the evening. Not just a nice addition t the Fi-Di, the place is a pleasure for all of San Francisco.
author: Nish N.

description:
P- Prompt service (Our resos were for 6:15 and they sat us at 6:00)

E-Eager bread man who kept appearing all magician-like and bringing additional sourdough rolls.

R- Really gross pear/gorgonzola salad.  Duck was very fatty.  Fortunately, since I only ate 8 bites total at Perbacco I am a little less fatty.

B- Be back?  Moi?  Nah.. third time wasn't a charm for this place.

A- Actually, I did like the rolls...

C- Can't justify $100+ for sourdough though. So no, I won't willingly return.

C- Crap! Carbs DO have a way of calling my name in that sweet, sweet way.

O- Okay, I'm not coming back.  Sorry Perbacco, can't do it.
author: Janney B.

description:
This little piggy went to market. 
This little piggy stayed home.  
This little piggy had roast beef.  
This little piggy had none.  
This little piggy cried "Wee! Wee! Wee!" all the way home. 

Well, in actuality, this little piggy *me* went to all the way to Perbacco and had some suckling piggy served with a blood orange and arugula salad.  What can I say?  I'm a sucker for finger suckling good piggies.  And this piggy was very tasty.  Tasted like buttery textured ham.  Why did I order this though?  I just had ham for Easter dinner and pork loin and bacon last night.  Oh yes, because I dine on swine and love to fork the pork.
author: Christina S.

description:
Perbacco = Little Italy in New York but really in San Francisco

This ristorante boasts a grand brick wall that welcomes local San Franciscans to New York and feeds them as a French person residing in Italy would. Their dishes are amazing! I hear the pasta is out of this world, however, having come here for a private dining event, I was only able to select from the filet mignon or sea bass. The filet was superb, the mash potatoes were a tad on the salty side, and the chocolate volcano cake melted in my mouth. 

After 3 hours of eating and mingling, my private dining party and I went back downstairs, walked past the large brick walls and left New York. We opened the doors leading outside and were greeted by cable cars...
author: Sue L.

description:
The food was great.  The noise level was deafening.  3.5 stars.

One does not cancel out the other, but it does take away from the experience.  What happens when a restaurant that is already loud is that the real loudmouths turn it up several notches so that their voices end up piercing through you like bars of steel.  I think I heard every annoying laugh in existence.

Funny choice for a date place, although that is who we were surrounded by.  I know this for a fact because we could hear every word of our neighbors' conversation, and boy, I wish those two on the right of us good luck.

I was there for a date with my husband to celebrate Mr. S's and my 20th anniversary of our first date.  Sweet occasion.  The lighting gave him a migraine (candles on the table would add much-needed warmth), and we couldn't hear each other.  Not terribly romantic.

Despite everything, I thoroughly enjoyed my food.  We started with the Chef's Choice Salumi Platter which was delicious.  They cure their meats in house, and each type was tender and tasty and full of interesting flavors.  The blood sausage was the standout for me, unique and with amazing depth.

The next dish was my favorite of the evening:  the Baccala, or Spicy Salt Cod Fritters.  This is a generous dish and should be shared.  God, those things were heavenly - fried spheres filled with creamy, spicy salt cod.  Hubby had the Frito Misto, which was also good - I liked that it included unusual ingredients like fennel and olives in the mix.

For dinner, I had the Braised Spareribs, which were very good.  Wonderfully tender with a tangy tomato sauce, they were filling but not overwhelming.  I loved the polenta, too.

For dessert, we shared the Semmifreddo, which made with milk chocolate with hazelnut cookies mixed in - dense, creamy, decadent.  This is a huge dessert, perfect to share.

The service, which I was wary of after having read the reviews, was uneven.  At times, very attentive, at other times, lacking.  We were very looked-after at the beginning of the meal, but were searching for our server by the end.

The food has an intimate, hand-crafted feel, but unfortunately the atmosphere has the opposite effect.  If you are in the Fidi and need a spot for a corporate dinner, I think you'd be fine.  If you are looking for a place to take a date, or have an in-depth conversation, I would look elsewhere.
author: Liz S.

description:
So, Today was my second time visiting this charming place.

I walked in late in the afternoon for lunch as is my style.

It's 3pm and the hostess is so sorry to say that they stopped serving lunch at 2:30. 

I really didn't want to stay for the bar menu......When Saint Maria (manager) comes up to me and scoops me up and away to the bar and asks me if I'm willing to order Pasta . .....I can still order off the lunch menu for about the next five minutes because the Pasta Chefs were still there......

Far be it from me not to order homemade pasta from Perbacco when The Pasta Gods are obviously beckoning......

AND,.....There were a lot of pasta dishes to decide upon Thankfully.

 So I chose a Ravioli Style pasta filled with Chard (Spinich Family) and Riccotta with Olive Oil, and Butter and Nuts....it melts in your mouth .

Maria had it herself that day and recommended it and I think it's what bonded us at the end of the afternoon...along with girl talk of course !

Isn't it funny how good food does that with people, you start talking about the food and then everything else flows.

First, There is no substitute for fresh homemade Pasta. The flavor of their Pasta is rich and tasty and so easy to eat.  I don't know the recipe and I'm sure they'll never tell me  !

Second, Their ingredients are Fresh and True to their flavors.

Third, I think it's safe to say their Chef knows what he's doing and don't ask me his name.

Eating at the bar this afternoon was a really lovely way to celebrate becomming a Elite Yelper.

I'm just around the corner from this place and I'll be back.

Oh, The waitstaff are so professional and efficient. They can't do enough for you.  I Love That

Along with being a bit hot !
author: Katherine N.

description: This is one of favorite restaurants. A little strong taste for me, but good service and atmosphere.
author: Ted R.

description:
Absolutely amazing restaurant. Very simple but well prepared food. We had reservations at 8, arrived at 8, and were seated in only a few minutes. Very efficient considering how busy they were.

We started with the salumi misto plate, it definitely didn't disappoint. I think my favorite was the blood sausage...excellent balance of flavors.

For my entree, I chose the hanger steak. I asked for it medium rare...more rare than medium and it came out absolutely perfect. The salad and potatoes were very simple but were delicious. 

Our server was very attentive and knew the menu well. She even went as far to ask us if we wanted to wait to fire the entrees while we let the salumi plate settle. I love people who don't make assumptions.

Final price (including 2 bottles of wine) $160 for two people. Excellent value for the meal and atmosphere.
author: William W.

description:
Went here with some friends/coworkers. Wasn't thoroughly impressed but it was just fine.

The place: very classy and chic place, lots of financial district workers coming for drinks or a nice dinner with others.

Service: Ehhhh, so-so. I like that they don't rush you in any means. We ended up having a 3-hour dinner, but that was partially us and partially them. They didn't take our entree orders for about 30 minutes after we got our wine and apps. And then we kept having to order with other servers because our server was dilly-dallying elsewhere.

DRINKS - bottle of CHIANTI, unfortunately I have no idea what we ordered because I did not order it, but they have a VERY VAST list of wines that are awesome, and the chianti we had was very delicious

APPETIZERS
Salumi Misti plate
- plate full of different salami. I suggest this if you have more than 3 people eating from it. My friend and I had to eat the entire plate, a bit too much salami for two, and too many different pig parts and other animal parts that didn't need to be mentioned to us
Hamachi Crudo
- very good and refreshing; highly encourage getting this; only 3 pieces

DINNER:
Pappardelle
- nothing spectacular; however, the home-made pasta was delicious and perfectly al dente. Tasted like goulash.
My friends had the scallops which were perfectly cooked and delicious with the sauce. Other friend had the sea bass, which I did not taste but looked great with mussels

DESSERT:
MIASCIA - APPLE BREAD PUDDING
- better of the two we had, still warm and melts in your mouth but not the best thing I've had
HAZELNUT BUDINO
- did not enjoy at all. came with a pudding-type custard thing which had a weird tangy taste to it
- the chocolate ganache was too bitter
- the small crackers were the only good thing about the dessert

Overall, I expected more out of this restaurant, with the way it looks and it's prices. However, dinner was satisfying but nothing spectacular. Not likely how much I'll go back, unless I know someone who knows complete Italian and knows what's the best thing to order.
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: Went here for a business lunch.  We were seated in a timely fashion.  The noise level was not bad.  The service was prompted.  I had what the waitress said was one of their "signature dishes," the tajarin -- hand-cut tagliatelle with pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.  It was very good, but the pasta didn't appear to be tagliatelle (it was much narrower) and the dish had an interesting yellow saffron-esque color.  Overall, it was quite good.
author: Dave K.

description:
I just had a fabulous dinner!

Tadich Grill right next door was bursting at the seams as we sauntered in a 7;!5 on a Thursday night., so we made our way over to Perbacco right next door.  This place was super busy too, but they offered us a bar table at the front right away where we could order from the full menu - right on! 

It had been a long and stressful week at work, and it wasn't over yet.  I should have been at the office, getting things done, but my very good friend was coming up specifically to see us.  How could I resist?  I think it was the best decision I could have made.

We were celebrating some very important and happy milestones, so we decided to go all out for dinner.  We ordered a lovely bottle of Syrah wine to share amongst the three of us, well, rather, the two of us, since one of my friends wasn't drinking.  For starters we had the prosciutto and melon and the sea scallops.  The melon was a strange and yet oh so perfect accompaniment to the prociutto, and the sea scallops, though raw (much to my surprise - I didn't really read the menu carefully) were excellent.

For dinner I had the saffron risotto with braised beef cheeks - WOW!  The saffron risotto was exquisite, so flavorful, and the meat was extremely tender, that everything melted in your mouth in just the right way.  I tried some of the ribs, which were also quite tender.  One thing I have noticed about this place on this occasion, and on a previous visit here, is that they leave a lot of the fat on their meat.  Does this make it more tender? Flavorful? I personally don't like the fat to remain on my meat, but that could just be me.  The halibut was tasty, but a bit dry.

Dessert was delectable!  I am a big fan of dessert, so I was really excited when I got to order what I wanted, then got my companions to order the other two items that I wanted to try. :)  I had the peach and raspberry cake with peach ice cream, all of which was excellent; however it came with this intriguing (and yucky) champagne jello type substance.  I like champagne, and I like jello, but those are two things that didn't mix well on my plate.  I got to try the chocolate torte - overwhelmingly chocolatey, but good, just make sure to order some milk or something.  I think the winner though, was my friends plum crostini.  He complained that it was too sweet, but if you ask me it was perfect.  

Tonight was perfect.  Well, almost.  Two people were missing, but that's not Perbacco's fault.  :)
author: Nancy M.

description:
I took out a home equity line of credit before going to perbacco, and still couldn't take the price vs food ratio. I was so hungry after leaving and spent so much money it was pathetic. I am not calling perbacco pathetic but I am saying they need to step up.

Great wine list Umby! good food and ambiance but for crying out loud I am a slim guy height weight proportionate and left thinking of the taco truck in fruitvale. Just thinking of perbacco makes me want to go some where else and eat.
author: Ellis D.

description:
My friend Fatty and his girlfriend hosted a dinner here.  We had the chef's table which is located right next to the kitchen.  I was skeptical at first but when we got there, it was pretty cool.  

I got the risotto and the steak.  The steak was perfect and it had a topping of breadcrumbs and seasoning that made it extra tasty.  The risotto was good but a little bland.  This, of course, did not stop me from eating the entire thing.  The staff was great and didn't stare too hard at our entourage of asian hotties.  

For dessert I got the cheese plate which i regret.  Not that it was bad, but everyone else's desserts were 10x better.  

Would definately go back especially if Fatty is picking up the tab again.
author: Archie R.

description:
Party of 2 @ 8:30 on 6/14

Restaurant was hot- so much so that every guy removed his jacket.

Attentive service.
My veal tartare was very heavy on the garlic- couldn't finish it.

Wife's scallops were overcooked
My lambchops (2 small) offered little meat.

Dinner came to $140 with their least expensive bottle of Pinot, no coffee or dessert
author: Art V.

description:
My date dropped me at home after having dinner at Perbacco.  I took my shoes off and marched straight to the kitchen for chips and salsa. I swear I'm not one of those dainty date eaters either.    

The cuisine was much more about flavor and quality than quantity.  

SERVICE
The service was fine. Maybe a little too attentive actually.  The server would come over and ask how the first bite was? and the 5th,10th.,15th...It went on like this for four courses. 

AMBIANCE
The tone of the restaurant was very stiff.  It kind of launched me back into childhood. I could practically hear my mother whispering, "Nadja stop wiggling at the table.  Where is your napkin? Chew with your mouth closed, Don't pick your nose".

I looked around at one point and saw a sea of 'blue hairs'.
Blue hairs on business dinners, blue hairs with buxom blonde's they had no business being with, blue hairs with blue hairs....

Perbacco is good for business not for pleasure( unless you're dabbling in infidelity).
author: R M.

description: Eaten here a few times and I have left satisfied every time.  I love the octopus dish and the rabbit agnolotti.  Great place for a date or birthday.   It is a large restaurant with an open kitchen and they pump some high quality food out with amazing precision.   The menu itself is large  and has something for every type of eater out there.  I also enjoyed the way you can split up the dishes and  try so many options in 1 meal.
author: Duke B.

description:
Have you heard the track 'make it rain?' by Lil' Wayne?  It is money, only eclipsed recently by that Akon song 'I wanna love you.'  Anyway, if you haven't heard it basically the phrase basically means 'throw around so much money that there is a storm of cash blowing around the room.' Or... as defined by urban dictionary...

"Term used in strip clubs, it defines when you in da club, with a stack and you throw the money up in the air at the strippers, and the effect is that it seems to be raining money on to the strippers."

I really don't think that you need to be in 'da club' though, as I saw one of the line backers in the super bowl game pantomiming 'make it rain' after his teammate made a touchdown... What does any of this have to do with Perbacco? Nothing.

Except for the fact that some partners in crime and I made it rain (figuratively) on our friend (the beautiful, charming and captivating) Melissa H. earlier this week.

We started with some bubbly in the loin while watching the princess open her mountain of gifts (including a Law and Order coloring book) before hailing a cab to meet the rest of the party downtown at Perbacco.

We arrived a little before the time of our reservation and lucky for us our table was already set and ready to go so we didn't have to squeeze into the happening (read: crowded) bar. We started with some cocktails from the signature menu... well... the women did... I wasn't turned on by the liquor combinations that were available so I stuck to the martini... the chicks did like their drinks though.

When the rest of our party arrived one of our friend Bobby quickly snatched up the wine list and bought a wonderfully tasty bottle of champagne.  Good thing I love that stuff.

I will not go into exactly what was ordered but I dare say that there wasn't an unloved plate in the bunch.  Standouts included the huge plate of Salumi that included one of the better pates I have consumed along with some really interesting spicier meaty blasts.  Also, I am very happy that we decided to get the 5 hour pork ragu pasta dish.  It was exactly how I love my ragu... meaty and rich... it was also a good idea to split this at the table as eating a pasta course and protein course here would send you into a food coma that might last until your NEXT birthday.

Let's see, this is getting long... the pork entre is freaking killer.  The gelato was amazing and the cheese course was stinky. All in all I think that this place will be somewhere that I return about every year, it is on the spendy side and there are too many other restaurants that demand my attention throughout the year.

It was such a wonderful night that I hate to bust balls on anyone but our waiter in training was nothing to get excited about... I loved it when the super cute waitress came by from time to time recommending wines and talking about the food.  Not only was she easy on the eyes but she knew her stuff... the other guy would have been great at a funky place in the mission but looked like he lacked fine dining chops.

It was a great night and Perbacco played a huge part in that. Total Party All the Time.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I love my job. I have a view of the Bay out my office window, work with super smart and hard-working staff, I ride my bike to work, I reside directly above three pubs, and am across the street from a wine bar and a Peet's Coffee. 

Typically I run along the Embarcadero at lunch, where I can shake off any angst and pound out knotty client or personnel problems. I look forward to my run and only sparingly accept business lunch meetings. But I said heck yes (tm Dynamite) to a potential-teaming partner lunch at Perbacco with enthusiasm, having been past it several times and peeked longingly at the menu. You can tell me all day about your "synergistic services" and "high-quality technical products," so long as I have a plate of house-curred meats and hand-blown mozzarella (don't ask me what that means, it just tasted like fresh-squeezed heaven) in front of me!

I will nod and grin and appear engaged for over an hour if you then bring out the BEST Ligurian tuna salad (Italian version of the nicoise) I have ever set taste buds upon. Prepared with veggies and giant beans (no lettuce even, to distract) and a hunk of delightful, light-colored tuna seared to perfection; I wiped a tear when it was finished. The desserts look great (strawberry panna cotta, oh man), but after eating the slab of mozzarella nearly on my own, I decided to pass and have a cappuccino breve, which was a treat in and of itself. The service is also excellent (and flirty--is this to lend to it's Italian authenticity?!). Yes, folks, this is all in a days work--it does not suck to be me. 

I am also requesting that the green-eyed boy go back with me for a leisurely, decidedly non-work-related dinner so I can try the wine as well!
__________________________________________________

Back for dinner and was not dissapointed! Took all of our server's recommendations (sea bass with quail egg, pork chop, beet greens, Swansons Merlot) and enjoyed every last bite.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Sadly, I would except SF to have more good Italian restaurants than it does. The pastas here are good, but I don't think they're anything to write home about. Yes, it was a solid meal, did I think it was going to be better? Yeah, I did. 
 
A plus is that the service was unbelievable. The waiter would come, almost to the second, to retrieve my place or refill my glass. And they were pretty busy when we went there so that speaks volumes to the quality of service they provide. 
 
There's no real ambiance to the place. I'd describe it as bland. Plus, since it's in the financial, the crowd is stuffy and boring. Visually this place was a disappointment. 
 
Overall I'd say the food was decent, service was excellent and ambiance was horrible.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Last night was night one of my wife's SF Birthday celebration, so we BARTed in, went to the Cornell exhibition at SFMoMA, had a lovely cocktail at Seasons, the Bar at the Four Seasons, and then on to Perbacco.   

I had been here only once before, at a wine luncheon in the private room, so couldn't really comment on service, decor or menu.

First the positives:
It's really lovely and refreshing to see that an upscale restaurant is finally letting Hispanic workers do more than deliver bread and refill water.  Hispanic workers run most of the restaurants in the country (look in the kitchens and see who's making the food).  Our server was hispanic, as were most of the runners and servers were in the room.    About time.  Bravo!

The pastas are great - well seasoned, balanced with deep, deep flavors.  Carol had the Papardelle with Short Rib Sauce - wow! - and I had the Agnolotti with Bunny and Truffles - also very good, but they were really Agnolotini or Gnocchi sized, but I'm probably just splitting hares (sic).  

The wine list is very well chosen and fairly priced.   Kerner (a fairly obscure Riesling cross) from the Alto Adige by the glass ?!?!   Well aged Barolos in half bottles?!?!  Nice.   

Now the negatives.  
The room is ugly.  Tables butted up against columns, concrete, brick, shiny surfaces.  The designer for the space should be whipped with a pappardelle!!  And it's ungodly loud.  

Wine service could have been a little more attentive.  The pours were too large for the glassware, and not done with any flair.  Also, Barolo shoudn't be served in Pinot Glasses, but that's minor....

The salad was fine - boring really. But, the lettuces were sopping wet from not having been dried, which made the vinaigrette overbearing. 

The "signature" fritto misto was tired - the lemon slices were too thick to eat, and the batter was waay too dough-y to appreciate the interplay between the succulent rock shrimp and the crunchiness of the green beans.   Needs a rethink.

All in all 3 stars.  We won't be back
author: Cheesemonger Jeff D.

description:
It doesn't hurt to keep refreshing your page on Opentable.com. Had we not done so on Saturday night, we wouldn't have scored an 8:30pm reservation here 2 hours in advance. We arrived early, so we decided to grab a cocktail at the bar. Shortly after I got my tasty Mandarino, we were brought over to our table in the back dining area.

We skipped appetizers and went straight to our main dishes. Fiancee ordered the beef short rib and I ordered the tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo, by accident. I actually meant to order the pappardelle with braised short rib ragu. When the dishes were brought out to us a minute later (literally) and I had realized I had ordered the wrong dish, the server offered to bring me the pappardelle saying "Though it will take 4 minutes." Is 4 minutes considered to be a long time at this place?! Needless to say, service was wonderfully gracious and lightning fast. The pappardelle was very good, but I might have to really order the tagliatelle next time!

We didn't see anything that jumped out at us on their dessert menu and decided to pass. BUT, that didn't mean we weren't going to have dessert at all (see my next review)! Our kind server brought us some complimentary squares of house-made chocolate hazelnut gianduia and some torrone nougat so we didn't leave without something sweet!
author: Connie C.

description:
The best meal in a long time

So why do I only give four stars for such a great meal?  Because at Perbacco, ordering carefully is the key to dining success.  Perbacco has only been open like a month, so maybe in time every item on the menu will be incredible, but for now there are great heights as well as some duds.  My ideal dinner there would consist of the following: Salumi, most of which they cure themselves -- maybe you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear but you can make wonderful salumi out of it!  Then the freakin' agnolotti, which descends from heaven on a cloud -- everybody else is writing about the agnolotti so I don't need to reiterate, just get some.  Then two desserts, the gelato trio and the panna cotta -- in particular, the caramel gelato is not to be believed.  Breadsticks throughout the meal, and a glass of vanilla bean mint lemonade, and that is nearly a perfect meal as you will find in SF.

Contrariwise, their risotto was avearge, the skate was dull, the short-rib stracotto was tender but boring, the artichoke soup was nothing special, and the beet greens were just too oily and salty.  Fortunately no one is forcing you to order these dishes!  Just stick to the winners.  The staff was great and the decor is too.  If I drank wine I'd probably praise that as well.
author: Ian G.

description:
Made a reservation for lunch with 2 coworkers.  Believe you me, lunch time here is not worth the wait.  I was told 11:15 or 1:30 were the only reservation openings, which is understandable for financial district lunch time crowd.  We arrived promptly at 1:25 and weren't seated until 1:45, by that time I could have gone to Fatt Dogg.
Seating downstairs is definitely sleeker and less stuffy than the upstairs, where you don't get the high cielings and nice atmosphere.  Nonetheless I had the better than average petrale sole.  Unfortunately I didn't order the burrata cheese or anything else due to the almost 2 pm seating.  
Service was good for a trendy financial district lunchtime spot and you get what you pay for.  I'll try it again, when all the hype dies down.
author: Aaron I.

description: I was staying right around the corner when I discovered this place. We made reservations for 5 on Wednesday, and by the time we left it was packed! I got the sangria which was excellent, then salumi and orecchiette. The plates were surprisingly big and everything on the huge menu was $10-20. Ended with prosecco and olive oil cake! So good!
author: Julia A.

description:
Wow, people are all over this place.  My first thought is, why?

I'm giving it three stars though that's a little much, only because it's right by my office and I know it will be on rotation for weekly fancy lunches, and I must psych myself up for coming back.  It's easy to get bored in the FiDi and I am thankful to have a new restaurant to break the monotony, even if the restaurant itself IS monotonous.

So let's get down to it.  Ambiance first.  Basically, decor schizophrenia.  Sleek and elegant bar area, ugly-toned corporate-ish main dining room with low ceilings and a long stairway to underbelly-of-the-building restroom oblivion.  Where am I?

Service next.  This was one of the longest dinners of my life.   Why the almost one hour wait between apps and mains?  Maybe I would not have minded if I actually liked the person I was with.  But I was on a blind date.  That was boring me to death.  Bad date + long wait = drink entire bottle of wine almost entirely on own.

Now food.  See, usually I put food first because it's what I care about the most.  But this food did not want me to care about it.  It was... meh.  I think the kitchen is afraid of salt.  Because the veal tartare desperately needed it (and where were the black truffles?).  And both pasta dishes (yes, I ordered two, because I needed to eat constantly to provide myself some form of amusement) suffered from a glaring lack of flavor - and I ordered the most flavorful-sounding ones: the much-touted agnolotti and the papardelle with short rib ragu and chanterelles!   What is going on here if butter sauces and long-cooked meats and earthy mushrooms taste like nothing?

But I think there is hope.  Sit at the chic bar, order a glass of wine from the nicely thought-out list, and have a bunch of salumi (which I did not get to order due to date's embarrassingly vanilla palate - I mean, I insisted on the veal tartare and he wouldn't even eat it!).   I mean, how could that be bad?

UPDATE:

Had a biz lunch there today.  

The good:

*Butternut squash ravs (if a touch, undersalted, no surprise there)  *Pear/blue cheese salad.  No complaints.  
*Pork sugo: sauce was delicious, complex, flavorful,  BUT

The bad:

*It was glopped on some very thin, very overcooked delicate pasta - think angel hair gone south.  No cohesion here.  I am perplexed: why this noodle choice?  
*Burrata app: cheese was on the verge of going bad.  Nothing worse than past-its-prime burrata.  Plus it needed salt (I know, shocker).  

The ugly:

*They FORGOT my cappuccino!  And I had to run back to the office with no caffeine to get me through the afternoon.

The verdict:

Sticking with my initial 3 stars.  But I still need to go back to try that salumi...
author: Melissa B.

description: Love this place. My go to place for business meetings. They service is great, always take care of you in a hour to hour and 1/4. I have been here multiple time over the last year and have never had a bad meal. I love their Fritto Misto appetizer. For a main course you can't go wrong with the chicken breast or steak the are equally good.
author: Frazana S.

description:
My Chief made arrangements for me to have my birthday lunch at Perbacco. 
And so I had lunch here today. As I checked in with the hostess she nicely greated me and said "Happy Birthday" to me. That was really sweet. Then I was escorted to my table and as I sat at my table there was a birthday card for me from Perbacco. 
Then my server was my ex-boss from another restaurant we both work at. How FUNNY
Over all the food was great the service was top noch and I would so good back. Having lunch here today set the tone of my day....Great day!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
This is a great restaurant.  Its one of those fancy Italian kind of joints.  

We went overboard and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  After starting with a mediocre salad, we dived in with 2 pastas which were completely delicious.  Then,we got the scallops and the braised short rib both of which were excellent.  The scallops were tender and cooked to perfection.  We finished it off with a chocolate mouse cake thing.  Easily a top 10 dessert of all time.

Great atmosphere and excellent food.  The service was attentive but not pushy, all in all a good experience.  We'll be back.
author: Greg F.

description:
one of the classier and pricier lunch options in the downtown area.  it makes total sense that it's within a few steps of aqua and tadich grill - two other classy and pricey options.  Perbacco actually got even pricier now that i see they've removed the sandwich option from the menu.  that pretty much did away with the only lunch option on the menu for less that $17!  

but anyway, if you have a client or you're just looking to splurge a little, head over here and you can enjoy a stellar plate of pasta or a nice piece of fish or meat - for about 22 bucks.  i had the pappardelle pasta with short rib ragu.  very nice.  interesting flavors and well prepared and presented.  my friend had a glass of wine and the soup and the salad which apparently were excellent.  the service is friendly and good.  the overall decor is really beautiful and thank goodness we got in without a wait.  people must take lunch late downtown SF these days because there was no wait when we arrived at 12:15pm but an hour later, when we left, there was quite a line of people waiting to be seated.  so get there before the rush!
author: dan h.

description:
Update: 6-1-07

PERBACCO!  Truly!  WOW!!!!!  One of my absolute FAVORITE places now.  And I owe it all to one of my Absolute Favorite People in the whole wide world (AFP).  Ever eat with someone whose recommendations are consistently flawless?  I'm so lucky!  I have!  And I got to do that at Perbacco!

I KNEW I ordered wrong before (see below).  This time, we relied on the know-how, recommendations and talents of one of the hawtest, friendliest, knowledgeable, talented bartenders around.  His name is *drumroll* SCOTT.  Wait, did I mention he was talented AND hawt?  Scott conjured up some seriously yummy and original cocktails.  And per his suggestions, we got to partake in some of the best food I've had in a  long LONG time.  And for that I am truly truly grateful.  

PERBACCO!

Must Gets: 

-SALUMI MISTI, including a generous portion of pate topped with a fruit compote relish.  Amazing selection of varying flavors and textures.  I can't say I have a favorite, since all of them were excellent and exceedingly fresh.  And so different.  Served with a couple of slices of toasted bread, their famous breadsticks and a few cornichons.  I can't stop thinking about the salumi! 

-CHEESE.  Scott recommended a huge hunk of soft cheese topped with a generous helping of lovely, flavorful black truffle oil.

-PISTACHIO CAKE with a vanilla custard filling and fresh cherry compote.  HOLY MOTHER OF GOD, this is ONE OF THE BEST DESSERTS I'VE EVER EATEN.  The cake and filling were not overly sweet.  The cake itself was amazingly fresh, perfect texture and divine fresh pistachio flavor.  A miracle in a cake.  That's what I'm calling it from now on. 

Perbacco makes you re-think your notions of food and good food.  The dishes are flavorful and inventive and seriously take the dining out experience to The Next Level.  Not many places can achieve that.

PERBACCO!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
12/27/2006 3 star rating

This is a "Nothing was really bad, but . . . ?" aka "I really wanted to like this place" review.  Just OK.  I read rave reviews on this place and was desperate to try their papardelle w/ braised short ribs and the salumi.  So maybe my expectations were too high.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things.  Actually, most of my stars are for the stellar service and accommodation by the hosts and the servers, who really go out of their way for you, i.e., quick, efficient, friendly, helpful but not wanting to join you for dinner service.  Plus the place is rather spacious.  

Cocktails are alright.  We had the pearlini and the rosmarino.  Alright, not stellar.  Not wanting to make you want more :(.

Eats -- hamachi, shrimp (appetizer) and risotto.  Other than the hamachi, which was simple and fresh, the other dishes were not partic. inspired.  I really really want to like this place.  So,  I think I have to go back again and get the short ribs.
author: Natasha S.

description:
The service here was horrible! Just because I was there with a party of 6 girls in the early 20's does not mean that I am not going to tip well- I hate stuffy places like this! I always tip well... so frustrating! 

Also my pasta was very undercooked- I think the whole entire restaurant was just trying to rush us out of there! 

I do not want to go back... ever...
author: Janae L.

description:
I've eaten here about five times now, always on an expense account, usually for lunch.  I return on the condition that it's on someone else's nickel, because it is otherwise not worth it.  Expense aside, it's a greasy, butter-dependent place.  I expect a high-end Nor Cal restaurant to do better than rely on those kinds of crutches. 

I also think that Perbacco is NOT a good place for a business lunch.  It's taken as long as 3 hours to get in and out of there, even when we weren't going for the leisurely route.  More often than not, the wait staff was less than helpful.  I think this place wouldn't do such a brisk business if there were a lot of other good lunch spots in the Fi-Di.
author: Ben A.

description:
UPDATE 3/8/07 - came here for dinner and was really, really impressed.  Got one of the best seats in the house (I'm guessing because I have an embarassing number of Opentable points).  Waiter was great and knew the menu inside and out.  Great selection of Italian wines.  Love the trend of offering pasta in a starter or entree portion.  Fantastic desserts.  Up to five stars from four!

Came here for drinks after I was definitely a few in, but I was really impressed.  Sleek design in a great space.  The place is deceivingly big.  It's an odd thing to notice, but I thought the bathrooms were some of the nicest I'd ever seen.  Then again, I'm used to places like the Mauna Loa and I lived in a fraternity for three years, so my frame of reference is a little off.

Anyway the bartenders were friendly and the drinks quite good.  The place was pretty empty for a Friday night but it's a new place so I'm sure it will pick up.  I looked at the menu and it all seemed very reasonably priced.  I'll definitely come back for dinner.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Scratch another place off my list!  I only wished I had enjoyed my meal more.

I enjoyed everything about this place, the people were friendly, service was stellar and there was a nice vibe in the air, and then I went and ordered the pappardelle/braised short rib ragu.  Hmm...sounded good enough, and really, pork is always a winner in my book, until that day...it was so blah and it left me with nothing but an empty feeling in my belly.

Oh, but how can I judge this place based on this one meal when everything else was so right???  That is why I am giving it a 3.  I know it has to be good.  I just need to order something else next time.

P.S. The fritto misto is really good.  So good, that I wanted to to lick my fork and touch every fried veggie and piece of seafood on the plate so that no one else would want any and I'd be left with it all.  Unfortunately, wait I mean FORTUNATELY, I have some table manners : )
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I am giving this place 3 stars.   I have been there 3 times.   The first time the food and wine were superb.   The second time the wine and service was great but food just average.  and the third time, the food was just terrible - neither I nor my dining mate could eat our entrees.    

It is too loud to be romantic but if not in a romantic mood it works.  Based on the other review I will try 2 more times and hopefully order well.
author: Lynn P.

description:
Super trendy SF spot with pretty good high quality food, but nothing utterly amazing. I may have been affected yet again by the hype and high expectations of having it on my to try list since it opened. :-O

Cost to worth it ratio: 3

Highlights:
- Waiter: I nicknamed him Italian Mr. Happy. I have never in my history dining ever encountered a sunnier--like warning: wear sunglasses--disposition. It got a tad bit unsettling at times only because I could only imagine what that type of happiness would be like, but you can't fault a naturally cheery happy person--the rest of us try to reach that point artificially. 
- Atmosphere: bustling with activity. Bar area up front, spacey open area with a lofty ceiling, and another area to the side with lower ceilings.
 Loud so not necessarily a romantic spot, but my girl friend and I were there for a good time together, so we didn't mind. Only thing is we couldn't understand Mr. Italian Happy with his soft voice amidst the full dining room.
- Tomato bread salad: a rainbow of tomatoes (red, yellow, green, and even purple) with a side of a pile of mooshy bread mixed with a fresh tomato sauce. I'm a big tomato fan so I liked it all.
- Short ribs: pretty good and also big portion.
- Trofie pesto pasta: only place I've seen this outside of cinque terra in Italy. Exciting that it was on the menu, but I refrained from ordering it for fear it wouldn't live up to the original.
- Location: just a few doors down from the legendary Aqua and Tadich Grill.

Midlights:
- Wine: good sized list. We got a few recommended glasses, but didn't care for them so much.
- Frito misto: kind of a guess what that fried piece is game. After a few bites, we discovered fennel which was a unique choice, but a bit too much of it in the slice sizes and amount of it in the mix. The rounded light green items I originally pegged for okra, but ended up being olives. There were two different colored peas (green and white) which I liked, but wish there were more shrimp.
- Brussel sprouts: halved with a lot of parmesan cheese--a bit over for my taste like it started snowing on top of it and if they waited any longer in the storm, it would have been a mound of white.
 
Lowlights (my flip side to highlights):
- Crowds: even for a early weekday after work, so just keep that in mind. I was going to have a drink before dinner, but could barely fit through the door so went elsewhere.

Decent meal, but I was looking for a knock my socks off standout for the relatively new hot-spot.  I may be back to try some different wine and the cured meats they are known for.
author: Eve K.

description:
The hamachi crudo was out of this world!! The expectation that subsequent courses would follow suit was unmet. Roasted beet salad was okay. The seafood risotto was extremely overcooked. The risotto was taken off the bill and the server offered another dish - she actually seemed more upset about the risotto than I was. That's a nice gesture and appreciated though, I prefer to enjoy my meal with my companion.
The atmosphere was lively, the decor modern and elegant and the booths were very comfortable. The booths overlooking the downstairs dining room are a great place to people watch! Service was spot on.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Not much to say except:

Convenient - post work drinks or a fancy-schmancy lunch. Wouldn't trek to the FiDi to go here otherwise. 
Decor - Cool, clean decor. Nice bathroom sinks - if you're into that kind of thing. Can't remember, but the toilet paper was probably soft too.
Food - Pretty tasty. What I'd expect from the looks of the place. The braised short ribs were yummy.
author: Deann M.

description:
Oh, this place is delicious! But you already knew that. I love SUPER-indulgence. We had the wine flowing and the meats coming all evening. 
This place is not under Yelped, but here is my rundown. BTW I find the menu to be WAY overloaded, too many options. In this case, less would be more. 

SALUMI
don't skimp. order it. a double double if you must. because I BELIEVE this plate is life changing. seriously, I woke up the next day CRAVING bacon. It's like crack kinda good.

HANGER STEAK
I ordered this medium-rare, and it was. A bit tough, but tasty. Loved the Gorgonzola butter. Should have ordered a double-double on that.

CUNIJ AL SIVE
Kill the wabbit, kill the wabbit...tastes like chicken, but better.
http://www.metacafe.com/watch/430148/whats_opera_doc/

We had a couple of deserts, all were tasty...none particularly memorable.

Order the SALUMI. Again.
author: Carnley P.

description: A new menu everyday based on what's available at the market and fantastic fresh pasta. Yum.
author: EB B.

description:
It is difficult to obtain a reservation for dinner here.  With that said, we decided to try our chances and went there for drinks after work.  The place is lively.  In the 5pm to 7pm time frame during the week, there are a lot of folks who appear established in their trade who frequent the bar area.  

After 7pm the age of the crowd dwindles exponentially.  The staff behind the bar is very engaging and knowledgeable.  When we transitioned to a table for dinner no one hassled us about transferring the tab.  Bonus.  Everything we ordered was prepared perfectly.  One of the owners stopped by and asked us questions with his thick European accent, thus, none of us could understand what he was saying but he was pleasant nonetheless.  

With the good food, good drink, and engaging staff I bet you were expecting me to reward the coveted 5th star.
author: Richard R.

description:
Really loved this place.  Am usually averse to painfully trendy places, but the service was excellent, food was amazing and the cocktails were fab.  
The menu is a little hard to get thru.  It's all typical Italian fare, but they try to make it sound more fancy-schmancy.  But the wait staff was very helpful, and it was soooo worth it to figure out the menu.

I had the Perbacco cocktail to start.  Yum!

Appetizers - heirloom tomato salad was good, but not terribly special.  the rock shrimp was breaded and fried much like calamari - very light breading, etc.

At this point I needed another beverage.  I perused the limited list of wines by the glass.  For an Italian place, they had no Pinot Grigio!!! But the waiter made a great comparable recommendation.

Main course - I got the veal and cabbage ravioli.  If you love any pasta stuffed with any food product as much as I do, you'll be a happy camper.  Yes, the cabbage part sounds bizarre, but in fact, it added the perfect crunch to it. 

Dessert - I'm usually hell bent on having something chocolate, but I'm glad I broadened my horizons.  The warm pistachio cake is possibly the best dessert I've ever had.  Moist cake with just enough nuts to add crunch and cold ice cream to balance the warm cake.

Cheese - yes, this was a dining event based on the number of courses we had.  How can you go wrong with a cheese dish.  The goat cheese was the best one.
author: Sam D.

description:
Yum.  This place has great food, great service, and a great atmosphere.  I need to go back!

If you feel like being fabulous...Perbacco has a great atmosphere.
author: Yvette M.

description:
Every meal I've had here has been excellent, but I want to relay one particularly great experience.

My family and my wife's family was in town for the Christmas holidays, so we booked a reservation here for 9 people for the day after Christmas--a nice break from our own cooking.

We waited a few minutes at the bar and ordered aperitifs, which were served with wonderful friendliness by the bar staff. Once we were seated, we were shown to Perbacco's private dining room--unexpected and very nice! Floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the kitchen which was a great treat for those interested in behind-the-scenes of a great restaurant. Our families are a boisterous group, so it was good to have our own space and not worry about interfering with others around us. 

We were served by several people, and each one was professional and a pleasure to interact with. Our families area boisterous lot, with most a type-A personality that can be difficult to deal with, but the staff was incredibly adept at dealing with us throughout the evening. One of my major concerns about taking two families out for dinner alleviated!

We ordered their fantastic salumi platter for the table, and when it arrived we were told that the chef decided to give us two platters that contained everything he offered rather than two platters with duplicate items. Wow. Not only great food, but great consideration in thinking about optimizing our experience. Not surprisingly, we had a great time sampling and comparing everything served--a wonderful start.

We had some real wine connoisseurs at the table, and the sommelier  showed up and dealt with three people simultaneously making demands on his wine list. He handled us adeptly and we ended up with some incredible wines: some that he recommended given our food orders and a description of the kind of wine that we liked, and some varietals that we specifically pointed that we wanted to try.

Most of the table was from out of town but had sophisticated palates, and they were all impressed with what they were served. The dishes were served simultaneously, not easy to do for a table of 9, and really done to perfection. The quality of each dish was truly amazing--one or two great dishes out of nine is expected, but the number of incredible quality dishes was truly amazing. I was so happy that my out-of-town family was ecstatic over the food they were served--as were the in-towners! And I can't overstate the quality of service that we received.

It was my wife's birthday and they brought out a nice dessert for her, but subtle and no crass "happy birthday" celebratory motions that would not have fit with the mood.

Not only did the evening impress our sophisticated out-of-towners, but also our more demanding local foodies, and me who probably had the highest expectations for Perbacco which I know well. Truly one of the great dining experiences I've had in SF--which says a lot!!
author: Brent E.

description:
This is a fantastic restaurant.  The service was so-so but the company made up for it.  I love the bar and the booths that are reserved for the "walk in" business are the best seats in the restaurant.  The menu has a nice selection of fish, pasta's and steak. AND the restaurant is truly beautiful with a great bar...next time I go I might just sit at the bar!  I will definiltey be back.
Also, the sommelier was super sweet and very knowlegable.  I like that they pour the wine into your glass at the table...even if you ordered by the glass. 
=)
author: Michele K.

description:
I had a lovely leisurely lunch with a friend on my day off at Perbacco.  The service was stellar and warm with all the Italian accents floating around.   The space is comfortable, yet upscale--not at all pretentious.  We started with a really nice cheese topped with truffle served with a nice toasted bread.  For my main course I had the papardelle with pork ragu.  It was delicious, and just the right size portion to satisfy my hunger without giving me the stuffed pasta feeling.  My dining companion had another pasta dish with pork and was quite pleased with her dish as well.  For dessert we shared the chocolate tart with coffees.

Overall, I'd recommend Perbacco to anyone looking for a fine dining Italian experience.
author: mandy f.

description:
Major disappointment.

I haven't reviewed Taco Bell because I don't eat there, but if I did, I'm sure I'd be giving it a max of two stars. Does that mean that Perbacco is on par with Taco Bell? No. I just hold them to different standards, and in both categories ("fast food" and "finer dining"), both establishments fall dramatically short of satisfaction. 

FOOD - not so much. 
1) Salad - I got a salad that had a strong citrus element, with slices of grapefruit, I believe. The fruit slices had lots of internal skin, meaning that I had to pick at it and rip is apart to make it satisfactorily edible, and there were SEEDS left in it, which, in my book, is inexcusable. Maybe that's just my tastes, but.. you're a restaurant that's attempting to create good food and give it a decent presentation... don't lay it out so that your customers have to finish the basic prep work for you when the food hits the table. 

2) Main - buckwheat pasta
I ordered a pasta dish that normally comes with prosciutto, but  had them skip the ham. It tasted good, but came with slices of potato (??!??!?@??!?) in it. I'm sorry, but if I'm ordering a CARB-BASED entree, I really don't need extra starches tossed in. It made no sense. 

CHOICES - 
As I recall, there was literally ONE vegetarian option on the menu for entrees and most of the desserts were laden with alcohol, which I detest. Unfortunately, you couldn't request an alcohol-free version, since it was cooked in. 

PALATE DOMINATION
I think what left the worst impression on me, regarding the food, was that the menu seemed dominated by one palate that was very particular - really rustic meat oriented. There were plenty of choices on the menu, but they all seemed to come from the same vein of culinary style, one that, as a pregnant woman, I clash with. Even the fish was unworkable for me at the moment. It seemed like the head chef created this menu to please his or her whims, without considering the varied tastes of their clientle.

The customers shouldn't have to hunt the menu to find what they can "settle" with and then have to have modified in the kitchen. Ideally, a good menu should offer a few options for a variety of types of palates. 

ATMOSPHERE: 
1. UNBELIEVABLE NOISY - great for after work drinks and apps, wind-down socialization. Horrendous if you want to have actual conversation at your table. 

2. CIGARETTE SMOKE - We were seated on the third floor, yet somehow cigarette smoke wafted up and emanated around the dining room for a good 20 minutes. Given the location of the front door versus the staff area in the basement, I'm thinking it's a lot more likely the smoke came from a staff member having a smoke break, rather than someone out front. The bottom line is that a staff member on the third floor should have noticed and immediately had the situation addressed. 

SERVICE
This is a pet peeve... If I'm eating at a relatively fine-dining location, I want my service to be unnoticeable.*** The ideal is minimal interaction with the table, getting orders, etc, and then seamlessly refilling waters, beverages, delivering food, removing empty plates in a way that is unremarkable. 

Sadly, our waitress was of the "hey folks, welcome to my show" mentality, so we had constant interruptions from her that were wholly unnecessary - interrupting us in mid-sentence to inquire if we wanted more to drink, if we were DONE with our food that we were still eating, etc. Ridiculous. Also, it was all delivered with an overly engaging, disruptive and peppy attitude, like she was inserting herself into our dinner company and trying to join our table. 

The rest of the staff was equally bad - the busboys literally hovered near the table to try to swoop in the moment a fork was set down. 

They seemed to be rushing us to turn the table, but we were by no means lingering and wasting time. 

Bottom line - major disappointment. I will NOT be going back, even if someone else is footing the bill. 

***I worked for many years as a waitress in a variety of restaurants, from fine dining to pizza joints. As a waitress, I enjoy the chit-chat and casual attitude of slinging pizza, but I also deeply appreciate appropriate deference in a nicer establishment.
author: Hannah Q.

description:
Calling Perbacco a day ahead for reservations will most likely end with a late, late dinner and after eating here last week, I understand the reason why.  

Located two doors down from some stiff competition, Aqua, they follow the new wave of SF restaurants where the interior is a mix of modern and old San Francisco.  The service is accommodating as expected from a restaurant of this caliber and the setting is a little loud, but still intimate for those couples out there.  

The food is California Italian cuisine with seafood being the standout and a well prepared Pork Chop.  Try not to miss the grilled squid appetizer that is paired up with beans and drizzled with olive oil.  Also the Tuna Crudo is a nice light and refreshing way to start your dinner with glasses of champagne of course!  If you're a corn lover like me, the side of corn is a perfect compliment to any dish, especially the pork chop that is well flavored and is enjoyable to the last bite.  Desserts are spectacular, especially the Nuvola (a macaroon filled with lemon curd surrounded by raspberries).

Perbacco is a wonderful addition to the San Francisco dining landscape, bringing dishes that will tease you enough to come back for more.
author: Jason A.

description:
What can you say about Perbacco that hasn't already been said?
How about a place that is so highly rated and such a culinary gem that treats their customers like minor royalty, a long lost relative or the consummate city-zen?
Maria Eugenia is the best of course!
author: Raul L.

description: This place is not for vegans but I Love It anyway. I want all the meat eaters I love to go on poshy dates here. Fancy, but subtle and not stuffy. Lovely waitstaff, hosts & beautiful dishes.
author: aerin w.

description:
Had dinner here last week with some friends. I read the reviews beforehand to know what to get and what to avoid. I thought the food was quite good, but I'd stop short of saying it's excellent. 

We started off with the raw fish appetizer, which I didn't know you would find at an Italian restaurant. I'm half-Japanese and have had plenty of sashimi in my life. So, I was a little skeptical of this appetizer, but my friend really wanted me to try it. I did and was pleasantly surprised to find the fish very fresh, and tasty with the light sauce and garnish they added. My only beef is that it was too pricey for a few pieces.

For the entree I ordered the house-made pasta with the pork sugo, which is meat sauce. I believe it's called Tajarin. I liked it from the first bite. The pasta tasted great and the sauce was delicious. However, I like more variety in my food and this was very simple, pasta and meat sauce. 

I guess I should have figured out what it was before I ordered it. If you like it simple, then you'll like this dish.

We didn't have dessert, but the very kind owner, who stopped by to say hi as my friend knows him, perhaps decided to bless us with a few hazelnut cookies. They were chewy, airy and delicious. They even gave us a few other small sweets with our check. I thought that was very generous and nice of them.

By the way, my other friend ordered the sea bass and thought it was terrific. It came with large corona beans that looked like elephant garlic or small peeled potatos. I was told they were buttery and very good accompaniment for the fish. 

I thought the interior was done very well, but a little too live for me. I like my restaurants less noisy. I would dine here again to try the house-cured meats and other dishes.
author: Michael N.

description:
i wanted to like it, really. 

i had a good glass of wine an app and a side since there were not too many main options for a vegetarian. none that i even recall off the top of my head.

the first app - the beet salad - was fine, but the sauce on the bottom had something weird in it. like chicken or something meaty. my friend said it wasn't meat but something pickled. but on the few occasions when i have non-intentionally chewed on meat over the past 23 years i noticed that it has that sticky feeling when you chew, and it had that. ew.

the second thing i had - the side of brussel sprouts - was just bad. granted it was cooked in brown butter, but that made it look even more overcooked than they already were and absolutely ugly. brown brussel sprouts; how depressing. and it was like eating a mouthful of butter.

the waitress was very nice, and offered to replace them with something else, but i am not a big food waster. so i choked down what i could and called it.

she brought us over cookies and chocolate which was very very nice. like i said she was great but the food itself was meh.
author: Kenna T.

description:
Another good FiDi place for a business lunch that I wouldnt recommend running to for a normal meal.  Pricey but good.  

Had the Salumi plate, the fritto misto and the mozzarella apps.  All good but not nearly "best in sf" worthy.  Short rib for main course which was super tender and hearty, but could have handled a bit more zing.  

If you aren't drinking wine, try the colas.  Had some diet cane soda that was strange but tasty in that I'm getting messed up on nyquil kinda way.  Others in my party apparently dont like taste of nyquil.  To each their own.
author: Brad C.

description:
This placed opened just a week before I started my new job. Plus, it's located only one block from where I work. A sign? Hell yes it's a sign.

I have only tried lunch here (just once) so far but it definitely warrants a glowing review. 

I started with a salad. It had pears and green leafy things. Whatever. It didn't taste like shit, that's as much praise as I'll give a salad.

The entree was homemade tagliatelle with pork sugo. I have had this dish numerous times but by far this is the best. Many times the pork sugo is some over greasy, highly salted mess that resembles high school cafeteria sloppy joes. Definitely not this time. And the tagliatelle? I finally know what "Al Dente" tastes like. Just a note (not good or bad): the tagliatelle here is cut thinner than anywhere else I have been to. Given the taste, perhaps all other restaurants should follow their lead.

I really want to give this place 5 stars. The only thing holding me back is that I have only eaten there for lunch, and only once. This will change.
author: Shawn T.

description:
Update: Since writing the below review, I've been contacted by the Proprietor who would very much like to remedy the situation and after researching the incident, believes it was a misunderstanding. I have not had a chance, however, to return.

Original:
Alarm bells sounded from the moment we ordered a bottle of wine and a) it took longer than it should to arrive and b) when it did, it was the wrong one, as we discovered when we saw the tab later. It was a full $30 more than the one we'd ordered... and we had two bottles of the stuff.  Talk about a surprise.

As for the food, our party ordered three appetizers: I liked the pear salad, they liked the hamachi the best, and none of us were super impressed with the short rib pasta.  I did like my entree, which was thin tagliarini with pork sugo sauce. The flavors were perfect and it wasn't too rich or heavy.

Dessert of course had to be the five blue cheese plate. It was superb, along with a dessert wine (the name escapes me at the moment.)

Service was superb, with the exception of the beginning wine debacle. I'm still not sure what that was all about. Plus, it's interesting that they don't open the bottles at the table.
author: a p.

description:
This is a lovely Italian restaurant with great service and knowledgeable staff.  I have only been here once, but hope to return soon to further experiment with their creative menu.

We started our evening meal with the local marinated anchovies and the squid and white bean puree appetizers - both quite tasty and fairly priced.

Next up - the salumi misti (chef's selection) and the Burrata cheese with broccoli rabe.  I would probably go straight for the cured meats next time (or at least ask to include lardo), but the shredded pork pate rounded out the selection nicely.  I'm not a huge fan of Burrata, but it grew on me to the point that once it was gone, I wanted another bite.  It really blended well with the greens.

Although the first 4 courses were plenty enough to call it a night, we had to try some fresh pasta.  We went with a half-plate of the pappardelle with short rib ragu.  I enjoyed the nice, deep meaty flavor and tender noodles.  It reminded me of my grandmother's Hungarian goulash which is a very fond memory indeed.
