Unfortunately, we had no room for dessert.  The panna cotta was calling our names big time, but we had to call it quits.  They brought a couple of pieces of nuget and chocolate with our bill, which was a nice little sweet to end on.

Next visit I will bring a bigger appetite and more friends in order to taste more items.  Cheers
author: Kirk L.

description:
Food was OK. Service was OK. There are too many great restaurants in SF to settle for OK.

The much ballyhooed parpadelle was inelegant & overly thick.  The accompanying ragu lacked any deep flavor. Someone had tried to cover the lack of flavor with salt before serving, buy it was a solid meh. The servers consistently delivered food to the wrong diner with a flourish instead of simply asking to whom the food belonged.

Pass.
author: Drew L.

description: A girlfriend and I who hadn't caught up in forever came here for dinner on a Thursday night -- and it was puhhhfect!  We weren't super hungry, but wanted to taste a few items.  Our server (although he thought he was too sexy for himself), was attentive and brought each dish split onto two plates since he knew we were sharing.  They have a fantastic wine and champagne list that includes all of your favorite French, Italian, and California varietals.  We had the buratta (heaven!), the seabass (perfectly seasoned and practically melts in your mouth!), and a hazelnut dessert that will make you sing!  It was a weeknight, so you definitely see the see the business crowd.  The bar had a nice scene too, and the ambience (including the staff) is wonderful.  Highy recommend!
author: Amber K.

description:
More like 3 and a half stars. The bread is delicious. Maybe i just needed carbs that day :) but it was very tasty, especially with the spread. We ordered the shrimp appetizer which was ok. There were barely any shrimp and the ones we found were tiny... wouldn't get it again.
For my main course, I ordered the pork shoulder. The waitress recommended it and I was very content. I rarely order pork but it was tender and flavorful. Also ordered a side of the brussel sprouts; great addition to the meal. 
The service was good, it was upbeat and pretty crowded, and all in all, I enjoyed my meal.
author: shadi m.

description: OMG delicious! Their pasta has the absolute perfect texture. The rabbit agnolotti is NO FAIL; I could drink it all up.
author: Nicole L.

description: Perbacco stands out in the field of excellent Italian restaurants in San Francisco. First and foremost, the food is excellent . . . on top of great service, a good wine selection and a stylish ambiance. It's well priced too. It's not cheap, but you can easily spend $10+ more a dish at other Italian restaurants of this caliber.
author: Tad B.

description:
I adore this restaurant. The food is delicious, the staff is friendly and efficient. The atmosphere of this place transforms me every time I step through the front door. I love bringing friends here so that they can experience it, too.

The pasta is so amazing. I also love the crudos and simple salads. I dream about the pasta here. Especially the pappardelle (soooooo gooood!). Order the mint tea and ugly cookies for dessert. I completely forgot to tell you about the salumi plate. Try that, too.
author: melissa n.

description:
While the place is beautiful the food is lacking - especially when compared to the price. The trout sounded good however the execution left much to be desired. The fish was on the dry side, the cauliflower was borderline raw, the red wine sauce clashed with everything on the plate and overall it was bland, bland, bland. Will try them again - maybe I caught them on an off day.

The service was good.
author: Ann H.

description:
I believe in second chances and I errored with Perbacco.  My first visit was after an exhausting day's work with girlfriends.  We had just finished a long, food-less seminar and arrived for dinner hungry.  We placed our order and - needless to say - devoured our breadsticks while waiting for our first course.  We asked for more and were given a cold, hard stare like we asked for the waiter's first-born.  Although a decent meal, the service was steely cold and unfriendly that night.  

So I returned for the cocktail hour with a business colleague on a Monday.  I walked in and inquired where I could sit (bar, dining area, etc.?).  The hostess gave me the meanest look ever, as if I had interrupted her busy afternoon.  I made an attempt engage her and she wouldn't "lighten-up".  Again, I felt like I was stealing her first-born child.  Disappointment is putting it lightly.  Management needs to work towards improving the staff quality and let me remind them - the customer comes first.
author: Kelli F.

description:
My dining experience at Perbacco was good, not poor nor outstanding, but merely good.

Like any other S.F. restaurant at it's level, Perbacco has the requisite hostess, decor, tablecloths, silverware and attentive waiter with an accent.  You can check those off the list.

Now, for the food:

1. (appetizer) Yellowfin Tuna Crudo - tasty but my dining companion found a bone in his piece.  Erh, the only explanation I could come up with was I don't recall Italians being known as sushi chefs.  It was also a bit fishy.  The good thing about this dish is the taste and texture of combining watermelon cubes with the fennel and tomato.  Amazingly inventive!

2. (entree) Garganelli - excellent flavor and juicy rabbit meat.  Definitely a winner among the risottos.

3. (entree) Beef Short Rib Stracotto - tender and flavorful but could have used a bit more flavor.  The mushrooms were a great touch but I didn't understand the purpose of having peas mixed in.  Perhaps for color?

4. (dessert) Red Plum Crostata - the crust was a bit soggy but the plum made a great contrast to the basil gelato.  The basil is potent.  Take small bites.

Overall, this is a nice restaurant for little occasions.  Despite what you might think walking in, this is a fairly large restaurant.  For a place where I was hoping to catch a casual dinner, it was a bit extravagant.  However, the prices are very reasonable for the quality and they have a good Italian wine selection to pair with the food.  The crowd's a bit stuffy (i.e. lots of suits whose hawk eyes follow any females walking through the room...ladies, if you're looking for that sugar daddy...) but the bar area's great to get some quick after work drinks and appetizers.

Delfina was mentioned during the meal. Yep, next time, Delfina.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Our initial visit left us disappointed but convinced that the food was worthy if you steered clear of so-so main courses in favor of pastas. We decided that the colossally amateurish service we experienced was what prevented us from having the sort of night that we'd gush about. But after a second visit with significantly better service but much worse food, we just can't join the chorus of praise.

All through both meals, we noticed, over and over again, problems of size and intensity. Too much, not enough, too much, not enough... like some practical joke played by the kitchen at our expense.

First, the overkill: On our initial visit, we loved the burrata appetizer, but quickly tired of its unctuous, truffled intensity. A strongly flavored salad was another tastebud-killer: All the components hung together well, but by the time he was halfway through, the richness of chestnut honey, gorgonzola, and hazelnuts was just exhausting. On our return trip, a beet-and-arugula salad offered just too much of the same flavors, over and over, without relief.

Next, the underwhelming flavors: Although the feta-like Castelmagno cheese on that same beet-and-arugula salad provided too much salt, the beets themselves were nearly flavorless. On our second visit, a pasta didn't appear to have any salt in the dough, and had been dressed with unsalted butter. A cauliflower soup was perfectly velvety but didn't actually taste like cauliflower.

And then, unpredictable portions: We loved the tajarin (hand-cut tagliatelle) with pork-and-porcini sugo as a middle course on our first visit, but an entre portion that we ordered on our second visit was only a smidge larger. Similarly, the sides accompanying all three main courses we ordered (over the course of 2 visits) were so skimpy that you wished the chef would just offer his entrees a la carte and be done with it.

And frankly, Perbacco's entrees are its weakest link. The pork shoulder al latte turned out to be an unappetizingly symmetrical chunk of pig --- plated like Lean Cuisine on a small oval dish --- that lacked the cut-it-with-a-fork tenderness that's the hallmark this traditionally braised dish. And again, the sides were laughably meager. (Could there be anything cheaper than corn mush and cabbage?)

Both times we opted for gelato for dessert. Presented in adorable ceramic dishes made to look like partially crushed Dixie cups, the flavors ran the gamut from delightful (fleur de sel caramel) to overwhelmingly unpleasant (pistachio).

Sadly, we doubt we'll take another stab at dinner at Perbacco. We can envision returning for a plate of salumi at the bar, alongside one of their well-made cocktails... especially the Rosmarino. And certainly, if friends suggested we meet at Perbacco, we wouldn't decline. But for the price --- dinner both times hovered near the $200 mark for a full complement of food but minus any blow-out wines or other additions --- we can't afford the gamble of another hit-and-miss meal.
author: anita c.

description: Pretty good place. I went there for lunch, and had the hanger steak. I appreciated that there were several menu items that appeared to be gluten free. Some of the people I ate with said their food was too salty, fwiw.  Mine was not.
author: Isaac S.

description:
One of my favorite go-to places for a wine trade lunch - the staff is so accommodating and welcoming that it's hard for this not to be my first choice even though there are so many other restaurants in the FiDi. None of them are as consistent on so many levels though; I can honestly say I've never had an awful meal or service here (and I honestly can't believe it's taken me this long to get a review up). Anyway, today was a winemaker lunch for ten, and of course most everything was marvelous. We shared some apps around the table but everyone ordered their own entree, so I got a nibble from quite a few different menu items. And I could make a meal out of the crisp grissini & salsa verde that garnish every table!
Salumi misti: an assortment of at least ten different meats, all cured in-house. I tried the dark venison salami, the Nebbiolo salami, and a milder salami with chanterelles. There was also a crostini topped with pancetta and some more grissini wrapped with cured lardo, both delectable. I even tried the salami di testa (my first headcheese experience!) and it was really good! There was a delicious, somewhat spicy mostarda on the side as well. I was surprised that there wasn't any mortadella, but it was still  a great mixed platter, perfect for sharing.
Burrata: always a classic! The seasonal preparation included thinly-sliced zucchini, marinated fiorelli (zucchini blossoms) and (peeled!) cherry tomatoes, a shmear of pesto, and crushed marcona almonds. It was good but surprisingly not my favorite app this time - needed salt for sure, and I didn't really get a lot of almond flavor. I almost would rather have had the piastra-seared squid w/chilies and corona bean puree, which I have enjoyed in the past.
Fritto misto: rock shrimp, fennel, green beans, yellow wax beans, and even Castelvetrano olives (my fave!). Bummer though, no fried lemon slices like I've had before.  Delightfully fresh lemon aioli was served on the side though, in a large enough ramekin that I didn't have to ask for more :)
I ordered my favorite, agnolotti dal Plin, as my entree. I am never, ever disappointed in this dish. The pasta is delicately folded around roasted veal and Savoy cabbage, with tender cabbage bits and an incredibly flavorful vealy jus drenching the plate. I got a bite of my neighbor's trofie w/pesto & potato that was good as well. I've also enjoyed the tajarin w/pork sugo (such a simple sauce but sooo flavorful). I would now like to call out the first dish that I ever had here (last October) as one of the most amazing pasta dishes I have ever experienced: housemade garganelli with squab ragu and golden chanterelles. That alone warrants the five-star rating, ten if I were allowed to go that high! Steffen's pasta creations are seriously amazing.
Grazie mille a Umberto & Mauro for consistently providing a great service experience, and thanks also to the familiar faces of the staff (Juan & Alexandra). See you all in a few weeks or so - alla prossima!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I wanted to give it 4.5 stars, but I really couldn't find much I didn't like about it.  I called to see if they could accommodate our party of 15 for a celebration lunch in a private room.  They put us in the Barolo Room upstairs, an enclosed room, but with glass so you can see down to the main dining area.  They even decorated the room with a huge colorful floral arrangement in the center of the table and another bouquet of fresh flowers at the window.  The catering manager was very attentive.  I had no problems booking the room and although it was a set menu, she gave us four options, which was plenty to choose from.  The one server for our room was extremely attentive, always keeping our glasses full and the table clean.

First course - Market Greens preserved with lemon vinaigrette and marcona almonds.  A huge portion, giant salad plate and giant pieces of lettuce.  Honestly after the bread we started with and the salad, I probably didn't even need my main course.

Main course selections:
Grilled Quail Risotto with roasted grapes, grilled chicken battuta, spinach salad and roasted mushrooms, and grilled hanger steak with fingerling potatoes, arugula salad and gorgonzola butter.  Vegetarian option was a spinach ravioli that appealed to our one vegetarian.

I had the steak, topped with the butter - my healthy option.  I ordered medium rare and it turned out just right.  They could've cooked it with a little less salt though.  I could hardly eat the potatoes because I was so full.  The salad was just as good.  Several of my coworkers had the quail risotto.  It was literally a quail on top of the grape risotto.  They all seemed to enjoy it, but thought maybe there were too many grapes.  Everyone who ordered the chicken really loved it.  It was perfectly cooked  - not dry, but moist.  The only thing I heard was there were too many vegetables on the plate.  Well I don't know what kind of complaint that is.

On to dessert.  We had a strawberry rhubarb tart with vanilla gelato.  Now THIS is a dessert.  Definitely 5 stars for dessert.  It was so delicious.  Plus it had basil sauce, which surprisingly went well with the tart.

Overall, I thought the place was great.  We arrived early in the lunch hour and watched the whole restaurant quickly fill up.  It's quite a modern looking restaurant with really good food and great for a party of up to about 20 people.
author: Stacey C.

description:
My new favorite restaurant.  LOVE that it is so close to work.  

I dream about their Tagliatelle w/ 5-Hr pork sugo...  mmmmm....!  Heaven on a plate!  Can it get better than this?!  Um, I don't think so!  (Well, certainly not at these prices!)

The bread stick thingies are SO good!  Please just leave them at the table and keep bringing us back some more!

I need another excuse to go back...  and soon!  ooohhh..  I need to "pay" my tax guy....  I think I'll take him to lunch at Perbacco!
author: Christine T.

description: Truly a memorable meal with friends here last night.  I loved the short ribs, but sharing my wife"s duck dish was the highlight.   5 stars for us all around.
author: R J.

description:
Stepped in here after we were quoted a 30 minute wait at Tadich Grill and I'm glad we did.  Our meal was fantastic.  Great service, great food.

The nduja was AMAZING.  Great pairing with the pickles.  We also had their squid appetizer which was good but not mind blowing.

For our entrees we had gnocchi in a creamy cheese sauce and the short rib.  Both were excellent.  I have never had a gnocchi as soft and tender as this.  Melt in your mouth.  Maybe I've never really had gnocchi before...  The bar has certainly been raised.

We were in a rush so we couldn't go for dessert, but I will definitely be back.
author: Tempe M.

description:
I have been here for various work lunches, and am impressed by the food and the decor. Not being "wine'd and dine'd" much outside of work, this place lets me get my "high maintenance fix" with out having to admit it to my friends.  

The cured meat plate is great, their grilled chicken tasty, and the caramel gellato with sea salt is my version of "heaven." Service is good, they hand write out a "Happy Birthday" card to the customer if you tell them ahead of time, and write out in chocolate sauce on a dessert plate! 

I can't review the upstairs seating area, but if you have a large party you should definitely reserve the "chef's table" I tried too for a lunch we had on Thursday, but the hostess didn't have 5 people confirmed on the reservation and there for gave the table (that I specifically requested) away to another party (hence 4 stars- your screw up should not mean I look dumb to my colleagues). 

I am not a high maintenance girl... sure I would love to be taken out to a nice restaurant on a date, but peanut shells on the floor are okay by me!  Perbacco is definitely not a peanut shells kind of place, and its nice to be spoiled sometimes! :)
author: Jessica R.

description:
Took a group of clients here and the service was top notch.   For example, I forgot to order my soup and when everyone else's soup and salad came, I asked the waiter to bring me some and he managed to have it to me well before my dinner mates were halfway through theirs.    My wine snob co-workers/clients were well tended to and we often had several staff around our table, whisking things in and out. 
Please take my review with a grain of salt.   I don't eat meat and am limiting refined carbs.  My peeps were really happy with their meals, but I found my halibut...fine...which is usually how I find halibut...but I couldn't find anything else that was appropriate for my wonky diet.
Of course, no dessert for me.
author: Maria C.

description:
Food was good - i got the Agniolotte filled with Rabbit. Can't say I've had rabbit before that but, I guess I really like it! Felt a little bad seeing as how I had a bunny growing up, but eh, he was kind of jerk anyways.

3 stars because the service sucked! The waiter was either super stressed or just really bad at his job. He was very flustered every time he came over and didn't refill our completely empty drinks until after we'd gotten the check and were getting ready to leave (I had pulled him over and asked him to refill them mid-way through the meal). Oh did I mention they were just sodas and iced teas? Not hard, bro.

Probably not going back unless for another business function.
author: Sarah P.

description: My taste buds like to write checks that my ass can't cash, then I realize the afterlife may not have restaurants... so I let my mouth do what it wants!  My tired Pilate's ball sitting ass wiggled while I inhaled the HOUSE CURED SALUMI PLATE & RABATÒN TRUFFLE-HERB GNOCCHI. Mmmmmm Mmmmm !  pinch me baby, my toes have curled and my eyes are closed!  This shit is beyond yummy! Some guys waste money at strip clubs, I like to throw down Benjamin's for orgasmic food to dance on my tongue. Yeah, it's like that!
author: Mark B.

description: I took a colleague to lunch one week day and was delighted and impressed with the professionalism of our server...she was on top of each and every situation...our food was delicious and beautifully presented...we both savored the luscious lamb stew...and split a bergamot panacotta.If you are looking for a special spot to take a valued friend...this is it!
author: Kay H.

description: Took out of town guests here, had fabulous food (went for the (small plate) pastas and didn't get guff about not ordering the full dinners) and a great time.  The restaurant is pretty without being precious, wait staff were swift and each course was visually appealing and delicious.  The noise level was energetic, but not too loud for conversation without straining.  Desserts (each one had multiple small tastes on one plate) were a standout.  #Happy
author: Sarah L.

description: Every dish phenomenal. The porcini-stuffed raviolis were heavenly.  The duck breast had the texture of filet.  The wine was to die for.  The only thing that was a bit off was the Russian guy at the table near ours with his shirt unbuttoned halfway, and two women running their fingers through his chest hair.  Weird thing to see in a restaurant, but I guess they felt they could not throw the guy out?!?
author: Matthew C.

description: I know Perbacco is richly historic, but I was not impressed. There are so many fabulous places to visit other than here, to say the least.
author: Gina G.

description:
4 and 1/2 stars. This is an excellent place to dine in the heart of the financial district, and lucky for me -- right around the corner from work! The atmosphere is warm, inviting and sophisticated and the service is attentive and friendly. 

I have dined here on many occasions and always enjoy my meal. Today I had braised beef with polenta and cipolini onions, it was cooked to freaking perfection. I also shared a butterscotch pudding with my dining companion - it was *eyes roll to back of head* good. 

Perbacco has an excellent wine menu and they go to town on their imported (DOP) Italian cheese's -- I cannot get enough of their Burratta (Buffalo) cheese.
author: Colleen B.

description: Wow, this place is great.  We started with the breadsticks which came with a green sauce.  The gnocchi with mushrooms was really tasty.  My date had the risotto which was really meaty tasting.  The wines that they paired were perfect and earthy, just like I like.  We also had the hamachi.  It was spicy and sweet and just melted in our mouths.  The thing about this place is it's very business-like.  It's not like going into the Mission where people are more laid back.  It's definitely pricey but worth the money.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Downtown knock out.  My 'local' colleagues had no clue this was here and they were very impressed. I suggested the hangar steak, medium rare. It was cooked perfectly. My dish was a meaty meat ball kinda thing that I can barely remember since I woofed it down. Good wine list and EXCELLENT service. A little pricey, but what do you expect considering the location. 
Make reservations, or roll the dice for a booth in the bar area.
author: J S.

description:
A good alternative to the fancy lunch that you experience at Palio or Jeanty. The restaurant is split into 4 areas: the bar in the front with a couple high tables for 4, the upstairs and two downstairs areas. The right side of the downstairs feels almost like a cafeteria with low ceilings, strange lighting and crowded so I wouldn't recommend that. We sat in the left area which is spacious, has nice leather benches and great big tables.
The food was pretty good. Nothing super exceptional but the steak on the open faced steak sandwich was very tasty and exactly cooked the way we asked for.
Overall the menu is a little bit confusing and I wish there would be more soups on it. 

4 stars because the FiDi needed another place for fancier but not over the top biz lunch.
author: Doro P.

description:
Everything is good here, but the real fun lies in the Salumi.

After we received a personal tour of the 'meat locker', I was even more intrigued by the house cured meats and had to try each one. 
We found the favorite to be the Salumi Misti - since it's a sample of everything it pretty much covers it.
And the Hamachi Crudo - should not be missed.

A slam dunk since opening, Perbacco is the perfect downtown spot for after dinner drinks, a client lunch, or dinner with friends. Chef Terje knows his stuff...so you can't really go wrong no matter what you order.

Did I forget to  mention the seamless design by CCS?
author: Melissa W.

description:
Perbacco is still quite trendy, and the bar can get a little intense on weekend nights. If you want a quiet place to take a close friend, this isn't it. It is also somewhat expensive. 

HOWEVER if you know what to order and don't mind the noisy atmosphere, the food here is truly wonderful and immensely satisfying. Like many of the other reviewers, I would recommend the salumi plate as a first course.  My guest and I had the the burrata cheese which was distinctive. For the main course we had the beef short rib stracotto and maiale al latte (braised pork shoulder) which were both perfect. It's hard to describe them in any other way. We also had the recommended Italian wines which were married well with our meal. 

I've been to Perbacco previously but wasn't familiar with the menu of the cuisine of Piedmont / Liguria. This time I ordered what people suggested to me and found the whole dining experience absolutely amazing. Also the service was excellent and the wait staff very well informed about the menu. I would say that this is one of the best restaurants in the City.
author: Tony G.

description:
Lets smother everything in butter, oil, or "lardo" to make up for lack of actual flavor. 
Overpriced corporate restaurant with nothing unique and no real reason to go. Service was good, but that doesn't offset the bowling ball in my stomach right now (the next morning). I don't know how this place survives with so many better restaurants in San Francisco. Don't waste your time.
author: N S.

description:
I hadn't read much on this place so had no expectations. Great location though. The furnishings' typical of these kinds of restaurants, but I liked the mossy green/brown/taupe color scheme, always put me at ease. My party of 4 (including yelper Jennifer y) had 11:30 res for lunch and was seated immediately. We were the first party on the second level, and within minutes the entire level filled up. I observed that the paintings hanging on this level was pretty fugly-please get some new ones! We were looking forward to the Michael Bauer-recommended bread sticks, and they were pretty good. Throughout our meal we were also served this foccacia bread that was steeped in way too much oil. 

For apps we shared the beets salad (I'm not a beets fan, but the thin layer of castelmagno cheese on top was really good), and some kind of cod dish that was SUPER salty. For our main courses, Jenn y and I both had the short ribs that were so tender it fell off the bone. I loved the accompanying celery root, but didn't like the salad. Our companions had the scallop risotto with a lovely tinge of meyer lemon, and the agnolotti pasta that tasted really hearty. We shared a refreshing meyer lemon semifreddo, and I particularly enjoyed the candied lemon zest on top. And we all washed it down with a glass of celebratory bubbly.

Our wait staff was efficient and capable, although our waitress had a shrill voice not that pleasant on my ears-but obviously that's got nothing to do with the restaurant. Everyone was pleased with the experience, and we had to squeeze through a huge crowd of diners waiting their turn. Good thing we came early; this is obviously a hot FiDi lunch spot. I'll be back for sure to try the famous salumi.
author: Linda L.

description:
Had dinner there last night and it was great!  The menu seemed pretty foreign to me at first but the waiter did a wonderful job answering our questions and making some tasty recommendations. Just be aware of his wine recommendations, which are usually the highest-priced ones on the list.  Although I have to admit that they were both very good wines.

We started with the chef's sampler of cured meats, which had a plateful of meats I still can't pronounce but they were all so yummy.  The pork pate that came with it was a nice compliment.  

Next, we had the organic peach salad with arugula that was so fresh and unique.  We also had some fried rock shrimp and green beans with a creamy sauce.  

Next course included a stuffed pasta with rabbit and duck meat along with another dish of papardelle with a meat sauce.  Both were so satisfying despite my hesitance in eating rabbit for the first time. 

Our meat course included short ribs with a creamy mashed potato on one plate and duck breast with a sweet glaze and more of those juicy peaches.

Our dessert course included a fig panna cotta that was so silky and not too sweet.  The chocolate torte with a side of whipped cream and candied hazelnuts really finished off this very indulgent dinner.

Overall, it was a fun but expensive dinner.  Be sure to bring friends and share.  There are plenty of dishes to try!
author: Nina L.

description:
Seeing less than 4 star reviews surprises me because first time was a charm for me. Chic two story setting with a mezzanine overlooking  the spacious modern beautiful bar scattered with tables adorned with white clothes. Lovely wine list. Incredible Piemonte Northern Italian specialties. 
We began with the raddicchio & chicory salad with hard-boiled egg. Then enjoyed several vegetable sides including brown buttered brussel sprouts with capers and shallots, fingerling potatoes in rosemary and garlic.  A fascinating unique albacore tuna ragu on large pasta tubes both were delicious. I had a difficult choice between the 5 hour pork sugo or the short rib ragu on papparadella and decided on the latter. Juicy, tender and succulent short rib in a beautiful ragu and homemade papparadella. Paradisio!...or however they say it in Italian!
I highly recommend Perbacco. The chef is a genius!
author: Terri V.

description:
My wife and I went to lunch here the other day after reading about it on OpenTable.  We booked a lunch reservation, and were looking forward to the experience.

I agree with Brian D.'s review that the breadsticks are top-notch, but that alone can't earn too many stars.  Like Ann, we also had to wait 10-15 minutes for our table, despite a reservation; it didn't bother me too much, though.

My overall impression was that everything was way too oily.  Maybe we chose poorly from the menu, but I left the restaurant feeling pretty lousy and glad to be finished.

We started off with the Salumi Misti and Brandacujun (salt cod and potato gratin served with crostini).  The salumi plate was OK, but nothing special.  It wasn't nearly as good as the salumi misti that we had the previous week in Seattle at Salumi, and it wasn't nearly as good as the charcuterie plate we had at Daniel Boulud Brasserie at the Wynn in Las Vegas.

The best part of the Brandacujun for me was the crostini (breadsticks and crostini were the highlight of my meal) -- I've never had this before, so I don't have any point of comparison, but it was fishy and salty (too be expected), but also very oily.  Maybe that is how this dish is made, but it left me feeling very lethargic after eating less than my half.

Our entrees (seabass for my wife and petrale sole for me) were good tasting, but also very oily.  I guess I was hoping for a lighter fish dish, and got a very heavy one.  Combined with our appetizers, it made for an unpleasant combination.

One other positive note, I did enjoy my drink, a watermelon concoction that was very refreshing (I'll have to check my notes to find the exact name).

Overall, it was a stylish restaurant with nice decor, lots of beautiful patrons (quite a few speaking Italian), attentive service, but food that didn't match my tastes at all.  I would opt for a different Italian restaurant next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Bruce R.

description:
This is a long story that starts with frustration and ends well.

I read that restaurants are having a hard time attracting business and are working hard to make their customers happy.  Perbacco is still learning about this message.

Over a month ago I made a reservation for our wine tasting group to go to Perbacco, we heard good things about their food and wanted to taste Chianti Classico's.  When making the reservation for our group of 6, I explained to the hostess that we would be bringing 6 bottles of wine and would likely buy one or two.  She explained that there was 20 dollar corkage and a 2 bottle limit.  I told her this was a no go and she paused and said we will work it out for you.  I told her great and the group was ready to go tomorrow.

So today I get a call from the host, he says there is a note here that you want to bring 6 bottles; we have a 2 bottle limit.  So I explain my conversation.  Instead of saying OK, he says, you have to talk the sommelier.

The sommelier got on the phone after a long hold and told me there was  a 2 bottle limit.  I told him what happened.  He told me OK, if we made a mistake then we will waive the policy but added that he wants to sell his wine to his customers and let me know that he was not happy about our coming with our bottles.  I even asked him to come over that evening and share a glass with us and sell us a Chianti of theirs and he blew me off.  He made it clear that I had to convince him to let us into their restaurant.

The more i thought about it after I hung up the more irritated I became.  And then I picked up the NY Times dining section (does anyone else miss the Chron food section on Weds?) and there was an article on how restaurants are becoming more hospitable to their clients!  Here is a link:  http://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/04/dining/04note.html?_r=1&ref=dining

That did it,  I cancelled and will stay in the East Bay.  And when I callled to cancel they didn't really seem to care.  Hope their business holds up, they are not working to attract new customers in these funky times and that does not make sense.  Not to mention blowing off a 600 dollar check.

That afternoon I received a phone call from Umberto, the owner of Perbacco who apologized for what happened.  He asked if there was anything they could do to make up for the situation, he was very professional and respectful, and I appreciated that.  I said no, we had moved on.  He has emailed me as well.

That same evening I attended a great panel discussion on the life of MFK Fisher  and it reminded me once again that the love of food and company and wine are great passions that drive our lives. She was also someone who told it as like it is.

I am sure that the sommelier at Perbacco has great wine knowledge and is a good person but he needs to realize that when a commitment is made to a customer, it must be kept, not challenged. Frankly, the host should never have transferred the call to him in the first place. That is what customer service is about, keeping your promises and empowering your staff.

And a final note.  The next evening the owner, who knew where we would be eating in the East Bay after our conversation, went out of his way to buy us a bottle of Proseco before our meal.   That was exceptional and for that alone, the rating goes to a hopeful two stars.
author: Jules K.

description:
What more needs to be said? A perfect martini served in a nice sized glass allowing a few glasses of wine with dinner. The salumi plate needs no more praise - it is totally incredible! 

I love tripe, but the appetizer was a bit too chewy, although the flavor was great. Had the ricotta gnocchi with mushroom sugo - outrageous! My pals had the short ribs on English pea puree which was outstanding; and the sea scallops were great! The side of brussels sprouts were wonderful, but I'm a sprout freak.

The waiter recommended a nice 1/2 litre carafe of Gamay that went great and couldn't have been that expensive since the total was $175 for a round of drinks and dinner and wine. I can't wait to go back again to see what's on the menu - great use of seasonal produce.
author: Renee R.

description: Our appetizers were great and so were ore drinks but the main courses were incredibly salty.  My wife couldn't even finish her pasta dish.  The flavors were great and so was the service so I really wanted to give this place 4 stars but I just couldn't.  Maybe IF we go back and we don't feel like drinking a pitcher of water after we eat, I'll bump them up a star...
author: Erick Z.

description: This place was packed on Thursday night & we have to sit at the bar but it had full service. Waitress/service was great, she explained the menu and took care of me especially being vegetarian. Food quality was just awesome!
author: Mandar P.

description: sat at bar; Saturday eve. though busy (and then crazy busy) attentive service; nearly  all Italian wine list--good selection though with the risible bottles from Gaja exceeding $1k/bottle. Having said that, there are good selections by the glass, quartino, and half bottle. Had a near perfect ocotopus starter followed by tajarin with slow-cooked pork sauce (pasta needed more salt); great cheese course with good sides; comped the dessert wine. Noise level moderate. Definitely worth a return.
author: Dave C.

description:
OK this is really more like a 3.5 rating, explanations follow: 

1) The restaurant is beautiful, but very very full.  My Mother and I had to sit sideways on chairs while waiting for our table, and were hustled and bustled around by various servers as we were edging into the flow of traffic.  Think of a solution for this people. 

2) The waiter was charming and very excited to offer us his thoughts on the menu. We followed his suggestions to the "t" and I would note that the beef short ribs were amazing!!!  Super duper good.  On the not as good side, the fennel seasoned pork salumi, tasted like a slab of butter. 

3) Not sooo good dude.  We waited 40 minutes, yes that's 40 minutes, for our appetizer.  Granted, we had some of the Salumi to tide us over, but you cannot eat salumi and breadsticks for 40 minutes without becoming, well, annoyed.  Sooo I cancelled the recommended salt cod appetizer, that, of course, arrived a mere 30 seconds after I cancelled it.  Sorry dude, but that is a seriously long time to wait and Momma gotta work tomorrow. 

3) The entrees were fabu and the wine list is really kick ass. The Italian Sav Blancs by the glass were excellent, and the Nebbiolo I had with my short rib was also great.  The wines by the glass selection actually gets 5 stars. 

Conclusion: They took the salt cod off the bill and also comped us our glasses of wine to make up for the ahhh, rather long wait.  I think this place has great potential, but is a little wobbly on its legs.  In time this place may evolve into a full 4, we'll have to wait and see.  But for now, it needs a little work.  

Cheers!
author: Claire C.

description:
Food: High quality ingredients, excellent execution. Pastas are stellar; risottos usually are winning combinations and perfectly cooked; seafood also cooked perfectly-- done, but never too done. Deserts are inventive, highly buttery (mmm), sinful and not to be missed. Only thing I think is lacking on the food front is imagination-- the dishes are usually fairly predictable, although its hard to argue when the results are so good.

Service: As a general rule, friendly and attentive without being intrusive. The only time I've had even a hint of bad service was my most recent lunch visit, when our waiter did not mask his disapproval of our table's decision not to order wine or cocktails. 

Ambiance: Can be noisy when crowded. Decor is upscale/sophisticated without being really show stopping or particularly standing out. The space flows well and doesn't feel crowded even when it is.
author: Catherine H.

description:
I've been remiss in not writing a review of Perbacco despite the fact that it is my FIRST-choice FiDi restaurant for client lunches, networking lunches, and sneaking-away-from-my-desk-for-a-treat lunches HANDS DOWN. It cracks me up that so many well-suited biznessfolks are always milling around the entrance during the weekday lunch-hour, and the fact that many of them are turned away because, due to the quality of its service and food, tables at Perbacco are hard-won without a reservation beforehand. Which is why I ALWAYS remember to make a reservation, because it's not to be missed.

They've added a few new delicious menu items as of this week (10/28/09), and may I say that if you have ANY interest in risotto, you should try the new risotto with braised ox-tails entree! It was so flavorful, rich and creamy, and thankfully, my lunch companion and I split the dish because it was a huge portion. I also thoroughly enjoy the cool red and yellow beet salad appetizer, which they've just re-vamped with a new plating drizzled with (what I believe is) cilantro-infused oil, tossed with lovely pieces of fennel, and sprinkled with a creamy bits of goat cheese.

5-stars, and I go often, people. It's hard to have 5 stars on every occasion, but that's been my experience with Perbacco. Highly recommended!
author: wildhippychile d.

description:
Perbacco for me is a 5-star restaurant but the service makes the experience a 4-star.   I look at several items with particular focus 1) ingredients 2) preparation 3) plating 4) environment 5) service and 6) wine list.   When these items are not working together the experience is un-even.  

  
The service element was off from the beginning.  When I arrived I checked in with the host to my departure I was completely surprised and disappointed.  Disappointed with the hosts - the first host asked me to "relax" in a very crowded bar.  There was no where for me to "relax."  Another host queries if I have been helped; I replied yes and then I am asked to check in again.  This was a sign of what was to come.

  
The wait staff was less than friendly--even chilly.  Hardly excited about menu; was not willing to allow me to see which wine I would like the best by agreeing to my request for a splash.  When I get a splash I am always satisfied with my choice.  We were having a hard time deciding what to eat; little guidance or suggestions were made.  

  
The food was quite different from the service.  The food was beautifully executed such an opposite experience to the service.  We began with the Ahi Tuna--the Ahi was perfectly fresh; even the olive oil was superb; gently drizzled; in my opinion it is easy to over use olive oil--that olive oil just a touch of lemon--so little of a touch that you may not detect it.  The other first plate was a salt cod fritti - four large spheres of slightly spiced salt  cod--a completely abundant dish.

  
My stripped sea bass was a beautiful masterpiece of green abundance; pieces of olive complemented the sea bass.  There two large slices of potato--I was completely filled but the potatoes were so compelling.  When I am full I stop; I kept going and enjoyed each morsel as if I would never eat these potatoes again.

  
The food portion, even by, San Francisco standards were generous I had only wished my pour of wine was as generous.  Over all I will go back even in spite of the service.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Really...after 103 reviews, do you need another??

Just went for a standard "business lunch" at Perbacco. I recently read Josh Sen's review in San Francisco Magazine, so was interested in going. 

The highlight was the bread sticks....oh so addictive. I think I had a Ligurian fish soup next but, can't say for sure. Okay, that's too harsh. It was pretty good and I'm a sucker for anything that says aioli in the description. I had the lamb sugo pasta with classic" mint and peas.  Watching my weight sore, I skipped dessert and slammed down a double espresso and admired the art on the walls before stepping out into the dreary rain.

This is a competent restaurant built for a bustling business lunch crowd. Not as pricey as Aqua next door...and not as good, but good enough and a clear upgrade from the Gold Coast which was there before.
author: John H.

description:
Lunch with a client led me to Perbacco for the first time.  I wouldn't recommend it for a business lunch- we were there for over 2 hours (a shared app and entrees only) and there is a loud din.  Hence, Perbacco looses one star. 

Everything else was excellent. The service, while slow, was friendly and informative. The atmosphere is modern and comfortable. We started with the grilled octopus salad. They divided it neatly into two portions without being prompted... very much appreciated. The octopus was tender while firm and had a delicious marinade that was both tangy and spicy.  I'd go back just for this dish.  For entree I chose the goat cheese gnocchi. The lunch portion was very generous. The gnocchi were soft but not at all gummy. The goat cheese infused every bite and left a rich, salty flavor in my mouth. The presentation was beautiful also. Another winner. While I did not glance at the wine list (business lunch!) I'm convinced they have excellent wine service, as I saw a somellier taking care of another group a few tables away.
author: Jenni D.

description:
With really no expectations coming in, I was pretty disappointed.  For a Saturday night, the restaurant was deserted.  Waiters were standing around chatting because they didn't have enough people to wait on.  Restaurant has 2 stories with different atmospheres - upstairs is a bit more private, downstairs is open and has a bar.  

They serve breadsticks and a olive-based salsa as you are looking at the menu.  I started with the bean soup, which was nothing special.  Tasted like something you could get at Pancho Villa.  I had a taste of the Bartlett Pear Salad, which was a better appetizer option but still somewhat bland.  I had the Monkfish for my main course, and it was horrendous - unpleasant rubbery texture, in a tomato-based sause.  The Risotto was much better.  In an effort to wash the taste of my meal away, I ordered a desert  -- the Lemon Semifreddo.  A strangely hard texture.. frustratingly difficult to eat and not helping my opinion of Perbacco.  My date's Panna Cotta was much better.  

Maybe it was a series of bad choices on my part, but maybe not.  I don't think I would come back here unless they completely re-vamped the menu.
author: M P.

description:
Earlier this week, I had the pleasure of visitng Perbacco for the first time.  I have heard very good things and looked forward to this evening.  This was a special event in the restaurant as it was an Italian interpretation of a traditional Jewish feast for Passover.  

First, the dining room- sleek and stylish though quite loud.

Second, the service- first rate.  Our server was attentive and thoughtful touching our table in just the right away.

Now, the food- this was a temporary menu developed by Joyce Goldstein who formerly operated Square One.  The culinary team of Perbacco did a fantastic job of bringing her vision to  our plate.  Vegetable dishes were executed beautifully.  We also had great veal and lamb stew as our main courses- also beautifully executed.

I enjoyed the experience and would consider going back.
author: Emanuel B.

description:
Food looked good, but I was blowing all my hard earned stripper money on Chimay. And at $11 a bottle for the Red, the strong Belgian ale replaced my hunger pains. Although the fresh, green as I have ever seen olives were delicious, with a nice buttery flavor and salumi plate hit the spot. Not sure how I still got lost on the trek to the bathroom. Like three flights of stairs down, knock twice, give your secret password, and look for the M on the door. 

Actually just go downstairs and look for the M. If you suffer from upside down dyslexia look for the W.
author: Ryan G.

description:
This is a solid 4.5 star restaurant, bumping up to 5 because it's Friday. The entire experience was flawless from start to finish. We went an hour before our reservation to grab drinks at the bar. While the bar was PACKED, the bartender saw me squeezing my way towards him and patiently waited. 

Drinks:
Mojito - I hate mint but my friend really liked it
Perbacco - very refreshing, citrus vodka with a splash of amaretto
House champagne - solid
Wine - we really enjoyed our bottle of Dama Montelpulciano and it was cheap!

At 7pm on the dot, our table was ready for us. The restaurant gets pretty loud, which is where they lose the half star. We were upstairs where I thought it would be quieter, but there was a private party in the room behind us and you could still hear the riff raff from the bar. 

Food:
Breadsticks w/ pesto - awesome!
Bread - fresh!
Fritto rock shrimp starter - good, wide assortment of freshly fried stuff, great for sharing
Pappardelle - awesome flavor, homemade pasta was perfectly done and made the dish!
Pork chop - thick, meaty, and juicy
Tajarin - again, homemade pasta melted in your mouth! simple, tasty.

The dishes were just the right size, well for me anyways. At first glance, you wonder if there's enough pasta but by the end, you feel great. Service was impeccable and our waitress gave us great recommendations. I thought the prices were extremely reasonable - with appetizer, pasta, and bottle of wine, we all came out under $40 each. I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone in FiDi!
author: Susan L.

description:
This gem was recommended to us by numerous people who've experienced its delights over the last few years.  We checked it out on a Friday evening in spring, when it buzzed with contented diners, most of whom - to my surprise - didn't look like they'd just left the office. 

Perbacco is a stylish restaurant, although somehow more Manhattan than San Francisco in its style.  Its relatively narrow entranceway belies the large dining room that unfolds over two levels towards the back of the long space that it occupies.  The front of the restaurant is dominated by a long, classic cocktail bar, where dinner is also served either at the bar itself or in one of the booths directly opposite.  The main seating areas - a large, open ground floor space with a mezzanine overhang - lie beyond the bar area.  The space has a high ceiling, with a tall exposed brick wall (another Manhattanesque touch) opposite the mezzanine level.  

It's deceptively big, with the main section of tables tucked away under the mezzanine, out of the view of the bar area.  The conversation buzzes, but the space seems neither noisy nor crowded.  If I have one criticism of this beautifully designed space, it's that there are a few support pillars that obstruct the tables that are close to them.  Our - otherwise nice - table for two was next to one of them and it was a bit of an encumbrance both to the dining experience and the service.  But no big deal.

The food is mostly excellent - standard rustic Italian fare with lots of enticing, ingredients-driven dishes.  We split a fritto misto to start with - a delicious mix of shrimp with fried olives, fennel and beans, before moving onto pasta.  The Tajarin with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms was delicious and perfectly sized.  The parpadelle with short rib ragu and grated horseradish didn't quite deliver - the horseradish slightly overpowering the ragu.  The cheese board is worth the visit by itself, and Perbacco boasts an excellent list of predominantly Italian wine.  The well-dressed, convivial proprietor greeted diners with warmth and (on this evidence, justified) pride.  A great place - we'll be back!
author: Dom B.

description:
I am a big fan and can't wait to get back. Have been there twice, most recently for a whisky seminar, and didn't get experience the actual restaurant all that much, but the food lived up to my past experience.

My first visit preceded a comedy show with a group of friends. I was impressed across the board. We all shared bite, the only way it should be done, and we all liked everything. I had veal tartar to start which was awesome, it was a large portion and seasoned perfectly which is common downfall among tartars. My friends got the ahi (I think) sashimi which was served on a giant salt block. It was excellent as well. I got the chicken which was served with an amazing crawfish and tomato sauce with crawfish tails. AMAZING. Two people got the short ribs and one got the steak. Everything was good. 

Service was good. Our server was attentive and friendly. Nothing amazing but I believe she said she was relatively new, so I'm sure she'll become more familiar with the menu as she continues.

I will be back.
author: Parker H.

description:
Wow- incredible transformation from the very seedy Gold Coast restaurant. Sleek interior but nice seats (a lot of seats by the way). Amazingly you can have a conversation and hear your companion even in a packed dining room.

Had a very nice pear salad with fennel and blue cheese - and chestnut honey dressing. Instead of a main course, ordered the tajarin with the 5 hour pork sugo - wow! Great, light eggy pasta cut to just the right width for tajarin - and the sugo was very good and very close to what you would find in the Piedmont region. Wines by the glass selection was very good. Didn't have room for dessert but will definitely try it again.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Overall, very good, despite a few issues. I've been here twice so far, and the food is quite good, the service mostly so, and the ambiance is pleasant.

On our first visit, we were seated promptly, but on our second visit, we had to wait for a good 20 minutes beyond our reservation time for our table for four -- yikes. Not so good. Our waiter on our first visit was a man who displayed the essence of professionalism; on our second visit, we were helped by an Italian woman who, while not super-polished, was lively and opinionated and made us chuckle (not necessarily a bad thing). She seemed to know her wine, too. Still, a little less levity, a little more gravity would've been nice.

Appetizers are big, particularly the fritto misto and the grilled calamari, and they're excellent. Mmm, squid. The mixed salumi plate is fun, even if you're not a cured meat aficionado -- I enjoyed tasting the different types of salami, prosciutto, etc. Pastas are top-notch, too, although there's an unfortunate tendency for noodles to clump together. This is somewhat understandable with the tajarin since the noodles are so thin, but it's not excusable with the wide papardelle. Because I like pasta so much and have really enjoyed Perbacco's in particular, I haven't sample much in the way of main-course meats, and I've been too full for dessert as well.

I'll be back -- the food is wonderful. I wouldn't rate this place above Delfina, as I've heard some might, but it's a go-to option. They need to work on de-clumping the admittedly tasty pasta.
author: Tara M.

description:
6 of us co-workers plus 1 new possible new hire went to Perbacco for lunch to get to know each other a bit. 

The menu was a bit of a challenge to figure out - words not in my vocabulary had me asking the very knowledgable and friendly waiter about what this and that was.  I settled on a garden salad and a grilled ham with salsa verde and some kinda veggie as my meal.  The lamb was excellent - very good flavoring.  The salad ... was a salad (shrug).

The dessert was the most memorable item I ordered. It was a pear and apple bread pudding with some fresh whipped cream on the side.  Yummmmmmmmy!!!!  It was very tasty!!!  If I could just come here for a dessert after a movie at the Embarcadero, it'd be just right.
author: Jamie W.

description:
LOVE this place. It's hip and refreshing compared to the other sleepy places in the financial district. I love it for lunch and dinner. They have an amazing wine list and everything from the appetizers to dessert are superb. 

They have a nice (albeit cramped) private room upstairs which could be nice for private parties but it can be loud since it opens up to the main dining area.
author: Patty G.

description: Do not bring more than 2 bottles of wine no matter how large your party is, cork fees go up per bottle as only 2 are allowed at regular price.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
***UPDATED*** - 2/25/2007
I wanted to come back and update my review for Perbacco.  I went back to this restaurant last night (2/24/2007) and wanted to tell you that the place is bustling and the food is still amazing.  I also have to say that the one negative I had listed in my previous review is no longer there.  In the previous review, I had mentioned that the lighting was too bright for a dinner experience. Well, not only did I notice that the lighting was 100% better but Umberto, one of the 2 owners of the restaurant spoke to our table and told me that the restaurant's first few weeks had an issue with the dimmers not being installed.  Once the dimmers were installed, the lighting was corrected.

As for food, last night I had the Burrata Cheese with arugula and black truffle - amazing!  The Beef Short Ribs with Celery Puree - tender and smooth, and a chocolate torte with caramel sauce and hazelnuts - divine.  

10/31/2006We had dinner here 2 days after it opened and it was great.  The food and service was truly well thought out.  Our waiter was attentive and courteous and the food was sublime.  Their wine list is amazing - great Italian section.

We started with a red wine from the Langhe region of Italy - very good.  For appetizers, we had the Prosciutto san danieli and the crudo viteloni (spelling?).  The crudo (Veal tartar basically) and the prosciutto melted in our mouths.  The we split the sirloin with a reduced sauce made from marrow - it was great.  We ended with the chocolate tart - also very good.

The only thing that I did not like was the lighting in the place.  I prefer more intimate lighting for dinner and this restaurant was all lit up - a bit too bright for me.  

Overall - it was a wonderful dining experience.
author: Ingrid P.

description:
Great service, very good food though not spectacular, nice atmosphere (casual yet upscale). 

FOOD: This was my first time coming for dinner and although there were some dishes I really liked, others were just OK.  

Liberty Farms Duck Breast- I've had much better duck breast, this was not very tender :(

Crudos: We tried four crudos- Halibut, Hamachi w/Fennel, Halibut, and House-cured Anchovies. These were all very delicate and really yummy!

Salumi- an assortment of house cured meats and we also added the house made Pate which was EXCELLENT- a small bowl filled with spreadable pate topped with a fruit "mostarda" (like a fruit chutney/jam)- was sweet and savory, perfectly balanced. I would go back just for the pate!

Tripe entree- Super yummy, with white beans and a nice light sauce. 

Dessert- Espresso Semifreddo with a Gianduja Emulsion- I don't know much about semifreddos but this one was super yummy, creamy, cold, smooth and crunch textures. 

SERVICE was awesome--our waiter was accommodating, friendly, funny, and even gave us free cookies and took us to the kitchen to talk to the pastry chef!

Altogether, the food here is very good although a couple dishes came out just ok. Service is very good and the atmosphere is good for a date or a business lunch/dinner. Noise level is not too loud.
author: amy k.

description: Disappointing.  The drinks and apps are decent, but the main courses are just terrible.  The cavatelli came out looking like bugs on a plate - and the taste was nothing special.  And the sea bass did not taste like sea bass at all - I wouldn't be surprised if it were simply salmon re-labeled.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Mmmmmmm soooo gooooood!!!!

Sat at the bar with a date and shared a few plates. We had a game plan until all was changed by our opinionated bartender/waiter. Sooo glad he pushed the goodness on us!!! We shared the duck breast, burrata app, agnolotti pasta for dinner. I'm not a duck eater typically but the flavor was out of this world. Duck was served with some sort of cabbage creation that we were basically fighting over because it was that good!!! For dessert- we shared the Gianduja because we both have a crazy chocolate sweet tooth. The opinionated waiter insisted that we have the burnt caramel ice cream but we had to have our choco fix;-) Sooo he brought us one anyway!!!! Needless to say, he knows his shit (or food)!!! We couldn't stop eating the ice cream. It was ridiculously fantastic!! I would put it on my cereal if I could, smother it on just about anything to make it better. My only mistake is not getting the waiter's name. He was wonderful!!! Thank you:-))
author: Gina H.

description: Let me start by saying that the food would probably have garnered four stars but the cocktail I had was 2 stars at best and seeing as how I had 2 of each, Ill split the difference with 3 stars for the review.  My Martinez (which I ordered twice in hopes of it improving) was beaten so badly it was hardly recognizable on both occasions.  It really should be simple not to over-stir a classic cocktail like the Martinez, especially at a place like Perbacco.  I left disappointed in that respect, however, the service was great and so was the food, so ill be back to see if they've fixed this Martinez situation...
author: Zack H.

description:
3.5.  Went here for dinner with friends the other night - and my initial impression was this is a great place to go for lunch in the FiDi when it is being expensed but it is so loud that it couldn't be for an actual meeting or an interview because it is hard to hear the people at your table.
Food is good.  Waitress was a little pushy in terms of wanting us to order more, but otherwise she was very sweet.  Parpadelle pasta with the lamb ragout was fantastic as was the heirloom tomato salad.
author: Katie P.

description:
Great restaurant.  Bonus points for having bar seats available for walk ins.  

We had grilled shrimp and calamari for an appetizer.  The calamari was tender and flavorful.  We also had a scallop crudo with vanilla sea salt and olive oil.  So tasty that despite the generous portion, it left me wanting more.

For my main, I had wild king salmon over fresh corn.  The corn was very sweet and had a great crisp texture that complimented the excellent salmon.

I'm looking forward to trying the pasta next time I go.
author: jeff k.

description:
Went in for lunch on a Monday with a few good friends. Have heard mixed reviews, so unsure what to expect. 
I ended up being very impressed. 
Upon entrance you first notice the decor.. stellar. Warm colors fill the room. 
For a lunch menu, it was hefty in size, containing 10-12 items from each section of the menu, very nice. 
To start, The four of us split a beet salad, a charcuterie plate, a burrata cheese dish, and a spinoff of a seafood ceviche. 
The burrata cheese was amazing, and the marinated bell peppers and crunchy toast points that accompanied it made the dish divine. 

For the main course, I enjoyed a panzotti (sp?) plate. Similar to ravoli's, they were stuffed with ricotta cheese, walnuts and spinach. Very good. 

Our table shared a plate of veal meatballs. The meatballs were amazing and went great with the nebbiolo we were drinking.

The hazelnut cake is a must for dessert. I like...

Take a chance on this place, you won't be sorry.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Run do not walk to Perbacco - but wise to check if you can get a ressie. Not always easy. There is a reason why they are always packed. It is delicious, tasteful and fresh - each ingredient can be tasted - is not overdone - is not underdone - everything is made with thoughtfulness. 
I've been here several times - maybe 10 since they opened in Oct. Finally, I brought my husband - who hails from Torino - and is very very very picky about Italian restaurants in the U.S. and S.F. He loved it. Found the food to be fresh, perfectly flavored and authentic. He even remarked that many of the ingredients that were utilized tasted better here than in Italy. Could be. . .
author: laura p.

description: I've been here a few times now and have always had a delicious dining experience. What prompted a review was the impeccable service we received. It was a last minute decision to go here and without reservations. We expected to be waiting at the bar for an opening but after about 5 minutes the hostess said they had found a table and sat us. My friend was on somewhat of a schedule and let the server know that we had to be out of there in a little under an hour. We ordered a delicious Dolcetto, the crudo, the gnocchi and the burratta with asparagus. Literally a minute later we had the wine and maybe 8 minutes later the food appeared. The server did such a great job on helping us out with the timing of everything. The food was quite tasty and well presented as always. It was such a great meal and the service was fantastic.
author: Kacey H.

description: I'm gonna be real with everyone here: I am an Italian food snob. My ability to be impressed by Italian fare has been numbed by a handful of extended stays in Italy throughout my life, and consequently I tend to avoid trendy Italian places with high price tags because there are so many ways that my pasta dish can result in an underwhelmed MEH from my palate (I know I sound insufferable; bear with me). So, when I stumbled into Perbacco after a few drinks on a Saturday night, I was not prepared to be astounded- I just wanted to carb load and check out the wine list. JOKE'S ON ME because I was BLOWN AWAY by the gnocchi with chanterelle mushrooms. It was seriously a religious experience. Everybody around me ordered the pappardelle and they were making the same mmMMMMMmmm noises as I was, so I take that as a positive sign. I also sampled the raviora- CRAZY GOOD (pomegranate seeds all up in my pasta, what an unexpected love story!). Service was good, wine was fantastic. My only complaint was that I was not totally into my caramelized white chocolate bar, which I think has more to do with my taste than the actually bar itself. Overall, it was a very memorable experience and until I return, I shall dream about the chanterelle mushrooms.
author: Margaret L.

description:
NOTE: This review is for Perbacco's pris-fix Passover meal on 4/22.

A+ for effort! I was so excited to get an email from a friend regarding Perbacco's exclusively kosher-for-Passover meal for last night. Three of us booked a table and had a lovely evening. Now, anyone who knows about kosher-for-Passover food knows that it's REALLY hard to have a full course, delicious meal. Passover food is just blah, there's no other way to explain it. Perbacco did their very best and worked with what they had to produce a pretty good meal. The night started off with two small pieces of matzoh and a very thick harroset (I feel like there were figs in there...). Then I had artichoke soup (non-dairy based) ---- bland but once I added salt I enjoyed it more. We also shared (family style) grilled eggplant, marinated zucchini and duck liver, 3 of 8 choices. I had the chicken entree; drenched in fresh tomatoes, onions and olives. Super tastey. The entrees were accompanied by grilled fennel, a mashed-potato type side (again, no dairy...) and another lettuce based thing that is escaping me. Finally for dessert we were served (family style) caramelized strawberries (heavenly), a sponge cake (very good) and an almond pudding (not very good as it can't really be pudding without milk...).

The service was impeccable and the whole staff was very knowledgeable about each dish and choice provided. I was impressed at how Perbacco pulled this off and I am thankful that they catered to the Jewish community on a night that is truly different than all other nights.

Thanks, Perbacco! I'll be back for my non-kosher meal very soon.
author: Meredith R.

description: After my last visit with my fiance wasn't all that great, the manager responded to my yelp review and asked if we would come back.  With over 1000 reviews, he really didn't need to do that, which made it mean that much more.   We returned last night for a very nice dinner.  Service was excellent, food was delicious, and we had a great booth in the corner of the restaurant.  Thanks Perbacco!!!  We will be back!
author: Kristen V.

description: EVerything here was just awesome. The bread is obviously fresh and delicious and made in house. The veal meatballs were awesome, as well as the soup. Can't wait to go back to this place...
author: Jim B.

description:
Can't believe I've missed out on Perbacco for so long. Love the design of the restaurant- open, modern yet warm. The bar area is perfect for waiting for your table and sharing wine with friends (I never felt cramped and the bartenders were very friendly- going out of their way to suggest and pour samples of wine I may like even when the bar was pretty crowded). 

My group of 4 sampled a few appetizers and main courses- all were superb. I was with a couple who has been to Perbacco many a time and it was clear they loved and felt very at home at the restaurant- chatting with the somalier, asking the waiter to add a little extra of some ingredient to a particular dish, etc.

The raw fish was amazing (try the hamachi with jalapeno) as were all the dishes we ordered. I would list everything we tried, but I don't think you can go wrong.  The desserts were equally impressive- we had a caramel/seasalt gelato (huge serving) and a cheese plate...sublime.

I really love this place.
author: Sonia S.

description: Excellent food, excellent service.  A bit noisy.  Very pricey.  A good place to go for a special occasion.
author: Alan M.

description:
I came on a business lunch, and ordered the Tajarin pasta - a plate of tagliatelle with pork sauce on top. This dish seemed too simple and I couldn't make my way through half of it because the flavor got tiring. We ordered a side of carrots which came in all sorts of colors, and was quite tasty. 

I think this restaurant is a little too creative for my classic, home style Italian food taste. 

Service was slow, which confused me because the place was completely packed with business people, so you would think that you could get through your meal in an hour or less.
author: Irene P.

description:
I walked right in at 1 PM without a reservation and they seated me at the bar.  Staff was polite and friendly.  I ordered a glass of barolo ($16) and when I sniffed it, it brought a flood of memories to my mind of living in Italy & France.  Appetizer was the "BURRATA CHEESE / MARINATED FRIARELLI PEPPERS / WHITE ANCHOVY / ARUGULA" - the white anchovies were very good, very similar to boquerones.  The burrata was good, but I personally find the burrata at the Palace Hotel better.  For the entree, I had "TAJARIN - HANDCUT TAGLIATELLE / 5 HOUR PORK SUGO / PORCINI MUSHROOMS" - wow, very good - the tagliatelle was very thin and the sugo was very savory and earthy.

Would definitely go back and try more things on the menu.  A very nice place to treat yourself to once in a  while.

Edit: Have since returned 4 other times, I really enjoy this place and have yet to order anything from here that I didn't like.  The cheese plate is a must.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Cured meats and cocktails...what could be better?
 
A friend and I sat at the bar started off with a martini and the Notte Picante.  I began to salivate at the locker full of various salamis and proscuitto as well as the plates of salumi mista being created right in front of me.  Before we ordered some of that salty goodness, I had a sip of my Notte Picante and choked a little bit on the cayenne in my cocktail.  Our bartender Daniel noticed my reaction to the drink and came over and asked me if the drink was ok.  I didn't want to seem like a wimp that couldn't handle the heat, so I said that although I liked the addition of cayenne in a sweet cocktail, that maybe it was a bit much, so could he just add a little more of the mixer in the drink to dilute it for me.  Daniel, being the uber-mixologist that created the Notte Picante would not have it, and he made me another drink with a little less cayenne...it was perfection.

We couldn't resist ordering the Finocchiona (fennel salami), proscuitto, and the buratta cheese dish.  Everything was so yummy, including the breadsticks and the filone bread that came with the burrata.  We loved every bite.  We paired it all with a glass of red bubbly on Daniel's recommendation to celebrate my friend's recent engagement (yippee!), and had a delicious evening.  

I would definitely come back and sit down for dinner...and to have more of Daniel's cocktail creations.
author: Sheryl D.

description:
Yowzers...the food here is REALLY good. We had to sit at the bar area (because we didn't have a reservation on a Saturday night) which isn't bad, it just isn't the same atmosphere as the restaurant. But same menu as the restaurant, which I thought was outstanding! 

We each started off with their crudo selections - sockeye salmon and yellowfin tuna. So raw and fresh...yum yum. Then we each had a half order of pasta - one was some sort of egg noodle pasta with a meat sauce and the other was a tortoloni with pork and english peas. I love that they offer the half order - it allows you to try more things without getting stuffed and paying a zillion dollars when you're done. 

I thought everything tasted so fresh and homemade and look forward to going back again very soon to try more.
author: Kate S.

description: Great food and friendly service in the Financial District. The salumi is house cured and not to be missed! We started off with the salumi misti which featured a nice variety of house cured meats (very nicely explained by the server). The fresh, homemade pappardelle pasta with slow cooked short rib ragu was delicious; the beef short rib stracatto with bone marrow herb crust was tender and savory; and the brown butter brussels sprout was yummy.
author: Cindy G.

description:
We had a lovely experience:

Boy brought me here to celebrate the ending of a long week. What a shweetie. Our server (Claire) was really nice and never left us waiting for anything -- my (3) Peronis came one after the other, while boy chose a half liter of the Syrah. We like drinky.

I had the herb roasted gnocchi. It was THE best gnocchi I have ever had and I eat a lot of gnocchi -- I love love looove gnocchi. Gnocchi gnocchi! The dish was full of melted cherry tomatoes. They were like little explosions of flavor. THE greatest flavor explosions on Earth. Oh, man. So good.

Anyways, boy had the ahi steak and a plate of the crudo, which he said was d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s. My pear and arugula salad was quite good as well. The desserts looked delicious, but my belly so full that if I ate anymore I would've needed to be rolled home.

We had the corner booth with the best view in the house, so it was easy to people watch. We especially enjoyed watching the 2 Japanese businessman with the two scantily dresses call girls. One of the girls downed her champagne with each glass and kept staring at herself making fish faces in the mirror above the bench seats. That was weird, yet very entertaining.

The only thing I thought was strange was that they had Miller High Life on the menu and I think it was priced at $5. But for $2 out-the-door of the liquor store, don't buy a High Life at Perbacco.

All in all, Perbacco has good food/drink, good service, good atmosphere, and interesting people to watch.  A++
author: Syd V.

description: Perbacco is always solid, from meats (salumi plate) to the pasta to the service. Great place for a work dinner or otherwise.
author: Sherrick M.

description:
Wow. Funnily enough, I had my first Perbacco experience last week, and I have to say, I have never been compelled to write any review on yelp for any restaurant- I mainly use yelp as a way to surf the city for new restaurants, not to pretend to be a critic.... however, I had such an amazing experience that I truly felt moved to let everyone know about it!!!! .... That being said, finding"KIM D"s review below HAS INFURIATED me into taking a moment to address it:

Kim, You are "confused." There is never any excuse to demean anyone with a child. Even if they are loud, or in your eyes, out of line. To each his own. I cannot believe you would fault the restaurant or it's staff for another persons behavior anyway......

Besides- what would the alternative be? To turn families away and have them write scathingly negative reviews about it on yelp??? Perhaps people with children have a little more patience and perspective than you... Perbacco, if you have lost this guest, you have gained one in me!!! So ciao bella, Kim- Please don't procreate.

that being said.... I sat at the bar, and although crowded, was fun and lively! I was never wanting for anything for the entire time I was there. The bartender- Scott- was proffessional and lovely. He suggested amazing pairings of wine with our meal..... And our meal!!!! Oh! The chef of Perbacco should be handed an award for the amazing food I tasted that night. Rubicon, Bix, Aqua, I apologise- Perbacco is THE best restaurant in SF... Thank you so much Perbacco, for enhancing my night!!!!
author: judy b.

description: Good food, but very small portions.  Also, service was too slow.  For those prices you need a bit more attention.
author: Linda H.

description:
The menu at Perbacco spoke to me in a way I'd been searching for.  Upfront, romantic and kind, straightforward - as if knowing what I was thinking:

House Cured Swordfish...
Summer Peach Salad with Marcona Almonds...
Strip Loin Steak with Heirloom Tomato Panzanella...
Pan Roasted Fennel...

It's almost overwhelming that I found love so right and so pure.  Thank you, Perbacco, for giving me hope that there is romance out there for me (albeit in the form of a superb italian eatery, but romance none the less).
author: Jaimey W.

description:
This place is aight...The quality of the food is good, but it is somewhat of a let down.  The menu reads as if the food will be something special (5 star caliber), but in the end, it's not that memorable.  I've been here twice and both times I didn't even remember what I ate. 

Don't waste your time on their desserts, not good.
author: Burrito M.

description:
Had dinner here w/ my hubby, sis, and bro-in-law.  It took them about 10min to seat us, but once we were seated, everything was great.  

We had trouble picking out a first wine, since we wanted something Italian, but didn't know too much about Italian wines, but the sommelier was very helpful and picked out a nice light red (Dolcetto d'Alba) that went perfectly with the Salumi plate (and it was cheap too at $35!).  They were also very nice about the bottle of Ledson Sangiovese that we brought, no corkage if you buy a bottle on the list, so we saved a bundle on wine that night!  That means more $$$ for food, which we sure spent.

Everything looked great on the menu, so we went a little crazy and probably over-ordered, especially since the portions were much larger than expected.  We got the chef's choice salumi plate which was awesome...and huge!  Nonetheless, we finished every last bit of meat.  I had a big carb craving so I had the raviolo appetizer AND a pasta dish (agnolottie filled with roasted rabbit).  The rabbit pasta was ok, but I really loved the raviolo, it had such a nice truffle flavor to it, and the truffle butter leaked out once you slice it open...yum!  The other entrees ordered by my dining partners (rabbit, chicken, and steak) were really good as well.

Being the gluttons that we are, we wound up ordering dessert still even after all that food.
