I had a cheese craving as well, so we got 2 choices of the cheese to share, the piedmontese cookies, and the gelato.  I loved the cheese, especially the "la tur" soft cheese, which really shined with some honey and almonds.  The cookies were really good as well.  We were so full by the end we could barely finish the cookies and the last bit of cheese (their portions are very generous, 2 people can share a dessert).

We had a late reservation, so I can see how it could have taken a little while to get seated (maybe the previous party lingered a little too long), but it was nice that we got the table for the rest of the night and we did not feel hurried at all despite taking over 3 hours to eat (we did have 4 courses).  The service was warm and all the servers as well as the sommelier were very friendly.

I would definitely come back again.
author: Arlene M.

description:
I like breadsticks.
Perbacco has good breadsticks.
That's all I gots to say.

Well, not quite all I gots to say.
This place got a lot a buzz recently from a lot of people.  After sampling the fare, I have to wonder why.  
Maybe wifey and I are getting jaded and cynical from eating out too much.  Maybe our expectations are too high.  Maybe we're just whiney snobby  gourmands who like to toot our own horns.  After all, wifey's been on a rage booking us for 2-3 restaurants per week.  This blistering pace has left me exhausted and weary.  At this point, the  only way a restaurant's gonna get a rise outta me is if unicorns serve the meal and buxom strippers dance in the background... that's not weird, is it?

The food here is pretty straightforward.  I found the entrees fairly standard.  Like others, I think the pastas are worth investigating if you decide to try this place.  Also, the salumi and cured meat samplers are nice.  I had a duck mortadella that would make a grown Italian paisano weep.

Remember to try the breadsticks.
They keep a big bin of them on the way to the bathroom.  I got greedy and grabbed a handful of them on my way to the john.  It helped pass the time.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
I'm very up in the air about Perbacco.  I LOVE the space.  It's beautiful; big bar, high ceilings, boothes, exposed brick, quiet upstairs dining area, open kitchen area.  It really is an amazing space.  And it's much bigger than I had expected.  I just wan't THAT impressed with the food.  

I enjoyed the beet salad to start with, but its pretty difficult to mess up a basic beet salad.  My boyfriend had the slow roasted veal appetizer and it was nothing like we had expected.  There just wan't any amazing flavor to it.  A very weird combo with the tuna sauce as well.  And it's cold!  Not a favorite whatsoever.  I wouldn't recommend it.  

For my main entree I had the paparedelle.  I definitely liked the dish, but it wasn't anything special.  It is rare to find a short rib ragu, but nothing really stood out to me.  It tasted like short ribs.   I feel like my boyfriend could have made it for me.  He had duck tortiloni, which again, was nothing special.  Duck being as gamey as it is, really needed something extra flavorful to make taste really good.  It was just ok.  

We had two veggie sides, the fingerling potatoes and the cornona beans.  The fingerling potatoes were amazing, but thats just because fingerlings are amazing.  The corona beans were alright, but I guess I was really looking for some green beans or broccoli which wasn't an option.  I would have liked to see more "green" options for sides. 
  
Overall the service was great.  Our SERVER was really sweet and had great recommendations.  She paired wine for both of our dishes and was all around very friendly.  The "manager"? was quite annoying though.  He gradually walked around the entire upstairs checking in on every table.  I don't know how often he checked on everyone else, but he interrupted our dinner THREE times to ask how everything was, sparked random conversation and made recommendations when we hadn't asked for advise.  I could have gone without him.

I think it would be a really fun spot to go for some after work drinks and apps with some friends and sit down in the bar area.  But if I were going on a nice date and really wanted to be impressed by the food, I'd probably choose somewhere else.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Our team went there for a team lunch, except our boss wasn't there but her company p-card was.  I just love it when money is not an issue when we go to restaurant... who doesn't!   Anyway, below is a list of what we ordered:

Fritto Misto of Rock Shrimp - A little bit like an ordinary fried calamari appetizer except for it's with shrimps, and slightly lighter.  I like it

I forgot what my coworkers ordered for entree, but I ordered the...
Grilled Lamb Sirloin Tagliata with Mint Salsa Verde - wow... the lamb was cooked just right, and the mint sauce accentuated the natural sweetness of the lamb... omg.. so delicious

Finally, we shared the following desserts:
Pear & Almond Tart - soooo tasty!!!  Refreshing, yet a little buttery, mmmm

Gelati Misti with Vanilla Sea Salt (Chocolate / Hazelnut / Caramel) - MY FAVORITE!  I just love love love them.  3 flavor of gelato with a little sea salt on top, the caramel gelato was just heavenly, it was my favorite out of the 3 flavor....   

Warm Hazelnut Cake with Roasted Grape Compote - mmmm....  that's it... mmmmm....

Just the dessert is well worth 5 stars.... mmmm...
author: Gigi T.

description: Each year I attend the special dinner event at Perbacco for Passover. This year I invited my children to join the fun and we were not disappointed. Joyce Goldstein, premier chef and author, oversees the dinner this one night. The owner is always gracious and attentive to the packed house. Everything was fantastic. Look forward to enjoying dinner throughout the year at Perbacco!
author: Gerry C.

description:
My rating is really 3.5...only because the portions are not that big for the price.  Otherwise I thoroughly enjoyed the food.

We shared the Pappardelle (pasta with braised short rib) and the lamb.  The pasta was really good....probably one of the top 5 pasta's I've had.  I just wish there was more of it!  The lamb was tasty too.  It was odd that they kept the fat on it -  it's okay though because I actually like the fat...as gross as that sounds.  Again, the portion is not that big.

For dessert, we ordered a sort of caramel custard with apricot marscapone on top.  It was recommended by our waiter....his recommendation was great!  It was rich, but light at the same time.  It was goooood!  

Nothing really struck me on the cocktail menu so I opted for wine.  My bf got a campari/grapefruit one....umm I think he liked it, but it tasted like nail polish remover to me!

I think service was pretty good.  Our waiter was very attentive and very helpful with any questions we had.  He also brought out seperate plates and serving spoons/forks for us because he knew we were going to share entrees.  I thought that was nice because most places don't do that.

I don't know if I would go back any time soon, but I did enjoy my dinner.  My bf was very proud to have chosen a place that I actually liked (apparently I'm a picky eater...hmmrph!)
author: Neety P.

description:
I don't know how Perbacco could get any better...My "sexy hombre" brought me here for my BDay dinner and I fell in love...with the food, the wine, the service and the desserts!  "Yay"!  

Upon arriving, we did have to wait a bit for our table, because the original table he requested was not yet available so we stood around the bar for a drink.  Yum.  I started off with the Prosecco with organic strawberries.  What a perfect and bubbly way to begin a meal!  

When we were finally seated, they sat us in a cute little corner table, slightly away from everyone, but still in the midst of all the action.  Very romantic.  Nice alternative!  

Once we were settled, the hostess presented a hand-written Happy Birthday Card, such a sweet touch!  Then, our cute server came and introduced himself to us...Very sweet and very personable from the start!  I looked at Sexy Hombre and said "Where are we?  Are we still in San Francisco?"  

Okay, onto the food.  
-Pesce Crudo: Wonderful tastes of Albacore Tuna, Watermelon, Celery, Chili and Cherry Tomatoes.  Squeezing everything into one spoon and devouring it whole, you get a variety of flavors, that pair surprising well together!
-Carne Cruda: Veal Tartare (I know...poor baby lamb!) quail egg (love quail eggs!) and truffle atop toasted bread.  Oh lord...I think Sexy Hombre had a few moments...I know I did!
-Agnolotti: My Sexy Hombre may need to translate again what was in it, but I will say that it is A MUST!  So much flavor coming out of such a little pocket of pasta!   
-Parppardelle: With Quail Ragu and teeny tiny little mushrooms...It was good, but the Agnolotti shoved it aside and took first place on my palatte!  

Now, on to my favorite!  Dessert!
-Glass of Vin Santo: See the below description of how "Ridiculous" this wine is!
-Semifreddo: It's like a cross between a creme brulee, and an ice cream cake.  Have a bite and take a sip of the Vin Santo.  "Ridiculous".  It's so ridiculous that Sexy Hombre was enticed to use profanities to describe how (again) "RIDICULOUSLY DELICIOUS" it was!
-Chocolate Gelato with a side of Toffee: This was on the house, which made it that much yummier!  I don't know if I've ever had Chocolate Gelato THAT good!  The cute server, originally from Boston (love him!), told us about the rarity of the chocolate...I can see why.  Oh, don't let me forget to tell you about the Toffee.  Be careful, it will stick to your teeth, but let it marinate in your mouth to form a caramel consistency.  Take another sip of the Vin Santo and there goes my "RIDICULOUS MOMENT"!  I literally had to pause for a moment and wonder if this was real.  It was.  

Thank you a million times, Sexy Hombre!  Definitely a night to remember...I heart Bday dinners!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Order the Tortelli di Zucca - Pasta filled with Roasted Butternut Squash, Sage Butter, Rapini and Hazelnuts. DELISH. Went here for lunch today and it was delectable - everything from the bread sticks to the lunch entrées. Why not five stars? While the service was good, it was a little slow for a business lunch, which can be tricky when you're tight on time. Fun tidbit - according to the restaurant's website, "Perbacco" is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.
author: Brittany M.

description:
open for only four months and they already have 105+ reviews?!  crazy.  anyway, went here after one of the partners of my company suggested it.  menu at the door looked decent so we walked right in on a busy friday night without reservations at around 8ish and were seated right away at a nice table along the banquette.

service was a little slow but at least the food was good.  breadsticks with the salsa verde were a little bland but OK.  we shared the yellowfin tuna crudo to start.  it was also nice but a tad bland.  but then again, i do prefer mild over in-your-face flavor.  during another visit, we shared a large plate (4 slices of each variety) of the chef's selection of salumi: so good!  the meats were sweet and meaty and not at all overly salty.  definitely recommend getting that to share.

and then our main plates eventually arrived.  i went with the half order of the butternut squash mezzalune and i'm so glad i did!  the pasta part of it was perfectly cooked and had just the right thickness.  and the filling had a pleasant flavor and wasn't ridiculous chunky at all.  that was definitely the highlight of my meal.  during another visit, i had the ricotta and garlic gnocchi.  again, the half size.  it was alright, but not nearly as fabulous as the butternet squash.

decided to get some dessert as well since i've been in a dessert kind of mood lately.  went with the meyer lemon semifreddo which was just a huge cylinder of lemon ice cream with a side of huckleberry(?) compote.  let me tell you, their desserts are no joke.  i'm pretty sure they're meant to be shared, but no one warned us!  we ended up getting one dessert each, and those two desserts definitely could have been enough for four.  the next time i visited, i made sure to order the "brutti ma buoni" hazelnut cookies that my friend ordered the last time.  they are really sweet but the airy texture makes it an overall delight.  oh and the tiny little nougat cubes and chocolate cubes they brought at the end were cute and pleasant.
author: spiff e.

description:
Three stars:  Food rates 5 but the corporate execution and noise of the place detract significantly.

The food is excellent but soulless.  I like the sole.  Their filled pastas are excellent.  LOUD almost everywhere except near the walls upstairs.  Like the frito misto appetizer (the fried olives are excellent).  

Can't stand getting to the restroom downstairs because the stairs are hazardous (take the elevator even if it seems stodgy).
author: Rachel E.

description: This place rocks! And doesn't rock the bank as one would suspect! The food is so, so, soooo good but the wine is so on! No paring needed here, you point and click! The service is very on! Right when you think, oh shit! Another snobby ass, wanna be joint meant to please the new yorker snob f#@k! You can stroll your a$$ in there and you are sure to find a lower life than you, but you will eat great food, drink very good wine, be treated very very well and rub elbows with the city's no so so pretentious prick! Get in there kick back, feel good, leave and get some booty from your girl, cuz it was a good night! Thanks Perbacco! The FOOOOOD is GOOOOOD and The WINE is KILLER!
author: Miguelito C.

description: Here for dinner on a busy Saturday night with some friends and a good time was had by all - we shared the salumi platter to start and loved it, then did the pasta tasting - we chose the ravolini with lemon and ricotta which was lovely, very delicate flavor, the noodles with short rib ragu which was rich and comforting and the sea urchin risotto - I was worried that the sea urchin would be too strong for me, but in fact there were just a few small pieces on top and the risotto itself had more of a citrus flavor.  For us, that was perfect, but if you're expecting a big plate of sea urchin, I could see that you would be disappointed.  For dessert, we shared the berry gelato (not my thing), the caramel gelato with sea salt (incredibly creamy) and the ugly hazelnut cookies, which we all agreed were the best of the desserts.  The waiter was very friendly, not intrusive, and when he realized he had messed up my drink order not once, but twice, he provided the cookies free of charge, which was a nice gesture.
author: Jocelyn R.

description:
Excellent!  
We enjoyed the frito misto appetizer (soo yum!), the duck...truffle-herb gnocci...and steak.  All of it was fantastic,  

Was it croweded and nosiy? Yes, but despite this, the service was great, we were very well taken care of and left very happy campers.  I would recommend this for a "see and be seen" night out.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
A nice addition to that Financial District.  I went there for drinks one night - definitely try the Perbacco! cocktail, a yummy blend of vodka, Amaretto and Meyer lemon.  It was a good scene for a Thursday night.  Not too crowded, not too noisy in the bar.  

Then, we were seated for dinner, and the dining area was a somewhat different experience.  So loud you almost couldn't hear across the table, although the food was fantastic. Try the pappardelle, it's great.  Would've been a five-star experience if I hadn't needed to shout and pantomime to my friends across the table to continue the conversation.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I know I am the 390th person to review this place but I had to throw my hat into the ring. Finally made it to dinner at Perbacco last night after wanting to go there for quite some time, and after hearing all the rave reviews.

Upon arrival, I was partially turned off immediately because of the crowd. There was a crowd out front, a crowd around the reception desk, and a crowd in the bar. I opened the door, got a rush of hot air, the loud boom of a few hundred people talking in an echo-y room, then fought my way to the reception desk to check in for my reservation (this is 6pm on a Thursday).

Throughout the time I was there, the staff were all very nice and professional despite the stress of having a packed restaurant. The receptionist smiled and had her act together, the waiter was attentive and gave great suggestions, and everyone thanks you on the way out. No complaints over service.

The food was equally good. We started off with the chef's selection of Salami - and it was actually a very impressive spread of cured meats (all done in-house so they say). We also ordered the Red & Gold Beat salad which was fresh, and the Hamachi which was equally as fresh (but I am spoiled by being able to get fresh Hamachi anywhere in SF practically). For dinner I had the duck and it was cooked to perfection - very good. She had the Butternut Squash Lune, a little heavy on the butter but fresh and delicious. Desert - we ordered the Pistachio cake and it was soft and decadent.

SO WHY 3 STARS CRAIG?
The problem is the NOISE LEVEL. It is loud. I could barely carry on a conversation without shouting. I found myself rushing through the meal so I could get outside and out of the noise. I've come to Perbacco before for drinks, but now I am thinking that the inviting bar scene is a real dis-service to the restaurant scene.  The food highlights by far are the salami selection and the wine menu. I'd come back anytime for a glass of wine and a nice salami appetizer plate - but I think I'll bring by top-dollar dinner budget to a quieter location where I can relax a bit more.
author: Craig G.

description: Great menu with great flavorings and lots of creativity. Sat in a private room in the back so it was very quite versus the much louder main area.
author: Joe P.

description:
I've been meaning to try Perbacco for the past year or so and a coworker took me here today for lunch.  

From the minute I stepped in, I felt like I was in swank New York eatery...soo cool inside. The bathroom is down in the basement, through tunnels and over train tracks; it's deep in there.
 
The food was awesome -- I had the market salad and the grilled hanger steak.  Hot, fresh and the meat was perfectly cooked.  She had the daily special which was fish, and really enjoyed it. Service was fast and friendly.  

The inside is really cool too with the brick and industrial feel.  I'll definitely come back and try their dinner menu.
author: Joe U.

description: We hosted an event here and it was SO wonderful! Such a cool atmosphere and the food was DELICIOUS! Great service too! Loved this place!
author: Jessie S.

description:
Let me start by saying that I joined Yelp JUST so I could write a review of this restaurant. This was the best dining experience I've ever had. 

The food was excellently prepared. After watching all those shows on the Food Network, I finally understand about different flavors complementing each other. I had the sea bass and my boyfriend had the quail. When I tried a piece of his quail, I wasn't even sure I had picked up a piece of poultry. It was so soft and buttery! My sea bass was perfectly cooked and came with an amazing flavored butter of some sort as a garnish. I wish now that I had paid more attention to the details of each dish on the menu.

Our waiter suggested we try a side of brussel sprouts. For those of you who claim to hate brussel sprouts...you need to try these. They were so delicious! Cooked with a slight crunch, topped with Parmesan cheese and served over capers.

The service we received was above and beyond anything I've experienced. Our waiter was present enough to take care of our needs before we even had to ask, but not so present that it was annoying or even noticeable in some cases. They also don't rush you out immediately after your meal, allowing you to sit and relax, perhaps finish up the bottle of wine you ordered.

I wish I could dine here more often, but distance and price would prevent that. This is a great restaurant for that once-in-a-while fine dining excursion or maybe a date night.
author: Kim. B.

description:
Went here for a birthday party with 8 people (also see review by Carolyn B.)- food was delicious but the service stunk! I can't say I'd never go back but I'll keep my eye on reviews to see if the service improves. I thought the homemade pasta was delicious but we should have ordered 4 for 8 people as appetizers instead of 3...especially since we waited so long for them to even take our order. The pasta came out quickly but that was about the only redeeming part of the service.

If you're going to try this place, maybe go with a smaller party and give it a try...everything we ate was great...hopefully they can get their act together with their service.

Oh- and they DID hail us a cab at the end of the night, so that was a plus.
author: Diane S.

description:
"Good gracious, good heavens...expressions of surprise"...this is the definition of "Perbacco" and it's apt. Last night I dined again, for maybe the fifth time, at Perbacco and for the third time I closed the place without even realizing it. The poor staff...

We usually start at the bar with a cocktail. I'm partial to the Mandarino. If you hit the bar before 9pm its usually packed. It's a convivial joint and gets loud. The centerpiece at the bar is a meat slicer, but this isn't any old kitchen tool. This is a completely refurbished big red Berkel meat slicer from 1905. It is a beautifully designed piece of mechanical engineering and sets the stage for the (exceptional) salumi selection you'll find on the menu. Admiring the meat slicer and draining the Mandarino we were escorted upstairs to our table (I prefer sitting upstairs over the main floor...much quieter), seated and menu'ed.

I started with the Heirloom tomato salad (heirlooms are everywhere right now). I entree'd with the Liberty Farms Duck Breast. Around the table was the ricotta and spring garlic gnocchi, the lamb shank and more pasta. We ordered a bottle of light red...the conversation was so much fun that I just passed the ordering off to the sommelier who delivered a perfect choice and a very modest price. For dessert we shared gelati misti ( bitter-sweet chocolate /caramel with black sea salt /torrone), lemon -buttermilk panna cotta (strawberry compote /black pepper shortbread /mosto cotto) and warm polenta cake with olive oil gelato /rhubarb compote. All were fabulous...especially the salted caramel ice cream.

As we finished the desserts, we looked around and found ourselves the last to leave. A beautifully prepared meal, excellent service and a warm atmosphere led to a memorable evening with friends and great conversation. For an evening out with friends this is a hard place to beat. (4.5 stars)
author: Gary C.

description:
I've been to Perbacco three times in the last year.  Once last December, another time about a month ago, and a third time this past Friday.  I have to say, I have never had a bad meal or had bad service at this place.

The first time around, my husband and I went for my birthday.  We had the salumi appetizer, w/c was very good - good variety and flavor.  I had a fish entree w/c was good, but the standout was my husband's shortrib entree.  So flavorful and rich without being overly greasy.  

The second time around, my hubby and I went w/ my sis and her hubby.  We also shared the salumi misti plate and the portions were very generous, and also had the local anchovy crudo, which was nice and briny but not too salty.  We also brought our own wine and ordered a bottle off the regular menu.  The sommalier was great, they were not snooty or condescending, which can sometimes happen when you bring your own wine (it helped I think that the wine we brought was unusual and not normally available to restaurants).  My hubby ordered the rabbit, which meh, I am not a fan of game, so I didn't taste it.  Apparently it was good, but I"ll take his word for it.  I had the roasted chicken w/c was absolutely luscious.  It was juicy and flavorful.  Yum.  I loved how attentive the service was, not too pushy and hovering, but always there whenever you needed them.

Last Friday, I went back w/ my girl friends, one of whom was desperately craving good prosciutto.  We tried to order the prosciutto, but apparently the restaurant was all out.  We were extremely upset, since the whole point of going to Perbacco was to get prosciutto.  Happily, the manager managed to find us some prosciutto (despite their earlier protestations) and we were able to eat our fill.  We also shared the salumi plate and a bottle of wine.  We were looking for a particular type of wine - medium and full bodied, tannins, not too fruity and the sommalier let us taste a number of different bottles before we settled on one.  Service was realy top notch, IMO.  It probably helped that we were four cute young gals.

Well, that's it, I LOVE Perbacco.  I give four stars for the food and the eminently reasonable prices, but an extra star for the service beyond the call of duty.
author: Leah S.

description:
OK - this place is the bomb. Ive been here several times and Perbacco has yet to disappoint me. I even think that this place is better than Delfina - yes - I said it..better than Delfina.

let me tell you why - 
-for one thing you dont have to wait two weeks for a reservation :)
-freshly made pastas - try the 5 hour pork sugo with tagliate or raviolis
-great appetizers - love the seared squid which melts in your mouth  and the breadsticks that accompany your food
-awesome entrees - fall of the bone beef short ribs..yum!
-tasty wine list - 
-complementary chocolates they give you after dessert.

I heart Perbacco
author: Christian S.

description:
I think this is one of the best restaurants in SF...The wait staff is really friendly and knowledgeable, the food is delicious, and the wine list is great!  Oooh, and the cheese too...don't forget the cheese.  

My only gripe is that sometimes, on extra super busy nights, it can get loud.  But eh, for really yummy food, I can take the noise.
author: Stef Z.

description: Went here on a Wednesday for lunch with a group of 11.  I didn't know what to expect, but this place has a very elegant and fancy first impressions when you walk into the door.  They sat us up stairs in their back room that was for groups.  Waiter service was good and they were very prompt in refilling out water glasses/drinks and brought us our orders within 20 minutes for a group of 11.  I ordered the Gnocchi and I thought it would be filling for a $18 plate, but it was pretty small, but luckily I filled up on the bread before hand.  They do serve the entrees on big white plates, so that could be another reason why portions seem so small.  This place is definitely for a dinner date or business meeting.
author: Joseph C.

description: Nice atmosphere. We sat upstairs were it was quieter. Had octopus appetizer which was good. The pieces were nice and big. Then had seared duck medium rare, which was really good. They serve small breadsticks and you have to ask for a roll of bread on the house. Dessert was chocolate mousse. Overall, a nice place for dinner and located near embarcadero.
author: Felecia W.

description:
I confess that I'm partial to celebrating my birthday at the same few select restaurants in San Francisco each year, with the guarantee of a fantastic meal. For my recent 27th, my foodie Father suggested we make a reservation at Perbacco, having himself had a great meal there prior. I hesitantly agreed but was soon thereafter reminded that way way back as a teeny tyke,  I professed to my parents that "it's so important to sample new products" which actually stuck as my motto. In this case, Perbacco stood as the "new product" and I'm pleased to report, I'm quite glad I tried it. From a vast and pleasing wine-list to delicious appetizers, entrees and great service, Perbacco proved to be not only a satisfying alternative to my usual birthday spot, but a delicious Italian restaurant worth coming back. 

As someone with dietary restrictions (gluten, no soy, spicy, fatty, creamy foods, limited dairy, no acidic, etc), eating out poses challenges that often a restaurant is not equipped to deal with. In this case, I bashfully explained to our server my particular restrictions and was pleasantly surprised at how immediately accommodating he was. To me, that set the tone for the meal and I knew I'd be able to fully enjoy my choices without feeling the need to settle. He pointed out menu selections that included wheat and even options I might want to avoid just in case. When our barrata and heirlume tomato appetizer came to the table topped with breadcrumbs he-apologetically-asked if I'd like my own small slice sans breadcrumbs. I, not wanting to be a hassle, declined but after insistence from my father and the waiter, gratefully obliged. Good move as I absolutely loved the fresh cheese and tomatoes, paired in perfect harmony. With my taste buds delightfully ignited I eagerly awaited the arrival of my main course. 

I consider myself a healthy eater, food-intolerance's aside, but every now and then I get a craving that I must satisfy. When my craving focuses on meat, or in this case, pork, nothing else will do and my mindset is to go big or don't bother. As this was my birthday and my pork craving on an all-time high, I found my perfect match in Perbacco's "porchetta" entree. All I can say is HOLY PORCHETTA. It was cooked perfectly, juicy and tender rather than swallowed in fat as is oven the case especially with a technique of pork using the belly. Personally, as much as I love meat I can't handle the texture of fatty cuts nor can my stomach digest them. So, I was incredibly pleased to be able to truly enjoy pork with the texture and flavor components I prefer in line. Finally, dessert of sorbet left a refreshing finishing touch to a great meal.  

I would most definitely return to Perbacco
author: Lisa H.

description:
After reading all the great reviews, I had a surprisingly lackluster business lunch here.  We ordered the squid appetizer, salumi plate, tajarin (tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo), and salted caramel ice cream/raspberry sorbet for dessert.

The squid and salumi were good, but really nothing special.  The pasta was beautifully hand-cut and tasted good, but again, not amazing.  The meal was quite heavy also.  Nothing particularly subtle about any of it.  

The service was also surprisingly bad, given that this is an upscale joint.  We ordered an Arnold Palmer that didn't come until the end of the meal.  And when I asked for my leftover pasta to go, they took it away and forgot to bring it back to me.  I had to get their attention and ask for it after we had already paid.  

The food was good enough to return if this were a modestly priced restaurant.  But at $90 for lunch for 2 people (including tip), I really expected better.  Good thing this was a business-expensed outing.
author: Leslie L.

description: Just took a client here for dinner.  The waiter was very knowledgeable and the service was very good.  I started with the potato leek soup which was tasty and I really enjoyed the pinot noir we ordered.  My main course was a pasta with 5 hour cooked pork.  YUCK.  Seriously, this is the worst thing I have had at a restaurant in a long time. It was bland and seriously looked like dog food on the plate.  I say again, YUCK.  For desert I really enjoyed the salted carmel ice cream.  Hence the two star review - good service, good soup, great ice cream, and minus three stars for the worst pasta dish ever served at a restaurant.  I have to also say that the pasta was served overcooked, which to me was adding insult to injury.  I would recommend skipping Perbacco and heading over to Barbacco.  I have never had a bad meal there.
author: S. S.

description:
Good food, good service and complimentary drinks!

I was there on a girls' night out. We arrived on time for our 8pm reservation, but waited a few mins for the table. We didn't mind nor did we complain as we were having a good time chit-chating. The manger was nice enough to give us complimentary drinks because of the wait!
author: C L.

description: Fabulous dinner, lovely private room, attentive staff, amazing food. It was truly a pleasure to work with the staff at Perbacco while planning our company dinner on May 18. Our guests loved the experience and, even more importantly, my bosses heaped me with compliments...
author: Tess R.

description:
Second time I've eaten here and it was just as good as I remember. It was just an early dinner with a friend so we actually only ordered drinks and a pasta dish each. Service was excellent, from the hostess to all the waitstaff. I know we weren't a big bill, but it was a Monday night so I didn't feel too bad, but even as we stayed chatting, they kept filling up our water and weren't rushing us out at all.

The breadsticks, as well as the bread they serve are tasty. I had their cucumber drink with vodka instead of gin and it was good. I went with the octopus and squid ink pasta with bone marrow, hoping it would be like a similar dish that Marea in NYC is famous for and while it wasn't really the same, this one was still very good. One complaint though, it was very salty, I couldn't drink enough water during and after dinner. My friend got the papparadelle with braised short ribs and she really liked it to.

The other complaint I have about this place, and yes, I realize we're in the Financial, but the dinner size pasta servings aren't very big. I'm not expecting North Beach family style Italian, but still, the portions are definitely on the small side, especially when you're spending $18 on pasta.

The cheese selection looked great but we passed, I couldn't think about having anymore salt after my salty dish. I will definitely go back here though, glad to see that over the years as restaurants come and go, this is still a solid option for really quality food.
author: Lauren M.

description:
After finishing a movie at the nearby Embacadero cinema, we went over to Perbacco for dinner. After reading all the reviews, we ordered the Salame Nostrano for appetizer, delicious! You also get breadsticks with pesto dip at the beginning.

For entree, I ordered the Pappardelle, braised short rib ragu and roasted chanterelles and bf had the Tajarin, Handcut Tagliatelle, 5 hr pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.
I really liked my pappardelle dish and bf's Tajarin was equally good with fine angel-hair-like pasta. Both were really flavorful and not too cheesy and pasta to sauce equation was excellent!

We loved the decor of the restaurant, very modern and yes good space. The bathrooms downstairs is cute and has lovely sinks. Maybe it was too cute that the couple next to us disappeared downstairs together when their entree arrived! (Hmmm....) Case of aphrodisiac?

To finish off the meal, we ordered the pistachio panna cotta with blood orange, it was VERY good. I love panna cotta and this restaurant serves up a great and smooth textured panna cotta! Excellent.
author: Yan M.

description:
Okay, so I didn't actually get to eat a full-on meal at Perbacco, so my rating is kind of arbitrary...however, I was lucky enough to get to join in on the tail end of my aunt's 53rd birthday dinner there! 

I was going out with my aunt and uncle for after-dinner drinks, and they asked to me to meet them at Perbacco, but they weren't quite finished with their meal when I got there, so they let me squeeze in with them at a booth and I got to try my aunt's salmon dish and my uncle's pesto gnocchi! YUM! 

They had also saved some of their appetizers from the beginning of the meal for us to sample, so while they finished up dinner, their server was kind enough to have their leftovers re-plated, which were then brought out for my boyfriend and I to enjoy at the bar!

I thought this was a very nice service, to tell you the truth, I have never, in my life, thought to have anything I ordered at a restaurant "re-plated," to then revisit at a different juncture in the meal...! But then again, my aunt has been part of the fine dining circuit for far, far longer than I have, so I guess she just knows about these things!!! 

Thanks to my experience at Perbacco, I learned about the concept of re-plating! YESSSSS!!!!

And, fyi, my aunt and uncle both really liked their food, which says a lot because they are both UBER-PICKY and sometimes quite hard to please...and they liked Perbacco, so it must be really good :)
author: Shannon R.

description:
I would give 2-3 stars if we hadn't had the sommelier. He suggested the perfect wine and when we loved it, we asked his opinion on the food and he suggested 3 of the dishes we had already decided we wanted. Yesss. Great wine list. 

Our meal was good. We had the burrata - came with an olive compote and crostini. Perfect portion size. Not as good as Farina, better than Delfina. We also got the octopus. I remember it was good and that's all I remember.

We had the ricotta gnocchi with wild mushrooms which was GREAT. Really rich, very big portion.  We also got the house meats platter thingy for my guy. It came with a piece of homemade pancetta, homemade blood sausage, and homemade regular sausage. Pretty gnarly stuff but he liked it.

Our appetizer came before our bread basket, and the entrees quickly after. Dessert took twice as long to get to us than our food. The boy ordered the butterscotch panna cotta. To DIE for. As for me...the gelati/sorbet had 3 options. I asked our server if you were to order 1 for $7 or you get a selection of all 3 for $7. She said she could give me a little scoop of each for $7. Great. She comes back with 5 scoops of gelato and said "oh the chef misunderstood me and they gave you a scoop of each in the freezer." Then she charged me $12. Who does that? At least the gelati were awesome--the burnt caramel with salt was one of the best things I've ever tasted. The espresso had chunks of fudge, the lemon was super bright and sour. The truffle honey was .... well let's just say it tasted like mushrooms. 

I'll be back for a glass of wine, appetizer, and the gelato.
author: Abbie B.

description:
I was so excited to try out Perbacco, and they did not disappoint.  Definitely try some of their homemade salumi...the fennel salumi was absolutely delicious. I had the monk fish which was excellent, and my boyfriend had the pork shoulder, which totally blew my dish out of the water. The pork was so tender, it was like cutting into a stick of butter. For dessert we had the gelato trio...so amazingly good, especially the carmel and sea salt gelato.

**UPDATE**
Their reservationists and management are incredible. I made a reservation for 10, which they were extremely helpful with, which I unfortunately had to cancel. Their policy states that, if you cancel outside of 48 hours prior to your reservation, they will charge your credit card $25, and mail you a Perbacco gift card. Well, I didn't cancel within 48 hours, and I told them I was just fine with being charged. I just received a call from their management, who said that he wouldn't be charging me. So fantastic...God I love this place!!!

Service was extremely attentive, but not obtrusive. Just perfect.

The only downside to Perbacco is the noise...it's a pretty open space, so conversations definitely reverberate throughout the restaurant, but it would never stop me from coming back.  Five enthusiastic stars!!!
author: Brianne K.

description:
Perbacco in dialect means WOW! I love the brick lined walls and the soft overhead lights - giving the place a modern twist on Rustic Northern Cuisine.

I've been to Perbacco numerous times (my birthday dinner celebration, a co-worker luncheon, a stop-over for wine and salumi misti) always had a nice experience.  

My friend & I decided to stop by on a gorgeous Tuesday night without reservations and were immediately seated. NiCE.

For starter we shared the Vitello Tonnato - DELICIOUS.  Thinly sliced veal with a wonderful lemon tuna sauce.  The sauce is so delicate and the tuna (which you can not taste) gives the veal substance and enhance the sweetness of the slow roasted meat.  The arugula and capers cut the sweetness with a nice tangy finish.  I highly recommend trying it.  It's worth it!

We both ordered a pasta dish - tajarin (think il ragu' bologenese) and pansotti (ravioli).  Wonderful home made pastas topped off with a nice complementing sauce.

Of course, we washed it all down with a nice bottle of Barbera D'Alba - Andrea Oberto 2005.  Wonderful with pasta dishes.

As usually we skip dessert.  At the end of the meal, our server brought out 4 itsy-bitsy dessert amuse morsels - perugiana and torrone.  Perfect ending.

Service was nice.  Our guy is friendly but he tends to forget to fill our wine glasses.  The sommelier is knowledgeable.  Noise level is nice unless you are seated next to a loud-mouth drunken patron.
author: Veritas V.

description:
Had lunch here.  The food was good and the service was good.  No reservation for 2 for lunch; but of course always recommended.  

What I didn't like was how quickly they usher you in and out of this place.  You sit, the bread sticks came, order placed in, the bread immediately came, 5 minutes later, entree in front of you, barely done eating and still wanted to nibble on the bread sticks/breads & the cleaning guys comes and takes everything off the table, including the salt & pepper.  We were done with lunch in 20 minutes.  

We didn't pay this much for "fast" food.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Came here to help celebrate my Mom's Birthday last night.  It's an elegant Italian restaurant that's right in the middle of the Financial District on California Street.  

We went in and sat upstairs.  Tried the Salumi appetizer combination, which we had a variety of 10-12 different types of salumi from different parts of Italy made in-house.  Different, exciting and tasty.  

We then decided to try their pasta dishes as our main course.  
All of the various pastas were hand-made, fresh and delicious.  
You must go to the restaurant to dine if you would like to try some 'el dente' pasta.....  very good, indeed.

We ended up having some of their almondine cookies as a dessert to end the meal.  They had these freshly, soft and chewy cookies that were a welcome treat.  I can't say that I've had such a 'almost-airy' type cookie.  

I would definitely recommend going to the restaurant as this Italian establishment seems to have the right mix of quality food and service for such an occasion.
author: Edward L.

description:
Perbacco offering northern Italian cuisine opened in San Francisco in late October '06 and has by now ironed out most of the wrinkles many new restaurants face.  Combining historical elements (original brick wall dating from around 1914) with sleek, modern lines the ambience is both comfortable and appealing.  

Prices are reasonable for the Bay Area with small plates (half orders) and most appetizers in the $10-14 range.  It's nice to go with friends who enjoy sampling several dishes and ordering several half orders that can be shared.  

I started with a Rosmarino cocktail ($9) of Grey Goose vodka with lemon, rosemary simple syrup and apple brandy - sweet but good, served with a sprig of rosemary.  Consult with their Italian sommelier who knows his stuff and can assist you in selecting a wine to pair with your meal.  

We started out with a half order of the Salumni Misti ($18) which featured a variety of cured meats including mortadella and fennel salame.  We also sampled half orders of the Butternut Squash Mezzelune ($9) - delicious with sage browned butter and Castelmagno cheese - and the Tajarin ($10) handcut tagliatelle pasta with pork sugo and porcini mushrooms - very succulent and smooth with a orange zest addition which worked very well with this dish. 

Entrees for the most part are in the $20-29 range.   My party selected the Beef Short Ribs ($21) with celery root puree, and the Pork Shoulder ($19) with savoy cabbage and polenta.  I had the Pork with was so tender you didn't need a knife to cut it.  The flavor was good and the cabbage paired well with the meat.  Sadly, the polenta had absolutely no flavor whatsoever.  Considering the soupy texture and bland taste - this side was very disappointing.  

The chocolate tart ($8) and the trio of gelato ($7) - hazelnut, bitter-sweet chocolate, and pistachio were the perfect ending to a delightful meal.  

A few added notes -  portion sizes were a bit small so be aware.  Service could have been faster, but due mainly to the kitchen and not the servers themselves who were quite attentive.  

The acoustics of the warm and inviting interior when filled with people can make it challenging to hear your own conversation.  Ask for the 2nd level dining area, if available, or a table near the back where it may be more quiet.  

Parking may be a bit of a hassle in this area - Perbacco is next to the Tadich Grill and near Aqua - so either be open to walking a distance or go with the valet which is available.  

Finally, the restrooms, which leave a little to be desired, are on the basement level.  You can however take the stairs or an elevator.  Overall, rating the quality of the food, the flavor combinations and options available, the staff, and the interior design you will enjoy the experience of dining at Perbacco.
author: Mike G.

description:
The menu was full of delicious things which really made choosing difficult.  I ended up going for the prosciutto and pea stuffed tortelloni preceded by the selection of cured meats, both of which were delicious.  Desert and wine were both above par and the service was excellent.  There was quite a din in the room...not sure if it's the acoustics or what, but it definitely was loud.  

Overall, great food and I'd head back, even for lunch.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Good food, nice ambiance, decent prices. 

Oh their roasted octupus was so flavorful! Come here if you are looking for authentic Italian cuisine.
author: April Rose D.

description:
We are regulars at Perbacco. After a few unsuccessful attempts for waterfront restaurants on NYE, we decided to go to Perbacco for the 2nd nite in a row. Walked in and got a table at the bar with no problem.

I had somethings I've not tried before. The pear/hazelnut/fennel salad was very good with a mild gorgonzola dressing. But what's really incredible was the crab gnnochi, first time on the menu. OMG, to die for. I hope they keep it on menu!
author: Judy D.

description: This place is awesome.  If you have a group try getting the chefs table by the Kitchen.  The seared Sea Scallops are wonderful!
author: David C.

description:
I've been a few times for lunch, and the food has always been good and the service has always been nice.  I went yesterday and was pleased to see that the pork shoulder was back on the menu...  it was my previous favorite and was great this time as well.  The cabage and polenta that came with it were very good as well. 

A special thanks to the owner Umberto.  I met him when I was considering venues for the rehearsal dinner prior to my wedding.  Ultimately I went a different direction, but Umberto was the nicest, most professional person I dealt with at any of the 10+ SF restaurants I considered.  (The space is also great too, by the way.)

The food, atmosphere, and service at Perbacco get a solid 4 stars.  Umberto earns the bump to 5.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I had dinner for three here last night. This place was recommended to me by a former SF concierge. She said to eat appetizers mostly and she was right. Appetizers blew the entrees out of the water. The cured meats were fantastic as well as a meaty grilled octopus. A ricotta cheese over three summer melons was also pleasant if slightly hard to eat. Entrees included leg of lamb and a pasta. Neither were as good as the appetizers. Service was fine.

Eat upstairs for more quite dining.
author: R K.

description: Went there for a large corporate group dinner.  I was highly impressed that even in the group dinner, fixed menu situation, the food was outstanding!  Had scallops which are hard not to over or under cook in the best of circumstances.  Looking forward to returning.
author: James S.

description: Ok.  This was a great place.  Food, wine list, service, ambiance.  All great.  You may be wondering "why only one star?".  Im gonna keep it short.  After we paid our bill. After we got up off our seats.  After we all agreed that we all had a wonderful evening....a COCKROACH is racing across our table.  We gave our leftovers to a homeless man.  'Nuff said.
author: Carlos P.

description: My husband and I love this restaurant and dine here whenever we visit San Francisco. We are always warmly welcomed and the hip urban atmosphere is perfect. The menu is very interesting and the food is well prepared. I had the Lagaroli and my husband had Rabaton. Both were outstanding. The extensive, fairly priced wine list is always appreciated. As usual the restaurant was full. The only negative during this visit was our very perfunctory server. We almost felt like our presence was bothering him. We have had always had excellent service here - one of the best in a SF restaurant but not this time. It will, however, not deter us from returning.
author: MC B.

description:
Had an excellent dinner here last Friday night.  I was a bit disappointed to be seated upstairs, away from the beautiful bar, but the staff upstairs quickly made us feel welcome.  We had the crudo (raw fish appetizers), salumi assortment (most of which are truly excellent and way different textures than you experience w/your average deli stuff), a mini pasta course (chard, ricotta and walnut ravioli for me, some kind of pork ragu for hubby) and entree (short rib - yum and rabbit for hubby -- also yum).  Oh, and we split the lemon buttermilk panna cotta for dessert -- which was outstanding.

The food was excellent.  The stand out for me was the service, and particularly on the wine front.  We weren't drinking bottles that night and the way we were treated when "just drinking glasses" was incredible.  New bottles were opened and presented to us at the table.  Our server even suggested splitting glasses so that we could have an ideal match with each course.  Marvy.  Most interesting was a sparkling red w/the salumi course -- a Lambrusco.  If you want to try some Italian wines you haven't seen anywhere else -- here you go.  (You can even sign up for the Italian Wine Sommelier courses scheduled for Fall 2007!)

Give it a go -- eat at the bar down stairs (or in one of the cozy booths) for probably the most 'hip' experience.
author: Amy A.

description:
I've been here for both lunch and dinner so I have a particular insight into this place.  For dinner, it's best to go all out and order cocktails, house made salumi and fritto misto to start.  It may sound icky buy the blood salami has a great rich, salty flavor.  Also the rosemary cocktail tastes better than it sounds.  Both tajarin and papardelle pastas are good but I agree with the others that the papardelle is better.

At lunch I ordered the hangar steak.  Although the waiter hadn't asked my preference, the steak came out exceedingly rare.  This is fine by me (I ate the blood salami, didn't I?) but one more squeamish might have had an issue with that.  Yes, lots of FiDi types, but for once I was one of them, score!
author: Rosie L.

description:
I can't say enough good things about Perbacco. After wanting to go for sometime, we finally made it last night for a birthday celebration. 

I had booked online at Open Table and put in the remarks: birthday celebration so we'd love a good table. Now, I almost always ask for a good table but so far, I don't think anyone has actually read the notes! We arrived to a fantastic table with a handwritten "Happy Birthday" notecard. Wow. 

The food was excellent. The server, Michael, superb. He even got us a taxi at the end of the night! The wine delicious. And the bill, as someone else noted, not as bad as I imagined. It is pricey if you do it right but for a downtown restaurant, I felt there was a lot of value. 

We can't wait to return!
author: Danielle L.

description:
I have to yelp about Perbacco. Loved this new Italian place in downtown SF. I took a chance on this new restaurant for a birthday dinner I was hosting. My four guests and I arrived a bit on the early side. While it was a bit noisy, we were escorted to a seating area near the bar where we were served a few delicious cocktails. While we caught up over drinks, I had a chance to notice the surroundings. The bar is complete with a real old-fashioned meat slicer - available to slice the fresh Italian prosciutto, salamis, etc.. We were shown to our seats and I immediately got into the spirit by ordering a bottle of the Drusian Prosecco and the 'salumi misti' (an assortment of the cured meats).

While we waited we munched on some deliciously thin and perfectly salted breadsticks which came with a pesto paste for dipping. For our mains, we ordered pasta, fish, and the short ribs as well as a number of the vegetable sides. Everything was delicious.

Dessert left a bit to be desired. I really enjoyed the chocolate tart, but not so much the lemon tart.

Overall, the service was enthusiastic but not overwhelming, the atmosphere was cheerful (although a bit loud) and the food was wonderful! I recommend Perbacco the next time you're looking for a special Italian night out!
author: Deborah S.

description:
Food: Good.  2 of 7 salumis were delicious.  The rest were all right.  hamachi sashimi was good.  Sea bass and veal agnolotti were good.

Wine: Good list.  Full of Italian varietals.  Had a white wine that I have never heard of.  No complaints.

Price: High for the quality of the food.  Near $100 a head (including wine)

Comfort: Sat at a 2 person table with a crack in the banquette.  Looked around for other open 2 tops and they all has the same problem.  Not a smart design.

Atmosphere: Teeming with 50 year old men and their second wives.

GI effects: Explosive.  The next morning.  and lingering for a few days.  Not thrilled.  Both of us had the same result.

Going back?: What do you think?
author: Eric B.

description: I have been to Perbacco 4 times, with friends, on a date (twice) and with my 2 young kids.  Every single time I/we had a fantastic time.  Everything is really, realy good, very authentic and the menu is wide enough that everyone can enjoy this place.  I will be back again and you should too!
author: M W.

description: had a nice three course lunch here. gotta love it when you can enjoy three courses over a noon hour. the staff was welcoming. we were sat promptly, which clearly means a lot when you are on a schedule. even with time constraints we were able to enjoy unbelievable food and relax in a cool environment.
author: Kelly C.

description: I won't bore you with flowery descriptions and bombastic critiques of each individual dish that we tried.  Suffice it to say that the food was excellent, our server, Kamille (?) was superb and a $40ish bottle of wine that was surprisingly good (utilize the sommelier, he knows what he's doing and not just trying to upsell).  I love this place.  I like the ambience at Boulevard a tad better; but other than that, it's right there.  The sommelier was spot on in his recommendations but his countenance is a bit stern, therefore somewhat intimidating.
author: Patrick R.

description:
I had my birthday dinner at Perbacco the other night and it was great!
Their ravioli was so fresh and had a lot of flavor. Beef tongue salad was also yummy. 

I had a roasted rabbit for my main dish...mmm it wasn't really my fave. The sauce was a little bit too strong for me...

Everything else was just great! Good service, good people, good wines too :) It's gonna be my new favorite Italian restaurant in SF for sure.
author: Christa K.

description:
As soon as you walk into Perbacco, you feel like you are walking into the lobby of the W Hotel. Slightly industrial, minimalist looking. The men are wearing jackets, and the women are wearing black.  

This is the "power lunch" or "power dinner" kind of restaurant. I have no doubt that the group of stern looking men sitting next of us were discussing the possible merger of their 2 companies. 

The food is delicious. I did not get to order off the menu because we were guests of a very generous, philanthropic San Franciscan. In other words, I ate for free. And such an enjoyable meal it was.

I had the fritto misto (delicious), and the pear salad (good if you like sweet salads like Waldorf). I also had the duck with a copious side of brussel sprouts. This is just really good, high-quality Americana on a plate.

Cocktails are strong. The occassion demanded a dirty martini. It goes without saying that the rest of the night is a blur. Before the night faded to black, I made sure to clean off my plate.
author: D N.

description: Absolutely amazing. Service, food, ambiance. I was so full but i would have done it again. This place makes you feel like you are in Italy. Rustic done right. Cheers
author: Sarah P.

description:
Perbacco is a sleek and cool Italian restaurant in San Francisco's Financial District, focusing on the flavor of Italy's Piemonte and Ligurian regions, with a tinge of French and Provencal tastes. With all these diverse influences, Perbacco puts up a long and interesting menu, featuring house made salume selections, a crudo list, and a selection of interesting hand-made pastas. I always appreciate a long-ass and interesting menu, and Perbacco doesn't disappoint.



I am exceedingly fond of our West coast sardines so I couldn't resist sampling the house cured local sardines with salsa verde, celery heart, and marinated egg yolk ($7.00). These were served chilled and had a pronounced and distinctly sardine flavor: you love it or you do not, there is little in between. I found the egg yolks played nicely off the oily fish-ness of the sardines, and the salsa verde gave things a nice herbal flavor.



Next was the roasted red and gold beets with arugula, Castelmagno cheese, and white balsamic vinaigrette ($10.00). This was a simple but successful salad, melding two different varieties of meaty and slightly fruity beets with the peppery bite of arugula and the earthy flavor of a good strong cheese. I have had variants of this dish all over the place in California and this was a pretty worthy (and nicely sized) rendition - and a very attractive presentation to boot.



We flipped for the handcut tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo, porcini mushrooms ($16.00 entree size, $11.00 appetizer sized). Perbacco prides itself on its freshly made pasta, and this dish backs all tha talk up: the fresh and tender tagliatelle went perfectly with the rich and meaty sugo, which had a delightfully earthy flavor derived from porcini mushrooms. My mother enjoyed this so much that she had it for an appetizer and an entree, and I suppose that is a fitting testimonial.



My dad went for the Coniglio al civet with Devil's Gulch rabbit, spiced red wine sauce, otto file polenta, and crispy pancetta. This was a face-foward and distinctly wine flavored dish, and the combination of slightly gamey rabbit, powerfully flavored sauce, and crispy, porky pancetta was a successful one. I wish rabbit found its way onto more menus, Thumper-related sentiments be damned.



I selected the special Ligurian fish stew with lobster broth, mussels, fish, scallops, shrimp, and mussels. The meaty and decadent broth was spiced lightly with saffron and had a piquant flash of tomato: it reminded me rather of a highly refined cioppino. The seafood was fresh and perfectly cooked, bypassing seafood stew's common issues with overcooked and rubbery shellfish. It's a light dish, almost too elegant: I would have liked a bit more of that delicious broth.



The sleeper hit of the evening were the side of brown butter brussels sprouts with capers and parmigiano reggiano ($5.00). These charmers flavored the falling-apart tender sprouts with a powerful hit of capers, rich brown butter, and distinctly stinky parmigiano. The overall flavor was that of a decadently rich and interesting casserole, and these were pretty impossible to risk - although the actual flavor of the sprouts was a secondary player here.

For the dessert course, we tried the pistachio panna cotta ($8.00), a straight forward and satisfyingly firm pudding with a nutty, slightly perfumed pistachio flavor. This was not a fancy dish, but it was a good ending to a rich meal.



We finished with a cheese plate, picking from Perbacco's nice selection of artisan cheeses. We settled on Bianco Sotto Bosco, a cow and goat milk cheese infused with truffles, and Caprino Di Riofrano, goat's milk cheese wrapped in chestnut leaf. ($12.00 for selection of two). I am no cheese critic, but both cheeses were earthy and tasty (and it is very hard to make truffled cheese bad.)

Perbacco's dining room is very sleek and contemporary, and those expecting some sort of homey regional Italian experience will be disappointed. The place has the appearance of a restaurant tailor-made for power lunches and important networking dinners: in other words, don't come expecting a romantic environment or overwrought opera music on the sound system. The beautiful people are served by what seemed to be an engaging and well trained waitstaff: our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and our food came out with impressive speed and timing.

We will certainly return to Perbacco soon. It's excellent and interesting regional Italian dining at surprisingly regional prices - there really isn't much not to love.
author: faine g.

description:
The atmosphere here is very hip.  I saw this restaurant in Food and Wine and had to give it a try.  I walked in here on a Friday night and was told that a table would be available in two hours.  My friend managed to charm an immediate table.

A friend and I were arguing about whether this would be a good date restaurant and he thought no while I thought yes.  He apparently preferred a more chez papa type restaurant, quiet and intimate, while i thought this might provide a good atmosphere for an unknown date.  It was loud, but you cold drown out the din of talkers if you really wanted to.  If not, there was some good people watching.

That said, the food was pretty good.  The menu was extensive, with different selections of meat and pasta,  We had the sea bass, the halibut and the duck with grilled peaches.  Appetizers were the octopus and watermelon salad.  The watermelon salad was decent but not the best i have had.  I recommend trying it yourself.  Watermelon with vinegarette and watercress.  i didn't taste the caviar in the watermelon salad but it was there.  The sea bass was ok, it had a faint taste of scrambled eggs which I couldn't quite place.  The halibut was nice, but had a tasteless affect.  The best and most orginal dish in our party was the duck with roasted peaches, a nice combiantion that went well with a white wine that had peach notes.

We ordered from the wine list by the glass, which comprised primarily Italian wines which were very well selected.  Every wine that we sampled, from light red, to more fruity full bodied red, to fruity white, was solid.  Go here for a solid introduction to Italian wines.  Will not disappoint.  The accompanying food will suffice but will be a mere complement to the extensive wine selection.
author: apple r.

description: This place was impressive on all the in-house made salamis, meats, cheeses. I like the fact that a Swede can outdo an Italian in their cuisine- I think the challenge makes him a better innovative chef. However, the pastas were not impressive at all. We ate at Farina which was far more overpriced, but almost worth it because the pasta was so fresh and melting in your mouth... They are good with meats here. Not so much pasta plates. I guess I would come back if I was craving meat. The prices were very reasonable- that's what would keep me coming back. High quality at a reasonable price.
author: Adelia R.

description:
It's a tough place to open a restaurant: you're on the same block as Aqua and Tadich Grill.  I mean, the former is one of the premier restaurants in the City, and the other one ... umm ... has been in business since 1849.   It's an interesting location choice, especially given that the decor suggests more of a SoMa location.  Exposed brick, stainless steel, and art deco inspired logo reminded me of my dot com days.

It's not your grandma's Italian restaurant.  Instead of focaccia bread and olive oil, you have gourmet breadsticks and pesto dip; instead of generic plates and silverware, you have elegant table settings; instead of spaghetti with meatballs, you have something more gourmet; instead of uncle Mario who is also the host and a short order cook, you have a knowledgeable, pleasant waiter.

I started with a gold and red beets salad with greens and vinaigrette dressing.  Beets are beets, but I liked the presentation.  I only ordered beets because my dinner companion ordered the arugula salad that I really wanted.  Don't blame me for wanting to be original.

Then my entree came.  I opted for the risotto with veal.  The risotto was delicious, and veal was very tender.  Granted, my plate only had two tiny medallions of veal, carefully and delicately placed in the middle of the plate, but they were really, really good.

For dessert, I opted for the pear and almond tart served with Creme Anglaise.  The tart was very rich, and the almond paste was fantastic.  Creme Anglaise was a bit too tart for my taste (no pun intended).  It tasted a bit like sour cream and custard mixed together and left in the sun for a couple of days.  Not my favorite item.  My dinner companion, however, opted for a chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream, which was clearly a better choice.  

Oh, and don't forget to order the espresso.  The tiny cup alone is worth the money.  You can feel very European drinking the espresso, or you can feel like a giant just holding a tiny cup.

Overall, Perbacco is a welcome addition to the San Francisco landscape.  I would gladly go back if I am ever in the mood for an upscale Italian meal in a quiet setting.  I think Perbacco is great for both closing the deal with a big client and for a romantic dinner with that special someone.
author: Yan G.

description:
The food here was fantastic! We started with the salami appetizer and the squash blossom (I think thats what its called).  The salami was good but the squash was excellent.  Its deep fried in batter and stuffed with cheese.  

I ordered the wide ribbon pasta which comes in a short ribs ragu         (forget whats it called)..it was delicious but the sauce was less like a pasta sauce and more like a stew.  My boyfriend ordered the steak and he loved it.  

The dessert was to die for.  We had the apple tart and a butterscotch creme caramel...the creme caramel was awesome!

Our waiter (blonde hair) was great.  He was so nice and gave excellent service without the snooty attitude you get from some restaurants.  Very attentive.  We will definitely be back
author: c L.

description:
Well, it was OK - but nothing too exciting, which disappointed me, given the hype.  Seated promptly, drinks and bread brought quickly.  The breadsticks were deliciously crispy and served with a little ramekin of pesto.  I didn't try the foccacia that was also brought to the table - look kinda doughy.  We ordered right away since we had gotten word that it takes about 45 minutes to receive your food, and being on our lunch hour didn't have that much time to spare

I got the Ligurian tuna salad and my companion got the tortellini and English peas.  The food was brought really fast - almost too fast!  My salad was so pretty to look at - little nicoise olives scattered around the plate along with tiny tiny little green string beans, cherry tomatoes, capers and some hard boiled quail eggs.  Unfortunately, the tuna was way overcooked and had the consistency of chicken of the sea, and there were eggshells on my plate from the hard boiled eggs.  Not quite what I was expecting.  Still, it was kind of good due to the wonderful dressing.  Ron's tortellini were kind of a dull - even the presentation was dull.

The place is pretty cool, and if you've ever eaten at it's predecessor, the Gold Coast, you would never recognize it.  They've preserved the long wooden bar and brick walls, but that's about it.  Lots of light wood paneling, thin strips of mirrors at eye level that really open up the room, and fabulous lighting.  I am a stickler for good linens and cutlery,ery, and Perbacco gets an A on that level.

All in all, it was sort of OK - but not for the price.  I think I may  try again for dinner with a group of people so we can really sample the menu.

And it was TOO DAMN LOUD!
author: .Hon H.

description:
My wife and I ate at Perbacco for Valentines day this year and overall we had a very wonderful experience.  I won't go into any detail about the aesthetics other than to say that the place was visually appealing and very comfortable with plenty of space between tables.  

The service was very pleasant and we had a great waiter who always kept our glasses full.  There was a rather long lull between courses but probably a result of the kitchen and not the waiter.  Our server had great suggestions which we found to be very reliable.

The menu, printed daily, is very complete with something for virtually any palate.  I highly recommend the house cured salami's - while plenty to share between 2 people these meats are so good you'll probably need a second serving.

For our second course we shared the Tajarin which was unbelievable and it was clear why this was the waiters recommendation.  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the Pork Sugo w/Porcini was very rich.

For the entrees my wife had the Sea Bass which was good but unmemorable.  I had the Pork Chop w/Pomegranate condimento which was fantastic.  This was really a great entree which seemed to be the most popular choice that evening.

Dessert was also great.  I had a pear bread pudding which was perfectly done.  My wife had the parmigiano reggiano which was some of the best we've ever had.

We highly recommend Perbacco.  It's a great complement Aqua and Tadich which it neighbors and is a very well priced alternative with very high quality cuisine.
author: Joshua J.

description:
I dined here for the very first time with two friends.  Perbacco is a prime example of service!  The front of the house was very nice and helpful when we thought we had reservations but didn't.  We were seated upstairs and it was packed with all these business meetings/luncheons.  Our server knew the menu.  When my friend wanted wine, she was immediately tended to.  
We shared Piasta Seared Local Squid and Frito Misto Rock Shrimp.  Flavorful and beautifully cooked explains those appetizers.  We each had a pasta dish: Tajarin, Pansoti, and the Pappardelle.  The noodles of the Tajarin were so fresh and I loved the handmade texture and look.  Its meat sauce was comforting and delicious.  The Pansoti was flavorful of herbs and just perfect with the cheese.  The Pappardelle was amazing, especially its shredded short rib.  Tender, juicy, scrumptious!  Any meat eater would love that dish.
Of course we had dessert: Bonet-Piemontese Expresso Custard and the Huckleberry and Meyer Lemon Semifreddi.  Two awesome, dessert scores!!!  I'm not one for anything coffee flavored, but this custard was perfecto in every way.  The semifreddi was presented beautifully and just a wonderful fresher and touch to the end of our meal.
I want my husband to take me back here for sure.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
You know you live in a city that spoils your taste buds when a place like this only receives two stars. Still, Perbacco comes dangerously close to the overpriced/under-impressive touristy feel that befalls downtown restaurants. Everything about Perbacco was good, but nothing about it was really great. 

I arrived early for my early meal (5:45 pm), and was seated in a rather unfavorable seat right under the Muzak speaker. When I asked to be moved shortly thereafter, the hostess became irritated and said the more attractive section I was pointing to was "reserved for those with reservations," as if to say I didn't have one. (I did.) Still, I was moved to a slightly quieter--if more claustrophobic table--further in the back. It wasn't like they were really hurting for seats--this two-level place is rather large, despite its modest facade. But whatever. At least I could dine without K.T. Tunstall blaring in my ears.

The food arrived promptly and with a competent pacing. The introductory bread sticks we received were strangely greasy, although tasty. We opted to try the house-cured prosciutto, which was delicious, especially when paired with the bread sticks. I started with the sugo pasta (nice that they offer their pastas as small or large portions, btw). Was very good, but definitely not the best I'd ever had. The entrees that followed were equally tasty... and good, but not great. My seared tuna was a generous cut of fish, but sort of bland. My friend seemed a lot happier with his skate wing. Desserts came to nearly $10 apiece, and considering the non-stellar-ness of everything thus far, it was enough to make me decide that tuna and sugo had filled me up.

Considering our tab came out to nearly $100 apiece (including a cocktail and half-bottle of wine), I'd probably save Perbacco for out-of-towners on an expense account. It seems the perfect power lunching spot, but for a nice San Francisco dinner, you can definitely do better.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I went on a business lunch here.  The food was very good.  And it is in a great location relative to my office.  I didn't really care for the full length bedroom mirrors turned sideways that form a border around the restaurant walls or the cave type seating area under the upper seating area or the light fixtures.  

But all of this is pish posh.  The main thing here is good food for a good price in a great location.  The rest is all details.  Oh, and Perbacco also gets a thumbs up for their open kitchen area.  If you get the back table you can watch the action.  

If you want to get a group larger than 6 people in here, book more than a week ahead!
author: Alexis M.

description:
The fiance and I went here for a nice little anniversary dinner on Saturday night.  Although we had a reservation, we still had to wait a little bit (and it seems like they were trying to get us a particular table until we said we'd just take anything since there were like 5 other open tables).  
We started off with the tuna tartare, which was average.  But then we had the trotter and, OMG heaven!  It was so amazing that the fiance ordered another one!  Fried pig's feet topped with foie gras has to be one of God's gifts to mankind.  We didn't think much could measure up to that, but we were floored with our duck breast and steak.  The sizes were ample--we definitely could have shared an entree.  The staff was very efficient and helpful and even brought us out some free ice cream to celebrate our anniversary dinner.
Overall a very delicious pick--perfect for a nice evening out.
author: M. C.

description:
Maybe more like "debacle" for us (couldn't resist the pun). We came here after having drinks a couple of dooors down at Aqua. Funny that the group that in front of us also was at Aqua for drinks. Apparently this was an omen of things to come. They arrived about 15mins before and after another 10mins the person in charge went up to the hostess and said cancel our reservation and this is the third time it's happened to me. OK, not us but... we we seated 15mins pass our reservation (happens, it's a Saturday night). We are taken upstairs and seated in a booth. Drafty and dark along the railing overlooking the main dining area and bar. We're moved one over. Still dark and a small book-light was supplied to help us read our menus.

Appetizers:
Tasting of Salame (good)
Prosciutto de San Danielle over melon (very good)
Raw seas scallops with tomato cruda, coriander oil and sea salt (fair-scallop taste lost in the oil)

Entrees:
Beef short ribs with chanterelle mushrooms/peas and mashed potatoes (1-Very good and one was cold and was changed to the Tajarin pasta and the other barely any sauce)
Tajarin pasta (tagliatelle noodles with pork sugo and porcini mushrooms (very good).

Once ordered, everything came very quickly. The entrees came right after we finished our appetizers. Even the replacement dish came quickly. Now an odd part. It's starting to empty out alittle and the service just about disappeared. They'd walk by but not check-in to clear the empty plates. Finally when cleared, the dessert menu came very late so we passed and went to Buena Vista for some Irish Coffee.

Granted, it's unfair to rate places on a 1st visit which is what many of the reviews are and I like to give the benefit of the doubt most of the time. That's what so nice about this site/forum, you can change the rating up or down with future visits.

I really wanted to like Perbacco and many people do, so certainly give them a try.
author: Ed L.

description:
This place has become what Aqua was about 5 years ago. It is THE place for the power lunch.  Fi-Di folks left and right wining and dining and making the deal. 

Prices might be considered a little higher than most places within the Fi-Di but the quality of the food is quite excellent. I believe they are more liguarian style italian food.  As a chef had once told me, "to judge an italian restaurant, you have to try their pasta"  We'll get to that soon enough.

Appetizers:
- Fritto misto - crisp, delicate and not oily!  
- Salumi misti - housemade cured meats!  Need I say more than SALAME and PROSCUITTO! my oh my....
- Beet salad - absolute SUGAR bomb!  paired with arugula and light sprinking of cheese 

Pasta:
- Parpadelle with a short rib ragu: anyone who knows me knows my insane love and obsession with finding the best ragu in the world. Right now, my italian friend's "mama!" still holds the top accolade but Perbacco might be able to kick her off ---- maybe.. :) 
- Agnolotti - pillows of tasty raviolis filled with veal.  YUM!!!!
- Trofie - very fresh pesto and a pretty generous portion of pasta.  

Mains:
- Ligurian tuna salad - the italian style nicoise with a substantial piece of tuna seared on the outside and rare on the inside. 
- Grilled chicken breast - not the most spectacular of their menu but for a lighter option it is good.  Chicken is very moist, even for chicken breasts.  hehe.

Be prepared for a wait, especially without reservations... OR go early i.e. 11:30.  You might also be able to find some financial district eye candy - men in suits! (it totally does something for me!) :)
author: H. Q.

description:
Went there today for a lunch meeting.  Quickly, I was quite impressed with the restaurant.  The hostess was very friendly and efficient.  I also loved the atmosphere of the restaurant.  Classy and cozy.  That's a tough combination to nail.
