When the food was brought to us, I was a bit underwhelmed.  I thought "this is kinda small".  However, it tasted much better than I imagined.  And that's saying a lot!  After the meal, I actually felt satisfied with the portion.

4 stars only cause the service needs a little work.  I had to grab a waiter to get my friend his dessert menu and then he disappeared.  It was a good 10 - 15 minutes before someone asked for my friend's dessert choice.

It's a new place so I'm sure they are working out the kinks.  Definitely, definitely a place to go back to ANYTIME.  Really good crowd and totally okay to have a  conversation.  I didn't have to raise my voice at all.

Like all good places to eat in the Financial District, you need to RSVP to get a table.  Completely worth it.
author: R G.

description:
I went to this place after my friend turned down the idea of Michael Mina's so I guess after having my expectations so high, I wasn't blow away with this place.  When you're a few doors down from Aqua and Tadich Grill you really need to come with your 'A" game to differentiate yourself or offer such a unique experience that folks will come back.  We got neither.  

We shared a few appetizers....salume, bacala fritters, tempura veg and seafood, etc.  I believe the meats are house cured and they we're pretty good, but i really wanted some cheese or fruit to cut through the fat. Don't get me wrong, its was good, but just like melon will make procuitto even better, I was looking for a combo to accentuate the cuts.  Instead it was grissini or baguette slices.  Okay, but cmon....its was a pretty expensive plate of cold cuts.  The bacala was a bit mushy and seemed like it sat in the window too long or the steam just took out all the crispiness.  My wife has the hamachi appetizer topped with qumquat and jalapeno's but the whole this was soaked in olive oil.  Not drizzled but soaked.  

I ordered the RibEye and really didn't have enough of it to comment, but there was some blue cheese butter on top that added some nice saltiness.  The greens that came on the plate were almost entirely cold.  By this point I was uninterested with my meal, so I would sum it up as okay.

SF is a tough place to stand out and unfortunately for my this place didn't.  In comparison to other places priced equally, this place gets left behind.
author: Dude D.

description: One of the few excellent Italian restaurants in town. And I know what I talking about given that I am Italian. Very expensive, but the food delicious, the service excellent and the decor upscale.
author: Luca R.

description:
I ate here about a week ago and can't stop thinking about the house made sardines with egg yolk and salsa verde.  Absolutely delicious, local, and memorable.  I also had some agnolotti filled w/ roasted rabbit and brussels sprouts.  The agnolotti were delicious - the brussels sprouts were very good but not the best I've had.

Try the Antico Manhattan.
author: Thomas T.

description:
Slick, Modern, Hip and Great for people watching - investment bankers, executives and politician types... I was the first of my party to arrive at Perbacco and headed to the bar for a glass of wine.  Seats were not available at the bar, somehow I managed to hang on to the wine in front of the doorway awkwardly until dinner time.  It was amazingly busy for a Tuesday night.  We had reservations for 8:00 pm and weren't seated until 8:30, but redemption was earned by a complementary platter of salumi misto and an explanation from whom I assumed to be the gm of the place.  The salumi misto was terrific ( I would have ordered it anyway).  It instantly made me feel better.

The place was sleet with some exposed brick.  The front of the restaurant was rather narrow.  As you walk through the front door, you would never expect that it opens up to large dining area in the back.  I don't remember if the restaurant had white marble/stone walls, but as you enter the lower level to the restrooms, the walls were in white stone.

The food was decent.  My favorite, as you may have guessed, is the salumi.  My second favorite was the breadsticks with the pesto sauce.  We ordered the hamachi - big mistake - perhaps sushi at an Italian restaurant is not the most brilliant idea - it was on the fishy side.  My pork shoulder was good, but a little on the dry side and Hubby's sirloin  was slathered with blue cheese - which he thought was a pity -- good meat should not be covered with heavy cheese flavoring!

The wine list was predominantly Italy.  It was a great opportunity to try Italian wines in preparation for Hubby and my upcoming trip to Italy.

My recommendation would be to go there for drinks and appetizers (salumi).  Dinner would be okay - just because they try hard and the food is decent and the staff are genuinely nice.
author: Uimuim B.

description:
Went there for a business lunch with 6 other people.  Sleek interior, attentive and fast service.

I judge the service by requesting a slice of lime for my sparkling water.  If they forget, that's bad.  If I have ask twice, that's questionable.  At Perbacco, I got my lime right after I asked.  So points for that!

Most of us had the Organic Peach salad with arugula and almonds.  Nice pairing of juicy Peaches and crunchy almonds.  I decided to have the sole for entree which the waiter chose when I asked what he would recommend between the sole, swordfish and the duck.  It came in a big portion.  The sweet corn from the sole dish was very delicious.  Fish was well done, juicy, not too cooked.  But nothing special for a $20 dish. 

Desserts looked very pretty.  I didn't have any but everyone else seems to like theirs.  I had a cup of organic English Breakfast instead and that was satisfying to me. 

I am surprised that people liked the bread sticks there.  I thought they were very ordinary (I like bread sticks from Hog Island, actually).  

Overall, I enjoyed it as a free lunch.  But if I had to pay for it myself, I would've gone somewhere else.  Although it does seem to be a very popular lunch spot.  When we were leaving around 1:45pm, there were about half a dozen people waiting to be seated.
author: Candice B.

description:
Great place to dress smart and grab lunch at in the Financial District.  

A nice, big menu with appropriately small portions.  4 stars more for the stylishness than anything else.
author: Tim G.

description:
Had a work dinner there last night. We chose this place because of the variety of dishes to choose from. Overall an average experience. Bottom line - everything was "pretty good" but nothing was "spectacular"...below are the items I tried:

Pappardelle / Braised Short Rib Ragu / Red Wine / Parmigiano Reggiano: 
- I actually liked this the most.

Tajarin / Handcut Tagliatelle / 5 hour pork sugo / Porcini Mushrooms: 
- Sounded delicious but was pretty disappointing overall - nothing tasted like it needed 5 hours to cook.

Grilled Dry Age Ribeye Steak: 
- Ordered the steak medium rare - it came out closer to medium. Quality of the steak was good, very tender but it was a little fatty. Taste was good though, maybe a bit too salty from the butter, but not overpoweringly so.

Others in my group had the following dishes which were all rated as "pretty good." 
- Onion Soup
- Scallop and shrimp risotto
- Duck
- Quail
- Pork Chop

We also ordered dessert and it pretty much followed suit as the rest of the meal - good but not great.
author: Joe M.

description:
I love this place! I just want to say thank to the waitress that night for being great and helpful!! 

I was getting a happy hour together for clients and needed a table for 12ppl. The dinner tables were not available - apparently lots of xmas parties that night. BUT I was able to hold the front two tables which they usually don't let you.

The waitress with the awesome hair (sorry sweetie I forgot your name) was so nice to us even though we were rowdy (after a couple too many sippies) and explained the menu to us.

Appetizers:
Castelvetrano Olives
Salumi Misti
Fritto Misto
Medjool Dates Filled with Gorgonzola and Coppa

CHEESES - I love their cheeses! The girl was very knowledgable and explained all the cheeses - especially the bleu pointing the lightest to strongest taste:
Castelmagno Dop
Cave Mixed Milk Cheese
Rutulin Di Capra
Fresh Goat's Milk Cheese 
Testun Al Barolo
Mixed Milk Cheese 
Brescianella All'Aquavite
Cow's Milk Cheese
Parmigiano Reggiano
Cow Milk/Aged

Drinks
PERBACCO! - I love this signature drink! 
Mandarino - This is okay. I had more (3) of the Perbaccos

Desserts:
Olive Oil Panna Cotta
Pear and Almond Tart
Warm Hazelnut Cake
Warm Chocolate Souffle Cake
Gelati Misti

YUM YUM YUM.....Will definitely go again.
author: Alice C.

description:
Great servers. Place is a little on the pricey side but the food is also pretty good. I would say that the food here is pretty equal to the price, but nothing in particular really stood out to me here.

If friends were downtown and asked for a fancy place to get a decent lunch, i would not hesitate in sending them here, but I would probably try to think of something better and fall back on this joint.
author: Jeshua B.

description:
My co-workers and I were treated here by our office for lunch.  It is a very busy restaurant.  We waited at the door for quite some time till we we were seated.  The place was modern and spacious.  Very loud though it was hard to talk.  This is not a place to come for a quiet meal.  

We were seated upstairs in a smaller room where the noise level was more decent.  I ordered the flank steak that was marinated and cooked perfectly with fingerling potatoes.  The portion was modest it could have been a tad bigger but very tasty.  The service was good and very attentive.  They were very quick to refill our glasses of water practically every 5 minutes.  

My co-workers ordered the sunchoke soup, grilled chicken and the gnocchi with mushrooms.  Next time I would order the gnocchi since my boss wiped the plate clean with his bread not leaving a smear of sauce.  

For dessert even though none of us ordered any dessert, the owner was so thoughtful to send over a plate of their "ugly but good" cookies.  We were in heaven it was so light an fluffy I could have ordered a dozen of those cookies to go.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
There were three of us.  The octopus appetizer was the best followed closely by the barata salad w/ anchovies.  The crudo was ho hum.  The pastas were ok but wouldn't order any of them again (garganeli w/ octopus ragu, paparadelle w/ short rib ragu, and the seafood risotto).  The horseradish grated on the paparadelle was a good touch.  The risotto was salvage by my adding lemon and lots of red chili seeds.  The desserts we ordered were excellent (meyer lemon panna cotta w/ huckleberry compote and ginger bread cake w/ brittle and ice cream).  They weren't overly sweet so the flavaors were clean and true.

We are from Los Angeles so we have limited opportunities to eat out when visiting.  I might go again but not order pasta.  We went to Delfina during same weekend and loved everything we ordered there altho the desserts here were a bit better.
author: Helen D.

description:
It kind of breaks my heart to write a bad review for a place that has such good food, and because I myself am in the restaurant industry so I know how much bad reviews hurt,  but I must write in about the service. My husband and I went here for my b-day dinner. We had heard many great things about the place, plus we have a friend of a friend who used to work here, so we were looking forward to a nice b-day dinner. We went on a Tuesday night, 9p.m. reso, and it was bustling when we got there. We were seated in the section in the back with a very low ceiling, with tables very close to one another, but it was a pretty space. Our server came and got our drink order, and asked us if we wanted tap or sparkling water, to which we requested a bottle of sparkling. Five minutes later, somebody tried to drop off glasses of tap water, and we had to tell him that we had asked for sparkling. We got our sparkling water and cocktails a while later. When we ordered our food, we specifically told our server that we were worried that we were ordering a little too much food, but she told us that although we were ordering a lot of food, she thought it wasn't a crazy amount, so we should be able to manage. (We ordered an octopus and beef tongue app, arugula and strawberry salad, spaghetti with pork ragu, rabbit entree for my husband, and fish for me.) Anyways, while we're waiting for our appetizers, the table next to us starts eating (they were seated after us and ordered after us). A long while later, our server came up to our table and asked us if we had gotten any of our food -- not a good sign. We told her no, we hadn't gotten anything yet, and she mumbled something about it being a "long night" for her (which is something I never to say to my customers unless the customer is a super regular). Anyways, some time later we got our apps, which were delicious. After those get bussed, we waited for another long while for the pasta. When the pasta finally arrived, our server also droped off the raviolo dish as a sorry-for-the-wait gesture, which was nice, but it was an odd choice of making amends since we were already worried that we had ordered too much. (I think the more practical thing to do would've been to comp our cocktails or give us a dessert at the end of the meal.) Pastas were delicious, again. However, after the pasta plates got bussed, we waited for a very long time yet again for our entrees.  By this time, the place was starting to look like it was closing up. The customers next to us, who were sat after us, were paying their bill. (On a side note, I saw that when they ordered a bottle of wine, the server brought out a bottle that was already opened, and poured a taste for the gentleman. I thought bottles are supposed to be opened at the table.)
The rest of the meal was a disaster. The food was really good, and we ate it, but since everything took so long to come out, by the time we were done with our entrees, we were the last table in our section. Our server brought out dessert menus, and while I was in the ladies' room, came up and asked my husband if we were having dessert in a slightly impatient tone of voice. We chose not to get dessert even though I was looking forward to a b-day candle dessert. My parents overseas had wanted to pay for the meal, but we decided we couldn't let them pay since it was such an unpleasant experience, so ended up paying for it ourselves. As soon as we signed the credit card slip, the server whisked the checkbook away like she couldn't wait to get her hands on it. There were no more apologies for the insanely long wait. And the worst part of it all is that we left an 18% tip after all that because I work at a restaurant myself, so anything less than 20% is a bad tip from me. Looking back, though, the tip should've honestly reflected our feelings about the service.
author: Y. M.

description:
Tired of Subway or Bistro burger and looking to splurge a little for lunch?  Perbacco is your place.  Good place for business or informal meetings.  The place can get a little packed at times, so I always take a later lunch.  
Salumi is a safe bet to start, pasta dishes are great, try the ravioli or gnocchi.  I've tried the sea bass once for dinner, fresh and tender is all I can say.  
I don't like the noise though, it can get loud in that place, good for groups at night.  Service is a-ok.  Panna Cotta is a can't miss by the way and choco cake goes great with their espressos.  All in all, this place does food right, nothing really negative to say.
author: Jon Z.

description:
Give this place a try!  Great space, great food and friendly wait staff.

I go here for lunch since its a few blocks from my office and I am crazy about it.  Good Northern Italian food, the space has been completely gutted and they have done a great job with the interior.
author: David K.

description:
This place has so much going for it: great food (check out the daily menu on their website!), beautiful space and great location.  The only drawback is the service.

Needs more training of the staff.  All throughout a delicious lunch, my friend and I were forced to notice inconsistency in the service.  The bread person dropped off the butter but didn't give the bread until his next round.  The delivery person didn't know which table the wine in his hand goes to.

Still, do we expect more because of the locale and the price range?

Note, the portion is generous, so try to plan accordingly.  My friend and I were bummed that we didn't make it to dessert...
author: Jennifer H.

description:
A friend took me here for lunch during a work day.  Fortunately he remembered to make a reservation.  Since it was a little early for lunch (11:45), we skipped the appetizer and went straight for the main dishes.

He ordered the steak flank and I had the roasted duck.  The waiter paired our order with wine based on his suggestion.  Since I love Pinot Noir and they do not serve it by the glass, he suggested anther Italian wine that was the perfect compliment to my duck.  

The roasted duck was so tender and juicy.  I am not normally a fan of duck, but the waiter highly recommended.  Well, he was right.  It was fantastic.

I agree with other yelpers' review on their great service, food, and drinks.  It is a perfect place to go to for lunch in the financial district.
author: Gin H.

description:
I went to Perbacco to meet an old friend for dinner a few months ago. Overall, I came out of the dinner with a lot less money in my pocket, and only semi-satisfied with the experience.

First of all, the interior is very sleek. Unfortunately, the tables are really close together. I kind of felt like I was eating dinner with the people next to us.

Secondly, the service is not as impressive as it should be. It was slow, and we didn't feel like our waiter was giving us an honest impression of the food. My dining companion asked if the appetizer salad was big enough to share. The waiter said no, it was very tiny. When it came out, it was massive!

The food overall was pretty good. I had a very delicious pork chop. Unfortunately, that pork chop probably wouldn't be enough to make me go back to Perbacco again.
author: Ava S.

description:
Here's the scoop... the place is too big, serves too many people and I believe it results in food that's just OK.  

Don't get me wrong... it's not bad, it's just not really, really good (e.g. 4 stars).  

I think all the folks that give this place 4 or 5 stars really enjoy the experience of dinning in the middle of the City with all the beautiful, rich and hip people... the food is secondary.

However, if you grade this place strictly on their Italian cuisine you have to give it 3 stars.

Personally, I suggest walking a few blocks to Caffe Macaroni Sciue Scuie (http://www.caffemacaroni.com/sciue.shtml) if want VERY GOOD and reasonable Italian food.
author: Marc H.

description:
I celebrated my 30th birthday here w/my girlfriends and it did not disappoint.  Ambiance was great, service was superb.  I walked to the table and already there was a little card w/my name on it propped up in the center of the table.  It was a birthday card from Perbacco - I thought that was a very nice touch.  :)

the food:
yellowfin tuna w/watermelon, mint and pepper: this dish was so refreshing and delicious.  the sweetness of the watermelon was really accentuated by the sharpness of the mint and pepper.
salumi misti: the platter has everything you could want from salami to lardo to ciccioli (pork pate) - i especially enjoyed the pork pate on bread and the breadsticks.
pappardelle: wide ribbon pasta w/duck ragu - this was extremely flavorful and satisfying w/o being too filling, i would highly recommend it!
gelati: the burnt caramel gelato was to die for!  the sea salt tickles your tongue to bring out the sweetness of the caramel.
author: erika n.

description: I've been going here quite regularly now and have found that they've really stepped up their service and martini. I can't fault this place with anything they do. The last few times I was here for work and I never felt like I was made to wait or that the service was slow. Also, the martinis come in larger glasses.
author: Jim B.

description:
Rather tasteless. The calamari/veal tongue was pretty blend. The broccoli slightly overcooked and too "fatty." Hazelnut meringues would have been better with less sugar. Goat cheese with honey was very good. Black seabass also rather blend.
Maybe I'll try lunch menu, I hear it is better. Breadsticks with pesto mediocre.
My clothes smelled bad afterward.
Service was good.
author: yvette c.

description:
My husband and I just had a terrific lunch at Perbacco. The atmosphere was perfect. "Casual elegance" gets overused, but this place embodies that description.

Excellent service. Water glasses were never empty and my napkin was neatly folded at the table when I got back from the restroom. 

The food was amazing. The bartlett pear salad with marcona almonds was exceptional. The fennel and brussel sprouts sides were super savory and the butternut squash ravioli was heavenly. Very rich though so I'm glad my husband I split that dish!

I would love to go back to Perbacco, and if it were in Portland, it would become a favorite spot.
author: Plumeria P.

description: One of our favorite restaurants in SF, for its excellent upscale Italian food -- everything we've eaten here has been first-rate -- and great service.  It's always crowded, so reservations may be hard to come by for dinner hour, and it gets very noisy (a common problem with many modern restaurant designs), so don't expect to have quiet conversation with your companion(s).  And while it's pricey, I'd still rate it highly on value for money, as all of the food we've had here has been excellent --appetizers, salads, pasta dishes, main courses, and the desserts.
author: Matt M.

description:
HUGE improvement over last time, I'm a fan again.  Sat downstairs and had a very attentive waitstaff.  Food arrived at the proper temperature and the dishes were quite good.  The winner plate of the evening was the porcini in padella--a very interesting dish: porcini shrooms (freshly harvested from Mt. Shasta) and peaches served in a cream sauce with parmigiano reggiano.  Very savory and wonderful.  

The hamachi crudo was very fresh.  I really loved the gratin of salt cod, which was pleasantly salty.  And you cant go wrong with burrata cheese, greens, and roasted onions, served with toasted bread drizzled with olive oil.  Good gnocchi and ravioli, and the honey glazed heirloom carrots were a nice touch as a side-dish.  For dessert we had the fig panna cotta, served with salted marcona almond crisp (wonderfully paired with a moscato d'asti).  My friends liked the almond crips part, but werent as excited by the panna cotta.  I liked the whole thing, though, and wish I had some more right now!  Oh, and the rosmarino cocktail is still as good as I remembered.
author: brewgirl b.

description: The food is really a cut above most Italian restaurants.  Interesting menu, with unusual and beautifully crafted dishes.  A highlight for us is Nahide, the witty, knowledgeable, sommelier, wait-professional.  She can describe every nuance of each dish, knows its heritage, and will pair an amazing wine with it.  She listens very well, and will take what you say into her recommendations.  When you ask for her favorites, she definitely has an opinion, which I value.  I don't like that wishy-washy "everything is good" answer from wait staff.  Really a consummate professional. Goes more than the extra mile.  Just in passing I mentioned something about my friend's birthday.  Magically a lovely happy birthday treat arrived with dessert.  She is perhaps the best I've ever met.
author: kim m.

description:
Mmmmm so yummy!  I had a wonderful experience at Perbacco!  The ambiance was great- super hip, but you don't have to be hip, can be casual or dressy and great for all occasions!

The burrata was phenomenal with heirloom tomatoes.  Just what I would expect for a top of the line Italian Restaurant.  I also got the ricotta gnocchi with  mushrooms and mushroom sauce and it was delicious!  The gnocchi was not heavy like other gnocchi but so fresh!  The mushrooms were also amazing too and the aroma was to die for.  

Also, I had to get dessert-- couldn't pass that up!  I got the chocolate dessert with a bunch of little testers of yummy chocolate.  I loved it all!  The only one complaint was that one of my little desserts was too bitter, and I love bitter chocolate.  Surprising.

Lastly, I really enjoyed the wine I had.  With the help of our waiter, we selected a delicious wine that complemented our meal!

All in all, this is a great experience with great food!  Defiantly check this place out!
author: Cara D.

description:
I had dinner on a slow weekday and left feeling underwhelmed and  cranky.  The food was generally very good - lovely hearty, meaty pasta's and a chocolate tart that I fell deeply in love with.  The space is mellow but feels impersonal.  

The service drags Perbacco down to 2 stars.  I knocked off early and went to wait for some friends.  I sat at the bar (alone).  While at the bar I asked for the wine list, asked to order wine, asked for water, asked for a dinner menu, asked a question on the menu, asked to order food, asked to order another glass of wine.  

Ouch!  That's a lot of asking when the staff to patron ration is 4:1.  When engaged, the staff was friendly and knowlegeable.  But mostly I was ignored (until I got the bill for $75, which come to think of it, I had to ask for).
author: Lena J.

description:
We had a networking dinner event so we had been seated in the private room which by the way it is a little to noisy for been "private". We had a pre fixed menu' which was good value for money. We had a parmiggiano souffle' (delicious) followed by handmade rveal ravioli  very fresh even though the veal was a little bit too mcuh for the delicate  ravioli. Last but not least delicious wine ribs and rich chocolate cake. Superb service. Lovely ambiance, noise can be a problem.

UPDATE
wha is up with this place? if you don't pay attention they'll bring away your half full glass and plate why you are still eating,,,,I hate when there is still food on my plate and they ask me if I am done and 5 minutes later they come by while I am conversating and puff my plate is gone !
author: Biemme B.

description:
update: Jan '08
Went back for dinner and had the same solid quality experience. 
***************************

My best friend and I ducked in here late on Tues night and grabbed the table in the front corner. 

We had a myriad of items off the menu that didn't really go together, but hey, it looked and sounded good to us. We ordered 4 small plates and some wine. 

The hamachi was really good (but i love hamachi, so am biased). 
Buratta - Excellent (could have eaten two servings)
Pear and endive salad (eh, it was ok; first bite good, after that it got a bit bitter... endive)
Honey Glazed carrots (so so so very good. would order this as appetizer)
Gelati -(all 3 flavors excellent, the caramel with the sea salt is amazing) 

I'll be going back to have the tajarin. It was ordered by the table next to us... it smelled incredible. I would have ordered it to go, but I was stuff from the randomness we just devoured.
author: melissa g.

description:
Want to feel like you are on the east coast (brick wall inside), want a great atmosphere, want great service, and want great food? Perbacco is the place!

The ambiance was great, very cozy and upscale. They start off by giving you bread sticks w/ some pesto dip, then come and individually put bread on your bread plate. They were very prompt on filling the water glasses and towards the end of our dinner after I had said I didn't need any more water, the waiter came and filled it and said, "sorry, I hate seeing your glass empty." Now that's good service! Although our server was a little clumsy, he was very charming, attentive & cute too!

The first dish I ordered was a pear and endive salad, which I liked, but was not impressed by...maybe b/c it is such a common combination for a salad. My next course was the butternut squash ravioli, which I LOVED...although had a tiny bit too much oil on it. The dessert was AMAZING. I ordered the warm chocolate cake, which was really rich and was served with awesome hazelnut ice cream...I can still taste it in my mouth, YUM!

I feel like 4 stars isn't enough for Perbacco, but I am hesitant to give it 5. I will most likely be going back sometime in the future!
author: Elaine S.

description:
Went here a while ago for a business lunch and was definitely impressed.  Wonderful selection of classic italian flavors and fresh ingredients.  Sampled many of the great appetizers and settled on the sole as an entree.  Everything was delicious.  Staff was knowledgeable and friendly and the environment was terrific.  Overall, a great experience.

On another note, please have the BURRATA cheese!!  I don't know the words to describe it, but I highly recommend everyone have it.   I don't run across it a lot (maybe its the places I go), but I definitely love it...
author: Gordon M.

description:
There is a reason this place fills up both at lunch and after work.  Amazing food, good service, and top notch wine and cocktails all contribute to the continued success of Perbacco.  And it's a block from my office!   But honestly, I'm always impressed when the quality of food and service remains high no matter how packed the bar area gets.  The interior is sleek and maneuverable, even during peak crowd times.

My recommendations are the Minestrone soup, the Pappardelle, the white beans, and their signature cocktail The Perbacco.  If you're in a wine kind of mood, there are many good picks.  

Less formal than Aqua, less stuffy than Tadich, but more posh than beer and meatballs at Harrington's or Schroeder's around the corner, you can't go wrong with Perbacco.
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
This place is excellent! (I will only give 5 stars for something outstanding)

Pricey but well worth it. Have only been here for lunch but I would go back without hesitation. 

Must try!
author: Nick B.

description: This gets a 4.5 for the food.  I was not crazy about the salumni - too fatty and some off-putting flavors - but scallops with chantarelles, corn and red wine butter sauce were amazing.  My husband had the braised short ribs - very tender and flavorful.  Definitely worth going back.
author: Julie H.

description: We went there last night for about the eighth time and.. did not think it could happen it was even better last night. Truly great food and EXCELLENT service. Highly recommend!
author: Amy M.

description:
So last year we went for the Passover meal. It was delish and considering all the restrictions of a Kosher Passover dinner I was especially impressed. It was funny watching the wait staff serve the food though, they seemed almost apologetic, since it isn't what they usually serve up. 

However he had nothing to be apologetic about! Heading back again this year but I so need to check out dinner when it's their regular Italian food! Will have to update my review once we go back for a meal any other day of the year.

Convenient location, easy to access via public transit. Had a drink at the bar while we waited for our table reservation. Overall will say I like the wine/champagne selection, ambiance and service.
author: Abby W.

description: We really enjoyed Perbacco. The atmosphere was very "classy" and fairly formal. Service was spot on but friendly enough that it didn't seem overly formal. We were fully ready to order quite a bit more than we did but our server suggested we share due to portion size. The charcuterie selection was excellent, much more focused on raw sausages and pates than cured meats, which was a nice change. Our server was right, the portions were large and we were able to share a an appetizer and a main after the large salumi selection. The wine list is fairly large and our server gave us excellent direction on glasses and then a bottle. Our only difficulty with the evening came when it was time to try to get a cab at the end of the night and basically none were to be found in the fairly empty financial district. We had to wait a while, but obviously that has nothing to do with the restaurant. Highly Recommended
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I had amazing service when I dined here with my boyfriend and his father.  We were dressed very very casually and still received excellent service.  The waiter was amazing and we asked him to choose our meals that evening and he presented our meals family style. It was a great way to taste a Little bit of everything.   
To start we had the house cured selection of salamis, the hamachi, and the squid.  Then we had the agnolotti dal plin, gnocchi,  a squash filled ravioli, and tajarin.  And for the main course we had scallops, duck, and short ribs.  Everything was amazing.  Among our favorites were all of the house cured meats, and the tajarin.   I can't quite remember what we had for dessert the evening due to the many glasses of wine.  But I remember it being chocolaty and delicious.  Great wine pairings as well by the way.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
We came here in January without a reservation because the first place we had a reservation for had problems with the utility service, effectively shutting their kitchen down.  

Let me start out by saying the food at Perbacco was very good.  

However, all the other negatives led me to giving this place one star.  

First, this restaurant is LOUD.  We got a table right by the bar, which didn't help.  Could barely carry a conversation here.  Be sure to request a table away from this area if you go.  

Second, we got what was probably the newbie in the service staff.  While he was polite and efficient, he made the biggest mistake any server could make......by dropping utensils into my expensive Abboud dress shirt.  I realize it's an accident, but the restaurant did not do enough to offset the blunder.  Nothing was comped on our bill, even though the manager, Mr. Cirilli, came by, apologized, and handed me his business card and said he'd take care of the dry cleaning bill.

Third, to this day, I've yet to be reimbursed for the dry cleaning.  It's been over five weeks since I sent him the email with the attached receipt.

Three strikes and you're out!  I don't care how good the food is at this place.  I'll neither come back nor recommend this restaurant to anyone
I know because of the bad taste left in my mouth by its poor customer service.
author: S V.

description: I'm not a fan, because it was soooo busy. Everyone seemed hectic, and the food was alright. Maybe this type of place is just not my cup of tea. It was my dad and i who went, and everything was just over rated. The bread was delish, as well as the bread sticks. I wish the serving was a little more personable, less fancy and more real. Probably won't go back to this place.
author: Sasha L.

description: Perbacco is good value because it excels on the quality-price ratio.  The antipasti are creative and tasty.  The pasta is delightful.  Dessert was definitely worth ordering.  What's not to like?  Wine list is comprehensive.  Limited grappa selection but I can't say that I crave grappa.  There are a decent number of Super Tuscans on the list.
author: Koy T.

description:
Had dinner here last night (1/9) and was completely disappointed. I wanted to love this place, but the service was terrible. I had reserved a mezzanine table as it was my boyfriend's birthday, but was told that someone else was seated there by mistake, and we would need to wait for 30 minutes for our table!

Our waitress was nice, but our appetizer took over an hour to get to us, and it was only the salami plate! Overall I was unimpressed by the food and the service. With so many other great restaurants around, I would skip this one.
author: Nina B.

description:
I was so excited to try this place and then so disappointed once I did.  The service was awful and so was the food.  Our server seemed like he should be working at the Olive Garden instead of this upscale restaurant.  After a minor beverage mistake he reminded us 3 times that it would not be charged to our bill.  When a friend stopped by to say hello and sat down to chat he wasn't even offered a drink.  Several times our server rushed off without getting all our requests which forced us to flag down other servers.
The beet salad and the pear salad way too sweet to finish and the pasta was overcooked and completely mediocre.
Bummer
author: Vivienne B.

description:
A friend told me about this restaurant last week and I saw it on the SF Chron Top 100 list for 2007.  I decided to bring a couple of colleagues by.  Everyone enjoyed the food.  Portions were good sized and well presented.  Prices were reasonable for the quality level.  

I thought the atmosphere was uninspiring.  I wouldn't recommend it for a date, but for a business meeting, it worked well.  Service was just "ok", but our waitress was great - aggressive and had distinct opinions when I asked about the food and wine options.
author: Alex F.

description:
veal tartare - veal TARTARE really? 
lardo (slice of cured pig fat on a toasted crostini)? 
poached wagyu beef tongue? 
house made salumi?

yes yes yes, PLEASE yes!!

this place doesn't shy away from its fresh ingredients and the bold local flavors definitely shine through.

this is the kind of place you keep thinking about, days after the meal.

yuuum.
author: Lily L.

description: Very good service, an elegant and quiet setting, and delicious food! I had a spinach raviola stuffed with butternut squash and sprinkled with pomegranate seeds and diced squash, but there were several other unique and tempting vegetarian options that I would also like to try. My husband really liked the pork and pasta dish that he ordered. We highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Peggy E.

description: Had a 1 hour break from work. Ordered the liberty farm duck entree and only spent 40 minutes from the time we got in to the time we left. Didn't have to rush with the eating because the food came out fast. Service: A+
author: Aaron C.

description: The food is very good there is no doubt.   This is a classic Italian restaurant with a great location and interior.  The pasta sampler was an excellent idea but I felt the gnocchi was underdone.  The salami sampler was a great lesson in salami styles and we really appreciated it. The wine selection was extensive and had a huge price range.  On the down side, the server didn't seem enthused about giving us details on the salami platter.   We were placed close to a door or something because it was cold enough for some people in our party to reach for their jackets before we were even to dessert!
author: Miles B.

description:
I'm not usually one for fancy meals (which should be painfully obvious by the fact that I'm calling this place a fancy meal), but I was pleasantly surprised when I came here for lunch.

I'm no food enthusiast.  To me, what goes in just ends up coming back out anyways.  But every so often I'm reminded that the entire process can be made much more pleasant if what goes down is smooth and well prepared.  Since I don't really have much in my palette to which I can compare the meal I had here, I'll just say that it was delicious, and that I left not a smudge on my plate.

What was truly intriguing about this place though was the bathroom downstairs.  I was confused looking for the mens' room until I realized that the individual booths/stalls/toilets sorta negates the need for separate bathrooms...at least I hope that was the correct conclusion.  Anyhow, if you get the chance to go, check it out.  It's nothing that special, nor is this restaurant for that matter, but if you want a good meal and haven't tried Perbacco yet, there's really no reason why you shouldn't go.
author: Philip W.

description:
The waiter was very knowledgeable on the wine list and food choices. The gnocchi was so tender and soft. The beef melted in your mouth - slow roasted for hella long.

Looked for the bathroom - they even escorted you! 

So going back.
author: Mary P.

description:
co-hosted a lively baby shower in one of their private rooms.

with guidance from the lovely dining director, nicole:
we rented the smaller room which seats up to 18 people.  they put up a "gift" table for all of the fun prezzies and even had our theme printed on the menu.

corkage was 20$ a pop for our bubbles for toasting that we brought but they did pair some affordable wines with our entrees.

due to the large size, we had to have a set menu and it's a big task for a foodie to pare it down to only a couple of choices but i did...and here was our selection:

we had the egg raviolo - you cut into the pasta and a lovely soft egg ran out and blended with the sauce.  absolutely fantastic!  everyone was sopping up the sauce with bread.

the pear salad was light and perfect (i sampled it off the guest to my left) but i'm for all carbs, carbs, carbs!

the filet mignon was a giant block of tenderness that just melted in your mouth.  the potato gratin was heavy and creamy.  thank goodness i left the spanx at home and put on a roomy dress.

the fish of the day (perbacco knows how to do their fish) was sea bass - i didn't sample it so i can't attest to it but the ladies who did enjoyed it.

dessert was a warm chocolate cake with whole pieces of hazelnut tucked in.  we also had two cheese plates with a variety smooth and hard cheeses that were enjoyed with our coffees.

so if you have a special event...i've shopped around all the places in sf with an ocd excel spread sheet of room charges, food prices etc...and perbacco won by a mile.
author: Anh V.

description: I heart Perbacco liking because of past memories of yummy lunches. The food isn't super unique but always delicious and something about the place just gets to me, but again on a personal level. =)
author: Jemma L.

description:
Update fall 07:
Came here a few more times recently, and it's even better than before.  Everything was excellent.  They use a lot more farm-fresh ingredients, and it shows in the food.  So fresh, rich and delicious.

===

If you're in the mood for a big, grand, but comfortable Italian meal downtown, come on down.  A few doors down from Aqua...  You definitely pay for the scene and fun people-watching.

great house-made salumi.  great wines by the 1/4 liter.  great service. amazing veal pansotti.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Drinks only - well almost.

Scott served us some port the other night and one of the cheese platters. He is seemingly filled with all sorts of reasons on why he's the best bartender in all of San Francisco.

The olives and the cocktails onions they serve in their cocktails are to die for... Kitchen closes at 10PM. Be warned.
author: Steve K.

description:
The boss taking you out to lunch?  Dining on the company expense account?   Need to impress a client?  Does a friend owe you a favor?  Just trying to milk someone for all they're worth?  This is the place for you!  Perbacco is a great choice for an upscale lunch date in the Financial District.  

My former co-workers were sweet enough to treat me here on my last week of work.  I started off with the Market Salad and my coworkers had the Pear and Arugula.  I don't think they expected the salad to be JUST that....pear and arugula.  I think the waitress has experienced this reaction before, so she promptly brought over lettuce to add to the salad.  Nice of her, but strange....

For the main courses, we ordered the Herb Ricotta Gnocchi (this is NOT the kind of dish I usually order--but it was out of this world), Grilled Chicken Breast Battuta, and the Trofie.  Everything was delicious.  I will also note that we were on a little bit of a time crunch and the food was served in a timely manner (even though the place was jumpin').  

Perbacco is a solid 4 stars.  I plan to come for dinner soon, so look for an updated review.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Perbacco is the perfect restaurant for any occasion. It's sophiscated and classy for a business dinner. It's intimate and not over the top romantic for a date. It's also nice and not pretentious for a dinner out with the girls. And that was just what I needed last night!

For my entree, I had the Tajarin: 5 hour pork sugo tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms. It was delicious! The pasta were so thin and freshly made. (looked like ramen) The pork sugo sauce with porcini mushrooms was amazing! The pork meat was so delicious, you could tell that they were cooking it for a long time. It was savory, but slightly sweet. I had a bite of my friend's pappardelle short ribs and that was very good. I was slightly jealous of her dish. My other friend had the duck risotto and it was very rich and heavenly. There was  a lot of duck meat in it too.

For dessert, we had the chocolate tart and squash crostata. The chocolate tart was pretty good. The crust was very flaky and it was filled with a thin layer of caramel and the chocolate was very smooth and almost pudding like. It came with a large scoop of whipped cream and sprinkles of hazelnuts. My favorite of the desserts was the squash crostata. When I first read the description, I was very intrigued by the use of squash in a dessert. Since I love being adventurous, I decided to give it a try. I'm SO glad I did! It looked like a piece of pie, but the crust was made more flaky and the filling was sweet squash. It also came with a side of pumpkin ice cream. It was such a unique combination of ingredients and I loved it!!

I would definitely recommend checking this place out if you're in the financial district. It's the perfect place to go for dinner after work!
author: Denise L.

description: awesome pasta!! there was a problem with our reservation but they promptly seated us. great service and beautiful restaurant.
author: Scott L.

description:
I love perbacco. We eat here about once a month since I work only 2 blocks from the joint. I can't tell you how much I love the hazelnut cookies and the braised pork shoulder with savoy cabbage. It literally falls off the bone after being braised in milk and cooked for hours...YUMMMMMM....

That being said, the service can be a bit slow, so don't come here if you are in a rush. If you're in the mood to mellow out and take in the lovely decor while savoring your glass of italian wine, you're in the right place.
author: Glory W.

description:
I see a bright future for Perbacco.  I had the pleasure of dining here for the Slow Food Golden Glass dinner last Sunday and it was lovely. 

 We enjoyed two successive Primi courses, first of Louisiana Prawns over several bean varietals with arugula; and the next, a course of rabbit raviolis.  The Prawns were flavorful and tender and paired beautifully with the beans and arugula.  The raviolis were absolutely divine, perfectly cooked and had the most amazing gravy.  Secondi was a Roasted Pork over polenta that melted in your mouth.  It was braised in wine and milk, I assume for hours, because the meat was so tender you could cut it with your fork.  For dessert, we were presented a Meyer Lemon Semi-Freddo which was good but not spectacular.  The chocolate cupcake offering was, however, quite yummy.

All the courses were accompanied with lovely Italian wines and we enjoyed a explanation from the chef and winemakers on their craft, philosophy and approach.  In true Slow Food fashion, our dinner lasted several hours -- they way it should be.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Situated across the street from our office, it's the business lunch of choice for most of my colleagues. Without reservations, it's best to be there right when they open (11:30 on weekdays) to secure any sort of seating. By noon, the place gets pretty packed and busy. 

For someone who prefers a lighter lunch (e.g. salads and sandwiches), the menu offering for Perbacco can be a bit daunting as most of its food is on the heavy side. I opted for the market salad (fresh ingredients with a tasty lemon vinaigrette) and gnocchi (too creamy and rich for my taste) - couldn't finish either one, and was a bit disheartened to turn down dessert because there just wasn't any room left in me (the pear bread pudding sounds so good!). 

Catering to the business crowd, one thing is certain - service is excellent. They are friendly and extremely knowledgeable. Definitely worth checking out.
author: buggy b.

description:
Sometimes the best places are right under your nose. This doesn't mean that much since I am blessed with a large Punjabi one and it doesn't narrow the choices by much. 

Its difficult to say anything bad about Perbacco. Its specially difficult when you didn't pick up the tab.  The food was very good and the service was excellent. The gentleman that was waiting on our table was warm, classy and very helpful (I was tempted to call him sir on many occasions). 

The salumi is made in house and is excellent! This was followed by the local sea bass with golden chanterelle  and potato stew. 

The pasta selection could be more extensive and they don't have beer on tap - it probably isn't the right place to be drinking beer anyway.
author: Abhi S.

description: Food was fabulous and so was the service.  I had the filet of sole and an arugula and strawberry salad at lunch and it was cooked perfectly.  The wait staff was very cordial and attentive.
author: Jay S.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up to 4

Preface: This was my first visit, and it was just two of us so I can't comment on a lot of the dishes, but here goes:

- The menu was really appealing. But the stuff that looked best was in the apps and pastas, so we just made a meal of those.
- I wanted a quiet table but there was a private party upstairs so I couldn't get a table up there : (
- But downstairs wasn't too bad after all
- Service was a tad snooty but our server was very well-informed
- I don't drink, and our server seemed to sort of write us off when it appeared we wouldn't be having cocktails or wine.
- There were inexcusable delays between courses. Dinner took nearly 3 hours and this isn't a 3-hour-dinner kinda place. They blamed the private party, but I'm paying for a table and the excuses don't matter to me. (To their credit, they did offer an additional free dessert to apologize for the slowness, but I'd rather have just gotten out of there 60 min. sooner.

Now the good stuff: the food.

- Beet salad: delicious (although we've all had this elsewhere)
- Smoked goose breast salad. Nice. Really intense shaved goose breast - a lot like proscuitto, like nothing I'd ever tasted before
- Ricotta ravioli with asparagus: exactly what is sounds like, and done to perfection. Tasted like spring in a bowl
- Sunchoke pasta w/ mushrooms: intense, sweet, earthy and unexpected
- Pappardelle with lamb: perfectly done pasta, tender braised meat, a sauce you could cry over
- Agnolotti with bone marrow: they explode in your mouth like shanghai soup dumplings but it's intense rich marrow. Served with braised beef cheeks. Talk about gilding the lily...

Desserts:
- Rhubarb Sorbetto: oddly giant portion, quite tart, texture could have been smoother, I'd have liked more of the strawberry garnish. Cookies were insanely good.
- Panna Cotta with Bergamot: not nearly sweet enough for my taste. A very "sophisticated" dessert, but I've never been into the not-sweet-gotta-put-herbs-in-desserts movement that everyone's doing these days.

Value: Better than I expected for what we ordered, the amount of food, and the level of classiness.

Extra points for not tacking on that B.S. health "tax" on the check but doing what all restaurants should do - just incorporate it in the prices.

Bottom line: If you like really really good pastas and you're looking for some interesting (and presumably authentic) regional Italian dishes, this is a great spot. Also good to impress out-of-towners with some sophisticated city dining.
author: Al M.

description: We had a late dinner here on a Saturday night. Service was excellent, and the food was great. Their wine selection is extensive, and the sauteed Brussel Sprouts we had for appetizer was fabulous. We also had a prosecco.  I had the quail for my main course, which was crisp on the outside and juicy inside, with some sweet cherry tomatoes.  Its the financial district, so a lot of suits (good or bad?).  The wait staff was really nice, and did something special for the birthday girl at our table.  Overall, a wonderful place to go with friends, and enjoy great wines.
author: Morpheus T.

description: So, a $10 cocktail made with Seagram's vodka... Why yes, it was a delicious introduction to rhubarb plus alcohol. And no, I couldn't tell the difference between that and an appropriately priced vodka by taste alone. But if I can get a 1.75-liter handle of the base liquor for less than twice the drink's price, dear bartender, it will be necessary for you to replace the label in order to avoid a snarky two-star review.
author: Peter B.

description: Was here for a dinner party. Had an amazing halibut dinner, with a giant ravioli appetizer (was that soft egg yolk inside?) and a magically refilling glass of red wine. Somehow managed to lose my jacket though... Hmmm...
author: Maximillian M.

description: Great wine list.  Great dishes.  The service was always very good when I went.  I'd give it 5 stars, but there are other places I think are better, but this will not disappoint.
author: Amber S.

description: Yet another one of my favorite lunch spots in the heart of the FiDi.  Tables are very tight in the dining area so conversations are not considered private here.  Bustling scene during lunch and dinner but expect food consistency and top notch service in a trendy atmosphere.  Reservations are mandatory here or you'll be sorry.
author: Carmina B.

description:
Having thoroughly enjoyed my  lunch at Barbacco it was time to move on to the main event . . . dinner at Perbacco.

Everything unrelated to the flavor of the food was pristine at Perbacco.  Service was excellent.  My fiancée and I arrived a bit early for our reservation and the host informed us that we could be seated immediately or we could have a drink at the bar and then go to our table whenever we were ready.  We choose the latter option and enjoyed a glass of wine at the bar.  Sadly, the "by the glass" wine list was a bit lacking not offering as many choices as you would expect from a place like Perbacco.  Once ready to dine, we were promptly seated at our table.  The staff was very accommodating - and there was no delay in getting our table because we choose to have a drink first.

To begin, we shared the roasted octopus (a favorite of mine that I order every time I see it on a menu) and the burrata with asparagus.  (For my lone follower, the octopus was good (cooked well) but not nearly as good as at Bottega.  It was far better than Kokkari's, however.)  Despite its proper preparation, the octopus lacked flavor and was overpowered by the lemon flavor of the grilled scallions (lemon that was already added to the dish in the kitchen).  The burrata was good but overall the dish was nothing special as the asparagus lacked flavor (definitely needed salt).  We ended the appetizer portion of our meal wishing that it had more punch . . . more flavor . . . but perhaps that's just our palate preference.

For an entree, my fiancee and I got the trio of pasta.  Perbacco has a very cool option where for $18 per person, the entire table can try three different pastas (risotto does not count as pasta for this purpose).  We tried: (1) the tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms; (2) the tortelli filled with wild nettles and toped with toasted hazelnuts; and (3) the gnocchi with duck ragu and chanterelles.  Out of the three, the gnocchi was by far the best.  The other two pastas, while cooked beautifully, lacked flavor.  The sauce accompanying the tortelli wasn't flavorful enough to cancel out the earthiness of the nettles (which, if you had nettles before, has a strong weed (think pests in your garden not the medicinal herb)  like flavor).  As for the tagliatelle, it needed some heat . . . some flavor to make it sing . . . however, in lacking that flavor dimension, it was fairly standard pasta with a braised meat sauce.  Good . . . but something numerous other Italian restaurants with far less cache offer up.    

For dessert we got the chocolate gilato with espresso cookies.  It was good but exactly what you would expect it to be.  It is the same chocolate gilato you've had at many other places.  

So, as you can see, I don't have anything scathing to say about Perbacco.  The ambiance, service, and execution of the food was exceptional.  The flavor, however, was lacking and that's what dropped the restaurant down a star for me.  The flavor of the food is what makes a restaurant stand out and Perbacco lacked that essential element.  Thus, for me, Perbaccao has been lowered to the level of just another good Italian restaurant in SF that doesn't do anything different or note-worthy.
author: Oski B.

description:
My husband and I picked this place, last minute for a 10 pm dinner on our 6th wedding anniversary. I just read the book "Heat" (Bill Buford, about Mario Batali and Italian food) so I was craving Italian. Perbacco specializes in Italian food from Piemonte and Liguria...I think it's the same region of Batali's expertise.....cured meats, amazing stuffed pastas, unadulterated seafood (they have a crudo selection), and braised meat sauces.

There's not much to say, really, except that I recommend Perbacco. It was very delicious, well prepared food served without pretension. Easy parking on the week-end is a big plus. Nice room, nice art on the walls. Just plain delish. I also recommend the book "Heat". You will crave this kind of food after reading it, and since going to Babbo is not an option here, try Perbacco.
author: Neile R.

description: I've only been here once, but I like it.  Great italian food in the city.  I was there with a goup of five and we all had appetizer sized pasta and one main course.  Everything was good, my rabbit dish was particularly delicious.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Shen J.

description: Nice lunch spot.  I've had both the Roasted Chicken Breast and the Pappardelle (short rib pasta).  Fritto misto starter was pretty good--olives are winners.  This is a good lunch spot for business lunches.  Service is good.  Can't say it is the best or most authentic Italian restaurant in the city.
author: Platform Universe S.

description: Both the service and food were outstanding, but felt the atmosphere was a bit cold.  The Douglas fir pasta with blueberry sauce was unexpected and delicious.  But my favorite was the goat cheese cake to finish.  However, the restaurant was too large to be inviting and the decor was a bit too business formal for me.  Would be good for a business meeting, but left me disappointed for a romantic date night.
author: Courtney J.

description:
I'm not sure where the skeptical ratings come from - we found Perbacco to be an excellent dining experience on all fronts.  

Our course by course review is below - but to summarize for those in a hurry, an excellent meal in a warm, friendly environment. 

We made a last minute reservation via Open Table and were seated promptly.  Our server hit the perfect balance, setting a warm tone without ever being intrusive or elusive - and his recommendations and wine pairings were spot on.

We decided to go with 3 courses, and started with seasonal fare, the poached asparagus with 63 degree C egg and Reggiano Parmesan crema was a wonderful way to enjoy fresh "grass", and the salad mixing local stawberries, spring onion, argula, ricotta salata and condimento balsamico was nicely balanced.  

We followed with two different pastas (the offer half portions so you can enjoy them as a course or as a meal) - my wife enjoyed the Truffle-Herb Ricotta Gnocchi with roasted wild mushrooms and Parmigiano Reggiano - light pillows of wonderful flavor - and I was blown away by the rich yet light  Herb Angolotti filled with Roasted Rabbit in a truffled sugo d'arrosto - the chef again hit a perfect balance between rich flavor and lightness.

For our main courses, I savored every bite to the Piatto Norcino - featuring 4 distinct and perfectly spiced sausages over a bed of lentils with seasonal greens. A simple plate of peasant food, with flavors a noble would love - a wonderful dish.  My wife found the Coniglio al Civet - with 3 treatments of Devil's Gulch rabbit, a wonderful choice, The belly portion was  "rabbit bacon" and offered  crispy, flavorful goodness, complemented by generous portions of a braised leg over polenta,

For dessert, the seasonal Strawberry Semolina Cake and Goat Cheese Sorbet - yes, goat cheese, and yes it worked bee-you-tee-fully! - was a great finsh to the night.

For each course, I asked our waiter to offer wine pairings, and each Italian wine complemented the course perfectly at ~$10-$14 per glass. Total cost for 2 people, 6 dishes, 4 glasses of wine and dessert - $160.
author: David F.

description: Delicious sea scallops with complex, delicate flavors. 5 hour pork sugo sauce was also amazing. Disappointed in the truffle gnocci (no truffle flavors) and papardelle. A definite banker vibe.
author: Caroline Y.

description: I came here twice for a work lunch in the span of one week and really liked it! I tried the papparedelle with rabbit ragu (really good!) and the tortelli di zucca. Both very absolutely fantastic! For dessert I had a chocolate custard with candied persimmon (again, really good!). I would definitely recommend this place! The service is great, as is the food.
author: Maria G.

description: consistently delicious dinners, cocktails are fresh.  the staff seem to enjoy working together, very good service from every person we encountered.
author: Noel J.

description: Love it.  Ambiance, service, food.  It was very lively on a Monday night.  I had short rib ragu over pasta and it was divine.  I am definitely going back. It is a fun place to go if you are celebrating something special.
author: Anna P.

description: Very over rated! We had scallops which were bland, served over potatoes or sliced apples (I could not tell which) and we also had the rabbit which was under seasoned and served over a watery polenta. The starter salads were roasted pear which was mushy and the octopus salad which was very rubbery. The one redeeming dish was the pan a cotta for dessert which was really surprisingly good considering the rest of the dinner. The hostess did not make eye contact or smile when we arrived and our server was robotic and a bit slow. We will not return and would not suggest  this place to any of our friends. A big thumbs down.
author: Liz W.

description:
Went here the other night on a "spur of the moment" kind of thing with my GF.  I've been there many times on "business" lunches/dinners and have always enjoyed this place.  We showed up, sat at the bar, and just had a great time.  Place was packed as always , but it was a lot of fun.  The bartender (Scott) was awesome - very friendly, attentive, entertaining and clearly a pro at what he does - a really cool guy.  Food was totally up to their usual standards.

Went there a few months ago with my 18 year old daughter and they treated her like a queen - she loved it!!!  Two thumbs up for sure.

Totally recommend this place  - nothing but positive experiences about it.
author: Steve A.

description:
I had the pleasure of swinging by this place on the whim of a good friend and I have to admit I found it a nice change of pace from the "scene" I am so used to in my neighborhood haunts. It had only been open for a week, but I found the staff to be very friendly and attentive and informative about what they were serving. I was unfortunately only there for drinks, but I have to say that the bartender Daniel was great! He served up a concoction of pomegrante and smooth tequila and a reduction of spices that was DIVINE that was experimental,and hope to see it permanently on their bar menu. I did sneak a peek at the food being brought out and it made my heart swell ( I know, I am a food dork) when I saw the fresh proscuitto and salamis hanging and the meat slicer which means to me, they mean serious business when bringing out an antipasti plate. 
I recommend it ! The atmosphere is nice and modern with a bit of a swanky bar feel, without the swagger. I agree with poster about the lighting, perhaps during the dinner hours they can dim the lights a little?
author: Kathy K.

description: Impress your date or impress your clients with this Italian gem:  take them to Perbacco.  Yes it's pricey, but if you don't mind paying good prices for good food, check this place out.  Fresh pasta, bring on that awesome Italian wine list, have their homemade salami (try the appetizer Salumi Misti - mixed cured ham and meats dish).  For those that haven't been to Italy, remember one thing: the pasta is what you want to taste - the sauce should complement the pasta -  Perbacco does this wonderfully.   For dessert, these are top notch:  Apple Crostata (apple tart-like), Gelato (3 different flavors with Sharfenberger bittersweet chocolate, pistachio and hazelnut), and my favorite the Meyer Lemon Semifreddo.  I don't want to write too much and spoil your tastebuds, just go and eat it up!
author: Mary H.

description:
Went there last week for dinner and was pleased, though not overly impressed.  The service was fairly good, though there were a few things that stood out.  First, I appreciate the fact that restaurants will decant wine for guests when appropriate, but for some reason Perbacco decided to buy decanters that are very pretty but extremely hard to use (the ones with the super wide base). The poor table next to us got their wine spilled all over the table and into their food as the waitress tried to get the last wine out of the decanter.  Secondly, when I ask the waitress what her favorite dish is I kind of expect her to know how its cooked.  Ours didn't, she just knew to pick the priciest thing on the menu.  I have been a waiter and I know the game, but if your going to pick the priciest thing as your "favorite"  (I should have said favorite thing to eat, not sell) you should know how to describe it in an appealing way.

As far as the food goes, the first two courses were great (hamachi crudo and blood orange salad first, then truffle gnocchi in mushroom brodo) but the main courses were far short of expectations.  The duck was a huge portion but chewy and the rabbit was very dry.  

If you go, I suggest sticking with the pasta dishes which are quite good and available in app or entree sizes.  And don't let them decant your wine!
author: Pete M.

description: Thanks Yelpers for another great recommendation! The food was so good. We tried the pork pate, grilled peach salad, pork ragu on homemade pasta, beef short rib on papperdelle, and plum and fig tart with fig leaf gelato & plum sorbeto. I can't say enough good things about the food and they do have valet so no worries about parking if you are late like I um sometimes am. Every one of the staff was incredibly professional and helpful.
author: Liz J.

description:
Pros: Yummy food, price, ambiance, customer service
Cons: I don't even know!

Due to all the great reviews, my boyfriend and I decided to eat here for our mini anniversary dinner.  Lucky for us, we were able to make reservations only a few hours before.  Don't get me wrong, it's not that the restaurant was empty that night...in fact, it was completely filled...and the restaurant is also a lot bigger than it looks!  

The interior of the restaurant is a nice mix of old and new.  The exposed brick walls and painted pipes on the ceiling opposite the clean light wood walls and glass and mirror touches all compliment each other well.  From the street, the restaurant looks small and narrow, however, it actually goes back a long way and widens towards the middle of the restaurant.  Suprise, surprise!

Let me tell you, Perbacco definitely knows how to take care of special occasions.  The minute we walked in, we were greeted by the hostess and were wished a happy anniversary--nice!  and immediately walked to our table, which was a "special" corner booth--double nice!  and placed on our table was an anniversary card--nice, again!

I'm not some type of professional food critic...in fact, it's hard for me to even describe the difference between sweet and sour...but I can tell when food tastes good or not...and the food at Perbacco tasted just as good as everything looked!  We started off with the salumi misti which had a nice variety of salami.  And followed with the raviloi--my favorite!!  Cooked inside the ravioli, was spinach and ricotta and egg yolk...ahh soo good!!!!  The egg yolk really made it that much better!  And for our main dish, we had short ribs which had so much flavor and were also very, very tender.  For dessert, we decided to stick to something light--lemon sorbet.  It was a nice change to our meal, but it was a bit too sour.  However, when we mixed it with the lady fingers (I think), it sort of neutralized the sourness.  But, despite the taste, the presentation of sorbet was so cute...the chef had written "Happy anniversary" in chocolate on the platter...nice way to end our meal!  :)

All in all...great experience with good food.  Just a couple spaces down is the sister restaurant, Barbacco...I cant' wait to try it one day!
author: Lisa Marie R.

description:
I have to admit I was a little nervous after seeing some lukewarm Yelp reviews.  But my fiancée and I were quite pleased with Perbacco.  All the courses were good and the pasta was exceptional.  Next time I would probably get a full order of pasta instead of a meat entree.  I found the food prices to be reasonable compared to similar restaurants, but maybe the wine markups make up for it.  

At least when we went (Saturday night), the restaurant seemed to attract a slightly older and dressier crowd, so guys should wear a nice jacket.
author: Greg H.

description:
I like this place.  I always have a hard time deciding between two or three things on the menu, so that's a good sign!  I relied on the server's advice and had the ravioro - so good!  It was light and tasty, and had some fantastic fresh sweet asparagus.  Highly recommended.  The beet salad is tasty too!  

The only annoying thing is the individual tiny bottles of soda.  I guess they're tying to push the wine menu, but not always appropriate for lunch.  Seriously, spring for the machine.
author: Allison M.

description:
Came here for a business lunch about a month ago. We had a noon reservation and were seated immediately upon arrival. The service was great and the atmosphere was good for a casual business lunch. As the place filled up, It was harder to hear each other due to the general chatter of the restaurant patrons but it wasn't too bad. 

We shared the rock shrimp and seasonal beans appetizer. It had great flavor, but really, fried seafood is hard to mess up. I ordered the potato gnocchi. The portion size was perfect for lunch and the gnocchi was not too heavy. The flavor was decent but didn't wow me. 

This is a solid place to have a meal but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Aileen P.

description: I love Italian anything so I'm a little biased, but still - this place has great food and great service. Great spot in the FiDi to do your business lunches. Salumi Misti - so savory. The poached chicken breast - so clean and tasty. The menu has so many options, I must come here again.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Amazing fucking duck cracklings over slippery smooth papardelle in a light, slightly sweet ragu sauce. 

Louder than my folks' place on Thanksgiving, even for SF standards. Other highlights include the interesting salumi selection, delectable pork pate spread over bread and succulent asparagus salad.  

Beautiful, stark digital photos on the walls,  very Roger Deakins-like.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
UPDATE:  I was just surprisingly contacted by Perbacco about my last visit.  I had responded with a little more detail than I had included on this rating.  The outreach is very much appreciated and has proved to me that Perbacco strives to keep the patrons absolutely pleased.  Many thanks U.G.  I'm adding on another star for the exceptional customer service in the effort to make contact with their customers (Wish I could add on more from this pleasant experience).   

Attractive interior decor, Great dishes & not the friendliest staff (one person & if you do think about it everyone has a bad day here and there) but heck sadly it's common around the Financial Dist.  Still doesn't take away from the wonderful selections the menu has to offer for lunch and dinner.  Risotto is delish here.  The menu is nicely thought out, a nice change for this area.  Prices are what is expected but I think worth it.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Perbacco is really one of my top fav's in the city, despite the volume that is almost deafening, (this is not a restaurant you go to talk in), the food and service are just so perfect that I can deal with the harshly modern decor and noise.

The Scene
"Wow" is what perbacco translates to, and "wow" is how you feel when you walk in. The soaring ceilings, marble topped bar and 1912 brick wall give a feeling of awe. The crowd, depending on lunch or dinner, ranges from the business power lunchers to the swanky SF elite that come here to be seen. Personally, I love sitting at the bar, letting Scott (the amazing bar tender) surprise me with wonderful drinks, food and conversation.However, when I come here and want a more private dining experience, I always request the upstairs. It is far more intimate, and the noise is muffled down to a low roar.

The Food
The menu changes daily, and as I do in most trusted restaurants, I let the server suggest everything...although certain staples are always sought after....the duck!
The bread and breadsticks with the pesto dip...just fabulous
Tasting of Salame/Salumi Misit-just order, the fruit compot and pate, YUM!
Octopus in Zimino-cooked to perfection, not chewy at all, (a fear a have with octopus).
Burrata Cheese-I order this anywhere I see it. The peppers give it a unique taste which I enjoyed.
Brandacujun-ligurian salt cod...yes, I know...this is a matter of taste, but I  loved it...not too salty
Roasted Pears-cheese,honey,pear...could life get better?

Truffle her gnocchi-I love truffles and gnocchi, these were to die for. Light, fluffy, creamy and then the truffle flavor....
Liberty Farms Duck Breast-I have an addiction to duck, so needless to say, I always order it. From chestnut polenta to roasted pears, the duck here is always rare, flavorlicious and never fatty

Olive Oil Panna Cotta-delicious, always served with a different seasonal fruit....yummy

****Note***Perbacco is pricey! Well worth every penny, but not friendly to the wallet. For two, with cocktails and wine, be prepared for $200+
author: Bianca L.

description:
I visited Perbacco as a part of a release celebration lunch with 38 other people and had an excellent experience. The interior is very classy with stylish contemporary decorations. The menu was small and fixed, but each item was well combined. 

The appetizers and salad were meant to be shared around the table with a separate individual entree and shared desserts. Each course was fresh and flavorful. I was very impressed with the smoothness of the service and lack of any delays for such a large party.  Very well organized! My sweet-tooth loved the runny chocolate cake. The only downside is the relatively high price.
author: Charles B.

description:
Perbacco is wonderful for so many reasons.

1) The salumi; try each and every one.

2) No corkage fee if you order an additional bottle.

3) HAMACHI CRUDO 

4) Lively atmosphere for work, pleasure, and hunger.
author: Leslie A.

description:
Ah, Perbacco...  What Can I Say?
Perbacco = For Bacchus translated.  Brilliant.
One could say that I Live my Life Perbacco...  Corny, but True.
I've been here three times already and I really like Perbacco a lot.
Once for Happy Hour, another time for a Client Lunch and now Dinner.

I'm gonna break it down for the Dinner...
Went last Friday night for my girlfriend, JZ's Bday Dinner and we were extremely impressed by the Service and the Food.  
When we sat down, there was a bday card from Perbacco as well as a bottle of MV Laurent-Perrier Rose Brut from Champagne, France waiting for us chilled.  Highly Recommend.  (Note: The Champagne was a call ahead present from her boy in NJ)  After we were sat, the Restaurant Manager came to our table to greet her happy birthday and to thank us for choosing Perbacco for her celebration...  Nice.

Perbacco has quite an extensive Wine List.  We enlisted the help of the Sommelier to help us choose a good wine to go with our Dinner and he recommended us a fabulous Chardonnay called Karia by Stag's Leap Cellars.  It was Lovely.  So lovely that we had two bottles of it...

The Food:
We started off with the Tasting of Salame and the Heirloom Tomato Salad prepared with Sea Salt, Olive Oil, Manodori Balsamico and Fresh Basil.  It was a perfect combination and a great start.  Perbacco is known for their Salumi, which they cure themselves and for their Pastas which they also make themselves.
We were a party of 4 lovely ladies and we decided to do the Dinner Family Style.  So we shared 2 Pasta Entrees and 2 Meat Dishes.

For the Pasta, we had the Agnolloti filled with Roasted Veal and Savoy Cabbage.  This was my Favorite, as well as an overall Ladies pick.  Our second Pasta Dish was the Pappardelle in a Braised Short Rib Ragu and we thought that was delicious as well.

For our Mains, we had the King Salmon with Roasted Padrone Peppers, Artichoke Passato & Melted Cherry Tomatoes.  Sounds pretty fancy, huh?  Our other Entree was the Grilled Lamb Sirloin Tagliata with a Summer Bean Salad & MInt Salsa Verde.  Both were good, but I think the Pastas were more of the Star.

For Dessert:
They brought us a Warm Pistachio Cake with a Cherry Compote and Vanilla-Thyme Syrup, which was Divine.  It even had Happy Birthday written on it in Chocolate Sauce.  We also had the Gelati Misti, which was a Trio of the following Flavors - Chocolate/Vanilla & Caramel with Sea Salt and a Vanilla Strawberry Twirl.  All Delish...

Here's the Breakdown:
-Definitely Try - The Salumis & The Pastas.  It's what their known for so don't sleep on 'em.
-Service was Exceptional. 

Additional Info from My Prior Experiences:
-I tried their Burrata, which I thought did not touch the Burrata at A16.
-Had the Salumi Misti which was the Chef's Selection, which I highly recommend.  We do this sort of thing for Sushi, why not Salumi?
-Next time I want to try some of their Crudos.  Sounds like a perfect little plan for Happy Hour, no?

Mangia, People... Mangia!
author: Rose C R.

description:
Wonderful service, ambiance, great food!

In the big sea of exotic fine dinning in SF it's hard to choose a favoriate. So I just don't. But I rate each place on the overall dinning experience.
