I have no funny stories, no this review with not be ROTD award but I just wanted to add to yet the hundreds out there that this place is worth going to.

My experience overall was great. The bar area was nice and happening, the appetizers and entree's where all so good. We tried duck egg on a bed of mushrooms for appetizers, with the squid and rock shirmp, the quail entree, sea bream white fish entree, side of carrots and of course, my standard Champange. Dessert was the chocolate souffle with hazelnut gelato....yumm, yumm.

Everything was fantastic! Will be back. Service was TOP NOTCH! 
Great experience
author: Kristina A.

description:
To be honest, I'd never heard of this place before. I don't kick it much in the Financial District with all the suits. My gf had plans to meet some of her old coworkers there and asked me to join along...I said sure, decided not to wear a t-shirt and Chuck Taylor's since I'd probably stick out like the only designer in a banking establishment, iPhoned directions, and made my way over there. 

I was pleasantly surprised with the no pretense, down to earth wait staff and the excellent service. The food was definitely worthy of 5 stars...we had the Cooked Salumi meat plate to start and I went with the braised short ribs for my entree. They were so tender I probably could've eaten them with a spoon. My gf had the quail which was insanely good. The place was definitely loud, but we sat upstairs at a table overlooking the downstairs area which was much more private and out of the way.

There were so many options on the menu that I'd definitely go back and try, but next time I might try rocking the chucks just to spite 'em.
author: Cliff C.

description:
Amazing meal here, really outstanding, authentic Italian. Great room, good energy without pretense.  Bartender was knowledgable, though a bit of a tool. Service was wonderful.

I had the hamachi to start, kind of Nobu meets River Cafe. Good stuff. After that a simple, hand-cut pasta with a pork ragout, magnificent. Would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Michael T.

description:
#10 on the quest to conquer the 2008 Top 100...

Pretty nice restuarant downtown that's not too classy but formal enough. Love the breadsticks with pestos, a little change up from the typical bread and butter although they serve that too. I decided to be gutsy and order the rabbit. The bunny tasted like chicken, but a little more moist. Very nicely cooked and the mushrooms were great. 

Didn't have that wow factor I experienced in other top notch places in the bay in terms of food, but the service was great. All the waiters speak with an Italian accent. It's either a prerequisite to the job or these guys are great at manipulating thier voices at the job.
author: Ed L.

description: Arguably the best Italiano ristorante in San Fran!  One of the owners (Umberto Gibin) is from Venice, so he knows his stuff.  The rabbit dish, mixed with foie gras, cream, and mushrooms, is TO DIE FOR.  As are their brussel sprouts...tossed in brown sugar, capers, shallots of Parmigiano Reggiano.  Check out my full review here: http://itstodie4.com/perbacco-san-franciscos-best-italian-ristorante/
author: Erin I.

description: My husband and I were vacationing in San Francisco for our anniversary, and we dined at Perbacco to celebrate. Even though we were out-of-towners and first-timers, they treated us like special guests. They had a "Happy Anniversary" card ready for us when we checked in, and they prepared us a delicious dessert specially adorned for the occasion. Plus, the food was outstanding! I highly recommend Perbacco for a special evening out. Looks like it has a lively after work happy hour crowd as well. Enjoy!
author: Cat S.

description: Been here a few times for lunch. The food has always been very good, fresh and surprising at times. Add in a couple bottles of wine and you are having a great day. The most simplistic dish that looks like nothing more than noodles and some ground beef was the most delicious thing I've had there, and I can't recall the name of it! Anyway, it's a good business lunch spot but I haven't been there for dinner or cocktail hour. A busy atmosphere being in the fiancial district and parking pretty much reflects it's location- parking sux!
author: C W.

description: Poor menu choices, not really Italian, since I am. I sent back my entree and they brought it back,saying it was the best the chef could do. I sent it back again and was going to re-order something else, but by that time the rest of the table was finished. I just told them to take if off the bill, since i had two bites. I was a guest, but never again. No apologies.
author: Dennis A.

description:
EDIT: To include my second lunch here.  The place wasn't as crowded, but then again it was 1:45PM and not noon.  

The gnocchi made me cry.  Seriously.  And the butternut squash soup.  Seriously.  

Great Service all around this time, so I added the star I had initially docked.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I wasn't going to turn down free lunch here as one of my collegues wanted to go somewhere close to (right below) my office.

He made reservations but reservations don't really mean much during the Financial District Power Hour.  We waited an additional 10-15 minutes for our table.

The waitstaff was friendly and knowledgable about the menu.  We started with the Frito Misto and it was lovely in all its frito glory, fried but not dripping with oil.  

The Agnolotti was rich and the rabit was tender and the truffles were enough to make me wet my pants.

And it wasn't even my dish.  I ordered the risotto and while I had my doubts on the mint, summer squash and prawn combo, it was perfect and well balanced for a random warm day in San Francisco.  It's amazing to have a pasta dish on a hot day and not feel like a manatee afterwards.

Too much in a time crunch, we skipped dessert although the gelato looked sooooo good.

Only docked one star for the wait and how long it took to get food,  but that's the price for lunching at a hot spot!

I'll definitely be back for dinner AND dessert!
author: Jen I.

description:
3.5 stars.
I kept on forgetting what this place is called: Pergamon? Percusset? Percolate, Persimmon....?  

N'empeche...

The ambience- noisy downstairs and upstairs quieter, but the decor not on par with downstairs or other places in its class.  Frankly, it reminded me a bit of the French Laundry- not terribly inspired.  Still, as my dad always said, you can't eat ambience.  

Most memorable:
-- A red sparking wine! (grace au sommelier).
-- Light-as-clouds gnocchi... how do you take something heavy like potatoes and make them an almost insubstantial- vehicle for getting truffles in your body.  Delish.
-- My dessert: a mocha gelato with salted (yes!) vanilla.  Most tasty- I've been exploring salt on sweet things lately- this is the latest.

Prob. not worth getting again: the ravioli filled with sauteed greens.

Service quite friendly.

Would I come here again?  Mm... there are so many neat restaurants in the city, it might take a while to circle back here.
author: T W.

description:
Mmm...how is this place one of the Chron's Top 100? I don't get it.

I think this place was good; like the description of the three star rating, it was A-OK. The restaurant is gorgeous, the service was excellent but the food was just ok. We started with the albacore tuna crudo...good, tuna was slightly on the tough side but the cherry tomatoes were fantastic. BF had the pork chop, which came highly recommended by our waitress. It was good but not great - slightly tougher than we would have liked, and way too salty for my tastes (had to drink an extra glass of water). I had the tajarin - hand-cut tagliatelle noodles which were to die for, but served with a very so-so pork sauce. I swear it tasted like an expensive version of Hamburger Helper - Beef Stroganoff. Now, I really like Hamburger Helper, but at home, not in a restaurant.

However, the wine was good and like I said earlier, the service was wonderful. It was good but not extremely memorable.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
We made reservations here for a friends birthday. When we called in we specified it was for a birthday and gave the host the name of the birthday girl, we'll say Betty, and we made the reservation under another name. When we arrived we gave the host our reservation name and he asked who Betty was...yeah real smooth. 

We sat down and started going over the menu to decide what we wanted. Another table sat down 5-10 minutes later. The server greeted us then followed by greeting the other table next to us. Several minutes later she walked over to the other table and took their drink order. She passed our table...the table are less than a foot apart. When she dropped off their drinks she took our drink order.

When she dropped off our drinks we ordered our food. The drinks were really good and decently strong. The food came out fairly quickly. We ordered a fried shrimp appetizer and the burrata. The burrata was really good and I would definitely order it again.  The fried shrimp appetizer came with fried green and white beans also. The beans were really good but the shrimp itself was very salty. 

When we ordered our entrees we requested for the server to add mushrooms to one of them. The rest we ordered regular. When the entrees came out she had added mushrooms to one of our side dishes instead of our entree. We split two of the entrees between two of us. They were very generous and split the two entrees for us which was a nice touch. The entrees were really good too. 

As we were finishing our entrees the server came up to the table and very loudly, "whispered" to one of my friends, "Which one is Betty again?" Oh my gosh are you serious this was supposed to be a nice surprise at the end of the dinner, NOT SUBTLE AT ALL!   

They brought out a very nice desert with Happy Birthday Betty written on the plate itself in very nice writing. The desert was pretty good but it was more aesthetically pleasing than tasting. They also gave the birthday girl a nice handwritten card which I thought was a really nice touch.

Overall the food was really good and I like the atmosphere of the place. They kind of ruined the whole birthday ambiance though which was really irritating. I would go back though for a nice occasion non surprise related.
author: Samantha T.

description:
Great food and service. Only thing I would change is adding some sort of wall coverings to dampen the sound. It's hard to have a conversation here during lunch or dinner with sounds bouncing from all directions.

Perbacco is popular for a reason, make sure to get reservations and seating in the back.
author: Steve S.

description:
I want to give more to this new restaurant but it might have to come at a later time.  Had a B-day dinner here with the folks a couple nights ago and overall it was average.   

First of all, if there is a lot of people at the bar, as it was that night, the noise just resonates down into the dining area.   Second of all, if I ask the waitress what would she get if deciding between the quail and the pan roasted chicken, give me some ideas on the two.  Don't just ask me if I like mushrooms and since the chicken has mushrooms go "then get that one" Didn't seem like she wanted to give us her thoughts on the menu even though she was more than happy to give her menu thoughts to the table of 6 sitting beside us.  

Thirdly, don't send out a bus boy to ask us how our meals were.  I thought that was truly bad service.  What, you can't come by our table to ask us waitress?  

Other than the service, which is a major thing with me, the food was all right.  I had the chicken, like I said up there, and it was pretty good.  Although it was a lil rare near the bone, but what's a lil chicken blood gonna do to me right?   Not like I haven't gotten food poisioning before. 

So the gist of the 3 stars comes because of the service.  And that's the reason why I hope to bump up this rating the next time I feel like going to Perbacco.
author: Herb C.

description:
Yummay!

Went here today for lunch- their pasta selection looks soooo good- the pasta with 10 hour pork looked delicious and I also heard the pasta with short ribs was amazing. Of course, I am on a diet (must...fit...into...dress...for...holiday...party...help... can't......breathe!) so I wasn't able to partake in the carb-a-licious feast, but no matter, my dining companion lived it up.

I enjoyed the striped bass (hold the potatoes, THANK YOU) very much and it satisfied this little lassy.

Atmosphere was warm, energetic and definitely on the loud side past 12PM. Service was very friendly... on the way out I noticed a big bar area- looks like a fun spot for happy hour, hmmm?

I'll be back!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Ate dinner with some friends here 2 weeks ago, and while it is still a little rough around the edges, I was impressed.  What used to be the Gold Coast has been given a thoroughly modern (and likely expensive) update... and while it's no Acquerello, Perbacco has taken its place as one of the classier Italian joints in town.  

The menu: a good selection of crudo and cured meats to share, a variety of pastas and risottos (I had the Tajarin with Pork Sugo, which was a perfect hearty winter dish) and several savory meaty mains.  We were too full for dessert, so I can't comment.  As you'd expect, the wine list is heavily Italian; plenty of interesting selections that  are fairly priced.  I'm definitely looking forward to a few more meals here... For those of you who work in the financial district with a decent-sized lunch budget, (or, if you can eat on the company's dime), you owe it o yourselves to give it a shot.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Perbacco is a easy, loud and impressive Italian restaurant in the Financial District.  Nice bar scene and easy for diners eating alone.  The service is very competent but fair warning that the portions are small making it a high $/lbs. meal.

Still, it is a place to be scene and to have truly authentic Italian cuisine.  They have a great wine list as well as a nice selection of cold cuts for appetizers.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Okay I've been here for dinner on two separate occasions.  The verdict:  Good tasting food and creative menu.  I liked my beet salad and short ribs with mashed potatoes and haricots verts.  Attentive waitstaff but kitchen can be very slow on a crowded night.  Stylish if somewhat bland setting.  One of the current places "to see and be seen".  Prices are reasonable for what you get.

A nice place to go with a group of family or friends.
author: J. O.

description:
I work in Silicon Valley, which translates to 2 hour commutes to the city and not having much of a chic life during the work week. It's also exactly why I go to restaurants like Perbacco on weeknights.

After spending twelve hours in front of a computer, I'm in desperate need for some face time and a wee bit of culinary pampering, so I pinged a co-worker and made reservations for Perbacco on Wednesday night.

It was my second time at the restaurant, and I'm still in love with the sleek and classy decor, and the great front of house staff. We were seated on time for our 8:30 PM reservation, and started off with delicious cocktails (a friend had a Manhattan, and myself a Hendrick's and tonic). 

The server walked the perfect line between being polite and being excited about the menu, and we ended up with a bottle of white from Liguria, split a lovely pear and arugula salad, risotto with quail, and herb gnocchi - all of which were delectable. 

However, dessert knocked my little cotton socks off. We split the gelato trio, and let me tell you, the caramel with black sea salt sprinkled on top was better than my last three dates. Honest. 

Moral of the story is that it's an impressive space with great food - don't miss it.
author: Carla C.

description:
Everything was solid, but maybe I was too hyped up by yelp and opentable.  I tried their paparadelle and i thought it was nice, but lacking oomph.  The pear bread pudding was nice, but not super delicious.  Service was nice, but food was not up to par.  

It's so near my company that I think I'll be back to try their other stuff.  Maybe I'll change my mind after trying other dishes.

I must say that the nebiolo was really good.  but i've always loved Italian wine, so guess it doesn't matter.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Veal with Tuna sauce?  Are you kidding me?  Should tuna ever be a sauce?  
Actually, it was quite good:  savory and tangy.   The pastas were delicious and cooked to perfection.  

The bread sticks were so tasty.  I'd go back just for them!
author: Monica L.

description:
Fantastic service, amazing wines: first a powerful Barbaresco and  then another one that was a blend of Sangiovese and something else (shoot, why do I always forget: I should take notes).

Fantastic pasta... amazing caramel and vanilla sea salt gelato, perfect espresso.

I am not sure I like the decor though. 

But god that was good!
author: Lili G.

description:
I had heard differing reports on Perbacco since it opened, but I finally made it down there a little while back for lunch.  I thought everything was awesome.  My squid app was so good and the portion was pretty generous for fresh squid.  I also ordered the paparadelle with duck ragu.  Holy hell, that shit was good.  And there were mounds of duck.  HEAPS of duck.  And it wasn't fatty duck either, just tender morsels.  Jesus.  I almost ate every bite, which is rare for me.  

Fuck, now I am craving duck.  This isn't good.....
author: Katie M.

description:
Finally!!!! I have been dreaming to eat at this place. I've read the reviews and harped on my friends to eat here. Will today was it. It's my birthday today and they took me here for my surprise birthday luncheon. 
Perbacco has gone above and beyond. Their selection of food was wonderful and the service was great. We all had different things from the menu and lord knows I should remember what we ate but my gut is so full that I forgot. Oh wait, I do remember I had the beef short ribs because the meat was so tender that it kept slipping from my fork. But that is all I can remember. I do know that the food was delicious and that we were happy campers. 

So, Perbacco receives a 5 stars from me and I will definitely keep coming back.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Service excellent, meal good, price expensive, ambiance upscale.

From the moment we walked in, the service here superb; from the hostess to our server to who seemed like the manager or owner. We started out with the piastra seared local squid which was just so-so.  It was extremely tender, but it had an awkward smell to it that I really didn't like.  I had the hanger steak as the main dish, and other than it being a little chewy it was excellent. I'm usually picky when it comes to seasoning (especially if it's too salty), but the seasoning was just right and the side of potatoes was delicious. The portion looked very small at first, but it was surprisingly filling for a lunch serving. 

My firm has also held happy hours here where I found the service to be consistently excellent.  They don't actually have a "happy hour", so don't go there expecting discounted drinks though.  The appetizers were a bit too fancy shmancy for me, and I would've rather preferred fries and onion rings.  But if you're into fancy sandwiches and meat and cheese, then give Perbacco a try.
author: Daniel L.

description: Though I am not a big fan of Italian food, I think it a pretty good place to dine.  Very good location on California street, decent service and food.  The Salamu cold plate is my favorite, make sure that you get that as a starter of a good dinner!
author: Karen Z.

description: Had dinner there tonight. So happy we did because it was as perfect as the last three  times we have eaten there. They seated us at the table we like, even though we had put the incorrect table number into the Open Table reservation. Made a dinner salad for me, again, even though (inexplicably) they do not have a dinner salad on the menu. The pasta dishes were so good, we will be back soon! I apologize for not giving more facts on our dishes, but it is late and if I don't write this now it won'd get written. Suffice it to say, you were most certainly not regret dining here. Our waiter was so nice and did such a good job giving us great service. I love this place.
author: Amy M.

description: Great dinner and excellent service.  The scallops and octopus were very fresh and prepared well (not overcooked).  Will definitely go back.
author: J A.

description: We sat in the upstairs dining room, which is more spacious and quiter than the main dining area on the main floor.  Service was attentive.  We had the Heirloom tomato salad and salami misti appetizer, both of which were really good.  My wife had the Short Ribs which and I had the Agnolotti Dal Plin, which is meat filled pasta.  Both dishes were very tasty, but nothing mind blowing.  Solid option if you're looking for an upscale Italian dinner.
author: Chris T.

description:
What an amazing lunch. Some co-workers and I ordered a boatload of small, plates, two pastas, a dessert and a bottle of wine. 

We started off with the salumi misti, vitello tonnato, and the puntarella salad. The main courses were the butternut squash mezzalune with sage butter and castelmagno cheeese, the herb agnolotti filled with roasted rabbit and truffle sugo d'arrosto, and the fingerling potatoes roasted with herbs and ciccioli.  

To top it all off we had the burnt caramel with sea salt gelato and the hazelnut chocolate gelato. 

All were simply fantastico! The wine was perfect too. 

Oh yeah, super great vibe, the staff was really nice and the venue is great.
author: Chris G.

description: The food was top shelf, the wine list was robust, and the service never missed a beat, all this during a pack to the rafters night. We actually were in the upstairs table..... the fois grous appetizer was great, I can't wait to go another round here. Good work Perbacco.
author: Dave R.

description:
I've had two business lunches here and both of them were excellent experiences.  The service is extraordinarily attentive.  I have found the food to be excellent.  Prices are in the strike zone for this kind of place.  Location is great.

The missing star is for the greeting and reception area.  When you arrive they make you wait in a 5' x 5' area in front of the door.  Everyone is clanging around and its very uncomfortable.  However, once you're seated, you're all good.
author: David E.

description:
FIne italian dining in SF.  Cured meats and paste fate a casa (made in house,) warm atmosphere but still with an edge.  Lively, but not loud.

Went with PF 6/09
author: Rich B.

description: I was visiting San Francisco and found this restaurant online. This place is unique, amazing, and has the best Italian food I have ever tasted. The staff is very attentive and they really care about serving the best quality your can expect at a fair price. Don't miss the opportunity to experience an amazing meal that you will not get in Italy.
author: Mark D.

description:
Yes, the downstairs area is really noisy when full, but since we couldn't get a table until 1pm, the noise level dropped rapidly as the noon crowd cleared out.  

The pasta is absolutely the freshest.  I expected chunkier mushrooms or stronger mushroom flavor in the Tarajin pasta dish from the description, but it was tasty nonetheless.

For dessert, the chocolate platter will make a chocoholic swoon.

Service was efficient and attentive...though it was tough to hear our server over the noise when the restaurant was full.

I'd return and try one of their non-pasta dishes...several of which sound great, but I'd definitely do a late lunch again if I could to avoid the din.
author: Lauri H.

description: I wish I would have read the reviews from yelp before we came here. What the other people have said is true. The service from the hostess to the waiter was awful. Worst service we have ever experienced. The food was yummy but nothing we have to ever return for.
author: Daphne D.

description:
Ah, the ever so affluent Financial District houses some of San Francisco's finest restaurants - One Market, Boulevard, Aqua. Would Perbacco hobnob with the aforementioned heavyweights? 

As the host ushered me to a table, she asked if I had ever dined here before. I told her I had not, but mentioned that I had eaten at neighboring Aqua not long ago. This is not like Aqua, she said. Ever so right she was. 

Perbacco exudes a brasserie ethos, interested more in turning tables rather than allowing diners to patiently peregrinate through a meal. 

Before commenting on the food, I ought to describe the interior. A long, narrow path runs from the entrance through to the kitchen with seating areas bordering on both sides. When dinner service starts and men and women strut through the dining room, it looks as if an incondite fashion show is taking place.

First, I ordered the pork liver with gherkins and grain mustard, which just so happened to be my favorite dish tonight, for it reminded me of childhood lunches at home with libamáj spread liberally on sandwiches.

I ordered to small pastas - the herb ricotta gnocchi and herb agnolotti - that were delivered on the same plate. Neither was that memorable. 

For my main, I ordered the sausage assortment. I appreciate that Perbacco makes these sausages in house. I would have appreciated them even more if they tasted good. Seriously, did the kitchen think I hungered for a coprophagy experience? The blood sausage was cloying; the "crispy pancetta," as stated on the menu, was gelatinous. 

I opted to forgo pudding dessert, but the server still brought four bite size chocolates.
author: Andrew F.

description: It started great with the salsa verde dip. The squid salad was excellent.  The handmade pasta was pretty good but the pork was only ok. And to end it with amazing desserts.  It was a good lunch.
author: Mary L.

description:
Visiting for my first time over lunch today.  Place is quite small and the tables are pretty close together.  Food was so-so ... I guess I expected something more and was disappointed when it arrived.  First they leave you with some tasty, cheesy bread sticks (not bad), then they serve you this *warm* focaccia bread that was hard and solid.  The entrees came out soon after.  I had the pappardelle w/ braised shortrib ragu, along with chanterelle mushrooms.  BLAND!  Granted the meat was tender, the entire dish was way too bland for me.  I had to season it with more salt.

As for dessert, I ordered the Dolcetto Sabajon with poached pears.  Again, it was only ok to me.  The sabajon had way too much alcohol in it.  You can barely taste the pear since the alcohol was so strong!

Needless to say, this is my first & last visit.
author: elaine i.

description:
I've been hearing alot of buzz about this place and it's close to work/home so I was excited to try it.

I also understand that the restaurant biz is tough...but guys...don't pull the "I'm sorry sir, but we've run out of the duck" on my inaugural visit.  I guess if the place was French that would have been REALLY bad.  So to end on a positive, at least they didn't run out of raviolli.

Staff was friendly and attentive.  
Decor was classy.  
Food was solid but not spectacular.

Definately needs a few years behind it to iron out some kinks.
author: Dpb T.

description:
I'd rate it as one of the best Italian in the financial district.  The place is packed all the time, and the decor seems a little too white table cloth-ish for an Italian joint...  but the food is real hearty Italian good.    Even the side dish that I had could have been a real enjoyable meal by itself, with capers and spices to bring out the sweet taste of roasted bruseel sprouts, sprinkled with aged cheese.   

My friends Esther and Marcus would definitely approve.    

Reservation is definitely a good idea.   If not, you'd be drinking a lot of Prosecco at the bar and waiting for a loooong time..., or maybe that's why the food tasted so good.
author: Shirley F.

description:
I've been here twice for lunch and once for dinner.

They have a good salumi plate: various types of meats and pate, served with homemade bread sticks. 

Entrees include a chicken breast: pounded thin, served with arugala and mushrooms. I've had this twice and found it a bit salty both times. They also have a delicious short ribs' entree. The meat simply falls off the bone. I highly recommend this dish for an entree.  

Wine list is humongous! However, the server I had at lunch did pick out an amazing Sauvignon Blanc which balanced the saltiness of my  chicken.

I'd go back again to try their other items.
author: Jonny M.

description:
Solid Northern Italian affair in an upscale setting.  Personally I love Italian, and I generally hit the Jackson-Fillmore-esque trattoria.  But it's nice to dine outside the regular Italian box and get fancy.  Nice calming decor.  Can't say for the downstairs but the upstairs is LOUD.  Sound keeps on bouncing off the walls.  They could stand to add some calming music so everyone doesn't feel the need to yell.

But onto more important matters... the food.  Very very nice.  Started with a simple organic peaches, (fantastic) ricotta, arugula, and marcona almonds salad.  Simple.  Great ingredients.  Roasted quail and balsamic figs - delicious.  Dessert - definitely solid as well.  Everything was consistently good.  

Older stuffier crowd though.  Just saying...
author: Adrian L.

description:
I came here on a Friday

Service was fast and courteous
We didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes for a seat

Wish I had more time, but the menu was nice and simple and my Halibut was really good.  Hope to come here another time and hopefully have time for dessert.
author: Omar L.

description:
Perbacco is just around the corner from my office and it's a shame I've only been there once because it is absolutely amazing.  I went for a team lunch and had a 12:30 reservation for a table of 7. We only waited a few minutes before being seated... thumbs up.  The service through out the lunch was very good, as well.

We shared several delicious appetizers, but the one that stays in mind is the salumi misti.  It has the most amazing pate! My pappardelle for entree was excellent.

The lunch prices aren't half bad - and I'm definitely coming back!
author: Han C.

description:
Perbacco is near perfection. The atmosphere is chic, the food is AMAZING (and reasonably priced), and the service is even more amazing! Our waitress was so helpful and full of suggestions, and every person in the restaurant serves with a smile. 

I wanted to order the papardelle, but the waitress talked me into the fettuce, and she didn't steer me in the wrong direction. It was SOOOO good! I also recommend the pear, endive, and gorgonzola salad - yum! Finally, you must try one of the desserts. I was full and saying no, but we decided to share one for the table, and the pistacchio cake was beyond delicious!

Great great restaurant!
author: Jamie C.

description:
When: Sat, Mar 01, 2008
Time: 6:30 pm
Occassion: Top 10 Open Table

What we had: 
- Duck Liver Pate
- Roasted Octopus
- TAJARIN - HANDCUT TAGLIATELLE / 5 HOUR PORK SUGO / PORCINI MUSHROOMS
- Seabass
- Mocha Creme Brulee

The Tajarin seemed to be their signature dish. I saw many people order it. The girl next to me sounded like she really loved it. It was just okay to me. A bit too eggy, and reminded me of instant noodle (feel bad saying this). 

The other dishes were good, though. The seabass was pan-fried; crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. It came with Manilla clams, celery, and potatoes, and sauce that did not overpower the fish.

Our waiter was really nice. Always smiled and attentive. Would go back to try their other pasta dishes which sounded yummy.
author: Aldo H.

description:
Maybe I would have had a better dinner if they hadn't put us in the small and hot room off to the side with low ceilings.  It was a great corner table, but my hubby (who is NEVER hot) and I baked in the corner.  It was so warm and uncomfortable that I was sweating with a short sleeved top on.  Don't let them seat you there!

Cured meat plate was super yum...I couldn't tell you exactly what was on it but there was three pork (coppa and two others), duck proscuitto and a cured lamb cut.

But the pastas were kind of sad:

Tagliatelle with porcini and pork sugo was flavorless and tasted only of the porcini.  It was served with the pasta on the plate and a dollop of sauce.  It was better as leftovers the next day as the flavors had more time to meld.

Agnolotti filled with duck had a dry filling and not enough sauce on the plate to make up for it.  Cute but definitely could have been better.

I must, again, have had higher expectations due to the positive reviews.  The service was good but somewhat mechanical.

Maybe I was in a highly critical mood...I'm sure the heat of the room didn't help.  I just wanted to get out of there.

Maybe I'll try it again and request a better table.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Been here enough time... for business & for pleasure.

The price point for the quality of food is worth it.

It's loud downstairs, but ask to be seated upstairs. it's quieter and the ambiance is a bit different.

Took sis here for her bday with the fam. Perbacco did a really good job! Reserved us a nice round table upstairs and wrote my sister a cute birthday card! What a nice touch! Oustanding service.

LOVE, love, love it!

P.S. the steak is HUGE. Pappardelle is REALLY good. I'm not lying. Get it. I'm serious! Please also don't skip out on dessert. Get the warm hazelnut cake and tell me how you liked it. :)
author: J T.

description:
UPDATE 5/29/08
revisited and the food didn't quite hit the high notes from our previous experience.  the roasted octopus was still top notch, but the other items (crudo scallops, potato gnocchi and john dory) were not as impressive.  first class service and overall enjoyable dining experience.  removed one star for slightly disappointing food.

--------------------------

FANTASTIC Italian!!  definitely one of the best spots in the city.  I'd recommend getting several smaller plates to share, and perhaps one pasta dish.  the pasta dish we ordered, while tasty, was overshadowed by the delightful flavor combinations of the smaller plates.  Lively atmosphere but not too loud.
author: melita s.

description:
Why I love my firm.. Recruiting lunches.  Those lunches where I get to go to super nice places in the financial district and not pay and sit next to people that definitely have more money than I do. :-)

Anyway, picked this place because it's one of the only places I have yet to go to in the Financial District.  We started with quite a few appetizers.  (I had no idea what 1/2 the things meant on the menu by the way, so we picked these with the help of the waiter.)  We started with the Burrata cheese, the Frito Misto,  a strawberry type salad, and I believe the veal.  Things I would recommend: 1- strawberry salad.  Strawberries were extremely fresh and full of flavor.  The  mix of the salad was excellent.  2- Burrata Cheese- we had no idea what this was but it was delish.  It comes with a couple pieces of toasted bread.  The cheese tasted very fresh and of high quality.  Things to not get: 1- The Frito Misto- it basically was tempura.  I'd pass. 2- the raw veal- tasted like beef carpaccio.  Just not my personal preference.

Next they brought this bread.  This foccacia bread was REALLY a treat.  I seriously could live off it.  Definitely high in cals I'm sure but the crust was crispy and it was delish all around.

Then our main entrees came out.  We were told to get the pasta.  I got the pasta with the duck ragu on top.  It was out of this world.  Meat was tender, seasoned VERY well, sauce was put on just right and pasta was very authentic.  Everyone at my table (except the one who ordered the risotto) though their dish was great.

What's a recruiting lunch without dessert?  Unfortunately I wish we had passed.  We ordered the warm hazelnut cake and I believe the chocolate souffle.  We were all very disappointed in the desserts.  None of them were very appetizing.

Also, the over all atmosphere at lunch was pretty loud.  It was hard to socialize.  The ambiance is fine, new trendy restaurant like.

So this place does serve high quality and great pastas.  But because of the disappointment with our appetizers and desserts, I'm bringing the review down a couple stars.  And unfortunately next recruiting lunch, I may be choosing One Market.
author: Rachel S.

description:
IMPECCABLE SERVICE upon entering the door right thru to the end. Special thanks to HOPE our waitress for being really attentive and knowledgeable in the menu. I loved the fact that everyone was friendly and they kept changing out the silverware. Way to go!!!!

Now onto the food -
The Salumi Misti (chef's selection) was excellent but it was a pretty big platter of cured meats so pace yourselves. I especially loved the serving of pork pate in it. It was soooo soo yummy but really rich.
Peperoni Ripieni (Baked Peppers with Salt Cod Mantecato) - mmm i dunno about this one but my fiance loved it. 

TAJARIN - DEFINITELY TASTE THIS! This is sooo tasty, you just cant get enough of it and must be the top fave cos I saw lots of people ordering it.

We were feeling adventurous that night and went for Rabbit. It taste like chicken but really dry...so that was 1 star down for it. But the mushrooms that came along with it was really packed with flavor.

Of cos onto dessert. We had a blueberry mascarppone tart which came with a small dollop of sorbet and this was excellent.

We'll certainly be back cos this place is just so welcoming and personable.
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Dear, Perbacco: 

I love you.  You made my 30th birthday (er ... whatever bday it might have truly been) super special.  Number 1, you seated me and my husband in a private corner, away from the kitchen and bathroom.  Number 2, you wrote me a personal card - how f'ing sweet!.  Number 3, hello, awesome food! The crudo and pastas are to DIE for - so good that I ordered 2 dinners! Number 4, you gave me a super special dessert that said "feliz cumpleanos" - mwah! That's a kiss from me to you - excellent service, amazing food.  Great upscale date place.
author: Veronica Y.

description:
Went here for friday lunch. Service was excellent and food was amazing. Had the gnocchi with asparagus and toasted hazelnuts (beautiful combination!) and espresso semifreddo. I imagine this place could be a bit noisy if more crowded.

Came back and was somewhat disappointed. I had the ravioli with green peas. It was a bit dry and tasteless, and I left hungry.
author: Dennis G.

description:
Great Italian Restaurant, Tasting Pasta Course was awesome.
A must !  if your in San Francisco.
author: Sherman S.

description: Great food and great atmosphere! Not a far walk from where my hotel was (The Westin) and the busy restaurant was able to easily accomodate my party of 2.
author: Angela A.

description: The pasta here was excellent!  We went there on a whim on a Friday night after happy hour elsewhere, and even though it looked busy, we were seated quite promptly.  I'm not a big fan of risotto, but this was good.  I had the 5 hour pork pasta, and it was very flavorful.  However, my friend got the short rib pasta, and I wish I had gotten that instead.  The sauce was perfect and the meat was tender.  I will have to come back again.
author: Foo L.

description: Food was very flavor full. Had the rabbit ragu and really enjoyed it. They also made a perfect dirty martini.
author: Jason C.

description:
I read an article many years ago extolling the virtues of Manhattans served in San Francisco. I decided I had to see for myself. The first place I stopped on my exploration of Manhattans in San Francisco was Pebacco. Pebacco is in the middle of the Financial District, with a rather small facade that belies the size of the restaurant inside. I of course situated myself at the bar and, after introducing myself to the bartender, mentioned that I heard they do a great Manhattan. With pride he replied, "We absolutely do", and he put one together for me. The Manhattan was very good; it was well assembled, but it didn't have quite the level of bite I was looking for. The best way to describe their Manhattan is it's one with training wheels; if you're new to classic cocktails and are just looking for somewhere to start, this would be the Manhattan for you. It was mellow, approachable, but still tasty.

For dinner I decided to start off with the pesce crudo. Frankly, I had no idea what it would be, but the ingredients included hamachi, basil, ginger and a little jalapeño, which all sounded good and I took a chance and went for it. I'm glad I did. The flavors all came together perfectly, and the jalapeños were sliced thin enough that they brought just a little heat to the party but didn't overwhelm the dish. I went with the scallops for my main, which was served with corn and pearl onions. Scallops, like shrimp, are very simple to do well, but also very easy to overcook. I'd say that a good 80% of the time when I order either one in a restaurant it's rubbery and overcooked. These, however, were cooked to perfection. The wine the bartender recommended (a sauvignon blanc) matched nicely. With great food, service and cocktails Perbacco is the perfect place to start off any evening.
author: Christopher H.

description:
Their fresh and unique pastas, along with the house-cured sardines, are to die for. They rival Farina's and Quince's pastas. Thank god they're not close to where I live or I'd be there every week. 

They have this great elderflower lemonade that's superb, and the desserts are just as tasty...a definite must-go!
author: Tami Y.

description:
I'm wavering between four and five stars on this one...this is the time I really wish Yelp would do fractions... 

Perbacco really is exceptional, authentic Piedmontese from the moment you sit down (bread sticks and pesto, rather than bread to start). I went two weeks ago with my girlfriend, and without fail the food was delicious. 

I started with truffle and ricotta gnocchi, mixed with wild mushrooms; the pasta was cooked wonderfully, and the flavors were very well balanced, with a distinct truffle note but not allowing either fungus to overpower the dish. She started with fritto misto rock shrimp, served with a lemon aioli; the shrimp was cooked very well, but to me the real standout here were the other bits in the dish. Green beans and a squash or cucumber were present, but the real surprise and delight was the occasional olive, prepared fritto misto as well. 

Our main courses continued this theme of excellence. Her pesto was some of the best I have ever tasted, striking a perfect balance between the powerful ingredients. I ordered the quail, which was presented steaming hot from its original dish onto my plate. The bird was stuffed with a sausage, which helped to balance with the gamy flesh, with beet greens and "polenta rustica", a coarse-grained polenta, on the side. Each of these was incredible, but the real finishing touch was black truffle grated over the polenta. That this was not advertised as part of the dish impressed me all the more. 

Between our dinners and the free bread and bread sticks, my date and I almost had to skip dessert, but we managed to eat our way through a raspberry sorbetto and strawberry gelato; that each of these tasted as if we were eating the chilled berries helped us in our endeavor. 

Service at Perbacco was also a head above the rest; we arrived early, and were seated prior to our actual reservation. As we are rather young, my girlfriend and I are rather used to being ignored at restaurants; not the case here. Our waiters were attentive and professional throughout the evening, and we never were wanting for service. 

All told, Perbacco was a great experience, and one I would readily repeat.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect given the hype, but I really enjoyed this place. The restaurant itself was comfortable and generally had a nice ambiance that wasn't so noisy we had trouble hearing each other, but felt lively.  We also had a really friendly and knowledgeable waiter.

We tried some of their crudos - the hamachi and the anchovies and enjoyed both a lot. We also tried a sampling of their house cured meats, which we also enjoyed. As an entree, I had a seafood risotto, saffron-flavored, which was tasty but not amazing. I'd definitely go back to try some new dishes in the future!
author: Sophia L.

description: BF and I went here for his birthday and we were not disappointed.  Wonderful food and even more wonderful service.  I made a res with Open Table and mentioned that it was his birthday.  Not only did he get a lovely birthday card when seated, the server (Kamile - awesome btw) insisted on sending us a dessert (we were already too full) and it was a lovely light sorbet... perfect!
author: Laura C.

description:
Perbacco is a polished dining experience. The restaurant is clean and sleek; all of the details appear to have been well thought out. The wine list should be noted for breadth and quality.  

The food isn't memorable sans the enticing caramel gelato with sea salt. There isn't a single tasting plate, appetizer, pasta or main that lingers in my mind as being exceptional from visits in 2007 and 2008. That said, the truffle herb ricotta gnocchi and the seafood risotto are both solid dishes that are prepared well. 

Perbacco is a solid spot for a business meal or for a meal with a large group of people.
author: Adam L.

description: terrific......sophisticated and casual. Amazing flavors. Unique menu every visit. The chef rocks!
author: K A.

description:
Had dinner there last night, didn't expect to be anything different since it says "Italian".. OMG.. it was fantastic. 

for people that like the raw stuff, gotta try the hamachi and uni. the fish is so fresh like it's fresh out of the sea. Especially the uni, really unique dressing. (in Japanese cuisine, you usually eat it with touch of soy sauce) this one is served on a metal spoon, has little bit of syrup on the bottom, top with a tiny sliced of Jalapeo.. the spiciness gives a kick for your palate. totally awesome!

we shared an entree which was also incredible. Pork shoulder.. it comes in a size of a meatloaf, and the meat is so soft that it really just melt in  your mouth.. this is by far the best pork i ever had.

A MUST TRY PLACE!! great food and atmosphere, and even better, the service was fantastic!!
author: Cindy C.

description:
I was very happy to see that Perbacco made it on the Top 100 Restaurants list of 2007! :)

I love how they totally transformed this space which was formally known as the Gold Coast (I never liked the Gold Coast, it was always really dark and crowded inside and having worked in the same building a few floors up, I hated the smell of cigars wafting up into our office at 3pm on the dot everyday - yuck!)

Lunch Menu

APPETIZERS
Brandacujun - salt cod and potato gratin is pretty good.  A little on the salty side but not bad.

Fritto Misto Rock Shrimp - delicious morsels of lightly breaded and fried shrimp and when dipped in the lemon ailoi it's even better.

Roasted Beets - goes really nicely with the white balsamic vinaigrette.

Squid with chili pepper and meyer lemon - I like all 3 of these ingredients but for some reason I didn't like this dish.

PASTAS
Butternut Squash - with crispy sage, brown butter and castelmagno cheese is heavenly.  The filling is so buttery, creamy and the pasta is perfectly tender - yum!

Tajarin - 5 hour pork sugo is pretty good.  It melts in your mouth and has a rustic Italian taste to it.

MAIN COURSES
Petrale Sole -  had a light crust of semolina and was nice and tender.

Pork Shoulder Al Latte - was absolutely delicious!  Al Latte means that the meat is braised in milk - sounds weird but it definitely worked!

DESSERTS
Panna Cotta flavored with Pistachio (they have a seasonal menu so I'm not sure if they still have this particular flavor) - I'm not a big fan of panna cotta in general,  but the waiter said it was his absolute favorite so I gave it a try.  I was VERY happy with it!  Smooth, silky and crunchy bits of pistachio...awesome!

Meyer Lemon Semifreddo - pretty good espcecially if you like REALLY tart desserts.

I can't wait to go back!
author: boots b.

description:
I had a really dynamite meal here last night.  The place was packed at 8:15 on a Tuesday but we were still able to get right in.  Good bar scene but we sat directly.  Opted for a bottle of wine instead of the standard cocktail and glass of wine so no comment of drink quality.

The wine was super good though, the list looked impressive (I'm no sommelier) and our waiter knew what he was talking about.  

I had the ribeye which was huge and great.  Girlfriend got the pasta Tajarin which was as good a plate of pasta as I've ever had.  Really. It was decadent (and only 15 bucks).  

Pistacchio cake for desert.  

We were stoked.  If it wasn't in the financial district I would go back soon.  

Oh, and our waiter was funny in a cheesy hit on your girlfriend sort of Italian way.
author: Eamonn T.

description:
Perbacco is the name that always comes up when Fin District folks talk about after work drinks/meals.  I went there with an open mind and was not disappointed. Their decor is simple yet elegant and unobtrusive. I went right after work and dimmed lights were a very pleasant change from the office lighting. I liked that this place was quiet enough to have a conversation without having to raise our voices.

I love meat of all kinds, so the salami sampler plate was a sheer delight. The meats were fresh and arranged beautifully. One plate was plenty for 2 people. 

The only downside to this experience was wine tasting. Perbacco offers a good selection, but our waiter wasn't very savvy when it came to talking about wine. He basically read the menu to us and was very awkward with answering questions. He was really pleasant, but maybe new to the job. 

Overall the place is a nice find, nothing to be super thrilled about, but a good spot to catch up with friends after work.
author: Sophia G.

description:
My second financial district lunch in as many days, this one on one of our distributors. 

The beef short ribs were delicious and you can bet I mopped up the rest of that sauce with the mashed potatoes. I was surprised when the waiter suggested two of the cheaper wines by the glass, but my Italian white was super crisp and refreshing. I should have written down what it was, but oh well. 

Thanks, work!
author: Cory G.

description:
What a novel idea, solid service AND great food.  The stellar service at Perbacco, prompt seating and beyond helpful attitude of the front desk just made the evening that much more enjoyable.

We happened upon the restaurant since Tadich was overflowing with it's usual over-eager crowd.  We didn't have reservations but they were still accomodating and suggested that we could sit near the front, a more than adequate enough area to dine.  We were seated in 15 minutes, unheard of without reservations at most restaurants.

As for the menu, the food, the ambiance:

The in-house cured salami was amazing.  The waitress knew, extensively, everything about everything on the menu.  I asked if they cured the salami with sodium nitrate and she knew the answer right off the bat.  The heirloom salad was fresh and scrumptious.  The rest of the meal, including the rib, was perfectly cooked.  

The hazelnut cake and ugly cookies will be revisited, most definitely.  The menu beckons you to try everything.

The ambiance was excellent, having a great vibe, bustling with activity rather than frenetic pace.

A new fave in the city.
author: Mary Ann K.

description:
This is not my kind of place. It's  large, loud, and cold. Not the temperature so much, but the general feeling of the place is cold. Our service was extremely attentive in an impersonal way:  a petite woman with a loud voice over-articulating every word and making no attempt to smile at us. We were eating late, and perhaps she was tired, but we're pretty easy (and fun!) as far as customers go. 

Wine was great- they offer a nice variety by the glass. Food was good, though nothing was great.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Decided to go for a nice leisurely meal with the wife before seeing Flight of the Conchords so read my review...if your into it.

On good advice we requested to be seated upstairs, Perbacco is BIG and downstairs is outright LOUD. If you want to hear others at your table sit upstairs, if you having drinks and apps sit downstairs.

We started with the Salumi selection which we both enjoyed esp. the fruit compote with pate'. Great salumi but not enough.

I started with a Gnocchi with wild mushrooms that wasn't on the menu but that our waiter said was fantastic...it was ask for it. My girl had papparadelle with duck ragu, she wouldn't let me have a bite so it had to be good.

We were going to split an entree but once we saw the menu we decided to go all out and get our own. I had the John Dory which was absolutely perfect, crispy and just tasty. As noted here previously though it had a bit much butter.....it didn't need it.

#1 wifey had the short rib over polenta. Again I didn't get a bite I think she growled at me when my fork strayed to her plate. She thought the polenta was undercooked as it had a bit of tooth to it.

Service was fantastic, really surprising for a place of this size. Attentive without being intrusive.

Pistachio Gelato and Carmel something or other were really good desserts. They also have excellent dark roast very Italian style coffee.

The only real disappointment was the wine. I asked the sommelier to recommend a lighter italian red. I know CA andf FRA wine pretty darn well but just have never gotten a full grasp on Italian reds so I trusted her. Big disappointment we ended up with a very Tannic 'y bottle that didnt match our description of what we liked.

Perbacco is a fun place with darn good food, it is loud, it is expensive, its downtown. If you want an intimate neighborhood experience go elsewhere.

Ciao!
author: John D.

description:
Business-casual restaurant that is too noisy for a romantic dinner, but the setting is nice for small groups.  If you want a quieter table, try the upstairs dining area.  They are not pretentious nor over-hyped.  Overall, Perbacco delivers nicely in every category:
1) Relaxed ambiance with soft-lighting and high ceilings.
2) Good food all around.  The highlights for us were: the house-cured meat appetizer plate (ask the servers for wine pairing recommendations) which was fantastic and the agnolotti with rabbit and truffle was rich and not gamey.   The rib-eye with gorgonzola butter was tender and flavorful.
3) The service was very friendly and attentive.  There was someone who was probably the manager floating around and was quite knowledgeable about their wine list.  She was not a sommelier but made great recommendations for pairing each part of our meal.

I look forward to our next dining experience here.
author: Rick T.

description:
The food here was amazing. Hands down some of the best I've come across in the financial district. I'd highly recommend the Pappardelle and Peach and Arugula salad!

My only complaint would be the service - when we arrived the hostess didn't seem to know what was going on or where to seat folks and our server was non existent for most of the night (we had to ask the manager for someone to take or order).
author: Summer C.

description: I can't remember what we had here, perhaps because of the rounds of solid cocktails we had at the bar.  But I do remember the 5 hour pork sugo and tagliatelle.  Mmmmm!  It's possibly the richest, most delicious pasta I've ever eaten.  The meat was so incredibly tender - little bits of pork coated in rendered, savory fat - and the noodles were cooked perfectly al dente, rich, eggy, and so yummy.  We also had a thinly sliced fish dressed simply in olive oil and lemon.  Fantastic - will definitely be back.
author: Pearl L.

description:
My son raved about this restaurant for a while and thought I'd give it a shot. Perhaps he might have over-hyped it and I was not as impressed.
Food was good but so are quite a few restaurants in SF.Had reservation but still made us wait 30 minutes. Perhaps they were busy on a Friday
and the service was slow. Just an ok experience.
author: Serene C.

description: A lot of good reviews about this place....I wasnt impressed.  Came here for dinner after work.  The service was on the slower side (it was crowded) but not horrible.  The food was a little too rich for me.  Maybe I ordered the wrong item off the menu.  The wait/price/ overall taste wasnt worth it to me.  My girlfriend enjoyed her dinner and the place is actually pretty nice.  I would try them again but not in a hurry to do so.
author: Huy T.

description: This is my favorite San Francisco restaurant.  Superb Northern Italian cuisine with excellent service and stunning atmosphere.  The last time I was there for lunch.  Risotto with pancetta and mushrooms was perfect.  I started with a shaved fennel & citrus salad with olives, and it was a perfect mix of flavors, with tart & salty flurishes. My partner had veal & pork meatballs on a bed of pureed potatoes and it not only tasted great, but it was presented beautifully.  Dinner is terrific.. it works for a romantic date, a festive celebration with friends or family, or as a business meal.  Great wine list too.  Five stars all around!
author: Scott G.

description: The restaurant has a good city feel to it; it's lively and the setting is contemporary, yet warm inside because of the brick wall on one side.  The menu is printed daily because it changes depending on the seasonal foods available, which is partly why the foods taste excellent; the presentation of the food is like it had an artist's touch. Don't expect traditional Italian, as it has a giant Californian influence. My pasta dish, like all their pastas was homemade and scrumptious, and the portion just right. My husband was more than satisfied with his crusted short rib meal. The wait staff is very attentive and professional-hardly skipping a beat and perfect timing between courses. The only tiny mishap was our knives were removed before the meal, so when it arrived we didn't have them, but staff has a keen eye out, so it's easy to get someone's attention. If you are in San Francisco, I recommend you going here for a delicious dinner.
author: Karen L.

description:
OHMYGOD 
can i say amazing??? I really love these guys- the food is amazing- the staff is really really lovely- they are welcoming, friendly and have such good food

ok- today I had SHORTRIBS with a root veggie mash onions and green beans (haricot vert?) at any rate- yummy - we began with a plate of salumi and finished with a cheese course- all along drinking copious amounts of brunello 

FABOOOO 
I understand they are opening a small plates bar/trattoria next door called BARBACCO
Yippee
Jr
author: Joel R.

description: Good service.  Over priced, mediocre food.  All three of us had to send our almost raw fish back to be cooked.
author: Nicole L.

description: I didn't love it as much as Barbacco next door, but was still great. Look forward to next time.
author: Joshua S.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco.  Don't look here for spaghetti and meatballs, this is Northern Italian (Piemonte predominantly) with a French twist.  The braised short ribs are to die for! Salumi and cheeses are great, too, along with a lot of great seafood choices and great sides (try the brown butter brussels sprouts!)  Restaurant is beautiful but not huge and bar is small, so make reservations.
author: Andrea D.

description: Went here for lunch on New Year's Eve expecting it to be crowded for a Friday.  I'm told it's usually a reservation-only place for lunch.  We were one of four couples in the entire place, but that changed about 20 minutes later.  The place was jumping!  We sat in the alcove-like area on the first floor just to the right past the bar.  Not much to say about the decor there.  But, the bar area was awesome.  I had high expectations for the food and wasn't disappointed.  Great flavor.  I added a side of Brussels sprouts - which I don't ususally like - and loved it!  The highlight:  Awesome service!  For me, poor service can ruin the entire experience no matter how good the food is, and since this was my first time there after coming highly recommended, I am definitely a fan and can't wait to go back for another meal! Cheers!
author: Larry N.

description:
Perbacco is your typical SF fine-dining establishment - where the powers that be know what foodies their patrons are. Service is brisk and warm and the interior is comforting. Our waiter was knowledgeable and friendly, even though we brought our own bottle of wine (cutting into our bill, his tip). My girlfriend and I ended up just splitting a bunch of things: a plate of charcuterie and dried salame, followed by a beet salad. We split our entree which was potato gnocchi in a red sauce. Our portion was very small - small enough that if combined (equaling a full entree) I would have been dismayed. But in the end it worked out because we mentioned this to the waiter and when we orderede dessert, the kitchen way over-compensated and gave us a whole menageries of gelato flavors, when we just ordered one.

Overall, a good pick. The bar has great mixed drinks and of course the wine list is very extensive.
author: Cody C.

description:
Had a great experience here last night. For a new restaurant, service was remarkably smooth, and the food was terrific.

We especially loved:
- Grilled shrimp and calamari salad with corona beans, arugula, and roasted tomatoes. 
- Tajarin with pork sugo
- Pappardelle with short rib ragu and mushrooms
- Brussels sprouts (another fine example of how butter can transform anything)

The only snag in service was a long delay between two courses, but our waiter came by to check on us twice, and on the second visit generously refilled our wine glasses to compensate us for the wait. 

We left well-fed and determined to return.
author: joanna p.

description:
The only thing that needed some work here was the service.  Our waiter seemed, I don't know how else to explain it, a bit awkward and not at all comfortable being our waiter.  It was kind of odd. 

However, the food was incredible!  Everything on the menu sounded great, so my friend and I decided to split everything we ordered.  The busser was good about bringing us extra plates for sharing. 

We had the ahi starter, gnocchi, the pork shoulder and the beef short ribs.  The short ribs were by far the best thing we had.  We asked to take the leftovers home, but they never brought us our boxed up leftovers.  Bummer.

Flourless chocolate cake was, eh, OK.  The trio of gelatos was fantastic!
author: Jackie D.

description:
Huge menu.  Solid wine list.  Great salumi and cheese selection.  The burrata with truffled salsa was excellent.  Pastas were good (not amazing).  The main courses were incredible.  The duck was beyond words good.

Pull their dinner menu here: http://www.perbaccosf.com/menus/store/dinner.pdf
author: Scott W.

description:
This is solely a lunch rating - I liked it.  Of course, dinner would include more range - one is more likely to eat dessert, wine and spend more $.  My Sister mentioned that dinner was good too.

Came here by accident.  It's an Italian place right next door to that good old institution Tadich.  Intended on going to Tadich but too crowded and I missed out on my calamari steak =)

Sum up the place in two words:  Modern and Clean

Modern and clean inside.  No way to tell it's an Italian restaurant.  Could be a club, fancy bar or museum.  Good acoustics and tables are not too close together.  Probably a good place for a date or business meal.  

We had the halibut, grilled chicken and short rib - all were very tasty and well-prepared.  Service was friendly and fast.  Would like to go back fof dinner.
author: Jimmy F.

description:
My boss and I went to Perbacco for lunch yesterday.  We'd both been looking forward to it, and it lived up to our expectations.

They started us out with both breadsticks, coupled with a nice, fresh pesto, AND bread and butter.  We shared all of the dishes.  We started off with the pear/arugula/gorgonzola/hazelnut salad (smallish, but really good) and the papardelle with short rib ragu.  The papardelle dish was so good we were fighting over the serving plate to lick it.  It struck the perfect balance between being really satisfying comfort food and not being too heavy.  Flavors were blended perfectly and textures were great.  The fresh pasta was superb.

Our entrees were braised pork shoulder over savoy cabbage for her, and grilled chicken for me.  The pork, as with the beef in the appetizer, was fall-apart yummy, but not too heavy.  I would give a lot to have that dish again on a cold, rainy day.  It came with polenta, the perfect accompaniment.  My grilled chicken breast was the best I've ever had.  My boss agreed.  It was fresh and moist, grilled perfectly, with a lovely sauce.

Finally, dessert--the reason we wanted to try this restaurant:  a trio of gelati, all of which were quite good, but the highlight was the caramel gelato with chunks of sea salt blended in.  The combination of textures and sweet/salty flavors was practically orgasmic.

The service was pleasant and efficient.  Although it was crowded, it was not so loud that we could not converse.  I can't think of a thing about this place I would change.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Earline A.

description:
TASTY TASTY! 

More of a "special event" type of place for my bohemian lifestyle, but a fun splurge.  It was packed and I think reservations are a must.  Upon walking in, it had a frenetic new york style feel to it, but once I sat down at the table with my wine I felt pretty calm.  A bit noisy, I think the sound is just bouncing off the walls and cement floors.  But the food is high quality.  Delectable appetizers and amazing pasta dishes.  Our true joy came when we ordered every dessert on the menu.  And every single one was a treat.  There were no complaints to be heard at our table!
author: Charley C.

description:
Amazing new restaurant.  Ambiance & service is top notch.  The place was packed. 

I honestly didn't care for the fried shrimp appetizer or my dinner which was a Butternut squash pasta plate (I'm pescatarian, but I had enough seafood in SF for a couple of days), but my associates certainly enjoyed their other options of beef.  I do have to comment their dessert was to die for.  Incredible food.  I really enjoyed it.  I certainly would love to come back and try their other entrees. 

Perbacco can certainly stand up on its own against the heavyweights around the financial district area.
author: Rishi D.

description:
I recently went here for the first time to meet a friend.

The atmosphere and vibe are nice and cool and having a booth (which we did) is certainly preferable to not.  The wine selection was decent and the staff courteous and helpful without being overbearing or hovering too much.  I'd definitely come back again!
author: Rich N.

description: Last weekend i visited this restaurant. I have to say the reviews are dead on right.  Walked in without any reservations the service was perfect and the management made sure that we were comfortable with our setting due to a weeding party that was going on. The food is very good and they serve you the right proportions. well i have to say it has my 5 stars keep up the good work.  cheers
author: SAMAY A.

description: This is a late review, so I don't remember everything we ate. However, three of us ate dinner here - took a buddy for his birthday. We are not shy, ordered 4 apps, each an entree and dessert as well - cocktails and wine too. I like the atmosphere, brick, wood, metal - the insides of an old building. Noisy but fun - and if you're in a group like ours, the outside world won't matter. Upstairs or downstairs you can't go wrong (unless you really want to be in the middle of things, which would be downstairs). Food was incredible from beginning to end - and service was just as good. This was truly one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco in a long time.
author: R F.

description: Enjoyed it quite a bit. Excellent daily soup with spinach and butternut squash. Tender pork loin. Good beet salad. More upscale twin to next door Barbacco which is also a big favorite.
author: Josh B.

description: Authentic Italian, some interesting flavours, good service, I did not pay so I do not know how much the damage was but I do not think I can afford to eat here every day.
author: luca d.

description:
What a gorgeous place to celebrate a special event and/or just go for a lovely dinner. I love Perbacco, it has been one of my dearest places to dine since they open years ago and continues to be up to this day, not only the food is prepared with the freshest ingredients but you should see the food presentation and wait until you taste. It is so good. On this particular evening my dinning companion and I shared the Crudo (hamachi) grapefruit/serrano chili/radish/and peppercress it was outstanding full of flavors. Then we tried the Piastra which is a roasted octopus/fingerling potatoes/castelvetrano olives and fennel salsa verde d e l i c i o u s!! Now, you are there for the pastas (all hand made) loved the pappardelle -wide pasta ribbons/slow cooked short rib ragu/roasted cipolline and horseradish. This is just a sample I can assure you that you will enjoy every item on the menu. The ambiance at Perbacco is very lovely and always superb service. If you go ask for the corner tables on the main dinning room.
 
Make sure you leave room for dessert!!
author: Ernesto C.

description:
this is now one of my favorite resturants.  

the beef ragu pasta dish was really good. we shared it as an appetizer, but i wish i had eaten it all by myself.  

i had the lamb.  it was darn good.  kokkari is stll my favorite for lamb but theres was also bone licking good. or maybe it was because it was so small... my girlfriend has the bird with foie gras.  which i didnt love but it was still good. my dad had pork chops.  im finding that i dont like pork so much @ 30/pop.  they all kinda taste alike.. well unless its deep fried or circumferences another kind of meat or cheese.  

im gonna head pretty soon to splurge on some pricy pasta because i believe from the small sample tasting we shared, it will be effen awesome.  

i dont do dessert.
author: Doug ..

description:
Very good food and exceptional service. We had the three-taste of pastas: papardelle with rabbit ragu, potato gnocchi with hazelnuts, and tagliatelle with pork and porcinis. The pasta was the freshest I've ever had, and the gnocchi were the soft pillowy goodness that they should be.

We had the duck breast and pork shoulder as mains. The pork shoulder was good, but not particularly memorable. The duck breast was good, and cooked perfectly, although it had a spice in the rub that my companion did not care for.

Cheese courses and the best hazelnut cookies we've ever had (sort of a soft meringue).

Highly recommended.
author: Steve F.

description: I still love this place. Just went there for a Christmas Dinner and the food and service is outstanding. I was a bit adventurous and tried their black pudding with sausage and even though it was nowhere close to the ones I had in Scotland last year - kudos for putting something like that on the menu and thumps up for continuing to be a great spot!
author: Conny F.

description:
I went there for a belated Valentine's day meal and quite liked the place. 

I made the mistake of ordering too much and all beef. Not what I normally do (I'm a fish lover), but it's what made sense at the time. The veal tartare with truffle and lardo toast was delicate and flavorful. I was amazed by the generous portion. The agnolotti dal plin were probably the highlight of my meal, perfectly executed and just as generous as the starter. 

My main course were shortribs topped with a bone marrow crust over a carrot puree. It was delicious and huge, but not the most delicate composition. The richness of the bone marrow kind of got lost in the sauce. 

The desserts are a rip off. A $7 sorbet came frozen to -10 C -- ever heard of tempering your ice cream, pastry chef? -- accompanied by two old slices of pear and an insipid, stale ginger shortbread.

My partner had worse luck with his first courses, but his entree of foie gras-stuffed quail was superb.  

The location is beautiful, understated and urban, not ultra fancy. The service was impeccable. 

I'd eat there again, but stick to two courses.
author: Halle L.

description:
I used to eat in this space a couple years ago when it was the Gold Coast cafe. Believe me, it was funkier and more "old San Francisco" then. They have done a real make-over for Perbacco -- very nice looking inside and you will not recognize it if your last memory is of Gold Coast! The food is Italian as you might be able to tell from the name and it is Italian like you haven't experienced before. I had a filet of skate with a glass of Pinot Grigio. Very well-prepared and delicious dishes. The crowd is typical daily downtown --  corporate grazers. Not the cheapest lunch you can have but it isn't as expensive as two doors down :)

Service is smart and relatively timely. 

I'll be back
author: Mark K.

description:
I am updating my review of Perbacco. 

After my initial review, where I gave the restaurant 2 stars, I received a letter of apology from them which came a a pleasant surprise. I have never had such a thing happen to me and as a result my boyfriend and I decided to give them another try.

Our second visit to Perbacco was a totally different and far better experience.

When we got there we were seated within a couple of minutes at a nice table on the ground floor.  The area we were in was fairly quiet and my boyfriend and I could have a pleasant conversation.  We had a great server, who spent time explaining several of the items on the menu and make very good wine pairing suggestions for the dishes we ordered.

The food:
I"ll start with my dishes.
House made salumi: Delicious.  Very fresh and for the first time I had  blood salami and it was really good.

Grilled Octopus with potatos and haricort vertes:  This was an amazing appetizer.  The octopus was so tender, it didn't even really seem like I was eating octopus. 

Tagliatelle with Pork Sugo and Porcini Mushrooms:  Again another winner.  Very savory and rich in flavor, the pasta and the pork/mushrom sauce were a great pairing.

I also asked my boyfriend to tell me how his dishes were and here are his comments.
Hamachi:  Excellent!   Unusual combination of flavors including mint lime and honeydew melon with the hamachi, which combined to create a dish that melted in the mouth.

Seared Sea Bass:  This was a delicious dish as well.  The fish was excellently seasoned and was a good portion size in that it wasn't too small.

Overall, our second visit to Perbacco was completely different  in terms of food, service and ambiance.  I feel that this was a truer experience of Perbacco and that it does live up to its reputation.  I had a great time and will be back.
author: Brett H.

description:
I had the pleasure of being "treated" to Perbacco today for lunch. I've been looking for an excuse to try the place and someone finally offered to introduce me to the fantastic lunch menu. The meal was satisfying, the portions generous and the service prompt and pleasant.

We sat in the main dining room and, contrary to other reviewers, my companion and I were perfectly able to carry on a conversation without shouting to be heard. Service was attentive without being bothersome and we were given all the time we needed to make our decisions. 

Food: very good, 4 stars. 

Here's the breakdown ...

Salads:

I enjoyed the beet salad, my companion loved her tomato salad (end of season, probably the last chance to indulge). We tasted from one another's plates and agreed both salads hit the mark - well balanced flavors, appropriate portion sizes, great textures. 

Pastas:

I had to try the pappardelle given the number of people I've spoken to who raved about it. I thought it was very good, but I kept thinking it needed something ... like salt. The flavors were complex, but they didn't blow me away and I just couldn't get enough of the taste of the sauce. However, the pasta itself was exceptional. I could have eaten it with just a little olive oil and salt and pepper and been just as happy. Still, not a bad dish and I recommend it to my pappardelle loving friends.

My companion enjoyed the agnolotti filled with veal and cabbage with a bit of the short rib ragu drizzled over the top. It looked great, but I didn't try it. I will next time!

Cheese:

We finished our lunch by sharing a 3-choice cheese plate. I ordered the gorgonzola dolce, the goat and the Brescianella All'Aquavite (a cow's milk cheese coated in rye husks and soaked in grappa). The portions were unbelievably generous. I'm accustomed to cheese slivers when I order a cheese course out. It was almost too much cheese (saying a lot for an addict like me). It came with a plate of sliced walnut bread, roasted almonds, honey and re-hydrated golden raisins. Perfection!

I'll go back for lunch, but I'd also like to try the dinner menu with a little wine.
author: Steve J.

description:
Any place you can have a two and half our lunch starting with cocktails to wine to dessert cocktails, and have amazing food at each turn is ok by my.  The house made salumi plate was delightfull as was the grilled calamari.  seems to be a theme through out my dinning lately, grilled calamari once a week.  weird.   also had a delicous beet salad as a starter that was fantastic.

the gnochi we had as a mid cousre was light and fluffy and scented with black truffles, hell yeah is all i have to say about that.  and fllowing that was a nicly prepared sole. 

desserts get a big holla as well.  chocolate moose cake or something fantastic along those lines,  we were two bottles deep by this time, and a hazel nut cake kicked my ass.
author: brian m.

description:
Visited on 10/26/07
    Great food, from the bread sticks to the icy cold gelato. Everything on the salumi platter was housemade, excepting the prosciutto. An excellent fritto misto that included calamari, shrimp, green beans and olives. All of our pasta dishes were cooked perfectly al dente, with exquisite sauces. Wines are available by the glass, bottle or half liter. Definitely going back!
author: Chili Bill E.

description:
I think Perbacco is another one of those solid places with the exhorbitant pricing of some of itsneighboring restaurants.  Incredible decor and their antipasto meat dishes are spectacular.  

Their wide range of pastas were great.  Try the pig head terrine if you are bold enough.  You may be pleasantly surprised.

Waiters are very attentive

Very hard to get a reservation at times especially on friday and saturday night. 

Plan ahead
author: Patrick T.

description:
