I stumbled on this restaurant at a friend's suggestion and was very impressed. Perbacco had a great open, airy environment.
The restaurant is very crowded and the financial district location makes it seem very "after-worky", but the food, service and wines are all in good order. I would highly recommend this place for a night out for some good italian.
author: Peter K.

description:
Anyone who wants to learn how to braise properly should eat their braised short ribs.  The short ribs are the most perfectly tender and flavorful braised meat I have ever tried.  

Note on the house cured meats:  they really don't stand up to Incanto's, so I would suggest saving your money on those plates.
author: Ginger C.

description:
We had our office xmas party here and I was excited because I heard it was supposed to be a fancy high-falutin place with great steak. Just like the rest of my life, this place was an utter disappointment. 

The food is expensive (thank god I was not paying) yet very uninspired. And what the hell is up with restaurants serving midget sized portions of food - when I pay an arm and a leg for a meal, I want the whole freaking cow not bite sized portions. The steak I had was overcooked (burnt) and had very little flavor. They tossed all different types of food into a bowl and called it a salad. 

Only plus to the night was the great wine, which I had way too much of and proceeded to make an ass of myself in front of my coworkers with these gems:

"I can self-control myself"
Asking our office manager "is it ok if I sexually harass people tonight, like can I get a free pass"
Berating my boss in front of his wife (he deserved it) and I still got a big xmas bonus
author: Arin N.

description:
Took my man here for his birthday. We had a perfect dining experience. Everything was stellar. 

But reading reviews on yelp makes me realize that people tend to have different experiences of the same restaurant and you can't really gauge what your own experience will be like from someone else's. That said, if you are not a fussy person, love big flavor and big wine, I highly recommend Perbacco. Bang for the buck.
author: Hallie A.

description:
This gets 5 stars because I've been looking for a new place for work/client dinners.  This is a safe bet and a replacement to One Market, Cosmopolitan Cafe, and the sorts from back in the day, circa early 2000s.

Seating was on time.  Attentive service.  Great food with a wide variety.  Wine recommendation was right on, fun and different big red.  

It's just an all around safe bet...  Also good for a networking dinner, haven't seen someone in a while, first date after work...  There's enough distractness for a conversation topic, that is if you are a people watcher.  

The topping on the night though was David from Venice, the waiter.  His skills were great, an example of how service should be and brings professionalism back into the service industry.  It may be a whole different story if I go back again and have someone else as David really accented the experience.  He'll soon have his picking of where to be in this city at this rate...  Always nice to give props to those that work hard.
author: Mayah C.

description: Hands down some of the best Italian food I have ever had.  The menu was amazing, from the wine and cheese selections to the house cured meets, to the entrees.  The scallops and fusilli pasta were amazing.  The service and ambiance of the restaurant are top notch.
author: Clint A.

description: Good but definitely second place in the Italian contest behind Locanda.
author: Cris V.

description: Perbacco is conveniently located to the financial district and a good place for a work lunch, albeit a tad noisy at times.  I've been here a few times and haven't been disappointed.  Last time I was there I had one of the pasta dishes - not sure if it was the short rib ragu or the pork one but whatever it was, it was delicious!  This last time I opted for something different and went with the butternut squash ravioli.  It's served in a brown butter sauce and topped with sage and toasted hazelnuts.  Yum.  I hear the burrata is to die for so I'll keep that in mind for next time.
author: Carrie L.

description: Had dinner there last week....yawn.  Food was ok- not great. I was falling asleep while eating. The really hard, cold bread kept me awake for a while- one needs some concentration while attempting to get a bite of the hardened slab of concrete.  I would have graciously given three stars for the rest of the food and service if not for my painful jaw afterwards. It takes all but a few minutes to warm up bread in the oven and make a world of difference.
author: nenette d.

description: Went back on a girl's night out birthday dinner during the week, and Perbacco was offering a 4 course tasting menu for $45 (appetizer, pasta, entree, and dessert)  It was a LOT of food, but really delicious.  The service was impeccable and helpful as was expected!   I LOVE this place.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: Ok, Here you go yall.... I'm an asshole when it comes to eating Italian...ASSHOLE!  I hate and hate and hate (thanks alot Bay Area) but that is why Perbacco gets my vote. I hate to admit it but I actually crave the expensive Italian fare in the financial district. I don't care about the service or the parking or whatever you yelpers love to cry about. This food just is.... I've been a regular for quite some time and i have to say my compliments to the team. My recomendo is the Agnolotti and the Vitello Tonnato!
author: David G.

description:
Just awful!  

Thanks for ruining my valentines dinner...    Let me qualify that one star is  based on the expectation that a $200 dinner for two would live up to the expectation.   What can I say, atmosphere was marginal (were those really diner booths in the front of the restaurant), salad = terrible, pasta course = average, fish = god awful    

There are about 20 better restaurants in this price band that come immediately to mind.  2 on the same block !!!
author: Cadillac X.

description:
My wife and I were super impressed with every aspect of the experience here. The staff are very friendly and accommodating. We made our reservation on opentable.com and when we arrived the hostess offered to seat us right away or to wait until 6:30 and have a drink in the bar. We tried the mojito and a house special with gin, cucumber infused syrup and lemon juice, both were superb. The servers were very friendly and professional. I asked to be seated in a quieter area (it's not overly loud inside but it's not super quite either) as it was our anniversary, and we were seated in a corner booth which was perfect. The server was helpful in her wine recommendations, as neither of us are familiar with Italian varietals. Wine also comes by the glass, 1/4 L or 1/2 L which is perfect for a couple. The mixed salumi plate was excellent but rich, it's probably a bit more than two people need but offers a nice variety of cured pork and veal. 

Dinner was the duck for me and meyer lemon/mint ravioli for the wife, both were excellent. The duck was cooked perfectly and melted in your mouth, and the ravioli were flavorful and tender. Dessert for me was the buttermilk panna cotta and the doughnuts for her, both excellent and the wife's doughnuts came in a cute little white takeout bag, I thought it was a nice touch. They offer dessert wine suggestions with the desserts which is helpful for those who enjoy dessert wines. They also offer a selection of digestifs and bourbon, brandy. The pacing of the meal was so nice, there was ample time in between courses to digest and the food came out at a proper temperature, ready to eat. I notified Perbacco that it was our anniversary mainly to get a quite table but they also gave us a nice card and a special dessert presentation, which I thought was a nice example of going above and beyond, and why they deserve five stars. The price provides good value for the food, the service is top notch and the ambience is fun enough for a group and still romantic for a couple. Parking is probably a beast, they offer valet but we got a ride in and out. Highly recommend for a special event.
author: Christopher V.

description: 3.5 stars but rounding down.  The thing I remember most about Perbacco is the long wait times.  Not sure why I keep coming back here when after every meal I tell myself I'm not coming back!   Don't get me wrong, the food is pretty good but it's not so extraordinary that I would need to wait hours to eat here.  It's not just dinner either, once I came with coworkers at 11:30am and we could only sit at the bar even though half the tables were empty because they were already "fully committed."  That being said, my favorites are the salumi misti, the pappardelle ragu, the langaroli and the cheese board!  Just make sure when you have more than a party of 2 to have a reservation!   (and even then be prepared to wait)
author: Susan L.

description:
Absolutely nothing I would change.  

I know a restaraunt is noteworthy when I keep thinking about it weeks later.  

I came here with some vendors for a work lunch and it was perfect.  The service from the moment I walked in was friendly and attentive.  And being the only female in the group, I took note that the servers always took my order/ delivered my food/ asked to refill my drink first.  Refreshing curtousy.  The food was absolutely delicious!  I had the roasted beets and arugula for an appetizer and the most marvelous gnocchi for a main course.  The gnocchi was light and fluffy, I ate every last one.  We just kept ordering wine, so we skipped dessert.  If you're a wine person, you'll love the BOOK of a wine list.

Overall, a wonderful experience and convenient to parking.  Highly recommended!
author: Nica W.

description:
This is my new favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  Now, granted I live in North Beach and am not really a fan of Italian food, but the dishes at Perbacco are light and fresh...not your heavy standard fare.

The interior is gorgeous; all interactions with the staff were great (friendly, genuine, and knowledgeable); and the food is wonderful.  

We started with the burrata cheese- so yummy!  (even if it did kick my lactose intolerant ass later in the night).  Then, we shared a half order of the pasta with short ribs which was also excellent.  The actual pasta was the best I've had in SF and the meat was not over-powering.  Finally, the duck- delicious and served with a lovely stone fruit salad with perfectly ripe and juicy cherries and nectarines.

We complimented all this yumminess with a bottle of primitivo (essentially the only Italian red varietal I know anything about) at the bargain basement price of $31.  The food only made the wine taste even better.

I'd definitely go back for drinks/snacks or dinner (love that it's like 3 blocks from my office so it makes a great weeknight choice). Highly recommend!
author: Amy K.

description:
One friend from out of town, another friend who recently moved to SF, my husband and I met up at Perbacco to have dinner on a Friday night.  Although we had reservations, it took about 15 minutes to get seated and an uncomfortable 15 minutes at that because there was little room to stand and wait.

However, once we were seated, the service was great and the food and alcohol began to flow.  We shared the gnocchi, burrata and cured meats appetizers.  All were very tasty.  Us girls also started out with fragolinos (also very tasty) while my husband had beer.  We each ordered something different - the two fish dishes, the beef short rib and the duck breast.  The wine steward selected a light red wine that was delicious and accompanied everyone's dishes nicely.  The fish dishes were okay, the beef short rib a bit underseasoned and the duck breast sublime.  My friend (recent transplant from NYC) likes to pick a "winner" of the all the dishes that are ordered when we dine out.  The duck breast won easily.  

We also had desserts - sharing the pistachio cake, sorbetto and another litle cake (I can't remember what was in it except it was fruity).  The pistachio cake was my favorite - warm and crisp on the outside and gooey on the inside.  The sorbetto was delicious too - like taking a bite from a frozen strawberry.   The sorbetto came with two cookies.  I'd like to point out that my husband offered a cookie to my friend before offering it to me.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Better than average dinner...enjoyed the appetizers quite a bit...my two co-workers and myself probably could have just eaten off of that section.  The beets, the selection of Italian meats, the mozzarella...all great.

When it came time for a main course I decided to simply go with the butternut squash soup...usually a staple in my restaurant diet, I like this version as they didn't overpower the soup with too much sugar.  Literally tasted like fresh butternut squash with a hint of brown sugar.

Good thing I saved room for dessert....we enjoyed the hazelnut cake and the hazelnut cookies.

I didn't pay, but based on what we ordered, I think the prices were quite reasonable....no main courses though.

Overall, a nice experience, but I can't see this place staying THAT popular with the menu being as large as it is and just not THAT spectacular.
author: Mark C.

description:
From the moment we stepped in, the atmosphere was fun and quite lively.  There were 4 of us girls dining and the night started out with the bartender flirting with 2 of us...  We dined upstairs....  not  as fun as downstairs, I thought...  Kind of more stuffy and quiet.  So we had to behave....  oh shucks...

We ordered the salumi platter, the roasted beet salad, all to share and both were excellent.  Next we had the risotto and the gnocchi and the rib eye.  Every single dish was spectacular.  

Service was very attentive and courteous.  And when more of our friends joined us, the bus help was very attentive to add more chairs.  
An excellent dining experience and  very reasonable.
author: Loves G.

description:
The Rabaton, ricotta gnocchi with mushroom sugo, is amazing.  The sauce is so good I sopped up every drop with some bread.  We started with the salumi appetizer which was good.  All of the salumi had good flavor and wasn't too salty.  The fiance had angotti with rabbit and it was good as well, though the sauce was a bit salty.

We went for lunch.  On my way down the stairs to the basement a cook passed me on his way up to the kitchen with a large pan of what looked like brains, maybe sweetbreads.  I asked our server about it and she said that was on the dinner menu.  I'll have to go back in the evening for sure.
author: Dave P.

description: Fancy fancy...I expected a trendy place but as I dined I watch women dressed in high heel stilettos and avant garde outfits. The diners really amped up the atmosphere. Now I don't remember much else of the decor except grays colors and white table tops. Also, food was great--fresh pasta and good wine. I was a happy diner!!
author: Royce L.

description:
I'm not typically a Downtown diner, preferring the less formal and more inviting experiences of neighborhood restaurants.  But we had a gift certificate to Perbacco.  And we're so happy.  Started with a small salumi misti plate that was fantastics and very generous.  You could simply make it a lite bite with drinks if you wanted.  Then had the anglotti (sp?) pasta for the second course.  For dinner, I had the rabbit (three small piece prepared differently) and my partner had the quail.  The quail was delicious.  The rabbit sauce was excellent, but the rabbit itself seemed overcooked to me.  Our outstanding server paced the meal very well, kept our wine appropriately poured (we brought a bottle) and followed up to see how we were enjoying things.  When she asked about the rabbit, I simply told her that I loved the sauce but the meat was overcooked for me, she immediately asked if she could bring me a new serving.  I didn't want another dish because I was getting full.  So she insisted on bringing us dessert, which we reluctant accepted.  I forget was it was because we wolfed it down in two seconds, even though we were stuffed.

Had the rabbit been as perfect as everything else, this would be a 5 star review.  We'll definitely be back.

BTW - total bill was $150 (incl corkage, tax and tip).  Not bad for such superb service and wonderful food.  Plus, the gift cert covered most of the bill! :)
author: Kevin M.

description: Food was good, service was good, ambiance was good. Good, not great. Especially for the price. The best thing, the breadsticks, were free! I go to less expensive restaurants with better food, so will not be returning to Perbacco.
author: Presto G.

description: Wonderful epicurean experience. Salumi platter was scrumptious. Veal based had the perfect balance of fat. Coppa mista nice texture and meaty flavor. Rock shrimp was lightly battered in a tempura style with out of this world green and white long beans and olives. Olives are the bomb! Split the papparadella and short rib dish. Noodles are perfectly prepared. Short rib ragu and sauce was too overly reduced which left a strong after taste and a bit too salty. Sea scallops were good. White corn was a perfect compliment with the scallops. Piemonte flight was good. Had I one off bottle which was replaced with a pour for a new bottle. Great service. Staff and place were hopping. Would highly recommend for special occasion and just to get out of house meal.
author: I have something to say... A.

description: This place is great!!  I went with my dad and sat at the bar for lunch. Had the burrata appetizer- fabulous. We both had pastas, me the tagliatelle, he the pappardelle- both were excellent.  We split the chocolate ADD dessert - I call it that as it was choco dessert 4 ways: and olive oil layer cake, a truffel with honey in it, a warm dark chocolate bergamot tartlet and a milk chocolate bonbon - all were stellar- mega creativity points to the pastry chef!!  Its not cheap, but its well worth paying for.
author: Catherine R.

description:
Not too many restaurants in the city that get 5 stars from me.  Especially Itialian ones....  A bowl of pasta, 5 stars?  Not a likely combo.  This was not an Italian restaurant with your run of the mill bowls of pasta.  
We walked in at 6:30 on a Thursday night, the place was packed.  We were promptly seated in the back part of the restaurant (we had a reservation).  Our server quickly asked us if we wanted water, and asked if we had any questions or needed anything off the bat.  I always liked that, just shows attentiveness of the staff to make sure you are going to get what you need.  After looking over the menu which was packed with pretty much something for everyone, we both settled on an appetizer and entree for each of us.  I started with the Burrata and tomato salad, and then moved on to the braised short ribs.  My girlfriend had a green salad, and ligurian pasta with basil pesto.  
To start, we both loved our first courses.  The greens on her salad were about as fresh as they could get, packed with flavor, it wasnt a complicated salad, but all in all it was a perfect blend of greens and paper thin sliced parmesan cheese, with just a hint of dressing.  
My salad was absolutely amazing.  The cheese was like eating cream, but just solidified enough to keep some sort of a shape,  and perfectly salted.   The tomatoes were fantastic too.  By far the best burrata I ever had .  
Our main courses came and we were both blown away.  My short ribs were braised and braised perfectly.  The meat was accompanied by the smoothest mashed potatoes I have ever eaten, also the green beans were lightly salted, peppered and steamed just enough to have some crunch to them.  My girlfriend's pasta had the greenest and tastiest pesto.  It had some other veggies blended in as well.  It was very tasty.  
After we finished our main courses we didn't want to finish this meal, so we decided on having one more glass of wine and some cheese.  I know nothing about cheese, but we settled on two (robiola tre latte and boho bel), and they were fantastic.  We selected one off the "local cheese" section of the menu.  It was like eating a brie but a bit lighter in flavor.  Sadly enough it was time for us to move on with life and end the meal.  I couldn't have fit another bite of food in my stomach after everything, but it was a great feeling.  
I was shocked when I got the bill.  It wasn't a "cheap" dinner, but very reasonable I thought. 
2 glasses of wine
1 cocktail
2 appetizers
2 entrees
2 cheeses
120 bucks....
Needless to say, I have spent that kind of money in a restaurant in San Francisco more then once, and not felt that I got my moneys worth.  This was well worth it.  I will be going back, and hopefully soon.
author: Mike G.

description: Today was my first time at Perbacco and fell in love. Can't wait to go back again, definitely want to try dinner here as well! For lunch I had the Tajarin (5 hour pork sugo with fresh handmade pasta) it was amazing! It came surprisingly fast - you can definitely have lunch here in 1 hour! Excellent espresso as well. Service - just as other reviewers have noted was impeccable.
author: Denise V.

description: superb. excellent bar. Alana is top notch server.
author: spin b.

description:
overcooked my fish
found a hair in my dish

Davids bottom line-  
too curly to be mine

Oh well at least there was beer.
author: David L.

description: I had some fatty expectations for this place.  The service was excellent and the food was good but it didn't blow me away.  The skinny cow and I shared the Pappardelle and Tarajin pasta.  The pappardelle was decent with braised short rib sauce.  I thought EOS wine bar and Mint 54 had a better pappardelle.  The Tarajin is a speghetti like noodle the had a similar texture to noodles in chinese soup.  It was cooked nicely but it wasn't my favortie.  The grilled octopus was charred nicely and fairly soft in teh middle.  Angelinis Osteria in LA has spoiled me.  I don't think I can even look at Italian food the same.  Sucks to be fat.  I am glad to try this place once but I am going to Aqua or Tadich Grill next.  woot!
author: Fatty A.

description:
I don't feel that much for this restaurant yet to write a write up :) Here are some facts instead.

1. Service was very good
2. Wine list is gynormous
3. Food is very good
4. Desserts are awesome
5. Parking is easy
6. Definitely worth the money
7. Front staff shows attitude for no reason. However, walk to aqua (2 doors away) and then you will find the unwelcoming host very sweet. Still, the host's attitude has been consistently bad over the 3 times I have been there. 

I'd say forget the host and enjoy the rest of your night. If you don't have reservations, you can sit in the front bar area. It can get really noisy there so watch out.
author: Ashwin K.

description:
Perbacco is Perlicious!! That is my new word for delicious food at Perbacco! My husband and I went here for dinner to celebrate so we went all out- we had the following:

Plate of assorted salami- by no means run of the mill
Homemade stuffed ricotta gnocchi w/ melted cherry tomatoes
Homemade pesto tagliatelle w/ summer squash and potatoes
Grilled sardines on grilled salted watermelon
Grilled lamb
A lovely peach topped ricotta cake, with warm berry compote and peach caramel gelato
2 types of wine- you can get 1/4, 1/2 or 3/4 carafes so that you can sample different types

All of it was fantastic, and we felt like we got a lot for what we paid considering it was a fine dining establishment ($175 including tip and tax). It was a memorable meal, and we were lucky to have a really great server. The only downside to this place is that it is in the financial district so you have to deal w/ patrons whom you would likely never associate yourself with, if you are anything like us (our stomping grounds are the Mission District). 

Enjoy if you choose to go!
author: Sonal B.

description:
Went here again for happy hour this week for the same items as my first time after I told a coworker about the limonata. DELISH! Makes it even better now that I know they are quite consistent in service and yummie food.

Previous visit: I went there for a quick drink after work Friday and refreshingly enough, it was not overly packed like most of the area's bars/restaurants.    Not sure if that is a good thing or not, but I appreciated not having to push through a crowd or have to wait to order my drink.  I tried their limonata scozzese as I've never tried a drink that had cucumber.  It was very delicious and of course, refreshing in the sense that it had cucumber and was something new to try.  We also tried the fritto misto, which had fried green olives that I really liked.  Generally, I think green olives are too salty for me but with it being fried, it made it less salty but a slight tanginess that I liked.  "Happy hour", (as the prices are not the norm of happy hour) was a great experience, which makes me want to come back to try the dinner menu.
author: bunnymouse k.

description:
I went here with two of my bosses for a business lunch (company treat!). My VP had held her husband's birthday dinner here when it first opened and they had been so accommodating and helpful (and yummy)  that she kept coming back for business and personal lunches and dinners. I have to say that I was a little nervous looking at the menu because everything looked so gourmet that it might be over-whelming. I got the gnocchi and it was DELICIOUS! Usually when I get the potato pasta, it's heavy and not cooked very well, but the mushroom gnocchi was so good I wished there was more (that's another thing: there's not too much food per serving so you won't feel like a fat-ass when you finish your plate-- and you WILL finish every bite)! 

I highly recommend this restaurant for the atmosphere, the food and the service. Everything from the private dining loft upstairs to the cool-looking private bathrooms downstairs to the chatty, helpful waitstaff to the incredible food is done to perfection!
author: Jami G.

description: Great food, great service, great prices, drink prices are reasonable.  Consistently a pleasure.
author: mi m.

description:
Perbacco used to be good years ago.  However, the operative description today is bland. 

First, we were early for our table but were left cooling our heels in the bar for 10 minutes past our reservation.

Second, the bathrooms were not clean with dirty toilet seats and sticky floors.  This was a bad sign for the overall managment.

The rolls were slightly stale and quite bland.

We got the nduja which was supposed to be spicy but only mildly so.  The crostini had no interesting seasoning on them.

The fritto misto with rock shrimp literally had 5 tiny shrimp on it and was packed with deep fried olives.  A few olives would have been nice but there were at least a dozen.  The poor shrimp were outnumbered.

The pasta with pork ragu was bland.  The pasta was overcooked in water that had no salt in it.  The ragu had little depth of flavor.

The short ribs were bland, no depth of flavor.  No herbal taste or complexity.  Also a bit greasy.

Did not stay for dessert.  

If I were you, I would hop next door to Tadich Grill, get a martini or manhattan, a nice shrimp cocktail, and a plate of pan-fried fish and you will spend less money and have a much better meal.
author: Jonathan H.

description: After 3 rich courses and 2 glasses of wine, I needed a 2 hour nap. Woke up with the memory of the chocolate gianduja semifreddo dessert still on my tongue. And the chef- who stopped by our table- was such a sweetie.
author: Joan P.

description:
the food was good....i got the Fritto Misto of rock shrimp, which was tasty...light and crispy.  also got the gnocchi with peekytoe crab (apparently this is the nickname of the Maine rock crab...which was a throwaway critter in lobster fishing until someone gave it a nickname and started charging money for it...go figure.  also, why is it called lobster "fishing"?)...anyway, the gnocchi was tasty and they give you a lot of crab.  i got the appetizer serving of this, and it was enough because it was pretty rich.  

all the other dishes in my group were also good...the john dorry was flaky, light, with a crispy skin.  the butternut squash ravioli in brown butter sauce was good, albeit maybe a slightly too sweet for me, but my dining companions liked that.  the brussel sprout side dish was also good.

the service was attentive and good.

they breadsticks with the pesto was yummy...hing: save some of that pesto and slather it on the bread they give you.

anyway, the food here is really good.  it's in a cool building too.  it kinda has this sterile financial district vibe to it though, which isn't necessarily a horrible thing, but maybe it's just not my cup of tea.
author: Miss P.

description: Liked the gnocchi stuffed with crab. House bread was tasty, but would have been better if it were served warm.
author: Meghan B.

description:
An exceptionally good restaurant. One caveat -- I don't find it romantic,.  It's nice, but if you're looking for hearts and flowers stuff -- this may not be your place. 

PERBACCO delivers.  The food is TRULY excellent.  Their meat sauces are cooked for hours and if you think that doesn't make a difference, you haven't eaten at Perbacco yet.  

I'm from SF -- grew up here -- so I'm used to good food, though I am not a "foodie."  And I'm not wealthy and there is a lot of very good food in S.F. that is not at "expense account" prices -- so I really expect good food and good service if I'm going to spend the big money  -- esp. since I am not "On expense account." 



I find the decor a bit uncomfortable and not as warm as I'd like it to be - but the restaurant is run incredibly well, the staff are top notch, the owner runs a tight ship and -- usually great bar staff, too.  they had TERRIFIC bar staff a couple of years ago -- very welcoming yet professional (it's a big power business spot), and they had memories -- go in there once and they'd recall what you drank.  that justified the high drink prices to me.  Then they had a guy who was a total dick who had worked at some high profile bars and therefore thought he was a "star" - and acted like it.  Apparently that was his "schtick" -- but not mine. In fact, I didn't go in for a year because the "attitude" was infuriating.  Went back in about 3 months ago, had a drink at the bar which is a bit of a twist on a common drink.  Lovely women bartender I'd never met before.  I came in a MONTH later, sat down, was talking with a friend before ordering and...my drink, perfectly made  (it's an easy drink, but you'd be amazed how many people really mess it up...)  set down in front of me before I had even said a word and she smiled and said "I'm taking a chance that this might be what you want..."

THAT, my friends, is worth $10 -- and a tip!
author: L M.

description:
I went here for my birthday. It was a bit improvised because the restaurant I wanted to go had closed. 
For me, italian is always a good improvisation, so when I saw the reviews for this restaurant I thought it was a good idea.
My husband and I tried a couple of things in the menu. I had a burrata salad with heirloom tomatoes, which was average and my husband had a crudo which was actually really good. For entree we chose a plate with three pastas. The size was really small, for the price you could have had three full plates. Two of them were good.
I didnt like dessert at all. Too fancy and nothing italian.
I thought it was going to be more expensive than what it was.
author: carla f.

description: this place is a must try if you haven't by now! The chef's choice salumi is the best when you request the back fat...it's like butter, so baaaaad...but so damn good! Tajarin is a must...I think I can eat that dish in like 2 minutes all to myself! service is awesome here too...you'll have good times here indeed! FYI - Be careful if you've had too much wine and need to use the restroom...the stairs will kill you!
author: Brian C.

description: Perbacco is good, but fails to blow me away.  It's a bit crowded and very loud, but doesn't disappoint.  I think, in many ways, it tries too hard, but it's well worth a return visit.
author: David G.

description: Amazing Italian Food in downtown SF.  I highly recommend the veal tartare - its amazing!
author: Johnna M.

description:
Just went there for dinner last night.  We ate in the bar area and had a fantastic time.  We didn't have the same service problems that a lot of other people seem to have had.  It was kind of slow, but that's what we wanted since we were on a girls' night out - and our waitress and everyone else who came by were totally great.  She recommended a fabulous wine just up our alley (for $30! when she could have gone much higher) and another super-friendly waiter who wasn't even working our table dropped by to recommend the polenta cake with olive oil ice cream and rhubarb compote for dessert - yum.  When we were done, the host ran outside to get one of the valets to hail us cabs.  It was fun.

We had the cured meat salumi plate - San Daniele prosciutto, goose prosciutto, pancetta, and coppa - it was awesome.  We were feeling pretty greedy, so we each got two half-portions of pasta... what a genius concept that is!  We had ricotta and green garlic gnocchi with asparagus; tortelloni filled with roasted pork and prosciutto in brodo with fresh peas; tajarin (kind of reminded me of ramen noodles) with a duck sugo; and tagliatelle with short rib ragu and wild mushrooms.  Everything was amazing.  We ended up paying $140 total, including tax and tip, for the wine, salumi, 4 pastas, and 2 desserts - seemed totally reasonable to us.  

I thought it was fantastic and will definitely go back.  The only downside is that it was pretty loud - if there'd been more than 2 of us, it would have been hard to hear anyone not sitting next to you.  We were yelling as it was.  Otherwise, I just wish we could have ordered more things, and would especially have liked to try some appetizers.  

In conclusion: it's not quite A16, but it's pretty damn good.
author: Ace P.

description:
From the moment we walked in at 8 pm with the audacity of thinking we could get a table we were treated like queens. We were fortunate to slip in between turns and were seated immediately in a comfortable booth near the bar. The service was exceptional from our first greeting by the hostess, to our server from Italy and our charming busser, the GM, the bartenders--essentially everyone who works at Perbacco was concerned with our comfort (and we were high-maintenance: cold, then hot, then cold).

Then there was the food. We had four courses beginning with the Frito Misti with olives, the freshly made paparadelle in a short rib sugo, to the liberty duck breast with pears and finally the most amazing homemade gelato with fennel and caramel next to a perfect tartitine, followed by a great machiatto and (I didn't think I'd have room) balanced, crispy yet soft, house-baked biscotti. We had one of our best dates ever and we can't wait to go back. Go!  Go now.
author: Basa P.

description: My boss hosted our Marketing Department holiday luncheon in a private room at this beautiful, highbrow restaurant, so my experience is limited to a prix-fix menu for large parties. The food was good, but it kind of sucked that they don't permit by-the-glass choosing for boozing groups (full bottles only). Luckily, I was able to strong-arm everyone down a champagne path. And the loo was a little too "Ally McBeal" for me. Don't get me wrong -- I like pretty ladies knowing that I do, in fact, scrub my paws after a piss, but didn't really enjoy awkwardly washing up at the same basin with them. Bottom line ~ I definitely want to come back and order like a civilian.
author: Gregor G.

description: We loved this place!  Was able to get a last minute reservation on a Saturday night.  Our table was ready on time and it was a bustling scene.  Tried the salami misti platter - it was excellent!  The pastas we ordered were delicious.  The pasta was cooked perfectly and the sauce was rich and flavorful.  I love that you can order an entree or appetizer size to try a few different pastas.  And the chocolate-hazelnut semifreddo is maybe one of the best desserts I have ever had.  For such a lovely meal, the prices were definitely reasonable.  We will definitely be back - and often!
author: Michelle C.

description: I love this restaurant. It's close to my office and the service is fantastic. Especially with Brett Tebo! He is a fantastic asset to the business. (His expertise is in wine as a sommelier, and a fine server). Make sure you get his station, you will have a wonderful experience. The food is great and the cocktails are generous. The atmosphere is fun and hip. A great place to bring a date or have an office lunch or dinner.
author: C T.

description:
I received a gift certificate to this restaurant and so my boyfriend and I went here on a Monday night. I would highly recommend making reservations because it was packed when we arrived for our own. The atmosphere is fancy and definitely where the people of the Financial District go to wine and dine over business talk.

Slow roasted veal- I really recommend this dish. It was thinly sliced and the lemon and albacore tuna sauce created a great combo.
Piatra roasted octopus- The octopus was a little bland and slightly overcooked.
Potato gnocchi- The cheese/cream sauce was yummy and didn't feel too heavy. The toasted hazelnuts created a flavor that reminded me of winter.

For my main course, I had the duck. This dish came out with 4 generous pieces of duck that had a nice crispy skin. However, the dish was a little salty and 2 out of 4 of my duck pieces were uncooked. For dessert, I had the bread pudding; it was dry. I liken the dessert to french toast with raisins. 

The service was good though. The restaurant was busy but the waiter was able to provide an explanation on the wine and answer any of our questions. The lady who brought out our food was also very nice.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Simple food but very well made.

For lunch, ordered -
Taglatelle with short rib ragu
Mackerel with caponata
White corn and chanterelle mushroom (side)
Green beans in a tomato based sauce (side)
Hazelnut cookies with espresso
Approx $65.

We had decided to share the main entree, so the kitchen had split it for us. I haven't seen this service in a long time so I really liked it. Short rib ragu was just perfect. Tagliatelle could have been a little more al dente.

Caponanta had large pieces of roasted peppers that were extremely soft without being mushy. The mackerel was served with skin on but was cooked to perfection. 

White corn with mushrooms was unexpectedly good. The sweetness of corn worked very well with the smokiness of mushrooms. It was a very buttery dish but worked well with both the pasta and the fish course.

From the description, I was expecting a slow cooked whole bean dish. It turned out to be green beans cooked very soft - almost falling apart. But the sauce was unctuous and sweet with tomatoes. Overall the combination was one of those things you want to scoop up with thick slices of bread.

The cookies were plentiful. Very nutty and bit too sweet. Espresso was adequate.

It was a lot of food but my stomach felt easy later.  If I go there again, I would just split a soup and a pasta dish.  Or maybe split a pasta dish and a cookie plate. Or a soup and a side. I wish it were a neighborhood place. 

Service was unobtrusive and friendly. Lots of financial types talking business at lunch time waving their latest gadgets about. Finding cheap parking on a weekday is impossible.

For more:
http://locomotoring.net/2010/03/13/sex-in-the-city/
author: Mishti D.

description: Haven't been here in awhile but so far the best fresh pasta I have tasted! The pasta melts in your mouth and the ragu's are so comforting. Their salami/lard plates are a must try and since they are known for pasta - don't even look at the rest of the menu! Desserts are really good too.
author: Reena C.

description: Can't image better unless you flight to Italia. I've travelled through Italy going to top restaurants.
author: Paul W.

description:
I try to only rate businesses that I absolutely love, and I do love Perbacco. 

Everything about it is great, and I've eaten here quite a number of times. The ambiance, the food, and service are fantastic. 

-1 star for our one and only shaky experience at the bar.  My recommendation to the barmen & sommalier: Don't assume we don't know what we're talking about simply because we're young or look young.    That's all.
author: Carla Y.

description:
My parents hosted at Perbacco our wedding rehearsal dinner for 40 people.  They put our group in a intimate yet spacious private room, setup a separate bar so that guests did not have to walk/wait for drinks, and provided great service for our large group.  

The food was even better than the outstanding service!  Everything tasted fresh and cooked-to-order, rather than tasting like "banquet" food.  In addition, the vegetarian dishes were OUTSTANDING!  One of my groomsmen is a Hindu vegetarian, and I was so relieved when they brought him dishes on par with the carnivore meals.  I was also glad that he was at my table so that I could steal tastes of his food.  

All in all, I would host a dinner here in a heartbeat, and my wife and I and all of our friends are buzzing about the need to go back for dinner.
author: Masa S.

description:
"I want to take you out to dinner for your Christmas present." sez my seester.

"Okay, I'd like to go to Myth."  sez me.

"Really, Myth?  Are you sure?  Myth, really?" asks my seester.

"Yeah."  Sez me.  

"Hmmph. . . just seems like a scene to me. . .I am surprised you picked it."  

Oh.  I am overwhelmed by indecision.  

"Okay then, how about Fleur de Lys?"  I ask.

So we settle on Fleur de Lys.  

Then through a maze of miscommunication, bad weather, missed trips, cancelled reservations and general discombobulation, we ended up at Perbacco for San Francisco/Seattle Seester Christmas Fest 2006.

I like the design as you first walk in . .. it's welcoming and spacious.  The salumi plates are plated at one end of the bar and they have a kick ass chef's dream Italian meat slicer at the end of the bar - I was pleased as I took this as a sign of the restaurants seriousness about their food.  It was a good omen.

The next good omen was that the bartender had a lovely Irish accent . .. one from Cork I believe and it's one of my favorite accents ever.  He was darling and made us two very delicious drinks. . . as we waited for our table (we were early for our reservation) I perused the menu.  It all looked amazing!  It's one of those menus that makes you wish you had more than one stomach. . .sort of a reserve, if you will, for those times where you just don't want to be limited to one.  Like a ruminate but better.   I mentally made my choices and hoped my seester was hungry!

Next good omen is when we were shown to our table;  I like that altho we were only a deuce, they sat us at a four top.   I do truly appreciate some elbow room!

We ordered the ciccioli from the salumi menu which is a pork pate of sorts very similar to rilletes.  It was delicious - it came with some crostini and a small dollop of orange marmalade to offset the richness.  

Next came the burrata.  A very generous mound of unctuous cheese drizzled with black truffle oil.  Served with perfectly toasted filone.  My only disappointment here was I would have like more bread with this dish.

Next came carne cruda - a steak tartare of sorts made with veal instead of beef (same but different) - very delicious with just the right amount of garlic to accent the veal without overwhelming it.  We also got the fritto misto which was good as well with the usual suspects (rock shrimp, green beans, fennel) and a surprise of olives. . I'd never had a deep fried olive before and really enjoyed it.  

Next came three appetizer portions of pasta - a pappardelle with braised shortrib sauce and porcini, penne with meatballs and tajarin; which is a thin, square cut pasta similar to angel hair with a five hour pork sugo.  Of the three, the best was the pappardelle - really deep flavor - almost buttery from the braise.  The tajarin was very good, too.  The pasta was obviously fresh and perfectly cooked and the sauce was quite delicious.   One complaint would be that it was that none of the pastas were hot enough - I think it would have been helpful to heat the plates and serve the pasta in small, shallow bowls as opposed to flat plates.   Also, the meatballs were a little tough - flavorful but tough. 

Next (no, I am not kidding!), came the pork shoulder, short ribs and a piece of cotechino  - cotechino is one of my favorite Italian sausages and they were featuring it in a bollito misto - I didn't want all the elements of a bollito misto so I asked for just a piece of the cotechino and they very graciously complied and even served it with the three sauces that would have gone with the bollito misto - an orange marmalade, a finely pureed salsa verde and a piquant tomato relish.  The pork shoulder was one of my best dishes I've ever had.  I love braised meat and this dish was just so perfect, I wanted to eat only that.  But then the short rib was not too shabby either. . it's kind of like if you had Jeffrey Dean Morgan standing next to George Clooney and you had to pick between them.  Both luscious!  The cotechino was stellar as well - perfect texture and very balanced spices.  I was so happy with the entrees!  These days, it seems that restaurants present amazing appetizers and then fall short on the entrees but Perbacco dishes up some amazing entrees.

We were full so we didn't get to have dessert - next time less entrees, more dessert.  

This restaurant is only 7 weeks old so there were some service bumps - kind of slow on service and lag time between pastas and entrees was a little long.  The clientele is a trip - there were a lot of really drunk people there - and while that is not the restaurants fault, it was kind of a distraction.  The bathrooms are funky.  Unisex but not. . .you'll go, you'll see.  

I can't wait for my seester to come visit again so we can again - next time, my treat!
author: Lainie L.

description:
I have dined at Per Bacco about a half a dozen times now, and it is consistently good.  I especially love their squid appetizer.  I have had excellent gnocchi, papperdelle, short ribs, heirloom tomato salad, and countless other dishes - and lots of good bites from others dishes too.  The only dish I had that i was not crazy about was a veal risotto.  Unfortunately, I have a hard time giving it 5 stars for two reasons:
1 while the food is fairly consistent, service is not always so.  For example, I went there for a business lunch and we let our server know that we needed to be back at the office within an hour and we ordered right away.  An hour and 45 minutes later i paid the check- with no apologies for the delay.  
2 ambiance is good but not great.  why?  because that place is just so dang loud!  for my birthday dinner last year, my husband and i could not understand a word the other was saying because it was so loud.  oh well, we just spoke up.
author: Kari P.

description: Went to Perbacco with my parents for a special meal and enjoyed everything I ate, but I was glad someone else was paying. I had the seared scallops, but I tried everyone else's entrees, and thought mine was the winner. We suspected that we were seated upstairs because we were dressed somewhat casually. Everyone upstairs seemed a bit more casual than the people we peeked at through the glass ledge. We weren't offended, but consider yourself warned--if you want to sit in the main dining room, cotton isn't going to cut it.
author: George L.

description: This place is always a good pick for lunch, I have been many times and exceeded my expectations on my recent visit as usual.
author: Brad T.

description: When I come across a restaurant with an average of 4 stars based on over 1000 reviews, I've got to believe that it's going to be a delight to eat there. Ok, so apparently there are 1000 people on Yelp who have not had truly good Italian food, I guess.  The restaurant was fine; had I come across it walking by and had a meal, I'd be ok with it. Presentation varied between delightful (beet salad) sloppy (agnolotti appetizer dumped on a plate).  The taste? Well, as ex-Californian (born and raised there), I can only say this ... It's like a stereotypical Hollywood blonde with surgical 'enhancements' that make her look like a cover girl ... You would do anything to date her based on appearance but when you sit down to talk, you realize that she is as vacuous as a blank canvas. The food was monotonous, at best. The ideas looked nice on paper but when the plate came to the table, "meh" is all I could think. My wife actually sent her dish back it was so bland.   My advice is to take what you read with a grain of salt; even my evaluation.  Just be cautious, that's all.  Oh, and so you think I'm not sophisticated enough to appreciate the food, I do NOT think that Olive Garden is gourmet (although probably more worth the price than Perbacco)!
author: Richard N.

description: Only 414 reviews? Wow. What more can I add? How's this for an idea: Cut your solo dining customers a break and eliminate a couple of the bar chairs so it's possible to enjoy lunch without knocking elbows with the person sitting on either side? I've never been in an upscale restaurant - like Perbacco - where diners are so packed in at the bar; it's quite unpleasant. This isn't a diner - or is it?
author: John B.

description: I went here a while back, the quality of food I remember was excellent, fresh pasta with yummy moist ribs. Salame platter was good but with some new interesting things too, i was eating pig brain for all I knew. The atmosphere was nice, small, I sat at the bar. Fancy place good food
author: Karen T.

description: Solid northern Italian food and friendly, prompt service for dinner.  Our table ordered the giant (if not obnoxious) showing of salumi misti. If you like salumi, this is heaven. Remaining menu changes daily, however I ordered the carne crudo di vitello (veal tartar)  which was excellent. Followed with a main dish of northern halibut with artichoke hearts and new potatoes- which was decent but not the best I've had. Companion ordered the roast quail which, hands down, was the best dish at the table. If you like cheese, you're in for a treat on the dessert menu. The mascarpone semifreddo is also outstanding.
author: Vanessa N.

description: Wow, this place is freakin over-rated.  I have to beleive it might be usually better since its reviewed well.  However, after trying the non-inspiring hamachi appetizer with an over salted, not tener pork chop, I will have to say no thanks.  You are better off next door at Aqua or Tadich Grill if you want better food in my opinion.  Nice staff though and great bar.
author: Charles C.

description: Even though everyone and their brother has been here I still feel it's a bit of a hidden gem due to its lower profile.  Go here and order a bunch of pasta dishes to share.  The best, most tender, flavorful pasta I've ever had.  And every time I'm here someone like Al Gore walks in.
author: Stephen P.

description: Had dinner here last night and the food was truly wonderful. We started with the Agnolotti filled with veal and cabbage.  They were amazing and so delicate.  Much better than ravioli so don't compare the two! Then for my entree I had the Monkfish, which was slightly mushy and bland... but it's monkfish, which to me tastes good no matter how it is prepared...and the sauce and artichokes tasted terrific.  My dining partner had the Sirloin Steak which was amazing and had a great topping of marrow and herbs.  The dessert was as big of a highlight as the agnolotti.  We had the Chocolate tart which has an amazing buttery and flaky crust, a layer of caramel and hazelnuts that tasted like soft nut brittle and a layer of rich chocolate ganache! The wine was also great.  The service was not as bad as I read in some other reviews, but it is definitely something they should work on in.
author: Stacy R.

description: I looked at the menu as I passed by the other day and didn't notice any vegetarian entrees on the menu.  No doubt they can whip up something upon request, but why not just have something listed officially?  Based on this, it's not a place I'm planning to go.
author: Andi T.

description:
5 Reasons not to return:
1.  The chef loves salt...WAY too much.  Everything gets TONS of salt, from ravioli to breadsticks to desserts.....damn..
2.  Wine is kept at another table.  We ordered a bottle, they poured it, and put it on a communal table of other people's open wine bottles.  Of course, when you want to be refilled, they are nowhere to be found.  I do not need my wine intake to be controlled by waitstaff (ok-maybe I do, but that's not gonna make me come back!).
3.  Dirty Radicchio-My salad was not washed and in the midst of eating it, found a huge clump of dirt in it.  To their credit, they took it off the check and provided me with a free (salty) dessert.
4.  Wine glasses-So, we ordered a Zinfandel.  The table next to us ordered the same bottle.  They received wine glasses designed for drinking Zin and enhancing the taste.  We were left with the original glasses on the table.
5.  Medium means medium-Medium steak does not mean bloody and raw, it means MEDIUM.  Luckily, still tasted good.
Ok, I lied--6 reasons, but #6 is really important:
6.  Cheese plate-So, we picked the cheeses for dessert-a blue and 2 soft cheeses.  First of all, the cheese are kept on a table with the communal wines.  They are not covered either for safety or to keep the moisture in the cheese, so it was no surprise one cheese was quite dried out.  Then, they brought them on a plate with nothing on which to place/eat them (crackers, fruit, bread).  When asking for bread, we received the DINNER ROLLS that came at the beginning of the meal.  If there is one thing I know and love, it's my cheese.  The wrong bread or accompanyment can ruin the experience of tasting the cheese.  Thick, wheat rolls do NOT go well with a gorgonzola piccante.  That was the last straw for me, nobody should ruin my cheese.......ever.........

Update one day later:  Guess the unwashed radicchio was more of a problem than I thought.  Spent the night with food poisoning and everyone else at the table was fine.  The only thing I ate that they didn't was the radicchio.....STAY CLEAR FOR YOUR SAFETY!
I will never go back.
author: Jessica L.

description: I'm a fan of Perbacco (pronounced per-bah-ko) I asked.  Fun and innovative cocktails and fabulous wine.  Also had some proccuito and some sort of sashimi.  Also yummy.  Anyway, this place is a bit of an older crowd and in the FiDi.  I forsee it being a fun new happy hour spot.  It looks like a great date place and from what I've experienced so far, I'd like to go back.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: My lunch here was great, and the service was AMAZINGLY fast.  I think I was in and out in less than 40 minutes on a Friday, at noon.  My dining companion and I both had pastas, and they were both great.  A touch pricy, but not beyond what you'd expect when you walk in.
author: Ben P.

description:
God-dam I love Yelp mobile...I think it's changed my life. I now feel like some kind of fine dining superhero when I don't want to waste my money and time and I'm stuck on the outskirts somewhere unfamiliar.  Take for example a few Friday nights ago. My beau and I are heading off to go see a play in the city, yet we have to get off an an early station for an emergency situation *don't ask* and hence, we miss our play despite our long fruitful journey on BART.  So we're stuck in the financial district, I need a bathroom (which is the curse of death anywhere in SF) and Perbacco just looks convenient at this point.

We decided to just grab a glass of wine at their bar tables up front, but when I yelped the place and saw the great reviews, we decided to stay  for some appetizers. The antipasto plates coming out were making our mouths water, so our cool waitress recommended the chefs selection, which is basically whatever he feels like giving us. When the selection came out, we were told that they cure all the meats there and were told more about the specific region of Italy that the food originates from...I live for this stuff. To me, that whole engagement with your server makes the experience really special and our waitress was very attentive, knowledgeable and charming. My favorite standout for me was the pate' served with a kind of apricot compote-- the savory and the sweet together just pops on your tastebuds. 
I can only speak for the appetizers, drinks and the waitress- but I'll be back for entrees the next time around- but this time, intentionally.
author: NaNa M.

description: Great Location (next door to the Tadich) Gorgeous inside. about 120 tables total at about 2.5 turns a night. They must be doing something right. I found it eerily similar to One Market in atmosphere. The food is good to very good, but overpriced. Also, the vast menu is hard to navigate. There are to many choices. The presentations and service are good, the food is good. To paraphrase an old saying, "that was the best twenty dollar meal I ever paid a hundred bucks for"
author: ken s.

description: The atmosphere here is very inviting and warm, but still in tune with the sophistication of the financial district. I haven't sampled their edible offerings but if you're looking for an after work hang out spot this should be on your list. To put it bluntly, this restaurant is Italian to the core, even all the wines are italian. I thought the service was great, they even offer you samples if you aren't sure what you're in the mood for. A definite on my list.
author: Venatius P.

description:
My friend and I arrived early for our reservation so we sat at the empty bar which really has too many chairs. The bartender handed us one wine menu to share and we had to ask for another. We overheard a girl ask him how their pinot grigio was and his response was, "good." She seemed satisfied with the answer, but I wouldn't have expected him to say it was bad. Shouldn't a bartender be able to elaborate on the selections on the bar menu?  My friend and I decided on a cocktail with prosecco and strawberry puree. The drink was great and the scene at the bar began to pick up. They have a mirror running the entire length of the restaurant which is nice to check out yourself (and others) in because the bar is hard to move around if you're sitting because you are locked in by all the chairs. 

We were seated for dinner under the upstairs portion, and the ceiling was very low and the whole section was claustrophobic. There were cheesy paintings of Italy on the walls but I didn't find it attractive. Along with the vinyl booths that lined the walls, it evoked Olive Garden instead of Upscale Italian Eatery. However, the exposed brick and high ceilings on the opposite side of the restaurant were charming. The white and grey marble subway tiles clash with the warm colors on the walls. And the mirror that extends all the way throughout the restaurant gives you a clear view of the kitchen floor if you are seated toward the back of the restaurant.  The bathrooms are downstairs and around the corner with the same ugly tile thats in the restaurant. In fact,  the tile looked like it belonged only in the bathroom as opposed to throughout the whole dining room. The bathrooms are also mixed male/female, but the individual stalls are designated male/female.  Not bad but odd.

The wine director "helped" us pick out a bottle of wine... we discussed wanting a red that leaned towards the fruity side with notes of cherries. We got our $76 bottle of Sangiovese and it had notes of band-aids (really, it smelled like band-aids) instead of cherries and was spicy which is exactly what we told him we didn't want. The appetizers came very quickly and my friend's burrata with truffled salsa was fantastic. Very creamy and the truffles weren't overpowering as they can sometimes be.  I would definitely order that if I were forced to eat there again. I had the pear and endive salad which was extremely hard to eat. There was more arugula then anything else. The pear was too ripe and I couldn't get the endive on my fork it was julienned lengthwise and there wasn't much of it. The hunk of gorgonzola on this side would have been better crumbled on top. For dinner I ordered the ricotta and garlic gnocchi --- nothing to write home about and I didn't even finish it. My friend had the tagliatelli with pork sugo that was just a plate of pasta that looked like ramen with a big dollop of pork sugo on top. Edible, but that's about it. We ordered the panna cotta for dessert. The panna cotta tasted good, but the presentation was lacking. It was just a hunk of panna cotta in the middle with some strawberries on the side. And the strangest thing was the black pepper they deliberately (I think) sprinkled around the edge of the plate. It didn't add to the presentation, and we couldn't figure out why they would put it there because it certainly wouldn't add to the taste. 

The service was just strange. Halfway through my meal the waitress asked if I wanted more bread and I told her no. She then walked over and took my bread plate with the half a roll I was saving for the sauce. It was bizarre. She left my friends' bread plates with bread on them. I was pissed! Hey, I just said I didn't want MORE bread not get this bread out of my sight! Although the food came fast it took forever to clear our plates. The waitress walked by about 5 times and none of us had touched our plates... and our forks were resting in the "take me away" position. But as soon as one of us was finished with our wine, she would come and take away that glass only. But our plates were still sitting there. And once our plates were finally cleared, we had to get her attention and ask for the check, because she was ignoring us at that point. 

They are not a fold-your-napkin while you are in the bathroom restaurant.... I hate that. 

Overall, I don't think I'll be going back.
author: All About Town ..

description:
Opened by famed former Scala's chef, Steffan Terje, PerBacco specializes in Northern Tuscan food.

They have done a wonderful job with the space.  Lots of different woods conspire to make a very timeless and comfortable feel.

Service was fantastic....our waiter was very attentive but not overbearing.

And the food...aaaaah!  Short rib pappardelle was spectacular.  The salumi selection was large and the taste incredible (Terje makes it himself).

I highly recommend this joint
author: Papandreou A.

description:
after jardiniere, no duck is amazing.  this duck though, held its own 

calamari (grilled) was zesty and very satisfying.
author: Hannah W.

description:
i think the best thing about perbacco is the service. from the cute ladies who host, to the adorable italian waitress who took care of my mom and i, to the flirty, energetic and attentive bartenders. i think the service here is WAY more memorable than the food is. 

at dinner w/ mom we shared a salad and each got our own pasta. i had something with truffle oil and rabbit, a dish that from the menu discription soudned like it would explode with flavor. instead it was a bit heavy and uninspired. i actually got tired of it about half-way thru! my mom found her pasta slightly disappointing as well. 

 i went again about a week ago and sat at the bar where we got to experience those uber-friendly bartenders. i could see how eating near these guys would get you excited about the food. they're terrific salesmen, and when you get treated nice like that it makes everything taste better. still tho, i was a lil underwhelmed with our apps and pasta dish. again, pretty good. but not great. not even really memorable. i ate it, i got full. i watched the bartenders swing maniacally back and forth between thirsty patrons with smiles and winks and all manner of flirtatiousness. i was entertained for sure, but not really satisfied. 

if the one thing people seem to rave about on reviews are the salami and cheese and cute bartenders, then you need to step it up a bit. nuff said.
author: rachel p.

description:
If Perbacco could accentuate the wonderful dinner menu- it certainly can accomplish this through its extensive wine selection.  It is without a doubt why people come here- it is  to taste what is Italy- through its wine, food and service.

My friend and I decided to meet here for dinner- it was both our first time to dine here and was very much looking forward to celebrating a recent promotion!
For starter:
Tasting of Salame- Nostrano, Finocchiona, Finocchiona picante and sangunato. This was a wonderful selection of the finest salami I have ever tasted.  The Nostrano was tender and sweet dotted with peppercorns, the finocchiona (cinta senese) was rich and seasoned with fennel- accompanied with the spicy version for contrast.  The sanguinato "blood sausage" was suprisingly delicious- a tarty sweetness but not too rich.
The Fritto Misto- was crispy and light- the rock shrimp was fresh with the  addition of  green beans, olives, fennel and lemon rings -all suited the aioli lemon dipping sauce.
My friend ordered the Beef Short Rib Stracotto- an italian version of pot roast- deliciously flavored with carrots, peas and gremolata.
The Braised Lamb Shank was the best I've had in a while, it was stewed to perfection- meat almost falling off the bones- the reduced stew sauce was impeccably rich and bold- I highly recommend it!
None of this could not have been more accentuated  by the Avignonesi 50 & 50 Capannelle, 2000 Tuscan wine- rich tannins- fresh tartiness that when allowed to breathe revealed its layers of complexity.  From appetizers- they were lush plums, cherries, and chocolate.  By the main dish- they were ripening raisins, prunes and light tabacco...ahhhh wines do breathe :-) 
I really liked the modern feel to this place, the dusk lighting and Cezanne-esque Italian countryside paintings were nostalgically entertaining, the staff all uniformed in crisp white shirts- not only conveyed tidiness but knowledge and courteousness.

PS- Making Perbacco your next lunch/dinner venue will certainly accentuate a positive outlook in your life!  Si- La Dolce Vita!
author: Arissa C.

description: Attentive service, sexy clean atmosphere, flawless dishes.  Everything we had here was spectacular, and the prices were fair for the quality and presentation.  A great uncrowded alternative to Delfina, although not for long once this place catches on.  I cant wait to come back!  Try the Pork Shoulder, and the grilled calamari appetizer (the best I've ever had)...its fantastic!  GREAT place to impress a date.  The bar up front is also wonderful for a nice drink after work!
author: Cathleya G.

description:
I have the most awesome friends. 
I know you think yours are the most awesome but you are wrong, unless you have exactly the same friends as I do but if that is the case then stop trying to steal my life you freak. 
My most awesome friends all contributed to a great birthday yesterday, except for you, you know who you are, which culminated in the Roman Orgy feast at Perbacco. 
Oh that's not what it's called? Because it reminded me so much of something I saw on the Discovery channel on the decadence of ancient Rome it was uncanny. Well no vomitorium or slaves that I saw but otherwise it was dead on. 
So yes my party of morally bankrupt Roman senators and I dined on the Salumi misti, which lived up to the hype, 5 hour pork ragu on taglitelli, also quite tasty and some great entrees. The most outstanding of the entrees in my opinion were the Tuna and the Pork Shoulder. Both completely spectacular. I had the Salsiccia and it was fucking great, the only thing that I didn't like was that the Cipollini onions were served cold but that's ok. I fucking love sausage and this was damn fine. The wine was flowing and fantastic. 
I have to say the service was good, not great but good. The busser stacked up all of our dirty plates and silverware until he could take everything at once which I really hate. It's so obtrusive but I forgive him.
Desserts and cheeses were right on. I fucking love cheese and they have many choices all runny and stinky on a big board in the middle of the room! Hell yeah I wanted to sit at the board with a box of crackers and just scoop at things.
So great birthday, good job Perbacco, Great job friends especially you Thadd L, you're better than Zoloft.
author: Melissa H.

description: I had to remove my last review because the owner called to apologize and offered us to come back for a free dinner after they had forgotten our food for an hour until we got up to leave. But you know what, why the hell would I go back? The service was so lousy and we sat behind this ridiculous pillar, hiding us from the servers and of course they really forgot us. This place is nothing but hype. Even if the food is good, poor service (in this case, no service) beats it out.
author: rosanna m.

description: We went here before we headed over to Cirque du Soleil at AT&T Park and what a fabulous restaurant this is.  Friendly staff greeted us and then showed us to our table upstairs, which was a great atmosphere!  Some of us started with their butternut squash soup and it was to die for.  Then had a variety of pasta, scallop and prawn dishes and all were yummy!  Wine selection was top notch and service was wonderful :-)  You're definitely in for a treat if you visit this financial district gem...
author: M S.

description:
Perhaps my expectations ran high, mostly based on the fact that I was taking my mum here for her big birthday dinner. Oh how wrong this place was, at least on this night. This was shortly before Christmas, and I had reserved a table upstairs both through Opentable and talking to one of the managers.
Low and behold when we get there, the table was still not available, and I wasn't having that for my mom. The manager said he would do the best he could to secure the table as the occupants had been there a long time. Personally, I didn't felt his bedside manner was lacking for some reason. So we decided to wait an extra half hour or so for the booth. In the meantime, we ordered drinks. Now, a smart person who full well knows this is a special night for new clientele would comp the drinks straight out and say so. But the whole time we were drinking, I was not sure if that gesture was even thought of. Not until the end of the night did I find out that my cocktail was taken off the bill but not the wine. I'm not even sure why that was.
Anyhow, on to the food. Also all around disappointing. Both our dishes, the ribs and seared tuna, both came to the table lukewarm at best. In her words, Mom has had better ribs at Jardiniere and Ad Hoc. My tuna was seared almost all the way through, which is a big no no. If I want to have Star of the Sea tuna served on a fancy plate, I can go to Safeway anytime.
The one upside of this whole affair was that one of the staff was very kind in trying to make us feel comfortable, so much so, he even took a little break to sit with us. He sympathized with the wait time and even said we should have had the booth behind us, which overlooked the kitchen through frosted glass. He was very concerned when we came down from the meal in less than an hour without even trying dessert. It's too bad restaurants cannot survive on goodwill alone.
author: Kevin A.

description: I enjoyed this experience. The food was great (I had the halibut for dinner, fried rock shrimp for appetizer) and the service was excellent. The waitress was enthusiastic, knowledgeable (she broke down the history of the food/restaurant themes) and attentive. The bartender made some great wine recommendations and even brought out a few options for us to taste. The ambiance was warm, elegant and inviting, with a comfortable buzz . . . I could hear my friends even though the place was fairly packed. Good dining experience .  . . I am looking forward to going back and trying more of what looked like amazing menu options . . . it all looked so good it was hard to decide. I highly recommend.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: My boyfriend and I went last night for the first time. We both have been wanting to try it for some time. I heard it was the number one hard to get a table anytime kind of place in SF. Fortunately, last minute got a table for 2 on a Friday night. The atmosphere and decor of the restaurant was great. It is very San Francisco...exposed brick, big bar..lots of wood. I really liked it. The food was standard. Italian salumi, raviolis. Awesome breadsticks. I don't understand the whole raw fish sashimi bar. Random. The server was defininitly preoccuppied. She took forever with any requests we made. I woud go back though...
author: Fallon F.

description: A very nice place to enjoy tasty Italian food.
author: Tom F.

description:
We were coming up to SF to see Wicked and decided to hit up Perbacco for dinner before. 

WOW.

Although I was totally underwhelmed by their breadsticks and herb oil that comes out with the menu, the rest of our food was DELICIOUS! 

I would say that the service was 5+ stars...best I've ever had.

The food only gets 4 stars, but still excellent. I ordered the highly recommended Sea Bass. It was great. Perfectly cooked with a gorgeous and light warm salad of fennel and citrus under it. My husband had the herb gnocchi with mushrooms. YUMMMMMM. I have decided that I'll get the pasta when we come back. The couples sitting around us had pasta and it looked fantastic.

The portions were perfect. We also ordered the pistachio cake for dessert and it was by far the highlight of the meal. PERFECT!!!! I strongly recommend saving room for this.
author: Marisa M.

description:
One of the best dining experiences in FiDi. Been here on a couple occasions for business meals. The Events Manager was great to work with and very accomodating. They had an HVAC delivery which snagged our original plans to accommodate our large party of 20 all in one table in their private dining room upstairs. She made sure to call me ahead of time (2 days in advance) to talk about seating charts and options. She ended up seating all of us in another private dining room upstairs overlooking the kitchen. Loved the glass window that allowed us to see the chef and cooks at work. We had 3-4 options for a prix fixe menu that our clients were able to choose from. The meatball was delicious.

Food was amazing, server was attentive, overall, a great dining experience. Will do business with them again.
author: L. N.

description: LOVE, love, love Perbacco!!!  Beautiful, fresh food, great service, easy to get to location.  Going for the third time next week, can't wait!!
author: Kiki R.

description: This place was really good!  The cured meats were excellent.  I had the strawberry salad and it was very tasty and unique; very fresh.  For my entree I had the tarajun (sp? forgetting exactly the name) which was a pasta with thin noodles.. also did not disappoint.  I would go back here again.
author: Anna L.

description:
aqua vs. perbacco ... 

perbacco vs. aqua ... 

decisions ...

PERBACCO!

***

this place is SOOO* me ... 

if you don't know me, and want to get to "know me" go to perbacco and see for yourself ... you walk in, and it should give you that "JEN IMPRESSION" meaning, this place suits me well ... from the minute you walk in, to the second you step out ... the brick walls, the place mats, everything.. it was perfect until you step beyond the kitchen area where it gets a bit busy busy ..

this is THEE perfect place for anyone! meetings w/clients, boss, friends, whoever. with a prime location in the FiDi, i think it serves itself well ... 

service: above and beyond ... super attentive, friendly, awesome!

food: it HAS A LOT of potential ... for an awesome place like this, they need a better chef IMHO... i think it was more of a cheapy ordeal ...sry perbacco ... 

i had the polpette and veal meatballs $17 w/peppers and unfortunately, the picture came out fuzzy that i didnt upload the picture, but that was more on the sweeter end, especially since emmy's (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg&q=emmys) spoiled me BIG TIME... size was nice, but you want that juicy italiano flavor you gots to be at emmys FO SHEEZ.  the tajarin $16 super cheapy pasta was probably my fave of the two, the noodle kinda tasted like those cup noodles (sry, but it's true), and the red and white roasted beets salad for $9 was good ... 

but i was fairly impressed with the service and the ambiance ... i definitely will be back ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: The bar was nice, and the service was good, better than good (warm, normal, pleasant and helpful but not intrusive).  We also had a delicious obscure (to me) Italian wine from Puglia.  But the space was disjointed, with bad feng shui, and the food was unremarkable.  We tried at least 9 things collectively, including what the waiter recommended.  All pedestrian.  It's too bad:  I never get my act together in advance enough to get reservations at Delfina, and I wanted to like it.  I would never go back.
author: Laurel B.

description: Took my girlfriend here for her birthday, and she took me for mine! Out of the hundreds of restaurants we have been to over the years, Perbacco is one of our favorites. The food is great, the servers are friendly. The Ugly But Good cookies are a great light way to finish off a wonderful meal.
author: Rob C.

description: Another boring, bland Italian place for all the suits in the financial district.  What's so great about this place that they've landed on opentable's top 10?
author: Amber L.

description: The lady and I came here to celebrate her recent raise.  All and all - Perbacco receives very high marks from both of us.  Easily the best duck I've ever had anywhere - and I like duck quite a bit.  Of equal note, the pistachio cake is fantastic.  When it arrived I think we both were initially disappointed: it looks like a well-plated muffin or cupcake.  It didn't take long for us to realize just how deceptive appearances can be.  Again, if you decide to make check this place out - you'd be crazy not to save room for the cake!
author: Matthew H.

description:
This perennial Open Table hotspot is one of the powerful trio of restaurants (including Aqua and Tadich Grill) on the strip of California St. between Front and Battery.  Perbacco in Italian means "by Bacchus," the Roman god of wine (and debauchery) - love the name.  With all this going for it, and the strong word of mouth, my expectations were high coming in.

Food:  2 stars.  Appetizers and pastas definitely outperform the disappointing entrees here.  Also, Michael Bauer loves the breadsticks, but there's nothing special about them.  We took the server's recommendation and tried the salumi misti (chef's selection), and were immediately wowed.  I usually don't care too much for salumi, but Perbacco's exceeded my expectations.
