Especially good were the sanguinato (blood sausage), mortadella and ciccioli (shredded pork pate).  Skip the pickled watermelon rind included with the salumi, it's pretty nasty.  I was equally impressed with the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted veal and cabbage.  The agnolotti is very similar to tortellini or ravioli.  We also tried the burrata cheese, which didn't have as creamy of an interior as I expected, and the tajarin (tagliatelle with pork sugo), which had a good texture but was a little bland.  Given the server's awesome picks on the first set of courses (he didn't recommend the burrata cheese or tajarin), we decided to go with his picks for the main courses (duck breast, ribeye steak, and devil's gulch rabbit).  While the rabbit and duck breast were not spectacular by any means, I would rather have those entrees than the charred ribeye I received.  All I tasted was ash.  Dessert (fig leaf panna cotta) was decent, but not memorable.

Service:  3 stars.  Service was smooth, attentive, and extremely friendly....but I took my server's recommendation and had an ashtray for my main course, which is unforgivable.

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  There is a lot going on in this restaurant from a design point of view.  The design is quirky yet modern and sleek.  It's definitely a vast improvement over the Gold Coast (not to be confused with the Gold Club), which previously occupied this space.  Extra points for the wall mirrors perfectly angled for people-watching (and my, do the people look good).

Hits:   Salumi, agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vittelone and savoy cabbage.

Misses:  Grilled dry aged ribeye steak, extra-charred.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Delfina, Oliveto, Acquerello, Incanto
author: Keith C.

description: this place is quickly making its way higher on my list of fancy lunch time eats in the FiDi.  I took myself here the day after xmas to make for eating my xmas dinner at Jack n the Box on the way home from Tahoe.  I sat at the bar and was treated well as soon as I walked through the door.  I started off with the Bartlet pear and gorgonzola salad.  It was the perfect marriage of light flavors to awaken my palate for my main course, the Risotto.  I don't think I have ever ordered a Risotto before.  The only reason I did this particular time was because it had seared shrimp on top and was finished with a Meyer lemon oil drizzle.  I had people around me asking what it was and I was making it a heavy recommendation as well.  I've been back once since and it continues to dazzle.
author: Chard M.

description:
too soon, somebody else will have to pay ... never got past the flight of wine, disappointing ... service very disappointing ... place the blame on the general manager .... who else ... funny thing, i care about this business and in this case, i dont care!

welcome to my world: professional cook and wine steward, who gives a damn!

caveat - beautifully created space for dinning ...
author: tim y.

description: This place was a real dissapointment. I went it in hoping to really enjoy it but left very upset. The service was terrible. Our waiter was not very helpful and kept walking by our table serveral times before even acknowledging us. We ordered some cocktails which actually came out AFTER our appetizers. The waiter never checked up on us besides the times he brought out our drinks, appetizers, and entree. Although the food was good, the overall experience was a real disappointment. Maybe it was because I didn't look like the usual clientele but it was rude nonetheless. I was tempted to go to this new restaurant due to all the "hype" but I guess thats all it really was.
author: Steven H.

description:
Before today, I'd been to Perbacco once for a couple rounds of drinks with a co-worker.  So at that point I didn't really feel educated enough on this establishment to publish a review (even though my experience there was fantastic).  But today I came here for lunch, so I am now well versed enough with Perbacco to give a well-rounded review.  I'd like to preface this by saying that my 3-course lunches during the week are few and far between, so anytime that situation comes up is a treat, but my experience today surpassed any expectations in my mind.  
We had a 1:30 reservation and were seated promptly after our arrival.  Our server was very attentive and gave us great suggestions when we were stuck deciding between menu items.  Everything sounded great, but we ended up getting the burrata mozzarella and gnocchi appetizers.  I'm almost certain the gnocchi was mad in house - it was so moist and perfect and delicious.  For my entree I got the seared halibut with a tomato sauce and fingerling potatoes.  My coworker got the sole which looked incredibly delicious as well.  For dessert, I'm a sucker for chocolate cake, so I got that which included hazlenuts, whipped cream, and caramel sauce.  Impeccable.  I also tried my lunchmate's gelati (caramel, chocolate, and pistachio) and, once again, delizioso!  Another thing I'd like to mention is that the space is really cool, there's an open kitchen at the back end of the restaurant, and as we were escorted to our table there was a table adorned with a beautiful spread of cheeses which completely whetted my appetite!  Overall great experience, highly recommended, and I hope to go back again soon!
author: Michelle L.

description:
mindblowing delicious food. 

just read Linda L.'s yelp for deets. i'm far too lazy to write and/or be "creative" aobut my enjoyable time at perbacco. 

after casting one cursory glance at the menu on their website, i knew i had to try this place, and let me tell you - i was not disappointed (except for the incongruous second floor decor - where are we? olive garden?!). 

went there for lunch, and it got bumpin' in no time. fabulous meal, shockingly good. any place that understands and values the beauty of celeriac is good in my book. everyone's entrees were incredible. and yes, the breadsticks are ALL that. probably the best beet salad i ever had, topped with this pungent, crumbly, intense cheese - castelmango. 

i bet their mozzarella di bufala is insane.
and check out the salumi selection - what would paul bertolli think?

in regards to the decor: yes, yes, it's all sleek, sex, and contemporary - i'm sure it enables the clueless financial district business power-trippers to feel good about themselves...it's pretty, but almost in an offputting sense. however, i won't complain b/c the food is wonderful. if a restaurant can pull off both looks AND substance, more power to it. 

wonder how long this huge enterprise can hold on to their mojo - serving lunch AND dinner to voracious crowds is a consuming undertaking.
author: jennifer y.

description: Great experience every time we go.   Exquisite food, lively atmosphere with lots of energy and expedient service.   We stopped in last night for a quick bite before seeing a movie at the Embarcadero on a Friday night at prime time.   Barbacco was booked solid but there were seats at the Perbacco bar.    Within minutes of ordering, our tuna crudo arrived and our pastas soon after.   Ah, the memory.   Short rib filled perfectly cooked pasta and a glass of pinot noir.   We were in and out of there in 30 minutes with time to leisurely walk to our movie.   Highly recommend the restaurant to those in the City as well as those coming up for a solid dining experience.
author: Roger B.

description: This place is pretty amazing.  The food is so good, and the waiters are top notch!  And for me and my husband who don't mind spending a lot of money for good food and service, the value was incredible.  We both got drinks, appetizers and entrees, and the total was less than $100!  We couldn't believe it!  We'll recommend it to all of our friends who are in SF.  We'll be back for sure!
author: think h.

description: My friend took me to Perbacco after having been working out of state for two years. The waitstaff was very knowledgeable and friendly. The entrees were good and the desserts were fantastic. I have to go back again for a more in-depth and fair review; however, I can say that on first impressions, Perbacco did very well. We developed a very good rapport with our waiter, and he found out that I'd just returned back to California. So, to my surprise, he had the kitchen prepare a special dessert (on top of the two desserts we ordered) that came with a special, personalized message.
author: May C.

description: Definitely a refreshing touch to the financial district . Somehow I struggle to find an Italian place with the hip modern atmosphere in San Francisco., and this place definitely hit the spot  The experience was somewhat New York - like, with the oversized dining room and exposed brick.  The food is a wonderful mix of fresh raw fish and classic Italian.  The service was amazing, with the staff ready with useful recommendations and always present, but not hovering.  The wine director is quite charming and very helpful without being even slightly snobby.  Altogether, the experience was wonderful.  And the meyer lemon semifreddo will ensure I'll be back soon.
author: Nellie L.

description: Here's the thing. Every time I pay a lot of money for Italian food I go home thinking, "Why did I just shell out so much cash to eat pasta and bread?"  That said, Perbacco has stellar service, nice wine and an old San Francisco ambiance that I appreciate. Our server was a beautiful Italian woman who was so warm and gracious and wonderful I wanted to put her in my pocket and make her my Italian pocket friend for life! I ordered the fritto misto (great, not greasy) the strawberry arugula salad (good, but the strawberries were syrupy) and the gnocci with pesto (light and pillowy!). Everything was good but nothing was memorable to me. At the end of the day Italian food is always good and hearty and filling but I always feel ripped off when I pay a lot for it.
author: Shira G.

description: Perbacco is a very well presented Italian Restaurant.  They have home made pasta's, great service and a lively atmosphere.  However, I feel like the hype is Perbacco's problem.  I always hear such good things about Perbacco and when I go there I feel the dishes are good, service is good, but nothing is great.  Not cheap for lunch, more reasonable for dinner but overall I would not go on a regular basis.  Perbacco does however, show you how powerful connections and word of mouth are because they are full all the time!
author: Cory C.

description:
Le sigh. I've been awaiting a feast of Italian savories at the raved about Perbacco since it opened. Delfina is one of my favorite restos and I loved my Xmas overindulgence at A16. The dishes I tried at Perbacco were mostly good but the service approached awful.
We waited for 15 minutes at the bar for our 830 res; the place was absolutely full. Drinks at the bar were crisp; I had a greyhound for an extra dose of vitamin c during cold season. At the bar, you get to watch the crudo and salumi stations prepare their platters. 

We were seated downstairs in the low ceilinged nook that housed the kitchen at the Gold Coast. They've done a lot with the space, conversations were held at normal levels despite the crowd. As our entire table wanted to try as many items as possible, we opted for the small ($18) salumi misto. Our waitress pushed us to order the large ($30) but we were also ordering a crudo, 2 salads, and entrees, which sounded like a lot of food. The small platter ended up being more than sufficient with about 3 pieces each of prosciutto, mortadella, a few salumi, and a pork pate. Although I'm a sucker for cured meats and will go to extreme lengths for crocks of pate, nothing on the plate was craveworthy. Everything was good, but it lacked sparkle. 

Service issues became apparent as the crudo, radicchio salad, and pear, gorgonzola, and endive salad arrived. Our food runner would silently drop plates onto the crowded table with a complete lack of finesse. We were left holding plates and moving glasses out of the way as we waited for our waitress to return for the used items. It was definitely awkward, and there was no coordination between the bussers, food runners, waitress, etc. 

The crudo was very fresh and the portion was quite large especially compared to the tiny portion at the Slanted Door. The kitchen nicely split the basic radicchio salad with creamy garlic dressing. During the chaos of the starters our wine, a Piedmontese Roero Arneis, arrived. Interestingly, they pour the wine for you and whisk it away to a table at the center of the room. While this is usually fine with me, there was confusion throughout the night if our bottle had been finished or was merely hiding. A major complaint of mine was the wine service. For a 4-top eating a multi-course meal, they completely dropped the ball on our booze. We had friends from out of town visiting and it was impossible to get a second bottle despite trying to flag down our waitress, asking our food runner, and asking some other guy for it. I was shocked at how difficult it was to order the second bottle. By the time our waitress returned, half of our entrees had been eaten and some of our guests thought it was too late for another bottle. The manfriend and I ordered another 1/2 liter, but this aspect of the meal really bothered me. I like my beverages! 

After another round of musical plates when the entrees arrived, I was finally able to tuck into the lauded agnolotti dal plin, little pockets filled with a mlange of veal, sausage, and vegetables. It seems everywhere I turn these days, this newly chic pasta shape is receiving heaps of praise from food mags, bloggers, and critics.I liked it, but it did not illicit the same toe-curling need to lick my plate as the chicken and foie gras ravioli at Delfina or even the need to order another serving immediately afterward like the crab and toasty breadcrumb pasta at A16. The filling was balanced and savory, and I enjoyed the sheer wisps of savoy cabbage in the pool of browned roasted meat juices that coated the pasta. However, I expected thinner wrappers to ensure a maximum filling to noodle ratio.

I anticipated more from the Berkshire pork shoulder al latte. I cook a lot of pork roasts, carnitas, and other succulent cuts at home. I turned to the manfriend for his reaction, it was "yeah, it's okay." Some bites were on the dry side which is really odd for such a fatty cut that had been braised. He later reported that some bites were quite good, but it's pork shoulder, come on! The rest of the table was happy with their gorgonzola and nettle gnocchi and tuna mains. 

No space for dessert after all that. We asked the waitress to put $100 on the card and gave her $140 cash; equaling the total plus exactly 20% for tip despite the service issues. I did not take up any of the issues with the manager and give them a chance to correct them. It was so hard to get a 2nd bottle of wine and I had guests with me, so I thought it would be a big scene. When entertaining, you want things to go as smoothly as possible. Instead, what we got back was the full bill ($200) on the card and $140 cash had been taken for a tip. A 70% tip! WTF? No way, not after the wine debacle. We eventually got the bill corrected but she acted like it was someone else's fault. I'm not sure who would make that sort of mistake, as a 70% tip is unusual. Service issues bumped a 4 or 4.5 star meal was bumped down to a 3 star experience.
author: Candice L.

description: The place is modern and comfortable...casual classy and delicious creative food indeed!
author: cecille p.

description: Pretty lame service, hair in food food itself good not great, hard to imagine this being a special place, but probably good for a drinking group
author: Peter F.

description: The food was great, the service friendly and I could actually have a conversation, which I really appreciated.
author: Keley P.

description:
Who should eat here:  Looking for a great Italian place in the financial district?  Definitely look up Perbacco.  Especially good for a business lunch/dinner, given the crowd, but don't let this turn you off, the food makes it worth a visit.  

1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better

Atmosphere/Ambiance: 3.5 stars.  The feel at Perbacco is on the serious side given its location in the financial district.  Think Aqua, One Market, Boulevard, but just a tad more causal.  The place is general bustling with the typical downtown business crowd.  They have a nice bar, where you can grab a drink and apps before sitting down for dinner.  The dinning room is a little bland, and can get a little bit noisy.  Its fun though and would work perfect for a meal with a friend/friends or business acquaintances.

Service: 3.5 stars.  I found our service to be better than adequate.  Our waitress was nice and accommodating.  The timing of the food was perfect and I really have nothing to complain about here.  However, one thing to remember, is that there is little intimacy and the service is more on the serious side given the clientele.  Don't take this the wrong way, they are not rude in any way.   Additionally, when we were there (Thurs night) it was very busy, so our waitress only made a couple of stops by the table.  Overall though, I was totally satisfied with the service, but it wasn't anything to rave about.

Food: 4 stars.  I have heard some very mixed things from friends on Perbacco, but I have to say everything we ordered was very good.  We started with a Salame plate that had four different preparations.  There was a blood salame, a fennel salame, and two others that I forget.  I liked all four and I thought the portion side was more than generous.  Next we moved into some apps: the steak tartar and the bresaola.  The tartar left something to be desired.  It was good, but not really all that special, and I have had much better tartar, so I would look to the bresaola if you want a meat as an app.  For those of you that have never tried Bresaola give it a whirl, it is basically air dried salted steak.  Yum.  It was thin as paper, but had amazing freshness and very concentrated meat flavors.  For entrees we ordered the Pappardelle with braised short rib ragu and the duck breast.  The pasta was delicious, made fresh and cooked perfectly.  The short rib ragu was a very nice touch adding a nice richness to the pasta without making it over the top.  The duck was also good, and I think some of best duck I have had in the city recently.  It was a breast, but came whole rather than the thinly sliced preparation you normally receive.  I felt this locked in the flavors better and created more rich earthy flavors that speak more to the heart of the food.  Very tasty and highly recommended.  Finally for desert we had a trio of gelatos.  All were really good, there was a chocolate flavor, a hazelnut and a pistachio.  Nothing special, but all really good, and a nice refreshing end to the meal.

Wine: 4 stars.  Perbacco has a really solid list, specializing in Italian varietals.  Most of the regions (not just the popular ones) are represented in both whites and reds.  This is great for experimenting with some of the rarer Italian wines.  We ordered a bottle of the Paolo Scavino Barbera d Alba.  For $42 you can't go wrong.  This is one of the best producers in Piedmont, and for those that don't want to drop $150 on one of his Barolos this is a fantastic option.  Next we dipped into a 1997 Tignanello (which I brought).  The Som waived our corkage since I bought a bottle, which I thought was pretty cool.  As far as the wine goes, though, I would first choose what you want to eat and then ask them to suggest some wine options.  Ask for something out of the ordinary, there are some really fun things on the list.  Bravo!

Overall: 4 stars.  I was impressed all around with Perbacco.  Definitely not a great date place or a place for a romantic dinner, but a really well done Italian restaurant with a good up beat crowd.  A must try in the financial district.
author: Scott P.

description: Mmmmm.......so unexpectedly delicious!  My favorite part about being a summer associate was going out to lunch almost every single day on the law firm.  I had the pleasure of going to every single upscale restaurant in the FiDi (might explain my expanded waistline) - and this was by far one of my favorites.  I had the strawberry and goat cheese salad, the pappardelle with short rib ragu, and the burnt caramel gelato with sea salt.  Everything was absolutely fantastic.  In fact, I went back the very next day with my mom.  I would definitely recommend this place for a date, could be tres romantic.   ps the elder flower lemonade is amazing!!
author: Liz C.

description:
My search for the perfect gnocchi dish has ended.  Yummy, delicious, fluffy ricotta heaven smothered in wild mushrooms. 5 stars.

The salumi platter is excellent too.  I went for lunch and they were able to accommodate my request for a half portion since my husband doesn't eat pork and I wouldn't be able to eat the whole thing PLUS an entree.  5 stars.

Service was excellent and our waiter deserved 5 stars.

Minus 1 star for:
1. It's LOUD downstairs - so next time I'll request a table upstairs
2. Even though I had reservations, it took 15 minutes for them to prep my table.
3. Breadsticks are just OK and the foccaccia was too greasy.  If you're gonna serve me bread w/butter, I'll take an Acme Epi over that greasy stuff any day.

Next time I'll go for dinner, try one of their cheese flights for dessert, and order the rosemary cocktail.
author: Dorene K.

description: this place is very good but not great... safe spot for a work lunch but i am really surprised at the high ratings.  this place is 60% as good as acquarello and delfina
author: nick g.

description:
2nd time dining at Perbacco..
this was my second time dining at Perbacco, the first time for lunch this time for dinner. We sat in the dining room in the back to the right, my least favorite part of the restaurant, the ceiling is low and it was about 85 degrees in there. Way too hot to be enjoyable. 
Our server, slow to greeting us almost like we had been forgotten. She looked a little rough, like she had jsut gotten dressed and dragged herself to work, a little fluff of the hair and cold water on the face would've been nice. So not the most attentive server, she seemed like she may have been on a cigarette break for mst of the evening. 
The food:
we started with the salumi platter it was delicious, loved all the cured in house meat selection. we also had the hamachi fennel crudo. it had a such potential but fell short with the large amount of sea salt on top, whaaaa mouth full of saltiness, and the pool of olive oil on the plate was over kill. Next the raddichio salad, the two types of raddichio nice but alas one was extremely bitter and the parmesan and croutins couldn't cut through that.
For pasta we shared the angiotti pasta first filled with veal sugo and nettle ricotta gnochi, both fantastic flavors, the gnochi was wonderful melted in your mouth, one drawback to both the dishes were they were barely luke warm, chilled almost. Had our server been around and not on her break i would have sent it back. unfortunatey she never reappeared till we were almost finished. 
we also shared the braised short rib entree, it was also only luke warm but the parsnip puree i believe it was, maybe celery root, was steaming hot. The flavors were very nice.
For dessert we shared the pistachio panna cotta and the trio of gelatos. the pistachio panna cotta different to say the least, it took a second to want to try it, the color kind of scares you away, it looks like and experiment more than a dessert. it was a deep swamp green color, the flavor grew on me after a couple of bites and  i liked the compotes, blodd orange segments and kumquat compote.
the gelatos, great, but again there was this sea salt thing on the caramel flavor, slow down there big guy with all the extra salt. a small amount to compliment would've been just fine, why'd ya have to go overboard and overkill. Overall i would go back, the food has shown to be good and the pricing reasonable. Hopefully you don't get the haggard server.
author: amy T.

description:
A great way to spend Friday night dinner out with 4.  This was our first time to Perbacco and will not be the last.  The dining room is modern and you could carry on a conversation with your table, but there was a general buzz (i.e. not a quiet dinner spot)

We sat at the bar waiting for friends to show up.  It's always nice to have bartenders that give you a chance to taste before you decide on a wine.  Also, watching them slice up their house cured meats made that a must try for dinner.

Dinner started with the Salumi Misti (house selection of cured meats) which also came with a great country style pate.

We then proceeded to split 4 appetizers:  I would definitely recommend the veal and tuna sauce (delicious, must try traditional dish).  The sardine dish we ordered was good, but a fairly small portion relative to the other dishes.

We actually decided not to have a main, instead splitting 3 pastas to save room for dessert.  The Tarjin (hand cut tagliatelle which is like a flat spaghetti) and papardelle were delicious.  

There was not a dish that we did not like.  One of the better restaurants we have tried recently and a two thumbs up.  I would be comfortable recommending this place to anyone.
author: George C.

description:
3.5 stars

Perbacco and I have a complex relationship. On one hand, it's ingredients are fresh and local and taste awesome. Some of the individual dishes I've had there are best in category (see short ribs below). Yet, I've felt at times like I'm intaking food from a rail gun (see salumi plate below), or there's just an item that's off...

Bread and butter:
- Bread: for a high-caliber Italian place, your bread is passable, but it's nothing to write home about. It's not very chewy and tastes a bit dry. I think the density is the main issue--there's to much air and too many air pockets that make the bread not enjoyable on its own. However, it does soak in sauces well, and most of your meat and pasta dishes have sauces that are simply divine. This bread + shortrib sauce + my mouth = happiness. 

- Butter: high-five for room temperature butter, but needs salt. 

Appetizers:

- SALUMI MISTI - I ordered a small, and this could feed 4 people. It was pleasant and a nice snack with bread, but nothing stood out as being terribly distinctive. One of the salumi items tasted like raw, ground meat, which was slightly off-putting. I don't know if the issue is even with the plate--Italian cured meats are categorically inferior to Spanish Jamón ibérico. (As a plug, the BEST cured meat I've ever had is the 5-yr old ham from Brindisa in Borough Market, London; pretty good manchego and membrillo too)

- Goose salad (ordered to-go) - 5-slices of goose breast over some arugula for $22? Are you kidding me? Say hello to my little friend, the log of dining disappointments

Mains:

- PAPPARDELLE (WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / ROASTED CIPOLLINE / GRATED HORSERADISH) - wow, this was a solid pasta dish with really fresh homemade pasta and awesome short ribs on the inside. The technique was flawless and the texture was al-dente chewy and gorgeously umami-rich and buttery. Would suggest putting a touch more salt in the sauce. Only note on presentation is that it was a little messy and felt more like a home-cooked meal (which I'll take any day over wow-factor presentation at the expense of flavor)

- BEEF SHORT RIB STRACOTTO (ROOT VEGETABLE PASSATINA / CAVOLO NERO / HONEY GLAZED CIPOLLINE AND CARROTS) - this baby came out and my jaw dropped. I was literally mid-conversation with the guy next to me at the bar, and I just stopped talking while my mouth went into epileptic shock. The smell envelops your head in a cloud of charred meat, tobacco and browned butter flavors. I talked to the bartender and he mentioned that the meat cooks for a 3 hours at 120 degrees, making the entire piece of Niman Ranch boneless short rib fall apart as soon as you touch it. Fat and meat juices were so well distributed throughout the short rib that I hesitated every time I touche it with a fork. I just wanted to admire this (large) piece of short rib perfection. The purple, white and orange carrots and other baby winter root vegetables elevated the plating to a stratospheric level. I'm not kidding when I say this is perfect plate of food. I could have this once a week for the rest of my life, and I would be a happy camper. I cannot emphasize enough how good this particular dish is--of all the deliciously memorable dishes I've had in my lifetime, this easily ranks in the top 10. 

Desserts:

- MEYER LEMON PANNA COTTA (HUCKLEBERRY COMPOTE / ROSEMARY SHORTBREAD) - technically perfect preparation of panna cotta, though I wasn't 100% set on the compote. The compote's texture was a bit too stiff for this dish and tended to stick to my fork as I ate the panna cotta. 

In short: check this place out. It's a fun place to go with friends, prices are reasonable for the quality of food and service. The selection of Italian wines is off the charts and the short rib dish is the best preparation of short rib I've ever had in my life. P.s. $20 corkage!
author: Alex W.

description: This place is alright... pretty fancy menu.  The dining area appeared to be a simulation of a below deck yacht cabin.  The meal started off with plus points for the red and golden beet salad.  I heart beets!  The meat sampler platter with the pate was also enjoyed by the entire table (minus the non-red-meat-atarian) -- and the prosciutto was sliced ever so thinly.  The little cornichon pickles on the side are rad... reminded me to pick up like 3 jars at Trader Joe's that I can put away in under a week.  The mortadella? Fuggeddabadde ... it was like butta.  For main course, I had the quail, which was two bites of tender juicy deliciousness.  The 3 gelato dessert was divine, though some of the cookies paired with the pistachio and dulce de leche were a bit stale.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
You know those things where you're literally the last person on earth to try it, but you're still so tempted to go there nonetheless cause of all the great 'hype' that's been building it up???.... well, tonight, I felt that Perbacco was THAT place.  We were taking some clients out and was able to manage a large table in the upper room... literally in the back cave.  Our party came sporadically (i.e. not on time) and so we sorta ordered bits and pieces here and there.  The coppa di testa (warm pig head terrine) was really good... and even some of the naysayers at the table gave it a nod of approval.   The other appetizers were just okay (the hamachi crudo, scallops, fritto misto and one other dish that didn't quite make it down to my end of the table)... ditto for the pasta.... tagliatelle with pork ragu, some ravioli dish were just 'Oh hum' at best.  Then my entree, the house made sausage, took the longest to prepare, yet once I took the first bite, the middle of it was cold... so I had to ask to reheat the thing.   Desserts were not spectactular, even borderline flat... we sampled five different dessert items and not one jumped out at you.  The ice cream sampler, the 'ugly' hazelnut cookies, the meyer lemon semifreddo... I've had better elsewhere.

And the wine list... it's a large selection and mainly all Italian varietals... there were some Napa selection... and the price was very reasonable all around.

I guess the thing is... Italian cuisine is readily available and there plenty of good Italian eateries in the city that it's hard to find a place that just blows everything else out of the water.  I felt like this with Perbacco.  The food is good, but I know I was just buying/being influenced more by the recent hype of this place vs. a hole-in-the-wall joint that focuses on the beauties of their food.

Would I go back to Perbacco?  Yes, but only after the hype has died down...
author: Dale K.

description: Started with cocktails and apps while we waited for our guest to arrive. The drinks and apps were tasty. The staff was very accomidating even though we were late.   We got  the chefs table that is raised next to the kitchen so we could see all the action and were treated to a great meal great service and a good time.
author: Zole A.

description:
After reading the the opening review my gf and I decided to try it.  We were a bit confused as citysearch had this restaurant listed as $$ (which it is), but it is definitely more upscale than similar restaurants in that price range (which is an absolute positive)

Our server was terrific.  Very knowledgable, taking time to explain the dish but didn't talk down to us.  Bus staff was incredibly professional as well (not coming by every 5 min to ask if you are done and waiting until both my gf and I were finished...I hate when people want to clear one dish while the other person is still eating)

Food was great.  We tried one of the white truffle dishes on a whim since we would never order this stuff (I think that is another compliment to our server).  I had the pear salad and the pork shoulder which was so moist it was incredible.

My gf ordered the sole and I have to admit this was a bit salty.

Desert was wonderful and their coffee (a place where most restaurants skimp) was incredible as well.

So, all in with wine and the truffles dinner was only $200.  That is a lot but you could easily get out of there around $100 and with the service like that it is an incredible deal.

Only other bad thing was restaurant was a bit loud.  I would recommend hanging some simple canvas frames along some of the walls.
author: Christopher C.

description:
It almost doesn't matter that the food was great because the service was fantastic.  It's a good place for birthdays.  I got a birthday card when I sat down; every waitress, sommelier, and hostess wished me a happy birthday.  They catered to my pickiness when it came to finding a great Pinot Noir.  I ordered a quail appetizer with cabbage and lightly friend mushrooms (delish but a little dry) and for an entree scallops with capers and raisins in a butter sauce (it aired on the side of undercooked and not too rich, both things I prefer).  The desert sealed the deal.  I ordered the espresso-mouse bar, and the waitress brought me a chocolate custard with 'happy birthday' written in chocolate sauce. The well-informed and kind waitress knew the custard to be my second choice; my mom and I both agreed it beat my mouse and her lemon panna cotta with fennel sorbet. My parents both ordered pasta dishes.  The pasta is amazing--homemade and fresh.  

The restaurant is on the louder side (but not too loud). I was happy to be sitting in the area with the high ceilings, as the low ceiling area seemed somewhat cramped.    

Overall, a stand up restaurant with good food, and good service.  I hear it's among the top 4 Italian restaurants in SF.
author: Margan M.

description: Really really great!  I was going to give it 4 stars, but then realized I couldn't think of a reason to do so, so 5 it gets.  Prices are totally reasonable for the quality of food and the service.  Great location too, stop in to Tadich next door for a cocktail, then head over.
author: Chase N.

description: What a treat! Just like what everyone else said. Expense lunch paid by my boss who knows what's up.
author: Kat H.

description:
Loved this place! The food and wine were delicious!

The Salumi Misti is a must, all the salamis were amazing as well as the salsiccia cruda di bra. My mouth is still watering over the Raviolo with truffled ricotta and spinach, this was amazing and I should have had more thinking about it. We ordered more dishes that were all great, but those two are the ones that are a must order. I highly recommend this place, it has a great atmosphere and the staff is very friendly and helpful.
author: Michelle D.

description:
I've been there many times, but this week's trip was a bit of a disappointment.  The short rib ragu was a little short on the ragu.  It wasn't bad, just rather ordinary.

The staff was attentive, the wine list massively wonderful and interesting, but the food was a notch below where they have been (and where they should be for the prices they charge).
author: Happy C.

description:
I've been to this place a couple of times and had to give this restaurant another shot. There were just too many things on the menu that I wanted to try again. Perbacco definitely has one of the best charcuterie platters that I've had in the city (even slightly better than Incanto, who make there own salumi). Get the chef's selection or assorted platter. They also have a mortadella or salumi one but if you get the selection, you get a little bit of everything. They have loads of appetizers but you can't leave without trying some of their handmade pastas. They offer most of them in small or large plates if you just want to have a taste. The papardelle and tagliatelle with pork sugo or short rib ragu were the best things on the menu! The pork shoulder and short rib entrees are the highlights of the main courses. I've gotten both and wasn't that impressed with the pork shoulder. Although they say it is slow braised, it's not as tender as you'd expect. The short rib is sooo delicious though! Juicy, tender, and so flavorful. It comes with a celery root puree that you can sop up all the beef juices with.

Wine list is also fairly extensive and reasonable. Check with the sommelier though...not all the waiters appear to be too knowledgeable. The ambience of this place is great. It's got a rustic yet modern feel to it and filled with great energy. There is a long bar area in the front with some booths for casual dining, along with the full dining area in the back. This place is usually packed by 7 on any night so book ahead!
author: Josephine H.

description:
I went here with clients yesterday, and it surely impressed.  Rather than a light lunch, we all ordered 3 courses.  My appetizer was some kind of soft, sweet, mild, creamy cheese with black truffle "salsa" served with toasted bread  and arugula.  It was the perfect palate whetter.  Made me wonder what else was in store.  My main course was a ricotta-gnocci with some kind of asparagus sauce.  It was very simple, a beautiful color, and delicious.  To top off the meal I had the most exciting dessert--get this--polenta cake with olive oil gelato.  To finish off the plate, olive oil was drizzled around the plate along with a bright red rhubarb sauce.  It looked so much like tomato sauce that I was dying of curiosity about how it would taste.  I was very surprised at how well the flavors blended together in my mouth.  I can't stop thinking about my meal there and I can't wait to return!  I also swiped a spoonful of my colleague's apple/pear bread pudding, and it too was scrumptious.

Update after more than a year and countless meals at Perbacco (today is 7/24/08):

I recently had a watermelon salad with honey-olive vinegrette and marcona almonds and it was so refreshing!  The menu is constantly evolving, so every time I eat at Perbacco I get to try something new and yet just as wonderful as the last visit!  HOW DO THEY DO IT?!

1)  I brought some friends here.  They LOVED it.
2)  I brought some other clients here.  They LOVED it.
3)  I suggested Perbacco to my company's Chief Operating Officer.  She LOVED it.
author: Kandi K.

description:
the dining experience was above average and i would probably come back again. the service was very attentive and at no time did i ever have to look around to ask for something, unlike other restaurants.

we started off with the salumi misti and the meats were good, but nothing to rave about. the pate was probably my favorite. me and my girlfriend were finishing up the plate, but it seemed like the waitress was subtlety hovering over to say that our pasta was ready. i don't fault her, but i would have liked a few more minutes before getting our meals.

i ordered the tajarin and my girlfriend got the papparadelle (sp?) w/ short rib ragu. i particularly loved my tajarin. the noodles had good texture the the pork sugo was delicious. the portions were just right as i ate everything on my plate. as for the papparadelle, this was good too and the horseradish wasn't too over-powering. the noodles had good texture as well and the short rib was tender.

overall, a good meal. the only thing i couldn't justify was the price for this kind of meal, hence the 3 stars instead of 4.
author: Sam T.

description:
Amazing dinner ! We had no reservations on a recent night but they had an empty table for us when we came by at 8:45.
It was crowded but not too noisy. Very good service from the waitress.
Hamachi appetizer, delicious. 2 course pasta sampler for the table was out of this world,such wonderful homemade pasta(agnolotti with veal and chard and gnocchi with chanterelles and leeks -melt in your mouth....). We were almost full then but had  ordered a main course to share: John Dory with chanterelles and root vegetables and a side of brussels sprouts. Good,good,good ! Brussels sprouts c ame with parmesan cheese on top. Mine are really good but these were out of this world. No easy job !! ( Given what you get at most restaurants). John Dory was sauted to perfection.
We had a great wine: Renato Ratti, not too pricey. Had only room for the lightest dessert - the panna cotta -delightful.
What a great meal and unplanned !
author: Maria C.

description: Great spot right in the heart of the financial district.  The gnocchi was really tasty and the prosciutto platter we ordered was the perfect amount.  Great spot for a business lunch.  Oh and the drinks are delicious!
author: Danielle V.

description: Was talked back into coming with Brewgirl b and things were vastly improved.  To be honest, I had trouble believing it was the same restaurant.  Service was attentive and friendly, the food was amazing (love the porcini & peaches - sounds bizarre, but it was incredible.)  I'll be going back - of my own volition!
author: She-Ra ..

description:
I was expecting to be blown away by Perbacco. The week preceding my night out to dine here, I had about five friends tell me how incredible it was. My mother even called me the night of and when I told her I was going to Perbacco, I could practically see her eyes lighting up. "TELL ME HOW IT IS!!" she shouted (because isn't that what all parents do on the phone? Think it is necessary to escalate their voice?)

GOD, I thought. Perbacco must be the SHIT.

Okay. It was fine. It was nice. It was GOOD. Solid. Yummy. Insert more decent adjectives here.

Was I blown away? Nah. Have I had better food for the price we paid? For sure. 

I'm very happy I tried it, but perhaps I wouldn't have been (slightly) disappointed if everyone I know thinks this place is heaven.
author: Nicole R.

description: This place is totally bourgeois. Seriously good food, awesome service, and a price to reflect it. But, don't get me wrong. It's not outrageous price-wise, it's just worth every penny.
author: Tyler D.

description: Came here for dinner. Nice atmosphere, food was AMAzing. beef tartar- is deliscious (though i wouldnt recommend it to people with weak stomach). appetizer with burrata cheese was also outstanding. For entree we got seabass and the duck. Duck was just perfect, so, i would highly recommend it to everyone. For dessert we had "bonet", chocolate mousse. it was the best one i've ever tryed. I'd give it 5 stars, if they would have some music on (felt kinda lonely without it), and service would be little faster. But we will definately come back!
author: Alex F.

description: Very meh!  Cocktails were great.  Appetizers (frito misti and salumi plate) were okay but not worth the hype.  Entrees were tastings of the pesto, the sugo and an extra entree portion of the risotto.  Tastings were okay but the risotto tasted like it was made with two day old fish.  Gross.  Very meh altogether.
author: Susan A.

description:
Squid and arugula salad was waaay to salty.  Not sure why the craze about arugula but it didn't work with the dish.  
The duck ragu papardelle was ok.  The pasta didn't get enough flavor from the sauce but it was good quality home-made pasta.  The almost hard to find strings of duck meat had almost no flavor to them...  I think the only reason this place is popular is because of it's nice surrounding and it's proximity to offices providing a place for people who wants to do lunch meetings.
author: Adele W.

description: Just enjoyed a great lunch here. Between three of us we got to try a number of items. Nice salumi platter, lovely beet salad, but hands down the winner on the starters for me was the burrata cheese platter with truffle sauce - yum! I'd get this every time for sure. They also bring out bread sticks with a salsa verde sauce made from parsley that is nice and very different, and really yummy bread. I had the pappardelle pasta with short rib ragu which was very good but not the best pappardelle I've had in town (which would be Sociale for sure - still, this one tops Tablespoon's). They change the menu daily so I'd be interested in seeing what they have to offer next time. Good service and a nice environment - I'd go back, definitely.
author: Sarah R.

description: An excellent restaurant in the financial district.  We were a party of 4 and we each tasted each other's appetizer, pasta course, and main course.  They were each outstanding.  A nice space, but noisy.  Cheese course was great, but the rest of the dessert menu was a disappointment considering the quality of the rest of the meal.
author: Chris O.

description: went here again and can not complain about the wait. It's worth it! Such a good vibe and the food wow! great big delicious for the taste buds! Keep it real...
author: kit a.

description: Came here partially due to all the hype I've heard about this place and I wasn't disappointed. The service was great, the food was better than expected (honestly, i'm not that big of a fan of italian food), and with the wine flowing, all in all, you have the perfect friday evening!
author: Hoiling W.

description:
I came here for drinks and dinner last night with friend of mine. We had reservations at 8:45pm, but showed up slightly early to grab a drink at the bar. When we walked in, it was pretty crowded. Well, it was in the financial district and on a Friday night. After getting our drinks at the bar, we had a lil trouble finding a comfotable spot to stand since waiters/waitresses and customers were all around and walking back and forth. I guess that was one thing I didn't like about my experience here.
Anyways, about 20 mins later, we got seated. One interesting thing I noticed right away was the menu is dated and I'm sure everyday they have something different on the menu. That's pretty cool. I was looking at the wine list and had a few questions, so they sent over a "wine-expert" to answer my questions and he gave me a few wines to taste before ordering. The entree I ordered was the Sea Bass and my friend got the Rabbit.....yea i said Rabbit. I personally can never eat rabbit only cuz my cousins used to have 2 when I was younger and the thought of eating rabbit makes me think of their rabbits. Anyways, the Sea bass was yum!! It was very tender and juicy, if you like fish or even if you don't, I recommend ordering that or giving it a try. My friend really enjoyed his rabbit too. He said it tasted like juicy chicken breast. Sounds good, but still not for me. The waiters/waitresses are very nice and the whole ambiance of the restaurant was wonderful. Definitely try this place out when you get a chance!
author: Christina T.

description: Great location for public transportation, lot's of buzz throughout, full bar, great wine list, very nice ambiance, reasonable prices  and a fresh updated daily menu.  What is there not to like about this place?
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Excellent -- from start to finish.  It was our anniversary, and upon our arrival we were presented with a card personally signed by staff, and my request for a nice quiet table was met with perfection -- a corner booth so we could snuggle.  We let our waiter, Moe, know that we would be 'dining' and weren't in a hurry.  He matched our pace perfectly, checking back often to make sure all was A-OK.  Paced our courses to match our wine choices and all.  We started with hamachi crudo, on to grilled squid over cannellini bean puree -- both bit-perfect.  Onto spring fresh herbed goat cheese gnocchi -- some of the lightest I've had.  I finished with the grilled rib-eye with gorgonzola butter, and my wife had the salmon.  Both very good --- and then all topped off with a comped dessert.  As the governator says, "I'll be back".
author: Don N.

description:
This place is great for a bite to eat after work and delicious martinis.  They use these special olives that are specially brined so they maintain the natural flavor of olives with a little salt.  
I've eaten dinner here a few times and it is okay but definitely recommend it for an after-dinner snack and drinks.  The staff is also very friendly and helpful.
author: A J.

description: This place is a reminder that I need to spoil myself more often.  Excellent service along with two great entrees, the rabbit and though I liked her scallop dish more,  I can't forget about the appetizers; hamachi crudo and beet salad.  The entire evening was on point.  I didn't even have to squeal a word to the waitress that she will be having another gibson w/ two onions and an olive.  Technically I didn't spoil myself this time around, by the time I tried to hand my credit card to the waitress, she had already taken care of it, it's a women conspiracy I tell you, but thank you for dinner Hama.
author: Jona C.

description: I went in for lunch. I walk past this place every day and never noticed it until I had a lunch meeting there. So you can imagine my shock at finding this treasure that was right under my nose. The prices were in line with the cuisine. A slightly higher priced menu, but it is worth it if you want to kick it up a notch. The service was great! I had a chicken breast and salad, following by a hazel nut cake. Yummy! So I definitely give this place a stamp of approval.
author: Stafford J.

description: A rather ordinary, over-priced, albeit stylish restaurant, just another SF place with very little to remember other than NY prices, mediocre food, decent appetizers, but nothing to go crazy...the bar was ok, but had remnents of the usual potpurri of stuffy regulars, unhip tourists from Idaho who looked as if they just got out of an 'American Idol' audition. In other words, there's nothing outstanding here; employees nice, friendly hospitality, but I wanted/expected more.
author: Rich L.

description: Three words.....Mi piace davvero
author: Mick H.

description:
Best meal I have had in the 19 years I have lived in SF.

Better than Gary Danko.

Blown away by the originality, wine list, service and most importantly the food.  Lots of variety.
author: l p.

description: I went here for lunch with work colleagues a few weeks ago for the first time and was super happy with my meal.  The place is a lot bigger inside then it appears from California street.  I really enjoyed the meat and cheese platter they offer as an appetizer.  The mushroom gnocchi was very good and filling.
author: Amanda T.

description: Went here for lunch with a large group.  They sat us in a back room upstairs.  The menu had many enticing options.  I finally ordered truffled ricotta gnocchi.  Yummy.  I plan on going back for dinner.
author: Cotille D.

description:
old world italian dining with a california twist . warm service offsets the industrial atmosphere.  phenomenal wine list.
 ( must-try items: agnolotti and lamb ragu)
author: aj s.

description: Went here for lunch with a co-worker, and we both had a fabulous dinning experience.  The food, service, and atmosphere were all great.  The place is loud, but that's because it's a VERY popular restaurant, packed with people dinning...duh.  Even though it was very busy (tables being cleared and the next diners seated within minutes of the pervious patrons leaving,) our server took the time to answer our questions in an unhurried professional manner, and even let me try a wine or two he recommended to make sure it was what I wanted with my meal.  I had the veal appetizer, and the agnolotti filled rabbit, and both were delicious.  Nice to see another top notch restaurant in the financial district where you (or your boss) can treat yourself.
author: Sean M.

description:
Just had my birthday dinner at Perbacco and it was fantastic.  We had a 6:15 reservation but got there early due to the abundance of parking available in FiDi at that time.  Not having to circle block after block to find parking is always nice.

We were seated right and got water, bread sticks with salsa verde, butter and bread right away.  Michael, our FANTASTIC waiter, was available to answer any questions we had on the menu and provide some great suggestions on what to order.  He actually had suggestions as opposed to some waiters who end up listing out the whole menu as "their favorite".

We ended up picking:
l'arrogante (cocktail)
salumi misti
local green asparagus salad / peppercress / herb vinaigrette / olive oil zabaglione
pappardelle / slow-cooked short rib ragu / parmigiano reggiano
alaskan halibut / asparagus & leek poached in chervil cream / shaved purple asparagus
wild chocolate gelato / salted toffee

The food was so delicious.  Well seasoned, salted, and balanced.  It's given me some inspirations on additional ways to prep asparagus.  We were also able to purchase 0.25 lb of the coppa al barbera to take home.  (Michael, if you are reading this...  Thanks for helping us make this happen and pls also thank the chef for us.)

And now I am happy, well-fed, totally stuffed, and in possession of 0.25 lb of coppa to nibble on for the rest of the night.  :D
author: J. F.

description: I had been to Perbacco before and it was excellent. I knew it would be good again, so I chose it for a special occasion. I was not disappointed. The staff are extremely accomodating and pleasant, the atmosphere is calming, yet vibrant. The food had a couple of issues, but the staff absolutely made sure we were happy. Try the signature Perbacco drink- thank you to Mike- he is a GREAT server, and should be recognized for his ability to make the customer happy! Good luck to him in his new "endeavor"!
author: Alicia A.

description: Had dinner here (1/3/07) and found the food to be excellent. I had a Bersotti (type of Ravioli) with Ricotta cheese and Walnut oil that was off the chain. We drank a nice dry Tocai from the Friuli region that was also very tasty. The waitress, who was an authentic Italian, was funny and enlivened the mood at the table appropriately. The decor is nice, not too dark and the staff is knowledgeable and friendly. Even more important, the prices are reasonable. Finally a good restaurant that doesn't charge $40 per entree. If you want to spend that kind of dough, go to Wackqua next door.
author: Sam S.

description: Had lunch here yesterday with Pam L.  We got 11:30am reservations and a nice table in the back.  I love the space.  It's very airy.  Our waiter was super nice.  I liked him a lot.  Very helpful.  They give you breadsticks to start - which I loved and a waiter comes around to give each person a piece of bread.  We decided to skip the appetizers and go right to the main course.  I chose the risotto with scallops which our waiter raved about after I ordered.  I totally agree with our waiter because my risotto was sooo good!  For dessert, we split one of their new items - the warm apple & pear bread pudding.  It came with this apple caramel sauce, grapes, and this creamy cheese which I really liked, but Pam L. didn't.  The meal wasn't too expensive and I'll probably go back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Kris L.

description: Ok, I've been to a lot of fancy shmancy restaurants and this one is probably one of the worst.  The food is OVERPRICED for the quality.  Also, the service is horrible.  The venue is nice and appealing to the eye BUT it's very crowded.  I've been there twice and each time I was sitting less than 1 foot away from another couple.  The food takes FOREVER to arrive and the quality of the food is equivalent to a Black Angus restaurant.  Don't get me wrong, I like Black Angus, but you get what you paid for when you eat at Black Angus.  At Perbacco, the price does not equate to the quality or taste that should be expected.  So Sorry Charlie.
author: Manton R.

description:
Delicious!  

Nduja salumi: spreadable and spicy!  Not your typical salumi, which the waiter was kind enough to warn of us, although we ordered it anyway.  The consistency is like stickier pate.  Also, they give you a generous portion of it, and there were three of us.  

Seared squid: cooked to perfection :) 

Burrata cheese salad: the burrata cheese melts in your mouth, the tomatoes firm and ripe, everything is well seasoned.  

Beet salad: we pretty much order beets whenever we can, this was good, but if you had to choose, I'd go with the burrata.  Nice big slices of golden and red beets, again well seasoned.  

Tajarin pasta: cheesy, meaty, thin pasta.  Yum!  

paparadelle: THE HIGHLIGHT.  Nice short rib meat, big belts of pasta ... all I can really think to say is NOM NOM NOM.

Brown butter cake: it was good, but not my favorite.  If you are a chocolate fiend (I am not), I think you would enjoy this more than me, because of the chocolate ganache they place on top. 

The people at Perbacco were so accommodating, they got us a high chair and then a regular chair for a baby seat (although it's not really a baby place, I do not recommend for them), and a table that was a bit quieter upstairs as opposed to one downstairs.  Also, because we shared everything, they divided the pastas for us and put it onto plates for each of us.  Great attentive service!  They kept on picking up the scarf my sister could not keep on the back of her chair, refilled water, etc. All of that for about 120, tip and tax included, is not bad! 

Am definitely coming back and would recommend to friends!!
author: Alison K.

description:
In my honest opinion, and I dine out A LOT, Perbacco is, hands down, THE best restaurant in San Francisco. Tonight was my fifth or sixth time dining at Perbacco AND it was my 33rd birthday. My boyfriend and I were seated in minutes and I was greeted by a personal birthday card from the staff. Amazingly nice touch! We ordered the fritto misto, the pear gorganzola salad and the spinach, hen egg and cheese ravioli as appetizers and practically licked the plates clean! For entrees, I had the scallops and my boyfriend had the sea bass. Again, we licked our plates clean. For dessert was the warm, delicious apple bread pudding which was TO DIE for. An added b-day touch were some sweet and delicous cookies, on the house! So awesome!!
     Onto the service. In my 5 or 6 times coming here, the service has been nothing short of exceptional! Very attentive, friendly staff. If you need to get up from the table, your napkin will be folded within 5 or 6 seconds of you leaving. 
     The wine list is extensive, and the staff is very knowledgable about perfect pairings with your dish. I cannot recommend this place enough. I've read other reviews that claim this place is noisy and small, but i've never had that experience. It is simply, the best. I am a committed and loyal customer and look forward to dining there again very soon! Thanks, Perbacco for your exquisite service and amazingly delicious food.
author: Jodi M.

description: the risotto with tomato was surprising combination, it was really good.
author: kulas a.

description:
Clap-clap clap-clap-clap O-VER-RATED clap-clap clap-clap-clap!
Why all the fuss over this place?  Sure, it's a nice enough place to go for lunch if you work in the financial district but the food is really mediocre at best.  Gold stars for their service, but our server completely oversold the quality of the food.  All this talk about handmade pastas, slow-cooked sauces, house-made salumi blah blah blah blah.  Look, if your sauce ain't that spectacular to begin with, it really doesn't matter how long it took to cook it.  Granted, the food wasn't bad or offensive, but I've had much more tastier pastas and entrees at other places that aren't nearly as pretentious about their food (see reviews of Delfina and Range, for example).  Specifically, tagliatelle with pork sugo was ok, and spare rib entree was not nearly as flavorful as I would have expected.  If anything, it was a bit bland.  Dessert (chocolate mousse)=nothing special.  Basically, I'd consider returning but only if someone else is paying.
author: Sharyn F.

description: I've already been critical of its neighbor, Aqua, so while I'm at it, why don't I take on Perbacco as well?  As with Aqua, I've been on countless business meals at Perbacco since it opened, and still fail to understand what the fuss is all about.  Yes, this is a nice, convenient place for a client lunch if you're in the Financial District, so it certainly serves a useful purpose in that regard.  But for the most part, the menu is thoroughly average.  I've been there at least 6 times in the past year and change, and can't remember a single aspect of any meal, which has to tell you something, beyond just the fact that I have a poor memory.
author: Ty D.

description: I am a fan! But not as wonderful as Barbacco... I went here on Valentine's Day and walked away with a full and satisfied tummy! The meal was not as memorable as Barbacco... but I will be back! The service was excellent!  My date had very specific needs and he listened and recommended thoughtfully and respectfully!
author: K L.

description: They still need to work out the kinks in running the restaurant smoothly.  The host could have been less...snobby.  (Host: It's your customers that get to frown disdainfully, not you!).  The service, though good overall, was just a tad off.  The food - just ok!  I will give this place one more chance  for dinner, since I only had lunch here.  You're better off getting cocktails or wine, rather than trying their "different" drinks, like vanilla bean lemonade.  My friend was the one with the weird iced tea.
author: Jeanne J.

description: I wasn't really expecting much from the food since I haven't heard the best reviews. I was pleasantly surprised. I loved the pesto dip and bread sticks they bring out! I had a nice glass of Cab, and we started with a cheese appetizer that was excellent! Our waitress was very attentive and helpful, but not over the top. I opted for the salmon entree. It was fairly mediocre. It had a lot of flavor, and don't get me wrong there was Nothing left on my plate, but the fish itself was a little dry. We had the gelato trio for desert which was excellent! It was a nice meal, but realistically I will most likely just be back for the bar. They have a fair amount of tables and it is relatively easy to get a spot and enjoy their bar menu.
author: Lisa K.

description: A friend and I tried this place, sort of randomly, while looking for a good Friday evening happy hour drink... and I am glad we found this place!  They have great cocktails (I had the Mandarina) and the cured meat platter/appetizer thingy was really good.  I would totally go back there, maybe try it for dinner.
author: grant l.

description: I am really surprised by the reviews for Per Bacco. I thought the pastas and vegetables were oily and bland. QUITE disappointing.
author: Lala B.

description: Exquisite italian food. The best lunch spot in the financial district.
author: Gina L.

description:
Outstanding service, memorable and perfectly executed meal.

After much deliberation and research on yelp, cross referencing with Michael Bauer, Gayot, Zagat, Open Table, and any other review I could find I selected this restaurant for my sweetie's birthday. 

Had to wait a bit for our table even though we had reservations, but that was no big deal.  I had requested an upstairs table (thanks Yelp!) so that it would be a little more intimate.  It was really loud at the front, but as you walk away from the bar towards the tables it gets quieter by decibels, so even if you don't eat upstairs, your eardrums shouldn't be overly assaulted by the end of your meal.  

Considered the salume plates, but when asked, the waitress indicated that it was a lot of food and would be more suitable for a larger party.  We instead started with the octopus which she got her approval.  Not squeamish by any means about consuming cephalopods, but traditionally Octopus is not a personal favorite.  In this case, it was excellent.  Great texture, nice smokey flavor (and low carb).  Next was the Pork Sugo with Tagliatelle.  I can see how some might liken the tagliatelle to ramen.  Both are thin and curly and very light to the teeth.  Even the Sweetie made a comparison, but being of Ramen heritage seemed to take to it quite fine.  He liked it and I did, too!  The flavor of the pork sugo was hearty, complex and almost lusty.  The tagliatelle was very delicate.  We were warming up now.  

For main course I was deliberating between the duck and the quail, but leaning towards the duck.  Waitress indicated that the quail was special, so quail it was.  Sweetie went with rabbit.   The quail was amazing.  Very filling, but struck all the right notes.  The truffle-oiled polenta was so light and creamy, and the grapes were very sweet with just enough tang to offset the richness of the quail.  The quail was super tender.  And ladies, don't worry about making a mess trying to eat a bony bird at dinner.  The waitress dissected the bird in half and just when I was ready for the next half she showed up in time (I think she was waiting in the wings) to serve me.  It pretty much fell off the bone, either that or the waitress took care of most of the major bones before serving me.  Either way, it wasn't an issue.  Also, the little birdy was stuffed with sausage.  Can't go wrong there! The Sweetie liked his rabbit, but I think he liked the quail at tad more.  He eagerly consumed the rest of my quail  when I couldn't quite finish it.   Did try his rabbit and must say it was quite tender and juicy.  Often my experience with rabbit is that it has a tendency to be dry.  

 For dessert we had the nectarine thingy.  Very delicious.

BTW, had informed the restaurant when making reservations that we were celebrating the Sweetie's birthday and it seemed like everyone was wishing him a happy birthday.  They even presented him a hand written birthday card at the start of dinner and spelled his name correctly.     

As for service.  Excellent. Our waitress made excellent recommendations, was very nice, super attentive without being overbearing, no hint of  haughtiness, and never hovered.  We had at  4 people attending to us throughout our meal, anticipating our every need, and yet we never for a second felt intruded upon.   We had an excellent experience. 

One of my most pleasurable dining experiences in a very long time.  Strongly recommended.
author: K K.

description: Everyone loves Perbacco, and that's for a reason: It is a great restaurant. Not cheap; hard to get into to, but the food is wonderful; the service is excellent and the setting is very pleasant. We had a corner table in the back, and they did not rush us. We were there almost 2 hours at lunch, eating slowly, talking, etc. They brought us our food as we wanted it, not as the chef want to prepare it. Lots of info about the dishes here on Yelp, so I won't repeat it. I doubt there is a less than super dish on the menu. Wine list is extensive, but focused on out of US wines, so the local selection is a little slim. But the staff were knowledgeable about the wine and helped us make a good selection. It's a real winner.
author: Mike B.

description: We had high hopes for a great dining experience since the restaurant is stylish and attractive.  Our spirits soon faded upon arrival of the Fritto Misto of Rock shrimp which was a heavily fried collection artifacts that we thought we could have done much better at home (it was real oilly). Our risotto was also a disappointment  due to its very heavy flavoring. Finally, our roasted fennel had no fennel scent.  Considering our high expectations I am going to grade severely. Perhaps other items on their menu are done better or perhaps the menu is just not in tune with our taste preferences (not too keen on heavy, rich foods).
author: Robert M.

description:
It was ok eating here today. My hanger steak needed a chain saw to cut through the toughness, but the staff and everything else was very pleasant. I't try this restaurant again...it'd be fun to have a Yelp party here.

This restaurant is a hop away from Aqua which I hear is closing down...not only for lunch but PERIOD.
author: Craig M.

description:
must try again, not wowed. really wanted to be though.

thought the space was broken up and weird but maybe that is b/c of the angles from my vantage point and the fact that the poor servers and bussers had to negotiate around the large column that i was hugging the entire meal.

no comment on service, which was perfectly pleasant, b/c this was night #2 of opening.

the bummer was the food, which i honestly do expect to be great even at the start.  the octopus crudo was downright nasty-chewy, tasteless and an insane portion for the price (when you start thinking of what a great "value restaurant aqua is...) but the server dealt with that nicely.

the pork pate - well, when you're basically indulging in pork fat, you want it to be so good you can't NOT eat it. Not the case here.  Again, seasoning folks.

The papardelle and the squid with beans were both ok - just no looks of "YUM YOU MUST HAVE  BITE OF THIS!!!!!!!!!! QUICK BEFORE I FINISH IT ALL!!!!!!!".  Presentation was very rustic and Italian.

a few glasses of wine later (i think they need better stemware for what they are charging), a comp'ed dessert (the highlight of the night, foodwise...it was a citrusy panna cotta...fantastic), we left for about $150, which just seemed damned pricey given the experience.

agree w/other poster on lighting.

i'll definitely try it again, but it seemed, in the words of a wise friend "more of a breakup restaurant than a date one".
author: Laurie A.

description: We have eaten here twice now and have not been disappointed.  If you can, ask for Giovanni (pronounced Joe-Vanni) to be your server.  He is AWESOME!  We had such a great time on both occasions!   Just beware that the menu changes often and the online menu is probably out of date.  Be sure to ask for the sommelier before ordering a bottle of wine as they match dinners and wine up nicely.  We would recommend trying any combination of sausages, the raddichio salad, and butternut squash ravioli.  I would recommend getting a few half-orders of the pasta dishes to share and sample the menu.  For dessert, you MUST have the panna cotta!!  It is FANTASTIC!  I am not a fan of panna cotta and I found myself pushing my wife away from getting her little mitts on this dessert.  Dinner for two with drinks and a bottle of wine was $200.
author: Luke L.

description:
Perbacco

Loved this place.  Service was excellent, knowledgeable and very friendly (our waiter told us stories of the guy they keep in the basement making the grissini placed on the table instead of bread, with a nice salsa cruda - AWESOME grissini - we went thru 3 plates of those in the first 10 minutes.  i lived in Italy for 5 months and never had better).  very crowded and noisy, but a beautiful, airy space.  But because it's so noisy, and huge, it feels a tad impersonal, not warm and cozy.  Ehh, that's a nit that doesn't need picking

Here's what 3 of us ate last night:  Brandacujun --- salt cod/potato gratin/crostini - perfect balance of warm potato with crunchy browned top and salty cod; mozzarella di bufala/black truffle condimento/arugula/grilled pilone (a type of bread) - SOOOO GOOD.  So creamy soft, like melting jack cheese, but not warm, with the truffle and arugula, on the nicely charred bread - very heady; Coppa di testa - warm pig's head terrine!!  like rillettes, chopped up and then spread very thin into two disks, had a sweet, almost clove-y, cinnamon-y taste; this was a wow, and even tho my friend was put off by the fact it was pig's head, he loved it; carne cruda of vitallone/black truffle condimento/crostini - raw cute little baby veal (i have to get over this, i ate veal all over Italy - you almost can't get grown-up cow there!) of course was yummy, almost like the texture of ahi tuna tartare; fritto misto of rock shrimp/green beans/olives/meyer lemon/fennel/lemon aioli - very nice, light batter, olives were a nice tart touch in a rich dish like this; pappardelle/braised short rib ragu/roasted chanterelles - another rich dish - slow cooked, meaty, dark sauce, mixed in with big flat homemade noodles; fijian (!) swordfish/fingerling potatoes/chanterelles - better than the pappardelle even - tender and dense and flavorful.  dessert was a sort of chocolate tart with carmelized hazelnuts and some kind of polenta cake/vanilla ice cream/fruit coulis/with more carmelized hazelnuts - have to say dessert was a disappointment to me, but i'm not a huge dessert person.  my two companions liked it.  i thought the polenta cake was heavy (tho the waiter described it as light) and flavorless, and the chocolate thing was a bit dry, and hazelnuts are my least favorite nut.

But i have to say, overall, YUM.  We shared everything and were completely, painfully stuffed.  We also had three bottles of prosecco, and our bill total was something like $210 before tip.  Then onto Aqua for 3 glasses of wine.  Too much is never enough.
author: maria a.

description:
I was really looking forward to eating at Perbacco and had brought along some of my fellow foodies who had also heard great things about the restaurant. 

We had reservations and were seated right away, thank you opentable.com. Once our waitress took our drink orders, it was at least another 10-15 minutes before she came back with the drinks. We asked several questions, and she left to give us a few minutes to decide - which in the land of Perbacco is more like 15 minutes. Based on her recommendations, we had the following:

Apps - the burrato cheese with heirloom tomatoes on filone bread was ridiculously delicious. Literally ridiculous. The hamachi was also good, but the gnocchi overwhelmingly tasted like asparagus and wasn't good at all. And I generally love gnocchi.

Main course - the pork loin was delicious and moist. The duck was surprisingly lean and much lighter than duck I had before - also very good. My dish was unfortunately a major disappointment. I ordered the beef short ribs based on the server's rave reviews and received about 10 ounces of beef fat with 2 ounces of gritty meat. This was surrounded by a sea of peas, one of the few vegetables I despise, and a couple of carrots and potatoes. 

Dessert - Since the service was so, so slow, we passed. 

Drinks - I had prosecco and ordered a second glass which never came. But the first glass was very good. My friends ordered the Perbacco cocktail, wanted another, but were never given the chance to order another.

The food is generally good, but not consistent. Our server was friendly and sensitive to my food allergies, but seemed overwhelmed with too many tables. From start to finish, it took almost two and half hours for a two course meal. Simply too slow.

Perbacco is a good place to go sit at the bar for drinks and apps. If you want to sit down for a meal - go to A16. The menus are strangely similar, but the service at A16 is FAR better, the food is consistently good and the prices are well worth it.
author: Rachelle P.

description: My wife and I ate at Perbacco earlier this week.  The service was great and the ambiance was very nice -- the place felt very alive, but not overly crowded.  We were both very happy with our starters -- Lisa had panzanella and I had burrata and tomatoes.  Their charcuterie looks amazing -- would love to go back even if just for that.  My entree, seared halibut in a tomato, fish stock sauce was excellent.  Cooked perfectly and very flavorful.  Lisa had yellowfin tuna, which wasn't quite as impressive.  Bit tough, but that's always my complaint with yellowfin.  Highlight of the night was the wine.  Sommelier recommended an excellent bottle of Veneto that I'll be looking for in stores, but will no doubt never find.  Guess we'll have to return to Perbacco!
author: Graham M.

description: I had a wonderful evening here during my recent business trip to the city.  Our group had two tables set aside in a secluded area that was pretty stark and had poor lighting, so we missed out on the chic decor of the main dining area.  Other than this fact, Perbacco was great.  We had a four-course menu with perfect portion sizes.  My favorite dish was the pesto flavored pasta with small asparagus cuts.  I've never had such tender noodles; they were clearly homemade.  I also loved the seared scallops with a mushroom sauce - I wish I had looked at the menu more closely so I could remember the other outstanding components of the sauce.  The berry crumble dessert was tasty, but I so wanted to order one of the other decadent Italian desserts off the menu.  If I ever have the chance to dine at Perbacco again, I think I'll have to order two desserts after hearing others' rave reviews!  Overall, Perbacco was a memorable and satisfying dining experience.
author: Alison T.

description: Ate here recently.  Love it.  Food was great.  Service was great.  Found a free parking space around the corner (I think because we had 6:15 PM reservations and many of the parking restrictions go off at 6 PM)!  Modern and warm decor.
author: Doctor G.

description: It's Ok and the menu hardly ever changes. Definietley get the Butternut Squash Ravioli. It's really good.
author: Sue S.

description: I had lunch here and enjoyed it. Started by sharing the salumi (very good) and salted cod (not a huge fan) both of which were salty but good. The gnocchi (Gorgonzola cream sauce w/toasted hazelnuts) was fantastic. Not usually a fan of gnocchi b/c it can be too thick and weird texture but this was amazing. If all gnocchi was like this it would become a staple in my diet. The service was fine, fairly attentive and timely. The only weird thing was my iced tea tasted really weird, like they put some smoked oil in it or something. Still can't place it. Next time I'll have a cocktail b/c those looked fantastic.
author: jess c.

description:
It is what it is, an excellent choice for downtown dining. With Terje gone from Scala, San Francisco lost a great chef in downtown dining options. As for a downtown restaurant without the extras offered by a French Laundry, it's as good as you get or would want.

It was impossible to get into Perbacco right after it opened..which may explain some of the bad reviews. A new restaurant is often overwhelmed, while the staff is still being trained. You should not expect perfection if you go in the first few weeks. We didn't even try.
