I had an opportunity to eat at Perbacco family style - four people sharing almost everything on the menu - after the post opening rush. I found:
1) The food was excellent. Not exquisite, but it is not intended to be Campton Place or the Fifth Floor. All of it very tasty and well presented.
Nothing pretentious or overly composed. The foods have a slight rustic element, which I find pleasant.
2) The service non memorable, which means just fine. I only remember bad service.
3) The bill acceptable. 

The only unfortunate thing is that it is located in a nest of similarly priced restaurants which offer excellent food: Acqua, Palio and others, leaving those of us working closer to the Downtown Centre with Scala, Kuletto or the Grand Cafe, all of which have slipped considerably in the past year, or Lark Creek Steak - which is excellent, but you don't always want to eat that hearty.
author: Otto S.

description: I was hoping to really like this place - cool interior, great bar area, friendly staff, but I was unfortunately disappointed by the food.  The fresh pasta could have possibly been fresh, but was overcooked and laden in grease that I really couldn't tell.  Nothing else was memorable.  Disappointing.
author: Bridget S.

description: Great simple food.  Loved the short rib which was cooked perfectly.  The desserts sucked yuck! freagin dry ayss cake and soggy cookies.  We had a wonderful server she was this little Italian lady who was just awsome, but yeah whats up wit desserts?
author: Kool G.

description: I was visiting SF running the Nike Marathon and had read good reviews so thought we'd try it.  We arrived for our reservation and were seated promptly.  The front bar was packed and loud, but in an energetic way without being obnoxious.  The dining area though, is quiet and comfortable.  The service was fabulous.  The wait staff were attentive without being overbearing; always appearing just before we thought of needing them.  We are vegetarians and had plenty of choices.  The food was delicious and inventive without being too over the top.  Would definitely recommend.
author: Lynn F.

description: You won't find anything here you've had before.  That can either be a good thing or a bad thing depending on your level of adventure.  Thankfully, the staff is extremely helpful and can steer you towards dishes that may fit your tastes.   The salumi plate was the best thing I had, but I was not a fan of most of the spices used in the other dishes.  I would not recommend it for a big group as it's not easy to find something everyone may like.
author: Dan c.

description:
This is a great and I maen GREAT dinning experience!
I called up on the same day for a reservation, I called on a Thursday at three and got in for the same evening ay 8:00pm. A very nice man with an Italian Accent answered the telephone and asked if was a special occation I said why yes thank you for asking it is my friends birthday and  this is her gift "Lovely" he said see you at 8:00pm! I thought wow excellent this just opened and I got right in cool! so I went at 8:00pm by cab which was best becasue parking is a joke in that area best to cab!
and when I got there my name was no where to be found, I wanted to turn my heels and go but before I even got a half a frown on my face the woman at the door very calmly applogized, and handed me I glass of Champane! which is super rare usually they (coast to coast) make you feel as if you made a mistake not them she applogize over and over and told me that she would fit me in. I stolled around to see the resturant it is LOVELY its big but comfortable and the lighting although bright is not over lit its not casual but its not dressy its very urban and crowed which I love becasue yes its like New York! its felt chick but not stuffy or "trying" everyone was well dressed and friendly 
which is sometimes a hard combination to find and the food wow!...
we had five or six apps in stead of having a full Entree' we shared everything the service was great and we left late for San Francisco (10:30) and people were still there not many but they were still there. Plus the location could not be better right in between Aqua and Tadish Grill which is a perfect discription becasue the admospher is like a great updated and slightly hipper mix of the two.
The price was not bad I was treating for my friends birthday and I spent what I planned to spend and that is delightful! oh and each dish that we ordered was amazing amzing amazing!
author: Susan B.

description: We came here for lunch and first ordered the salami platter.  It was good but not spectacular.  We also ordered the tagliatelle with slow cooked pork which was quite flavorful and a lamb dish which was also enjoyed.  The ambience is classy and the food is good but there are more restaurants in San Francisco to try before coming back here.
author: Lisey W.

description: Excellent service, claustrophobic seating area, underseasoned food.  I won't go back. I was so disappointed after everything I had heard. Short ribs under seasons, so was my friends rabbit. Expensive and overpriced. oh well, back to Americano at the hotel vitale!!
author: patricia d.

description: Great desert and cappuccino - but no service and weird food- skip this one!
author: Ruth D.

description: This has to be the best dining experience here in San Francisco.  I look forward to seeing what new items are on the menu to try and love the wine list selections.  I come here with clients and with family!
author: Audrey T.

description: Lovely little Italian place.  Great charcuterie plate and terrific home made pastas.  Nice wine list and great service.  I was on a business dinner so I could not take detailed notes but I'd go back.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Great place for lunch! Try the heirloom tomato and burrata appetizer! 

The service is great and the tables are all very nice.

But parking is problematic...watch out for the garages in the area because they will cost you a small fortune ($27/2.5 hours)!
author: Christi B.

description:
what's up with all of the utensils? we ate there last night and they gave us: 8 forks, four knives, two butter spreaders and four spoons between two people for four appetizers. plus placemats and numerous plates. too much pomp and circumstance for me but there are some really good dishes (any of the house-cured meats, the brandacujun and beets and some of the pastas) and dishes that sounded great on the menu but were not so great on the plate (tuna conserva and burrata and broccoli rabe). the cheese selection is nice and i'm very pleased with the little sweets they give you at the end.

cocktails are nice too. i remember the summer ones being especially refreshing! also, i highly recommend sitting in the bar area. good noise levels and feels a lot more fun than the stuffy dining room area looks.
author: Rowena M.

description: WOW - and then some. Yum, Yum, Yum. Agnolotti with veal, beet salad, a wonderful assortment of appetizers and really good desserts. Our company holiday party. Wine, coffee, sparkling water.....who could ask for anything more??????
author: holly B.

description: Too much oil in every dish.  Kind of like Rick James.
author: rerun w.

description: I think the food deserves four stars but something about it just makes me short them one. The food was good, nothing amazing. Their house-made salumi's were good but nothing spectacular. The tables are a little too close to each other and it's noisy. The only thing that stands out is the neighboring table's butt of a waiter. Every time he attended to them, he slid in between our two table so his booty was nearly touching my drinks. Gross! If you want to pretend you're Michelin rated and charge people as if you were, train your waiters better. My wife had to tell the waiter not to stand there and booty-up my drinks. Thanks wife.
author: Bruce B.

description:
went here for a little vino and appetizers before heading off to a company party.  the wine was great!  and the salumi misti was awesome, awesome!  the service was really good and i'm looking forward to coming here again to try out the other dishes!

if you're looking for something quiet and romantic, this would not be the place though.  it's pretty loud.
author: cindy c.

description:
Nice atmosphere, convenient if you're in the finanical district.  Contrary to some of the reviews, I found the service from the bartender and hostess to be great.  The girls and I had the salumi misti and squid with corona beans for apps - both very good.  I was so--- looking forward to the pork shoulder al latte and found it good, but not all that amazing or tender.  Between that, the short ribs entree, papardelle and  agnolotti with roasted veal, the agnolotti was probably the best entree i tried that night.   The highly recommended pitachio panna cotta tasted more like green tea to a couple of us but the hazelnut cookies were awesome - more of a macaroon style, which i normally don't like, but these were so yummy!  The entree portions were  decently sized, but the pastas seemed a bit skimpy.  I would suggest ordering an entree and sharing a small portion of the pasta with a friend...
This place was packed on a weeknight at 5:45 so reservations are suggested...the walk in tables are too congested by the bar...
author: Amina B.

description: Just had my birthday dinner at Perbacco last week. This was my first time eating there and I was very happy with the food! Service was excellent. Tons of stuff on the menu that I want to try so we are going back, yes yes!
author: Mar D.

description:
Still very good, but I just went here on a Monday for lunch and noticed a few things:
- The bread, (foccacia) although tasty, is a little greasy and the bread sticks alternative just doesn't cut it for me.  I wish they had a "regular" bread or roll option.
- The kitchen was definitely off.  Took ages to get a salad and the waiter apologized and we think she even said she'd comp us a dessert but she never did.  The main courses also took awhile after we were done with the salad.  NOT good when you're on a business lunch and watching the time till the next meeting.
- The brussel sprouts were good, but not as good as past times.  I don't think the heat was high enough when they were pan fried and they seemed a little more greasy and a touch overcooked.
- My hanger steak was very tasty, great meat flavor, but I ordered medium rare and it was a little bit over cooked, but not worth sending back (especially after that wait)
I will go back, but next time will stick to dinner service or I'lll sit at the bar...
author: Priscilla C.

description: pretty good food, very nice service and decor at a fair price.
author: Peter W.

description: Corporate lunches keep me from starving, so I'm glad a new dining option has opened in my FiDi hood. This one has menu items I can't spell or pronounce, but seem normal enough...I had the chicken salad, which was a perfect ladies-who-lunch option and tasted quite good. My lady counterparts chose butternut ravioli, some kind of fish, and risotto, which all recieved high-marks. The service seems in need of a bit of tweaking, but they're new and still working out the kinks, I think. A nice change from the usual upscale suspects.
author: Julia C.

description: I had the beet and arugula salad and a pasta that was like a giant rigatoni cut in short pieces with a short rib ragu, and my friends had the gnocchi and the tajarin, and everyone loved their meals.  The sauce on the pasta was nice and fatty and rich, and the beets were tender and the arugula nutty and spicy. I had a glass of Montepulciano that was also pretty nice. I want to go back and try the desserts.
author: cecilia g.

description: Underwhelmed. Maybe I should learn not to go into restaurants with high expectations. Went for a business lunch, we split an arugula peach salad with some kind of nuts and cheese which was pretty good and the perfect size for a small starter. My only complaint was the vinagerette was a little too sour for my liking. Ordered the gnocchi, and based on the reviews here was expecting something amazing. While it was very, very soft, the flavor was quite bland the sauce (more butter than garlic or flavor) didn't contribute much either. The mushrooms and onions were good though. Sigh...maybe I'm not meant for the Financial District, everything on yelp with great reviews seems to underwhelm me.
author: Rohan N.

description: SHORT & SWEET: generally overrated with a few notable exceptions; the "salumi" and the rest of the hanging meats are rather standard (do you need an acquired taste to recognize a "fine" piece of salami?  must you seek the council of a "salammelier"?); the Vitello Tonnato is quite nice, served with a dollop of zesty tuna puree; skip the ligurain salt cod (the name says it all) and go with the truly unique Fritto Misto (how often can you find fried olives?); for entrees, the duck breast was forgettable, but I saw (and heard) the folks at the next table devouring the short ribs; avoid the upstairs dining room at all costs; imagine a large broom closet with low ceilings (claustrophobic and bland aesthetics compared to downstairs); service is average; good after-work bar scene if you're a 40+ attorney or accountant.
author: Corey S.

description:
The atmosphere at Perbacco IS NOT sexy. This is a place that is managed pretty well, with the "general" riding herd on the tables, making sure that everyone is happy. We had a staff "miss" when my order was the wrong entree. The staff member dropped both plates, and when I brought it to the staff's attention, only my plate was removed, leaving my wife to eat alone. This lasted about a minute...the general walked by our table, looked, went immediately to our waiter who removed her plate. Within 10 minutes both orders were delivered with an apology. The food was first rate. The desserts were fantastic. My wonderfully beautiful spousal unit had the Dolcetto Sabajon...wow. Pears in a white wine sabajon that was exquisitely peaked. I had the Chocolate Tart....fantastic but second-best!
This is a family style restaurant with large seating areas and a large bar in the Financial District. It's a great place for dinner after work, or a family event. Wonderful. But don't go here expecting a romantic or intimate atmosphere....unless one of the light bulbs go out in a corner.
author: George M.

description:
I have mixed feeling about Perbacco. I went last December and most recently last week. Both times the service bordered on gaudy. I can't think of a better word. When the waiter read the specials he sounded like the Fonz.....no he reminded me Joey Buttafuaco. The first time I went we had a horribly obnoxious Italian lady who wouldn't leave us alone. She even lined up our glasses on the table to make it "prettier" interrupting our conversation. This time the waiter took my wine glass when it was empty (we still had a half bottle of wine!) and didn't come back. (I mean why would you take the wine glass away if you've still got a bottle of wine??)

Other than that the food is pretty good. Not blow your mind fantastic, but good. Started with the hamachi and cicioli. Main entrees were the seared duck breast and duck pappardelle. All reasonably good. Their salumi plate is their specialty and is good as well. Had the pear tart for dessert, crust was soggy, tasted greasy. I remember their chocolate dessert being better.

I think this place is great for having a glass of prosecco and some appetizers on your lunch break or on a  nice business lunch, but I wouldn't go out of my way there for dinner....better just to go to Aqua next door.
author: Tiger P.

description: Started with the roasted octopus (w/ saffron poached potato, meyer lemon vinaigrette, and salsa verde) - not bad.  For my main course, had the beef short rib stracotto (w/ root vegetable puree, roasted cipolline, and baby turnips) - as the name would suggest, it's tender and they did a great job with this one.  Pleasant dining experience and I would come back, so I'll give Perbacco 4 stars.
author: Mark K.

description:
have returned for several more lunches - both small and big groups - and have yet to be disappointed.  more menu must-order items (although the menus are seasonal and change frequently):

apps:
- burrata cheese - so rich and tasty!
- salumi platter - all cured in-house (even the mini gherkins!) a must for meat lovers, plus it comes w/ extra breadsticks

pasta/entrees:
- butternut squash mezzalune - plump half-moon ravioli-like pillows filled with mellow squash, livened up by a sage butter and salty cheese
- grilled hanger steak - always cooked perfectly to order, well seasoned and decent portion.  great roasted potatoe and arugula salad accompinament.  plus a rich gorgonzola butter that complements everything on the plate (not just the beef!) w/o overwhelming...

dessert:
- warm hazelnut cake - perfect for those who don't want a sickeningly sweet dessert; very dense and a bit grainy almost like cornbread with a nutella-esque filling (for those who do have a bit of a sweet tooth)
- chocolate cake - a chocoholic's delight!

servers are as well-versed in the menus and gracious as ever but timing and attentiveness has slipped a bit; it's always been a popular business lunch option, but now that aqua next door only serves dinner, it seems even more fidi suits are here power-lunching.  it's more crowded now than ever and service lags...

but i can't knock it down any stars b/c the food is still excellent, even when it's for a large private lunch for 20 people!  (and the pre-fixe menus w/ options for each course is great for groups)
author: Jen P.

description: Had some wonderful pasta here for dinner.  Rabbit pasta.  Woo-wee! Not much to say after that.  I recommend going here, I guess I could add.
author: Scott G.

description: Perbacco is my go-to restaurant. I've been here multiple times, and each time I've left 100% satisfied. The pastas are warm, loving plates, but you don't feel like you could have made it at home. The servers are always friendly and well-informed. I've never been disappointed in a suggestion they made.
author: Susan Y.

description: Went here with my girlfriends had a nice bottle of wine, and lots of the appetizers everything was delicious....  left completely satisfied!
author: Shirl C.

description: 3.5 stars.  7 of us came here for dinner on Saturday night.  Overall, the food was great.  We ordered the salumi and it was an awesome way to start the meal.  I had the hamachi crudo which was excellent, but my wife's tagliatelle with 5 hr pork sugo was ridiculously flavorful.  I also got to taste a small bite of the roasted octopus and that was well cooked and not at all rubbery or tasteless.  For entrees, I devoured my short rib (braised short rib with bone marrow crust?!  what's not to like?).  However, my wife and I felt her quail filled with foie was somewhat mushy; I'd expect the foie to be soft, but the quail really didn't have a nice consistency to it.  I also was expecting the dish to be awesome, but it was kinda bland.  Lastly, our orders kept getting messed up all night.  The right orders came to our table, but the waiters kept giving the wrong dishes to the wrong diner.  They even gave my Fernet Branca to my wife!  Place is definitely popular on a Saturday night and loud, but we had a nice round table in the back on the second floor.  So we definitely had a great time at Perbacco, but did experience some misses with the quail and with the service.
author: Tim L.

description: i've come here for lunch and dinner. the house cured italian meats are the best. my favorite is the pork ragu pasta. it's so soft and wonderfully seasoned.
author: Jen C.

description: The food was delicious and the service was absolutely stellar.  It was, however, very noisy which is the only reason my my review isn't 5 stars.  It was my friends birthday and instead of the horible humiliating birthday song she got a birthday card on our table, a free dessert and a discreet, but heartfelt birthday greeting from everyone from the hostess to the busboy.  Be sure to try the roasted octopus appetizer and the gnocci if they're on the menu
author: lisa l.

description:
been a # of times for lunch.

service: some of best in the city

groups of 4-6: ask for 1 of center tables upstairs...this rest. is LOUD

wine list: entirely reasonable if you wish...work w/waiter...

grilled calamari is a must...

pastas r  x-cellent

steak top notch

seafood: seabas no flavor...everything else a go

deserts: ok
author: john l.

description: excellent meal - had the salumi platter, tripe and gnocchi as an appetizer and the short ribs for the entree.  Was one of the better meals that I have had in SF in the past couple of years - service was outstanding, great wine list and highly recommended.
author: Ham S.

description: Went here for a business dinner recently. The food and service was good. I couldn't concentrate too much on the conversation since it was soooooo noisy though. Not a place to take a first date or someone that you actually want to have a conversation with. Drink list was reasonable in price which is somewhat surprising. Extensive wine list. Large bar area so looks like it might be a great place to grab a drink and a couple of appetizers after work.
author: Heather L.

description:
So I went the other night for another work function....usually boring.. not this time! We were escorted up to a private room lined with windows on one side that overlook the bustling kitchen. When we got there we were greeted with mini apps and wine. For dinner I had one of their signature pastas that was delicious!! I had the chocolate cake with the soft chocolate center. I can't resist chocolate!! 

All in all I really enjoyed the meal. The server was great and on it. (my wine glass was never empty) The only thing I would say is it was a bit too warm in the room. The server tried to help by opening the back door to let a breeze in. I would definitely come back to any party in that room. Next time I just wont have a sweater on.
author: m m.

description: Great service, nice ambiance, bland food.  I had a gnocchi dish (Truffle) and it was bland and my date had some type of pasta with pork on top and I ate some of hers and it was bland too.  Very knowledgeable server and nice staff, but I'm from the East Coast and I find the Italian food on the West Coast fair.  This place is overrated.
author: Michael P.

description:
I went here with 2 friends from out of town on a Saturday night and it was definitely fancier and quieter than we had expected, but that was OK. We ordered the burrata cheese and baby gem gorgonzola salads to start. Those were all good, and a lot bigger than we had expected which is always a nice surprise. For the main courses I got the Papperdelle short rib dish, and it was good, but I have tried that dish in a lot of restaurants, and it was no better than anywhere else. One of my friends got the tagliatte with pork, and she loved it.  After dinner we skipped desert and had espresso martinis and they were excellent as a desert substitute. 

All in all it is a good restaurant, but being in my early 20s it seemed a bit fancy. Definitely more a place my parents would go.
author: Katie G.

description: Out. Freaking. Standing. Went here for a work dinner Wednesday night, and the food was absolutely to die for. It was um, ample, to say the least. There were passed hors deouvres, then course 1 was a salad with some fantastic cheese and an Italian meat platter. Course 2 was a swiss chard ravioli with surprise! a full egg yolk in the middle. Yum. Course 3 was filet mignon and the mashed potatoes had so much butter in them (but not too much) I almost licked the plate. I have no idea how much it cost -- cause it was a work thing -- but it was amazing. I'll be back.
author: H H.

description:
Had the pleasure of dining here for my birthday and I must say I was very impressed with our entire meal.
The food was delicious and the service was impeccable.
With four of us we were able to try many of the dishes and I must say the stand outs were:
the peach salad- a perfect combination or savory and sweet-
the Tajarin- the pork ragu was perfectly seasoned and the homemade pasta was scrumptious
the vegetable risotto- perfectly cooked and seasoned

My husband raved about the rabbit but I didn't try it and a friend had the veal pasta appetizer and said it too was incredible.

Water glasses were refilled, bread plates were never empty and the waitress was attentive without being annoying.

Save room for dessert because the three we shared were all good.  The hazelnut cookies are perfect for dipping into an espresso and the brown butter cake was to die for.  They gave us a complimentary order of the sweet corn pane cotta which we all agreed was okay but would have been better served as the side to a savory dish.

Very delicious and left me wanting more.
author: Kathryn K.

description:
I hadn't been here before, but ended up going twice last week.  The first occasion was a lunch to celebrate a few co-workers' birthdays.  We were seated upstairs on the mezzanine, which was quite chilly when we arrived.  The service was pretty slow considering that people are usually in a bigger rush at lunchtime.  I started with a golden & red beets appetizer, which was yummy and refreshing.  For the main course, I had the Ligurian style pesto, which was freshly made pasta, pesto, potatoes, and green beans.  My fiance's family makes this dish, so I was very excited to see this on the menu.  It was tasty, but a little too salty.  Lunch was accompanied by an unbelievably good focaccia.  I could have eaten baskets full of it.  I'm generally not super excited about bread, but this stuff was amazing!

My second outing to Perbacco was for dinner, this time with 13 co-workers.  This time we were seated downstairs.  I was surprised by the seating arrangement.  One side of the table was along the booth-like wall.  That meant that those of us in the center on that side were completely trapped there.  I don't know if there was a heater under the seat or what, but everyone on that side was sweating when we left.  It was so damn hot (and I only had a sip of wine!)  We had 8 different bottles of wine on our table - 4 white and 4 red.  I was really impressed by the service in this respect.  The waiters poured the wine throughout the evening and gave us as many different glasses for it as we wanted.  The service overall was much better at dinner than it was at lunch.  I was very disappointed to find rolls as the dinner bread.  I really wanted that focaccia again!  For dinner I had the spring garlic gnocchi with asparagus sauce.  It was really, really yummy.  I would definitely order that dish again.  I had some dessert this time too - lemon panna cotta - super delicious!

While I think they have some atmospheric problems in here, the food is just fabulous.  I will definitely return again soon.
author: Squirrel L.

description:
UPDATE - 3/25/08:

I had lunch here with a friend today and we couldn't have enjoyed ourselves -- and the food -- more.  We'd asked for a secluded table and got one.  The table was far enough apart from our neighbors so that we -- honestly -- didn't even know they were there.  I had an exquisite soup of the day -- asparagus puree with pancetta on top -- and couldn't pass up the mushroom risotto (I never can).  

Perbacco holds to European service standards:  servers are efficient and courteous but not overbearing or overly-familiar, and best of all, they don't hover.  

Lunch was so good that we didn't even have room for dessert, but I'll definitely be back.  Thanks, Umberto!
author: Dennis H.

description: This restaurant was everything I wanted and more. The sommelier selected a wine for us that was absolutely perfect. We had the cured meats as an appetizer - amazing. I had the pomegranate pork chop which I would usually NEVER order at a restaurant but took a chance. It was amazing. I cannot wait to go back.
author: Becky M.

description: I found the service to be excellent, our server was extremely attentive. I had pasta stuffed with cabbage and veal. WOW, it was light and filling at the same time. My friend had a ground pork meat sauce over some sort of pasta and it tasted just like my family's meat sauce recipe from Italy, REALLY! We actually have one. ..but you can't get it. .. you have to suffer through creamed onions at grandma's during thanksgiving first.
author: Katherine B.

description: The pasta here is amazing.  There is nothing like homemade pasta for a comfort dinner.  The bf had the winning dish, the duck tortelloni, (mouth watering as I write).  The charcuterie was wonderful as well....we'll be back to enjoy the tender pastas and the wonderful service.
author: Brye L.

description: I was taken here for a celebratory dinner. I really liked the vibe of the restaurant and the service was pretty good.  The food just wasn't at a 5 star rating.  Also, I can't give a place 5 stars if they allow their patrons to use nose flutes while at the table!
author: Angie C.

description: Great place, -1 star b/c they could add more salt or flavor to some dishes.
author: F K.

description: Went in for lunch a couple of days ago with a client.  Perbacco was excellent yet again.  We both ordered the tajarin, and my client loved it.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
I LOVED dinner here! This was the best service I've ever received anywhere - it was so much fun! 5 stars given the impeccable service, excellent food, and the use of locally farmed foods.

The service:
We arrived about 20 minutes early, and stood next to the bar sipping on cocktails. Just as we are mid-way through our first drink, a lady comes up to us and asks if we are "ready for the next portion of our evening." She takes our drinks on a tray and leads us to a wonderful corner table in the back of the restaurant - it was perfect. I am clueless about wine menus, and ask our waitress to suggest a white wine, she offers her favorite and gives me a taste - it is exactly what I want. We also went along with her appetizer, red wine, and dessert suggestions as the meal progressed. She seemed more than happy to oblige our requests, and was never irritated by our questions.

The food:
When you arrive they give you crunchy breadsticks with pesto dip, a bread roll, and butter - I wasn't crazy about the pesto dip, and the bread roll was cold and hard. From here on everything was delicious. We started with the chef's choice of salumi, which was an interesting array of choices plus pork pate - between my boyfriend and I we managed to find which salumi's we like and finish off the plate. We followed that with tomato/bread salad and gnocchi - the tomatoes and gnocchi were both delicious, but the bread of the bread salad was just mushy cold bread. By this point we were drunk and full, but we still had the duck and ribeye entree dishes - both were delicious and the sides with these dishes were yummy as well. Finally we finished with the almond cake - very unusual and tasting dense little cake with candied saffron and ice cream. We finished happy, full, and grateful for an amazing evening.
author: Corinne R.

description: Good stuff: good service, understandable prices for the good atmosphere. If you have a birthday there and tell them ahead of time, they'll have a birthday card waiting for you from the staff. Gee, thanks guys! Had the lamb shank and just writing this review is making my mouth water... gotta go.
author: Trav K.

description:
I've been to Perbacco twice now - first time I had a very good meal, the second time everything I had previously enjoyed was gone from the menu (no pesto in a restaurant that claims to "introduce ... the full range of flavors... of Liguria"!?)  The fantastic cocktail I'd had on my first visit was also gone.

Still, high quality food, but not cheap.  You can get Italian food that's just as good for a lot less money, but you're paying for the big designy space.
author: Ritch G.

description: The food was pretty good, but the service was a little bit TOO quick. The portions were also way too small for the price.
author: Steve C.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and went here the night before our anniversary.  I was a little apprehensive after reading some negative reviews.  But I wound up really liking the place.  We ate upstairs where it was quiet and romantic.  The service was a little rushed and brusque but turned friendly and relaxed after I ordered a bottle of their most expensive prosecco.  The appetizers were wonderful.  A tuna tartar that was cut thick and set amidst the juiciest of fresh tomatoes was especially good.  The best dish of the evening was a tagliatelle stuffed with mushrooms and accompanied by blueberries.  It sounds odd, I know, but was terrific. I didn't even want to eat the ravioli my spouse had (we had agreed to share), since I wanted the taste of my dish to linger.  I highly recommend the place, especially if you order a nice bottle of wine.
author: Tania M.

description: we had the absolute best meal with family friends who were visiting. the salumi misti is incredible and their gelato is fantastic!  one of the best meals i've ever eaten.
author: Libbi J.

description: I went here for a business dinner a few months ago.  They did a great job of handling our party of 20 plus.   It was a Thursday night and very crowded but our servers did a great job.  We started out wiht some of the sampling plates of meats that were excellent.  I had a ribeye which is the best steak I have had since leaving Omaha.  The desserts were unique and yummy.
author: jane f.

description: I did not like this place... Seemed pretentious and they had my party with reservation waiting over half an hour. I thought... Maybe their food is worth it... But no. Disappointing... Id rather have pasta pomodoro
author: K T.

description:
I've been to Perbacco many times and aside from my most recent visit the experiences rated 3-5 stars. Unfortunately this week's visit rated 2 stars. We sat in a booth in the bar area (generally my favorite location) and ordered lots of small plates and a lovely bottle of wine for a bill that totalled about $230. My BF got mushroom risotto with pancetta (that's how it was described in the menu). What arrived was mushroom risotto with two large (3"x3") slabs of what seemed to be raw pork belly/fat on top. The risotto had no pork or meat flavor to it - it was good, but there was no connection to the weird "topper". My BF and I are by no means vegetarians and neither are we squeamish - especially him, not at all - and we both found the "meat" to be truly disgusting. When our very perky server checked on us, we expressed disappointment/concern and her response was "yeah, usually the pancetta is small, cooked and within the risotto, but I guess the chef wanted to something a little edgier tonight". And then she giggled and popped away. "Edgier"? Raw, large slabs of light pink fat? How about "grosser"?. 
It was so revolting that neither of us could eat anything else - my veal tartare was untouched as a result. 
My complaint was not as much with the food - there some things that I/we don't like - so be it - no big deal. But the fact that the server did not seem at all concerned that we didn't like it, that she didn't notice or care that we stopped eating and didn't touch large plates of food after it arrived, that she didn't even ask "was there something wrong with the tartare?" or when we expressed dissatisfaction with the risotto "can I bring you something else?" etc etc - you get what I mean... 
We were having a large, fairly expensive meal at a very nice, upscale restaurant and our server was either clueless and/or completely insensitive to our satisfaction. Extremely disappointing - the experience will seriously make me question whether to go back, which is too bad. 
The place is pretty, the food is often tasty and the wine list is very special - largely Italian, which I don't know well at all, but the sommeliers are extremely helpful - they have always helped me find things I like (which is no small challenge) - they are truly great.  But this dinner was far from pleasant - bummer.
author: Ellen H.

description: I read the yelp reviews and decided to try this place tonight. Had a 1/4 litre of wine, chosen by my companion. It was pleasant. I also ordered the Tajarin, which wasn't bad, but unlike Vasco, it didn't have lasagna. It also seemed to be more about the atmosphere than the food. I prefer Capannina on Union if I'm going to be paying more than 25 quid/person for food. Still, maybe the other items on the menu justify the cost. Oh, dessert consisted of miascia or warm apple/pear bread pudding, which was good, but that is to be expected from an Italian restaurant in the financial district. Oh, and parking was surprisingly easy to find.
author: Hasan D.

description: I like this place. The service was decent, and the filet mignon--out of this world. Of course, I was starving before I got there so take that with a grain of salt.  I was here for dinner, so don't know what the ambiance is like for lunch.
author: Rosie S.

description: We booked Perbacco for a pre-theatre dining on a Saturday night, handsome decor, good service, interesting wine list especially the selections from different regions of Italy, generous appetizer and entree portions, alas the desserts are average and could use some imagination and improvement.  No privacy in the main dining room, though, the tables are so closely arranged your fellow diners' conversation can easily be overhearad.  Overall, a lovely dining experience.
author: J S.

description: I came here for a birthday and had a great time.  Our server was nice and looked like she loved her job.  Its a loud-ish restaurant and suits large parties well with their large space and giant booths upstairs (recommended).  Four stars for their cured meat plate. mmMMmm.
author: Aileen N.

description:
Everything was elegantly presented, and while the menu is for traditional service, it lent itself well to the four of us creating more of a tapas, shared luncheon. Starting with the housemade salumi and burrata cheese plates, we were off to a great start.  Terrific flavors with interested herbs and spices in the various cured meats - I even dared to try the blood sausage, which was surprisingly delicate in flavor.  The pastas were over the top scrumptious - truffle herbed ricotta gnocchi were delicate pillows of yumminess, the butternut squash lune were delicate, earthly goodness in a light sage butter. The lamb was delectable, perfectly prepared and served with a basil/parsley tapenade of sorts. The desserts were on par with the rest of the menu - inventive balances of flavors - spice cake with pomegranate, trio of flavorful gelatos. Refined Northern Italian flavors, with a focus on market freshness. Service was great; the right balance of attentiveness and fabulous recommendations. While the wine list is nearly overwhelming, the recommendations from the wine steward/ess and our waiter did us right!

Such a fabulously decadent lunch!
author: Danielle R.

description: For a city like San Francisco with so many great restaurants, the food at this place needs to get an upgrade. While the main courses were good, the appetizers really need to go back to the drawing board.
author: Michelle Y.

description: Love it!  The must have is the fritto misto!  It is so light and fresh!  I always ask for pasta, meat, and dessert recommendations from the server which has never failed.  It's also a cool place to go with friends for a "date night".
author: Teresa M.

description: I took a girlfriend here for lunch on her birthday a while back.  The food was great.  I love their simplistic dishes and the service was excellent.  The only thing I didnt like was their bread.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Another highly recommended restaurant...we took 1 of my best girlfriends here to celebrate her 30th birthday.  The service was excellent - the restaurant was sweet had a birthday card handwritten to my gf when we arrived at our table.  
We shared starters: yellowfin tuna w/watermelon, mint and pepper - a-ok, it was interesting to try but could skip the next time I eat here. 
And the salumi misti - housemade, nothing notable/average.  
For dinner I ordered the truffle-herb ricotta gnocchi w/ roasted wild mushrooms - it was good & homemade.  My gf sitting next to me had the tajarin-handcut tagliatelle w/ 5 hr pork sugo & porchini mushrooms - I thought this was bomb!  Literally it was like ramen in a pasta dish.  Not sure if it's the Asian in me, but I might order this, if there is a next time.  Lastly, we shared the burnt caramel gelato w/ sea salt - I had no idea what I've been missing.  I could have this time & time again and not be sick of it.  Pasta prices were reasonable.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I followed the yelp recommendations to this place, which was convenient to my hotel and sounded, overall, delicious--assuming I got good service and the apparently bipolar food quality was on lithium.  I was not dissapointed.

On arrival alone at 8:00 on a Thursday, the place was swampped.  I could barely get in the door.  I weaseled my way to the bar and eventually grabbed a seat.  I was greeted by a very friendly and helpful chef (whatever you call the guy who does the appetizers--salumi and sashimi), and was immediately intrigued watching him prepare the various choices.  I was dying for the salumi misti, but quickly realized that I alone could not finish it, let alone try anymore food.  At the chef-guy's suggestion, I went for the CACCIATORINO SOTT'OLIO, a very rich hunter's salame--excellent for $7, almost filloing me up.  The bartender suggested a good red wine, which also was a good value.  I opted to get the Hamachi, which was very fresh and well-preapred with fennel and blood orange.  A sprinkle of sea salt brought out the buttery flavor.

For my main course, I went for the pappardella with short rib ragu.  You have to be in the mood for a very rich, sweet meal to appreciate this, and I was, even though I could have stopped at the salame and been satiated.  The pasta was perfectly cooked, not al dente, the ragu was meaty and tasty, and the horseradish added a bite that balanced the sweetness of the ragu.

I'll go back.
author: Jackson B.

description: One of the truly great Italian restaurants in the country.  Thier pasta sauce is so good you would be willing to buy it and eat it right at the table.  Their service is exceptional as is their wine list.  But the food is a wonder to behold!
author: Ron C.

description: Perbacco had great service, a huge wine list, and ok food. people had raved this place was the best value in the city, but i can't see how, aside from the fact that it is next to Aqua and insanely cheaper. it still isnt all that cheap, and although the food we had wasnt bad, it didnt deserve the rep we had heard. between 5 people we had quite  bit of food. the octopus was real good, the vitello was ok, can't remember other apps. entrees the pork wasnt anything to write home about, fish was good, and the pasta dishes good but not great. this place is more hype than substance
author: Rich B.

description: We had our celebratory wedding dinner here last Friday.  We had 17 people and reserved the Barolo Room.  The room was absolutely perfect.  Our server was so friendly and helpful and fun.  The food was some of the best I've ever eaten.  We asked the restaurant for help with our preselected wine and it was wonderful.  The overall experience was more than I could have hoped for.  Our guests cannot stop raving about how great everything was.  I highly recommend Perbacco!!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Amazing food, very good service and a beautiful dining room.  One of the top five restaurants in San Francisco, and much easier on the pocket book than many of the others.
author: C. W.

description: The food was terrific despite a complex menu... the bus folks kept our breadbaskets full... a really pleasant meal had by all.
author: H W.

description:
Outstanding food a very reasonable price.  Service was as good as it gets. If anything too quick. I split the tarajin or pork sugo pasta as an appetizer.  This is one of the most memorable dishes I have had in a awhile. I noticed quite a number of folks around us also ordered the dish, a flat noodle with tomato sauce and pulled pork. The duck breast for the main course was perfect. 

The wine list is goes on for ever.  Lots of italian wines but an excellent choice from.   Many bottles priced in the $40-$80 range.  Wines also came in a 500 ml carafe, great where half bottles are too little and full bottles too much. The waiter seeinghow interested I was in knowing about italian wines gave me a great introduction.  Where I was unsure about a wine he brought "sipping" samples until I found one I enjoyed.

As if this was not enough the ricotta cake incredibly rich yet not at all heavy sent us to heaven.
author: Bill P.

description: It's rare I go to a restaurant more than once in San Francisco (there are too many to try!) but Perbacco is an exception. It's absolutely fantastic in terms of food, service, and ambiance. Would highly recommend.
author: Sydney L.

description: "I love the relaxed feel of this place - tables are spacious and not too crowed in room. I definitely would return to try more dishes. The grilled calamari appetizer was amazing and the Burrata salad was refreshing. Loved the Rabbit Agnolitti and the side dishes were quite tasty - brussel sprouts and romano beans with bacon. Service was well-timed and friendly. Caramel gelato was "to die for", melt in your mouth - favorite over the chocolate plate. Only disapointment, I asked for my left overs to be wrapped up - Rabbit agnolitti and romano beans and the food runner put the pasta and beans in one small box. The bacon flavor did not meld well with the pasta, which was a great disapointment the runner did not take care to put in seperate boxes."
author: georgie g.

description: I went there after ice skating downtown in December.  The place was happening late, and was fun.  The food was above average, and the service was great.  The only negative was that the restroom is down a weird staircase just outside the restaurant (some other interior within the building).
author: Aim M.

description: oh burrata, how i love thee. the burrata here is good - a tiny bit inferior to A16, but very good and HUGE. It's so big that it's really too much for 2 as a starter, which isn't to say that i don't get it anyway. The 5-hour pork sugo is good too. I agree that it's a very different vibe upstairs from down - i generally prefer down, unless you're trying to have a serious conversation, for which up is quieter. My one gripe is that the bathrooms are in outer mongolia.
author: Erica W.

description:
I have been to Perbacco twice for lunch and have really like the atmosphere.  The service is solid also.  The food is good but not spectacular.  I had pasta both times; it was well prepared but nothing exceptional.  This is a perfectly good place for a business lunch or whatever, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there.

SFD
author: Peter H.

description: I have been here a hand full of times.  I can never seem to get a reservation, but if you are patient you can squeeze in sometimes.  I think the food and service is wonderful.  They have a great selection of cured meats, some are even a little too scary for me to try.   When I am in the mood for upscale Italian, this will always be my answer in SF.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: You know I have to say I am kind of surprised by some of the negative reviews about this amazing restaurant both on Yelp and from others I have spoke with. I have always received amazing service at this place. Their cure their own meats (YUM!) and have the most amazing deserts.  The wait staff is so nice and helpful in course selections as well. The owner, who is so nice and friendly, is always coming around to the tables to make sure everything is going smoothly (very traditional Italian restaurant). It is always packed so make sure you make a reservation!
author: Jessica K.

description: Very loud for lunch (on the lower level) but excellent dining! The heirloom tomato salad was decadent as was my pear dessert. Would definately suggest it again!
author: Rose J.

description: Filled to the gills with the business crowd. The salt cod was good, but I thought that the food was way overrated. The food was kind of on the heavy side and the agnolotti were ehh.
author: Molly T.

description:
(in the interests of full disclosure...  i didn't pay, so i can't speak to that aspect of the dining experience.)

i thought it was just okay.  i had the steak, and it was definitely overcooked - i asked for rare, and got medium.  

from what i gathered, it seemed like a pretty posh place - so make sure you're dressed somewhat nicely.
author: Matt P.

description: We are more than a little spoiled here in The City. What we consider mediocre is probably magnificent elsewhere and our magnificent is orgasmic almost anywhere else. So, is Perbacco's food magnificent? Probably not by our twisted standards, but it is very good. What makes this place great, though, is the overall experience. In a previous life, I worked in restaurants and one axiom is that great service can make up for not-so-great food, but great food will not make up for bad service. At Perbacco you get good food, but you also get great service (and usually with an accent). I have always felt very taken care of and very appreciated as a patron here. You get the full-on dining experience. You pay for that experience, true, but all-in-all, I think you get a nice return on that investment.
author: Don B.

description: Very nice indeed. I almost tried out every appetizer. The squid salad is good. Ravioli with rabbit meat is unique. The soup is excellent. The crowd and the setting is boring cause they try to be legit for businessman and woman.
author: Meo M.

description: Yum, yum, YUM!!  Superb service (go with David MacDonald and you're in) and food.  My favorites were the angliotti stuffed with veal, the pork chop, and the caramel gelati with sea salt (O my god).  Cute touches like the faux crushed plastic cups containing dessert and hip silverware.  I sound like a yuppie -- just blending in with the crowd there, really.
author: Linda N.

description: Very nice ambiance.I had the fried octopus and fish. Both tasted great. The best part of it was the dessert. Yum
author: David S.

description: They don't change the pasta menu often, which is a good thing.  But the panna cotta newly added to the dessert menu was SO excellent!  A lot of flavors but not rich at all!  The chocolate truffle and the cream were the best companions of it.
author: Ile F.

description: Went here again for my birthday and it was even better than the previous visit. What a great place!
author: Shwetha R.

description: very upscale place in the financial district and likely the kind of place where high powered people lunch during the weekday noon hours...as for the rest of us, my friends and i came here on a weekend evening for a meal and were entertained with delicious food, attentive service, and a nice lavish atmosphere to enjoy each other's company!
author: Grace O.

description: agnolotti dal plin
author: Nick C.

description: Great food but the service is spotty.  Not that it is bad it's just that some waiters are good and other are FANTASTIC.   I like the shortribs here.  I've tried several of the appetizers when I've come with co-workers and everything is always good.  Great place to take a coworker when they've done a good job or to celebrate a promotion.  They don't rush you out and depending on the waiter if you tell them a head of time that you are celebrating a promotion or some other occasion they will bring the person out a free dessert.  Again it depends on the waiter
author: P S.

description: I really like this place a lot. The service varies from ok to great-- pending on who you have serving you... but what makes me give this place 4 starts is really the food and the wine list. The salumi platter is fantastic and my favorite of all the appetizers but to be fair I haven't tried an app here that I didn't like and the pastas are to die for.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The first time I ate here back in May, we had awful service.  However, I have been back twice recently and the experience was MUCH improved.  Wasn't a huge fan of the rabbit ravioli, but really, who eats rabbit?  I highly recommend the ravioli with chard and pine nuts, and definitely try the burrata cheese.  So delish!
author: S B.

description: I had a business dinner here last Wednesday.  The bread sticks were so delicious that I pretty much stuffed myself with them before the dinner was served.  I had duck breast with roasted peach and peach sauce.  It was really tasty!  If I was not so full, I would definitely try the pistachio cake for dessert.  I like the fact that the restaurant offered a plate of sweets after the dinner so I got some sweet, but not too much!  I think everyone would agree that no meal should end without some sweets!  Oh, the bathrooms were downstairs and you have to make 2 or 3 turns before you can get there.  I almost got lost...  I was not alone as there was a man wondering in the lady's area when I finally found my way there...  :)
author: Michelle H.

description: Went here last night for dinner.  The high points included the cocktails, the salumi platter, and the duck.  The not-so-high points included the rabbit (overcooked) and the salad with hazelnuts (boring). The service really sets this place apart.  I told the server that I thought the rabbit was overcooked, and he immediately whisked it off the table, the sommelier instantly appeared with a plate of gnocchi so I would have something to eat while my husband ate his pasta, and then they brought us the duck to share after we finished the pasta and gnocchi.  I was a little embarrassed to send a dish back, but it's obvious that the staff at Perbacco really want each customer to leave happy, and we certainly did.  Both our server and the sommelier were friendly and helpful.  I would definitely go back.
author: Michelle A.

description: I had high expectations, but was somewhat disappointed.  First of all, the service is amazing and is a nice treat.  Too bad what they bring to the table doesn't match professional friendly service.  I had the mushroom risotto. Sure, they had another fancy name for it, but get real, it was mushroom risotto...and it was very over salted.  Mushrooms have an earthiness that stands on its own, no need to muck it up by shoveling heaps of salt in the dish.  I had also ordered a beet salad, but it was so uninspiring that I forget many of the details surrounding it.   Look, Perbacco isn't a horrible restaurant - it's just doesn't live up to the hype stirred up by the hyperventilating foodie crowd.
author: Lulu C.

description: I have been to Perbacco twice and really enjoyed the food both times.  I especially like the short ribs, the tagliatelle and the caramel/ sea salt gelato.  Service is very helpful and not snooty.  The atmosphere is a little bland for my taste.  A good place to impress the in-laws!
author: Melissa K.

description: We went for dinner on Friday night to celebrate our anniversary.  We were very happy!  Our waitress was great, didn't rush us at all and allowed us to take our time.  Food was great...definitely try the burnt caramel & sea salt gelato if you can.  Great!  :-)  We will be eating at Perbacco again!
author: Ann W.

description: Overall, a very lovely restaurant with great Italian cuisine. I understand why this restaurant is on some of the best lists in SF, The service is stellar and food is scrumptious but I think Oenotri in Napa is giving Perbacco some stiff competition. I came her last month with my sister and we shared a bunch of things, all delish. I recommend the pasta sampler or salumi plate. We also ordered the veal tartar, which was strangely chewy and had a gummy texture, not good! I'm a fan of ordering items  that you normally couldn't make yourself so the homemade pasta's don't disappoint. I seem to remember the riccotta meyer lemon gnocchi and a veal stuffed ravioli. We also ordered the brussel sprouts which were super good but can easily be re created at home. This review may sound a little snobby because Perbacco really is a 5 star restaurant but I think there are a lot of great Italian restaurants out there to still be discovered.
author: Jaimie B.

description: I dined with my friend on Monday, March 22 & we had a spectacular meal.  Despite the energy and noise of the dining room, we were able to have a romantic dinner.  Offering wine by the glass selections in two glass 250ml decanters is a great idea and helped us pair wines to our courses.  We enjoyed the arugula & strawberry salad, seafood risotto, rabbit ravioli (angolotti), Piedmontese blood sausage, cheese & dessert.  The food was delicious & portions were large enough despite the fact we split everything.  We enjoyed a glass each of Franciacorta  brut, a muller-thurgau from Alto Adige, a 375ml bottle of Barolo & a 20 year tawny from Taylor-Fladgate.  Service was impeccable; quiet, omnipresent & knowledgeable.  The speed and efficiency of the kitchen given the quality of the food is incredible.  I highly recommend Perbacco to you.
author: Tom B.

description: We went there for dinner a while back, I remember it was good but most of all I remember it was unbelievably loud. Couldn't carry out a conversation, and the guy at the next table was actually screaming. We donwloaded a decibel-meter onto the iPhone and saw the reading jump into the danger zone more than once. I'm sure there are other more pleasant places to spend an evening.
author: G H.

description: I hosted my fiance's 40th birthday dinner here this weekend (12 people at one table).  The services was perfect, the food even better and our table was set out of the way in a private area.  It was a fantastic night.  Perbacco staff were accommodating and kind.  We had a Merry Edwards Pino Noir that was wonderful.  The food came out quickly (not too quickly) and perfectly prepared for all guests.  The desserts were to die for.  Simply delightful.  I will go back again and again.
author: Julie H.

description: Good but nothing special.  Rack of lamb was overly salty.  Waitress was pleasant.  Not worth the price.
author: Ming H.

description: Very very satisfying meal, beautifully presented and for the most part delicious. I'd say the food was very good but not incredible. I didn't find myself wanting more but it was creative and very good. The space is beautiful and that was what made it special. The service was also very good bordering on excellent. Overall another great restaurant in a city chock full of them.
author: Roger G.

description: Four stars?? Really?  The salami plate needed some time hanging from the ceiling, 4 out of the 5 were more like mushy salami pate.  A mixed green salad was as boring as anything. Two pastas to avoid-bolognese out of a can plopped on dry egg noodles. Blech.  Gnocchi, soft and light, with salty brothy sauce with rubbery mushrooms. Very disappointing in the height of mushroom season. Truffle meals start nov 9, but after asking twice, no go for lunchtime truffles only 3 hours away from dinner. Our waiter did not move things in the right direction.  I was looking forward to perbacco as I heard so many great things, but sadly I won't be returning.
author: Lisa P.

description: Lunch for two with two appetizers and two pastas was $60.  Pappardelle  Short Rib Ragu reminded me of something from Scala's in Union Square.  I just finished a review that said chef worked there for 8 years !  Service was so-so but they are just starting off.  A great spot for financial district lunch to impress but I'd rather eat at Tadich next door for that old San Francisco feeling.  Next time I'm on the hunt for great pasta, I'll find my way to Scala's.  My advice : put on that 80s power suit and try it out.  It's not bad, just not special enough.
author: Beautiful B.

description: Fantastic good, great server.  Minus one star for the duck being a little boring, but everthing else shinned.
author: e w.

description:
I wish I could give this place four and a half stars but I guess it's not allowed.  The meal overall was amazing but it was a little too heavy on the butter and oil.  It's a personal preference thing.
I'm not a huge fan of Italian food and pasta in general but I thoroughly enjoyed my dinner here consisting of 5 small pasta dishes, one main, 2 appetizers, and 4 desserts (we like sugar).  The hamachi was delicious but nothing spectacular.  The salt cod, crab, golden yolk appetizer with the fennel and arugula salad was delicious but how could anyone go wrong with creamy egg yolk and something that resembled a cross between a latke and crabcake?  the chard, herb, and ricotta ravioli topped with walnut oil were delicious and were followed by some pouchy pasta filled with veal (i cried a little for the baby cow and then got over it because it was so good).  We had another pouchy pasta filled with rabbit and truffle oil, and thought to myself, "eating these little guys is better than sex."  The lamb was cooked perfectly in my opinion (dining partner would have liked to see it a little more rare).  The last pasta dish had wide pasta with chanterells and some beef ragu.  T'was my least favorite dish.  Tasted like high-end cafeteria food...just not that great.  Melon sorbet was my favorite dessert.  The chocolate mousse, ugly cookies, and apple  tart were good, but you could imagine when they'd taste like.  No need for me to 'splain.
As far as ambiance and service...Boss-man and I were seated at a lovely corner table (prime table for people watching, my favorite pastime) and received excellent service.  The plates were coursed two at a time as we requested and were set at a good pace.  I also love the feel of the restaurant.  It's elegant but not at all stuffy.  it's lively with the bustle of people chatting and it's bright enough inside for me to see what i'm eating...and of course to people watch aka find hot men and rape them with my eyes...
oh one last comment.  The bathroom set up suuuucks...they mix up the girls and boys room!  that's soo not cool.
author: Vonnie L.

description: I had high expectations for this place and in the end the experience fell a bit short.  I ordered the "signature" dish which was some sort of short rib pasta and while it was certainly good it wasn't very interesting and I found myself bored with it half way through.  That paired with a mealy heirloom tomato salad and my impression of the food simply was not great.  However, the prices were fair and the service was very good.  If you go to Perbacco try to reserve a table on the ground floor as the upstairs was a bit drab and had an odd odor.
author: Ben M.

description:
Perbacco is, hands down, my favorite restaurant. Here are just a few reasons:

1. Scallop crudo with pomegranate, mint, and olive oil. Completely luscious. My mouth waters just thinking about it. I would come for this alone. 

2. Warm, professional staff that are perfectly attentive, make recommendations, then leave you to your meal. 

3. Rich, delicious stewed meats with handmade pasta, like the agnolotti with rabbit and truffle. 

4. Gooey in the middle, warm and crusty on the outside, pistachio cake. 

5. The Notte Picante, a spicy cocktail special. A gimlet with a twist. 

I've never had a bad dish at Perbacco, and I almost hate talking to people about it because I don't want it to get any more crowded than it is! But the staff is so nice and friendly, I have to give them their due. Go to Perbacco, you won't be disappointed.
author: Tim H.

description: This is a solid resaurant.  Good for lunch, or a semi-romantic dinner.  The food is very good.  The Service is also very good.  I have been here twice and felt like I could have paid more for what we got.  Though not cheap, it is a good value.
author: Mike A.

description: If I could give Perbacco 3.5 stars I would. I went to a business dinner here last night and had an okay experience. Perbacco is LOUD, which makes it difficult to hear the person you're dining with. Also, I found the service to be a tad on the slow side. I'm all for leisurely, relaxed dinners but this felt like it was lagging. The food was good, though, and my glass of wine was delicious. Perhaps better as a lunch spot?
author: Shannon C.

description:
Authentic Italian handmade pastas with rich sugos... risottos are great too.
The fritto misto app is light and crunchy with a nice tang from the fennel and olives.
They also serve a delicious elderberry lemonade...so floral and exotic.
author: Sara K.

description: I am giving Perbacco five stars for the food since the food was tremendously tasty.  I was there last night with four others, we shared the appetizers and the main meals.  I was shocked at how good the food was after reading so many "ok" reviews on Yelp.  Maybe that's what needs to be done with this review, don't hype it up and let the guest be surprised at how good the food is.  The service was also very good.  The establishment was not so good, it reminded me of an upscale diner.
author: Aras A.

description: Perbacco is amazing and I can't recommend it highly enough.  Everything was fantastic from the moment we were greeted at the door.  Our waiter Moe rocked!  He gave us great recommendations on both food and drink and the overall service was stellar!  I will definately be back.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Really, really enjoy this place.  Been there for lunch and happy hour several times since I work near by and have never been disapointed by the food, drinks or the staff. The cured meat plate has to be one of the best I have ever had. I highly recomend this place if you work/live in the area or even if your visiting and just happen to be in the financial district.
author: Carter H.

description: I had the good fortune to be taken here for a "welcome to the company" lunch.  We had reservations for lunch and despite the noon-time crowds, we were quickly shown to our table.  The menu provided some great choices and the service was a real treat (our waiter was phenomenal).  The crowd seemed to attest to the quality food and service.  I will most definitely be back!
author: prior O.

description: I don't know, several of my friends think this place is really good. However, I have yet to have any food at this place that my taste buds would put in the really good to great category. Yes, the food is always fine. But Top 100 (SF Gate/Chronicle)?
author: Troy H.

description:
Four of us had a truly memorable meal here last weekend!  Initially we felt really out of place in the middle of the midwestern-Denny's-style upstairs dining room - a bunch of loud, high women surrounded by the staid and wealthy elderly crowd - but the servers were amazingly welcoming and gracious and responsive to our whoops of delight over the flavor extravaganza.  We brought a bottle of wine with us, but it needed to be decanted, so we ordered a half-liter.  The lovely sommelier came over and said that if we just got the whole bottle instead of the half liter, it would actually save us money because then the corkage would be waived on the bottle we brought.  That was so thoughtful!  And although she reminded us we could bring our leftover wine with us, we ended up drinking it all anyway!
The pork chop with the pomegranate was spectacular - there was something so rich and fatty (in a good way) about it, it felt like we were eating the soul of the pig.  The other truly outrageous item we freaked out over was the "chocolate cake", which was not chocolate cake, but a plate of different chocolate concoctions of varied flavors and textures.  In conjunction with the burnt caramel gelato, this was one of the best dessert experiences I've ever had.
author: lighter g.

description: Perbacco is one of our regular dinner spots.  The staff is always so friendly.  Ask to be seated in Michael's section.  He's so attentive and everything...and I mean EVERYTHING that he has recommended..never fails.  Thanks for suggesting the Veal Agnolotti, Mike!!!  The food is amazing.
author: Cooper T.

description: Without a doubt delicious! Those veal angolloti (sic) are divine (as is most everything)! Amazing food, great wine list, and excellent, professional service. The value of this restaurant is amazing. I love the bar area atmosphere the best.
author: Alice C.

description:
We were treated kindly, maybe a bit over eagerly by the waiter, who was friendly, but interrupted our conversations a few times too often asking if everything was okay.
The food was very mixed: We had the raw scallops and raw hamachi appetizers, and though the fish tasted good, it was quite horrendously overpriced. There were four translucent slices of scallop on the plate, and a few pieces of an herb - definitely not the promised arugula - which made each paper thin slice cost three dollars. The hamachi portion was a wee bit more generous, but only by an ounce or two.
With the main courses you also have to expect that if you order the smaller portion, it will be really small. The agnolotti with veal were very tasty, the short rib sauce that comes with the papardelle is excellent too, but the papardelle themselves were not very well cooked, too al dente, and still sticky.
Our friends ordered the grilled squid as starter and the pear salad. The squid was great, and the salad quite good. Our friends' risotto also tasted good, and the sole was nice and the only dish where we felt the portion size matched the price.
We were also very satisfied with the desserts: a lemon semifreddo, and a squash crostata with fennel gelato.
All in all it was a pleasant dining experience, but we felt that even though the individual price attached to each dish is not too bad, looking back at the quality of the food as well as the amounts you get, it still felt over prized.
author: Ursula S.

description: Heard some good things about this place. I came here for lunch with my sister and we started off with the salumi and beet salad. The salumi was a good sized appetizer to share. It was pretty standard (and hard to screw up, so long as you knew how to use a deli slicer): mortadella, coppa, salami, prosciutto, etc. The beet salad was great. The beets were sweet and the dressing gave it a good contrast. The pork shoulder with polenta was ok. I'll admit, it looked kind of funny when it came out and had this creamy, brown gravy over the meat. I figured that was the "al latte" part of the dish name "Berkshire pork shoulder al latte". I can't say I've had a perfectly round and boneless piece of pork shoulder before, but I decided not to dwell on that thought. All in all the meal was average. Perhaps I'll try the pasta dish next time.
author: David S.

description: Loved it all!  Agreed that's it's not a young crowd, but it's nice for a low-key dinner.  The octopus salad was good, as was the fesh burrata cheese.  Delicious dinners all around (my risotto was rich and creamy) and loved the brown butter brussel sprouts.  Dessert was my fave though - I had the meyer lemon with berry compote.  It came with candied lemon peel that I wish I could buy by the bagful.  My husband had the gelato tro and the caramel one with the salt was to die for!  Would definitely go back.
author: JP D.

description: The food rocks (5-hour sugo, nummy!).  The in-house cured meats are great.  The wine list is lovely.  The waiters are nice and competent.  Alas, the front of house staff sucks.  Snotty, rude and quite full of themselves.  I have been here four times and they same terrible treatment at the door.   Simply not necessary and casts a black mark on an otherwise delightful dining experience.
author: Kris S.

description: So, I've been on this yellow-tail kick and have three restaurants that top my list.  Perbacco has the second best.  Their "crudo" appetizer changes, but most recently they served healthy portions of the fish in a blood-orange reduction with shaved fennel on top. The combo made for a wonderful sweet/savory mixture.
author: Chris S.

description: When my husband and I were planning to try Perbacco, we knew the food would be fantastic - it is on theTop 100 list, afterall.  However we were also very pleasantly surprised by the absolutely phenomenal service and the gorgeous atmosphere.  We had an amazing meal - everything was absolutely perfect!  We both agree it is one of the best dining experiences we've had in San Francisco, which is, of course, saying a lot!
author: Jessica T.

description:
Excellent addition to the Financial District.  Great place for date night as well as meeting up with friends after work.

The pork sugo pasta is sublime.  The desserts, however, need some help.
author: Jessi T.

description: We had a very nice light dinner at Perbacco.  We ordered 4 appetizers and a cheese plate.  The great waiter we had picked a perfect wine for everything and he brought it all out in courses.  The food was very good and our waiter was awesome.
author: John S.

description: 5 stars for Mo, who is our favorite waiter at Perbacco!  Friends celebrating one of our very own's B-Day last Friday, started things off at the bar at Perbacco. Having been there many times before for lunches and dinners, we had the pleasure in the past of having Mo as our waiter. He is terrific and Perbacco is lucky to have him!   He was kind enough to take a minute and join our group last Friday for a picture with the birthday girl!  Thanks Mo!
author: M C.

description:
I had an ok dinner with my cousin here the other night- i had been meaning to try this place for while, but I think my expectations were a little high.

Food was good.  I liked the hard bread sticks and pesto to start, but the bread rolls that came after were too hard for my liking and I had trouble cutting it with the provided knife- my cousin had a second one and said that batch was marginally softer.  The potato gnocchi with a veal ragu was very tasty and the highlight of my meal- this may tempt me to come back.  Not too salty and just the right texture.  My beet salad was ok- a little bland. They give you little dessert finishers before your bill- not exactly sure what they were since i had stepped away when they were served.

Table service was average, but still professional.  Nothing stood out especially good or bad.  Neither myself or my cousin liked the suggested wines for our meals, but since neither of us are very familiar with italian wines in the by he glass selection it is half our fault:-) They did let my cousin check his suitcase as he was leaving for the airport directly after.

The atmosphere.  it looked really nice when i came in, but the longer i was there the less i liked it.  The tables were too close.  Being taken to our table the waitress had to ask two different diners to move in so we could get to our table.  The same difficulty existed when trying to get out to go the bathroom- I had to squeeze through.  I'm not sure if we just got the worst table in the whole place or if other tables are similar- I didn't see any reviews mentioning this so I thought I would mention it.  I felt like i was sitting with the table next to us.  We were also right near one of the support columns that seemed to contrast with the vibe of the other furniture- dark wood chairs/modern looking space- it made me feel even more crowded.  My other complaint was the bathrooms- I think a bit of this has to do with the space they got- but the paint on the walls was a weird brown and was chipping on the way to the bathroom and it seemed like the stairs were also used for entry and exit of supplies as it was a little industrial.  The bathrooms themselves didn't feel very clean- especially the floor.  For a place that is trying to be so nice it just seemed weird.

I won't be rushing back, but I may give it a second try at some point.  The tall table at the back near the kitchen looked nice for a big group- lots of room.  Hopefully next time a more pleasant experience...
author: Maria F.

description: Good reliable destination for biz lunch.  Attentive service, reasonable pricing.  SF financial district deserve several more like it.
author: Frenchy B.

description:
first they'll provide you w/ stick bread and some green dipping sauce.
i recommend the beet insalata, & fried calamari for appetizer & also gnocchi w/ mushroom...humm yumm yumm...
good service, nice food, i've been here so many times, mostly all the food are delicious! every time i come here, it's always noisy & energetic,  so if you want romantic/to-whisper say-i-love-you, don't come here, it's really good for groups, 
i like the ambience, so far i 'm lovin' it!
author: Ms C.

description: The pastas are really-really good. Very developed flavors and perfectly cooked pastas. I made reservations but canceled and decided to go with a friend and sit at the counter. We asked the waiter to recommend a moderatley priced red wine sine their wine list is HUGE. He did and it was good- as he said "it goes good with food" sounds like a sure thing right? The appetizers sounded a little boring so we skipped that course and got two pastas.  I want to go back and try other items on the menu anyways, maybe for lunch. Check this place out, one of the staples of SF dining!
author: C. G.

description: Fantastic place.  The place looks small from the outside however once you get past the bar it expands nicely.  The restaurant and bar are decorated nicely.  The menu has a little bit of everything for everyone from sushi and salami to pasta and steak.  The service is very good and knowledgeable.  I have eaten here 6 times and every time it has been absolutely fantastic.  My favorite so far has been the ribeye steak.  The salami selection is expansive and very tasty.  The wine list has a little of everything but highlights are definitely Italian.  I have sat at the bar and at the tables and the service in both locations have been excellent.
author: Dion G.

description: We dined 5/8 it was a bit noisy - especially with the wasted guys next to us - but the food was incredible, wine list - fantastic, and the service was the best we have received in a long time.    We came straight from the gym and were not dressed like the rest - at all - but were treated well from the friendly hostess raving about the food to our waiter - Adam - total pro.  Definitely recommend
author: Kasi S.

description: After writing my recent review, I received a very kind, genuine and heartfelt email as a response to my feedback. To me, customer service is what defines the exceptional from the mediocre. And the attention to detail was more than I have ever received or expected. I cant wait for my return back to Perbacco and am certain that my next food choices will receive a stellar review with 5 stars! Thanks Perbacco for distinguishing yourself from the many restaurants in San Francisco. It was a breath of fresh air!
author: Jillian K.

description: Went here on 7/22, courtesy of a corporate entity. I had read sample Perbacco menus and reviews, saw that it was heavy on the meat, esp. processed meats, so I wasn't expecting much. There were 2 entree choices for our party - either filet mignon or scallops - and I picked the latter. What came out was as follows: bread sticks - nice, but I'm not a stick fan.
