There was some sort of tasty dip, perhaps a chimichurri, to dip them into, and that gave them a little flavor. Next, real bread. Delicious, soft with a good crust, and fresh butter. The salad was mixed greens - arugula, radicchio, and endive.  Tiny granules of salt and pepper sparkled on the tongue - a nice effect, but sprinkled a little too generously for my taste. I would have preferred more vinegar in the vinaigrette. The scallops were huge and perfectly cooked - charred on each side of the "coin" and soft in the middle. The sauce was a demiglace or reduction, scattered with corn kernels, sauteed slices of wild mushroom, and little nubbins of something else - perhaps fennel. So good I had to sop it up with my bread.  Dessert was divine panna cotta with a mixed berry sauce. I don't know whose Pinot Gris I had, but I'm sure it had no effect on my judgment :) I'll be back soon to try the other dishes. Gotta introduce this place to my hub.
author: Leigh G.

description: Thoroughly enjoyed this place. Loved the squash blossoms and the sage ravioli. We celebrated a special occasion, and service was attentive without being intrusive. Will definitely be back!
author: tatiana W.

description: Love the food and service. I have to agree with the noise levels and would give higher marks if this were different.
author: Bubba R.

description: The salmon with roe to start and pistachio cake to finish made for a very tasty meal. The stuff in the middle was really, really good, but I've been talking about that cake for days. Days. Restaurant in back a little too loud, but the area by the bar was very cool. Very comfortable, not too snooty.
author: Jen D.

description:
Had drinks and apps last night with a friend at 7:30pm. We had a table and the service was attentive without being annoying. For people having drinks, neither of us actually had an alcoholic beverage (for our own reasons). However, I did have the elderflower lemondaide. Scrumptious!

We shared the Salumi Misti, Hamachi, heirloom tomato salad and the Piastra seared prawns and squid. Every single dish was perfect. Fresh, well prepared, nice presentation.

I will come back here with my sweetie for dinner!
author: C S.

description:
Had a long slow dinner here with two friends last weekend.  Some things were outstanding, some things just ok.  I thought the burrata cheese was OK.  A16 does it way better.  There it is so soft and served very simply w/salt and olive oil on great toasted bread.  I thought the Perbacco version was an interesting combo (with the red pepper) but the cheese itself was on the tougher side and the bread it came with was just not up to snuff.   The appetizer that was incredible was the albacore crudo.  OMG.  Explosion of flavor and nice kick of salt.  I will be back for this.  I had the papardelle in short rib sauce.  I thought it was great.  Warm and rich on a rainy night.  perfect.  Then we ordered the chocolate mouse cake or something like that and it was disappointing.  I didn't care for it.  Kinda dry and just nothing special.  We also got the "ugly" piedmont cookies and those were GREAT.  I wanted a dozen to go.  We sat up on the balcony.  We all enjoyed ourselves and although every dish didn't hit, I will be very glad to go back for a cocktail and more crudo.

UPDATE:  Ate a late lunch here today and it was stellar.  the arugula salad w/fennel, orange and marcona almonds was perfect.  also had the pansotti in brown butter.  very good, but had better in italy.  had the radish greens too and they were perfect - tender and flavorful.  then dessert.  oh.  my.  god.  had the carmel bonet (new on the menu) w/apricot compote and carmel sauce.  had it with a glass of vin santo and it was absolutely perfect.  incredible.  just amazing.  once again, giving it 4 out of 5 stars.  service was very very good - relaxed and personal.  of course it was an odd hour and not many other diners, but still just great hostess, waiter and owner, were very attentive.
author: Celia S.

description: Went there to meet friends.  Beautiful setting, amazing food, good service.  Nothing not to like about this place.
author: Kat B.

description: The food here is amazing infact everything is amazing here.  I dined here for lunch and it was one of the best dining experiences I have had in the bay area.  The kale ravioli melted in my mouth and the salads were absolutely fantastic.  I had a couple of italian wines that were wonderful and the waitress knew the wine menu better than I know my own wardrobe.  I was impressed with everything.  If you want to impress your self and others come to Perbacco.
author: Olivia L.

description: I have been here a few times and each time was fabulous.  The service is always inpeccable and the food delicous, I think my favorite entree has been the duck, I have had it a prepared a few differemt ways and every time it is just as good.  Make sure to save room for cheese and dessert.  They have an amazing cheese selection.
author: Simon N.

description:
In a word, uneven.  Definitely some highs and lows here.  

Highs: 
The house cured meats (if you like that sort of thing)
Professional service, although a bit slow
Strawberry and arugala salad
Excellent quality fish

Lows:
Very loud even upstairs at the very back where you would expect it to be a bit more reasonable
An oil slick on every plate.  Every dish I tasted was overloaded with oil and/or butter.  The strawberry arugula salad was swimming in a bath of oil.  A tragic near drowning of lovely ingrediants that in no way needed or deserved such dousing of their fine flavors.  The kitchen also took a gorgeous good piece of sole and gave it a stomach turning bath in butter and oil.  

If I do go back I will ask for my food cooked with less oil.
author: RB P.

description: I went here for lunch today and it was great fun, hip, trendy, crowded, high energy, if you like that sort of thing.  I gave it three stars for the food, but I'd say four stars for the decor and atmosphere.  Plus, it's fun to go to the moderately fancy places for lunch at which time they won't gouge you to within an inch of your life.  I'd recommend it for lunch highly, but do find its name looking so much like  "tobacco" to be sort of weird and unappetizing.  I kept looking in my food to make sure they weren't trying to nicotine me up.
author: Matt R.

description: Okay. Made reservations for a work b-day party. Service was very nice. There were 11 of us and they were very attentive. Our server was always ready to pour more wine and definitley kept an eye on us in this way. The starters were nice. The mains were mixed all around. I had the braised pork shoulder, it was just okay,  it needed more flavor for sure, but the polenta that came with was superb- it was a coarse grain variety. Extremely yummy. The presentation for all plates brought to us was beautiful it's just that the flavor was lacking- for all of us, it just came up a bit short. I will go again tho- maybe it was an off day and I'd like to try other menu items. Again, I do have to say that it was a very fun and pleasant lunch- it's just some items are spot on and others can be missed. Great staff!!!
author: lisa t.

description: Not bad, but I was expecting more for my money. Food was flimsy at best, the recommended salami plate was lacking (plus, maybe it's just me, but eating that much meat/grease by itself was a test--only reason I finished the plate was for the price). Ragus almost seem to grab your taste buds but flavors are soft/back of the tongue, which is not what I prefer for something so hearty. But atmosphere, service, etc. was a plus.
author: E C.

description: WARNING:  Gratuitous 90's reference coming!!  HOLLA, this place is da BOMB!  This last Sat. evening my GF and I hosted a dinner for eight and everything was perfect!  We started at the bar and had drinks and then moved our party to the "Chefs Table"!  If you eat at Perbacco, I highly recommend trying to reserve this table.  This table is right between the open kitchen and main dining room.  We were definitely the center of attention of the restaurant...Having 4 hot women at the table doesn't hurt the attention quotient either!  ;-)  I can't rave about how smoothly the dinner went, from making and confirming the reservation with Perbacco's owner Umberto to the smooth service and looking the other way on the corkage fee for a number of bottles of wine which were had!  The food that evening was excellent.  My steak was cooked to perfection!  The pastas were OUTSTANDING and desserts  were even better.  I can't recommend Perbacco enough.  We will be going back....VERY SOON!  Ciao...
author: Art S.

description: solid place for business lunch.  i've ordered a variety of dishes and i have to say the short ribs are fantastic.  a bit heavy for lunch but it's worth it.
author: Nana S.

description: nice appys, pastas and desserts.  apple tart with fennel gelato was very nice, as was the fig panna cotta.  most of the pastas are a cut above.  definitely worth a try!
author: Junglist S.

description: Came here on a power lunch the other day. Was the youngest person in the restaurant (I'm not old enough to drink yet), but the plethora of suits really isn't too intimidating. Had the ravioli, which was fab. However, a waiter came and took away my diet Coke before I could even finish it. I give it four stars because the pesto/breadstick combination clearly makes every power lunch a successful one.
author: Lauren H.

description: Had dinner here (10/23) on "Friends and Family" night, the night before their grand opening.  Although the place is still working out a few kinks, it clearly has great potential.  Wam inviting interior (with booths!), full bar, exposed brick, etc.  Each table had a pre-selected menu, to help the chefs practice.  Highlights included the sirloin with roasted marrow and a sensational wine reduction sauce, short rib pappardelle (not quite as good as that at Rubicon), and poached pear in caramel & wine sauce.  It's hard to fully judge a restaurant without knowing the menu prices; needless to say, I'll definitely be coming back in a few weeks.
author: Dacheng Z.

description: This place is awesome!  My husband and I decided to check this place out because we'd heard good things about it and we happened to be in the area.  We had already eaten so we decided to sit at the bar and get some drinks.  They have a great Italian wine selection plus other wines that aren't on the menu (if you tell the bartender what you like, s/he will be able to pick something out for you if there isn't something on the menu that you are interested in).  I started out with a nice glass of Chardonnay, but eventually made my way to a really nice Barbera and an outstanding Montepulciano based on the bartender's recommendation.  My husband enjoyed some extremely well made Limonata Scozzeses by bartender Steve (his own creation!).  It was so nice and relaxing at the bar drinking some really good drinks, we decided to order some apps.  We went with the olives and the parmesian cheese plate.  Both were delicious.  The parm comes with bread, a wine reduction sauce and some other sauces and marcona almonds.  The olives are a meal themselves.  The ambience is great- comfortable but downtown trendy.  We were there on a Friday night and it wasn't too packed, but it was definitely full.   They could've used some music, but other than that, it was nice to sit back and enjoy the surroundings.  I will definitely be back!  Big props to the bartenders.   They make amazing drinks!
author: Maral P.

description: The food was great, the prices inflated, the service something fellini-esque, "La Dolce Casino" (loosely translated sarcasm: the big fat chaos). With a 30+ minute wait with our reservation, no less than 5 random waitstaff for our table, weaving in, out and around, bumping into us from our time at the bar to the table and back (wasn't even that crowded), messing up our order, forgetting an order, and being overly eager and seemingly omnipresent about asking "how is everything?" with a toothy grin. At one point my 3 dinnermates had their plates in front of them and I had nothing for a few minutes (before we could flag someone down). The waitress came by and asked, "Was there something wrong with your order?" Flatly, "Yes, it's not here." Terrible. I can't remember the last time I was in a restaurant and the state of service took center stage. Hopefully this newish restaurant is able to work out the kinks, the food makes it worth coming back for, but the service is bad enough to keep me from there till further notice.
author: rebecca z.

description: As Rachel Ray would say... YUM-O... i went out with my girls Krissy and Crystal and we had a great time.  They gave great recommendations for both wine and food.  Our server was quite energetic and very friendly.  She even passed a note onto this guy for us at the end of the night.  I call that super service.  We started off with 2 raw dishes.  The scallops and the hamachi.  Both were delightful and full of flavor.  Next we had ravioli and sweetbreads.  The sweetbreads were amazing and so tasty.  The ravioli was another highlight of the night.  Next, krissy had the short ribs which were tender and cooked to perfection.  I had the risotto which was alright.  Crystal had the truffle gnocchi.  We toasted to a great year of friendship and awesomeness with a glass of champagne.  Overall, it was a great night, with great food, and great conversation, even if our conversation was inappropriate for any setting other than in the privacy of your own home!
author: Aaron G.

description: This was our 3rd time at Perbacco.  The food and service was outstanding.  The salumi plate was delicious.  The pasta filled with braised short rib and the pasta filled with veal were both amazing.
author: Andrea P.

description: Two years later I finally went back to Perbacco - why did I wait so long?  It was even better than I remembered!  Delicious and inventive dishes.  Lots of food, wine and cocktails for a little over $100.  They brought us dessert on them for my BF's birthday.  Best deal in SF.  YUM!
author: Beth D.

description: LOVE IT!!  What a pleasant surprise!! Perbacco!!  My friend and I wondered around the city looking for something new we haven't tried and Perbacco caught our eyes.  It's next to Aqua and the lighting/atmosphere looked appealing so we decided to give it a try.  The staffs were friendly and attentive.  Everything on the menu looks mouthwatering and alluring including the coctails.  I ordered a Rosemarino with grey goose, rosemary ??? and brandy.  It was refreshing and tasty!  The bread sticks were flavorish.  The fennel salad paired with bloody orange, onion and anchovy was a surprisingly good combination.  I love the tagliatelle dish I ordered with 5 hour pork/mushroom sauce.  I don't know how to describe the texture of the tagliatelle I had at Perbacco.  It's better than al dante!  I wish I had more on my plate.  I had pistachio panna cotta for dessert and it's was the best panna cotta I have ever had.  I highly recomend the place for food, wines and cocktails.  As for the staging/layout of the restaurant, 3.5-4 stars depending on the occasion/my mood.
author: Gina W.

description: This is one of my old faithful spots to go to when I don't want to be disappointed with the food. I can say the pastas and the duck are amazing.
author: Mike S.

description:
talk about a disappointment... this was one of those dinners when i really wished we had stayed and eaten at the first place where we had drinks. an UNbelievably good passionfruit caiparinha at frisson! not that i'm a huge fan of frisson, but that drink was so amazing it is still making me weak in the knees days later, and perbacco was such a downer... i almost got in a fight with my boyfriend because everything was so NOT good - i had to take it out on somebody.

to start off with, we were seated along the side in the back behind one of the huge columns. now clearly the columns are structural, i know, but if you have these huge things blocking half the people's view in the restaurant... don't you want them to look nice?!  The wood paneling is cut poorly, the edges don't meet, the stainless steel corner gaurds don't come up to the top, and then they just secured it all with huge bolts right through the finish wood. it looks like a job someone's drunk uncle would do in cheap basement redesign. and it is directly at eye level! soooo shoddy! i realize it's not about the food, but it's like the age-old clean bathroom theory... if a place can't get those small details right, what's going on in the kitchen?

my cocktail was terrible (frisson ruined me)... way too sweet with no flavor but vodka and sugar with a sugar rim. and some sugar. oh, and did i mention it had sugar? first thing they tell us is that there's no more burrata which is the one thing i really wanted. watercress salad was fine. watercress and ricotta salata with o+v. maybe .50cents worth of product on the plate for $9.00. what is that, like a 450% mark up? 

then we tried to order wine but i am not knowledgeable about italian wines and these are far and away the bulk of what they have. the sommelier came over, but he had such a thick accent i really could not follow what he was saying. granted that was my problem, so i just got a glass of cab (and the waitress did nicely swap it for my unpalatable cocktail.) but it would really help to have the wine menu broken up into some categories like "big reds", "dry whites", etc.

for dinner i had risotto which was also just fine. nothing exciting or out of the ordinary in any way, shape or form. the risotto i had a few months back at chez spencer... that was extraordinary! my bf ordered rabbit or something (probably the real reason i was pissed at him - how can  you sit down and order thumper's cousin with your vegetarian girlfriend?) anyway, she brought one dish and after he took a couple bites she comes back and said she ordered him the wrong thing. she takes the plate and leaves him with nothing while we wait for his main dish. i've worked in a lot of restaurants, and usually it's polite if it's your fuck up to just let the customer enjoy what you brought them while their correct dish is cooked. it's not like someone else was going to be able to eat it after my boyfriend already started it. and of course i was finished by the time his came. and no, we did not even get a free scoop of gelato for that.

we did order 2 desserts - i always like to give a place a chance up until the very end. the panna cotta was not very good - it was not nearly as rich or nicely tectured as many in the city ( it is as chic as molten chocolate cake at this point), though it did have a good cookie with it. the coffee custard w/ chocolate crust was quite good, but the best part of the meal was certainly the sambucca. too bad perbacco didn't have anything to do with that, or they might have gotten another star.
author: eva g.

description: Well prepared food, stays true to Northern Italian cuisine, with a focus on the Piemonte region.
author: JJ M.

description: Wow is all I can say.  Checked out the restaurant last night and the food there is soooo good!  We had the veal pasta appetizer and beef tongue salad...so much flavor and just delicious!  Hubby had the honey roasted pork loin which was amazing.  This restaurant also has five star service.  We forgot our camera and the host came over to take our pictures three separate times since we wanted to get shots of the appetizer, entree, and dessert and emailed us the pics from his iphone (unbelievable service).  Also let my hubby park his lambo right infront of the restaurant, pretty cool!
author: C L.

description: Went to Perbacco on a recommendation.  Skip it, unless you are in the area, maybe with a group that can share a variety of items.  The food was pretty good, but the service was poor.  Understaffed with aloof waitstaff; simply taking your order and dropping off food does not match the look or its price.
author: Ed T.

description: Went for after work drinks and sat at the bar.  Great service, gorgeous space and huge menu.  Staff was really good and very friendly. We had the cheese plate and 3 glasses of wine - set us back $30/pp.    Not something I can afford every day but a nice spot to meet friends for an after work drink in the Financial District.
author: Celia P.

description: writing an update for perbacco since my recent dinner there was much better than the first.  the food was the same great quality but this time, the service was much better!  basically they just checked in more.  we were definitely taking our time and they weren't annoying about coming over to see if we wanted to order or get anything else, etc. but i appreciated the thought.  food was delicious - we started with the salumi platter (salumi is a fun word to say, by the way), had a few pastas, and for my entree i had the duck which was hearty and tasty.  the highlight of dessert was the salted caramel ice cream, although all 3 desserts that we tried were good.  now i will feel better about going back again!
author: Carolyn B.

description: i'm not a fan of italian food for the most part...however this place is my new favorite. i absolutely love this place. warm, spacious, nice big table. 9sounds ridiculous but when you're 5'9" and your dining companion is 6'4" we regularly take turns switching leg placement at places like A16 and Zuni.)  I loved the enthusiasm of our waitress, the service was warm, unpretenious. The food was great from start to finish. i can't wait to go back!
author: heather m.

description: I am really half and half on this place. I"ve read all of these amazing reviews, and could not wait to try it. Our meal consisted of one outstanding dish and four good ones. I was disappointed. We started with salumi ($12, two pieces of house cured salami) and it was good. Then we had the Testa, which is (baked?) pigs head. this was PHENOMENAL. and I am not normally an offal person, but fiance loves the shit so I indulged him. I ate it with my eyes closed so I could get rid of extra stimulus. That's how good it was. It had pickled onions on top and it tasted like warm, pickled heaven. At this point in our meal we were both quivering with excitement for things to come. Our next dish was the agnolotti (sp?) which was good. nothing spectacular. Then we had the pork shoulder. again, it was good. I actually don't remember what we had for dessert, so I guess that says it all for that dish. I'd like to try it again because people rave about it so much, but I'm beginning to think it's more the power of suggestion than the actual food.
author: Chaka K.

description:
second time here, and both were really very good.
agree with all the yelpers suggesting requesting tables upstairs; we were a party of six for one of their 50th bday party, and upstairs is much quieter and more conducive to conversation

both times: servers exceptional.  know what they're doing and do it right

food: started with communal salumi misto mixed plate and some salads. all salumi cured on-site and very interesting to try a sampling, with some education from the server as well.  some hits and some misses, but if you like cured meat and pate, nice exploration

pasta mid-courses were all great. also all made in house

main courses: this was the surprise, how good it all ways. expected the salumi and pasta to be superb, that is their wheelhouse after all, but the pork chop was PERFECT, the short ribs excellent, and so was the duck.  win:win:win.

only minor downer were the deserts, none of which were memorable.

we started our evening with drinks at aqua next door, and found a new drink there 'breath of summer' that i really liked too.  absolute citron/lemon/cucumber/veev acai liquor.  wonderful
author: neil s.

description: I am new to Yelp but I have experienced some great restaurants in the Bay Area and thought I would post some comments on those places that stand head and shoulders above the crowds...first on the list...for a weekend dining experience Perbacco...one of my favorite weekend date night dining experiences. The service is excellent, the food is superb, the wine list is more than complete and the ambiance allows for a romantic evening without it being stuffy...
author: Mike H.

description: I enjoyed this place immensely.  The house cured salumi plate is a must get.  Other great dishes:  Carne Cruda, Batsoa (trotter cake), and the Papperdelle with Rabbit.
author: Nate M.

description: Perbacco was recommended by the concierge at our hotel (The Clift) this weekend, as a good place that we could actually secure a same day reservation. Keep in mind i went to Quince the night before, which was an incredible meal, so i may be biased and anything i ate the next night might not have stood a chance. Overall just an ok place. Wine list is nice since you can select 1/4 and 1/2 liters rather than just glass or bottle. The mixed prosciutto/salami etc platter was a good sized serving for the price but nothing was that great. I had the beet salad which was also nothing special and the beets had something off about their taste. As an entree i tried the pork ragu pasta which, as a previous reviewer said, did kind of taste like hamburger helper..and the noodles tasted like runny ramen almost, and needed to be drained. My sister tried the rabbit agnolotti which was better than my pasta but still not memorable. The highlight was my mom's steak, which was surprisinglly good and had a great char. The waitress was also very friendly and helpful but unfortunately i wouldnt recommend this restaurant to any visitors to SF, maybe an ok choice for locals.
author: Sara B.

description: I am so pleased that Perbacco opened. It has proven to be excellent for an after work drink with servers who know how to help you chose an excellent wine. Great appentizers, everything on the salumi plate was amazing. So, already loving this place, I finally had the chance to eat here and am now in love. Had the 5 hour pork sugo -Tajarin which now occupies my dreams. Can't wait to return.
author: Cbr A.

description: Yummmm....I was really surprised at how great this place is and not that expensive for what you get.  We were seated right at the time of our reservation.  The hardest thing is deciding what to order.  The wines we tried were great and priced reasonably.  I didn't expect them to serve glasses in the $8 range and bottles in the $30 range.  They were all great.  I ordered the ricotta gnocchi with roasted tomatoes as a starter.  It was melt in your mouth good and light for gnocchi.  I had the beef short ribs with mashed potatoes, peas and fancy mushrooms.  It was all delicious.  A knife wasn't needed and the sauce was amazing.  My friends has the heirloom tomato salad, beet salad, lamb and tagliatelle with pork sugo.  All were also amazing.  We each had a cocktail, 1 bottle of wine and two dishes each and we each paid $68.  I think that was quite a deal for what we got.  Also, they didn't rush us and the service was great.  Will definitely go back.
author: Gina T.

description: Really first rate.  Friends took me here for a birthday dinner. I know good food and they also know good food and boy was this good.  Every single course was excellent.  I loved the way the main dishes were variations on a theme, you had the same food prepared a few different ways right on your plate.  The food was sort of high end comfort food, very satistying.  The cheese plate was superior.  Their ugly cookies at dessert were addictive!  It was my birthday and they knew beforehand, and when we walked in the door the greeter at the front desk gave me a really thoughtful, hand-written birthday card.  The whole dinner was really memorable, one of those dinners where you remember all the different tastes for months on end.
author: M I.

description: Heard many great things about Perbacco and I love the space.  The service was fantastic and the food was really good.  Was it exceptional?  Not really in my humble opinion.  It is Italian and great but presentation was a little off in some of the dishes we had and that I saw other people had.  A lot of B and T's were awwing but there isn't much in Concord for fine dining!  Sorry--don't take offense!
author: Misti L.

description: I have eaten lunch here 3x and think it's overrated.  Despite each time telling them we were tight on time (HINT: all wearing suits and looking stuffy) they service is too slow.  The bread is very good and the food is also solid although I cant say I love it.  I have had the pasta ragu which is a little too meaty for my tastes.  They usually have a good soup though. One thing that bugged me last time I was there was that the waiter brought us another sparkling water when we finished our bottle without asking us if we wanted another one--has never happened to me before!
author: Abigail J.

description: For dinner, we decided to head into SF to try Perbacco.  Only a few doors down from Aqua, (one of my favorites in the city), I couldn't imagine that Perbacco could be better than the great seafood restaurant.  After scanning the menu, we decided to try the tuna tartare and tomato gnocchi.  The gnocchi was delicious and is probably one of the best I have ever tasted because of its puffiness and yummy sauce.  The tuna was okay (but Aqua's rendition is better).  For our main courses, we tried the halibut, swordfish, and hanger steak.  The two fish dishes were fresh and yummy, but the steak was SO tough.  I received a piece to try and was suprised when 1- I could barely cut the thing and 2-when I tasted it, I could barely chew and wanted to spit the piece across the table.  After taking that awful bite, we decided to tell the waiter.  I have NEVER complained, but the steak was nearly uneatable.  After many nice apologies, we decided to order a butterscotch pudding and a butterscotch ice cream which were mouth-watering and oh-so-good.  Overall, Perbacco was a plesant dining expereince, but I was not that impressed to visit it again.
author: Shannon W.

description: Don't think that because it's a Wednesday night your going to find a table here.  This  place is rockin' on the weekdays as well.  The pleasant wait staff were very accommodating and incredibly friendly.  They found seats for us as soon as one was vacated.  Friendly staff and incredibly fast service considering how busy this restaurant was.  I started with a braised ribs Paperdelle.  Perfectly braised rib with Paperdelle pasta cooked al dente with a rich and delicious brown beef sauce was a great start to the night. For the main course I had the Halibut in a light broth which was also delicious.  However, I thought that the pasta was definitely the star of the night.  Desserts were good, but were more of a refinement on classics.  I had ate here a few months prior and the both service and quality of the food were consistent.  Great food, great service...what more can I ask for?  Actually, the wine list is quite extensive and absolutely amazing!
author: Hiro A.

description: Just ate at Prebacco tonite and the food was GREAT and the Service was amazing.  I would recommend Prebacco as a special Ristorante to visit in San Francisco.  I find that they go out of their way to make sure you well taken care of in all areas of dining.  Enjoy.
author: linda G.

description: After sampling several exceptional restaurants, Perbacco holds its own against them...So I'm upgrading my ranking.
author: Aggie A.

description: What can I add that over 700 reviewers haven't already stated?  Not much other than to say that dinner last night at Perbacco was lovely!  The food was awesome and service was across the board attentive and gracious right from the front of the house to our server!  We were a party of three and requested a table upstairs and that is exactly what we received.  We started with three appetizers:  the AVIOLO FILLED WITH TRUFFLED RICOTTA, the FRITTO MISTO OF ROCK SHRIMP, and ROASTED D"ANJOU PEAR SALAD.  The Aviolo was my absolute favorite.  The Fritto Misto was very light - perhaps a few too many fried olives for my liking.  For our main entree, we shared three pastas ($18 per person for the entire table).  We had the RABATÒN (TRUFFLE-HERB RICOTTA GNOCCHI / ROASTED MUSHROOM SUGO), the PACCHERI (LARGE PASTA TUBES with ALBACORE TUNA RAGU / TOMATO / CAPERS / CHILI PEPPER), and my usual favorite, the PAPPARDELLE with SHORT RIB RAGU.  My absolute favorite last night was the pasta with tuna.  I thought the portions were quite ample as well.  I probably would have preferred that we had the option to have the food served family style as opposed to pre-divided into three piles on a long rectangular plate. I think it would have been a bit warmer.  Also, as a person who now lives and works in the Peninsula, I loved the $10 valet parking as parking is impossible in the FIDI.  Even lukewarm, the pastas were delicious.  Sad to say we skipped dessert and coffee as we were stuffed!  I really can't wait to go back again and I definitely want/need to check out Barbacco next door.
author: mun p.

description:
for the price and what looked like interesting menu items, i was dissapointed.  service wasn't so good.  went there a couple nights ago and i'm not even sure what i ordered... so, not exactly memorable.

not BAD by any means, but other places are better and not as expensive.

oh, and the people downstairs by the bar were quite drunk for 8pm on a wednesday, with one guy practically goosing my sister as we walked out the door.  definitely not where i'd grab a drink and mingle.
author: J B.

description: I've eaten at Perbacco twice and thoroughly enjoyed my meals, the courteous wait staff, and overall experience.  I'm not a foodie, but the foodies dining with me all raved about the "true Italian" fare.  The appetizers were absolutely deliciously tasty, and my main course was too.   Next time, I'll try to save room for the deserts!
author: Alex W.

description: Better than average gussied up Italian food, great service, best spot for a business lunch if you have to stick to an hour. They know how to get you in and out of there without feeling rushed.
author: John B.

description: Wonderful experience.  Superb service, cool ambiance, absolutely delicious menu from top to bottom.  Owner Umberto selected our wine which was amazing.  Can't wait to return.
author: T C.

description: Three stars because the food is indeed good.  I'm not going to argue about that.  And the service is fine as well, what you would expect from a FiDi frou-frou eatery.  So, we're looking at good food and good service, which would indicate at least four stars, but...  It's just something about this place.  The vibe is just a little off.  The design isn't entirely cohesive, but it's not quirky or clever either.  The whole restaurant just seems very self-assured in an odd way.  Maybe it's just not my style.  Looking forward to trying their new project next door, Barbacco, though.
author: Alice T.

description: If you like TAJARIN, this is the place. They make just like in Piemonte.
author: Yu T.

description: if you love more traditional italian dishes, then this i a good bet for you and probably even a five star place. i'm not so much with the traditional stuff, but  the staff was very friendly, the pasta prices were reasonable, the portions weren't going to leave you stuffed, but they did give breadsticks and rolls and the drinks were poured stiff. so because of these things i wont fault them their fourth star because of my taste bud's preferences. between me and my buds we had the butternut squash ravioli (delicious!) , the gnochi (i prefer it made with potato to the ricotta version they have) and the tajarin (spot on if you like bolognais (sp?) which i'm not so into, but the noodles were good). we  also tried the spicy (not too much of that) salt cod croquettes, which i was all about! but wasn't so much a hit with anyone else - they are quite salty.
author: Toisha T.

description: We went here a couple of weeks ago and I thought it was going to be great, but it wasn't. The ambiance of the interior seemed great until they took us up to the mezzanine level where it seemed as if you were taller than 6'-0" you'd have to duck. Good thing I'm only 5'-5"! The average age seemed to be in the 40's and 50's, so not quite a 'young' crowd, but maybe that has to do with the location and prices. The service was a bit slow and my food was nothing to write home about. I had the gnocchi, which I have almost everywhere it's on the menu, so I think I know good gnocchi, and this wasn't it. It didn't seem fresh and the sauce was bland and uninspiring. The endive salad I had to start was good, with a crisp lemon vinaigrette, but it didn't make up for an otherwise disappointing dinner. Also, the portions aren't huge and for the price, it didn't seem worth it. My friends said the salumi plate was excellent but I'm not sure if good salumi is enough to justify the rave reviews.  We had excellent drinks at the restaurant next door, so maybe next time, we'll just go there for dinner instead.
author: Amina R.

description: It is a beautiful restaurant and the staff was friendly and capable. I was part of a party of four.  The shrimp starter course was outstanding and you must order it.  The strip steak was very good and the pork chop was outstanding.  However the two pasta dishes that we ordered were not good at all. I know this is counter to some previous posts.  It was Christmas eve so maybe the regular chef had taken the night off.  If I were to go back, I would start with the shrimp and then have the pork chop.  There are lots of better restaurants in SF.
author: H S.

description: The food (main course and desert) was absolutely despicable. The appetizer and service was acceptable and the ambiance is good.
author: Milind S.

description: Bad and lousy service some lame-o who was running our food kept talking about the food like he knew so much . I thought how much do I need to know about salami? Whatever, this place just seems like a carbon copy of evey other italian restaurant. It sucks big time.
author: robert d.

description: Great service, killer grilled squid, neat blend of happening bar and cozy dining area, Perbacco was really enjoyable. Good wine list (especially Pinot Noir section) and nice glassware. We'll be back!
author: Anon Y.

description: We went on a Thursday night.  It came highly recommended so I was wanting to love it.  I like the look of the place very much.  I found it too noisy for conversation, which is a bummer.  We were a few minutes early for our table and rather than squishing into the bar area chose to bundle ourselves back out to the street.  Once we made it back to our table we found little respite from the noise.  A decent martini helped.  Menu-wise I found too much emphasis on pork dishes.  I like pork, so don't all pile on, please!  There is also an overemphasis on smoke flavor - note I say smoke flavor.  It wrecked for me an otherwise promising risotto dish.  Mushrooms, yes, some bits of bacon, yes, but then some smoke flavor from a jar infusing every bit of rice?  no.  Food portions are a bit small for the price so it looked like we were smart to order a selection of starters for the table.  My beets salad was very tasty.  I thought the wine list was interesting, but there are not a lot of values there.  We had a sangiovese blend for our starters and then a nice  barbera d'asti for the mains.  Overall, we had a very nice time but I can't think that I'm going to be rushing back because it's just not that pleasant to be saying "pardon me?" across the table for 2 hours!  Old fart?  yeah, probably.
author: Laura H.

description:
If I had to sum it up in one word - disappointing. I had read this was one of the luminary italian meccas in SF and I couldn't have been more disappointed. Let me frame this - if I had walked in off the street and didnt know anything about Perbacco, I might have been surprised. But, ranking with the heavy hitters in SF ? No way.
First off, the space sucks. Its noisy, crowded adn gives one the feel of a conference center and the smell of rank carpet. They sat us on the second floor under an exit sign. Since my wife refused to glow green all night we were given another table 10 feet away. Not much of an improvement.
Secondly, the service was abyssmal. I lost count of the times my mind drifte to 'where the hell is our waiter' and I had to flag someone down more than thrice to get some attention. He would leave in mid sentence to handle something else, not to mention forgetting whole portions of our order. I'm not even going to go into his limited knowledge of the menu ( where he had to return to the kitchen three times to get questions answered ) - it was pretty pathetic for a ranked restaurant.
The food for the most part was mediocre - traditional plates done in an American style with little surprise or panache. The sea-bass was soggy, the paperdelle dry and the sugo sugary like a chinese to go. 
The one savior was the older gentleman who acted as Sommellier - he reco'd some very interesting wines, and they turned out to be the highlite of the evening.
Overall, would not go back. There are too many other restaurants that have to earn their clientelle. Sayonara Perbacco.
author: John J.

description: I invite clients to this restaurant to show them what the financial district in San Francisco has to offer.  The presentation and the different tastes make each visit an absolute delight.
author: Julia M.

description: Well now that I am on the computer I figured I would write a couple of reviews quickly.  Great Place, Great wine selection and Sommelier(s) are very helpful (and don't just recommend the 80.00 bottle).  Is it THE BEST, no, not sure what is, but very solid.  Worth the try.  Upstairs if you want quiet.
author: Paul M.

description: I had lunch there recently with some colleagues from work.  I had been to Barbacco earlier and had enjoyed the food there and had gotten the names confused and accidentally arrived at Perbacco.  Perbacco has quite the flair of fine dining in decor and in clientèle.  The first thing that struck me was the monastic expressions on the faces of the wait staff.   Our server only cracked a smile, which all of us rated as 'fake' when we were presented with the bill.  We had to ask for the bread, although the server walked around us several times to make sure that the plates of the folks next to us were filled.  We tried a variety of appetizers (beets, shrimp, squid, cheese & tomato) and main courses (meatballs, sea bass and  chicken).  All of them were good, but none really stood out as great.   Everyone was 'stuffed' by the end and we only tried the Hazelnut cookies which were very good.  I had never come across such a lite and airy cookie that had a chewy and pleasant texture.   If the hype and the prices were lower, I would have given this a better rating.
author: Pramod J.

description: umberto, you rock. its been 4 years I think? maybe 3...who cares I love this place. the wine list keeps getting better and the food is fantastic.
author: J B.

description: my bf and i were really looking forward to eating here, as we had heard great things and Michael Bauer had said it was one of the better italian restaurants in the city. well, not so much. my first course was seriously underseasoned, and i can't even remember what i had for my main...which is saying something because i usually remember every bite of food that i put in my mouth. service was fine. my favorite part of the meal was the cheese plate and bourbon i had for dessert.
author: E P.

description: This place is exceptional. The roasted octopus is just insane - I've never tasted anything more tender, not even in Italy. Salumi is outstanding - great selection of all different kinds. Pappardelle was rich and comforting. The only drawback is that the crowd is mostly comprised of FiDi bankers and brokers. Otherwise, service was attentive without being overbearing.
author: Lemon S.

description: came here last year cuz my friend from out of state was visiting and he wanted to try it.  it was a busy weekday and the place was filled for lunch.  everyone was dressed in suits or business casual cuz it's in the financial district.  i don't remember what i ordered exactly but i sat upstairs.  it was less noisy upstairs.  even tho i can't remember which plate i ordered exactly but the food was good.  not GREAT but it's good.  i would definitely go back if i m in the area.  it's the financial district, of course parking is a pain. gotta park in parking lots which is a lot per hour.
author: Kapo T.

description: I had a business lunch there and with the posh atmosphere, I was expecting a lot. Overall, it wasn't bad, but it's not going to make the top of my list either. I had the mixed salad with lemon vinaigrette and butternut squash ravioli. The portions are quite good for a lunch menu. My colleague is a regular and noted that the prices have crept up slightly since they opened.  - I have no idea if that's true as it was my first time there. The salad was terrific and the pecorino cheese was delicious. Butternut squash ravioli is typically buttery, but this was just drowning in oil. It also was also bland compared to other places. The service was friendly but slow. We waited quite a while for the check, and then waited again for the waiter to pick up our credit card. He never did and we eventually had to ask a bus boy to take it to the register. I may come back to this place and give it another try, but I'm not in a hurry. It's 3.5 stars rounded down for Yelp.
author: Veggie S.

description: Absolutely fantastic service, the wine selection was phenominal, and the food, TO DIE FOR!!!  Been here a couple times and both times it has been wonderful.  The onsite made salame is yummy and just an amazing experience.    I think this place just replaced Luna Park as my favorite SF restaurant.
author: matt j.

description: Perbacco is a fantastic addition to the dining options in the city.  The chef, Steffan, has a true commitment to quality ingredients, and a passion for cooking.  The northern California cuisine is always outstanding in taste and quality, as well as creative.  The charcuterie is the best in the city.  I could sit at one of the bar tables and enjoy prosecco with some crudo and charcuterie and call it a meal.  I usually finish with one of the outstanding pastas, though.  Sit at the bar, it's cozier than the large dining room.
author: Grace R.

description: I attended a group birthday dinner here on a Saturday night. The restaurant layout was nice. We ordered all ordered different dishes and shared the food. I was huge fan of the Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts, the Truffle-Herb Ricotta Gnocchi, the Artichoke salad, and the Strawberry salad. The salads and the Brussels Sprouts were fresh and tasty.
author: Meg P.

description: Great, reasonable restaurant (especially since this area lacks them) with yummy food and a lively atmosphere.  Slightly older crowd - Russ commented that he felt underdressed in jeans and a T-shirt, and my response was that we were probably a decade or two too young.  The atmosphere is pretty lively, perhaps it was the lack of sound absorption on the walls/ceilings - but it definitely feels like a fun place.  Service was pretty slow, but it was okay since we weren't in a rush.  Food was very good - shared the burrata cheese (excellent on toasted baguette w/ arugula), beet salad (perfect, but it's difficult to mess up beets), fritto misto (excellently fried mix of rock shrimp, fennel, olives, onions, green beans), and pappardelle w/ short rib beef ragu (short rib was tender, pasta delicious, but the sauce could have used more oomph/flavor).  Desserts were good, not great.  Gelati (homemade - bittersweet chocolate and caramel fleur del sel were excellent, the pistachio nougat was interesting and made more for a conversation piece than good ole' dessert).  Pistachio panna cotta was unremarkable - although it could be due to my bias against panna cotta.  I'm definitely coming back!  Fun place for a date - even first date!
author: Christina S.

description: I've been here twice now since my return to this great city. Both times were fucking amazing! Both times I had the salumi which is house made and some of the best I've ever had. The first time I had the Buratta which was so creamy and delicious smothered in Olive oil and some sort of gastrique which I couldn't place the flavor  but it was divine. The second time I had the pear salad with Gorgonzola and candied walnuts over some honey-esque dressing. Had I been alone I might have licked the plate clean. Oh who am I kidding of coarse I licked the plate clean. Since when did I get manners. i had a pork belly dish the first time that was so tender that you could cut it with a spoon. The second time I had to go for the papperdelle with a lamb ragu that was amazing. The service as always was spot on and they also have a great wine selection. I hear they are putting a bottle of REAL Absinthe on their shelves very soon. I can't wait to go back.
author: Bill H.

description: I really enjoyed my  dinner at Perbacco.  We arrived a little early and had a drink at the bar.  The bar is insanely loud.  Noise doesn't normally bother me much but the bar was really, really loud.  Once we were seated the dining room was much more comfortable and much easier to have a conversation.  The wine list has many nice selections and our waiter was able to help us select a great wine.  We tried the salami plate which had four interesting selections and we both enjoyed them all.  The waiter recommended the roasted octupus appetizer and it was unique and really my favorite thing we tried. We also had the anglotti with rabbit ragout, it was tasty but I wouldn't order it again and finally we had the pork chop which was cooked to perfection but the butternut squash it was served with had little flavor.  Overall it was good, our server was trying hard but disappeared for great lengths of time but the excellent busboy made up for his lack of attention.  One odd thing about the wine service, he showed us the wine bottle and then left to open it in the waiter station.  He came back with and explained that they always do that because Italian wines are often difficult to open.  It was a rather strange way to serve the wine but we survived.
author: Kim O.

description: In this lively, even noisy FiDi eatery, Chef Staffan Terje and his team turn out delicious Northern Italian dishes that make the din seem like a communal celebration of how good the food is.  Perbacco shines with cooking that spotlights the Piemonte region and elements from Liguria and Provence.  The slow roasted veal appetizer with lemon and albacore tuna sauce is so tender and tasty, they should seriously make giant sandwiches out of that stuff.  While I thought about having the Salumi Misti, house cured meats and salami - after all, it is #18 on 7x7's list of places to try before you die - I opted for the squid which was also impressively tender and nicely accented with lemon and red chili flakes.  The folks here make their own pasta daily, and you can taste the freshness in dishes such as the roasted rabbit agnolotti.  The Subrich, or Piemontese meatballs, were perfectly prepared, not too dense or mushy, with a rich and savory spiced red wine jus offset by slightly sweet apples and potato puree.  Don't forget dessert.  They have a lot of chocolatey and nutty decadence on the menu, but they also have interesting items like citrus and vanilla infused rice pudding with a caramel crust, a cross between rice pudding and creme brulee.  At noon, the suit set converges upon this place, so be sure to have reservations.
author: Dina B.

description:
I just have to say that a black cloud has lifted.  I am only able to spend a year in San Francisco, and I have been trying to experience as much as possible of this enchanted city before I go home.  One of the things I do is try to dine out at least two times a week.  In the last 2 weeks  I've been to kokkari  lamb shank so overcooked, it was pithy, sauce great but who cares if you cant eat the meat.  Waiter soooo condescending. Slow Club hamburger well done, grey- ordered rare. Delfina chicken raw in center.  All so bad I felt as though I am in a cosmic vortex.  Then I came to Perbacco. What a delight,
 everything was as expected.  It was prepared to perfection.  Another Plus was my waiter Juan Porchar, who really seemed to care about what we all ordered.  He even recommended great wines to go with dinner.  With his help and the chefs, there were oohs, and auws  all night.  I will be back before I leave.  Thanks to the Chef and to Juan.
author: Susan W.

description: We went on 4/18 for my husband's birthday.  They had a card for him which was a nice touch.  The food was excellent and so were the drinks!  I had a couple Mandarinos (a mandarin cosmo) which was delicious!  For dinner, we started with the sardines and the roasted beet salad.  My husband really enjoyed the sardines.  The salad was good, but not as flavorful as I was hoping for.  The pasta course, we had beef short rib ragu and goat cheese ravioli with peas.  Both were incredibly delicious.  I highly recommend the ravioli since the flavors were a little more interesting.  The crispness of the fresh peas really added a wonderful texture.  For dinner I had the beef with gorgonzola butter which was perfectly cooked and incredibly juicy.  My husband had the black pudding and sausage with lentils which he really enjoyed.  We chose a bottle of 2005 Carolina Cascina Val del Prete Barbera d' Alba with the help of the sommelier which was complex and delicious.  Ended with the chocolate cake and hazelnut meringues whcih were also yummy.  We will most certainly be back!
author: Mira C.

description: What a terrific take on modern Italian. We had appetizers and pasta only, but based on the quality, freshness, and creativity of the dishes we ate, it is worth every penny. The grilled local squid with a hint of chilies were perfect. The frito misto done just right - not heavy and perfectly battered and cooked. The pastas were exquisite. I had the herb-ricotta gnocchi with mushrooms and a hint of truffle - absolutely memorable. My husband had the short-rib tagliatelle and he was in heaven. I definitely will keep this place on my favorites list.
author: Louise L.

description:
I booked a table for a Sat night through "Open Table"-it was my husband's B-day and I noted that on our reservation.  We sat at the bar and had very tasty cocktails ($9).  The martini olives were delish-could have eaten a dish of those.  We got a great table as far as view goes- had to squeeze by a column but it was comfy.  We loved the mixed salami platter-got the small and had a fish and a shortrib entree-they were good but not great-my husband thought the shortrib dish tasted too much like stew.  I liked my fish but it was nothing special.  They also have very good breadsticks on the table-scarfed them right away.  The salami platter was awesome-we also loved the pickles that came with-one was actually pickled watermelon rinde-wow.  
Next time we go-for sure we would go back- we won't get  entrees-we'll get the large salami platter and an assortment of cheeses and other small things and I think we'll be more that happy.  The decor is nice, service was nice-they brought a comp dessert with "happy birthday" on the plate-very impressive service from "open table" .
author: Shannon J.

description: i adore perbacco. i've been here twice now, in two completely different situations (first with a large group of family, to celebrate a birthday, and the second as a work lunch), and the staff and food were spot-on both times. the first time, we had the pleasure of being seated at the chef's table, next to the kitchen. fun fun fun! everything i've eaten there was fantastic- i always splurge and have pasta (since i'm normally low carb) and it is out of this world.
author: oona m.

description: I'm a fan.  It was just the kind of night I was looking for.  Sometimes I want an evening where a place steers a meal for me and it was exactly what they delivered.  Service was friendly, professional and lead us throughout the meal.  The wine steward picked perfect wines to compliment the meal.  (Even choosing a Spumanti to start that I would have never ordered!)  Wine list is Italian heavy of course with a few domestic. Nice charcuterie to start, followed by a pasta tasting menu (many choices to be made), beautiful crisp duck entree and the only mis-step choice of the evening unfortunately was the rabbit that my guests both chose. Very dry and not that flavorful.  (They did ask us our opinion and I believe in being truthful since it was such an excellent evening.)  Although unnecessary, they bought us dessert.  I will make this a must visit on my returns to San Francisco.  Definitely a noteworthy restaurant to visit.
author: Mark D.

description: Nice restaurant, but nothing special...  Went in with a big group and was able to taste a number of items on the menu.  Presentation was nice, but the only delicious and memorable item for me was the battered, fried olives in the mixed fried appetizer plate.  ...doesn't say much for the food since almost anything that's fried and salty automatically tastes good.
author: Tina H.

description: I really enjoy this casual Italian restaurant.  Good value for money in the Financial district.  The food is consistenly good, and excellent wine list.  Great business lunch spot, but also nice for a relaxed evening.  Will definitely be coming back.
author: Dan L.

description: I love this place. I went there again and again and again. The service is top notch, the food are delicious. Can't complaint anything. They have many of wine selection. highly recommend.
author: Grace C.

description: I am blown away by my lunch experience at Perbacco. The service was phenomenal, from the welcoming staff, to the waiter, service staff, and what looked like managers walking around the floor to ensure the flawlessness of each patron's dining experience. I had the strawberry salad to start, which was absolutely delightful, and the sea bass as my main course, a well-sized portion cooked and seasoned to perfection. As we walked out, I glanced around at the plates on the other tables, and each plate seemed very well thought out, enjoyable to the eye, and most certainly to the palate. A great dining experience.
author: Shai M.

description: Outstanding food, outstanding wine list.  You do get the feeling that everyone in the room is expensing the dinner to the corporate entertainment account, so this definitely lacks the intimate romance of a mom-and-pop italian restaurant.  Our server, as a comic aside, was a living parody of the overly-eager-to-please-european waiter one might imagine in a disney movie.
author: Andrew G.

description: I had a great meal here.  Authentic Italian.  Steak with marrow/herb crust- mmmmm.  I really liked it and intend to go back soon.
author: eiming j.

description: I've been there twice. The first time was flawless. Great salumi platter, wonderful pasta dishes, tremendous panna cotta. The second time, not so much. The rolls were like rocks;  the heirloom tomato salad was served ice cold on a chilled plate (obviously prepared in advance and stored). The pasta and panna cotta were still great. Service was good but nothing spectacular. I'm going with three stars for now. Many of the dishes clearly deserve a higher rating but there seems to be a consistency problem.
author: wayne c.

description: I you are looking for italian in the financial district for a business lunch, perbacco is a solid choice.  The food won't distract you from your conversation; it is very good and well presented but not amazing. The service is excellent.  The price is fair for its caliber.  A very good place for a business lunch.
author: susan x.

description: I went into Perbacco for lunch secretly pitting it against my favorite place, Oliveto. It was a bit unfair of me because Perbacco is just too new to have reached the maturity of experience present at Oliveto. That said, I had an ok lunch but it failed to really wow me. The wine flight was nice and I wish more restaurants offered a similar experience but the wines were a bit pedestrian. (I am spoiled and admit to a bit of snobbery here.) The dessert was very good, a tart with a half pear baked into it topped with creme fraiche and truffled honey. It was fun to debate creme vs. mascarpone with my adorably cute and tiny server Alexis. I'm positive I'll stop back in there to give dinner a try once I am back in my SF office and it fits the situation. The crowded nature kind of puts me off and it does get very loud in the space but it is also a block away from work.
author: Don B.

description: i'm not sure they always have this on their menu but the seafood risotto is one of those dishes that screams 'wow, you need to go there and try this'. i daydream about sitting at the bar with a drink and a hearty plate of this thing. terrific.
author: Isaac P.

description: Nice place.No weird pretense like Aqua next door. The appetizers in particular were excellent. I would definitely return at some point. Not  pricey at all for an upscale restaurant.
author: Steve P.

description: Excellent!  Food was very good and the atmosphere was outstanding.  Ate at the bar (place was packed) and the bartender knew the menu cold and did a great job of making sure things moved at a pace that was right for us.  Wine list was very good and wines by the glass were tied nicely to the menu.
author: Brian R.

description:
I had heard a lot about this new Italian place in the financial district and the opportunity to try it out presented itself.  I was taking several co-workers out to dinner so I was a little nervous about trying a new place, but am I glad we went!  
The food was fantastic.  We had way to many dishes to list them all. There were six of us so we split a few different appetizers, which were all delicious.  Almost all of us had a different entree, but everyone loved what they ordered.  And dessert!  Again, we all split a few desserts and I highly HIGHLY recommend the chocolate tart.  It's amazing.  That was our favorite dessert.  
The staff was very nice.  We never waited too long for anything, nor did we feel rushed.  The tables weren't too close together.  I can't stand it when it feels like you are eating dinner with the strangers next to you.  I didn't ever feel like any one conversation was overpowering and I'm pretty sure our group was OK.  The mezzanine was a cool place to be seated.  We didn't have a drink at the bar, but it looked fun and the place was pretty crowded when we left (it was a Thursday  night).
The only negative, and it's not really that bad, is that the menu is a bit pretentious, even for San Francisco.  There are a lot of fancy food words and you sort of find yourself looking for things you recognize (e.g. does that mean it's a chicken dish??)  But once you get past that it was a great dining experience and I would definitely go back.  I even sent my boss and my CEO to dinner there the other night and they thought it was great!
Overall, Perbacco is a wonderful new addition to the dining options in San Francisco.
author: Molly T.

description:
went to dinner with another couple.  sat us in a great location in the middle on the street level, 

parking - plenty of street parking at 6:00 PM on a Saturday

atmosphere - great, modern, refreshing,  a little noisy

food - first,  tried the salumi  - really good stuff and the pork pate           great   

 second,  got beet salad  wow; fritto and squid ok; parpedelle excellent

third main course - sea bass wow crispy and moist,  lamb tasty but not really juicy,  duck  nothing special, and monk fish  pretty good

fourth dessert - bread pudding good but not great, 

service - excellent
author: daniel s.

description: Perbacco is Fabulous.  I made a reservation here for my 3 year anniversary.  The man and I had a wonderful experience.  Cecilia provided excellent service and helped me pick exactly the wine I was looking for.  The fritto misto, rabbit, sugo and hazelnut crepes were all delicious and we were able to take our time and enjoy them.  I will definitely be coming here again!
author: Vicki K.

description: Maybe I've always hit it on an off night, but I continue to find this place completely overrated.  Last night's visit really capped it: over-priced wines by the glass, very skimpy poors, and arrogant, rushed service. Food was adequate but certainly not worth the wait or cost.   There are so many better spots for both the money and the scene. (Head to Aqua or Tadich next door for a far superior experience. )
author: Cynthy M.

description: We dined at Perbacco 8:30PM thursday night. High ceilings, brick wall, and large space. Good downtown vibe. We had a couple of glasses of the Barbera which was tasty. Service was great. Next table over, lady forgot her reading glasses so the waiter came back with a case of reading glasses for her to choose from. The other next table over another waiter picks up dinner napkin from floor and spends the time to fold it ever so nicely in a upside down V so it would stand up on the table before the customer returned from the bathroom. Our appetizer, octopus salad, came out promptly. First time I had octopus that wasn't slightly rubbery. Surprisingly it was soooo soft. Yummy.  My favorite part was the pasta sampling. Incredible home made pastas: Tajina  with the 5 hour pork sugo, pappardelle with shredded short ribs, and gnocchi stuffed with Ricotta. I absolutely loved their pastas. My favorite from the sampling was the gnocchi and Mr. ShiverMeTimber's fave was the tajina. Gnocchi was light in texture. I'm not sure how to describe but it was scrumptious.  We had the halibut which I couldn't finish because I was stuffed. Mr. P said that it was very good as he helped himself to mine. Next time I hope there's room for dessert or a cheese plate. Great dinner!
author: Seymour S.

description: I love love love this place.  I'm always coming back for more.  Basically modern California Italian cuisine.  Sounds a little trendy and maybe it looks that way too but a lot of the recipes are very classic basic good Italian.  The house made salumi misti platter is constantly changing as they cure different meats during different seasons but it's always a nice pile of salty savory happiness sliced thin.  The salads also revolve with the seasons but the ingredients are almost always what's available at the local farmer's market so that can mean shaved spring radishes or summer strawberries in a balsamic reduction or watermelon in a vinaigrette or little gem lettuce with lemon and shaved cheese.  It's always light, it's always fresh and I always rave about it.  But the pastas here are the showcase display- I think they are all handmade fresh daily but don't quote me on that... gnocci like potato clouds... handcut tagliatelle in a 5 hour pork sauce are tiny ribbons of heaven.  It's really a texture thing.  A master pasta chef knows how to keep the dough very tender and this place has learned the trick so for right now it's my reigning favorite for Italian.  The grilled meats are great. The fresh seafood is excellent but really... I almost always go back to the salad and pasta... if you have a winning combo, you don't' really ever have to mess with it...there's no need to.    I only had one bad dessert here and they have since taken it off the menu and hopefully burned the recipe but the vanilla panna cotta is so smooth and luscious, you could have dreamed it.  The bar is top shelf and the house specialty cocktails are completely worth trying.  Even happy hour is a blast here with bar menu specialties like the spiced marcona almonds and truffled egg toast.  Did I mention I love this place?
author: Angela W.

description: Holiday luncheon for work here that didn't live up to expectations. Mostly because of the staff assigned to our back room. Having perennial looks of boredom on your faces, spilling more wine on the tablecloth than the glasses, and dropping silverware in front of guests isn't all that great for service. The people at my table began making jokes about the size of the stains from red wine on the cloth and I had a few drops on my shirtsleeve. If you've been here it's the woman who looks like she swallowed Billy Idol. Just not pleasant at all. The butternut squash pasta was pretty good but it's been awhile since I was hungry two hours after eating Italian, which is what happened. The serving was more suitable for a child. And an Italian place that serves literally one piece of bread per person?? The group was about 25 people and the feedback on the way back to work was that it was a letdown altogether. Some of my colleagues had been before and thought maybe it was because it was a large private group and that may have been why it was as bad as it was. Whatever the reason I have no desire to go back when there are so many other options in SF.
author: Stanley T.

description: With 473 reviews, nobody needs my 2 cents about Perbacco.   But since I walked 4 hours to get there for dinner tonight, I might as well chime in.  True, I did not take the most direct route.  Starting at the Ferry Bldg, I walked up the Embarcadero, through Fisherman's Wharf and Fort Mason, up Chestnut St. to the Presidio, climbed the spectacular Lyon Street Steps, and headed out Sacramento St. to Presidio.  Then back along California to Divisidero and down Divis to Castro, where I thought I'd check out Gay Pride weekend.  Things were in preparation, but nothing had really started yet.  It seemed like there was better planning than in the past:  plenty of porta-potties everywhere around Dolores Park, scene of the Dyke Festival. ( I remember eating at Delfina a few years ago during that celebration when the restaurant was beseiged by revellers from the street wanting to use the restroom.  One particularly agressive young woman, when denied access stomped out yelling "Delfina hates lesbians!")   So I continued down 18th St, left on Valencia to Market, down Market and finally wound up at Perbacco on California St.   Of course, I could have just walked the 2 or 3 blocks from the Ferry Bl. but that would have been too boring.   I ordered two small pasta plates, the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vitelloni and savoy cabbage, followed by the tajarine:  handcut very thin tagliatelli in a brilliant saffron color with pork sugo.  Both dishes were a bit similar (the vitelloni and sugo were not that far apart) but each was quite good, with deep, complex flavors, more on the refined than the rustic side.  My glass of Barbera d'Alba was superb and complemented both dishes.   So that was it--a bit anticlimactic after the four hour trek, perhaps.  In terms of pure enjoyment, I got more out of the custard- filled bombolloni I bought from Boriana's at the Ferry Building, or the In 'N' Out burger  I indulged in at Fisherman's Wharf.  Most interesting to me was how each Italian restaurant attracts such a different clientelle.  Perbacco was filled with downtown types--jaded older patrons spinkled with a few young professionals, all very buttoned up.   A16, by contrast, attacts the young Marina yuppie crowd, whereas Delfina, which requires a trek to the Mission, is filled with a diverse, vibrant mix of everything,
author: David T.

description: perbacco is perfect for upscale tapas.  with the modern, woodsy design, its no wonder corporate 9-5ers flock to this place.  i really loved the non-alcoholic drink called limonata salata, which is basically a salty lemonade.  sheer genius!  the salt cod and potato gratin is genius too!  a bit salty so be sure to eat in small doses. the olive plate was good, but nothing special.  the salumi misit (all of the above) is highly recommended if youre into cured meats.  overall, this was a good experience.  the waitstaff was very attentive no matter how crazy it got during happy hour. also, if you would rather have an entree rather than go the tapas route, i would recommend the parpadelle ragu in wine sauce.  everything about it will make you speechless!  the risotto w/ duck confit was good, but not great.  the duck confit was spectacular because it really melted in my mouth, and unfortunately i cant say the same for the risotto.  it was runny and not thick/creamy as it shouldve been. the large mushrooms in the risotto seemed large and intimidating for such a delicate, yet rich dish...
author: Anthro Food E.
